site_title: Apple supply chain data shows receding exposure to China as risks mount
summary: Apple's supply chain data shows a decline in its reliance on China, with 41% of suppliers' production sites in 2020 and 36% in 2021. The shift is driven by investments in India and Vietnam, as well as increased procurement from Taiwan, the US, and other countries. Analysts expect the trend to continue, with some predicting that 25% of Apple products will be manufactured outside China by 2025. However, experts also note that China's prominence in the global manufacturing landscape is unlikely to evaporate overnight, and the risks associated with concentration in China remain a concern.

images.alt_text: Much will depend on how quickly Foxconn Technology Group can get people back to assembly lines after violent protests against Covid restrictions.

site_title: Australia monthly inflation slows in October, hints at possible peak
summary: Australia's inflation slowed in October to 6.9% year-over-year, down from 7.3% in September, due to a 6.3% drop in fruit and vegetable prices and a 6.4% decline in holiday costs. This unexpected turn may indicate that inflation is peaking, potentially easing pressure on the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise interest rates further. The trimmed mean core inflation rate rose 0.3% in October, slowing annual growth to 5.3%, a surprise to analysts.

images.alt_text: Broccoli and other vegetables sit on display for sale at an Aldi Stores Ltd. food store in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, June 25, 2015. Australia's biggest supermarkets are losing favor with debt investors as a challenge from German discounter Aldi intensifies competition. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: India’s growth seen to slow on higher prices, borrowing costs
summary: India's economy likely expanded at a slower pace in the third quarter, with GDP estimated to have risen 6.2% from a year ago, down from a 13.51% growth in the previous quarter. Inflation stayed above the 2-6% target since 2022, and rising interest rates and sluggish trade tempered demand. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to stay hawkish at its monetary policy review, citing signs that higher interest rates are feeding through to the real economy.

images.alt_text: The pilot would cover select locations in a closed user group comprising participating customers and merchants, the India central bank said.

site_title: HSBC shares rise on dividend optimism after Canada divestment
summary: HSBC shares rose 3% after the lender agreed to sell its Canadian unit for $13.5 billion, with the potential for a one-time dividend or fresh stock buyback. This comes amid pressure from Ping An Insurance Group of China, its largest shareholder, which has complained about the company's strategy and poor returns. The sale is seen as a positive move by minority shareholders, who have pushed for a spinoff of HSBC's Asian operations. Distributions related to the deal are expected to be made from early 2024.

images.alt_text: The sale comes as HSBC pursues a strategy of focusing its resources on its core markets, amid pressure from its biggest shareholder Ping An to improve its performance.

site_title: Australian banking system cushioned for imminent climate change-related risks: regulator
summary: Australia's top five banks, including Commonwealth Bank and Westpac, have been found to be well-prepared to handle climate change-related economic risks, according to a study by the country's banking regulator, APRA. The study, conducted over two years, found that potential economic downturns caused by climate change could pose risks to the loan books of the banks without resulting in severe stress to the system and the economy. Mortgage lending losses are expected to be higher in northern Australia, and banks have already adjusted their risk appetite and lending practices to mitigate these risks.

site_title: China’s BYD to sell EVs in Mexico in 2023, aims for up to 30,000 sales in 2024
summary: BYD, China's largest electric-vehicle maker, plans to sell its cars in Mexico starting in 2023, with a target of 10,000 vehicles in 2023 and 20,000-30,000 in 2024. The company aims to reach 10% of Mexico's total market share and sell cars through 15 licensed dealers by 2023 and 30 by 2024. BYD's country head, Zhou Zou, emphasized the company's affordability, saying "we are the brand for everybody." The move comes as Mexico aims to make EVs more affordable by cutting sales taxes and import tariffs.

images.alt_text: COE supply is not expected to be a key determinant of electric vehicle adoption, as COEs are not differentiated by propellant type, says Transport Minister S Iswaran.
BYD cited the phase out of Chinese subsidies for pure electric and hybrid vehicles at the end of the year.

site_title: 28% of new light goods vehicle registrations in 2022 are electric: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's Minister for Transport S Iswaran stated that 28% of new light goods vehicle registrations in 2022 were electric, a significant increase from 0.4% in 2020. This is the highest adoption rate among all vehicle categories. The government has implemented incentives such as the Commercial Vehicle Emissions Scheme and Early Turnover Scheme to encourage electric LGV purchases, and plans to continue monitoring and reviewing their efficacy.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Fitch Solutions is forecasting Singapore’s total EV fleet to reach just under 255,000 units by end-2031.
COE supply is not expected to be a key determinant of electric vehicle adoption, as COEs are not differentiated by propellant type, says Transport Minister S Iswaran.
Fishermen on the water as smoke rises from chimneys at the Suralaya coal power plant in Cilegon. A US$20b deal was announced on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nov 2022 to wean Indonesia off coal.

site_title: Revolut seeks rapid growth in Asia as regulators increase scrutiny
summary: Revolut, a UK-based fintech startup, aims to sustain rapid growth in Asia despite increased regulatory scrutiny. The company is targeting Japanese exporters to cut international money transfer fees, with a goal of reaching 1 million users in Japan by end-2023. Revolut wants to expand to 10 million customers in Asia by 2025, with 600,000 users already in the region. Following a run-in with Japan's financial watchdog, Revolut is in talks for regulatory approvals necessary to service small-to-medium-sized businesses in Japan.

images.alt_text: Ng previously held positions at Microsoft, Visa, Mastercard, other technology startups, and has more than 20 years of experience in the mobile, payment and travel tech sectors.
The startup has already hired 43 crypto staff this year, tripling the team's total headcount since July 2021.

site_title: New Zealand business confidence weakens in November: ANZ survey
summary: New Zealand business confidence fell 14 points in November, the lowest level since 2009, due to intense inflationary pressures. A net 57.1% of respondents expected the economy to deteriorate, while 13.7% expected their businesses to shrink in the next 12 months. Employment intentions were negative for the first time since October 2020, marking a significant decline in business optimism.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk past a sailing boat as it passes in front of the central business district (CBD) of Wellington in New Zealand, July 2, 2017. REUTERS/David Gray

site_title: Thousands sign up for Make-A-Wish Singapore’s Santa Race 2022 to raise funds
summary: Over 3,000 people have registered for Make-A-Wish Singapore's Santa Race 2022, a community event aimed at raising funds for wish children with critical illnesses. The event, which kicked off on November 26, will run until December 26 and features a leaderboard with prizes, an adventure game, and virtual participation options. Make-A-Wish Singapore aims to raise S$500,000 to continue granting wishes, with funds going towards activities improving the social and emotional well-being of wish children. The charity celebrated its 20th anniversary during the event.

images.alt_text: The workshops, held in person for the first time since the start of the coronavirus pandemic, use art and technology to highlight mental wellness and sustainability issues.
Daniel Han, director, Design Factory Asia, BNP Paribas Wealth Management, says: “The intent of DCA is to bring design thinking know-how to non-profits to solve some of their pertinent problems.”

site_title: Casino operator Genting to list Miami property with over US$1b asking price
summary: Genting, a major casino operator, plans to sell a 6.5-hectare Miami property with an asking price of over US$1 billion. The property, once home to the Miami Herald, is a prime waterfront location near art and concert venues. Genting aims to focus on investment opportunities in New York, where it plans to expand its casino offerings. The company has acquired several properties, including the Hilton Miami Downtown hotel and Omni Center space, which will remain. Genting's expansion plans in New York include a US$100 million slot machine parlour and a potential casino licence.

images.alt_text: Genting Malaysia had been considered a credible threat for a Macau licence due to its strong non-gaming track record and mass market appeal.

site_title: Alibaba founder Jack Ma living in Tokyo for half a year: FT
summary: Chinese entrepreneur Jack Ma has been living in Tokyo for nearly six months, following Beijing's crackdown on the technology sector. Ma, co-founder of Alibaba Group, has kept a low profile since his criticism of government regulation and has been spotted at private members' clubs, bringing his personal chef and security staff. He has also become an enthusiastic modern art collector. Ma's stay in Tokyo comes after his rare public appearances since his trouble with Beijing, which has derailed his initial public offering of Ant Group.

site_title: Singapore shares rise slightly on Wednesday; STI up 0.04%
summary: Singapore shares rose slightly on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index gaining 0.04% to 3,277.65. Gainers outnumbered losers 49 to 48, despite bearish sentiments on Wall Street and Europe. Local banks UOB, DBS, and OCBC were in positive territory, while Thai Beverage and Genting Singapore saw brisk trading. The gains were attributed to a flat trading session in Singapore, contrasting with a bearish market in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
SIA will invest 20.6 billion rupees in Air India, giving SIA a 25.1 per cent stake in an enlarged Air India group post merger with VIstara.

site_title: Let the WTO referee carbon border taxes
summary: A revived World Trade Organisation (WTO) could help enforce national limits on greenhouse-gas emissions through carbon border taxes, generating a wave of trade in green goods and services. The European Union's upcoming Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) aims to level the playing field by imposing tariffs on imports with lower CO2 prices. The WTO has the authority to permit environmental exceptions, and a revived body could provide a framework for beneficial carbon border taxes. This could benefit developing countries and the planet by fostering a global market for green goods and services.

images.alt_text: Solar panels on the rooftop of an HDB block in Ang Mo Kio. Singapore is looking to quadruple its solar energy deployment by 2025 by covering the rooftops of its public housing blocks with solar panels.

site_title: Yahoo eyes retail stock trading in growth push: Axios
summary: Yahoo, the owner of Yahoo Finance, Yahoo Sports, and TechCrunch, plans to expand into retail stock trading and new commerce businesses, such as sports betting, to boost revenue. The move is aimed at capitalizing on the growing trend of online trading and commerce. Yahoo generates around $8 billion in revenue annually, according to a report by Axios. The plan comes after a US$5 billion buyout by private equity firm Apollo Global Management last year. The company's expansion plans are part of its effort to increase revenue and stay competitive in the rapidly changing digital landscape.

images.alt_text: A Yahoo logo is pictured in front of a building in Rolle, Switzerland December 12, 2012. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Indonesia plans to subsidise EV sales next year
summary: Indonesia plans to subsidize the sales of electric cars and motorbikes starting next year to make them more affordable. The government aims to encourage adoption, with targets of 1.2 million electric bikes and 35,000 electric cars by 2024. A subsidy scheme of 6.5 million rupiah (S$568) per purchase is being finalized for electric motorbikes, with a similar scheme for cars also being considered. The move is part of the country's efforts to develop its own EV and battery industries, and follows existing tax cuts for EV sales since 2019.

images.alt_text: COE supply is not expected to be a key determinant of electric vehicle adoption, as COEs are not differentiated by propellant type, says Transport Minister S Iswaran.

A computer-generated image showing Indonesia's future presidential palace in East Kalimantan, as part of the country's relocation of its capital from Jakarta to  Borneo island that will be named "Nusantara".

site_title: Two Chinese cities ease Covid curbs after protests spread
summary: Chinese cities Guangzhou and Chongqing eased Covid curbs, allowing close contacts of Covid-19 patients to quarantine at home, amid protests against the world's toughest coronavirus restrictions. Demonstrations in southern Guangzhou and other cities have become a show of public defiance since President Xi Jinping came to power in 2012. Authorities have cracked down on protesters, with some residents reporting police questioning and taking videos of protests into custody. The easing of curbs comes amid record numbers of cases nationwide, with some experts believing former President Jiang Zemin's death could become a new rallying point for protests.

images.alt_text: Security forces clash with workers during a protest outside Apple supplier Foxconn's factory in Zhengzhou, China November 23, 2022 in this still image obtained by REUTERS from a video. NO RESALES. NO ARCHIVES

site_title: South Korea subway workers go on strike for first time since 2016
summary: South Korea's subway workers went on strike for the first time since 2016, demanding the government withdraw plans to shrink their workforce and hire more staff to improve safety. The strike coincides with a nationwide trucker walkout, causing supply-chain turmoil and pressure on President Yoon Suk-yeol to keep the economy stable. The Seoul Metro will operate normally during rush hours, but services will be reduced during the day. A nationwide walkout by Korea Railroad Corp workers is planned for December 2, also demanding an expanded workforce and better pay.

site_title: Italy plans to tax crypto trading gains, expand disclosure
summary: Italy plans to tax crypto trading gains, expanding a 26% levy on capital gains to digital assets for profits over €2,000. The proposed 2023 budget also includes disclosure obligations and extends stamp duty to cryptocurrencies. This move comes after Portugal's plan to tax short-term gains on digital assets at 28% in October. The aim is to encourage Italians to declare their holdings in tax returns, following a prolonged rout in digital asset prices and the downfall of several large cryptocurrency platforms.

site_title: HSBC to close 114 branches in Britain from April 2023
summary: HSBC plans to close 114 branches in Britain from April 2023, citing changing customer behavior and increasing online banking. The move is part of the lender's efforts to cut costs. Despite the closures, HSBC will invest tens of millions of pounds in updating its remaining 327 branches to improve customer experience. This decision follows similar announcements by other retail banks in the UK to adapt to changing customer habits.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past a HSBC bank branch in the City of London, Britain November 12, 2014.   REUTERS/Stefan Wermuth/File Photo

site_title: EU strikes deal to make ships pay for their carbon emissions
summary: The European Union has agreed to add shipping to its carbon market, requiring vessels to pay for their carbon emissions starting in 2024. The deal forces shipping companies to buy EU carbon permits to cover 40% of their emissions, increasing to 70% in 2025 and 100% in 2026. The move aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from maritime voyages, with 20 million permits' revenues dedicated to fund emissions-cutting projects.

images.alt_text: The slowdown is expected to impact shipping, which transports more than 80 per cent of global trade, although tanker freight rates could stay high.

site_title: New platform to trade Nifty contracts to be fully operational in Q2 2023
summary: SGX announces that its new platform, NSE IFSC-SGX Connect, will be fully operational by Q2 2023, allowing Singapore Exchange members to trade Nifty contracts with clearing and settlement through SGX Derivatives Clearing. The platform has already onboarded 14 clearing members, with more to come, and an enhanced infrastructure is expected to be delivered by technology partner TCS in early 2023. Dollar-denominated Nifty contracts will be exclusively traded on NSE IFSC.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Singapore shares snapped a 2-day winning streak on Thursday, spooked by the US Fed's hawkish tilt

site_title: Does this inflation hurt governments more than consumers?
summary: Inflation's impact on the global economy is being reevaluated as demand for household goods and travel remains robust despite recession fears. Governments are struggling to control inflation and prepare for potential unemployment surges, while citizens appear relatively unaffected. High liquidity, pandemic-era handouts, and pent-up demand contribute to the spending spree. Governments face significant challenges, including managing debt, financing subsidies, and cushioning potential housing crashes, as they navigate the uncertain economic landscape.

images.alt_text: Shoppers walk along 5th Avenue on Black Friday in New York. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: Chinese city hosting key iPhone plant lifts Covid lockdown
summary: Chinese city Zhengzhou lifts Covid lockdown after adjusting restrictions multiple times in response to rising cases. Authorities have declared hundreds of buildings as high-risk, subjecting them to targeted measures instead of full lockdowns. The move aims to balance virus control with less disruption to daily life and the economy, following Beijing's 20-point playbook issued last week. The city's experience highlights the challenge in meeting China's twin priorities of controlling outbreaks while minimizing economic and social impact.

images.alt_text: The Foxconn situation serves up another reminder of the dangers for Apple of relying on a vast production machine centred on China at a time of unpredictable policy and uncertain trade relations.

site_title: EY Entrepreneur of the Year Singapore winners find opportunities in tough conditions
summary: EY Entrepreneur of the Year Singapore winners highlight opportunities in various sectors amidst tough conditions. The winners, including Lim Wai Mun of Doctor Anywhere, Akshay Garg of FinAccel, and Jonathan Lim of Oddle, discussed their core businesses, challenges, and growth plans. They emphasized the importance of innovation, digitization, and accessibility in their respective industries, such as healthcare, financial technology, and food and beverage. The winners also expressed their commitment to addressing macroeconomic headwinds and uncertainty, with plans to deploy artificial intelligence, expand into new markets, and diversify their business solutions.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

Top (from left): Lim Wai Mun, founder and CEO of Doctor Anywhere; Akshay Garg, co-founder and group CEO of FinAccel; Mr. Julian Ng CEO and executive director of Grand Venture. Bottom (from left):  Kane Black, CEO of INEX Innovate; Jonathan Lim, CEO of Oddle; and Melissa Tan, CEO of Wah & Hua.

site_title: Aramco discovers two new Saudi gas fields
summary: Saudi Aramco has discovered two new natural gas fields, Awtad and AlDahna, in the country's eastern region. The fields were discovered in the Awtad field, southwest of the Ghawar field, and the AlDahna field, 230 kilometers southwest of Dhahran. Gas flowed from several wells, including Awtad-108001 and AlDahna-4, at rates of 10 million and 8.1 million cubic feet daily, respectively. The discovery is expected to increase Saudi Arabia's natural gas production.

site_title: Disney Channel, ESPN each lost 2 million subscribers in fiscal year
summary: Disney Channel and ESPN each lost 2 million subscribers in the fiscal year, finishing with 74 million subscribers. The company is grappling with changes in how consumers watch movies and TV shows, with returning CEO Bob Iger considering changes in management and strategy. Disney warned investors that these changes could result in impairment charges. The company also reported a $4 billion loss in its online TV businesses last year, with cord-cutting affecting regular TV results and impacting other channels like FX and Freeform.

images.alt_text: AMC Networks had 1,739 full-time and 287 part-time employees as of Dec 31.

site_title: Renault, Airbus to develop battery tech for cars and airplanes
summary: Renault and Airbus have partnered to develop advanced battery technology for electric vehicles and hybrid-electric aircraft. The collaboration aims to overcome energy storage limitations, a major hurdle for longer-range electric vehicles. Engineering teams from both companies will research and develop solutions for energy storage, with the partnership also helping Airbus advance its hybrid-electric aircraft technology. The move reflects the companies' efforts to navigate the electrification shift by teaming up with peers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, IHH Healthcare, BRC Asia, Jumbo
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and Tata Sons have agreed to merge with Air India and Vistara, with SIA investing 20.6 billion rupees (S$360 million) in Air India for a 25.1% stake. IHH Healthcare reported a 54% drop in net profit to RM251.8 million (S$76.9 million) for the third quarter. BRC Asia posted an 81% rise in net profit to S$50.4 million for its second half. Jumbo Group narrowed its net loss to S$91,000 for the full year.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: US: Wall Street opens flat ahead of Powell speech
summary: US stocks opened flat on November 30 ahead of Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments on interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 57.10 points, or 0.17%, to 33,795.43, while the S&P 500 opened lower by 0.45 points, or 0.01%, to 3,957.18. The Nasdaq Composite gained 11.42 points, or 0.10%, to 10,995.20. Investors closely watched for signs of a slowdown in interest rate hikes, which will be Powell's focus in his upcoming speech.

site_title: US retailers cheer strong holiday sales so far but fear rail strike
summary: US retailers reported a strong start to the holiday shopping season, with 196.7 million Americans shopping in stores over the Thanksgiving weekend, spending an average of $325.44 on holiday purchases. This represents a 17% increase from 2021 and is projected to grow 6-8% over last year's total of $960.4 billion. However, retailers fear a potential freight rail strike could still cripple the season, with a rail strike expected to have "devastating" effects on the US economy.

images.alt_text: Cyber Monday appear to be back in vogue this year, with major retailers including Target, Macy’s and Best Buy expecting a return to pre-pandemic shopping patterns.
US consumers’ 12-month inflation expectations increased to 7.2 per cent from 6.9 per cent last month.

site_title: AMC Networks CEO exits after brief stint; plans 20% US job cuts
summary: AMC Networks CEO Christina Spade stepped down after less than three months, citing a "termination without 'cause' or resignation for 'good reason' basis". The company plans to cut about 20% of its US workforce amid industry pressures and a challenging economy. Shares fell 4.4% on the news. Revenue in the streaming unit surged 41% in the last quarter, but overall revenue slumped 16%. The company's board is searching for a successor.

images.alt_text: Bob Iger, who served as Disney’s CEO for 15 years, has pledged to return as CEO for at least two years.

site_title: S-E Asia : Growth opportunities abound
summary: South-east Asia, despite global economic uncertainties, is a rare source of optimism, with strong fundamentals, accelerating growth, and a bright future. The region's GDP growth is expected to reach 5.1% this year, driven by its embedded trade deals, entrepreneurial spirit, and demographic advantages. Foreign companies plan to expand their presence in the region, with 90% expecting organic growth of 20% or more. However, climate change poses a long-term challenge, with the Asian Development Bank estimating a 11% reduction in GDP by the end of the century if left unchecked.

images.alt_text: epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES
A group of tuk tuks pass by the Democracy Monument in Bangkok on Nov 15, 2022. Thailand is hosting the APEC Summit this week.

site_title: Gold flat as traders brace for Powell’s speech
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Wednesday, with US gold futures falling 0.1% to $1,746.80, as investors awaited Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's speech for insights into monetary policy. Spot gold was flat at $1,750.00 per ounce. The speech will be evaluated for signs of hawkishness, which could impact gold prices. US consumer confidence fell to a four-month low, heightening recession risks, while the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic and China's real estate sector problems pose ongoing economic risks.

images.alt_text: Gold is sensitive to rising interest rates as they increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Twitter not safer under Elon Musk, says former head of trust and safety
summary: Twitter's former head of trust and safety, Yoel Roth, says the company is not safer under new owner Elon Musk, contrary to previous statements. Roth, who left the company after Musk laid off half of the staff, including content moderators, stated that Twitter no longer has enough staff for safety work. He cited the unilateral decision-making by Musk and the revamp of Twitter Blue as reasons for his resignation. Roth defended the permanent suspension of former US President Donald Trump, but expressed concerns over the direction of the company under Musk's leadership.

images.alt_text: A blanket decision on suspended accounts could potentially alarm government authorities that are keeping a close look at Musk’s handling of hateful speech since he bought the influential platform for US$44 billion.

A blue verification check on the page of Twitter Inc. on a laptop computer arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Monday, Nov. 7, 2022. Elon Musk’s agreement to buy Twitter Inc. is sending some users searching for alternative platforms — with mixed success. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg
Twitter’s relationship with Apple is particularly significant because the tech giant’s app store is one of the main ways that people get on the social network.

site_title: Fullerton Health weighs stake sale at S$1.5b value
summary: Fullerton Health is considering selling a minority stake worth up to S$1.5 billion to raise funds for expansion. The Singapore-based company, backed by private equity firms RRJ Capital and Ping An Capital, is in talks with potential investors for a 20% stake. The deal could value Fullerton Health at more than S$1.5 billion, with the company's revenue reaching S$800 million in 2021. Deliberations are ongoing, with no guarantee of a transaction. The sale would allow Fullerton Health to reduce debt and increase working capital.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong-based PE fund RRJ Capital's buyout of Fullerton Health will see the departure of its 3 co-founders, including David Sin of SIN Capital, from the firm

site_title: Exxon, Japan’s Mitsubishi heavy tie-up in carbon capture technology
summary: ExxonMobil and Japan's Mitsubishi Heavy Industries (MHI) are partnering to develop and deploy carbon capture technology. The joint venture will utilize MHI's CO2 capture technology for ExxonMobil's end-to-end carbon capture and storage (CCS) solution, aiming to reduce costs for heavy-emitting industrial customers. The partnership, supported by Japan's Kansai Electric Power Co, seeks to combat climate change by making CCS technology more accessible and affordable.

site_title: Amazon’s cloud unit plans to add staff in 2023, keep building data centres
summary: Amazon's cloud unit, AWS, plans to add staff in 2023 and continue building new data centers, despite a hiring freeze elsewhere in the company. AWS sales grew 27% in the September quarter, but at the slowest year-over-year rate since 2014. AWS executives had previously discussed implementing their own hiring curbs, but decided to pause instead. AWS is still growing rapidly and plans to moderate its data center growth when demand moderates.

images.alt_text: Amazon is issuing senior unsecured bonds in as many as five parts. The longest portion of the offering, a 10-year security, may yield 1.15 percentage points over Treasuries.
The newest chip is the latest piece of Amazon’s effort to build more of the hardware that fills the massive data centres that power AWS.

site_title: Violet Oon-Manoj Murjani court tussle – a case of too many cooks?
summary: Violet Oon and her two children have filed a lawsuit against Manoj Murjani and his company, Group MMM, over a disputed business partnership. The lawsuit claims that Murjani unilaterally increased their salaries and rebranded the company to promote his own brand, despite their significant contributions to the business. Oon and her family also claim they took on substantial personal financial risk, including giving personal guarantees for loans and insurance bonds. The dispute dates back to 2014 when Murjani partnered with Oon to start a chain of Peranakan-inspired restaurants.

images.alt_text: Venga (எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்)
Chef Violet Oon along with her children are seeking to buyout the 50 per cent shareholding of Group MMM in Violet Oon Singapore through legal proceedings.

site_title: World Cup: Pulisic sinks Iran as US advances to last 16
summary: US forward Christian Pulisic scored the only goal in a 1-0 victory over Iran, advancing the US to the last 16 of the World Cup. The win came after a tense match, with Iran's fans creating a hostile atmosphere, but the US controlled proceedings and dominated possession. Pulisic, who suffered a heavy knock in the process, was praised by coach Gregg Berhalter for his performance, and the US will face the Netherlands in the next round.

images.alt_text: Gihana Fava and Renan Almeida, soccer fans from Brazil, head for their rented room after checking in at Fan Village at the World Cup in Doha, Qatar, on Nov. 22, 2022. Fan Village is a sea of shipping containers converted to sleeping quarters, stretching almost as far as the eye can see. (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)
Marcus Rashford scores England's first goal from a free kick past Wales' Danny Ward at the Ahmad Bin Ali Stadium, Al Rayyan, Qatar, Nov 29, 2022.

site_title: Balenciaga sues company for controversial ad
summary: Balenciaga filed a $25 million lawsuit against production company North Six and set designer Nicholas Des Jardins for using documents related to a child pornography case in an ad campaign, which sparked widespread criticism and outrage. The fashion house withdrew the images after social media backlash. Balenciaga claims the use of the documents has "falsely and horrifically associated" the brand with the disturbing subject, damaging its reputation.

images.alt_text: In cutting ties with Ye, formerly Kanye West, Adidas will take a €250 million ($246.5 million) hit to net income in the current fiscal year.

site_title: Doctor Anywhere founder is EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2022 Singapore
summary: Lim Wai Mun, founder and CEO of Doctor Anywhere, has been named the EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2022 Singapore, winning the healthcare services category. He will compete with other global contenders at the EY World Entrepreneur of the Year in June 2023. Lim was praised for his courage in leaving his corporate role to pursue his vision of providing improved healthcare access to the elderly, as well as his continued innovation in growing the telemedicine ecosystem.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

Top (from left): Lim Wai Mun, founder and CEO of Doctor Anywhere; Akshay Garg, co-founder and group CEO of FinAccel; Mr. Julian Ng CEO and executive director of Grand Venture. Bottom (from left):  Kane Black, CEO of INEX Innovate; Jonathan Lim, CEO of Oddle; and Melissa Tan, CEO of Wah & Hua.

site_title: BOJ’s own reluctance to boost wages shows challenge for Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's reluctance to boost wages is a challenge for his efforts to achieve stable inflation. Despite core inflation rising 3.6% in October, the BOJ's base salaries increased only 0.2% and Kuroda's compensation rose 0.4%. Economists say it's difficult to set an example with higher pay for public sector workers, who are seen as "taxes" on the rest of the population. Kuroda has stuck to rock-bottom interest rates, even as global peers have hiked, in an effort to generate lasting growth through rising wages.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

site_title: World Cup: Rashford stars as England sink Wales 3-0 to set up Senegal clash
summary: England secured a 3-0 win over Wales in the World Cup, advancing to a last 16 clash against Senegal. Marcus Rashford and Phil Foden led the charge, with Rashford scoring two goals from free kicks and Foden converting another. The win marked England's second in nine games and eased the pressure following their previous goalless draw against the US. With Wales eliminated, England's next match is against Senegal on Sunday, while the Welsh squad will face a World Cup exit.

images.alt_text: Bruno Fernandes of Portugal scores a penalty during the World Cup match between Portugal and Uruguay in Lusail, Qatar, Nov 28, 2022.

Portugal's forward #07 Cristiano Ronaldo (L) celebrates scoring his team's first goal with Portugal's midfielder #08 Bruno Fernandes during the Qatar 2022 World Cup Group H football match between Portugal and Uruguay at the Lusail Stadium in Lusail, north of Doha on November 28, 2022. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: HPE projects sales that top estimates on office upgrades
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has projected revenue of $7.4 billion for the first quarter, beating analyst expectations of $7 billion. The company's profit, excluding some items, is expected to be 54 cents a share, surpassing estimates of 49 cents. HPE's Intelligent Edge unit saw a 18% gain in sales, while its Compute division revenue increased 16%. However, the company's high-performance computing and AI segment declined 14% due to a delayed contract. HPE reaffirmed its full-year guidance and plans to spend $500 million on share buybacks.

images.alt_text: An attendee at the Microsoft Ignite technology conference walks past the Hewlett-Packard (HP) logo in Chicago, Illinois, May 4, 2015. REUTERS/Jim Young
IBM says Micro Focus had access to its software for almost two decades and at one point copied it to make the rival product, Micro Focus Enterprise Suite.

site_title: Post-US midterms : Time for pragmatism, not ideological warfare
summary: The US midterm elections showed that Americans rejected extreme candidates, with most Republican candidates endorsed by former President Donald Trump failing to win moderate voters. The Democratic candidates who won were centrist and rejected progressive ideas. Despite the Republican takeover of the House, President Biden retains low approval ratings and can try to win bipartisan support for initiatives. However, the Trumpists in the House are likely to disrupt the Biden administration's agendas, potentially leading to a sovereign default and increased tensions with China. Americans want pragmatism, not ideological warfare, in Washington.

images.alt_text: The defeat of many Trump-endorsed Republican candidates in the recent US midterms Donald spelt the third electoral loss to date for Donald Trump : he lost the last presidential election, and Republicans also failed to maintain control of the two chambers of Congress in 2020.

Republican House Minority leader Kevin McCarthy (centre), at an election night watch party in Washington, Nov 8, 2022. McCarthy is poised to become Speaker if Republicans gain control of the House, but he faces resistance from the right flank as his party feuds over a poor midterm showing.
Governor Ron Desantis addressing supporters in Tampa on Tuesday night, Nov 8, 2022. DeSantis coasted to re-election, defeating his Democratic challenger, Charlie Crist.

site_title: Staying the course on decarbonisation
summary: Global efforts to achieve net zero by 2050 rely heavily on unlocking private capital for climate finance. However, the transition to a low-carbon economy faces structural challenges, including decoupling, demographic shifts, and the ongoing decarbonization drive. The production of critical green metals needed for decarbonization is expected to increase by 500% by 2050, posing supply chain risks and geopolitical concerns. Private sector finance is crucial, but large upfront costs, risk aversion, and lack of transparency hinder its growth. Initiatives like blended finance and Just Energy Transition Partnerships aim to bridge the funding gap, but their effectiveness depends on greater transparency and engagement with civil society.

images.alt_text: Catastrophic flooding in Pakistan has put a third of the country underwater and displaced 8 million people. Picture taken on September 26, 2022, outside a makeshift camp in Sindh province, which has been worst-hit by the flooding. Climate change has likely helped to cause the disaster.

Solar panels on the rooftop of an HDB block in Ang Mo Kio. Singapore is looking to quadruple its solar energy deployment by 2025 by covering the rooftops of its public housing blocks with solar panels.

site_title: Higher rates inflict pain on borrowers but economy, not just banks, benefits
summary: Singapore's three locally listed banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, have posted significant increases in net profit due to higher interest rates, with net interest margins rising 32-54 basis points. While borrowers may face higher loan rates, the banks' strong profits can support a strong economy, and they should invest in technology, create jobs, and strengthen risk management. The banks' boards and management teams should prioritize responsible growth, attracting and retaining talent, and building sustainable businesses.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
DBS continues to have a home loan specially for home owners of public housing flats at 2.6 per cent a year – similar to the current HDB concessionary interest rate.

site_title: Iterative raises US$55 million for Fund II, will back over 100 companies
summary: Iterative, a US-based early-stage venture capital firm, has raised $55 million for its second fund, Fund II, with plans to back over 100 companies across South-east Asia. The fund will invest in startups from pre-seed to Series A, with cheques sizes up to $500,000. Iterative's Fund I portfolio companies have raised $165 million in follow-on funding, valuing the VC firm's portfolio at $1.2 billion. The firm will run five cohorts of its accelerator programme with the new fund and host an annual event for portfolio founders.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Who wants to live forever?
summary: A financial planning approach, "Today, Tomorrow, Forever," helps individuals plan for their wealth across different life stages. This approach breaks down needs into three categories: "Today" (day-to-day living expenses), "Tomorrow" (wealth accumulation for future goals), and "Forever" (planning for generations to come). By allocating a "pot of money" to each goal, individuals can ensure they can afford to live comfortably through their life, whether it's just for today or for a long time. This approach helps people prioritize their objectives and make informed investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Most people are conceptually aware of compounding, but may not fully comprehend its power in savings and investments.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 logs best month since July on China, smaller rate hikes cheer
summary: The Stoxx 600 index rose 0.6% in November, ending with a 6.8% gain, its best monthly performance since July. Optimism about China's easing of Covid-19 curbs and cooler euro zone inflation data fueled gains. China-exposed luxury stocks, autos, and commodities drove the Stoxx 600 higher. The European Central Bank is expected to consider smaller rate hikes, with traders betting on a 50 basis point hike in December. Euro zone inflation is expected to decline, giving consumers and investors hope that the worst of the inflationary episode is behind them.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 closes slightly lower; focus on euro zone inflation data
summary: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.1% lower on Tuesday, despite rising 0.53% earlier, due to a fall in technology and chemicals stocks. Commodity-linked shares, including European miners and oil majors, gained 2.7% and 1.8% respectively, while banks also rose. Investors remain cautious ahead of eurozone inflation data and a US jobs report. Despite this, the index is on track to end November higher, boosted by optimism over potential monetary policy easing by central banks.

site_title: Astrid Hill bungalow in early stage of being sold for over S$55m
summary: A Singaporean director and co-owner of Midas NSSG International, Ng Keng Sing, has been granted an option to purchase an old freehold bungalow in Astrid Hill for nearly S$55.09 million, working out to S$1,989 per square foot. The property is next to another bungalow Ng bought last year for S$44.3 million. Market watchers speculate that Ng may have arranged for the option to be issued in favor of himself, allowing him to nominate someone else to exercise it. The Ng family is expected to amalgamate the two plots for redevelopment into one or more bungalows.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
The same site was put up for sale in January 2021 for S$68 million, pointing to a 55 per cent jump in asking price in under two years.

One of the 3 bungalow properties along Nassim Road.
