site_title: China’s nuclear arsenal to more than triple by 2035: Pentagon
summary: The US Pentagon has warned that China's nuclear arsenal is expected to more than triple to 1,500 warheads by 2035, surpassing the US and Russia's arsenals. China is also modernizing its ballistic missile arsenal and air force, with the third-largest air force in the world. The report highlights China's increasing military activity in the Asia-Pacific region, including coercive and aggressive actions around Taiwan. The US sees China as the most consequential challenge to the country, and the increased nuclear arsenal is considered a source of instability and concern.

images.alt_text: China and the US have recently sought to restore rudimentary links that would keep accidents or disagreements between them from spinning out of control.
China's Defence Minister Wei Fenghe arrives for a meeting with his US counterpart Lloyd Austin in Siem Reap on Nov 22, 2022.
Kishida’s administration has pledged to “substantially” increase defence spending to counter what Tokyo sees as a growing security threat posed by China.

site_title: Entrepreneurship: Resilience over uncertainty
summary: Entrepreneurs who adapt and innovate in the face of uncertainty can create value that appeals to a broad group of stakeholders. Despite macroeconomic challenges, South-east Asia remains a robust region, with the expansion of Asean consumer markets driving growth. Companies like Doctor Anywhere, Grand Venture Technology, and FinAccel are thriving by leveraging technology, innovation, and social responsibility. By identifying opportunities and collaborating with partners, entrepreneurs can build resilience and drive sustainable business growth, ultimately contributing to the region's economic vibrancy.

images.alt_text: Top (from left): Lim Wai Mun, founder and CEO of Doctor Anywhere; Akshay Garg, co-founder and group CEO of FinAccel; Mr. Julian Ng CEO and executive director of Grand Venture. Bottom (from left):  Kane Black, CEO of INEX Innovate; Jonathan Lim, CEO of Oddle; and Melissa Tan, CEO of Wah & Hua.

site_title: US: Nasdaq opens higher; Tesla leads gains in growth stocks
summary: The Nasdaq opened higher on Tuesday, led by gains from Tesla, amid hopes that public unrest in China could lead to a quicker easing of Covid-19 curbs. The Dow Jones fell 1.7 points, while the S&P 500 remained steady. The Nasdaq Composite rose 10.5 points, or 0.10%, to 11,060.018.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly retreat ahead of Powell remarks
summary: US stocks closed mostly lower on Tuesday ahead of Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks on monetary policy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended flat at 33,852.53, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.6%. Investors awaited Powell's address, expecting a shift in the central bank's policy to counter inflation. Consumer confidence in the US fell for the second straight month, but retail sales were better than expected, with 196.7 million Americans shopping between Thanksgiving and Cyber Monday.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - OCTOBER 13: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during afternoon trading on October 13, 2022 in New York City. U.S. stocks rose dramatically after falling to their lowest levels since 2020, recovering from a 500-point drop earlier in the day.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: SIA to own 25.1% of Air India as part of Vistara-Air India merger
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) will own 25.1% of Air India as part of a merger with Vistara, a joint venture between SIA and Tata Sons. The deal, expected to be completed by March 2024, will give SIA a significant stake in the enlarged Air India group. The merger is expected to boost SIA's presence in India, strengthen its multi-hub strategy, and provide access to a large and fast-growing aviation market. SIA will invest $360 million and participate in additional capital injections to fund the growth of Air India.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Singapore Airlines owns 49 per cent of Indian carrier Vistara while Tata Group owns the other 51 per cent. The two companies are in talks about a deepening of their partnership.
SINGAPORE’S Competition and Consumer Commission (CCCS) has raised anti-competition concerns over the takeover of Air India by the Tata group.

Now that Singapore and most other countries around the world have opened again for quarantine-free travel, SIA was able to increase traffic to more than 1 million passengers in April, the most since the pandemic began.

site_title: Goldman moves London traders to Milan in fresh Brexit shift
summary: Goldman Sachs is relocating some of its euro swaps trading desk from London to Milan, as part of a broader effort to shift traders to EU cities due to Brexit pressure. The move is expected to happen early next year, with staff relocating and new hires also being made locally. This is the latest example of banks moving operations to the continent in response to the UK's departure from the EU. The company currently has around 80 employees in Milan.

images.alt_text: The combined market capitalisation of primary listings in Paris overtook that of the UK capital in US dollar terms, according to an index compiled by Bloomberg. Domestic-focused UK shares have slumped this year, while French luxury goods-makers like LVMH and Gucci owner Kering have recently been boosted by optimism over a potential easing of China’s Covid-Zero policy.
FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England building in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: US house annual prices slow again in September
summary: US single-family home prices slowed further in September, dropping 0.8% month-over-month, with a 10.6% year-on-year increase. Higher mortgage rates eroded demand, driven by the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes to curb inflation. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate reached 7% in October for the first time since 2002, with prices likely to continue weakening due to a challenging macroeconomic environment.

site_title: IMF may have to lower China growth forecasts: director
summary: The International Monetary Fund's managing director, Kristalina Georgieva, warned that China's growth forecasts may need to be revised downward due to the country's strict Covid-zero policies and protests opposing these measures. The IMF previously cut China's growth forecast to 3.2% for this year and 4.4% for next year. Georgieva expressed support for China's efforts to adjust its Covid policy, aiming for a more targeted response to minimize economic disruptions and negative global spillover.

images.alt_text: A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

The IMF says that while China has weathered the initial impact of the pandemic well, growth has since slowed and remains under pressure because of Covid, the property sector and weakening global demand.
A neighborhood placed under lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: Why purpose should be at the heart of business
summary: EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2022 highlights the importance of purpose in business, as consumers, investors, and stakeholders increasingly seek alignment with a strong sense of purpose. Purpose-driven entrepreneurship is not about building not-for-profit enterprises, but rather about building a profitable business centered on a clear purpose. EY studies show that purpose delivers the greatest value in areas critical to businesses, such as innovation and risk reduction. Purpose is also linked to increased innovation, transformational change, and revenue growth. To build a purpose-driven company, leaders must articulate and communicate their purpose, embed it in the organization, evaluate progress, and accelerate the journey.

images.alt_text: Top (from left): Lim Wai Mun, founder and CEO of Doctor Anywhere; Akshay Garg, co-founder and group CEO of FinAccel; Mr. Julian Ng CEO and executive director of Grand Venture. Bottom (from left):  Kane Black, CEO of INEX Innovate; Jonathan Lim, CEO of Oddle; and Melissa Tan, CEO of Wah & Hua.

site_title: Record US$3b exodus hits credit ETF in abrupt risk reversal
summary: US investors withdrew nearly $3 billion from the iShares iBoxx $ Investment Grade Corporate Bond ETF (LQD) in one day, the largest outflow since its inception in 2002. The sudden reversal comes amid hawkish Federal Reserve comments, including St Louis Fed President James Bullard's warning that the central bank may need to be more aggressive in its rate hikes. The ETF's price dropped 0.7% on Monday, its worst performance in over a month, and has plummeted 19% in 2022 due to the Fed's historically aggressive tightening campaign.

images.alt_text: “Foreign investors, who are reluctant to invest directly in Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, can invest in those equities through ETFs and DRs on Thai stock exchange,” said Pakorn Peetathawatchai, the exchange’s president.

site_title: Amazon kicks off five-part bond sale in second deal of 2022
summary: Amazon is issuing senior unsecured bonds in up to five parts, targeting a sale of $7 billion, with a 10-year security potentially yielding 1.15 percentage points over Treasuries. The proceeds may be used for debt repayment, acquisitions, and share buybacks. This is Amazon's second bond sale in 2022, following a $12.75 billion offering in April. The company's total debt load exceeds $70 billion, but analysts believe its strong cash position and dominant businesses will support its credit profile.

site_title: China’s GDP growth to pick up in 2023, but pace hinges on reopening
summary: China's GDP growth is expected to pick up in 2023, driven by an exit from its zero-Covid protocols, with Goldman Sachs projecting a 4.5% growth rate for the year. However, the pace of reopening may be bumpy, with potential pauses if infection rates rise. The property sector is expected to remain a concern, with fixed asset investment growth forecast to drop to 2% in 2023. Consumption is expected to be a bright spot, driven by labor market, household income, and consumer confidence improvements. A full reopening is crucial for China's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: UK will allow banks to take more risk to stay competitive
summary: The UK government has announced plans to allow banks to take more risks in order to boost the City of London's global competitiveness. A new financial services bill, dubbed "Big Bang 2.0," will update financial rules to make regulators more nimble and reduce insurance capital buffers while maintaining high standards. The move aims to cut the UK's "discount" from other financial centers, including Paris and Frankfurt, and to make the UK a more attractive location for banks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England building in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo
Double-digit inflation has dented consumers’ purchasing power, and their confidence is also at, or close to, the gloomiest on record.
UK mortgage rates have risen above 6 per cent in recent months.

Shoppers in Oxford Circus in the heart of London's retail shopping area. The typical UK household will take a permanent 3.7 per cent hit to its income with the increase in personal taxes, says the Resolution Foundation.
UK finance minister Jeremy Hunt announced a string of tax increases and tighter public spending, saying they were needed to cut debt and bring down inflation.

site_title: Singapore green offices command 4-9% rental premiums versus up to 28% in Hong Kong: JLL
summary: Singapore's green offices command a 4-9% rental premium, lower than Hong Kong's 28%, according to a JLL study. The study analyzed 3,089 Grade A office buildings in 14 Asian cities, finding that green-certified buildings in Singapore, Tokyo, and Seoul have premiums ranging from 4-9%, 7-20%, and 7-22% respectively. The study suggests that green premiums are expected to decrease as regulations and supply of green-certified assets increase, but occupiers are willing to pay higher premiums for green buildings, especially in India and China.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
“We tend to figure on bigger developments (in) higher capital value (markets) because then you can amortise the cost better”, Lendlease’s chief executive officer for Asia Justin Gabbani said.
JLL's study found that 42 per cent of corporates has already signed a lease incorporating green clauses as at June 2022.
Guoco Tower Urban Park

site_title: ECB warns of losses for a decade of money printing
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) warns it may make a loss for a decade due to its massive bond purchases and cheap loans. The bank must pay huge interest payments to commercial banks on 5 trillion euros in deposits, forcing it to raise interest rates and potentially depleting its capital. The ECB's profits may fall, and some central banks, like the Netherlands, may seek a bailout, raising concerns about their independence and taxpayer funding.

images.alt_text: She says how much further we need to go, and how fast we need to get there will be based on our updated outlook, among other things.

site_title: China’s air traffic is shrinking again as Covid tumult grows
summary: China's air traffic has declined to 35% of pre-pandemic levels, with flights dropping to 2,800 per day, due to ongoing Covid restrictions. The decline has worsened since a rebound to pre-pandemic levels last year, with flight activity dropping sharply in the past two months. Localised lockdowns have shuttered cities like Chongqing and Zhengzhou, and protests have erupted in several cities, with demonstrators calling for President Xi Jinping to step down. The restrictions have had a significant impact on the aviation industry, with the "Big Three" airlines losing a combined 152 billion yuan.

images.alt_text: Travellers move through the Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport ahead of the National Day Golden Week in Shanghai, China, on Friday 30 September, 2022.

site_title: European gas prices jump ahead of frigid weather
summary: European natural gas prices surged 7.1% ahead of frigid weather, which is expected to start eroding gas inventories and cause outages at key facilities. Temperatures are forecast to be "unseasonably cold" across northern Europe starting next week, putting the region's resiliency to the test. The freeze comes amid Russia's reduced gas supplies to Europe following the war in Ukraine, with the continent relying on accumulated stockpiles. This marks the first real test of the region's resilience in the energy crisis this season.

site_title: China protesters defy authorities with dating apps and Telegram
summary: Protesters in China are using blocked dating apps and social media platforms to evade censors and spread information about their defiance against the government's zero-Covid policy. Despite authorities' efforts to delete posts, protesters are using virtual private networks and encrypted messaging apps to share videos and images of protests across several cities, including Urumqi, Shanghai, and Chengdu. The protests, sparked by a deadly apartment building fire, have been largely unreported by state media, with the government maintaining that the measures are not the cause of public complaints.

images.alt_text: Workers at Foxconn’s iPhone factory in Zhengzhou in central China clashing with riot police.
Students protesting against China's zero-Covid policy at Tsinghua University in Beijing, Nov 27, 2022.
Advisory firm Teneo says the social unrest could prompt the Chinese government to move faster in adjusting its zero-tolerance approach to combating infections.
Police officers stand guard during a protest against Covid restrictions in Shanghai, China, on Nov. 27. Source: Bloomberg
China on Monday reported a fifth straight daily record of new local cases of 40,052, up from 39,506 a day earlier.

site_title: China’s C919 narrowbody jet receives regulatory nod for mass production
summary: China's aviation regulator has issued a production certificate for the C919 narrowbody jet, allowing for mass production. The C919, a rival to Airbus and Boeing, received a type certificate in September but required a separate sign-off from the regulator for each individual jet. This comes after a 2.5-year gap for its regional jet predecessor, the ARJ21. The first customer, China Eastern Airlines, is set to take delivery of its first C919 next month, with plans to operate passenger flights from the first half of next year.

site_title: Croatia, heading to enter eurozone, adopts first budget in euros
summary: Croatia adopted its first budget in euros, targeting a 2.3% general deficit based on 0.7% economic growth for 2023. The budget was passed with 77 votes in favor and 50 against in the 151-seat Parliament. Finance Minister Marko Primorac stated that the euro's introduction will strengthen the economy, increase stability, and protect against external shocks. The budget revenue is forecast at 24.9 billion euros, with expenditures set at 26.7 billion euros, aiming to cushion the effects of the Ukrainian war-triggered economic crisis and maintain growth.

site_title: Confidence among US consumers declines to a four-month low
summary: US consumer confidence fell to a four-month low in November, decreasing to 100.2 from 102.2 in October, according to the Conference Board. The decline was attributed to persistent inflation and rising interest rates. A measure of expectations, which reflects consumers' six-month outlook, fell to 75.4, the lowest since April 2021. The gauge of current conditions also decreased to 137.4, the lowest since April 2021. This marks the lowest level of consumer confidence since July 2022.

site_title: HSBC to sell Canada business to RBC for C$13.5b
summary: HSBC has agreed to sell its Canadian business to Royal Bank of Canada (RBC) for $13.5 billion Canadian dollars, as the bank focuses on its core markets amid pressure from largest shareholder Ping An to improve performance. The sale, expected to complete in late 2023, will result in a pre-tax gain of US$5.7 billion for HSBC. The deal will add 130 branches and over 780,000 customers to RBC, making it the first major banking merger in Canada in a decade.

site_title: Indian billionaire Adani's firm wins bid to develop Mumbai slum
summary: Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's firm, Adani Enterprises, has won a bid to redevelop Mumbai's Dharavi slum, Asia's largest, with a $612 million investment. The redevelopment, covering 253 hectares, will include mixed land use and provide housing to thousands of poor families. The project, which has been in the works since the 1980s, aims to transform the area into a "township – a city within a city" with commercial and residential spaces.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of Dharavi, one of Asia's largest slums, during a 21-day nationwide lockdown to slow the spreading of coronavirus disease (COVID-19), in Mumbai, India, April 9, 2020. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Sweden’s biggest home lender to cut mortgage emissions by 40%
summary: Swedbank, Sweden's largest mortgage lender, plans to cut mortgage emissions by 40% by 2030. The bank aims to align its lending portfolio with a 1.5°C global-warming ceiling, primarily through commercial real estate and housing co-operative associations. The targets, which have been validated by the Science-Based Targets Initiative, will also apply to various business sectors. This move is expected to reduce emissions in these areas, particularly in property companies that have yet to invest in energy efficiency.

site_title: Parliament repeals Section 377A; endorses amendments protecting marriage definition
summary: Singapore's Parliament has repealed Section 377A of the Penal Code, decriminalizing gay sex, with 93 MPs voting in favour. The repeal also paves the way for constitutional amendments to protect the current definition of marriage. The amendments were endorsed by 85 MPs, with only two parties opposing the move. Law Minister K Shanmugam stated that the repeal shows Parliament's authority in deciding on issues of marriage, rather than the courts. The move aims to protect the current definition of marriage and prevent potential legal challenges.

images.alt_text: Shanmugam says most gay people do not cause harm to others, they just want to live peacefully and quietly and be accepted as part of society the same as any other Singaporean.

site_title: General insurers’ proposals for gig workers not viable or cost-effective: Koh Poh Koon
summary: Singapore's General Insurance Association (GIA) has proposed that gig workers rely on existing insurance solutions, such as MediShield Life, rather than requiring platform companies to insure them like employees under the Work Injury Compensation Act (Wica). However, Senior Minister of State for Manpower Koh Poh Koon rejected this proposal, stating it would essentially ask workers to pay for their own medical expenses. He instead recommended that platform companies provide the same scope and level of compensation as employees under Wica, citing concerns about conflicts of interest and higher business costs for companies.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Platform companies like Grab will be affected by the new regulations in Singapore.
The government has accepted a set of recommendations to strengthen basic protections for platform workers. Among these is a proposal for platform companies such as Grab and foodpanda.

site_title: BRC Asia H2 profit rises 81% to S$50.4m; posts unprecedented profit of S$90.2m for FY2022
summary: BRC Asia posted an 81% rise in 2Q net profit to S$50.4m, driven by increased sales volume and higher steel prices. The company's full-year net profit reached S$90.2m, a 92% increase. Revenue for FY2022 rose 45% to S$1.7 billion, an all-time high. BRC Asia expects a low-key start to FY2023, but expects robust project activity levels amid strong local construction demand. The company proposes a final dividend of six Singapore cents a share and a special dividend of six Singapore cents for FY2022.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Worksite safety issues and dengue outbreaks have impacted the productivity of construction companies.
BRC Asia's revenue for Q3 2022 rose to S$515.3 million, up from S$340.2 million a year ago,
Weakening property market sentiment could be a harbinger of flagging construction demand.

site_title: China cities under heavy policing after protests
summary: China's major cities, including Beijing and Shanghai, were under heavy policing on Tuesday after nationwide rallies calling for political freedoms and an end to Covid lockdowns. The protests, sparked by a deadly fire in Urumqi, were fueled by deep-rooted frustration with the country's political system. Authorities denied blaming Covid restrictions for the fire deaths, but protesters held up blank sheets of paper to symbolize censorship. Despite a heavy police presence, the frustration with zero-Covid policies remained palpable, with some local authorities taking steps to relax rules.

images.alt_text: At Tsinghua University in Beijing, dozens of people have held a peaceful protest against Covid restrictions.

site_title: Hong Kong crypto exchange falls silent, fuelling shutdown fears
summary: A Hong Kong-based cryptocurrency exchange, Atom Asset Exchange (AAX), has halted customer withdrawals, sparking fears of a potential collapse. This move comes two weeks after FTX, a major industry leader, declared bankruptcy due to a liquidity crisis. AAX cited "acute pressure" on its capital position after investors requested withdrawals. The exchange's silence has fueled concerns about its stability, adding to the sector's woes following FTX's implosion.

images.alt_text: BlockFi said in a bankruptcy filing that its substantial exposure to FTX created a liquidity crisis.

site_title: Singapore shares rise as China brings protests under control
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.1% on Tuesday as China brought protests against Covid measures under control, boosting investor sentiment. Stocks with significant China exposure, such as DFI Retail Group and Jardine Matheson Holdings, saw notable gains. China's lifting of a ban on property players' capital fundraising and possible exit from zero-Covid policy also contributed to the market's optimism. Meanwhile, US stocks edged to fresh records despite hawkish Federal Reserve statements.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
The return of some calm helped Hong Kong stocks rally more than 3 per cent and Shanghai more than 1 per cent on Tuesday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Transport Minister S Iswaran announced that over 10% of new car registrations in 2022 were electric cars, nearly triple of last year. Hotel room rates in Singapore dipped slightly in October but remained high. The government's electric vehicle incentives are expected to boost sales, but limited options may hinder growth. Meanwhile, Malaysia's new prime minister Anwar Ibrahim faces the challenge of fixing the economy, tackling inequality and inflation. Singapore's shares rose 1.1% as China's protests were brought under control.

site_title: Behind Foxconn’s China woes: Mistrust, miscommunication, Covid curbs
summary: Foxconn, Apple's largest iPhone maker, is facing a crisis at its Zhengzhou factory in central China due to strict Covid-19 lockdowns and communication problems. Tens of thousands of workers fled the plant amid violent protests over hiring bonuses and Covid curbs, potentially cutting production by 30% in November. The crisis has hit Apple's share price and could cost the company the output of around 10 million iPhones. Workers reported being forced to work with Covid-positive colleagues, leading to mistrust and clashes with management, highlighting the challenges of operating under China's zero-Covid policy.

images.alt_text: The Foxconn situation serves up another reminder of the dangers for Apple of relying on a vast production machine centred on China at a time of unpredictable policy and uncertain trade relations.

site_title: Oil prices jump on hopes of easing in China's Covid controls
summary: Oil prices jumped 1.7% on Tuesday, reaching $84.57 a barrel for Brent crude futures, due to hopes that China will relax its Covid-19 controls following rare protests over the weekend. Analysts say the protests were a vote against President Xi Jinping's Covid Zero policy, marking the strongest public defiance during his career. The price increase also boosted US West Texas Intermediate crude futures to $78.39 a barrel.

site_title: Euro, sterling rise on hopes of China Covid policy relief
summary: China's plan to speed up Covid-19 vaccinations for elderly people has boosted the yuan and weakened the US dollar, leading to a rise in risk-sensitive currencies such as sterling and the euro. The move is seen as a step towards easing China's strict "zero-Covid" curbs, which have been a major concern for investors. The US dollar fell 0.4% to 106.19, while the yuan surged 1% to 7.1777 per US dollar. Sterling strengthened 0.5% to US$1.2017, and the euro rose 0.34% to US$1.0375.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Banknotes of the euro, Hong Kong dollar, U.S. dollar, Japanese yen, GB pound and Chinese yuan are seen in this picture illustration, in Beijing, China, January 21, 2016. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: 💰 Can you invest on S$10 a day?
summary: A Singaporean newsletter, Thrive, offers a unique approach to investing by sharing real-life examples of two investors, Joan Ng and Ben Paul, who started investing small amounts. Joan Ng invested $10 a day into unit trusts, using dollar-cost averaging, and exceeded her expected rate of return by 8% by age 30. Ben Paul, on the other hand, started by investing in blue chips during the Asian Financial Crisis and made a significant profit. The newsletter emphasizes the importance of discipline, risk management, and staying informed, and encourages readers to start investing regardless of their financial background.

images.alt_text: Tee Zhuo

site_title: UK mortgage approvals fall in sign of weakening housing market
summary: UK mortgage approvals fell to 59,000 in October, the lowest since June 2020, as rising interest rates dampened demand for property. The average mortgage rate increased by 25 basis points to 3.09% and two- and five-year fixed-rate mortgages remain around 6%. Forecasts for property prices have turned negative, with the Office for Budget Responsibility expecting a 9% decline over the next two years. This marks a sign of a weakening housing market, with the BOE figures contradicting economists' expectations of a smaller drop.

site_title: Crypto lender BlockFi files for bankruptcy, cites FTX exposure
summary: Crypto lender BlockFi has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing substantial exposure to the collapsed FTX exchange as a major cause of its liquidity crisis. The company listed its assets and liabilities between $1 billion and $10 billion and owes creditors, including FTX and Ankura Trust, over $700 million. BlockFi plans to lay off two-thirds of its 292 employees and may recover a substantial portion of its investments for clients. The bankruptcy filing comes after two other prominent crypto lenders, Celsius Network and Voyager Digital, filed for bankruptcy earlier this year.

images.alt_text: Ether has underperformed Bitcoin over the past couple of sessions in part amid speculation that some of the US$663 million drained from FTX as it slid into bankruptcy is now being transferred out of the token.

site_title: Chinese official blames excessive implementation for complaints on Covid curbs
summary: A Chinese supervisory official, Cheng Youquan, attributes public complaints about Covid-19 curbs to excessive implementation rather than the measures themselves. He states that China will swiftly resolve the issues, and efforts will continue to fine-tune the "zero-Covid" policy to reduce its impact on society and the economy. This comes amidst widespread protests over stringent curbs.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q3 net profit falls 54% on forex losses, absence of exceptional items
summary: IHH Healthcare reported a 54% drop in Q3 net profit to RM251.8 million, primarily due to foreign exchange losses and the absence of exceptional items recognized in Q3 2021. Revenue grew 3% to RM4.6 billion, while earnings per share fell to 2.78 sen. The group attributes revenue growth to the strong recovery of core non-Covid-19 revenues, but notes that foreign patient volume has recovered close to pre-pandemic levels, mitigating the effects of lower revenues from Covid-19-related services. The company expects non-Covid business to grow with improvements in patient volume and bed occupancy rates.

images.alt_text: Dr Kevin Loh, managing director and chief executive of IHH Healthcare.

site_title: China property sector surges on fundraising support, but Covid protests cloud outlook
summary: China's property sector surged on November 29, 2022, after the China Securities Regulatory Commission lifted a ban on equity refinancing for listed developers, making it easier for them to access fresh funding. This move came as a boost to the sector, which has been a key pillar of China's economy. However, the outlook remains uncertain due to ongoing Covid-19 curbs and rare street protests across many Chinese cities, which may continue to challenge demand from homebuyers.

images.alt_text: Evergrande expects a loss of about 163 million yuan from the disposal of the 10,376.82 square metre landholding located in Shenzhen.

site_title: Saudi PIF-backed EV firm secures site for Foxconn project
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund-backed electric vehicle firm Ceer has secured a 1 million square-metre plot in the King Abdullah Economic Center for a US$96 million deal. The joint venture with Taiwan's Foxconn Technology Group will bring in US$150 million in foreign direct investment and create up to 30,000 jobs. Construction is set to start early next year, with initial car models expected to be available by 2025. The project is part of Saudi Arabia's push to diversify its oil-dependent economy, with projected contributions of US$8 billion to the country's GDP by 2034.

site_title: China to boost elderly vaccination amid reopening pressure
summary: China plans to boost vaccination among its elderly citizens amid reopening pressure, with authorities aiming to increase vaccination rates in nursing centers and encourage those unwilling to get inoculated to provide a reason for their refusal. The country has over 90% of its population vaccinated with two shots, but the rate declines with age, with only 65.7% of those over 80 fully vaccinated. Authorities will use big data to identify elderly people who need the vaccine, and cash incentives have been offered to dispel hesitancy. The move aims to prevent mass infection among unprotected seniors and ease the nation's reopening.

site_title: India central bank to start pilot of retail digital rupee on Dec 1
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) will launch its first pilot for retail digital rupee on December 1, covering select locations in a closed user group of participating customers and merchants. The pilot will test the robustness of the digital rupee creation, distribution, and retail usage process. Users will be able to transact with the digital rupee through a digital wallet on mobile phones or devices, and it can be converted to other forms of money as needed. The pilot will be launched in two phases, with several banks participating across multiple cities in the country.

site_title: Fund performance presentations – standards and potentially unethical practice
summary: CFA Society Singapore emphasizes the importance of presenting fair and complete performance reports to investors. The CFA Institute's Performance Presentation Standard requires managers to provide credible performance information, avoiding misrepresentations of past or reasonably expected performance. This standard prohibits misstating performance, stating that clients will benefit from a rate of return generated in the past, or failing to disclose detailed information supporting a brief presentation. A portfolio manager, such as Huang, who makes a one-time allocation of expenses to temporarily boost a fund's performance, is acting unethically and may be held accountable for misrepresenting the fund's performance.

images.alt_text: Financie professionals are not required to be experts on all the laws that govern their activities but they must be vigilant in maintaining their knowledge of the requirements.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, SK On in EV battery supply pact in North America
summary: Hyundai Motor Group and battery maker SK On have signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to cooperate on providing EV batteries to Hyundai's US plants after 2025. The partnership aims to meet US tax credit requirements under the Inflation Reduction Act, which mandates at least 40% of critical minerals for batteries to come from the US or a US free-trade partner. The deal also enables the two firms to shape a response to the increasing tax credit threshold, set to rise to 80% in 2027.

site_title: Juventus Football Club faces crisis after Agnelli, entire board resign
summary: Juventus Football Club chairman Andrea Agnelli and the entire board of directors resigned amid a probe into alleged financial wrongdoing related to the company's financial filings. The move comes after Turin-based prosecutors and Italy's market regulator Consob investigated the club's recent financial balance sheets for alleged false accounting and market manipulation. The club has denied any wrongdoing and will have to restate its 2022 financial statement, with shares dropping 10% in trading on Tuesday. A new board of directors will be appointed at a shareholders' meeting on December 27.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on October 15, 2022 Juventus' President Andrea Agnelli attends the Italian Serie A football match between Torino and Juventus at the Olympic stadium in Turin. - The entire board of directors at Juventus has resigned, including president Andrea Agnelli and vice president Pavel Nedved, the Italian Serie A club said in a statement on November 28, 2022. (Photo by Marco BERTORELLO / AFP)

site_title: Regulatory measures to support China's property sector
summary: China's government has taken measures to support the struggling property sector, which accounts for a quarter of the country's economy. Regulators have lifted a ban on equity refinancing, allowed developer financing through real estate investment trusts, and cut the amount of cash that banks must hold as reserves. Additionally, the central bank has released $69.5 billion in long-term liquidity and will offer cheap loans to financial firms to buy property developer bonds. These measures aim to stabilize the sector, which has been hit by defaults and construction halts, and boost confidence in the property market.

images.alt_text: The shares and bonds surge came after China Securities Regulatory Commission said on Monday it would broaden equity financing channels, including private share placements for China and Hong Kong-listed Chinese developers, lifting a ban in place for years.

site_title: Yes, substandard marine fuels can cause problems – but don’t panic!
summary:
Here's a 100-word summary of the article content:

A recent report by Lloyd's Register highlights the issue of off-specification and non-compliant marine fuels, with over 1 million tonnes detected annually, costing ship operators $27,000-$50,000 per incident. However, the vast majority of bunker deliveries are on-spec and cause no issues. The report emphasizes the importance of independent testing and verification, particularly with the introduction of biofuels and changes to ISO standards. Ship operators are advised to receive trusted advice and oversight on bunker procurement and refuelling operations to mitigate risks. Examples of prompt action taken by authorities after contaminated fuel was detected demonstrate the need for vigilance.

images.alt_text: Container ship operator Samskip is installing carbon capture systems of two of its ships.

site_title: How would you feel about a 100-year-old doctor?
summary: A growing number of older doctors, like 100-year-old Howard Tucker, are continuing to practice medicine despite physical and mental decline. While some argue for mandatory retirement based on age, a better approach is periodic competency assessments every two to three years after age 65. These tests would gauge mental and physical capacities for practicing medicine, helping to detect cognitive impairment and ensuring patient safety. Implementing such assessments is crucial to address the shortage of 38,000 doctors predicted by the Association of American Medical Colleges and prevent false positives that could harm younger doctors' careers.

images.alt_text: Moore in full flight practising a trick at the Santa Barbara Trapeze Co.
While locals will continue to form the bulk of the nursing workforce, the number and role of foreign nurses will grow.

site_title: Global shipping growth at risk from economic gloom, UNCTAD says
summary: Global shipping activity is expected to slow down in 2023 due to economic turmoil, conflict in Ukraine, and the impact of the pandemic, according to the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD). The agency projects a 1.4% growth in global maritime trade in 2022 and 2023, a slower rate than the previous three-decade average of 3.3%. The slowdown is expected to impact shipping, but tanker freight rates could remain high, and UNCTAD calls for investment in maritime supply chains to prepare for future global crises.

images.alt_text: The global yield curve inversion comes as bonds enjoy a rebound rally on prospects that a slowing economy will spur policymakers to slow or even halt rate hikes.

site_title: Thai economy may miss forecast next year as global growth slows
summary: Thailand's economy may not meet its forecasted 3.8% growth for next year due to a global economic slowdown, but this year's growth is expected to reach 3.4%, according to Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith. Exports unexpectedly dropped in October for the first time in 20 months, but tourism is expected to continue growing, driven by a strong tourism sector. The ministry forecasts 10.3 million foreign tourist arrivals in 2022 and 21.5 million in 2023, with exports expected to rise 8.1% this year and 2.5% next year.

images.alt_text: epa10285731 Tourists walk past a tuk tuk in a popular tourist area of Khaosan Road in Bangkok, Thailand, 04 November 2022. Over 3 million tourists visited Thailand in the month of October according to figures from the Transport Ministry, doubling the number of tourists arriving in the country in September, with the bulk of the tourists arriving by air. Thailand's tourism is experiencing a boost after the country lifted all COVID-19 restrictions measures in October.  EPA-EFE/DIEGO AZUBEL

site_title: Japan’s job market remains tight, keeping pressure on wages
summary: Japan's job market remains tight, with the job-to-applicants ratio climbing to 1.35 in October, indicating 135 jobs for every 100 applicants. The unemployment rate remains low at 2.6%, and the number of people with jobs increased by around half a million compared to the year before. Tight labor conditions are expected to keep upward pressure on wages, but the market still falls short of pre-pandemic levels. The Bank of Japan seeks a 3% wage growth to meet its 2% sustainable inflation goal, and further labor market strengthening is needed for the central bank to move away from its accommodative policy.

images.alt_text: Former union leader Christy Cain rallies workers on strike at Knauf plasterboard plant in Port Melbourne, Australia, Oct 5, 2022.
The small pay rise underscores the challenge of driving up wages in a country accustomed to decades of grinding deflation or low inflation.

site_title: Malaysia’s unity government is good news for country’s casino sector: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian maintains its "overweight" call on Malaysia's casino subsector, citing high dividend yields and minimal policy risk. The research team views Genting Malaysia's failed bid for a Macau concession as a positive development, as it will improve the group's gearing ratio and allow for capital management or dividend payouts. The analysts are neutral on number forecast operators (NFOs) due to lack of mid to long-term growth prospects, maintaining "hold" recommendations on Magnum and Sports Toto.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Like the party's name (Harapan means hope in Malay), Malaysian has high hopes on the new government for a change that could improve the country.
New Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim will be sorely tested as he works through his agenda.
Supporters of Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim cheered after seeing the end of the five-day political impasse.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (in white) leaves a mosque in Putrajaya after Friday prayers last week.
Genting Malaysia had been considered a credible threat for a Macau licence due to its strong non-gaming track record and mass market appeal.

site_title: Sky-high rates one way to defend HK-US dollar peg, says creator
summary: Hedge fund titans Bill Ackman and Boaz Weinstein are shorting the Hong Kong currency, citing the peg to the US dollar no longer makes sense. In response, Hong Kong is willing to tolerate sky-high borrowing rates to defend its currency peg, according to John Greenwood, architect of the 1983 currency board mechanism. The HKMA would allow Hong Kong dollar rates to rise to maintain fixed exchange rates, but acknowledges a cost with potential bigger impacts on domestic prices and capital markets.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong dollar has been pegged in a tight band between 7.75 and 7.85 per greenback for nearly four decades and tends to face pressure – and thus far unsuccessful speculative challenges – every time US interest rates go up.
The Hong Kong dollar is pegged to a tight band of between 7.75 and 7.85 versus the US dollar.

site_title: Taiwan cuts 2022 GDP growth forecast on weakening exports
summary: Taiwan's statistics agency revised its 2022 GDP growth forecast to 3.06% from 3.76%, citing a slower-than-expected economy due to global inflation, rate rises, and China's zero-Covid policy. The agency also reduced its exports outlook to 8.73% growth, down from a predicted 13.51%. This marks a slowdown from the 6.45% growth in 2021, which was the fastest rate since 2010. The revised forecast indicates a more cautious outlook for Taiwan's economy this year and next.

site_title: Toyota’s October global vehicle production up 23%, above its target
summary: Toyota's global vehicle production in October rose 23% to 771,382 units, beating its target and the same month last year. This marks the third consecutive month the company has exceeded its target, despite ongoing chip shortages and supply chain disruptions. Toyota now expects to produce 9.2 million vehicles this fiscal year, down from a previous forecast of 9.7 million. The company continues to adjust operations in China due to Covid lockdowns.

images.alt_text: Lowering costs and making sufficient electric car (EV) batteries is key for Prime Planet amid rising raw materials prices.

site_title: Global yield curve inverts in signal a recession is brewing
summary: The global yield curve has inverts, signaling a potential recession, with the average yield on 10-year sovereign debt falling below that of 1-3 year securities for the first time in at least two decades. This inversion typically precedes a recession, as investors switch to longer-term bonds due to economic pessimism. Central bankers' pledge to further monetary tightening to combat inflation fears has contributed to the curve's inversion, with the European Central Bank and Federal Reserve officials signaling potential rate hikes. This trend may lead to a global economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Protests against Covid restrictions spread across China. China's reopening is seen as a catalyst to propel Asian bonds, and some observers expect the protests to accelerate the country's exit from zero-Covid policy.

site_title: Vietnam smartphone exports fall ahead of Christmas as Samsung cuts output
summary: Vietnam's smartphone exports fell 1% in November, with output declining 9.3% to 20.6 million units compared to the same period last year. This decline is attributed to Samsung Electronics' production cuts, which have reduced the country's smartphone production by 6.1% for the first 11 months of the year. The cuts, which occurred for the second time this year, are believed to be in response to dwindling global demand. This move may exacerbate inflation in Europe and other importing regions, but if demand remains sustained, it could further limit Vietnam's contribution to Samsung's global smartphone production.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Employees make their way to work at the Samsung factory in Thai Nguyen province, north of Hanoi, Vietnam October 13, 2016. REUTERS/Kham/File Photo

site_title: TLDR: It’s early days yet for robo-advisers in Singapore
summary: Singapore's three robo-adviser companies, Stashaway, Endowus, and Syfe, have expanded their offerings and clientele since their inception. They aim to tap high net worth investors with personalized services, adding build-your-own portfolios and fractionalized products. The companies believe there's room for growth in the market, with a focus on expanding their services and client base.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
Robo-advisors leveraged on tech and easy passive investing to bring customers on board
Many use their smart devices for most of their transactions, including banking.
Bear market

site_title: Nomura sees US$1b revenue boost from equities, wealth
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest brokerage, expects a potential revenue boost of $1 billion or more from expanding its equities, private markets, and wealth management businesses. CEO Kentaro Okuda aims to replicate the firm's success in the US to grow the equities business globally. To achieve this, Nomura plans to review costs, including administration and location strategies, and cut 20 billion yen in retail costs by March 2025. The move is part of Okuda's efforts to revive the firm's fortunes after several challenging years.

site_title: Sony’s new metaverse bet: US$360 wearable that captures your moves
summary: Sony has launched the Mocopi system, a wearable motion tracker consisting of six pucks worn around the user's wrists, ankles, head, and hips, priced at $491. The system aims to bring users into the metaverse on their phones, with a focus on virtual and augmented reality experiences. The Mocopi kit is set to launch in Japan in January and is part of Sony's expansion into the metaverse and VR market, which the company hopes will drive growth in this niche segment.

site_title: Metallica announces new album, world tour
summary: Metallica has announced a global tour to support its 12th studio album, "72 Seasons", set for release on April 14, 2023. The tour will kick off in Amsterdam in April and feature multiple shows in Europe and North America, including in Paris, Hamburg, and Madrid. The band will play two dates in each city and promise different set lists and supporting acts for each show. The album's title, "72 Seasons", refers to the first 18 years of life that shape one's true self, according to frontman James Hetfield.

images.alt_text: Metallica performs at the Global Citizen Concert in New York City, New York, U.S., September 24, 2022. REUTERS/Caitlin Ochs

site_title: How China lost the Covid-19 war
summary: China's zero-Covid policy has led to immense personal hardship and economic strain, with cities under lockdown accounting for nearly 60% of the country's GDP. The policy's failure to adapt to changing circumstances and new evidence has resulted in widespread protests and a human cost. The lesson from China's experience is that autocratic governments are not superior to democracies, as they can make mistakes due to a lack of accountability. The failure to adopt flexible public health measures and to accept evidence that contradicts their stance has left China with a severe shortage of intensive care beds and a high risk of a Covid surge.

images.alt_text: This frame grab from video footage made available via AFPTV on November 27, 2022 shows students protesting against China's zero-Covid policy at Tsinghua University in Beijing. (Photo by AFPTV / AFP)

site_title: Electric cars make up over 10% of new car registrations in 2022: Iswaran
summary: Singapore saw over 10% of new car registrations in 2022 go to electric vehicles, a significant increase from last year. Despite cost pressures, the government continues to support EV adoption through tax rebates and charging point deployments. Transport Minister S Iswaran stated that COE supply, which is not differentiated by propellant type, is not a key determinant of EV adoption. The supply of COEs is instead influenced by deregistrations, which are affected by a 10-year cycle and the current economic environment.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Fitch Solutions is forecasting Singapore’s total EV fleet to reach just under 255,000 units by end-2031.

site_title: Anwar pleads for support from Malaysia's powerful civil service
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has pleaded for support from the country's powerful civil service, acknowledging the need for their cooperation to execute policies and form a key vote bank. In his maiden address to civil servants, Anwar said he cannot succeed without their backing, a marked departure from his fiery campaign speeches. With a hung parliament and a budget deficit of 5.8% of GDP, Anwar's unity government faces a crucial task to win over the 1.2 million civil servants, who are traditionally pro-establishment and live in Putrajaya.

images.alt_text: Newly elected Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim meets supporters during his first public appearance, attending Friday prayer at a mosque in Putrajaya, Malaysia November 25, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: Asia currencies set for best month in six years on Fed rate bets
summary: Asian currencies are set for their best monthly advance in six years due to bets on the Federal Reserve's rate-cutting cycle ending. The Bloomberg JPMorgan Asia Dollar Index has risen 2.7% in November, with South Korea's won and Thai baht leading the gains. Analysts expect Asian currencies to recover from a dismal year, but traders remain cautious amid China's virus outbreak and potential lockdowns. The outlook for Asian currencies is positive, with the Fed's rate bets supporting gains.

site_title: Foxconn offers more bonuses to win back iPhone city staff
summary: Foxconn, Apple's manufacturing partner, is offering additional bonuses to workers in China to soothe unrest and restore production at the world's largest iPhone factory. The bonuses include an extra 30 yuan per hour through December and January, as well as a returnee bonus of 500 yuan. The move comes after violent protests broke out against lockdowns imposed at the factory due to a rise in Covid infections. The bonuses are part of efforts to address production problems, which could cut output by 6 million units of iPhone 14 Pros, resulting in at least $6 billion in lost revenue.

site_title: China’s Covid policies once again upending car manufacturing
summary: China's strict Covid Zero policies are disrupting car manufacturing, with at least three major automakers - Honda, Yamaha, and Volkswagen - halting production due to virus restrictions. Honda suspended operations in Wuhan, while Yamaha partially suspended production in Chongqing. Volkswagen cited a component shortage as the main reason for halting production at a joint venture plant in Chengdu. The move may be impacted by rising public anger over China's Covid policies, with authorities deploying a heavy police presence to deter demonstrations.

images.alt_text: China steps up support for its embattled property industry by allowing listed firms to resume private placements to raise funds to complete housing projects, among other measures.

site_title: Venture capitalists flock to blockchain firms in third quarter: Pitchbook
summary: Venture capital investments declined 32% to $4.7 billion in the third quarter, with early-stage startup funding focused on Decentralised finance (DeFi) and Web3, receiving $879 million across 24 deals. Despite the decline, some blockchain firms, such as Mysten Labs and Aptos Labs, secured significant funding, including $300 million and $200 million respectively. The outlook for funding has darkened due to the collapse of FTX, but areas less exposed to trading activity may be less impacted.

site_title: Amazon’s new chip moves AWS into high-performance computing
summary: Amazon's cloud-computing unit, AWS, has released a new high-performance chip, the Graviton3E, designed to power tasks like weather forecasting and gene sequencing. The chip, which is twice as powerful as current versions, will be available for customers to rent computing power. This move puts AWS in direct competition with Intel, Nvidia, and AMD, and is part of Amazon's effort to build its own hardware to reduce costs. The new chip is expected to be 20% better than its predecessor when combined with other AWS technology.

images.alt_text: Attendees walk through the entrance to the Amazon Web Service Summit in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, April 19, 2017. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks jump more than 3% in morning
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged more than 3% in the morning session on Tuesday, driven by gains in property and tech firms. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.66% to 17,931.35, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 1.72% and the Shenzhen Composite Index put on 1.50%. China's easing of restrictions on property firms, which had been under pressure, contributed to the rally. The move comes as the country seeks to ease economic pressure amid ongoing protests calling for more freedoms.

site_title: Ronaldo remains the star attraction, but Portugal is no longer reliant on him
summary: Portugal's success in the 2022 World Cup, led by captain Cristiano Ronaldo, was not solely reliant on him. Despite Ronaldo's 37-year-old age, he still performed well, scoring a goal and celebrating with teammates. However, his team's overall performance was not just about him, as other players like Bruno Fernandes contributed significantly. The article suggests that Ronaldo's team was not as one-dimensional as it appeared, with a more balanced approach to the game. This shift away from relying solely on Ronaldo marks a new era for Portugal's national team.

images.alt_text: People watch a live broadcast of the World Cup match between Brazil and Serbia in a pub in Moscow. Russia was banned from taking part in the World Cup due to the country's invasion of Ukraine.
Argentina's Lionel Messi celebrates scoring his team's first goal against Mexico in front of jubilant supporters.a

site_title: China a ‘systemic challenge’ to UK values: PM Sunak
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak warned that China poses a "systemic challenge" to UK values and interests, calling for a more cautious approach to the country. The warning came after a BBC journalist was beaten covering Shanghai protests, with the UK government condemning China's actions. Sunak stressed the need for diplomacy and engagement to manage the sharpening competition between the two nations, prioritizing deepening trade and security ties with Indo-Pacific allies.

images.alt_text: Advisory firm Teneo says the social unrest could prompt the Chinese government to move faster in adjusting its zero-tolerance approach to combating infections.
Much will depend on how quickly Foxconn Technology Group can get people back to assembly lines after violent protests against Covid restrictions.

While the list of issues that Brussels and Beijing remain at odds over remains long, both sides are also keen to emphasise areas of common interest and cooperation.

site_title: Snap employees to work from office starting February
summary: Snap Inc will require 80% of its employees to return to office starting in February, following a shift from its hybrid model. The company, which laid off 20% of its staff in August to cut costs, aims to adopt an 80/20 work arrangement. This move reverses its remote work policy, which had been in place since the pandemic. The decision comes as the tech industry's approach to remote work diverges, with other companies such as Uber also scaling back remote work arrangements.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts downgrade Frencken after Q3 earnings miss
summary: Brokers CGS-CIMB and Maybank Securities downgraded their call on Frencken Group after the integrated technology solutions provider missed Q3 earnings forecasts due to a slower-than-expected automotive business segment recovery, weaker euro, and one-time inventory write-down. The downgrades result in reduced revenue and net profit forecasts, with a lower target price of S$0.95 compared to S$1.12 previously. Analysts expect the company's business environment to only recover from the second half of FY2023, with potential de-rating catalysts including cost escalation and weakening demand in its semiconductor business segment.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Frencken Group saw higher orders for front-end semiconductor equipment from customers in Europe and Asia.

site_title: ECB's Lagarde keeps options open on path for rates
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde kept her options open on interest rate hikes, stating that the size and number of future hikes will depend on variables such as updated outlook, shock persistence, wage reaction, and inflation expectations. Lagarde did not specify how much further rates need to rise or how fast, leaving investors to speculate about potential 50 or 75 basis point hikes at the ECB's next meeting.

site_title: Evergrande to sell Shenzhen commercial plot for 7.54b yuan amid debt woes
summary: Evergrande Group has agreed to sell a commercial plot in Shenzhen, China for 7.54 billion yuan (S$1.44 billion) to pay off debt. The 10,376.82 square meter landholding, which has not generated rental income since 2020, is expected to result in a loss of approximately 163 million yuan for the company. The sale will be used to repay debts related to the land. Evergrande, which has around $300 billion in liabilities, is struggling with a deepening property debt crisis in China.

site_title: Fixing economy will be real test for Anwar
summary: Malaysia's new Pakatan Harapan-led government, led by Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, faces a daunting task in addressing the country's economic woes. The government must navigate a painful reform process to tackle inequality and inflation, while also pursuing fiscal consolidation. Anwar's administration will need to implement targeted subsidies, reintroduce the goods and services tax, and address the root cause of low wages, which is seen as the main cause of Malaysia's brain drain and income inequality. The government's ability to balance economic effectiveness with political stability will be crucial in driving structural reforms and attracting foreign investment.

site_title: Biden monitoring China’s Covid-19 unrest as US rallies pop up
summary: US President Joe Biden is monitoring China's growing unrest over Covid-19 lockdowns and greater political freedoms, with smaller demonstrations spreading to international Chinese-speaking communities. Hundreds gathered in major cities over the weekend, and the US views China's zero-Covid strategy as excessive. The State Department expressed support for the protesters' rights, and Chinese-speaking communities worldwide held vigils to mark lives lost to the policy.

images.alt_text: Advisory firm Teneo says the social unrest could prompt the Chinese government to move faster in adjusting its zero-tolerance approach to combating infections.
UK prime minister Rishi Sunak speaks at the Lord Mayor's Banquet at the Guildhall in London, UK, on Nov 28, 2022.

site_title: Elon Musk says Apple has mostly stopped advertising on Twitter
summary: Elon Musk stated that Apple has significantly reduced its advertising on Twitter, and may even remove the social network from its app store, citing concerns over free speech. Musk claimed Apple had stopped advertising on Twitter and even threatened to withhold the platform from its app store. The move would be a major blow to Twitter, which relies on Apple's app store for many users. Apple did not immediately respond to a request for comment, and Twitter users continue to see Apple ads in their feeds.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk photo and Twitter logo are seen through magnifier in this illustration taken November 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Barkin sees slower rate hikes, for longer, maybe higher
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President Thomas Barkin expressed support for slower and potentially longer interest-rate hikes to combat inflation. He believes the Fed should not stop raising rates too soon and should wait until inflation is under control before loosening policy. Barkin supports a path of "slower, probably longer and potentially higher" rates, but declined to specify the exact level. This stance aligns with some policymakers signaling a potential need for higher interest rates, and may influence the Fed's decision-making at its upcoming meeting.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve has embarked on an aggressive path to cool demand and bring down prices as inflation in the US surged to the highest level in decades.
The Fed should keep its 2 per cent inflation target. Whatever the economic costs might be, the alternatives are worse.

site_title: Asia:  Markets mostly rise after calm night in China
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with Hong Kong stocks rallying over 3% and Shanghai gaining more than 1%, as China avoided another night of protests. The calm helped ease uncertainty in the world's second-largest economy. Property firms led the gains, with China easing funding restrictions on troubled developers. However, warnings from top Federal Reserve policymakers that US interest rates will rise further tempered sentiment, leading to losses on Wall Street. The Fed's comments also hinted at a potential slowdown in monetary policy, boosting markets.

images.alt_text: People walk past a screen displaying the Hang Seng stock index outside Hong Kong Exchanges, in Hong Kong, China July 19, 2022. REUTERS/Lam Yik

site_title: South Korea orders cement truckers back to work, citing economy risk
summary: South Korea ordered striking cement truck drivers back to work, citing an economic risk, amid a nationwide strike that has halted work at construction sites and suspended cement deliveries by over 90%. The government issued the order during a cabinet meeting, warning violators of up to three years in prison or a fine of up to $31,062. The strike, led by the union, demands the government extend and expand a wage system guaranteeing minimum freight rates, citing surging fuel costs. The move aims to prevent economic disruption and keep the country's economy on track amid rising energy prices and a slowdown in exports.

images.alt_text: Trucks parked at the Uiwang Inland Container Depot.Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Luxury home prices expected to surge in Dubai, drop in London
summary: Dubai luxury home prices are forecast to rise 13.5% in 2023, surpassing Knight Frank's ranking of prime residential price growth. This is attributed to the city's relative affordability and welcome of Russian wealth. In contrast, London and Seoul are expected to experience a 3% drop in prices, while New York's prices are forecast to grow 2%. Global prime property prices are predicted to rise by an average of 2% across 25 major cities, down from 5.2% in 2022.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s property slowdown spans residential, office and retail sectors, and both primary and secondary markets.

site_title: Singapore commercial EV sales to see boost from incentives, but limited options a barrier: Fitch Solutions
summary: Singapore's commercial electric vehicle (EV) sales are expected to see a boost from incentives, but limited options will remain a barrier to adoption. Fitch Solutions forecasts a 394.6% growth in EV sales for 2022, driven by government incentives, and expects commercial EV sales to contract by 47% in 2023. Over the longer term, commercial EV sales are expected to average annual growth of 28.5% to reach 4,500 units by end-2031. Passenger EV sales are forecasted to grow 36.9% in 2023, with locally assembled EVs aiding adoption.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Qatar Airways said on Wednesday that it had acquired a five per cent stake in China Southern Airlines, as it seeks to establish itself in the Asian aviation market.

site_title: Singapore shares open muted after Wall Street slide; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index opened 0.1% higher on Tuesday, following overnight losses on Wall Street and Europe. The index ended at 3,244.24, with Sembcorp Marine leading gains and DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rising. The most active counter was Sembcorp Marine, which rose 0.8% to S$0.135. Despite this, the market saw a slight decrease in trading volume, with 48.9 million securities changing hands.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

At Coliwoo’s newest location at Keppel Road, all its 47 units come with a workarea, an ensuite bathroom, kitchenette and a washer cum dryer. This is unlikeother co-living spaces, where there is more sharing of amenities.

site_title: Gold struggles for momentum as investors await more Fed policy cues
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,741.13 per ounce, awaiting more cues from the US Federal Reserve on interest rates. The metal declined 1% in the previous session as Fed officials signaled high interest rates to combat inflation. New York Federal Reserve president John Williams and St Louis Fed president James Bullard urged the Fed to raise interest rates further to control inflation. Investors await Fed chair Jerome Powell's remarks on Wednesday, while also watching the ADP National Employment report and nonfarm payrolls data this week.

images.alt_text: Total gold imports via Hong Kong were down nearly 43 per cent to 21.31 tonnes.
US gold futures fell 0.1 per cent to US$1,751.80.

site_title: Vietnam makes big inroads in global chip race
summary: Vietnam is making significant strides in the global semiconductor market, with tech giants like FPT Software and Intel investing heavily in the country. The nation aims to produce 25 million "Made in Vietnam" chips annually, with plans to build wafer fabrication plants in partnership with international stakeholders. Vietnam's favorable geographical position, extensive network of free trade deals, and strong policy incentives for high-tech businesses have made it an attractive destination for semiconductor manufacturers. The country's electronics exports have hit a record high, and the government is working to complete the local supply chain, which is seen as a key factor in the nation's growing economy.

images.alt_text: VinFast is in the process of building an electric-vehicle plant in North Carolina that is awaiting final regulatory approval from local officials.
Despite a pledge by Finance Minister Ho Duc Phoc to ease funding woes for builders, the sector’s repayment pressure in the next few years is keeping investors on the edge.
The market’s decline has sparked a cycle of selling to meet margin loan requirements, worsening losses for those remaining behind.

site_title: Labour turmoil sweeps Australia as inflation stirs ‘spirit of anger’
summary: Australia is experiencing labour turmoil, driven by inflation and stagnant wages, with strikes and protests erupting across various industries. The country has clocked its most days lost to disputes since 2004, with workers demanding improved wages and conditions. The Fair Work Commission is set to pass legislation giving unions greater bargaining power, despite business leaders warning of potential economic harm. The turmoil is especially pronounced in the resources sector, where workers are pushing for better pay and job security amid a global energy crunch.

images.alt_text: Australia’s jobless rate is hovering near a 50-year low, highlighting the tight labour market underpinning wages.
Resilient consumer spending was one reason the Reserve Bank was confident in its decision to keep lifting borrowing costs.

site_title: US to auction almost 400,000 hectares off Alaska for oil drilling
summary: The US plans to auction nearly 400,000 hectares off Alaska's coast for oil and gas drilling, as mandated in the Democrats' climate spending bill. The lease sale, set for December 30, could produce 200 million barrels of crude and 300 billion cubic feet of natural gas. Environmental groups, including the Center for Biological Diversity, oppose the sale, citing harm to the endangered Cook Inlet beluga whale population and other species. The sale is seen as a key concession to win the support of West Virginia Senator Joe Manchin.

site_title: Shell buys Nature Energy in US$2b push into biogas
summary: Shell buys US-based hedge fund Nature Energy Biogas for nearly $2 billion, expanding its transition to a lower-carbon economy. The acquisition, expected to close in Q1 2023, will make Shell the largest European producer of renewable natural gas (RNG). Biogas, made from decomposing organic material, is seen as a key platform for growth in the US and EU, with both regions identifying it as a way to boost energy supplies and cut emissions. The deal is part of Shell's plan to build an integrated RNG value chain globally.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Shell logo is seen on a pump at a Shell petrol station in London January 30, 2014. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett/File Photo

site_title: Crypto lender BlockFi files for bankruptcy protection
summary: US cryptocurrency lender BlockFi has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, along with eight of its affiliates, amid significant exposure to FTX and its associated entities. BlockFi had paused withdrawals from its platform earlier and signed a deal with FTX in July for a $400 million revolving credit facility and an option to buy the firm. The move comes after FTX filed for US bankruptcy protection and its founder Sam Bankman-Fried resigned as CEO, triggering instability in the crypto market. BlockFi's bankruptcy filing is the latest casualty of the crypto market's collapse.

site_title: Fernandes double sends Portugal into World Cup knock-outs
summary: Portugal secured a 2-0 victory over Uruguay in the World Cup, sending them into the knock-out stages alongside France and Brazil. Bruno Fernandes scored twice, including a penalty in injury time, after Uruguay's Jose Maria Gimenez was penalized for a handball. Portugal dominated the first half but created few chances, with Uruguay's Edinson Cavani and Darwin Nunez struggling to break through. The win sends Portugal into the knock-out stages and sets up a final group match for Uruguay.

images.alt_text: Cameroon's Vincent Aboubakar netted a fine solo goal with an audacious chip over the Serbia's keeper to reduce the deficit.
Ghana, who lost their opening group game 3-2 to Portugal, moved on to three points in the group, with the Koreans on one after two games.

site_title: Google, iHeartMedia settle charges of deceptive Pixel 4 ads with FTC, US states
summary: Google and iHeartMedia have settled charges with the US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and seven US states over deceptive ads promoting Google's Pixel 4 phone. The companies aired nearly 29,000 deceptive endorsements by radio personalities in 2019 and 2020, violating consumer protection laws. Google agreed to pay $9.4 million in penalties, while iHeartMedia and other radio networks paid $0. The settlement marks a small penalty for the companies, but highlights ongoing scrutiny of big tech firms over their advertising practices. Google has processes in place to ensure compliance with regulations.

images.alt_text: Google has called the lawsuit baseless and full of mischaracterisations. It said its deals to keep developers satisfied reflect healthy competition.
US tech giants, including Google’s owner Alphabet and Apple, are drawing increasing attention from competition regulators in Brussels, London and elsewhere.
Twitter’s relationship with Apple is particularly significant because the tech giant’s app store is one of the main ways that people get on the social network.

site_title: Amazon vows to replenish all the water it uses for data centres
summary: Amazon has pledged to replenish all the water it uses for its data centers by 2030, offsetting the 4.3 billion gallons of water consumed annually by its global data centers. The move follows similar commitments from Google and Microsoft to offset their water usage. Amazon's parent company, Amazon.com, will support efforts to replenish groundwater in California, the UK, and India. This environmental pledge aims to reduce the environmental impact of the company's massive cloud computing operations.

site_title: Google Play fee lawsuit by consumers grows to 21 million users
summary: A federal judge granted class-action status to a lawsuit alleging Google inflates Android app prices by taking a 30% cut of sales on Google Play. The class includes over 21 million users since August 2016 in 17 US states and territories, covering almost 70 million consumers. The lawsuit claims Google's anti-competitive conduct would require the company to offer discounts or subsidies to bring users to its marketplace, but Google's attorney argued that there are too many differences among app transactions to group users together.

images.alt_text: An illustration picture taken on April 21, 2022 in Moscow shows a smart phone screen bearing the Google Play store application logo. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Insurtech startup Igloo raises further US$27m funding; looking at M&A
summary: Singapore-based insurtech startup Igloo has raised an additional US$27 million in Series B funding, extending its previous round of US$19 million. The latest round was led by the InsuResilience Investment Fund II, a fund initiated by the German development bank KfW and managed by BlueOrchard Finance. The funding provides Igloo with a "comfortable multi-year runway" to accelerate regional growth, expand its team, and pursue merger and acquisition opportunities. The startup plans to strengthen its products and services portfolio, addressing traditional insurance gaps, and is well-positioned to leverage its expertise in the region.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
(From left to right) Animal print ballerinas, $314, by JOSEPH from Farfetch.com and Silk scarf, $946, by SAINT LAURENT from Farfetch.com.

site_title: October average room rates for Singapore hotels dip slightly but remain high
summary: Singapore hotels' average room rate (ARR) slipped in October to S$281.89, down 0.6% from September's record high, but still the next highest rate after September 2022's 14-year high. Despite a slight decrease, ARR rose 76.2% from the year-ago period. Hotel room revenues surged to S$411.4 million, up 5.7% from September, and tourist arrivals reached 816,758, the highest level since the pandemic started. Occupancy rates and RevPAR also increased, with October's occupancy rate of 84.8% exceeding pre-pandemic rates. Experts predict ARR may rise in the next months due to the return of unrestricted travel for the Christmas and New Year holidays.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Singapore saw 816,758 international visitor arrivals in October, setting yet another monthly record since the start of the pandemic.

An artist's impression of the proposed hotel that will come up on the Faber House site along Orchard Road.

Source: UOL Group
Copyright: UOL Group
Conditions: For SPH editorial use only. Please credit UOL Group.

site_title: The Fed shouldn’t raise its inflation target
summary: The US Federal Reserve should maintain its 2% inflation target, rather than increasing it, as alternatives would be worse for the economy and the central bank's credibility. A higher target would lead to higher interest rates during expansions, potentially limiting the Fed's ability to stimulate the economy during downturns. The Fed has already subtly raised its inflation objective by not compensating for recent inflation overshoots, and a higher target could increase economic friction and uncertainty. Changing the objective would also undermine the Fed's credibility and conflict with its congressional mandate.

images.alt_text: The US Treasury building is seen in Washington, DC.  The bond market is zeroing in on a US recession in 2023, with traders betting the longer-term trajectory for interest rates will be down.

site_title: US: Stocks fall ahead of heavy week of economic data
