summary: US stocks fell 1.5% on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 33,849.46, amid worries over China's zero-Covid policy and upcoming US economic data. Protests in China, sparked by strict coronavirus restrictions, have slowed the world's second-largest economy. Investors are also awaiting key US employment and consumer pricing data, as well as a Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell appearance, which may provide clues on monetary policy. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index also dropped 1.5% and 1.6%, respectively.

site_title: Don’t penalise employees who reject pro-LGBT diversity efforts: MPs
summary: Singaporean MPs urged the government to ensure employees are not penalized for refusing to support pro-LGBT workplace diversity efforts. Several MPs expressed concerns that employees might be pressured into attending pro-LGBT events or being shunned as unsupportive. The repeal of Section 377A, a colonial-era law criminalizing sex between men, was discussed during the debate. MPs emphasized the need to handle the issue delicately to avoid sowing discord among Singaporeans and polarizing society.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Shanmugam says most gay people do not cause harm to others, they just want to live peacefully and quietly and be accepted as part of society the same as any other Singaporean.

Delivering on policies over the years has put the People's Action Party on strong ground, but this approval of its performance must be converted into “strong votes”, said Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong.

site_title: US crude turns positive, Brent pares losses on output on Opec+ rumours
summary: US crude rose 76 cents to $77.04 per barrel, its highest since Dec 22, 2021, after rumors of an Opec+ production cut offset concerns about Chinese protests. Brent crude briefly turned positive but fell 0.6% to $83.16 per barrel. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and allies (Opec+) will meet on Dec 4, and a possible cut outweighed earlier sell-off caused by Chinese protests. Oil prices have posted three consecutive weekly declines.

images.alt_text: In the last week, crude futures contracts have flipped in and out of contango, where the prompt price of a commodity is lower than the future price.

site_title: Baguettes, Rai and Cuban rum: Unesco mulls heritage status
summary: Unesco is deliberating on 56 proposals for recognition as intangible cultural heritage, including the French baguette, Algerian Rai music, and Tunisian harissa condiment. The organization will also consider items like fairgrounds, traditional Chinese tea-processing techniques, and a central Asian lute called the Rubab. Cuban light rum and Serbian plum brandy are also on the list. The decisions will be announced on Twitter starting Tuesday afternoon, with a focus on honoring traditions, practices, and knowledge that promote cultural diversity and human creativity.

images.alt_text: A study of 18,600 glaciers at 50 World Heritage sites – covering around 66,000 sq km– found that glaciers at a third of the sites were “condemned to disappear”.

site_title: Stocks to watch: LHN, Golden Energy and Resources, Singapore Medical Group
summary: LHN's net profit rose 2.9% to S$13.6 million for the six months ended Sep 30, despite a 6.9% fall in revenue. Golden Energy and Resources' notes exchange transaction has been fulfilled, and its new notes are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Nov 29. Singapore Medical Group's offer to take the company private has turned unconditional after crossing the 90% threshold. Trading halted for Imperium Crown pending an announcement.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

At Coliwoo’s newest location at Keppel Road, all its 47 units come with a workarea, an ensuite bathroom, kitchenette and a washer cum dryer. This is unlikeother co-living spaces, where there is more sharing of amenities.

site_title: Mastercard, Block back group to lobby for Canada finance reforms
summary: Mastercard and Block, along with over 40 fintech companies, have formed a lobby group called Fintechs Canada to push for Canada to move faster on open-banking rules. The open-banking framework would allow consumers to share financial data with third parties, boosting competition in the financial sector. The group claims regulatory barriers are high, hindering fintechs' growth, and warns that the future of innovation is at risk if progress is slow. Fintechs Canada aims to promote data protection and consumer privacy in the open-banking framework.

images.alt_text: mastercard Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: EU-China relations remain ‘on rocks’
summary: EU-China relations remain strained, with numerous issues at odds, including human rights, trade, and security. However, both sides emphasize areas of common interest and cooperation. European leaders, including EU Council President Charles Michel and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, have visited Beijing in recent months, highlighting the need for a balanced approach to China policy. German leaders emphasized the importance of cooperation on global issues while acknowledging China's increasing competitiveness and systemic rival.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photograph taken on June 29, 2015, shows China's flag (L) beside the European Union (EU) flag during an EU-China Summit at the European Union Commission headquarters in Brussels. - China bristled March 23, 2021, after western nations lined up to impose sanctions over its crackdown on Uyghur Muslims in Xinjiang, the first concerted international action against Beijing since Joe Biden took office. On March 22, the EU, Britain and Canada blacklisted four former and current officials in the Xinjiang region, while Washington, which had already sanctioned two of those officials in July 2020, added the other pair to the list. (Photo by THIERRY CHARLIER / AFP)

site_title: Saudi Arabia announces plans for six-runway hub airport in Riyadh
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced plans to build a six-runway hub airport in Riyadh, designed to accommodate up to 120 million travelers by 2030. The King Salman International Airport will cover 57 square kilometers and create 103,000 jobs, handling 185 million travelers and 3.5 million tons of cargo by 2050. The project is part of the government's Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy and reduce dependence on oil, with the airport serving as the base for a new airline competing with regional carriers.

site_title: Worldwide Flight Services CEO sees near-term softness in cargo, but robust long-term prospects
summary: Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) CEO Craig Smyth expects near-term softness in the global air freight market due to Russia's war with Ukraine and China's Covid-induced lockdown. However, he believes the sector will recover within 3-4 quarters. Smyth attributes the current market to historical patterns, with periods of anomaly, such as the pandemic and global financial crisis. WFS is set to be acquired by Singapore-listed ground-handler and inflight caterer Sats for approximately 1.3 billion euros. Despite concerns over the deal's dilutive effect and potential integration issues, Smyth remains optimistic about WFS' long-term prospects, driven by structural tailwinds from e-commerce and a diversified clientele.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Phillip Securities analyst Terence Chua says the increased clarity on the funding for Sats’ acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services will “alleviate some of the overhang on the stock”.

Excluding the effect of reliefs, SATS net losses for the 3 months ending Sept 30,2022 would have been S$19.7 million, an improvement from the S$30.1 million net loss excluding reliefs in the year-ago period, the company said in a bourse filing.
Investors fear Sats will raise funds through a deeply discounted rights issue, and that the purchase of WFS will not boost its profitability as much as it implicitly claims
SATS shares have fallen more than 30 per cent from the closing price of S$3.87 on Sept 27, before the proposed acqusition was announced.
Kerry Mok, chief executive of Sats, said the company is working on a mix of 4 funding options that will give it the “right funding structure to maximise benefits for shareholders”.
The inflight caterer and ground handler on Wednesday announced its 1.3 billion euro (S$1.9 billion) deal to acquire Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services.

site_title: LHN H2 net profit up 3%; declares S$0.01 dividend for FY
summary: LHN Group posted a 2.9% rise in net profit to S$13.6 million for the six months ended Sep 30, driven by better profitability from its residential co-living properties business. Revenue fell 6.9% to S$52.6 million, but the group expects to continue growing its co-living business as rising rental rates drive demand for alternatives. For the full year, net profit rose 63.3% to S$45.8 million, with a final dividend of S$0.01 per share declared. The company plans to expand its co-living business and seek more external facilities management contracts.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Space @ Tampines, a 59-unit industrial property can host companies in general and special industries.

site_title: Banks in Singapore expand wealth, tech jobs even as Wall Street layoffs gather steam
summary: Banks in Singapore are expanding their wealth and tech jobs despite global investment banks cutting back. Demand for private banking and wealth management talent has grown, according to Ken Ong, director at Morgan McKinley. Meanwhile, lenders are hiring across various divisions, including tech-related roles, as they seek to enhance digital capabilities. This trend is seen as a positive for the Singaporean banking sector, which is looking to capitalize on the increasing flow of private monies.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Credit Suisse’s biggest round of job cuts in China comes at an awkward time for the firm.

FILE PHOTO: The corporate logo of financial firm Morgan Stanley is pictured on the company's world headquarters in the Manhattan borough of New York City, January 20, 2015.   REUTERS/Mike Segar (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS LOGO)/File Photo

site_title: Ghana hold off South Korea in five-goal thriller
summary: Ghana edged out South Korea 3-2 in a thrilling World Cup Group H match on November 28, staying in contention for the next round. Ghana led 2-0 at halftime but allowed South Korea back into the game as Cho Gue-sung netted twice. Ghana's Mohammed Kudus netted twice, including a late winner, to secure the three points. The win moves Ghana to three points in the group, while South Korea remains on one point.

site_title: Europe: China’s Covid-19 protests weigh on shares; Airbus tumbles
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.7% on Monday, following a global market rout due to China's rare Covid-19 protests. The protests, which began in Shanghai and Beijing, raised concerns about China's zero-Covid policy and its impact on the global economy. Shares of Airbus dropped 5.7% after a report suggested the planemaker may delay some jet deliveries. European oil stocks also fell, and China-exposed automakers and luxury goods were hit. The market's decline was partly attributed to worries about the outlook for China's economy and the potential for interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.

site_title: ‘Mpox’ – the new name for monkeypox to fight stigma
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has announced that it will start using "mpox" as a preferred term for the disease, replacing "monkeypox" due to complaints of racism and stigma. The decision was made after a public consultation and will be used alongside "monkeypox" for one year. The new name was chosen to help people take the health emergency seriously, with suggestions ranging from removing monkey imagery to more farcical options. The WHO has reported 80,000 confirmed cases and 55 deaths in 110 countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Test tubes labeled "Monkeypox virus positive and negative" are seen in this illustration taken May 23, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Meta fined US$277m for leak of half billion users
summary: Meta Platforms has been fined US$277 million by the Irish Data Protection Commission for failing to prevent the leak of personal data of over half a billion Facebook users. The fine, the third-largest under the EU's General Data Protection Regulation, follows a probe that found Meta's Irish unit failed to apply strict safeguards. The leak, which occurred between 2018 and 2019, exposed personal information of 533 million users worldwide. Meta has cooperated with regulators and made changes to its systems to prevent unauthorized data scraping.

images.alt_text: Despite WhatsApp’s popularity and its eye-popping US$22 billion acquisition price tag in 2014, to date, it has contributed only a sliver to Meta’s total revenue.

site_title: China may end Covid Zero earlier than expected: Goldman Sachs
summary: China may end its Covid Zero policy earlier than expected, with Goldman Sachs forecasting a 30% probability of a reopening before the second quarter of 2023. Social unrest and protests, particularly in major cities, are prompting the government to reconsider its approach to combating infections. Goldman Sachs' chief China economist, Hui Shan, warned that the central government may need to choose between more lockdowns and more Covid outbreaks, which could lead to a "disorderly" exit. The bank's growth forecast for the fourth quarter has also been downgraded due to the worsening virus situation.

images.alt_text: At Tsinghua University in Beijing, dozens of people have held a peaceful protest against Covid restrictions.
China’s onshore yuan finished the domestic session around 0.5 per cent lower at 7.199 per US dollar, the lowest close since Nov 10.

site_title: The new winners and losers in business
summary: The business landscape has undergone a significant shift over the past three years, with the digital hares giving ground to old-economy tortoises. The S&P 500 index has risen 25% since January 2020, with energy and information technology being the top-performing sectors. However, the recent inflationary stage has led to a decline in tech stocks, with investors increasingly favoring established firms that can generate cash from legacy investments. As capital becomes scarcer, the ability to marshal capital and use it efficiently is likely to become a key differentiator for performance, benefiting established firms across the economy.

images.alt_text: The e-commerce giant is planning to lay off about 10,000 people in corporate and technology jobs, the New York Times reported.
A corporate purpose that drives and underpins ESG goals is instrumental in attracting the finance, trust and confidence that are necessary to grow the business.

site_title: Britain U-turns over energy-saving publicity drive
summary: Britain has unveiled an energy-saving campaign to encourage lower consumption this winter, and increased financial help for home insulation, just two months after former Prime Minister Liz Truss ruled out such a move. The £18 million campaign will provide advice on measures such as lowering temperatures and installing draught proofing. The government also pledged another £1 billion in funds to help with home insulation, on top of its existing £6.6-billion scheme. The move has been criticized by opposition politicians and green lobby groups as "far too little, too late" and "a drop in the ocean."

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt making an autumn budget statement in the House of Commons in London on Nov 17, 2022.
UK Business Minister Grant Shapps said the prime minister backed building onshore wind farms where there was local consent.

site_title: Crypto fraud leaps in UK as scammers target unwary amateurs
summary: UK cryptocurrency fraud saw a 32% increase to £226 million in the year ending Sep 20, 2022, with 16% more reported cases. Scammers target inexperienced investors, promising high returns. The surge in crypto crimes is linked to a broader problem of fraud, which increased after the Covid-19 pandemic. Civil courts may see a rise in claims against crypto fraudsters, with possible class action lawsuits against crypto exchanges.

site_title: UK retail sales slide in November, pessimism rises: CBI
summary: UK retail sales declined in November, with a CBI survey showing a balance of -19, down from +18 in October. Expectations for sales in December fell to their lowest since March 2021, with orders from suppliers drying up and retailers foreseeing no improvement. The cost-of-living crisis continues to impact consumers, with soaring inflation contributing to the decline.

site_title: China’s net gold imports via Hong Kong nearly halve in October
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong nearly halved in October to 18.664 tonnes, a 45% drop from September, due to logistical issues from Covid curbs. Total imports via Hong Kong were down 43% to 21.31 tonnes. Analysts attribute the decline to supply chain issues, with China's central bank controlling gold imports. Gold trade into China in October accounted for only 7% of the 10-month total, reflecting a slowdown in the market.

site_title: AusGroup comes short again just when a brighter future beckons
summary: AusGroup, a Singapore Exchange-listed marine project and asset services provider, has faced significant challenges. The company has undergone key executive changes, including the resignation of its managing director and CFO, and has appointed a financial adviser to advise on restructuring. AusGroup's shares have plummeted to S$0.009, the lowest since its listing 17 years ago, and the company has opted to go down the judicial management (JM) route. This decision follows a history of struggles, including a 2016 default on notes repayment and a 2022 loss of A$32 million. The company's prospects are uncertain, and its future remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Shane Kimpton, chief executive officer of AusGroup; although the group is in advanced talks, there is no assurance that any sale will materialise, it said.
Shane Kimpton, chief executive officer of AusGroup. The company's application for judicial management comes after restructuring plans, talk of potential sales and several resignations.

site_title: Cyber Monday sales to touch up to US$11.6b as shoppers go discount hunting
summary: US Cyber Monday sales are expected to reach up to $11.6 billion, a record high, driven by discounts on various products, including electronics and clothing. Major retailers like Target, Macy's, and Best Buy are predicting a return to pre-pandemic shopping patterns. Adobe Analytics reports a 8.5% increase in spending from last year, with shoppers waiting for deeper discounts and fewer promotions throughout the holiday season.

site_title: Aboubakar inspires Cameroon rally in 3-3 draw with Serbia
summary: Cameroon's Vincent Aboubakar scored a fine solo goal and set up another as the Indomitable Lions drew 3-3 with Serbia in their World Cup match. Cameroon's Jean-Charles Castelletto gave them the lead before Serbia's Strahinja Pavlovic and Sergej Milinkovic-Savic scored two quick goals to take the lead. Aboubakar's late goals, including a chip over the keeper, levelled the score, leaving both teams on a single point and still in contention for a last 16 place.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources announces settlement of notes exchange offer
summary: Golden Energy & Resources announced the settlement of its notes exchange offer, exchanging US$346.3 million of existing notes for new notes of the same value due 2027, with a cash payment equal to accrued interest. The company fulfilled all conditions, and new notes are expected to be listed on the Singapore Exchange on Nov 29. This move follows its initial announcement to restructure or exit its energy coal business, with roughly US$28.7 million in existing notes remaining outstanding.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources

site_title: China’s Pinduoduo beats quarterly revenue estimates
summary: China's Pinduoduo exceeded quarterly revenue estimates, rising 65% to 35.50 billion yuan, driven by Covid-related lockdowns forcing consumers to shop online. Shares surged 10% in US pre-market trade. The company attributed its success to categories such as agricultural produce, consumer electronics, and beauty products. Pinduoduo plans to invest in technology and innovation, but warned that this may weigh on future profitability. The company also launched its international platform Temu, which has seen over 5 million installs in the US.

site_title: China allows resumption of local share sales to boost developer funding
summary: China has lifted a multi-year ban on private share sales by property developers, allowing listed firms to raise funds for debt repayment, project completion, and acquisitions. The move aims to support the "stable and healthy" development of the sector, which has been hit by defaults and declining sales. The China Securities Regulatory Commission also relaxed rules for developers to sell shares to buy property assets and access funding from a key bond sales program. The measures are part of China's efforts to boost its embattled property industry.

site_title: Temasek eyes Paris for third European office, operational by June 2023
summary: Temasek, the world's largest state-owned investment holding company, plans to open its third European office in Paris, set to be operational by June 2023. The new office aims to strengthen the group's global network and enhance access to deal flow, partnership opportunities, and talent across the European Union and broader Europe, Middle East, and Africa region. This move is part of Temasek's 2030 strategy to expand its global network, construct a resilient portfolio, and grow the organization, talent, and capabilities, with sustainability at the core.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
The Temasek logo at the Temasek Holdings office at The Atrium@Orchard on 9 February 2021.

site_title: Credit Suisse bonds slide, credit default swaps rise
summary: Credit Suisse bonds slid, with 5-year credit default swaps rising to 349 basis points, the highest since early October. The cost of insuring exposure to the Swiss lender's debt increased following reports of fresh troubles. The head of Credit Suisse's Swiss unit stated that some customers withdrew money, but few closed their accounts. The additional Tier 1 US dollar-denominated issues fell 1.7 US cents, hitting the lowest level since mid-October.

site_title: Bridging the financing gap en route to a net-zero world
summary: Singapore aims to quadruple its solar energy deployment by 2025, while countries in the Asia-Pacific region need US$276 trillion in investment over the next three decades to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. Private sector participation in infrastructure investments is crucial in the transition to net-zero emissions, with challenges including managing the orderly phase-out of existing fossil fuel-based power plants. Initiatives such as mobilizing institutional capital, leveraging blended finance, and working with multilateral development banks can help address the funding needs of Asia-Pacific's net-zero transition.

images.alt_text: Catastrophic flooding in Pakistan has put a third of the country underwater and displaced 8 million people. Picture taken on September 26, 2022, outside a makeshift camp in Sindh province, which has been worst-hit by the flooding. Climate change has likely helped to cause the disaster.

site_title: Astrea’s portfolio construction principles and key product features
summary: Azalea Investment Management, a private equity firm, has successfully launched five Astrea Private Equity (PE) Bonds, providing retail investors with exposure to investment-grade bonds backed by PE cash flows. The bonds are backed by a diversified pool of over 30 seasoned PE funds, with a robust collateralized fund obligation (CFO) structure in place to protect bondholders' interests. The bonds have received multiple investment-grade ratings from Fitch and S&P, and have consistently fulfilled all obligations, with five out of the five bonds being fully redeemed or reserved ahead of schedule.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., August 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: UK government moves to defuse Parliamentary row over onshore wind
summary: The UK government, led by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, has backed plans to build onshore wind farms where there is local consent, defusing a row with some Conservative lawmakers. Business Minister Grant Shapps stated that Sunak supports the move, saying it's necessary for local consent due to the potential environmental impact. The decision aims to ease tensions and potentially win back voters disillusioned with politics ahead of the 2024 election.

site_title: Hong Kong asks China to bar UK lawyer from defending dissident Jimmy Lai
summary: Hong Kong's leader John Lee will ask China to interpret the law to determine whether overseas lawyers can participate in national security trials, after a UK lawyer was allowed to defend dissident Jimmy Lai despite initial government attempts to bar him. Lai, 75, faces a possible life sentence for alleged collusion with foreign forces. The move comes after Hong Kong's highest court dismissed an appeal to overturn a decision allowing the UK's Timothy Owen to represent Lai in his trial, which is set to start on Thursday.

images.alt_text: Jimmy Lai made false statements to a landlord about certain business activities, in violation of a special-purpose lease, Judge Stanley Chan said in District Court on Tuesday (Oct 25).

site_title: US dollar drops, yuan slumps on Covid unrest in China
summary: The US dollar fell sharply against the yen and euro on Monday, November 28, amid rare protests in China, which pushed the yuan to a two-week low. China's onshore yuan finished the domestic session 0.5% lower, while the offshore yuan fell to a more than two-week low. The protests, sparked by an apartment fire in Urumqi, have raised concerns about the Chinese government's response, leading investors to "derisk" and sell the US dollar.

images.alt_text: Much will depend on how quickly Foxconn Technology Group can get people back to assembly lines after violent protests against Covid restrictions.
At Tsinghua University in Beijing, dozens of people have held a peaceful protest against Covid restrictions.

site_title: The industrial future is taking shape; VCs are missing out
summary: Venture capital and private equity firms are missing out on the industrial future as governments and big companies invest heavily in physical infrastructure, such as chips, 5G base stations, and electric vehicles, with multibillion-dollar subsidies. This is a response to global supply chain weaknesses and the need to prevent future shortages. In contrast, venture capital has largely invested in software and e-commerce companies, with energy and manufacturing accounting for only 4% of funding. Governments are now stepping in to fill the gap, and some long-term investors are also backing industrial projects, but private capital is needed to ensure the long-term success of these initiatives.

images.alt_text: business angel, dollar, money

(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 23, 2019 Facebook Chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg testifies before the House Financial Services Committee on "An Examination of Facebook and Its Impact on the Financial Services and Housing Sectors" in the Rayburn House Office Building in Washington, DC. - Facebook-parent Meta put out word to employees on September 29, 2022 that it will freeze hiring to cut costs as it endures tough economic times, The Wall Street Journal reported. Meta chief Mark Zuckerberg revealed a planned pause in hiring during a weekly all-hands meeting, the Journal reported, saying the move came as the social media titan planned to cut expenses by at least 10 percent. (Photo by MANDEL NGAN / AFP)
IBM's 433-qubits Osprey quantum processor, with more than three times the qubits of the IBM Eagle processor.
The AI computer will operate on Microsoft’s Azure cloud, using tens of thousands of graphics processing units (GPUs), Nvidia’s most powerful H100 and its A100 chips.

site_title: Toshiba’s preferred bid delayed amid loan uncertainty, sources say
summary: Toshiba's preferred bid to take the company private is delayed due to uncertainty over loan commitments from lenders, including Sumitomo Mitsui Banking. The lenders are reviewing the Japan Industrial Partners-led consortium's plans for Toshiba's business and assessing whether the loans will be redeemed on schedule. The original deadline for securing financing was November 7, and the deal is now expected to be completed in mid-December, later than initially planned. The consortium is seeking 1.2 trillion yen in syndicated loans and 200 billion yen in additional commitments.

site_title: No Signboard pares Q4 losses to S$0.6 million, prepares to resume trading
summary: No Signboard, a suspended seafood restaurant operator, reported a Q4 loss of S$0.6 million, narrower than the year-ago loss of S$4.4 million. Full-year losses came in at S$2.7 million, down from S$9.1 million. The company has entered into an implementation agreement with Gazelle Ventures, which will pump up to S$5 million into No Signboard, aiming to resume trading.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
No Signboard and OCBC have not been able to agree on the terms of repayment of a S$3 million outstanding bank loan.
The Singapore High Court has granted itNo Signboard Holdings and 2 of its subsidiaries a moratorium lasting till October.
The Singapore High Court was scheduled to hear moratorium requests by No Signboard and 2 of its subsidiaries at 2.30pm on May 26.
In No Signboard’s application, it requested that OCBC, which is the creditor of S$3 million under a temporary bridging loan facility, be excluded from the terms of the moratorium order.
No Signboard has flagged going concern issues amid operating challenges such as the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the food and beverage business.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Minister-in-charge of the Public Service Chan Chun Sing announced that civil servants meeting performance criteria should receive salary increments exceeding the inflation rate this year. In other news, 1,270 Singapore residents were retrenched from tech firms between July and November, and private trustees may handle all bankruptcy cases except those of public interest under a new amendment bill. Additionally, ComfortDelGro and Gojek partnered to address driver shortages, while Singapore shares fell due to China's Covid protests dampening market sentiment, with ST Engineering posting a 19% rise in 9M revenue.

site_title: SkillsFuture Singapore eyes strengthening regulatory powers against fraud, abuse
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Singapore (SSG) is proposing amendments to two laws to strengthen its regulatory powers against fraud and abuse of its incentives and loans. The proposed amendments would make it an offence to put up misleading advertisements claiming a course is funded or accredited by SSG. Convicted offenders would face a mandatory penalty, fine, or imprisonment, and SSG would gain the power to recover its funds or take action against those who put up false ads. The changes aim to enhance SSG's enforcement powers and prescribe new offences related to "abusive funding arrangements".

images.alt_text: Sharon See
2021年8月举行的“技能创前程月”路演。公众可在“技能创前程月”的路演中获得技能提升和职业规划等指导。

site_title: Global oil market signals short-term weakness ahead of EU ban on Russian oil
summary: Global oil market signals a potential shift ahead of an EU ban on Russian oil, with crude futures trading weaker than future-dated contracts and physical crude grades declining. Top oil consumer China's Covid-19 lockdowns and central banks' interest rate hikes are contributing to reduced demand, while an oversupplied market is building due to increased imports of discounted Russian oil. The EU ban, set to start on Dec 5, and a G7 price cap on Russian oil sales are also expected to impact the market, leading to short-term weakness.

images.alt_text: Brent and WTI’s market structure implies current demand is softening.
Oil’s recent leg lower is the latest twist in what’s been a tumultuous year.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group takeover offer turns unconditional
summary: Singapore Medical Group's (SMG) takeover offer has turned unconditional, with TLW Success, an investment vehicle owned by SMG executives, reaching a 90% threshold of shares and valid acceptances. The offer, initially set at S$0.37 per share, was raised to S$0.40 per share. The revised offer represents a 16.8% premium over SMG's net asset value and 357.1% over its net tangible asset value. The offer will remain open until December 19.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Dr Beng Teck Liang, chief executive officer (CEO) of Singapore Medical Group (SMG).

site_title: China Covid cases hit fresh record high after weekend of protests
summary: China reported a record 40,052 new local Covid-19 cases on Monday, marking the fifth consecutive day of record-high cases, amid widespread protests against the country's zero-Covid policy. Protests erupted in cities including Shanghai, Wuhan, and Lanzhou, with demonstrators clashing with police and overturning Covid testing facilities. The protests, sparked by an apartment fire in Urumqi, have raised concerns about the management of China's restrictive policy and its impact on the economy. China's authorities have denied that the Covid curbs hindered rescue efforts in the Urumqi fire.

images.alt_text: Police were out in force in some areas where huge crowds gathered in Shanghai after protesters at one location on Saturday called for President Xi Jinping to step down.

site_title: Barclays CEO Venkat to undergo cancer treatment, prognosis 'excellent'
summary: Barclays CEO Venkat to undergo cancer treatment for non-Hodgkin lymphoma, a treatable cancer. The 12-16 week treatment in New York is expected to have an "excellent" prognosis. Despite the treatment, Venkat plans to continue working and will run the company normally. Barclays has not appointed an interim CEO, and the executive committee will handle the management of the company during his absence.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chief Executive Officer of Barclays CS Venkatakrishnan walks outside the Treasury building, in London, Britain September 7, 2022. REUTERS/Hannah Mckay/File Photo

site_title: Amazon shutters some India businesses amid global cuts
summary: Amazon is shutting down parts of its Indian operations as part of its cost-reduction campaign. The company will exit meal deliveries and bulk doorstep deliveries of packaged consumer goods, resulting in several hundred layoffs. This move underscores Amazon's struggles in India, one of the world's fastest-growing e-commerce markets, despite having a large workforce of over 10,000. The company will focus on its core offerings, including online retail in India.

images.alt_text: Appario, a joint venture partnership between Amazon and India’s Patni group, has listed products on Amazon India since 2017.
The boom in India comes despite economic challenges elsewhere in the world, with broadening inflation in the aftermath of the Russia-Ukraine war and sharply higher interest rates.
Amazon’s renewable energy projects would total 379 after the addition of the 71 new ones.

site_title: EDBI’s Chu Swee Yeok leaving in Feb to start fund; Paul Ng to succeed as CEO
summary: EDBI's CEO and President Chu Swee Yeok will step down on February 1 after 14 years, to establish a new fund management entity aiming to raise up to $200 million for later-stage tech and healthcare investments. Managing partner Paul Ng will succeed her. Chu will remain a senior adviser to the chairman of the investment arm and help guide its growth. The transition is part of a deliberate multi-year succession plan, ensuring a seamless leadership change.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Chu Swee Yeok helms government investment arm EDBI, whose investments include Moderna, ByteDance and Grab.

site_title: Apple may make 6 million fewer iPhone Pros due to tumult at China plant
summary: Apple's iPhone Pro production is expected to be short by approximately 6 million units this year due to violent protests and lockdowns at Foxconn Technology Group's Zhengzhou plant in China. The situation remains fluid, and production could be further impacted if lockdowns continue. Apple has lowered its overall production target to 87 million units, and Foxconn expects to make up the lost output in 2023. Analysts say the incident highlights the risks of China's Covid policies on Apple's vast supply chain, potentially leading to diversification efforts.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest Apple iPhone factory has been grappling with strict Covid-19 restrictions that have fuelled discontent among workers and disrupted production ahead of Christmas and January’s Chinese New Year holiday.

site_title: Indonesia proposes 30% budget top-up for construction of new capital
summary: Indonesia's public works ministry proposes a 30% budget top-up, totaling around 12.7 trillion rupiah ($1.1 billion), to speed up construction of the country's new capital city, Nusantara, on Borneo island. The additional funds will be used to develop infrastructure, including toll roads and housing for civil servants. The government plans to finance about 20% of the total cost, with investors covering the remaining 80%. Construction is set to start in January, with President Joko Widodo planning to invite investors to visit the new capital in the second quarter of next year.

images.alt_text: A flag-raising ceremony at ground zero of Indonesia's future capital in Sepaku, Penajam Paser Utara, East Kalimantan on Aug 17, 2022, on the country's 77th Independence Day.

site_title: Japan PM wants defence spending to double to 2% of GDP to counter China
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has instructed ministers to double defence spending to approximately 2% of gross domestic product in five years to counter China's growing assertiveness in the region. The move aims to strengthen Japan's defence capabilities and address concerns about its security threat. Defence Minister Yasukazu Hamada stated that securing necessary funding is crucial to meet Japan's mid-term defence plan, which will be drawn up by the end of the year. The government plans to secure funding through both revenue and spending reforms.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida answers questions during the House of Representatives budget committee session at the Parliament in Tokyo on November 25, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: Vietnam’s anti-graft crackdown chills supply chains, investment
summary: Vietnam's anti-corruption drive has disrupted routine transactions, causing shortages of essential goods and dampening investor confidence. The crackdown has paralyzed imports of drugs and petrol, investments in energy and manufacturing projects, and hindered foreign investment. The pharmaceutical sector, particularly, has been severely affected, with 65% of large hospitals experiencing shortages of drugs and medical products. The government's efforts to address the issue are unclear, with officials fearing accusations of corruption and reluctance to approve procurement contracts, leading to economic uncertainty and anxiety among businesses.

site_title: Private trustees to handle all bankruptcy cases, except those of public interest, under new Bill
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Law has proposed an amendment bill that would allow private trustees to handle all bankruptcy cases except those of public interest. The new regime, expected to be implemented by September 2023, would enable private trustees, such as solicitors or public accountants, to administer cases instead of official assignees. Public interest cases, making up about 1% of the annual caseload, would still be handled by official assignees. The move aims to efficiently utilize public resources while maintaining orderly bankruptcy proceedings.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
CLOSED - FORECLOSURE - LIQUIDATION - JUDICIAL MANAGEMENT - BANKRUPTCY
The business environment is still challenging due to geopolitical events and the uncertain global economic outlook, MinLaw said on Thusday.

site_title: Wakanda still reigns on weak Thanksgiving weekend in North America
summary: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever dominated the North American box office this Thanksgiving weekend, earning an estimated US$64 million. The film's strong opening was followed by a sharp drop-off, with the top 12 films seeing a 12% decrease in ticket sales compared to the same weekend last year. Other new releases, such as Strange World and Devotion, had weaker openings, with Strange World's US$180 million budget reportedly a "catastrophic" result.

images.alt_text: The hugely popular Black Panther was a bit below industry expectations despite a current global total of US$546 million.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market saw improvements across various regions, with the Capesize market ending the week on a high note, reaching $13,373. The Atlantic region drove gains, while the Pacific market was more stable. Panamax and Handysize markets experienced corrections, with the Panamax market in Asia described as a "bloodbath." The VLCC market declined, with charterers reducing freight levels. The Suezmax market also topped out, with the 135,000mt CPC/Augusta peaking at $323.

images.alt_text: The Capesize market had little cheer this week as rates subsided throughout the week, albeit on the back of reasonable fixing activity.

site_title: Anwar Ibrahim has work cut out as Malaysian PM
summary: Newly minted Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim faces a challenging agenda, navigating a fractious coalition of alliances, including Umno, the Democratic Action Party, and Parti Islam SeMalaysia. His reformist election manifesto aims to reduce political instability and promote transparency, but faces resistance from opposition parties, particularly PAS. Anwar, 75, must balance competing demands and push through contentious proposals, such as a Freedom of Information Act and changes to constituency sizes, which may trigger alarm from those who stand to lose. His ability to successfully implement his agenda will be sorely tested.

site_title: Rolls-Royce makes leap forward with hydrogen engine test
summary: Rolls-Royce successfully powered a modern aircraft engine with hydrogen fuel, a world first for the aviation industry, as it develops zero-emissions propulsion to meet pressure from airlines and manufacturers. The test was conducted on a converted Rolls-Royce AE 2100-A regional aircraft engine using hydrogen created by wind and tidal power. The company plans to move on to rig tests and a full-scale ground test with a Pearl 15 jet engine, with a partnership with EasyJet. This follows similar efforts by Airbus and Boeing, and comes as the industry pushes towards achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: Slower growth will be good for India for now, economists say
summary: India's annual economic growth is forecast to slow to about 6% for a few years due to higher borrowing costs impacting demand. Economists from firms like Goldman Sachs and Barclays say this slower growth would help steer inflation back to the Reserve Bank of India's target of 4% by 2024, and narrow budget and current account deficits. The slowdown is consistent with a global slowdown, and economists forecast inflation to ease to 5.1% in 2024. This slower growth may also help control the current account deficit and enable a steeper glide path of inflation.

images.alt_text: A bird flies across central Mumbai's financial district skyline, India, June 18, 2019. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas

site_title: Brokers’ take: Lim & Tan positive on Innotek cash position, initiates ‘buy’
summary: Lim & Tan Securities initiated coverage on Innotek, a precision metal components manufacturer, with a "buy" rating and target price of S$0.60, implying a 42.9% upside. The company has a strong management team and a robust balance sheet with S$77.4 million in net cash, allowing for dividend payouts and benefiting from a high interest rate environment. The team expects significant improvement in cash flow in the second half of 2022 and maintains a dividend payout of S$0.02 for FY2022.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Mainboard-listed InnoTek's customers operating in China have been impacted by movement restrictions that were imposed to stem out coronavirus.

site_title: Eurozone credit growth remains brisk despite gloomy outlook
summary: Eurozone credit growth remains brisk, with lending to companies expanding 8.9% in October, the sector's largest borrowing binge in over a decade, despite rising interest rates and a looming recession. However, the monthly flow of loans to companies slowed sharply to 24 billion euros, and short-term loans came to a standstill. Household credit growth also slowed to 4.2% from 4.4% in the previous month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: The unbearable uselessness of crypto
summary: Cryptocurrencies, introduced 14 years ago, have failed to produce any tangible value, despite their initial hype. The industry is plagued by poor management, opaque accounting, and unrealistic expectations. The central promise of crypto – providing a better alternative to fiat currencies – has proven false. Unlike traditional currencies, crypto's value is not guaranteed by a central authority, making it vulnerable to market fluctuations and self-fulfilling expectations. Experts argue that cryptocurrencies are not a viable solution for economic growth, reducing war and corruption, or bringing about greater happiness.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The crypto universe does not provide a desirable alternative monetary system. But technology can and should do so.
If crypto is the future, why has Bitcoin (introduced back in 2009!) yet to find any significant world-world uses?

site_title: Prospects for Orchard Road malls may be better than suburban ones
summary: Orchard Road malls in Singapore may see brighter prospects than suburban malls due to the country's higher international visitor arrivals and rising status as a safe haven destination. The area's luxury retailers, such as those found at The Shoppes at Marina Bay Sands and Orchard Road, are expected to benefit from the influx of wealthy tourists and ultra-rich individuals. Additionally, new facilities and redevelopment projects, including a new action sports facility and a redeveloped Singtel headquarters, are enhancing the precinct's attractiveness. Despite rising inflation and economic uncertainty, high-end retailers may be better able to cope with economic weakness.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Compared to last year, retail brands have expanded their range of products and stocked up on inventory in preparation for the holiday shopping season.

site_title: Australia retail sales fall for first time in 2022 as rates bite
summary: Australia's retail sales declined 0.2% in October, the first decline this year, as households feel the strain of faster inflation and rising interest rates. This contradicts economists' expectations of a 0.5% gain. Consumer spending, accounting for 60% of the country's GDP, is expected to slow to 1.3% by end-2023. The Reserve Bank's decision to keep lifting borrowing costs, with a quarter-point hike expected next week, is being closely watched, with policymakers concerned about the response of households to rapidly rising borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: A couple walks past a real estate agent's window advertising houses for sale and auction in Melbourne on May 1, 2019. - Australian property prices fell faster in the past year than at any time since the global financial crisis, a closely watched report said May 1, fuelling speculation of a pre-election interest rate cut. (Photo by William WEST / AFP)

site_title: Repealing 377A is right thing to do, says Shanmugam
summary: Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam stated that repealing Section 377A of the Penal Code, which criminalizes consensual sex between adult men, is the right thing to do. He emphasized that most gay people do not cause harm to others, they just want to live peacefully and quietly, and be accepted as part of society. Shanmugam also highlighted the risk of the law being struck down in the courts and the potential consequences of allowing the courts to decide on such a difficult societal issue. He urged MPs to chart a path forward on the issue, stating that repealing the law would make it clear that gay people are not criminals and would be in the best interests of Singapore.

images.alt_text: In a survey this week by Blackbox Research, 66 per cent said they supported the government’s plan to amend the constitution to define marriage as “only being between a man and a woman.”

site_title: Singapore shares edge down on China’s Covid protests
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.1% down at 3,240.06 points on Monday, November 28, amid uncertainties from China's Covid protests. The protests have dampened market sentiment, with Asian equities falling. The China-focused stocks among the 30 blue-chip stocks were the worst performers. However, a research house made a "buy" recommendation on Precision metal components manufacturer Innotek, citing its strong cash position and potential benefits from a high interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Police officers stand guard during a protest against Covid restrictions in Shanghai, China, on Nov. 27. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Markets, crude drop on China unrest
summary: China's protests against its zero-Covid policy have sparked market uncertainty, with stocks and oil prices dropping on Monday. Hundreds of people took to the streets, calling for an end to lockdowns and the easing of strict measures. China-linked stocks fell, and the yuan was off more than one percent. Oil prices also dropped, with both main contracts down more than two percent, due to concerns about a hit to demand. The protests may lead to long-term benefits, forcing President Xi Jinping to shift away from economically damaging measures sooner.

images.alt_text: Regional sentiment was being sapped by ongoing fears about the spike in Covid cases in China.

site_title: Fitch downgrades outlook, ratings for LMIRT on refinancing risk
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust's (LMIRT) issuer default rating to "B-" from "B" and revised its outlook to negative, citing rising refinancing risk due to unfavorable capital market conditions. The trust's debt, including US$250 million senior unsecured notes, will mature in 18-20 months, increasing refinancing risk. Fitch also expects LMIRT's funds from operation fixed-charge cover to fall due to high exposure to rising interest rates, and the trust's operating cashflows to be pressured by a depreciating Indonesian rupiah.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Lippo Karawaci has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement with Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) to sell the retail components of Lippo Mall Puri in West Jakarta for an aggregate consideration of US$260 million.

site_title: Shanghai tightens security after anti-lockdown protests across China
summary: China has tightened security in Shanghai after anti-lockdown protests across the country, with hundreds of people demonstrating against the country's strict Covid-19 measures. Protests have flared in multiple cities, including Beijing and Wuhan, with demonstrators calling for an end to lockdowns and an end to the "zero-Covid" policy. The protests have had a significant impact on global markets, with oil prices falling and the US dollar rising, while Chinese stocks and the yuan fell sharply. Authorities have put up barriers and deployed police to prevent further gatherings, but experts say China must ramp up vaccinations before it can contemplate reopening.

images.alt_text: China on Monday reported a fifth straight daily record of new local cases of 40,052, up from 39,506 a day earlier.

site_title: Sri Lanka central bank sees inflation cooling to 4%-5% end 2023
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank expects inflation to cool to 4-5% by the end of 2023, down from a peak of 70% this year. The central bank's monetary policy transmission is working, and foreign currency inflows are improving, allowing for a more flexible currency. The central bank aims to convince lenders to lower market rates as inflation eases. The country also seeks International Monetary Fund approval for a bailout fund in January, with the goal of completing debt restructuring. This easing of inflation and debt restructuring are seen as steps towards stabilizing the crisis-laden economy.

site_title: Civil servants’ salary increments should ‘more than exceed’ inflation rate: Chan Chun Sing
summary: Minister-in-charge of the Public Service Chan Chun Sing announced that civil servants who meet their performance criteria should receive salary increments exceeding the inflation rate this year. The overall salary increments, combined with annual AVC payments, will "more than exceed" the inflation rate. A year-end bonus of 1.1 months and a lump sum of S$700 for junior officers were also announced. The government has support packages for those in need, but a small number of civil servants may not meet the performance criteria.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Office workers walk out for a lunch break at Raffles Place financial business district in Singapore on October 6, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Link Reit said to be frontrunner to buy S$2.5b of Singapore malls from NTUC Enterprise
summary: Link Real Estate Investment Trust, Asia's biggest Reit, is emerging as the frontrunner to buy a portfolio of assets from Singapore shopping mall owner NTUC Enterprise Co-operative for approximately S$2.5 billion, down from an initial S$3 billion after one asset was removed from the proposed sale. This deal could boost Link Reit's valuations and be the largest real estate transaction in South-east Asia in 2022.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust’s (MPACT) Mapletree Business City (MBC) recorded yoy growth in both gross revenue and NPI in H1FY23.

site_title: Japan studies plan to extend life of 60-year-old nuclear plants
summary: Japan is considering extending the lifespan of 60-year-old nuclear reactors, excluding periods when they were offline for inspections or challenges, to address an energy supply squeeze. The proposal aims to keep some reactors operational beyond the current 60-year limit. This move comes as the country shifts towards nuclear power, following a 2011 disaster and recent price hikes for fossil fuels. The government plans to develop and construct new reactors, and restart idled reactors, with the goal of reducing dependence on imports and alleviating pressure on the power grid.

images.alt_text: Japanese households hold more than half of their 2,000 trillion yen in financial assets as cash and in savings accounts.

site_title: ComfortDelGro, Gojek tie up to tackle driver shortage, share resources
summary: ComfortDelGro and Gojek have partnered to tackle the driver shortage in the point-to-point transport industry. As part of the tie-up, ComfortDelGro taxis will be made available to Gojek users via the app, and the companies will share resources such as electric vehicles, insurance, and driver training. This collaboration aims to improve driver welfare, increase earnings for drivers, and encourage more drivers to rejoin the industry, ultimately leading to better service for commuters.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee has seen three rounds of layoffs this year.
An association representing Deliveroo, Grab and foodpanda disagrees with the exclusion of street-hail taxis and certain logistics companies from the new rules.
Cost and inflationary pressures will continue narrowing ComfortDelGro's margins in the second half of the financial year, says CGS-CIMB analyst Ong Khang Chuen.
ComfortDelGro posted a PATMI of S$34.3 million, up 32.9 per cent from S$25.8 million in the year-ago period
UOBKH analyst Stevanus Juanda notes that GoTo is showing a “positive trend towards profitability”, with a 216.6 per cent year-on-year increase in revenue for its third quarter ended Sep 30.
Employees packing goods at Goto's e-commerce unit Tokopedia's warehouse in Jakarta.
The government has accepted a set of recommendations to strengthen basic protections for platform workers. Among these is a proposal for platform companies such as Grab and foodpanda.
Platform companies like Grab will be affected by the new regulations in Singapore.

site_title: Football tournament raises funds as its goal
summary: Singapore's Football With a Heart (FWAH) tournament has raised over S$1 million for charities and social enterprises, exceeding its goal. The seventh edition of the five-a-side tournament, held at Our Tampines Hub, featured 40 corporate teams, including parliamentarians and former football legends. The event, which began in 2012, has raised more than S$5 million for 45 unique charities and social enterprises, including FAS Cares and Filos Community Services. The tournament aims to use sports as a force for social good and reinforce corporate social responsibility.

site_title: South Korea mobilises firms to boost fund to ease credit stress
summary: South Korea's government is taking measures to ease credit stress in its market, with financial firms injecting an additional 5 trillion won into a bond stabilisation fund. The Bank of Korea will provide 2.5 trillion won in liquidity via repo transactions. Authorities have also relaxed collateral standards for securities and asked companies to refrain from selling new bonds. Despite these efforts, three-month commercial paper yields have reached a 13-year high, but the pace of increase is expected to slow. The measures aim to address the worst run-up in money market yields since the global financial crisis.

site_title: SGX iron ore snaps rally as China Covid woes spark unrest
summary: Iron ore futures on the Singapore Exchange slumped 3% after a three-day rally amid protests in China against strict Covid-19 curbs, sparking market caution. Despite this, Dalian iron ore for January delivery rose 2.4% to US$104.86 a tonne. China's further cut in banks' reserve requirement ratio to bolster its slowing economy supported prices. Protests in China and news about embattled developer China Evergrande Group's debt restructuring plans also affected sentiment.

images.alt_text: The most-traded January iron ore on China’s Dalian Commodity Exchange has ended daytime trade 0.4 per cent lower at 732.5 yuan (S$141.55) a tonne, off an earlier low.

site_title: ST Engineering posts 19% rise in 9M revenue to S$6.5b; reveals plans to reduce capital
summary: ST Engineering posts a 19% rise in revenue to S$6.5 billion for the 9 months ended Sep 30, compared to S$5.5 billion in the same period last year. The defence and engineering group declared an interim dividend of S$0.04 per share and aims to reduce capital employed to lower borrowing. ST Engineering is working on three measures: optimising net working capital, divesting non-core businesses, and securitising aviation leasing assets, targeting a reduction of a few hundred million dollars in capital employed in the coming months.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Vivienne Tay
The proposed divestment of ST Engineering's US marine subsidiaries is expected to result in a non-cash loss on disposal of about S$13.3 million.
ST Engineering's proposed divestment of its US marine business resulted from its ongoing portfolio review and rationalisation to focus on strategic ventures and those that provide higher yields.

ST Engineering says TransCore will replace the existing tolling infrastructure with its own flagship toll collection system that integrates automatic vehicle identification and vehicle classification.

site_title: South Korean house prices drop by most since 2013 as credit woes mount
summary: South Korean house prices dropped 0.32% in November, the largest decline in nine years, amid credit woes and the central bank's 16-month tightening cycle. This marks the beginning of a housing-market correction, which is expected to deepen, according to forward indicators. The Bank of Korea is forecast to raise interest rates to tame inflationary pressure. The decline in housing prices adds to credit concerns for policymakers, who aim to avert a hard landing in the market. Finance Minister Choo Kyung-ho and Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong announced steps to support the housing market.

site_title: China Evergrande winding-up lawsuit is adjourned in Hong Kong
summary: China Evergrande Group's winding-up lawsuit in Hong Kong has been adjourned to March 20, as the company aims to present restructuring proposals by the end of February or early March. Evergrande expects to receive support from offshore creditors by February, helping its plea to delay the case. The company's debt overhaul, worth 1.97 trillion yuan, is China's biggest and has broader implications for the country's financial system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of China Evergrande Group is seen on the property developer's headquarters in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China, Sept. 26, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

China Evergrande said it is communicating with the government of Jiangxia District in Wuhan City and “will file an administrative review on this matter to protect the legitimate rights and interests of the company”.
The Evergrande unit’s 30.99 per cent stake in Xinjiang Guanghui Industry Investment Group, which it had pledged to the Shengjing Bank has now been enforced, the notice said.

site_title: Indonesian startup TipTip bags over US$13m in Series A funding led by East Ventures
summary: Indonesian startup TipTip secured over US$13 million in Series A funding led by East Ventures. This follows the company's US$10 million in seed round funding earlier this year. TipTip provides an online marketplace for content creators to showcase and monetize their work. The funding round also saw participation from existing investors Vertex, SMDV, B.I.G. Ventures, and prominent angels.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
(from left) Agung Bezharie, co-founder of Warung Pintar and Brian Marshal, founder of Sirclo. Both startups merged their teams to form a workforce of nearly 2,000 at the start of the year.
Cosmart was founded by Alvin Kumarga (left) and Robert Tan (right) in the second quarter of 2022.
Investor interest grows in ‘on-demand salary‘ apps; rising rates, regulation may cap enthusiasm

site_title: Thai central bank to deliver third straight 25bps hike on Nov 30: poll
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, is expected to raise interest rates by a quarter-point for the third consecutive meeting on November 30, bringing the benchmark rate to 1.25%. This move is seen as a modest tightening campaign due to easing inflation and fragile tourism-reliant growth. The economy is expected to lag regional peers until early next year, and the central bank is not expected to aggressively increase rates to manage inflation like other countries.

images.alt_text: epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Emerging market bond laggard Asia is primed for rebound in 2023
summary: Emerging Asian bonds are poised for a rebound in 2023, with easing inflation pressures, predictions for peak interest rates, and growing optimism over China's economic recovery. The region's bonds trailed their global peers in the second half of 2022 due to concerns over policymakers' slow rate hikes. However, positioning from overseas investors is historically light, allowing for potential inflows. As protests against Covid restrictions in China accelerate, some predict a shift towards a more flexible zero-Covid policy, further supporting the region's bond market.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

A local official speaks with a demonstrator holding a blank sign during a protest in Beijing, China, on Monday, Nov. 28, 2022. Protests against Covid restrictions spread across China on Sunday as citizens took to the streets and university campuses, venting their anger and frustrations on local officials and the Communist Party. Source: Bloomberg
At Tsinghua University in Beijing, dozens of people have held a peaceful protest against Covid restrictions.

site_title: US retailers’ inflation-fighting discounts yield modest growth on Black Friday
summary: US retailers reported modest growth over the Black Friday weekend with a 2.9% increase in in-store traffic and average consumer discounts exceeding 30%. Despite inflation, sales were slightly up overall, with online sales rising 2.3% to $9.12 billion. However, some categories, such as electronics and smart-home items, saw strong sales, while others, like toys and sporting goods, also performed well. Retailers struggled to manage inventory due to supply-chain bottlenecks and inflation, but managed to meet expectations despite the challenges.

images.alt_text: While US consumers are still spending, they are growing more cautious after contending this year with the highest inflation rates in four decades,

site_title: New Zealand faces ‘shallow’ recession as rates need to rise more: senior central banker
summary: New Zealand is expected to face a "shallow" recession starting in mid-2023 due to interest rate hikes to tame inflation, according to Reserve Bank of New Zealand assistant governor Karen Silk. The central bank forecasts a 1% decline in GDP over four quarters, a relatively shallow recession compared to past global financial crises. Higher interest rates are justified by rising inflation expectations and a strong labour market driving wages higher, with the RBNZ likely to continue tightening policies in February.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is set to raise the official cash rate (OCR) by 75 basis points to 4.25 per cent, according to a Reuters poll, its highest since January 2009.

site_title: Oil plunges to lowest since 2021 as China unrest rattles market
summary: Oil prices plummeted to their lowest level since 2021, falling below $75 a barrel, amid unrest in China and concerns over energy demand. Protests over harsh COVID-19 curbs in Shanghai and Beijing have reduced investor appetite for risk, while a US decision to grant Chevron a licence to resume oil production in Venezuela has added to market volatility. The US dollar rose, making commodities more expensive for importers, and the outlook for energy demand remains fragile.

images.alt_text: Brent and WTI’s market structure implies current demand is softening.

site_title: Gold prices edge lower on firmer dollar
summary: Gold prices fell on Monday, down 0.2% to $1,752.66 per ounce, due to a stronger US dollar. The dollar index rose 0.3%, making the greenback-priced metal more expensive for foreign buyers. Despite this, gold remains attractive compared to interest-yielding assets due to lower interest rates. The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates, but at a slower pace. Other precious metals, including silver, platinum, and palladium, also declined.

images.alt_text: US gold futures rose 0.5 per cent to US$1,753.30.

site_title: Hyundai Motor, LGES consider building two JV battery plants in US: report
summary: Hyundai Motor and LG Energy Solution are considering building two joint venture battery plants in the US, with annual capacities of 35 gigawatt hours each. This would be enough to power approximately 1 million electric vehicles. The plants are planned for Georgia, but neither LGES nor Hyundai Motor has commented on the matter.

images.alt_text: A security guard is seen at the main entrance of a plant of Hyundai Motor Co on the outskirts of Beijing, China January 25, 2019. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Is the 60/40 balanced portfolio dead? Not quite
summary: A 60/40 balanced portfolio, traditionally consisting of 60% stocks and 40% bonds, has generated the worst returns since the 1930s due to dismal asset returns and spiking correlations. However, stocks and bonds now offer attractive entry points and yields, potentially benefiting long-term returns. Despite year-to-date losses, a regular investment still requires courage, and double-digit losses on a 60/40 portfolio are unprecedented. A balanced approach may be more suitable than calling the death of the 60/40 allocation.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
2022 has been challenging for stocks and bonds, but Capital Group's Mike Gitlin says it is now possible to obtain a yield of 7.5 per cent from a portfolio of investment-grade and high-yield bonds

site_title: Stocks to watch: ThaiBev, ST Engineering, First Reit, Vertex Technology
summary: Thai Beverage's shares ended the week down 0.8% due to its earnings release, which showed a 22.2% increase in net profit to 30.1 billion baht. ST Engineering's revenue rose 19% to S$6.5 billion for the nine months ended September 30. First Reit inked a facility agreement for a S$225 million term loan and S$75 million revolving credit facility. Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation's shares remained unchanged after Morgan Stanley became a substantial shareholder.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: 1,270 Singapore residents retrenched from tech firms since July: MOM
summary: The Ministry of Manpower reported a significant increase in tech sector retrenchments in Singapore from July to mid-December 2022, with 1,270 resident workers notified of layoffs. This represents a substantial rise from the 260 residents retrenched in the first half of 2022. The majority of affected workers were in non-tech roles, and most were under the age of 35, consistent with the median age of employed residents in the information and communications sector. The retrenchments are also higher than the sector's annual average of 790 workers over the past five years.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
From comic to heartfelt, the videos have one thing in common: the simple act of posting challenges the shame and silence that usually prevails after someone gets let go from a job.
Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee has seen three rounds of layoffs this year.
The recent spate of widespread layoffs by tech behemoths such as Twitter and Meta marks a  drastic shift away from the rapid and aggressive hiring in the tech sector during the pandemic.

site_title: Vietnamese e-grocery app raises US$4.5m for R&D
summary: Vietnamese e-grocery app Cooky has raised US$4.5 million in funding for research and development, led by South Korea-based Nextrans and Vietnamese venture capital firm Do Ventures. The funds will focus on creating a variety of healthy meal kits at better prices. Cooky's app combines an online grocery store and meal kit delivery service, with 1.5 million downloads in 1.5 years. The company aims to provide convenient meal solutions for customers, with plans to improve personalized services. Vietnam's online grocery market is expected to reach US$1.5 billion by 2025.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
New peaks for food delivery as the sector sees consolidation and maturity: Momentum Works

site_title: South Korea government plans first talks with striking truckers
summary: South Korea's government plans to meet with striking truckers for the first time since a nationwide walkout began five days ago, amid worsening supply chain glitches and concrete shortages. The government has elevated its warning of cargo transport disruption to "serious," the highest level, and may issue a workforce order demanding striking truckers return to their jobs. The strike, which began over better pay and working conditions, has already disrupted industry, with container traffic at ports down 76% and shipments to major steel companies at 5% or less.

images.alt_text: According to South Korean law, during a serious disruption to transportation, the government may issue such an order to force transport workers back to their jobs.
The union is asking the government to ensure big businesses are held accountable if they violate the minimum wages rule.

site_title: There’s a job-market riddle at the heart of the coming recession
summary: The global economy is expected to experience a recession, but workers have a better-than-usual chance of retaining their jobs. Despite weakening demand, companies are prioritizing retaining staff over layoffs, partly due to labor shortages caused by the pandemic and aging populations. This could lead to fewer job losses compared to past recessions. The jobless rate is at a historically low 4.4% in major developed economies, and some industries, such as tech and finance, may be more vulnerable to job cuts. However, smaller firms may hire laid-off workers at lower salaries, and central bankers expect labor markets to be more resilient than in the past.

images.alt_text: Manulife is shifting some property operations to Jones Lang LaSalle while it focuses on the investment side of the business.
Twitter has fired top executives and enforced steep job cuts with little warning following billionaire Elon Musk’s tumultuous takeover of the company last month.
Initial unemployment claims increased by 17,000 to 240,000 in the week ended Nov 19, Labor Department data showed on Wednesday (Nov 23).

site_title: Belgium-Morocco World Cup match triggers riots in Brussels, dozen people detained
summary: Riots broke out in Brussels after Morocco's World Cup victory over Belgium, with dozens of soccer fans clashing with riot police. A dozen people were detained and one arrested, while a journalist was injured by fireworks. Police used water cannons and tear gas to disperse the crowd, which set fire to a car and electric scooters. The situation was brought under control by 7 pm, with preventive patrols remaining in place.

site_title: UK housing market seen facing further ‘mini-budget’ fallout
summary: The UK housing market experienced a slowdown in October, with house price growth at its lowest quarterly level since February 2020, due to the economic plan set out by former Prime Minister Liz Truss and the cost-of-living crisis. Buyer demand fell 44% year-on-year, while sales volumes were down 28% compared to the previous year. Zoopla predicts mortgage rates will return to 4-5% by 2023, and house price growth is expected to head towards 0% and possibly enter negative territory next year.

images.alt_text: Industrial action is becoming more widespread across Britain’s transport network.

site_title: Malaysian businesses hope new government will boost investor confidence
summary: Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has ended a five-day political impasse, boosting investor confidence. Businesses are optimistic about a more stable government, citing Anwar's experience and the King's emphasis on inclusivity. The formation of a unity government is expected to improve market sentiment and attract foreign investment, according to Koong Lin Loong, chairman of the finance and planning committee in The Associated Chinese Chambers of Commerce and Industry of Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Supporters of Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim cheered after seeing the end of the five-day political impasse.

site_title: Kitchen Culture says current board unchanged; invites legal action from requisitioners
summary: Kitchen Culture, a Singapore-based company, has stated that an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) held on November 25, where five new directors were allegedly appointed, is invalid. The company's current board of directors will remain unchanged. Kitchen Culture has asked the Singapore court to determine the issues at hand and has written to the requisitioners' lawyers to apply to the court. The company claims that the EGM was in non-compliance with the Companies Act 1967 and breached the company's constitution, and its current directors believe there are no grounds to justify their resignations.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The meeting was requisitioned by a group of Kitchen Culture shareholders, including Ooway Group, who first requested to remove the incumbent directors in September this year.

In the bourse filing, Kitchen Culture said the redesignation is due to “the need for the chairman of the board to lead the company forward in the challenging business climate and shareholders’ issues faced by the company”
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Its largest shareholder Ooway Group together with seven individuals are requisitioning to remove five of the company's six directors.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The embattled kitchen systems provider reminds shareholders that an extraordinary general meeting intended to be held by requisitioners seeking to remove five of its six directors will not be proceeding.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture.  The group is urging its shareholders not to attend a Nov 1 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) proposed by requisitioners, as it deems notices for the EGM defective and invalid.

Kitchen Culture is in the midst of taking legal advice on the validity of the EGM Notice by a group of shareholders.
