Kitchen Culture was listed on SGX Catalist as a provider of solutions and products for kitchens and wardrobes.
A group of Kitchen Culture shareholders intend to convene an extraordinary general meeting remove these 5 individuals from their directorships as well as appoint 5 new directors.

site_title: Stagflation will rule 2023, keeping stocks in peril
summary: Investors predict a challenging 2023 for the global economy, with stagflation expected to dominate, according to a survey of 388 respondents. Almost half believe growth will slow while inflation remains elevated, while deflationary recession is the second most likely outcome. The survey also suggests a weakening US dollar could create opportunities in a lacklustre market, and investors expect the S&P 500 to finish 2023 within a 10% range. Despite this, respondents see some relief towards the end of the year, with US inflation expected to fall below 3%.

images.alt_text: Despite weakening demand for their goods and services, many businesses are looking to retain or even add staff, rather than let them go.

site_title: With Russia banned from World Cup, fans cheer on Serbian ‘brothers’
summary: Russia's ban from the 2022 World Cup has led to Serbian fans in Moscow gaining popularity, with many Russian supporters cheering on Serbia due to historical ties with Moscow. A poll shows Serbia as the favorite team among Russian supporters, and fans are discussing the team's performance. Despite the absence of Russia's team, Serbian football league champions Red Star Belgrade recently visited Russia, and Russian fans have shown solidarity with Serbia. The ban highlights Russia's isolation in the international community, with many European countries closing their airspace to Russian planes.

images.alt_text: People watch a live broadcast of the 2022 World Cup match between Brazil and Serbia in a pub in Moscow, on November 24, 2022, during the Qatar 2022 World Cup football tournament. (Photo by Yuri KADOBNOV / AFP)

Gihana Fava and Renan Almeida, soccer fans from Brazil, head for their rented room after checking in at Fan Village at the World Cup in Doha, Qatar, on Nov. 22, 2022. Fan Village is a sea of shipping containers converted to sleeping quarters, stretching almost as far as the eye can see. (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)
Argentina's Lionel Messi celebrates scoring his team's first goal against Mexico in front of jubilant supporters.a

Soccer fans pack the Red Lion, a pub discreetly tucked inside a hotel, in Doha, Qatar, on Monday, Nov. 21, 2022. The Red Lion Pub is an oasis for World Cup fans who are hoping to get some beer while in Qatar.  (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)

site_title: It’s time for fairer wages, but that alone is not enough to retain workers
summary: The National Wages Council (NWC) in Singapore recommends pay hikes for lower-wage workers of 5.5-7.5% or S$80-S$100, respectively, to narrow the income gap amid economic headwinds. This guideline aims to balance pay fairness with the overall economic outlook. The NWC also emphasizes that fair and competitive wages are essential for productivity and harmonious relations between employers and employees. However, research suggests that other factors, such as training, promotional opportunities, and leadership, are equally important for retaining talent.

images.alt_text: Staff can feel comfortable having candid conversations about their current state of wellbeing and workplace struggles, or arrange for one-on-one meetings with managers for professional guidance. When done right, coaching provides greater intrinsic motivation.
Some sectors are already seeing the early effects of slowing demand. Hiring activity has started to cool in the red-hot sectors of tech and manufacturing, for instance.

“I’ve just been a conductor. Everybody else in the company has to be bought in to how we want to develop and evolve as an organisation rather than just me telling them where to be,” said Li Xiaowen, deputy managing director of Apro Asian Protection.
The National Wages Council calls on employers to reward their staff with wage increases that are fair, in line with economic growth and the improvement in labour productivity.

site_title: Young Singaporeans need a trusted partner too
summary: The Business Times (BT) has launched a new initiative, Thrive, aimed at serving young Singaporeans with money, career, and personal development matters. The weekly newsletter and Instagram account will provide informal advice, unlike BT's more serious content, and will eventually expand to events and workshops. BT is investing resources into Thrive, despite not expecting to make money from it, as it recognizes a need for a trusted partner among young adults, who are increasingly investing earlier in life and seeking advice on personal finance and career development.

images.alt_text: Tee Zhuo
Thrive, BT's initiative to help young adults with money, career and personal development issues, will have a weekly newsletter, Instagram account and dedicated events.
Cross-functional BT stakeholders collaborating at a product design workshop in September 2022

site_title: Singapore stocks dip at Monday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.3% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index falling 9.3 points to 3,235.24, as losers outnumbered gainers 76 to 57. Key counters, such as Suntec Reit and Genting Singapore, fell 1.5% and 1.2%, respectively. Meanwhile, Thai Beverage gained 2.5% after posting strong earnings. All three Singapore banks also fell, with DBS down 0.4%, OCBC 0.3%, and UOB 0.2%.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Shares of Thai Beverage ends the week down 0.8 per cent or S$0.005 at S$0.61 on Friday.

site_title: Tengah Town’s Copen Grand EC fully sold
summary: Tengah Town's first executive condominium, Copen Grand, has been fully sold just a month after its launch. The 639-unit development, co-developed by City Developments Limited and MCL Land, had 146 units remaining after initial sales bookings. The units were snapped up by second-time buyers, who were limited to 30% of the project during the launch. The sale marks a successful start for Copen Grand, with no units left for future buyers.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Eligible buyers bought 73 per cent of units at Copen Grand, the first Executive Condominium project at the upcoming Tengah Town, developers City Developments Limited (CDL) and MCL Land said.

site_title: Flex office space market rebounds in Q3, further growth seen despite economic headwinds: CBRE
summary: CBRE Research reports that the flex office space market has rebounded in Q3, with occupancy levels recovering to 80-90% and leasing volume exceeding 150,000 sq ft. 17% of respondents expect flexible workspaces to account for 26-50% of their portfolio by 2024, up from 3%. Despite economic headwinds, the market is expected to grow, with flex spaces being more competitively priced and attractive to the tech industry amid uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Cushman & Wakefield data shows that CBD Grade A office rents rose 1.8 per cent quarter-on-quarter to S$10.35 per square foot (psf) per month in Q3 2022 while vacancy rates tightened to 3.6 per cent from 5.1 per cent in the last quarter.

Co-working spaces in the CBD to continue expansion in 2022: Cushman & Wakefield

site_title: USDCHF may be driven lower
summary: The Federal Open Market Committee minutes revealed a more cautious tone on rapid contractionary monetary policy, leading to a decline in the US dollar's perceived value. This contributed to a sharp drop in the USDCHF, from 1.0148 to 0.9430. The Swiss National Bank may reverse its low interest rate policy, potentially strengthening the Swiss franc and further driving down the USDCHF. The US economy's recent contraction and impact of high interest rates on demand may also contribute to the decline in USDCHF.

images.alt_text: The 55.4 billion Swiss franc decline in the value of the Swiss central bank’s foreign currency investments was the main reason for its balance sheet declining to 889.5 billion francs from 964.6 billion francs a month earlier.

site_title: China poses increasing threat in military space race, top US general says
summary: US Space Force director Nina Armagno warns that China's rapid advancements in military space technology pose significant risks to American supremacy in outer space. China has made significant progress in developing military space capabilities, including satellite communications and re-useable spacecraft, and may be able to surpass the US in the near future. Armagno also expressed concerns about China's reckless missile tests, which have created space debris threatening global security interests. The US is taking steps to counter China's growing space capabilities, with the launch of three astronauts to its new space station.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Chinese and U.S. flags flutter outside a company building in Shanghai, China April 14, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: China needs vaccinations more than lockdowns, US officials say
summary: US health officials Ashish Jha and Anthony Fauci stated that China's Covid Zero policy is unlikely to effectively contain the virus without an improved vaccination campaign to broaden immunity. They questioned the effectiveness of the policy, which has led to widespread protests in China. The officials emphasized the need for vaccinations to increase immunity and prevent the spread of the virus. This comes as China grapples with the consequences of its Covid policy, including protests and economic pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: Police officers stand guard during a protest against Covid restrictions in Shanghai, China, on Nov. 27. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: Is there room for F1 races amid Singapore’s broader green ambitions?
summary: Singapore's Formula One night race, known as the Singapore Grand Prix, returned this year amidst growing environmental concerns. The event's carbon footprint, primarily from logistics and transportation, remains significant despite efforts to minimize it through alternative energy sources, reduced waste, and digitalization. Experts say the event has symbolic value for showcasing good practice, but more can be done to reduce its impact. The Singapore Environment Council's Eco Events certification system aims to set standards for environmentally conscious events, and organizers have committed to increasing the use of alternative energy and reducing waste in future events.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

As the events industry returns to an in-person format, organisers must be accountable for their impact on the environment, says Jen Teo, executive director of the Singapore Environment Council. (PHOTO: SEC)
Singapore’s growth is helping it withstand the global slowdown that threatens to push many economies into recession as early as next year.
Overall, hotel room revenues surge to S$390.8 million for the month, surpassing August 2019’s S$383.4 million to mark a new high.

site_title: Yuan, commodity currencies slide as China Covid unrest hits mood
summary: China's Covid unrest has led to a decline in the yuan, with the currency falling 0.5% in early Asia trading, while commodity currencies such as the Australian dollar and South African rand also weakened. The unrest threatens to dash hopes for emerging-market currencies to record their best monthly rally in six years. Investors are shifting towards haven assets like the dollar, yen, and Treasuries, and risk sentiment in global markets has taken a hit. The protests may also weaken demand for stocks, commodities, and currencies tied to trade with China.

site_title: FTX collapse: 5 angles for investors to consider in this crisis
summary: FTX, the world's second-largest cryptocurrency exchange, has filed for bankruptcy protection under the US Chapter 11 regime. The collapse has sent shockwaves across the crypto market, with approximately $1 billion of customer funds unaccounted for. Investors are exploring options, including a US class action lawsuit against former CEO Samuel Bankman-Fried and affiliated parties, international arbitration, and recourse against Bahamian authorities. The mysterious hack that drained $650 million worth of crypto assets from FTX wallets has raised questions about the responsibility of those involved in the transactions.

images.alt_text: “I think most governments now understand that adoption will happen regardless. It’s better to regulate the industry instead of trying to fight against it,” Zhao said, speaking at a Binance event in Athens.
The inquiry will look into Genesis’s connection to such retail investors, and whether it or other industry participants might have violated securities laws, the report added.
Sam Bankman-Fried and the power of dressing badly

FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried speaks at the Crypto Bahamas conference in Nassau on April 27, 2022. FTX's collapse has left an estimated 1 million creditors facing losses totaling billions of dollars.
FTX and Alameda Research, both one time pillars of the crypto market, unravelled with astonishing speed this month.

site_title: WealthBT: How to achieve seamless wealth transfer (Ep 20)
summary: WealthBT podcast episode 20 discusses how to achieve seamless wealth transfer, with guest Angie Han, head of wealth planning at Pictet Wealth Management. The episode highlights the importance of planning and considers key factors such as family offices, trusts, and philanthropy in facilitating a smooth transfer. According to Angie Han, 70% of intergenerational wealth transfers fail due to inadequate planning. The episode emphasizes the need for a comprehensive approach to wealth transfer, including the role of trusts and philanthropy in keeping families engaged.

images.alt_text: Howie Lim
Evelyn Goh, head of Asia Investments from Pictet Wealth management Asia talks to wealth editor Genevieve Cua about how to address the world's needs with your capital
Learn about philanthropic approaches such as venture philanthropy, blended finance and donor-advised funds.
Find out what the investment themes for healthcare are with Genevieve Cua and her guest in this episode brought to you by Pictet Wealth Management.

site_title: CMC Markets seeks further growth in Asia
summary: UK-based stockbroker CMC Markets aims to grow its net operating income by 30% over the next three years through the introduction of new products and geographical expansion, particularly in Asia. The company has already seen a 21% rise in net operating income for the first half of its FY23, driven by increased market volatility and client trading volumes. CMC Markets plans to launch a new investment platform in Singapore, which it believes will capitalize on the country's favorable regulatory environment and proximity to other large South-east Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Younger customers want their online brokers to have a wide array of products, such as foreign-listed exchange-traded funds or unit trusts.

site_title: Reality ends some Qatari dreams of World Cup rental bonanza
summary: Qatar's World Cup has created an unexpected glut of rooms, with online portals showing 42 hotels and Airbnb offering hundreds of options for this weekend. Despite pre-tournament warnings of a shortage, Qatar's landlords have seen rents slump due to the surplus. Some landlords had sought unrealistically high rents, but many have now slashed prices. The World Cup has also had knock-on effects on the wider property market, with long-term rents rising by over 30% in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: UK mortgage rates have risen above 6 per cent in recent months.

site_title: Undervalued tech stocks could be nearing ‘inflection point’
summary: Tech companies' cost-cutting measures, including layoffs, may be nearing an "inflection point" as the industry faces an impending recession. Despite mass layoffs, some tech firms are showing improved performance, such as Grab and Sea, which have raised their take rates to accelerate achieving profitability. Analysts believe that investors will focus on cash balances and capital expenditures, and that some internet and tech stocks offer a "reasonable margin of safety" following recent stock price declines. Mega-cap tech companies are right-sizing their headcounts, but will continue to invest in strategic areas, and valuations have reset due to interest rate expectations and reduced liquidity.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
This is at least the third round of job cuts Shopee has made this year.
Employees packing goods at Goto's e-commerce unit Tokopedia's warehouse in Jakarta.
Offices for Twitter in San Francisco, on Oct. 6, 2022.

site_title: Hyflux criminal charges: Investors won’t be made whole, but may feel sense of justice being done
summary: Hyflux's former CEO Olivia Lum and four independent directors have been charged with alleged disclosure breaches related to the company's Tuaspring Integrated Water and Power Project. The charges, filed by the Commercial Affairs Department, Monetary Authority of Singapore, and Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority, could result in imprisonment of up to seven years and fines of up to S$250,000. The investigation, which began in 2020, came after investors expressed concerns about the project's profitability. The charges are seen as a tougher stance on corporate wrongdoing, but may not make investors whole, as Hyflux went into liquidation with only S$100 million in asset sales.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
In compulsory liquidation, Hyflux has filed pre-emptive lawsuits against former auditor KPMG and founder Olivia Lum.
Besides the criminal charges, Olivia Lum, founder and former chief of water treatment firm Hyflux, is also being sued by the liquidators and the Hyflux group.
If convicted, former Hyflux chief executive Olivia Lum will face imprisonment of up to seven years, a fine not exceeding S$250,000, or both, on each SFA charge

site_title: New SGX initiative recognises sustainable fixed income securities
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched an initiative to help investors identify green, social and sustainability fixed income securities that meet recognized standards. The SGX Sustainable Fixed Income initiative recognizes securities aligned with the International Capital Market Association's Green Bond Principles, Social Bond Principles, and Asean Sustainability Bond Standards. Approximately 200 SGX-listed fixed income securities already meet the criteria and will be onboarded over the next few months. Issuers must publish reports confirming their alignment with recognized standards to continue being recognized under the initiative.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
SGX and MAS launched ESGenome, a disclosure portal for corporates to report their ESG data, on Monday (Sep 12).
BT Explains: The complex world of sustainable debt

site_title: Chuan Park S$890m en bloc sale remains in limbo for now
summary: The en bloc sale of Chuan Park condominium in Singapore remains unresolved after three mediation sessions. The sale, valued at S$890 million, was initially rejected by 10 minority owners due to objections. However, three dissenting owners have since withdrawn their objections. The Strata Titles Board (STB) continues to mediate the matter, leaving the sale's status uncertain for now.

images.alt_text: BT understands that Chuan Park’s buyers have applied to the authorities for the Pre-Application Feasibility Study and Outline Planning Permission (OPP) approvals.

There will be an owners’ meeting on Jul 25, at which information will be shared on the preparation for the next stages and the estimated timeline for the sale completion.

site_title: Canada launches new Indo-Pacific strategy, focus on ‘disruptive’ China
summary: Canada has launched a new Indo-Pacific strategy focusing on countering "disruptive" China, amid frosty bilateral ties. The 26-page document aims to diversify trade and economic ties, boosting military presence, and tightening investment rules to protect intellectual property. Canada will invest in enhanced regional military presence, intelligence, and cybersecurity to mitigate coercive behavior and threats to regional security. The strategy also highlights the need for cooperation on climate change and trade issues with China, despite significant disagreements.

images.alt_text: Xi (far right) confronted Trudeau at the G20 summit, accusing him of leaking details of a private meeting to news media in a candid exchange that was caught on camera

site_title: Transforming trade finance through digitalisation
summary: SCI Ecommerce, a digital commerce solutions provider, transformed its trade finance process by adopting HSBC's digital solution for trade loans. The Trade Working Capital (TWC) facility allows businesses to draw on loans with a payment instruction file, eliminating the need for trade supporting documents. This digitalization has reduced processing time to under a minute and enabled automatic supplier payments, resulting in a 24-hour turnaround compared to 48 hours previously. The facility has enabled SCI to process 50% more payments and improve relationships with brand partners and end-consumers. HSBC plans to roll out the solution in multiple countries, aiming to achieve end-to-end digitalization of trade.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Digitalisation has been the crucial step which has enabled most businesses to continue operating through lockdowns and closed borders

site_title: ‘Gangnam Style’ brought K-pop to the world, but haunted its creator
summary: Psy, the creator of the viral 2012 song "Gangnam Style," has started his own music label and talent management company in South Korea, 10 years after his global success. The song, which became the first YouTube video to surpass one billion views, catapulted K-pop into the global spotlight. Despite his fame, Psy struggled to replicate the formula for success, feeling pressure to produce another hit. He has since made peace with his lack of global fame and is now focused on nurturing the next generation of K-pop talent.

images.alt_text: VIP’s focus on Korean entertainment shares reflects the growing worldwide popularity of the nation’s dramas and musicians, as blockbuster hits help deliver stock price gains to companies involved in their production and distribution.

site_title: US shoppers kick off holiday season with muted Black Friday
summary: US shoppers kicked off the holiday season with a muted Black Friday, with modest traffic at malls and a cautious spending approach due to high inflation rates. Despite deep discounts, retailers saw in-store traffic rise 2.9% and enclosed mall traffic increase 1.2% compared to last year. E-commerce spending on Black Friday rose 2.3% to $9.12 billion. Many consumers, like Miguel Martinez, are cutting back on spending due to higher prices, with some opting for deals online on Cyber Monday. Retailers are struggling to pass on inflationary costs to consumers.

images.alt_text: Many who opened their wallets in the United States said their purchases were strategic, not impulsive or splurges.

site_title: Qatar’s migrant workers enjoy the World Cup on the cheap
summary: Qatar's migrant workers, many of whom earn just over $400 a month, are attending the World Cup for a fraction of the cost of official merchandise. Thousands gather at a hidden corner of Doha to watch matches on large screens, buying counterfeit jerseys for $3 or less, while a cup of tea costs about $1. Rights groups have criticized the treatment of these workers, who have been subjected to abuse, despite increased safety standards and salary protections.

images.alt_text: The Hublot Loves Football pop-up is now on at VivoCity.

Soccer fans pack the Red Lion, a pub discreetly tucked inside a hotel, in Doha, Qatar, on Monday, Nov. 21, 2022. The Red Lion Pub is an oasis for World Cup fans who are hoping to get some beer while in Qatar.  (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)
England's teenage star Jude Bellingham celebrates after scoring the opening goal in his team's 6-2 thrashing of Iran at the World Cup in Qatar on Nov 21, 2022.

site_title: Certis’ Community Give-Back programme highlights mental wellness with art and tech
summary: Certis' Community Give-Back programme, in its fourth edition, aims to raise awareness of mental wellness among disadvantaged children and youth in Singapore. The programme partners with The Business Times Budding Artists Fund to hold three workshops over seven months, using art and technology to highlight mental wellness and sustainability issues. Beneficiaries from arts programmes supported by the fund will work with Certis employees, with a focus on inculcating the spirit of giving back. The programme has previously benefited 300 underserved children and youth since its inception in 2019.

images.alt_text: Over 50 Christmas trees light up the Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade walkways.

site_title: Philippines sees economy slowing, but ‘comparatively strong’ in 2023
summary: The Philippine government expects its economy to slow down in 2023 due to global risks and internal challenges, but it will remain "comparatively strong" with a growth rate of 6.5-8% between 2023 and 2028, according to Economic Planning Secretary Arsenio Balisacan.

site_title: Singapore’s Eco Events certification: how it works to minimise carbon footprints
summary: Singapore's Eco Events certification, launched by the Singapore Environment Council, aims to minimize carbon footprints of events such as conferences and exhibitions. The certification, secured by this year's Formula One race event, requires a reduction in carbon emissions and assesses event organizers' practices in waste management, resource consumption, and environmental sustainability. The certification is voluntary and targets the MICE industry, with a minimum score of 50% required for both pre-event and actual event auditing. The goal is to encourage eco-friendly initiatives and reduce environmental impact, paving the way for other events to follow suit.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
This year's Singapore Grand Prix may inform and aid Singapore in developing better models for less-carbon-intensive affairs in the future.  (PHOTO: AFP)
Overall, hotel room revenues surge to S$390.8 million for the month, surpassing August 2019’s S$383.4 million to mark a new high.
Red Bull Racing's Mexican driver Sergio Perez (left) leads at the start of the Formula One Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on Sunday.

site_title: Hong Kong property slump reaches city’s coveted luxury homes
summary: Hong Kong's luxury property market is experiencing a slowdown, with residential, office, and retail sectors all feeling the impact. Sales and rental prices are falling, and transactions are decreasing. A 1,875 sq ft apartment in Repulse Bay is currently listed for HK$95,000 per month, 17% lower than last year. The top end of the market is not spared, with an apartment listed for HK$30 million after a HK$2 million discount. The city's property slowdown is attributed to a combination of factors, including market saturation and a decline in demand.

images.alt_text: Houses at The V Group’s Twenty Peak Road by V residential project in Hong Kong. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s Cosco Shipping changes course in face of headwinds
summary: China's Cosco Shipping Holdings is shifting its focus from a container shipping company to an investment platform and logistical solutions supplier amid declining industry headwinds. The state-owned giant is investing billions in new dual-fuel container ships, expanding its stakes in major ports, and acquiring new assets to hedge against the next down cycle. Cosco has secured conditional approval for a 24.9% stake in Germany's Port of Hamburg and plans to invest 40.3 billion yuan in port assets and vessels. The move aims to counter rising uncertainties in the shipping industry and capitalize on its strong earnings over the past two years.

images.alt_text: The container ship 'COSCO Pride' of China COSCO Shipping Corporation is unloaded at the Tollerort Container Terminal owned by HHLA, in the harbour of Hamburg, northern Germany on October 26, 2022. - Germany's coalition government on October 26 allowed a Chinese firm to buy a reduced stake in a Hamburg port terminal, after Chancellor Scholz resisted calls to ban the controversial sale outright over security concerns. Under the compromise agreed by Scholz's cabinet, Chinese shipping giant Cosco has the go-ahead to buy a stake "below 25 percent" in the Tollerort container terminal owned by HHLA, the economy ministry said in a statement. China's state-owned Cosco had initially sought a 35-percent stake and the deal would have automatically gone ahead if a compromise solution wasn't found this week. Scholz, a former Hamburg mayor, backed the Cosco deal and has repeatedly stressed the importance of strong trade ties between China and Europe's biggest economy. (Photo by Axel Heimken / AFP)

site_title: China actions spark Canada review of foreign investment rules
summary: Canada's government is revising the Investment Canada Act to add new provisions to protect the country's infrastructure, resources, technology, supply chains, and intellectual property from foreign investments by state-owned enterprises. The move comes after a public lecture by Chinese President Xi Jinping to Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau at the G20 summit, where he accused Trudeau of leaking private meeting details to the media. The revised law aims to address concerns about Chinese state-owned enterprises and will be released on Sunday, November 27.

images.alt_text: “The video you mentioned was indeed a short conversation both leaders held during the G20 summit. This is very normal. I don’t think it should be interpreted as President Xi criticising or accusing anyone,” Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Mao Ning said.
In video footage published by Canadian broadcasters, Xi and Trudeau can be seen standing close to each other and conversing via a translator.

site_title: European Central Bank sees smaller interest rate hikes in 2023 if needed
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expecting smaller interest rate hikes in 2023 if needed, marking a shift from its previous aggressive rate hikes. This comes after the ECB increased rates at its fastest pace on record in July. Markets are betting on a 50-75 basis-point increase at the next meeting on December 15. The ECB's decision aims to control inflation, which has been rising due to high energy costs and supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Saudi Aramco refiner hires banks for US$1 billion share sale
summary: Saudi Aramco's refining unit, Luberef, plans to sell 50 million shares in a US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO) on the Saudi stock exchange. The company, which operates two production facilities in Yanbu and Jeddah, will sell a nearly 30% stake in the business. The IPO is the latest in a record-breaking year for Saudi Arabia, which has seen 27 IPOs. Luberef's shares are expected to be sold to individual investors starting December 14, with the final allocation announced by December 22.

images.alt_text: Saudi Arabia’s Public Investment Fund and Dubai businessman Mohamed Alabbar sold 2.5 billion shares in Americana Restaurants International.

site_title: Ex-Twitter, Meta employees take to TikTok to share their layoff experiences
summary: Former Twitter and Meta employees are taking to TikTok to share their experiences after being laid off, challenging the shame and silence often associated with job loss. The videos, ranging from comic to heartfelt, showcase the emotional aftermath and the process of coping with the experience. Many users are finding support and connection with others in similar situations, while also networking for future opportunities. The platform's community and vulnerability are helping to normalize the discussion around layoffs, with users finding comfort and solidarity in sharing their stories.

images.alt_text: HP, which makes most of its money by selling computers, has been navigating a sustained downturn in PC demand.
(from left) Agung Bezharie, co-founder of Warung Pintar and Brian Marshal, founder of Sirclo. Both startups merged their teams to form a workforce of nearly 2,000 at the start of the year.
Flash Coffee opens over 250 outlets across seven countries in two years after raising millions of dollars from investors.

The recent spate of widespread layoffs by tech behemoths such as Twitter and Meta marks a  drastic shift away from the rapid and aggressive hiring in the tech sector during the pandemic.

site_title: Jokowi tells fans to pick ‘white-haired’ leader to secure legacy
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged his supporters to vote for a "fully white-haired" leader, with Central Java Governor Ganjar Pranowo being the only presidential hopeful with a full head of white hair. Widodo called for a leader who understands the people's plight and wants to connect with them, rather than just sitting in the presidential palace. The move is seen as a show of support for Pranowo, who is currently the only candidate with a full head of white hair among the top contenders for the 2024 elections.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, home to the world’s third-largest rainforest, pledges to be carbon-neutral by 2050, 10 years earlier than previously planned, and to almost double its renewable energy generation by 2030.

site_title: Singapore-based office S-Reits see growth in occupancy and rent reversions
summary: Singapore-based office S-Reits have seen growth in occupancy and rent reversions. Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust's Mapletree Business City reported year-over-year growth in gross revenue and net property income. Office rents in Singapore have reached a near 14-year high, exceeding the pre-pandemic peak, with CBD Grade A office rents recovering in 18 months. Other S-Reits, such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, also reported higher gross revenue and net property income in Q3 2022. This growth is attributed to improved occupancy rates and rental reversions.

images.alt_text: CDL Hospitality Trusts, which owns W Singapore hotel, updated that its net property income for 9M 2022 improved 43.7 per cent to S$82.6 million.

site_title: France's CMA CGM sees profits ebbing as shipping boom fades
summary: French shipping company CMA CGM reported a net profit of $7.0 billion for the third quarter, up from $5.6 billion in the previous year, but down from $7.6 billion in the previous quarter. The company attributes the decline to high energy prices linked to the war in Ukraine and weakening consumer demand, which are dampening the shipping market. CMA CGM expects a pullback in shipping markets to accelerate in the fourth quarter, reducing its profitability. The company has used its earnings to support an investment spree and reduce its debt pile, which fell by $5.3 billion during the quarter.

images.alt_text: One of Cosco Shipping's container ships being unloaded at the Tollerort container terminal in Hamburg, Germany. Cosco has conditional approval to buy a 24.9 per cent stake in the terminal.

site_title: Japan PM Kishida’s approval hits new low after ministers resign
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's public support has reached a new low of 33.1% in a Kyodo news poll, down from 37.6% a month ago. Disapproval has surpassed 50% for the first time, as a series of cabinet resignations and scandals have fueled public anger over the ruling party's ties to a controversial religious group. Kishida's cabinet approval has been sliding since the July assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe revealed deep ties between politicians and the Unification Church, exacerbating government problems.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida answers questions during the House of Representatives budget committee session at the Parliament in Tokyo on November 25, 2022. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

Total fiscal spending in the package will be 39 trillion yen, Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said, but the smaller size of the extra budget suggests part of the spending will come from already available funds.

site_title: KKR nears 2.3b euro deal for CVC’s insurance broker April
summary: KKR is nearing a 2.3 billion euro ($3.29 billion) deal to buy a majority stake in French insurance broker April Group from CVC Capital Partners. The deal would be a rare investment in the European financial services industry for KKR, and marks a significant exit for CVC, which took April private in 2020. April's CEO Eric Maumy expressed his commitment to continuing the company's history and expanding globally with KKR's support. Representatives for CVC and KKR declined to comment on the deal.

images.alt_text: KKR is leading the US$48 million Series C funding round for Privy, an Indonesian digital trust platform.
Private equity firms are facing tumbling valuations, higher borrowing costs and a slowdown in asset sales as recession concerns weigh on the macroeconomic picture.
