In late September, thousands of investors and money managers arrived in Singapore to kick off meetings across the city. Hotels, ballrooms and drinking holes heaved as Asian portfolio companies, fund managers and analysts were finally able to meet in person after two years of  restrictions.

site_title: Breaking hustle culture: Whose responsibility is it?
summary: Singapore's rise-and-grind culture is leading to mental health concerns, with 50% of employees reporting burnout and 41% feeling unable to stop thinking about work. Employers can lead by example by prioritizing employee wellbeing, and employees can utilize resources provided and engage leaders to address concerns. Investing in mental health treatment can lead to a four-fold improvement in health and productivity. Small steps, such as practicing self-compassion and engaging in positive self-talk, can make a big difference in addressing hustle culture and promoting a more proactive and holistic approach to mental health.

images.alt_text: Thrive, BT's initiative to help young adults with money, career and personal development issues, will have a weekly newsletter, Instagram account and dedicated events.
Younger workers embraced the idea of a personal brand as a way to get ahead, and carve out some power and security in their careers. But posting through it has its drawbacks.

According to a Deloitte and Workplace Intelligence survey of 2,100 C-level executives and employees in June 2022, nearly 70 per cent of the C-suite are seriously considering quitting for a job that better supports their well-being.
burnout, burned out, disease

“Intellect’s mission is to normalise mental health and shift the culture towards more open conversations about personal well-being, ultimately removing the stigma attached,” said co-founder and CEO Theodoric Chew.

site_title: Malaysia PM Anwar eyes targeted subsidies for low-income groups
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced plans to review the country's government subsidies program, aiming to direct funds towards low-income groups due to rising costs of living. The program, which costs RM77.7 billion, will be reviewed within two weeks to ensure targeted subsidies. Anwar also plans to cut subsidies for industries no longer benefiting from them and reduce Cabinet size to end "extravagance." His focus on cost of living and targeted subsidies is seen as a positive move by investors, who hope for stability after three prime ministers in as many years.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (C) leaves Putra Mosque after prayers in Putrajaya, on November 25, 2020. (Photo by Arif Kartono / AFP)

site_title: US: Wall Street mixed at open with Black Friday sales in focus
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Black Friday, with the Dow Jones rising 19 points to 34,213.04, while the S&P 500 fell 3.9 points and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 54.3 points. Investors monitored retailers as they began Black Friday sales amid high inflation and recession concerns.

site_title: Airbus may delay some 2023 jet deliveries: sources
summary: Airbus is preparing to delay some 2023 jet deliveries due to supply chain and labor problems, including uncertainty over engine and part availability. The company is taking a twin-speed approach, meeting 2022 delivery targets while preparing for potential delays in 2023. This comes as engine makers face pressure to shift engines from production to spares for existing customers, and jetmakers struggle to get other parts on time. Airbus has no comment on deliveries ahead of its next monthly bulletin in early December.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Airbus is pictured on a flag at the entrance of the Airbus facility in Bouguenais near Nantes, France, November 14, 2022. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
Eva Air normally uses its Airbus A321 single-aisle planes, which carry up to 184 passengers, for flights to smaller Chinese cities.
Over 40 countries including Germany, the UK and New Zealand have asked the United Nations body that sets aviation standards to help make single-pilot flights a safe reality.
Matti Lehmus, Neste's chief executive, says the SAF plant in Singapore is able to support a number of different markets, including the European and American markets.
Asia has been slower than the rest of the world to open up its borders following the pandemic, with China still largely closed to outsiders.

site_title: Shanghai hit by Covid protests as anger spreads across China
summary: Protests against China's strict COVID-19 curbs spread to Shanghai, with hundreds demonstrating against lockdowns and censorship. The protests, which began after a deadly fire in Urumqi, have fueled a wave of civil disobedience across the country. Demonstrators in Shanghai chanted slogans and held up blank sheets of paper, a symbol against censorship. The protests come as China's economy faces mounting pressure due to the zero-Covid policy, with the country's industrial profits dropping further. Authorities have vowed to continue with the policy despite growing public pushback.

images.alt_text: With new Covid-19 cases in China hitting record highs and more cities imposing strict anti-virus measures, consumption is slowing sharply in the world’s second-largest economy.

site_title: Crypto lender Genesis subject of probe by regulators: Barron's
summary: State securities regulators are investigating Genesis Global Capital, a crypto lender, over its connection to retail investors and potential securities law violations. The inquiry, part of a broader investigation into crypto firms, will examine Genesis's ties to companies offering yield-paying products to customers who deposit cryptocurrencies. Genesis backs products from companies like Circle Internet Financial and Gemini, which operate stablecoins and other crypto products. The investigation aims to determine if Genesis or other industry participants may have broken securities laws.

images.alt_text: The Genesis website on a smartphone arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, US, on Thursday, Nov. 17, 2022. Reverberations from the collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried’s empire continue to spread through financial markets, threatening the future of crypto lenders like BlockFi Inc. and Voyager Digital Ltd. Photographer: Gabby Jones/Bloomberg

site_title: Czech pubs tap tech in bid to save energy costs on beer
summary: Czech pubs are using technology to reduce energy costs. Plzensky Prazdroj, a brewery, plans to install sensors to collect data on beer flow and tap temperatures. The data will be analyzed to make recommendations on improving the pub's systems, aiming to save up to 30% of energy needed for cooling and tapping beer. The system, using Internet of Drinks solutions, will track beer consumption, sanitation intervals, and cooling system state. The goal is to help pubs like Katr, where the system is already in use, reduce rising costs and ensure their survival.

images.alt_text: A bartender pours a glass of beer from a tap inside a pub in Prague, Czech Republic, November 24, 2022.  REUTERS/David W Cerny

Soccer fans pack the Red Lion, a pub discreetly tucked inside a hotel, in Doha, Qatar, on Monday, Nov. 21, 2022. The Red Lion Pub is an oasis for World Cup fans who are hoping to get some beer while in Qatar.  (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)

site_title: Treasury market’s big recession trade is gathering momentum
summary: The US bond market is signaling a potential US recession in 2023, with traders betting on lower interest rates despite the Federal Reserve's ongoing rate hikes. Long-dated Treasury yields have fallen below the Fed's overnight benchmark range, and investors are buying bonds, a stance advocated by Pacific Investment Management. The yield curve inversion, a widely watched indicator of potential economic pain, has intensified, with front-end rates holding steady. Investors will closely watch the monthly jobs report and Fed chairman Jerome Powell's words for signs of a potential policy course change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Treasury building is seen in Washington, Sept. 29, 2008. REUTERS/Jim Bourg/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Woman holds U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The Federal Reserve has embarked on an aggressive path to cool demand and bring down prices as inflation in the US surged to the highest level in decades.

site_title: Hangzhou vows video game funding as China crackdown eases: SCMP
summary: Hangzhou, a Chinese hub for tech startups, has pledged 100 million yuan (S$19.2 million) in annual funding for video gaming and esports, amid indications that a government crackdown on those industries has eased. The funding program is part of preparations for the country's hosting of the Asian Games. The Hangzhou government aims to create a "positive atmosphere of public opinion" during the event, while the gaming industry association claims the video-game addiction problem among minors is "basically solved".

site_title: Black Friday crowds thin despite deals
summary: US shoppers flocked to stores for Black Friday deals, but crowds were thinner than expected, with many opting for strategic purchases over impulsive shopping. Despite the slower crowds, retailers offered deep discounts, including up to 60% off on apparel and 50% off on electronics. Online shopping also saw a significant increase, with US shoppers spending 3% more on Thanksgiving Day this year. The National Retail Federation estimates 166.3 million people will shop from Thanksgiving to Cyber Monday, a modest increase from last year.

images.alt_text: A general view of a sign highlighting discounted items as Black Friday sales begin at The Outlet Shoppes of the Bluegrass in Simpsonville, Kentucky, U.S., November 26, 2021. REUTERS/Jon Cherry
A buildup of inventory has forced companies into widespread markdowns – a move that hurts profits but appears to be drawing in discount-hunting consumers.
Tension with workers has been a long-running issue at Amazon, which has faced complaints of unfair labour practices as well as employee activism and union drives at some facilities.

site_title: A great rotation is brewing in Asia as investors head north
summary: Investors are flocking to North Asian equities, with key gauges in Hong Kong rallying 20% in November, outperforming the rest of Asia and global peers. China's targeted Covid restrictions and policy support for real estate have driven the surge, while Taiwan and Korea also saw significant foreign investments. Strategists predict a potential bull run as China's gradual reopening and the chip industry's bottoming out intensify, with Asia's equity leadership expected to shift to China and South Korea next year.

images.alt_text: Berkshire Hathaway first bought stakes in Japan’s trading houses — also known as “sogo shosha” — in August 2020.

Driving the confidence among sell-side analysts are the surprise policy shifts in recent weeks, from easing rigid Covid controls to stronger remedies for real estate woes and efforts to improve ties with the US.

The Global Dividend Index report - published on Wednesday (Nov 16) - found that dividends in the region (comprising Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan) grew 14.6 per cent on-year to US$91.7 billion in Q3 2022..
Elon Musk expressed willingness to actively invest in EV charging infrastructure in South Korea.
The logo of Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) is pictured at the entrance to its branch in Beijing, China April 1, 2019. REUTERS/Florence Lo
A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song
China’s mega state-owned banks are offering at least 270 billion yuan (S$51.9 billion) in new credit to property developers as part of the nation’s push to ease turmoil in the real estate market.

site_title: Amazon settlement with EU antitrust regulators possible by year end: sources
summary: Amazon may settle EU antitrust investigations by the end of the year, avoiding a potential fine of up to 10% of its global turnover. The company agreed to tweak concessions addressing concerns over using sellers' data, including refraining from using it for competing retail and private label products. Amazon also increased the range of data it cannot use and promised equal treatment of sellers when ranking their offers for the "buy box" on its website. The European Commission has sought feedback from rivals and customers, leading to a possible EU decision by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: France’s SUD and CGT unions called for strike action in the country’s eight warehouses.
Tension with workers has been a long-running issue at Amazon, which has faced complaints of unfair labour practices as well as employee activism and union drives at some facilities.
Amazon.com said in a statement that it had made the decision to discontinue Amazon Academy “in a phased manner to take care of current customers”.
Amazon will release a smaller number of films in theatres next year and increase its output over time.

site_title: Neymar to miss Brazil's next World Cup match with ankle injury
summary: Brazilian star Neymar will miss the team's next World Cup match due to an ankle injury sustained in the opening game against Serbia. Neymar suffered ligament damage and underwent an examination, with doctor Rodrigo Lasmar confirming he will sit out the match against Switzerland. This is the second injury concern for Brazil, as right-back Danilo also misses the match with an ankle strain. Despite the setback, coach Tite remains optimistic about Neymar's chances of playing in the World Cup, citing the attacker's determination to help his country.

images.alt_text:
FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football - World Cup - Asian Qualifiers - Group A - United Arab Emirates v South Korea - Al-Maktoum Stadium, Dubai, United Arab Emirates - March 29, 2022
 South Korea's Min-Jae Kim in action with United Arab Emirates' Harib Abdalla Suhail
 REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo
A signage of Qatar 2022 on display in Doha, Qatar, where the Fifa World Cup will be staged from Nov 20 to Dec 18.

As the football world prepares to head to Qatar in 6 months' time, this World Cup is set to bookend the era in which Lionel Messi (left) and Cristiano Ronaldo have been the sport's 2 pre-eminent players.
Neymar 'very keen' on playing in MLS

site_title: US: Stocks end short trading session on mixed note
summary: US stocks ended a shortened trading session on a mixed note, with the Dow Jones up 0.5% and the S&P 500 flat, while the Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.5%. Investors kept an eye on retailers ahead of the Black Friday shopping season, despite lower trading volume. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks are expected to be watched closely, with concerns about recession risk and inflation. Individual companies, including Apple, were affected by concerns over production and supply chain issues, particularly in China.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo Traders work during the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on March 19, 2020, at Wall Street in New York City. - Wall Street stocks rose early April 8, 2020 as markets weighed the latest figures on the coronavirus against the prospects for additional measures to prop up the economy.About five minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average stood at 22,903.26, up 1.1 percent.The broad-based S&P 500 gained 1.0 percent to 2,686.75, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.2 percent to 7,983.68. (Photo by Johannes EISELE / AFP)

site_title: News Corp shareholder T Rowe Price raises concerns about merger with Fox: NYT
summary: T. Rowe Price, the largest shareholder of News Corp after the Murdoch family, expressed strong reservations about Rupert Murdoch's plan to merge News Corp and Fox Corp, citing concerns that the merger would undervalue News Corp. The move comes after other major shareholders, including Independent Franchise Partners and Irenic Capital, also opposed the plan. T. Rowe Price's concerns were made public in an attempt to help shape the process before a firm proposal is made.

images.alt_text: Franchise Partners told Rupert Murdoch’s special committee of News Corp’s board last month that a combination on its own would fail to realise the full value of the company.

site_title: Is homeownership slipping even further out of reach for New Yorkers?
summary: Homeownership in New York City appears to be slipping further out of reach for residents, particularly those with limited incomes. A city-run program, HomeFirst, aims to provide up to $100,000 in loans to first-time buyers, but approval rates remain low. Despite this, Jennifer Kopp, a Brooklyn resident, was recently approved for the program, bringing her goal of owning a home closer. The program's requirements, including loan forgiveness if the recipient keeps the home as a primary residence, may help increase access to homeownership for eligible New Yorkers.

images.alt_text: Broker Hamptons International has warned that home prices are likely to decline if the Bank of England’s base rate exceeds 2.5 per cent. It’s already at 2.25 per cent, and expected to rise to at least 3 per cent early next month

site_title: Binance CEO Zhao says don't fight crypto, regulate it
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao stated that regulation is a better option for governments than fighting against the crypto sector, as digital currencies continue to gain mainstream adoption. Following the collapse of FTX and other platforms, Zhao believes the industry will recover and that countries will start adding cryptocurrencies to their reserves, particularly smaller ones. He expects regulation to help stabilize the market and prevent future crashes. Zhao also expressed confidence in the industry's growth, citing lessons from traditional finance.

images.alt_text: Zhao has announced plans for an industry recovery fund to help strong projects facing a liquidity squeeze.
MAS said it placed Binance on its alert list after the exchange was found to be in potential breach of the Payment Services Act.
Voyager said in a tweet on Wednesday that the company’s proposed sale would not move forward and that it is in active discussions with several alternate bidders.

Changpeng Zhao, who was speaking at the Abu Dhabi Finance Week, noted that FTX’s fallout has shaken confidence in the industry, and industry players would need to be more transparent to rebuild that confidence.

site_title: China’s industrial profits drop further as Covid-19 woes take toll on economy
summary: China's industrial profits declined 3% in the first 10 months of 2022 due to Covid-19 outbreaks and strict anti-virus measures, with 22 of 41 major industrial sectors experiencing a decline. Profits for manufacturers fell 13.4% in the first 10 months, with the petroleum, coal, and fuel processing industry seeing a 70.9% drop. The data reflects a debt payment crisis in the property sector and a slowdown in consumer spending, with some analysts predicting China's GDP could contract in the current quarter.

images.alt_text: Brent and WTI’s market structure implies current demand is softening.
Earlier this month, China had published rules, listed approved products and named companies that can participate in the scheme.
Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: For Argentina and Germany, the ignominy of an early World Cup exit beckons
summary: Argentina and Germany face early World Cup exits after shock defeats. Argentina lost 2-1 to Saudi Arabia, with Lionel Messi scoring the first goal, while Germany was beaten 2-1 by Japan. Both teams must bounce back with wins in their next matches to avoid elimination. Argentina faces Mexico on Sunday, while Germany plays Spain on Monday, with a loss likely to seal their fate.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Spain's Dani Olmo scores the first goal against Costa Rica, Nov 24, 2022.

Germany looked in total command but, with each missed chance, left the door open for Japan, who showed almost nothing in attack until a series of substitutions injected some energy in the second half.
Doha, the capital of Qatar, which won its bid to host the 2022 Fifa World Cup 12 years ago. Criticism of the choice of host raises questions over how Western nations should deal with such regimes.

Soccer fans pack the Red Lion, a pub discreetly tucked inside a hotel, in Doha, Qatar, on Monday, Nov. 21, 2022. The Red Lion Pub is an oasis for World Cup fans who are hoping to get some beer while in Qatar.  (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)

site_title: Oil prices fall 2% as Chinese demand worries linger
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Friday as worries about Chinese demand and a Western price cap on Russian oil persisted. Brent crude futures closed at $83.63 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures at $76.28 a barrel. The decline marks the third consecutive weekly drop, with both contracts reaching 10-month lows. Chinese Covid-19 cases have led to a decrease in fuel demand, and diplomats continue to discuss a Russian oil price cap, which has yet to be agreed upon.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on February 23, 2014 a section of the BP ETAP (Eastern Trough Area Project) oil platform is pictured in the North Sea, around 100 miles east of Aberdeen, Scotland. - BP said on November 1, 2022, that underlying third-quarter profit more than doubled on high commodity prices after Russia's assault on Ukraine, adding it would take a major hit from Britain's windfall tax. Replacement cost profit, excluding fluctuations in the value of crude oil inventories, soared to $8.2 billion in the three months to September, London-listed BP revealed in a statement. (Photo by Andy BUCHANAN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Foxconn unrest risks iPhone shipments, weighs on Apple shares
summary: Foxconn's flagship iPhone factory in China is facing worker unrest and strict COVID-19 restrictions, disrupting production ahead of Christmas and the Chinese New Year holiday. The unrest has led to thousands of employees quitting and more than 20,000 workers leaving the plant, with estimates suggesting up to 30% of November production could be affected. This may result in a 12% lower iPhone shipment in the last quarter of 2022, according to analysts. Apple shares have fallen 1.9% following the news, with concerns over the company's ability to deliver products for the busy holiday period.

images.alt_text: The Foxconn situation serves up another reminder of the dangers for Apple of relying on a vast production machine centred on China at a time of unpredictable policy and uncertain trade relations.
The Foxconn situation serves up another reminder of the dangers for Apple of relying on a vast production machine centred on China at a time of unpredictable policy and uncertain trade relations.
A neighborhood placed under lockdown due to Covid-19 in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
Foxconn says workers had complained about pay and conditions at the plant, but denied it had housed new recruits with Covid-positive staff at its Zhengzhou factory.
The Foxconn situation serves up another reminder of the dangers for Apple of relying on a vast production machine centred on China at a time of unpredictable policy and uncertain trade relations.
Foxconn said in a statement that Chiang Shang-yi had been appointed its semiconductor strategy officer, a newly created role.
An unidentified high-ranking staffer at the plant, said Foxconn had received more than 100,000 job applications so far and was ending its latest hiring drive.

site_title: US FDA declines to approve Spectrum Pharmaceuticals’ lung cancer drug
summary: The US FDA has declined to approve Spectrum Pharmaceuticals' experimental lung cancer drug, poziotinib, citing the need for an additional study. This decision aligns with an advisory panel's recommendation to not approve the drug. As a result, the company plans to de-prioritize the development of poziotinib and significantly reduce its research and development workforce by 75%.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 logs sixth straight week of gains
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed flat on Friday, marking its sixth consecutive week of gains, as hopes of slowing interest rate hikes offset a real estate sector sell-off. The index has rallied over 15% since hitting a trough in late September, outperforming the S&P 500's 13% climb from its October lows. Despite a decline in retail stocks and real estate, investors are optimistic about the outlook, citing potential easing of interest rates and better-than-expected corporate earnings.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.5 per cent to its strongest level since Aug 18, although trading volumes were light due to a US market holiday for Thanksgiving.

site_title: BMW raises investment in Hungary EV factory to over 2 billion euros
summary: BMW has raised its investment in an electric vehicle factory in Hungary to over $2.9 billion, with a focus on building a high-voltage battery assembly plant. The additional investment will create 500 million euros in production capacity and 500 new jobs. The Hungarian government will provide a non-refundable subsidy of $33.92 million for the increased investment. BMW aims to produce 150,000 cars per year at the Debrecen factory, set to open in 2025.

site_title: US bans Huawei, ZTE equipment sales citing national security risk
summary: The US has banned the sale and import of telecommunications equipment from Chinese companies Huawei, ZTE, Dahua Technology, Hikvision Digital Technology, and Hytera Communications Corp, citing national security risks. The FCC's decision, made with bipartisan support, aims to protect the American people from potential spying by these companies. The ban applies to new equipment sales and is part of the Biden administration's ongoing crackdown on Chinese tech giants.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Letterings that form the name of Chinese smartphone and telecoms equipment maker Huawei are seen during Huawei Connect in Shanghai, China, Sept. 23, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: A turning point for Malaysia
summary: Anwar Ibrahim's ascension to Malaysia's premiership marks a moment of multiracial opportunity, representing a vision of liberal and practicable multiracialism. He acknowledges racism as a systemic problem, emerging from politics of race and institutionalized in governance. This bold stance is unusual for Malay leaders, who often shy away from discussing racism. Anwar's premiership could signal a shift towards greater diversity and inclusivity in Malaysian politics, but its long-term impact remains to be seen.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's newly-minted prime minister welcomes other parties including his rival Perikatan Nasional to join the unity government.

site_title: Macau's 6 casino operators get new licences, Malaysia's Genting out
summary: Macau's government announced that six incumbent casino operators - Sands China, Wynn Macau, Galaxy Entertainment, MGM China, Melco Resorts, and SJM Holdings - will receive new licences to operate in the world's biggest gambling hub starting January. Genting Malaysia, considered a strong competitor, was excluded from the new licence due to its non-gaming track record and mass market appeal, which Beijing aims to diversify away from gambling. The operators have invested over $50 billion in Macau over the past 20 years and will continue to operate under their current concessions.

images.alt_text: Genting has casinos globally including in Malaysia, Singapore, the US and the UK. It does not currently operate in Macau.
The plunge in tourism has rippled through other sectors, such as suppliers of slot machines, baccarat table systems and other casino equipment.
Macau’s new casino licences are expected to begin in 2023 and are crucial for the 6 incumbents to keep operating their multi-billion US dollar properties.

The main casino floor during a media preview of Resorts World Las Vegas in Las Vegas, Nevada, U.S., on Tuesday, June 22, 2021. Malaysia's Genting Group developed the 3,500-room hotel with 117,000 square feet of gambling space, 250,000 square feet of meeting space, a 5,000-seat theater, and seven swimming pools overlooking the north end of the Strip. Photographer: Roger Kisby/Bloomberg
Macau for the first time imposed a formal table cap and minimum income requirements for the new operators, set to begin their contracts at the start of 2023.

site_title: EDBI’s long-time chief leaving to start own fund
summary: EDBI's CEO, Chu Swee Yeok, is leaving after nearly 14 years to start her own fund focused on later-stage technology and healthcare investments. Chu, who oversaw investments in companies like Moderna and ByteDance, aims to raise up to $200 million for her new vehicle. EDBI managing partner Paul Ng is tipped to be her successor, while managing partner Basil Lui may join her new firm.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Andy Hwang spent 10 years at Meta and has personally invested in over 60 startups, special-purpose vehicles, and funds.
ImmunoScape’s proprietary “Deep Immunomics” platform enables the discovery and characterisation of rare T-cells specific to certain cancers at high resolution.

site_title: Southern Alliance Mining managing director adds to stake at 41 cents per share
summary: Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks from Nov 18 to 24, with S$56 million of net outflows. The Straits Times Index declined 1.0%, while the Hang Seng Index fell 1.9%. Meanwhile, share buybacks occurred in 24 primary-listed stocks with a total consideration of S$10.1 million. Notable transactions include Southern Alliance Mining's managing director Pek Kok Sam acquiring 1,616,400 shares at 41 cents per share, increasing his stake to 63.55%. Other transactions include Chemical Industries (Far East) director Lim Soo Peng acquiring 665,000 shares at 75 cents per share, and Accrelist executive chairman Terence Tea Yeok Kian acquiring 210,400 shares at 4.7 cents per share.

images.alt_text: Office workers walking past the SGX logo outside the SGX Centre 1 located along Shenton Way on 17 January 2020.

site_title: Global wildlife summit to vote on shark protections
summary: A global wildlife summit in Panama is set to vote on a proposal to protect sharks, which could drastically reduce the shark fin trade. The proposal, co-sponsored by the European Union and 15 countries, would control the trade of dozens of shark species, including requiem and hammerhead sharks, under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES). The move is seen as a major step forward in protecting these vulnerable species and combating the cruel shark fin trade. A decision is expected on Friday.

site_title: Zara shopworkers strike in company’s hometown
summary: Approximately 1,000 Zara shop assistants in Spain, mostly women, went on strike in the company's hometown of A Coruña, demanding better salaries and a bigger pay rise after rejecting Inditex's latest offer. The strike, which started on Black Friday, aims to increase monthly wages to around 2,000 euros, similar to those of warehouse workers. The proposal was rejected by regional union CIG, which is pushing for a bigger pay rise after the company's latest offer of a one-off bonus and a 200-euro hike in monthly salaries.

images.alt_text: Customers walk in front of a closed  Zara store in Moscow, Russia, Oct 19, 2022. Inditex said it had reached an “initial agreement” to sell its business in Russia to Daher group, which has business interests in retail and real estate.
With online operations in about 200 countries, Zara’s products are already among the most resold brands on the web.

site_title: Hosts Qatar on verge of elimination after 3-1 loss to Senegal
summary: Qatar suffered a 3-1 loss to Senegal in the World Cup, putting them on the verge of elimination. A win or draw for Netherlands against Ecuador later on Friday will mathematically eliminate Qatar. The loss marked Qatar's first-ever World Cup finals goal for Mohammed Muntari. The result leaves Qatar's tournament fate uncertain, with the team's World Cup run hanging by a thread.

site_title: Why Africa is primed for impact investing
summary: Africa is poised for impact investing due to its rapid growth, abundant natural resources, and vast potential for sustainable agriculture and digital commerce. The continent has the world's most rapidly expanding workforce, with over 60% of the population under 25, and forecasters predict strong growth in technology and infrastructure. Investing in Africa can drive both strong returns and positive global change, making it an attractive opportunity for investors looking to make a difference.

images.alt_text: Africa holds around 13 per cent of the world’s natural gas and 7 per cent of its oil, but has the lowest per capita energy use globally.

site_title: Amazon workers demonstrate at some German, French sites on Black Friday
summary: Amazon workers demonstrated at some German and French sites on Black Friday, part of a global call for better pay. In Germany, nine out of 20 warehouses were affected, with the Verdi union demanding collective bargaining agreements and good working conditions. In France, the SUD and CGT unions called for strike action in eight warehouses, seeking higher cash bonuses and overtime pay. The strikes were part of the Make Amazon Pay initiative, which targeted the company on one of its busiest shopping days.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial bags liquidity pool scheme for investments outside China
summary: Yangzijiang Financial, a Chinese company, has secured a liquidity pool scheme from the People's Bank of China, allowing it to grant inter-company transfers of up to 10 billion yuan (S$1.9 billion). This will enable the group to efficiently deploy capital outside of China, diversifying half of its portfolio and maximizing cash management returns through forex and interest rate differentials. The scheme also facilitates the consolidation and centralization of cash management, allowing the group to use its domestic and foreign funds in a tax-efficient manner.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

Vincent Toe, CEO of Yangzijiang Financial, said: "With the fund focused on investing in promising small and medium businesses in the region, there is a plethora of growth opportunities that we can target.”

Yangzijiang’s chief executive officer and chief investment officer, Vincent Toe, believes her appointment would serve to  strengthen the company’s market position, given her “close relationships with leading fund managers”.

site_title: Bank of Japan governor gets just 0.4% pay rise despite urging higher wages
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda will receive a 0.4% pay rise in 2022, despite urging higher wages to sustainably meet the bank's inflation target. The small increase, consisting of executive allowances, reflects the challenge of driving up wages in a country accustomed to decades of low inflation. This decision underscores the difficulty in justifying pay raises in Japan, where grinding deflation has made it hard to raise salaries.

images.alt_text: BOJ could decide in 2026 whether to issue a digital currency after verifying issues for two years, such as whether there are problems with deposits and withdrawals from bank accounts.
Core consumer inflation in Tokyo remained above the Bank of Japan’s 2 per cent target for six straight months in November.

site_title: Greta Thunberg, 600 youths sue Sweden for climate inaction
summary: More than 600 Swedish youths, including climate activist Greta Thunberg, have filed a lawsuit against the Swedish state, accusing it of climate inaction. The lawsuit, filed in the Stockholm district court, claims the government is not doing enough to address the climate crisis. The legal action comes as Sweden's new right-wing government faces criticism over lackluster climate goals. The plaintiffs hope to secure a verdict that requires the Swedish state to meet global measures needed to meet the 1.5-degree-Celsius target, with a potential win seen as a significant step in holding governments accountable for climate action.

images.alt_text: Circular fashion is apparel that is designed, sourced and produced with the intention of being used and circulated responsibly and effectively in society for as long as possible.

Some borrowers have balked at Australia’s role as a major producer of fossil fuels and other commodities: Sweden’s central bank dumped the bonds of Western Australia and Queensland states over the issue.

site_title: Resist Black Friday’s siren song
summary: To avoid financial regret during the holiday season, households can resist Black Friday's promotional sales and retail therapy by seeing through marketers' gimmicks, such as bonus discounts and urgency. By enlisting family and friends to limit gift arms races, making fewer online purchases, and waiting for big-ticket items to be discounted in January, individuals can maintain a solid balance sheet and avoid overspending. Creating mutual accountability and setting spending limits can also help individuals resist impulse buys and enjoy the holiday season without financial regret.

images.alt_text: A buildup of inventory has forced companies into widespread markdowns – a move that hurts profits but appears to be drawing in discount-hunting consumers.

site_title: Netherlands in talks with US on China chip policy: Dutch trade minister
summary: The Netherlands is in talks with the US government over new export restrictions for semiconductor equipment to China. Dutch Trade Minister Liesje Schreinemacher stated that the Netherlands shares concerns over China's security and is weighing its national security interests. The US has announced unilateral measures, which could affect ASML Holdings, the Netherlands' largest semiconductor equipment maker, with significant sales to China. The Dutch government has not commented on what would be acceptable, but is considering its own interests amid concerns over China's security.

site_title: First Reit completes early financing for 50.6% of debt after trustee enters facility agreement
summary: First Reit has completed early financing for 50.6% of its debt, securing a S$300 million facility with OCBC and CIMB Singapore. The proceeds will be used to refinance existing debt and finance social assets, with the proportion of debt tied to social impact rising to 76.7%. The Reit's gearing ratio remains stable at around 35.6%, and its weighted average debt to maturity improves to 3.64 years.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

Hikari Heights Varus Fujino, a nursing home in Japan under First Reit's portfolio. The manager of First Reit targets to increase its portfolio in developed markets to comprise more than 50 per cent of assets under management (AUM)  by 2027.
First Reit's acquisition of the Japan nursing homes will be fully funded by debt.

site_title: Dollar hovers near three-month low amid hopes Fed will slow hikes
summary: The US dollar hovered near a three-month low amid expectations that the Federal Reserve may slow interest rate hikes as soon as December. The dollar index edged up 0.2% on Friday, but on track for a weekly loss. The euro was set for weekly gains after a survey showed German consumer sentiment is expected to stabilize next month. Sterling was near a three-month high against the US currency, while the Japanese yen slipped due to rising core consumer prices. The offshore Chinese yuan fell 0.25% to a two-week low.

images.alt_text: The eagerly awaited minutes of the Federal Reserve's November meeting  showed that officials were largely satisfied they could now move in smaller steps, with a 50-basis-point rate rise likely next month, after four consecutive 75 basis point increases.

site_title: South Korean capital launches self-driving bus experiment
summary: South Korea's capital, Seoul, launched its first self-driving bus route on November 25, 2022. The bus, designed by 42dot, a Hyundai-owned start-up, uses cameras and lasers to navigate a 3.4-kilometer circuit with a safety driver on board. The bus has rounded edges and large windows, aiming to make people feel more comfortable with driverless vehicles. The experiment aims to make the technology low-cost, safe, and easily transferable to various vehicles, including delivery trucks.

site_title: Three pillars behind building a solid tech startup
summary: A tech startup's success relies on three critical components in its early stages: team, product, and capital. According to industry expert Aadi Vaidya, a solid foundation is key to a business's long-term success. The team should occupy 70-80% of a founder's mind-space, with a focus on building and training the right team of hustling generalists. A well-thought-out product strategy is also essential for long-term success, as it brings resilience to the business. Finally, capital is an enabler, not a goal, and should be used to support the business, not dictate it.

images.alt_text: Credit, rather than equity, is helping tech companies keep their operations going while avoiding a damaging “down round”, investors and tech startup heads said at the Web Summit conference in Lisbon this week.

site_title: Louis Vuitton picks Shanghai for first furniture and homewares store
summary: Louis Vuitton has announced plans to open its first furniture and homewares store in Shanghai, a world first for the French luxury brand. The showroom, located in a century-old mansion, will be trialed as a pop-up for several months before potentially becoming permanent. The store features designs by the Campana brothers and Frank Chou, a mainland Chinese designer, and offers items priced upwards of $134,000 and $10,500. The move aims to tap into the growing demand for lifestyle offerings among affluent Chinese consumers, with luxury spending pressured by economic uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Factory output in Singapore grew 1.9% year on year in October, excluding the biomedical cluster. However, the country's overall factory output contracted 0.8% year on year in October. This marks a reversal from the previous month's gains of 1.6%. The data from the Economic Development Board (EDB) suggests a decline in the country's manufacturing sector.

site_title: Banks oppose cutting interest on cash at BOE
summary: Banks in the UK are opposing a proposal by two former Bank of England officials to reduce interest paid on deposits held by commercial lenders at the BOE. The move aims to fill a hole in public finances, but banks warn it could hinder efforts to tackle inflation. The BOE currently pays interest on £850 billion of deposits at a rate of 3%, and tiering the rate could see a portion of those reserves remunerated at a lower level.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England indicated it wanted to sell the long-dated state bonds purchased during the market turbulence caused by the last UK government’s mini budget.

site_title: Morgan Stanley becomes substantial shareholder of Vertex Tech
summary: Morgan Stanley has become a substantial shareholder of Vertex Technology Acquisition Corp (VTAC) after acquiring an additional 603,363 shares, increasing its stake to about 6% of the company. The firm now holds approximately 2.5 million VTAC shares, up from 1.9 million prior to the transaction. This acquisition, attributed to an "aggregation of global position," may grant Morgan Stanley the right to "rehypothecate or dispose of" the shares, pending further review.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Relentless Iran do their talking on the pitch in defeat of Wales
summary: Iran's World Cup campaign got back on track with a 2-0 win over Wales, giving them a chance of reaching the knockout stage. Despite being thrashed 6-2 by England in their Group B opener, Iran showed impressive character and unity, punished a sloppy Welsh side, and earned their first point. The victory came after Wales was reduced to 10 men late in the second half, with goalkeeper Wayne Hennessey receiving a red card for a high knee on Iran's Mehdi Taremi.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Group B - Wales v Iran - Ahmad Bin Ali Stadium, Al Rayyan, Qatar - November 25, 2022
Iran players celebrate with Iran coach Carlos Queiroz after the match REUTERS/Amanda Perobelli

site_title: Cost-of-living crisis looms over Europe’s Black Friday
summary: Europe's retailers are bracing for a potentially worst Christmas trading season in at least a decade due to a worsening cost-of-living crisis and double-digit inflation. Despite this, consumers are expected to spend £8.7 billion over the Black Friday weekend, with many shopping early and prioritizing essential items. The event has become more online, with shoppers focusing on spontaneous deals and Christmas gifts rather than delayed purchases.

images.alt_text: In October German inflation climbed to 10.4 per cent, its highest in about seven decades.
Tension with workers has been a long-running issue at Amazon, which has faced complaints of unfair labour practices as well as employee activism and union drives at some facilities.

site_title: Credit Suisse hits new low as investors weigh outflow damage
summary: Credit Suisse shares plummeted 5% in Zurich, reaching a fresh record low, amid massive outflows of $89 billion in its core wealth management business. The bank reported that clients are not reversing outflows, and rivals UBS and Morgan Stanley are benefiting from the exodus, particularly in the Asian growth market. Analysts predict Credit Suisse will post another loss next year due to elevated funding costs, with its shares now trading at 3.39 francs. The bank's woes are seen as a result of its inability to halt outflows in its core wealth management business.

images.alt_text: A sign of Switzerland's Credit Suisse bank is seen on an office building in Zurich on November 8, 2022. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)

site_title: Japan proposes expanding tax-free investment scheme for savers
summary: Japan's government proposes expanding its tax-free investment scheme, NISA, to encourage households to invest more in riskier assets. The plan aims to double the number of accounts to 34 million and the amount of investment to 56 trillion yen over the next five years. The current scheme limits annual investments to 1.2 million yen, but the proposed changes would raise the upper limit and make the program permanent. The goal is to boost average household wealth and asset holdings, which have risen only 40% over the last 20 years, compared to 3.4 times in the US and 2.3 times in Britain.

site_title: Thai Beverage FY22 profit up 22.2% to 30.1 billion baht, 0.45 baht final dividend proposed
summary: Thai Beverage reported a 22.2% increase in FY22 profit to 30.1 billion baht, driven by a 13.2% year-over-year rise in sales revenue to 272.4 billion baht. The company's beer business saw a 23.5% increase in revenue to 122.5 billion baht, while its spirits business reported a 1% increase in sales revenue. Despite higher raw material and packaging costs, the group's gross profit rose 28.8% to 28.1 billion baht. Thai Beverage has proposed a final dividend of 0.45 baht per share, higher than last year's 0.35 baht.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

An aerial view of the Johor Strait. A study by the NUS Business School’s Centre for Governance and Sustainability scoped out the top 50 listcos by market capitalisation across 13 Asia-Pacific jurisdictions, and found that the overall nature disclosure rate is 31.4 per cent.
Analysts think Thai Bev's performance could get a lift from tourism revival and strong domestic demand in Thailand, as well as robust GDP growth in Vietnam driving up alcohol consumption.
The tussle revolves around an opposition-led proposal to liberalise the production and sale of liquor and beer, which is tightly regulated in Thailand.
Bottles of Chang beer move along the production line at Thai Beverage's Beer Thip brewery in Bang Ban, Ayutthaya province in Thailand.

site_title: Thai Airways names new CEO amid restructuring plan
summary: Thai Airways has appointed Chai Eamsiri as its new CEO, effective February 1, as part of its pandemic-driven restructuring plan. Chai, a 37-year veteran in the Thai aviation industry, was chosen from 53 internal and external candidates. The company's restructuring aims to restructure debt worth 400 billion baht. The appointment is seen as a crucial step to rebuild trust among creditors, passengers, and business partners, following the airline's bankruptcy-protected restructuring last year.

site_title: China rolls out private pension scheme in 36 cities
summary: China has launched a private pension scheme in 36 cities, marking the official start of the third pillar of its pension system. The scheme allows domestic workers to contribute up to 12,000 yuan per year to their individual accounts, with tax benefits, and invest in qualified products. This move aims to supplement the existing two pillars and address China's rapidly ageing population. The scheme is expected to grow to US$1.7 trillion by 2025, with domestic and international insurers promoting products and Chinese banks offering incentives to attract investors.

images.alt_text: People walk along a pedestrian street surrounded by shops and shopping malls in Shanghai on October 24, 2022. (Photo by Hector RETAMAL / AFP)

site_title: Deutsche Bank warns of peril in borrowing from US banks
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing warns European companies of the "danger" of relying on US banks for borrowing, citing the threat of being dropped when times get tough. This comes as the corporate banking unit of Germany's largest lender sees a resurgence in restructuring. US banks reject the criticism, with representatives stating they have committed to long-term relationships with European clients and operate on an equal footing with other banks. Deutsche Bank's CEO calls for a "concerted approach" by politicians and regulators to support European banks.

images.alt_text: Amit Khattar sees China as an important market that will continue “to be core to the bank and provide opportunities”.

site_title: Rising interest in private assets reflects ‘structural shift’: Fidelity International CEO
summary: Fidelity International CEO Anne Richards says a "structural shift" is occurring in the asset management industry, with more private assets being held in private hands rather than listed on stock exchanges. To adapt, Fidelity is exploring opportunities in real estate and private credit markets, and is re-evaluating its product offerings to meet changing investor tastes. The company is also grappling with a shift towards passive exchange-traded funds (ETFs) over active funds, but does not intend to become a "massive provider" of passive ETFs. Richards remains optimistic about the long-term growth of savings, despite current market challenges.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Twitter to launch blue check subscription next week, says Musk
summary: Elon Musk announced Twitter will launch its blue check subscription feature, dubbed "blue check," next week, with different color checks for companies, governments, and individuals. The feature was initially paused due to fake accounts but will be relaunched with manual authentication of verified accounts. The blue check mark was previously reserved for public figures and will cost $8 per month.

site_title: STI down 0.3%, regional markets hit by China Covid fears
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,244.55, mirroring regional declines due to rising Covid-19 cases in China casting a shadow over its reopening. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index, Tokyo's Nikkei 225, and South Korea's Kospi also declined. However, some investors remain optimistic about China's economic recovery, with SPI Asset Management's Stephen Innes predicting a "long and winding road to normalcy".

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Regional sentiment was being sapped by ongoing fears about the spike in Covid cases in China.

site_title: Flagship Adani firm to raise 200 billion rupees via new share sale
summary: Adani Enterprises, the flagship firm of the Adani Group, plans to raise 200 billion Indian rupees (S$3.4 billion) through a new share sale, increasing its public float to 27.4% from 27.4%. The company, led by Gautam Adani, aims to fund new initiatives, acquisitions, and projects, with a focus on energy transition. This comes amid concerns over elevated debt levels and large promoter shareholding. The share offering will be filed by December 31 and raised before March 31, subject to market conditions.

site_title: UK factory gate inflation higher than thought after ONS finds error
summary: The UK's Office for National Statistics (ONS) revised producer price inflation (PPI) figures for the year, increasing the annual headline output PPI to 19.5% from 19.2% previously, due to an error in diesel fuel allocation. The error resulted in factory gate inflation being higher than initially thought. The ONS also revised its October input PPI reading to 19.5% from 19.2%. The agency has implemented additional system checks to prevent future errors and apologized for any inconvenience caused.

site_title: Voluntary conditional cash offer for Chip Eng Seng turns mandatory
summary: Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang's voluntary conditional cash offer for the property player has turned mandatory after she and her husband, Gordon Tang, purchased 6.3 million shares, bringing their total shareholding to about 42.3%. This triggered the Singapore Exchange's rule on mandatory general offers. The offer remains unchanged, with the Tangs aiming to acquire all issued shares at S$0.72 apiece to privatise and delist the company, with the goal of reaching 90% ownership.

images.alt_text: The surge in trading volume comes a day after chairman Celine Tang and her husband made an offer to acquire all issued ordinary shares at S$0.72 apiece.
Celine Tang and Gordon Tang also recently privatised SingHaiyi Group at a significant discount to its net asset value.
Celine Tang, who is also group managing director of property player SingHaiyi and non-executive chairman at OKH Global, became Chip Eng Seng’s chairman in 2018 after becoming its largest shareholder.
Chip Eng Seng unit to acquire minority interest in Shenton Way property for S$2.1m
Chip Eng Seng unit to acquire minority interest in a Shenton Way property for S$2.1m
Chip Eng Seng in JV to provide hospitality management services

site_title: Oil sinks for third week as EU strives for price-cap compromise
summary: Oil prices fell for a third week as the European Union weighed a higher price cap on Russian crude, amid concerns about demand. Brent traded below $86 a barrel, on track for a 2% drop this week. The EU's price cap plan, part of its response to the Ukraine invasion, is expected to have a negative effect on the energy market, with Russian President Vladimir Putin warning of the consequences. The global economy is also facing recessionary fears, with the Institute of International Finance forecasting a weak economy next year.

images.alt_text: Global oil markets have weakened in November, with a host of widely-watched metrics flashing warning signs and dragging futures prices lower.

site_title: Germany’s economy was stronger than expected in third quarter
summary: Germany's economy grew 0.4% in the third quarter, beating initial expectations of 0.3% despite energy costs and uncertainty from Russia's war in Ukraine. Strong consumer spending, with a 1% increase in household consumption, drove the growth. The economy is expected to face challenges, but the risk of natural gas shortages has receded due to warm weather and full storage facilities. The government is preparing measures to subsidize gas and electricity to mitigate the impact of high inflation.

site_title: The best 50-year-old investing advice money can buy
summary: Wealth & Investing expert Peter Coy revisits economist Burton Malkiel's 1973 book "A Random Walk Down Wall Street," which advocated for investing in broad-based index funds. The idea was met with skepticism at the time but has since become conventional wisdom. Malkiel argued that trying to beat the market is futile due to its ability to incorporate new information instantly, making index funds a more efficient and cost-effective option. With nearly 50 years of experience supporting this theory, investing in index funds has become a widely accepted strategy for individual investors.

images.alt_text: dart board, game, target

site_title: ICBC leads China’s mega banks to offer US$179b to builders
summary: China's mega banks, led by Industrial & Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), pledged US$179 billion in credit lines to property developers to ease the nation's real estate market turmoil. ICBC will provide 655 billion yuan (S$125.6 billion) in credit lines to 12 developers, while other banks, including Bank of China, Bank of Communications, and China Construction Bank, also extended financing. The move aims to support the stronger firms that have survived the crisis and ensure unfinished homes get completed.

images.alt_text: The logo of Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) is pictured at the entrance to its branch in Beijing, China April 1, 2019. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: US retailers prepare for a muted Black Friday
summary: US retailers prepare for a muted Black Friday due to high inflation and sagging consumer sentiment, resulting in a 1.2% decline in seasonal sales. Despite this, companies' earnings reports show shoppers are willing to spend when prices are right. This indicates a balance between discount-hunting consumers and companies' desire to maintain profits through widespread markdowns.

images.alt_text: Tension with workers has been a long-running issue at Amazon, which has faced complaints of unfair labour practices as well as employee activism and union drives at some facilities.

site_title: Australia court blocks giant coal mine on human rights grounds
summary: An Australian court has blocked the Galilee Coal Project, citing human rights concerns related to climate change. The 1.6 billion tonnes of carbon dioxide emissions over its lifespan would more than triple Australia's annual domestic emissions and impact future generations. The ruling emphasizes that the project's contribution to climate change is a significant threat, surpassing the Paris Agreement's long-term temperature goal. This is another blow to Australia's coal export industry, following recent accusations of data falsification.

images.alt_text: Shares of Rio Tinto, BHP Group and Fortescue Metals advanced between 2.1 per cent and 3.1 per cent.
Gear has rationalised its break-up and privatisation with an ESG narrative

site_title: Anwar says his first priority is cost of living
summary: Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has stated that addressing the country's rising cost of living is his top priority as he takes office. Anwar, 75, was sworn in on Thursday, following an inconclusive election, with a focus on a slowing economy and a deeply divided nation. He plans to form a smaller Cabinet than previous administrations.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's newly-minted prime minister welcomes other parties including his rival Perikatan Nasional to join the unity government.

site_title: Tesla’s Pepsi Semis lose out to Coke’s electric Renault Trucks
summary: Tesla's electric Pepsi Semis, initially promised in 2017, have lost to Renault's electric trucks used by Coca-Cola in Belgium. Renault's E-tech D and E-Tech D Wide trucks can travel 200km a day, while Tesla's Semis have an estimated range of 500 miles. PepsiCo has reserved 100 Semis but plans to deploy only 15 by the end of the year, while Coca-Cola will start using Renault trucks for local trips in Belgium. Renault's trucks are part of Coca-Cola's efforts to cut carbon emissions.

site_title: Hong Kong demand for long-term UK visas plunges in latest quarter
summary: Demand for UK long-term visas in Hong Kong has plummeted 44% in the latest quarter, with 10,100 applications submitted between July and September. This decline coincides with mounting concerns about UK inflation and follows the introduction of the British National (Overseas) passport in response to China's national security law in 2020. The UK has received 150,600 visa applications, with 98% approval rates, but is still short of its estimated 320,000 applications in the first five years.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians cross a street in Hong Kong on October 31, 2021. (Photo by Bertha WANG / AFP)

site_title: China’s central bank cuts reserve ratio to help bolster economy
summary: China's central bank cut the reserve ratio for most banks by 25 basis points, injecting US$70 billion of liquidity into the economy, effective December 5. This is the second reserve ratio cut this year to support the economy, which is facing a property downturn and surging Covid cases. The move aims to maintain reasonably ample liquidity and solidify the economic recovery, following significant government actions to aid the economy.

images.alt_text: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang

site_title: Singapore’s factory output shrinks 0.8% in October, with further contraction expected
summary: Singapore's factory output contracted 0.8% year-on-year in October, reversing from a 1.6% gain in the previous month. Excluding the biomedical cluster, factory output grew 1.9%, but economists expect further decline, citing global headwinds and China's economic downturn. Economists warn of a gloomy start to Singapore's economic prognosis in Q4 2022, with manufacturing slowdown likely to persist into 2023.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Singapore's trade growth is expected to be flat or slightly negative in 2023.
The Purchasing Managers’ Index dipped a further 0.2 point to post a second straight month of contraction at 49.7 in October, the lowest reading since June 2020.
Manufacturing expectations still pessimistic, services sector less upbeat: surveys

site_title: Deutsche Bank hunts for more Asia deals as rivals turn cautious
summary: Deutsche Bank is seeking to expand its deals business in Asia despite rivals' caution amid a slowdown in China. Head of investment banking for Asia-Pacific, Amit Khattar, expects advisory and financing businesses to drive growth in the region for the next few years. Key markets include India, Thailand, and Singapore, while China's slump in equity and debt offerings is expected to return in the second quarter of next year. Khattar sees China as an important market for the bank, despite its relatively smaller presence compared to rivals.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 19, 2020 Britain's Prince Andrew, Duke of York, arrives to attend a church service at St Mary the Virgin Church in Hillington, Norfolk, eastern England. - Britain's Prince Andrew was sued in a New York court on August 9, 2021 for alleged sexual abuse of a woman who says she was "lent out" for underage sex by late US financier Jeffrey Epstein. (Photo by Lindsey Parnaby / AFP)
From a regional hub in Singapore, the bank covers countries such as Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines where de Sanctis sees “very, very attractive” business opportunities.

site_title: Tesla recalls thousands of cars in China on software, seat belts
summary: Tesla is recalling 81,000 electric cars in China due to a software issue and seat belt problems. The recall affects 70,434 imported Model S, Model X, and Model 3 vehicles, as well as 10,127 China-made Model 3 cars. The software issue may lead to a loss of power, while the faulty seat belt fixture poses a safety risk. This is the latest in a series of recalls for Tesla in China, which has been struggling to boost sales and meet its ambitious production targets.

images.alt_text: Coca-Cola Europacific Partners said it’s getting Renault E-tech D and E-Tech D Wide trucks that can travel around 200 kilometres a day.
Chief executive officer Elon Musk tweeted that the system Tesla calls Full Self-Driving Beta is now available to anyone in North America who’s bought the option and requests it from their car screen.

site_title: BT Market Focus: A week of market optimism (Ep 22)
summary: Market optimism drove sentiment this week, according to BT Market Focus. The podcast discusses the key factors behind the enthusiasm, including insights from SGX's wrap and the newsdesk. Notable macroeconomic and market news, such as hopes for dovish Fed, also contributed to the optimistic tone. The episode concludes with a focus on company news and invites listeners to sign up for the latest news and analyses.

images.alt_text: How have markets reacted this week to central banks' interest rate hikes?
How good a week did Singapore markets have?
With the Fed still hawish, how will markets react?

site_title: The curious case of the 0.1 per cent service charge
summary: A Singaporean coffeeshop chain imposed a 0.1% service charge on dine-in customers, sparking debate about its reasonableness. The move was later reversed after customer backlash. However, an exception in GST regulations allows hotels and F&B outlets to display GST-exclusive prices with a service charge, as long as customers are informed of the GST and service charge. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (IRAS) clarified that this exception would not apply to arrangements without genuine business reasons, citing the need for price transparency for consumer protection.

images.alt_text: About 40 per cent of the 100,000 or so GST-registered businesses will be dealing with a rate change for the first time.

site_title: Kitchen Culture requisitioning shareholders claim successful EGM; board denies validity
summary: A group of Kitchen Culture shareholders, led by Ooway Group, successfully held an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) and approved the appointment of five new directors, representing about 40% of the company's shares. The existing board denies the validity of the EGM, stating that none of the new directors submitted consent to nomination as required by the company's constitution. The requisitioning shareholders claim the new directors will focus on turning the company around and creating shareholder value through increased transparency.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

In the bourse filing, Kitchen Culture said the redesignation is due to “the need for the chairman of the board to lead the company forward in the challenging business climate and shareholders’ issues faced by the company”

site_title: China plans to build nuclear-powered Moon base within six years
summary: China plans to build a nuclear-powered Moon base within six years, with the first astronauts expected to arrive in 2028. The base, powered by nuclear energy, will be constructed by the Chang'e 6, 7, and 8 missions. This move is part of China's ambitious space exploration program, aiming to challenge NASA's dominance. The base will be located at the Moon's South Pole, an area believed to have water, and could eventually expand into an international research station.

site_title: China central bank to offer cheap loans to support developers’ bonds
summary: China's central bank will offer cheap loans to financial firms for buying bonds issued by heavily indebted property developers, boosting market sentiment and rescuing private developers. The loans, through the People's Bank of China's relending facility, are expected to be at a lower interest rate than the benchmark rate. The move follows recent support from China's biggest banks, which pledged at least $162 billion in credit to developers. The PBOC also plans to provide 100 billion yuan in M&A financing facilities to state-owned asset managers.

site_title: Hyundai Motor and SK On to build 2.5 trillion won joint venture battery plant in US
summary: Hyundai Motor and SK On, a South Korean energy group, plan to invest 2.5 trillion won (S$2.6 billion) in a joint venture battery factory in the US. The plant, expected to start production in 2026, will have an initial annual capacity of 20 gigawatt hours, enough to power 300,000 electric vehicles. The factory, likely to be located in Georgia, near Hyundai's new EV plant, aims to support the growing demand for electric vehicles.

site_title: Ringgit up for second day running after Anwar’s PM appointment
summary: Malaysia's ringgit rose 0.9% against the dollar, its strongest level since mid-August, following the appointment of Anwar Ibrahim as the country's new prime minister. The currency had surged 1.8% on Thursday, its largest single-day gain since March 2016. The stock benchmark index declined 1.3% on profit-taking after adding close to $19 billion in value in a single day. Analysts expect the unity government model to pose political risk premium to Malaysian equities, and investors will watch the announcement of the Cabinet line-up and revised Budget.

site_title: JPMorgan sees US$1t demand boost for global bonds in 2023
summary: JPMorgan predicts a $1 trillion boost in global bond demand in 2023, driven by a $1.6 trillion reduction in global bond supply and a $700 billion decline in demand. This improvement is expected to lower yields, with a predicted 40 basis point reduction in the Bloomberg Global Aggregate bond index yield. The forecast is based on central banks' quantitative tightening and commercial banks' trimming of holdings, as well as increased demand from foreign reserve managers, pension funds, and retail investors.

images.alt_text: HDB flats on Henderson Road. HDB is a quasi-government entity with government support. Its bonds offer a yield pick-up over T-bills.

site_title: Collateralised fund obligations: How private equity securitised itself
summary: Private equity firms have created "collateralised fund obligations" (CFOs), a financial security marketed to ordinary savers as a safe investment with a stellar credit rating. These vehicles bundle stakes in hundreds of private equity-owned companies, including Envision Healthcare, which has a low junk-grade credit rating and is at risk of bankruptcy. CFOs introduce new layers of leverage into the private capital industry and have flown largely under the radar, with little public disclosure of their contents. The rise of CFOs is an illustration of how post-crisis regulation has shifted the use of esoteric structures and risky leverage into a quieter, more lightly regulated corner of the financial world.

images.alt_text: Blackstone set up Breit as a semi-liquid product.
Temasek is now preparing to write off the entire amount, one of the people said, asking not to be identified as the matter is private.

site_title: End-times tourism in the land of glaciers
summary: Alaska's Glacier Bay National Park is experiencing end-times tourism as climate change accelerates the melting of its glaciers. Since 1950, the park's average air temperature has warmed 2.75°C, and the region has suffered the largest net ice loss of any of the planet's 50 World Heritage sites with glaciers. Cruise ships, which once carried hundreds of thousands of tourists, now have limited capacity due to environmental concerns. Visitors are witnessing the effects of climate change firsthand, but many are also in denial or seeking solutions that may not be feasible.

images.alt_text: Retreating glacier, at Diavolezza ski area near the Alpine resort of Pontresina, Switzerland July 21, 2022.  REUTERS
A study of 18,600 glaciers at 50 World Heritage sites – covering around 66,000 sq km– found that glaciers at a third of the sites were “condemned to disappear”.

site_title: Camsing Healthcare’s revival plan at risk as potential investor faces disputes with partners
summary: Camsing Healthcare, a mainboard-listed company, is facing a dispute over a proposed investment by Lin Qiren, who owns Qiren Holdings. Lin loaned up to $1.3 million to Camsing and also agreed to invest $4.3 million, but various individuals claim that the money did not come from Lin alone. Two individuals, Jeremy Toh and Jason Ng, claim they had an arrangement with Lin for Qiren Organisation to be a partnership, and six others who contributed to the investment are seeking investigations into the funds' utilization.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Camsing Healthcare to receive S$11.3m investment to boost Nature's Farm business

site_title: Stocks to watch: Chip Eng Seng, Kimly, Marco Polo Marine, Keppel Corp, Golden Agri
summary: Singaporean companies Chip Eng Seng, Kimly, Marco Polo Marine, Keppel Corp, and Golden Agri-Resources saw developments that may affect trading. Chip Eng Seng's chairman, Celine Tang, tabled a voluntary conditional cash offer to acquire all shares at S$0.72 each, aiming to privatize the company. Kimly reported a 13.4% drop in net profit to S$34 million for FY2022. Marco Polo Marine increased its net profit by 19% to S$10.5 million for the second half of the fiscal year. Keppel Corp's offshore arm received a US$160 million payment for delivering a jackup rig. Golden Agri-Resources saw Kopernik Global Investors LLC cease to be its substantial shareholder.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures of SGX

site_title: Crypto 3.0 will be more human: Causes for optimism in tumultuous times
summary: Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin revealed technologies to manage online identities, preserve privacy, and ensure the responsible use of AI at a recent Insead event. This marks the beginning of Crypto 3.0, a new stage in the evolution of cryptocurrency, which will focus on user-friendliness and addressing privacy concerns. Technologies such as the Ethereum Name Service and zero-knowledge proofs (zk-SNARKs) will play a major role in this phase, enabling users to control their identities and prove the validity of data without revealing sensitive information. This shift could lead to the creation of a more decentralized social network and social media.

images.alt_text: Developers have spent years working on a more energy-efficient version of the ethereum blockchain.

After dumping its holdings of FTX’s native coin and triggering an exodus of users from the rival bourse, Changpeng Zhao's Binance, the world’s biggest cryptocurrency exchange, is acquiring FTX in a rescue deal.

site_title: Mainland Chinese firms outnumber US ones in HK for first time
summary: Mainland Chinese firms have surpassed US companies with regional headquarters in Hong Kong for the first time in at least 31 years, according to data from the Census and Statistics Department. As of June 1, 251 mainland Chinese firms had regional hubs in the city, down one from the previous year, while 240 US companies had regional headquarters, down 14 from the previous year. Strict COVID-19 curbs, a national security campaign, and the struggling economy have led to a decline in Hong Kong's appeal as an international finance center, with businesses shifting resources to other centers.

site_title: Singapore services receipts up 14.5% in Q3 2022
summary: Singapore's services industries saw a 14.5% year-on-year increase in Q3 2022, with the recreation and personal services industry experiencing the largest yearly rise of 70.4%. The gaming and attractions segment contributed significantly to this growth. Non-seasonally-adjusted business receipts also rose 3% in Q3, extending the previous quarter's 5.1% increase. Analysts predict that growth in the services sector will moderate in the coming quarters as reopening tailwinds fade.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Visitors around the entrance of the casino at the Resorts World Sentosa on 21 February 2020.

site_title: China's tightening Covid-19 curbs fuel pushback
summary: China reported a historic high of 32,695 new local Covid-19 infections on Thursday, prompting widespread lockdowns and pushback from residents and business groups. The French Chamber of Commerce in China called for authorities to implement "optimisation" measures, including shortened quarantines, to ease restrictions. However, the measures have been met with frustration and confusion, particularly in big cities like Beijing. Some residents are proposing alternative approaches, such as quarantine at home for mild cases, and reports of public dissatisfaction are gaining momentum. The government is expected to respond swiftly to stem social unrest.

images.alt_text: People line up to get tested for the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) at a nucleic acid testing site at a residential area, following the COVID-19 outbreak, in Shanghai, China, September 25, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Sam Bankman-Fried and the power of dressing badly
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried, founder of FTX, was once ridiculed for wearing rumpled clothes, but the article suggests that dressing badly can be a power play if it aligns with one's message and story. Former President Donald Trump's oversized suits and John Fetterman's ill-fitting Senate suit are examples of how bad dressing can be used to project a certain image. However, former UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson's lack of respect for his audience and Representative Barney Frank's genuine slob-like demeanor were unsuccessful attempts at power dressing. The article concludes that bad dressing can be effective if it's done with conviction and respect for the audience.

images.alt_text: Most of FTX’s purchases were luxury beachfront homes, including seven condominiums in an expensive resort community called Albany, costing almost US$72 million.
FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried speaks at the Crypto Bahamas conference in Nassau on April 27, 2022. FTX's collapse has left an estimated 1 million creditors facing losses totaling billions of dollars.

site_title: China’s Meituan beats revenue estimates, swings to profit
summary: China's Meituan, a food delivery giant, reported a 28.2% revenue growth in the third quarter and swung back to profit after recovering from COVID-19 curbs. The company's total revenue rose to 62.62 billion yuan (S$12 billion) and sales from new initiatives grew 39.7% year-over-year. Revenue from core local commerce and non-food delivery services rose 24.6%. Meituan's Hong Kong-listed shares have lost nearly half their value in the last 12 months, but the company sees the city as a testing ground for its global plans.

images.alt_text: A man wears virtual reality (VR) goggles at the Meituan booth during the 2021 China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 4, 2021. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: Hot stock: Chip Eng Seng requests trading halt amid heavy volumes in early trade
summary: Chip Eng Seng requested a trading halt amid heavy volumes of over 15 million shares changing hands, a day after chairman Celine Tang and her husband made a cash offer to privatize the company at S$0.72 apiece. The offer is conditional on acquiring over 90% of shares. Despite the surge, shares dipped 1.4% to S$0.715.

site_title: Malaysia’s inflation rate eases to 4% in October, above economists’ forecast
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 4% in October, above economists' forecast of 3.9%. The drop in daily average RON97 petrol prices helped reduce transport inflation, while the consumer price index (CPI) increased 0.2% from September to October.
