This marks a slight increase from the 3.3% inflation rate for the first 10 months of 2022, which was 0.3% lower than the same period last year.

images.alt_text: The drop in daily average RON 97 petrol prices has helped to reduce the transport inflation in October.

site_title: Global oil market flashes warning signs on rising demand angst
summary: Global oil markets have weakened in November, with metrics flashing warning signs of rising demand angst. Asian oil demand has slumped to a seven-month low due to lockdown-like restrictions in China, triggered by surging virus cases. The Oman futures-Dubai swaps gauge has plummeted 80% this month, and Brent futures have declined to their cheapest price since January. Expectations for a recovery in Chinese oil demand are fading, with some Chinese refiners cutting demand for Russian oil ahead of a potential Group of Seven oil cap.

images.alt_text: The single biggest driver for the global economy next year will be China, where loosening Covid restrictions are likely.
A higher price cap could make it attractive for Russia to continue to sell its oil, reducing the risk of a supply shortage in global oil markets.

site_title: More than 20,000 new hires have left Apple supplier Foxconn’s Zhengzhou plant in China: Foxconn source
summary: More than 20,000 new hires at Foxconn's Zhengzhou plant in China have left the facility amid worker unrest, following a pay-related "technical error" and severe Covid-19 restrictions. The departures, which include most new hires not yet working on the production line, were sparked by protests involving clashes with security personnel. The move complicates Foxconn's target to resume full production by the end of November.

site_title: Tanjong Katong, Clementi housing sites, Bt Panjang EC plot up for sale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has launched three residential sites for sale under the Government Land Sales (GLS) Programme. The largest site, Jalan Tembusu, spans 20,572.1 sq m and could yield about 825 units, while the Clementi Avenue 1 site is expected to yield about 500 units. The third site, Senja Close, is an executive condominium (EC) site that could yield an estimated 300 units. Bidders are expected to submit offers in the second half of 2022, with top bids ranging from S$1,000 to S$1,400 psf ppr for each site.

images.alt_text: Leonard Tay, head of research at Knight Frank, points to the popularity of Copen Grand as evidence that “homebuyers are hungry for new products”.

According to poll findings by the National University of Singapore Real Estate, majority of real estate senior executives expect the benchmark of S$2,000 per square feet for private homes in the OCR to persist over the next one to two years.
The Bukit Timah Link land parcel is on a site area of 4,611.1 sq m and comes with a maximum GFA of 13,834 sq m.

site_title: Robo-advisers want to be more than a one-trick pony
summary: Singapore's robo-advisers, Stashaway, Endowus, and Syfe, are expanding their offerings to cater to growing demand for passive investing and sophisticated financial products. The platforms have crossed the $1 billion assets under management (AUM) threshold and are now targeting new markets, including the US, Hong Kong, and Australia. To achieve growth, they are investing in education, personalized financial products, and partnerships with fund managers. Robo-advisers are positioning themselves as a more human and personalized alternative to traditional financial institutions, which are digitizing their offerings. Despite competition, the market still has space for robo-advisers to grow, with about $965.5 billion in deposit accounts in Singapore's banks.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Endowus' Gregory Van (left) and Samuel Rhee. The firm expands into ultra-wealthy client segment with purchase of HK-based multi-family office, Carret Private.
Digital banks such as Trust Bank could be partners rather than competitors to some fintechs.

site_title: Bank of Korea needs strong signs inflation curbed before pivot
summary: The Bank of Korea (BOK) needs to see strong signs of inflation control before discussing a pivot away from policy tightening, according to Governor Rhee Chang-yong. The BOK raised its benchmark interest rate to 3.25% and is considering peaking at 3.5% or less. Strong evidence of inflation slowing to the 2% mid-term target is required before easing policy, and rate cuts are premature. The BOK has delivered 2.75 percentage points of rate hikes since August 2021 to combat asset bubbles and inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: The won has climbed almost 8 per cent against the US dollar this quarter, the biggest jump among major Asian currencies.
The BOK has delivered two half-point hikes this year as it sought to keep pace with the Federal Reserve’s rapid rate rises and stem pressure on Korea’s currency.

site_title: China’s daily Covid tally tops 30,000 for first time as curbs spread
summary: China reported 31,987 new COVID-19 infections on November 24, surpassing 30,000 for the first time, with cases in major cities like Guangzhou and Chongqing reaching record highs. The capital, Beijing, experienced over 1,800 cases, prompting lockdown-like restrictions and panic buying. The high caseloads weigh on equity markets, and Chinese authorities struggle to balance targeted measures with containing outbreaks, with some cities imposing mass testing orders and lockdowns.

images.alt_text: A major cause of the financial squeeze is the property crisis.

site_title: Ford recalls 634,000 vehicles worldwide over fire risks
summary: Ford is recalling 634,000 SUVs worldwide due to a potential fire risk from cracked fuel injectors. The affected vehicles, including 2020-2023 model year Bronco Sport and Escape SUVs with 3 cylinder, 1.5 liter engines, may experience fuel accumulation near hot surfaces, leading to fires under the hood. Owners are urged to have their cars inspected, and dealers will update software to detect cracked fuel injectors and provide a dashboard message. Repairs include installing a tube draining fuel from the cylinder head and checking for excessive fuel odour.

site_title: Americana’s landmark Saudi-UAE IPO draws US$105b in orders
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund and Dubai businessman Mohamed Alabbar sold 2.5 billion shares in Americana Restaurants International, drawing $105 billion in orders for the company's $1.8 billion IPO. The IPO priced at the top end of the range, valuing the business at $6 billion, and marks the first dual-listing in Riyadh and Abu Dhabi. This successful deal is expected to set a precedent for other firms, following a trend of Gulf IPOs raising $19 billion this year.

images.alt_text: Jars of Nescafe Gold coffee by Nestle in a supermarket at the Nestle headquarters in Vevey, Switzerland. The company plans to make infant products and ready-to-drink coffee at its plant in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Stellantis looks to India for affordable EVs for Europe
summary: Stellantis, the parent company of Fiat, Peugeot, and Chrysler, plans to shift its electric vehicle (EV) manufacturing to India due to the inability to produce affordable EVs in Europe. CEO Carlos Tavares stated that India's low-cost supplier base can meet quality and cost targets, allowing for the export of EVs to other markets. Stellantis aims to ramp up production slowly and profitably, with plans to launch its first EV in India early next year, an electric model of the Citroen C3 compact car.

images.alt_text: While the semiconductor crunch was easing, other supply chain issues were looming on Stellantis’ operations, especially around logistics in Europe.
Stellantis terminated the venture with GAC in July, only months after it said it would raise its stake in the business to 75 per cent from 50 per cent.

site_title: UK restricts Chinese cameras in government buildings over security fears
summary: The UK government has instructed departments to stop installing Chinese-linked surveillance cameras at sensitive buildings due to security risks. The decision follows a review of potential security threats associated with the cameras, which are made by companies subject to Chinese security laws. The cameras, made by Hikvision and Dahua, will be disconnected from core computer networks and may be removed altogether. This move comes after lawmakers called for a ban on the sale and use of these cameras due to privacy concerns and potential links to human rights abuses in China.

images.alt_text: London’s Metropolitan Police Service said on Thursday (Nov 24) it had shut down fraud website iSpoof and made more than 100 UK arrests in connection with the case.

site_title: Vietnam’s VinFast ships first electric vehicles to US customers
summary: Vietnam's VinFast has shipped its first batch of 999 electric vehicles to the US, marking a five-year effort to develop an auto production hub in North Carolina for markets in North America and Europe. The first cars, primarily VF 8 electric SUVs, are expected to be handed over to customers by the end of December, with some going to a US car subscription service and the majority to retail buyers.

site_title: Asia’s richest man makes a US$5b bet to silence debt-obsessed critics
summary: Asia's richest person, Gautam Adani, is raising at least $5 billion in equity to address high debt ratios and a limited investor base. The conglomerate, which has seen 2,000% gains in four years, aims to improve debt ratios, broaden its investor base, and trigger wider analyst coverage. Adani is courting global sovereign and pension funds, and the total fundraising size could be as high as $10 billion. A successful outcome would help Adani regain legitimacy and shed the perception that his rise is fueled by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's support.

images.alt_text: Using multiple instruments including foreign currency debt and green bonds, Gautam Adani's Group plans to raise up to US$6 billion to swap its existing high-interest debt with lower-cost borrowings and deploy the rest for project financing,
Adani Wilmar, the kitchen essentials firm owned by Gautam Adani, has earmarked 5 billion rupees (S$88.4 million) from its initial public offering for purchases.

site_title: Bundesbank warns of considerable risks to financial system
summary: The Bundesbank has issued a warning about considerable risks to Germany's financial system, citing deteriorating growth prospects, high inflation, and rising interest rates. The report notes that banks, insurers, and investment funds have recorded losses and that future credit risks are increasing due to rising costs limiting households' and enterprises' financial leeway. The institution advises financial institutions to assess adverse scenarios, engage in prudent risk provisioning, and exercise caution when distributing profits. The European Central Bank has also issued similar warnings, highlighting the potential impact on corporate profits and fiscal stimulus.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank chief economist Philip Lane at an event in New York in September. He says the plan is to continue with steep interest rate rises in the next few months.

site_title: Thailand’s cannabis industry clouded as legal threats emerge
summary: Thailand's cannabis industry is facing uncertainty after months of rapid growth following the country's decriminalization of cannabis. Businesses operate in a grey area due to a regulatory vacuum, with lawmakers expected to resume debate on a draft bill aimed at giving the government more control over the industry. The bill, which includes restrictions on recreational use and advertising, has been met with opposition from some academics and medical doctors who call for cannabis to be designated as a narcotic again. The industry's future is threatened by growing societal concerns and the threat of a clampdown on drugs and guns, which could undo the progress made since decriminalization.

images.alt_text: Some 5 billion baht of 10-year bonds will give a coupon of 2.9 per cent, Patricia Mongkhonvanit, head of the ministry’s public debt management office said.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang makes S$0.72 per share cash offer to privatise company
summary: Singapore-based property player Chip Eng Seng's chairman Celine Tang has made a S$0.72 per share cash offer to privatise the company, with the goal of delisting from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) if the offer exceeds 90% of shares. The offer represents a 36.9% premium over the volume weighted average price (VWAP) for the past 12 months and a 27.3% discount to the company's net asset value. The offeror, Tang Dynasty Treasure, is owned by the Tang couple, who also recently privatised SingHaiyi Group.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The consideration is below the book value of the property of S$38 million, and the company is expected to record a loss on disposal of around S$3 million, OKH said in the bourse filing.
Celine Tang, who is also group managing director of property player SingHaiyi and non-executive chairman at OKH Global, became Chip Eng Seng’s chairman in 2018 after becoming its largest shareholder.
Net profit for the first 6 months of 2022 climbed to S$38.5 million from S$99,000 in H1 2021, the company reported in a bourse filing on Friday (Aug 5).

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday’s open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% in early trade on Friday, with the Straits Times Index declining 7.28 points to 3,245.6. Chip Eng Seng's shares fell 0.7% after its chairman made an offer to privatize the company, while Marco Polo Marine rose 2.3% after posting a 19% increase in net profit. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also traded lower, with DBS down 0.5%, OCBC 0.3%, and UOB 0.4%. European shares rallied on Thursday, driven by gains in real estate stocks following the Federal Reserve's November meeting.

images.alt_text: Chip Eng Seng chairman Celine Tang and her husband have tabled a voluntary conditional cash offer to acquire all issued ordinary shares in the property player.

site_title: High mortgage rates push UK first-time buyers towards rental market: Rightmove
summary: UK first-time buyers are increasingly turning to the rental market due to rising mortgage rates above 6% in recent months. According to Rightmove, rental home enquiries jumped 23% in October compared to the same time last year. First-time buyers, in particular, are being deterred from purchasing, with 42% already saving their deposits and 43% in the process. The surge in mortgage rates has led to a 1% decrease in the number of people looking to rent or buy, with many opting for short-term rentals while waiting for financial certainty.

images.alt_text: A majority of British public bodies use surveillance cameras made by Hikvision or Dahua, privacy advocacy group Big Brother Watch said in July.

site_title: Manulife eliminates 50 jobs as it outsources property management
summary: Manulife is eliminating 50 jobs in the US and Canada as part of a plan to outsource property operations to Jones Lang LaSalle. Most workers will retain similar positions with the new partner. The move is part of Manulife's focus on investing and increasing its overall headcount. The company owns 63 million square feet of real estate in 29 cities worldwide through its asset-management arm.

site_title: Credit Suisse offers 889m shares to existing investors in 4b Swiss franc capital hike
summary: Credit Suisse has offered 889 million new shares to existing investors at 2.52 Swiss francs per share, raising approximately 2.24 billion Swiss francs to fund its turnaround plan. The capital increase is part of a four billion franc hike, with the bank seeking to recover from its 166-year history's biggest crisis. The shares will be listed on the Six Swiss Exchange on Dec 9, and the bank's nominal share capital has already risen 17% following the share placement portion of the capital hike.

images.alt_text: The loss of client money marks a major setback for Credit Suisse as its executives seek to put the lender back on course with a sweeping overhaul that places a greater focus on private banking.
Credit Suisse has said that its actual results will depend on “a number of factors”, including remaining its performance for the rest of the year and the continued exit of non-core positions.

site_title: Europe: Real estate stocks power Europe’s Stoxx 600 to fresh three-month high
summary: The pan-European Stoxx 600 index reached a fresh three-month high, rising 0.5% to its strongest level since August 18, driven by gains in real estate stocks after the Federal Reserve's November meeting minutes suggested a slowdown in interest rate hikes. The European Central Bank's minutes also showed policymakers feared inflation may be getting entrenched, but the discussion at the December meeting is expected to be more heated and controversial.

site_title: Cathay Pacific in talks on orders for medium-haul jets, freighters
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways is in talks with aircraft manufacturers to order medium-haul jets and dedicated freighters. The airline, which forecast a "substantial" annual loss despite second-half improvement, aims to rebuild after the pandemic. Chief customer officer Ronald Lam stated that existing long-haul aircraft orders will suffice, and the focus will be on acquiring medium-haul jets for the Asia-Pacific region and freighters. The talks come as the airline prepares to return to full pre-pandemic capacity by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific aircrafts prepare to take off at the airport, during the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic in Hong Kong, China, March 31, 2022. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu

site_title: Manulife US Reit selects Citigroup as financial adviser for strategic review
summary: Manulife US Reit selects Citigroup as financial adviser for its strategic review, aiming to recycle assets and diversify into other asset classes and geographical markets amid US office sector headwinds. The reit's manager formed a strategic working group to explore options, including asset recycling and diversification, but no assurance is given that these options will be implemented. The reit's units were trading 4.1% higher following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Artist's impression of Flex by JLL's lounge at 500 Plaza Drive, Manulife US Reit's property in New Jersey.

site_title: China’s local governments face squeeze from US$2t in debt
summary: China's 31 provincial governments face a financial squeeze due to unsustainable debt burdens. Local governments have a stockpile of outstanding bonds nearing 120% of their income, a risk threshold set by the Ministry of Finance. The property crisis and plummeting land sales revenue have contributed to the financial strain. Economists suggest the central government should take on more debt to alleviate the burden, with some experts warning of a potential fiscal restructuring if interest payments exceed 10% of spending. The situation is expected to worsen in the next five years as maturing bonds worth over $2 trillion come due.

images.alt_text: The resurgence of infections casts doubt on investor hopes for China to ease its rigid zero-Covid policy soon, despite recent more targeted measures.

site_title: Nestle to invest US$1.9b in Saudi Arabia over next decade
summary: Nestle plans to invest US$2.55 billion in Saudi Arabia over the next decade, with a focus on producing infant products and ready-to-drink coffee. The investment will create 3,500 direct and indirect jobs and contribute to food security and local innovation. Saudi Arabia aims to attract US$100 billion in foreign direct investment by 2030 to diversify its oil-dependent economy.

images.alt_text: Nestle said that following a recent independent assessment, it instructed its suppliers to ensure palm oil from 3 subsidiaries of AAL no longer enters its supply chain.

Nestle, which has already pledged to source all its coffee sustainably by 2025, said it is now also aiming, by that date, for 20 per cent of its coffee to be grown using ‘regenerative’ agricultural practices.
Plant protein makers that benefitted from a greater emphasis on health in the early stages of the pandemic have struggled as inflation pushes consumers to less expensive options.

site_title: Companies deleveraging while households gear up to buy property: MAS review
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) has flagged potential risks for the country's financial sector, including highly leveraged households and smaller businesses, amid a slowing economy and tightening financing conditions. The MAS expects the corporate sector to remain resilient, with debt-to-GDP ratio and NPL ratio falling, but warns of liquidity risks and rising default risks in certain sectors. Household debt is manageable, but vulnerable households may struggle under conservative scenarios of income losses and interest rate hikes. The MAS also notes rising risks from climate change and cryptocurrency assets, and expects banks to maintain strong financials despite economic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

cbd / ST20220716_202206887671 / Alphonsus Chern //

Generic photograph of the Singapore city skyline in the CBD 16 July 2022.

site_title: Asia: markets mixed as easing Fed fears tempered by China Covid
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Friday as easing Federal Reserve fears were tempered by rising Covid-19 cases in China. Despite hopes for monetary easing, regional sentiment was dampened by ongoing lockdown fears in China, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and other markets down. However, Shanghai and other markets saw gains, with investors cautiously optimistic that China's Covid-zero strategy is being loosened. The US jobs data release next week is expected to provide further market direction.

site_title: Gold flat; set for small weekly gain on hopes of dovish Fed
summary: Gold prices remained flat on Friday, but are expected to gain slightly for the week due to the US Federal Reserve's perceived dovish stance on interest rate hikes. A "substantial majority" of Fed policymakers agreed to slow the pace of rate hikes, leading to a decline in the dollar and making gold cheaper for overseas buyers. This signals relief for emerging markets, which have suffered their biggest rout in over a decade this year, and lifts the appeal for gold compared to other interest-bearing assets.

site_title: Low-carbon hydrogen is the future; how can we get there?
summary: Singapore aims to achieve net zero by 2050 through the use of low-carbon hydrogen, which can decarbonize industries such as petrochemicals, aviation, and steel. The government has launched its National Hydrogen Strategy, which includes steps to prepare for hydrogen deployment domestically and build a supply chain in Asia. The country plans to encourage businesses and individuals to adopt green energy alternatives through policy levers, such as higher carbon tax rates. However, challenges remain, including attracting global hydrogen players and facilitating the development of cost-effective infrastructure, and the government will need to be proactive in addressing these issues.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp's cogeneration plant on Banyan, Jurong Island.
An artist's impression of Singapore's LNG Terminal on Jurong Island.

site_title: South Korea’s President Yoon warns of crackdown on striking truckers
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol has threatened to crack down on a nationwide strike by truckers, calling it "illegal and unacceptable" to disrupt the national supply chain during an economic crisis. The strike, which began on November 24, has already disrupted multiple industries and is expected to continue. The government may issue a work start order to force transport workers back to their jobs, punishable by up to three years of jail or a fine of up to $30,975. The strike has already caused significant disruptions, including delivery delays and penalties for trade with overseas buyers.

images.alt_text: A truck carrying a shipping container travels past cranes at Pyeongtaek port in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, July 9, 2020. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo
The union is asking the government to ensure big businesses are held accountable if they violate the minimum wages rule.

site_title: China Evergrande communicates with Wuhan over repossessed land
summary: China Evergrande Group has begun communicating with the Jiangxia District government in Wuhan City over the repossessed 134,500 hectares of land used for its Evergrande Technology Tourism City project. The district government retrieved its land-use rights over 11 parcels of land, leaving 13 parcels under the project. Evergrande aims to protect its legitimate rights and interests and will file an administrative review. The move comes as the company navigates a deepening property sector debt crisis and prepares to start negotiating restructuring terms next month.

site_title: Sinopec says Qijiang shale project holds 146 bcm certified gas reserve
summary: Sinopec has confirmed a new shale gas field in southwestern China, the Qijiang shales, holds nearly 146 billion cubic meters of proven reserves. The Qijiang shales, buried 3,500 meters below ground, are considered a technologically challenging formation to explore and develop. No further details on development timeline or peak output were provided.

site_title: Mercedes unveils US$1,200 annual subscription to make its cars go faster
summary: Mercedes-Benz is introducing a US$1,200 annual subscription, dubbed Acceleration Increase, for its EQ electric sedans, allowing owners to shave off nearly a second from their 0-60mph acceleration time. The feature is already available on the vehicles, sparking concerns over the company's pricing strategy. This move is part of a broader trend in the automotive industry, with carmakers exploring "function on demand" services to boost revenues.

site_title: Twitter job cuts a concern as new EU rules kick in, EU justice head says
summary: Twitter has faced concerns over its ability to comply with new European Union rules against illegal online content after enforcing steep job cuts following Elon Musk's takeover. The company has fired top executives and laid off around 3,700 employees, with its Brussels office now shut down. EU Justice Chief Didier Reynders has warned Twitter and other tech companies to do more to tackle online hate speech, citing reduced content removals this year compared to previous years. Twitter has committed to full compliance with EU rules, but its ability to do so remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A blanket decision on suspended accounts could potentially alarm government authorities that are keeping a close look at Musk’s handling of hateful speech since he bought the influential platform for US$44 billion.
FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk photo and Twitter logo are seen through magnifier in this illustration taken November 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The coveted blue check mark was previously reserved for verified accounts of politicians, famous personalities, journalists and other public figures.

site_title: Oil muted as price cap proposal eases supply concerns
summary: Oil prices edged lower on Thursday as a proposed G7 cap on Russian oil raised doubts about supply limitations. Benchmark Brent crude fell 0.3% to $85.12 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures held steady near two-month lows. A higher price cap could make it attractive for Russia to sell its oil, reducing supply concerns. European Union governments are split on the price cap level, with a possible cap of $65-$70 a barrel.

images.alt_text: Brent futures for January delivery fell US$2.95, or 3.3 per cent, to settle at US$85.41 a barrel.

site_title: Consumer inflation in Japan’s capital rises at fastest pace in 40 years
summary: Consumer inflation in Tokyo, Japan's capital, rose at its fastest annual pace in 40 years, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target for the sixth consecutive month in November. Core consumer prices, driven by food and fuel bills, rose 3.6% year-over-year, surpassing market forecasts. This signals broadening inflationary pressure, casting doubt on the BOJ's view that recent cost-push inflation is transitory. Analysts predict core consumer inflation may stay around the 2% target, making it challenging for the BOJ to argue that price rises are temporary.

images.alt_text: Japan's manufacturing activity contracted at the fastest pace in two years in November.

site_title: Real estate tokenisation: an emerging trend
summary: Blockchain-powered real estate tokenisation is gaining traction globally, offering a solution to illiquid asset class and securitisation models. Decentraland and other metaverse platforms are emerging as virtual players vying for early dominance. Tokenisation can standardise data formats, provide a single cost-effective solution, and unlock new business opportunities, but requires balancing industry, market, and regulatory readiness. Key benefits include increased accessibility to investors, lower barriers to entry, and improved data security, potentially leading to increased liquidity and reduced transaction costs.

images.alt_text: Fraxtor tokenised 2 redevelopment projects in Singapore: freehold site Gloria Mansion in Pasir Panjang Road and a bungalow site at Mount Rosie Road.

site_title: Streaming TV shows are 21st-century ‘cathedrals’, screenwriting guru McKee says
summary: Screenwriting guru Robert McKee says the future of entertainment is in long-form streaming, with TV shows and smartphone content becoming the "cathedrals of the 21st century." McKee, 81, believes that dynamics of plot and character remain the same, and that the new formats may enrich the form. He cites the complexity of multi-season series like Breaking Bad and Ozark, and argues that binge-watching is a testament to concentration, contradicting the idea that humans' attention spans have shortened.

site_title: Toyota bZ4X review: bZ as a bee
summary: The Toyota bZ4X, the company's first mainstream electric car, is set to enter Singapore's car-sharing scheme in June, with a daily rental fee estimated at S$200. Despite its impressive roominess, the bZ4X is priced at nearly 15% higher than its combustion cousin, making it a costly alternative. Toyota's late entry into the electric car market has sparked criticism, with the company facing a hard road to recovery in the competitive market. The bZ4X boasts a robust battery, retaining over 90% of its capacity after 10 years or 240,000 km of use.

images.alt_text: The world’s No 1 automaker pioneered mass-market hybrid vehicles with the debut of the Prius in 1997 and contends that the technology still has a long way to go.

site_title: FTX invoked by Canada banks group in call for payment safeguards
summary: Canada's banking industry lobby group, the Canadian Bankers Association (CBA), has warned that the government needs to establish consumer protections for payment systems after the collapse of FTX and Celsius Network. The CBA, representing over 60 banks, says the absence of such protections in the Bank of Canada's supervision framework is a significant shortcoming, citing the need to prevent similar collapses in Canada's payments ecosystem. The group is urging the government to act to safeguard consumer losses.

site_title: Global growth to be as weak next year as 2009, IIF forecasts
summary: The Institute of International Finance (IIF) forecasts global growth to be as weak as in 2009 next year, at 1.2% due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine. The conflict's "forever war" scenario is expected to drag on into 2024, with China being the single biggest driver of global growth in 2023, driven by loosening Covid restrictions. This weak growth outlook is attributed to the prolonged conflict, which poses a significant risk to global GDP.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk along Nanjing Pedestrian Road, a main shopping area, in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Civil servants to receive 1.1-month year-end bonus; junior officers another S$700
summary: Singapore's civil service will receive a year-end bonus of 1.1 months, with junior officers receiving an additional S$700. The payment takes into account the eased economic growth, slight uptick in unemployment, and rise in retrenchments. Junior grade officers will also receive a one-time payment of up to S$1,100. The total bonus, combined with the non-pensionable annual allowance, amounts to 1.45 months of pay for the year.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The public service annual variable component, which is paid twice-yearly, is pegged to economic growth and sometimes used as a reference by the private sector.

site_title: Higher interest rates hit reinsurance capital, combining with climate change to push insurance costs up
summary: Higher interest rates and climate change are combining to push insurance costs up, creating a "perfect storm" for the reinsurance industry. Traditional reinsurance capital is expected to decline by $40 billion by the end of 2022, and margins for reinsurers in the Asia-Pacific region are likely to fall due to volatile capital markets and rising counter-party risks. This may lead to increased premiums for insurance buyers, as the industry struggles to meet the minimum cost of capital.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
coins, currency, investment

site_title: Tipping Singapore into a recession to ease labour market tightness would be a very bad idea
summary: Singapore's economy may be easing into a recession to address labor market tightness, but this approach is seen as a drastic measure. A tight labor market leads to higher wages and inflation, but a slowdown in demand can also ease labor pressures without a recession. Central banks aim to keep inflation low without hurting growth and jobs. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has already tightened policy and may avoid further tightening at its next meeting, as the global economy weakens.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
External economic and geopolitical headwinds are already brewing, with sharp slowdowns in major economies like the US and the Eurozone, noted OCBC chief economist Selena Ling.
Singapore's trade growth is expected to be flat or slightly negative in 2023.

site_title: US dollar holds losses as Fed minutes signal slower rate hikes
summary: The US dollar lost ground after the Federal Reserve's November meeting minutes indicated officials were satisfied with moving in smaller steps, suggesting a 50-basis-point rate rise in December, down from four consecutive 75-basis-point increases. This signals a potential downshift in the central bank's rate hike pace.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was broadly flat at 107.1, after shedding 0.65 per cent the previous day amid a pick-up in sentiment that supported riskier currencies.
Grab will deepen cost cuts, including by reducing its regional headcount via streamlining efforts and natural attrition.
FILE PHOTO: Woman holds U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: More Thai restaurants join Michelin list in boost for tourism
summary: Five Thai restaurants have been awarded one-star Michelin ratings, boosting the country's gastronomic appeal and potentially aiding tourism recovery. The new additions include Potong, Baan Tepa, Haoma, Maison Dunand, and Signature. The move is seen as a positive development by the Thai government, which aims to promote gastronomy tourism, with over 10 million tourists expected to visit the country this year and arrivals set to more than double next year.

site_title: JPMorgan, Deutsche Bank sued by Epstein accusers in New York
summary: JPMorgan Chase and Deutsche Bank have been sued by Epstein accusers in New York, alleging the banks enabled the financier's sex trafficking organization to "churn profits." The lawsuits claim the banks knowingly benefited from their relationships with Epstein, who was convicted of sex trafficking in 2019. The suits seek unspecified damages and aim to hold the banks accountable for their alleged role in enabling Epstein's abuse. The accusations come as several Wall Street figures and elites have faced scrutiny for their ties to Epstein, including Prince Andrew and Barclays CEO Jes Staley.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on January 19, 2020 Britain's Prince Andrew, Duke of York, arrives to attend a church service at St Mary the Virgin Church in Hillington, Norfolk, eastern England. - Britain's Prince Andrew was sued in a New York court on August 9, 2021 for alleged sexual abuse of a woman who says she was "lent out" for underage sex by late US financier Jeffrey Epstein. (Photo by Lindsey Parnaby / AFP)

site_title: Anwar to revitalise economy, fight corruption
summary: Malaysia's new Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim has vowed to prioritize recovering the economy and fighting corruption in his unity government. Anwar, sworn in as Malaysia's 10th prime minister, has formed a coalition with Barisan Nasional, Gabungan Parti Sarawak, and other parties, including rival Perikatan Nasional, which has offered to join the government. Anwar commands majority support in the House, with 82 seats from Pakatan Harapan, and plans to call for a vote of confidence on December 19. A revised budget 2023 will be released within a month, with the appointment of a deputy prime minister to be decided later.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (centre) takes part in the swearing-in ceremony at the National Palace in Kuala Lumpur on Thursday (Nov 24).

site_title: EU countries unhappy with 275 euro gas cap proposal
summary: EU energy ministers disagree over a proposed 275 euro gas price cap, which they deem unsatisfactory due to lack of clarity on its impact on prices. The proposal, aimed at alleviating the acute energy crisis, is opposed by countries like Germany and the Netherlands, who fear it could shift supply and cut incentives to lower consumption. The EU has agreed on other measures, but the issue of a gas price cap remains stalled, delaying joint EU gas purchases and a quicker permit process for renewables.

site_title: Amazon faces Black Friday protests, strikes in 40 countries
summary: Thousands of Amazon warehouse workers in 40 countries are protesting and walking out on Black Friday, demanding better wages and working conditions amid the cost-of-living crisis. The protests, dubbed "Make Amazon Pay," are coordinated by international trade unions and environmental groups, citing unfair labor practices and unsafe working conditions. Amazon has responded, citing its efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and offer competitive wages, but workers are concerned about the impact of automation and the company's decision to lay off 10,000 staff.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com said in a statement that it had made the decision to discontinue Amazon Academy “in a phased manner to take care of current customers”.

site_title: Philippines to cut tariffs on electric vehicles, parts
summary: The Philippines will cut tariffs on electric vehicles (EVs) and their parts to 0% for five years, aiming to spur demand and reduce dependence on imported fuel. President Marcos Jr. will issue an executive order, effective immediately, after a panel approved the move. The current tariffs range from 5% to 30%. The decision is expected to make EVs more affordable, with prices currently ranging from $21,000 to $49,000.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Treasury bills issued 2.5 times oversubscribed, causing a delay in publication. The yield for the latest six-month T-bill fell to 3.9% due to a shift in competitive bids. Anwar Ibrahim was sworn in as Malaysia's 10th prime minister after a five-day political impasse. SGX and Fidrec set standards for virtual general meetings. Retail occupancy in Singapore improved to a three-year low in Q3 2022, while Singapore stocks declined 0.1% despite regional gains.

site_title: Binance’s Zhao flags possible US$1b for distressed assets
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao announced plans to allocate around $1 billion for distressed assets in the digital-asset sector, with a potential bid for bankrupt lender Voyager Digital. This move aims to curb the contagion from FTX's collapse and support strong projects facing liquidity squeezes. Binance is also in talks with Genesis Global, a US-based cryptocurrency broker, and has expressed confidence that the industry will survive despite difficulties.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representation of cryptocurrency Binance Coin, the native token of the cryptocurrency exchange, is seen in this illustration taken November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

At a Tech Talk X on Nov 7, Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin unpacked tools that can help us tackle some of the most pressing problems in today’s digital space, such as identity and trust issues, privacy concerns and the ethical deployment of AI.
MAS said it placed Binance on its alert list after the exchange was found to be in potential breach of the Payment Services Act.

site_title: Chinese developers rally on prospects of additional financing
summary: Chinese developers saw a surge in gains as the government offered at least 270 billion yuan in new credit to the sector to ease real estate market turmoil. The mega state-owned banks' move came as part of a push to support the debt-ravaged sector, with property firms like Country Garden and Longfor seeing significant increases. The sector's debt and equity had previously pulled back following a surge in November, but the new credit offer and government support have boosted bond prices and helped developers rebound.

images.alt_text: China last cut its policy interest rate in August.
While the housing market was already showing signs of cracks, investors largely underestimated the depth of the crisis.

site_title: Credit Suisse clients flee to UBS in Asia as rich weigh options
summary: Credit Suisse clients are fleeing to UBS in Asia, with hundreds of wealthy customers seeking to place their funds with the bank. This marks a significant setback for Credit Suisse, which is seeking to put the lender back on course with a sweeping overhaul focusing on private banking. UBS is planning to re-allocate staff to handle the expanding accounts, but it's unclear how much of the funds will stick permanently.

images.alt_text: A sign above an entrance to the Credit Suisse Group AG headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland, on Tuesday, April 19, 2022. Credit Suisses’s chief executive officer at its securities venture in China is stepping aside after less than two years on the job, becoming the second top executive at a major foreign lender in the nation to quit this month. Photographer: Pascal Mora/Bloomberg
Credit Suisse, which predicts the transactions will be completed by mid-2023, added that it expects Apollo to hire the majority of SPG staff.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank UBS is seen at a branch office in Zurich, Switzerland, January 27, 2017. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Credit Suisse has said that its actual results will depend on “a number of factors”, including remaining its performance for the rest of the year and the continued exit of non-core positions.

FILE PHOTO: A logo of Tencent is seen during the World Internet Conference (WIC) in Wuzhen, Zhejiang province, China, November 23, 2020. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD/File Photo
The overall job reductions in Asia were less than what most employees had expected, three sources said.

site_title: Renault signs France’s largest green power-purchase deal
summary: Renault has signed a 15-year contract with Voltalia to purchase 350 megawatts of solar electricity, covering half of the carmaker's electricity consumption. The deal, worth 200 million euros, will see 100 megawatts of solar panels installed on Renault's French sites by 2025, increasing to 350 megawatts by 2027. The partnership aims to reduce Renault's carbon footprint and is part of the company's efforts to decarbonize its plants.

site_title: Annual UK net migration hits record of more than 500,000
summary: The UK has recorded a record net migration of over 504,000 in the year to June 2022, driven by an increase in non-European Union nationals. This is a 435,000 rise from the previous year, with 1.1 million long-term immigrants arriving, primarily EU nationals. The recovery of travel following Covid-19 and increased international student arrivals also contributed to the rise.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on May 3, 2022 Migrants picked up at sea while attempting to cross the English Channel from France, look on from bus driving them to a processing center, after disembarking from a UK Border Force boat, in the Marina at the Dover port, in Dover, on the south-east coast of England. - An attacker on Sunday, October 30, threw fire bombs at an immigration centre used to process asylum seekers crossing the Channel in small boats as the government seeks to curb record arrivals. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: Documenting yesteryear’s retailers
summary: American travel and documentary photographer Steve Golden has released a book, "Heritage Shops of Singapore," showcasing 34 family-run shops across the island. Golden spent 26 years in Singapore, capturing 70 such shops, with a focus on those at least 35 years old. His criteria included family-run businesses, multi-generational ownership, and physical storefronts. The book highlights the challenges of succession planning and the impact of online shopping on traditional shops, with many expected to close within the next five years. The book is available for S$24.50 at Books Kinokuniya Singapore.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Golden Mile Tower was completed in 1974, one year after its sister building, Golden Mile Complex.

site_title: No respite for Vietnam developers with debt maturities looming
summary: Vietnam's developers face significant debt repayment pressure in the next few years, despite a pledge by Finance Minister Ho Duc Phoc to ease funding woes. Shares in major developers have plummeted, and the country's corporate bond sales have tumbled, with investors worried about repayment risks and liquidity crunch. The sector's repayment pressure is keeping investors on edge, with some analysts warning that a clampdown on developers could damage investor sentiment and have repercussions on the entire property sector.

images.alt_text: Ho Duc Phoc, Vietnam's finance minister, speaks during an interview in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Tuesday, Nov. 22, 2022. Vietnam is seeking to expand the nation’s corporate bond market as it grapples with a credit crunch for a real-estate sector hurt by a handful of highly-leveraged companies, according to Finance Minister Ho Duc Phoc. Photographer: Linh Pham/Bloomberg

site_title: Won surges over 2% after Bank of Korea signals rate hikes to continue
summary: The South Korean won surged 2% to 1,324.90 against the US dollar after the Bank of Korea raised its policy rate and indicated continued tightening until inflation is under control. The won's 8% gain this quarter is the biggest among major Asian currencies. Bank of Korea governor Rhee Chang-yong signaled the central bank will stay on its rate-hike path, boosting risk appetite and driving the currency higher. Expectations for softer US rate increases and China's pivot away from Covid-Zero policy also contributed to the won's rally.

images.alt_text: The BOK has delivered two half-point hikes this year as it sought to keep pace with the Federal Reserve’s rapid rate rises and stem pressure on Korea’s currency.
The benchmark Kospi ends 80.93 points or 3.37 per cent higher at 2,483.16.

site_title: Big Four accounting firms on hiring spree as demand booms for professional services
summary: The Big Four accounting firms, EY, PwC, Deloitte, and KPMG, are on a hiring spree, with EY expected to hire around 220,000 people in the next 12 months. This is despite a potential break-up of its auditing and consulting divisions, which could further increase recruitment. The firms' growth and diversification, as well as a post-Covid staff exodus, contribute to the surge in demand for talent. The firms are also increasing salaries and promotions to retain staff, with some rivals, such as PwC, on track to hire a net additional 100,000 professionals by 2026.

images.alt_text: (Photo by GABRIEL BOUYS / AFP)
The salary increases came as firms struggle to retain staff.
EY’s official announcement on Friday (Sep 9) has confirmed what the market had been speculating for months: that it would separate into 2 distinct, multidisciplinary organisations.

site_title: Bootmaker Dr Martens' margin warning knocks shares down 20%
summary: Dr. Martens, a British bootmaker, has warned of a sharp hit to profit margins due to weaker than expected demand ahead of the Christmas season. The company expects its core earnings margin for the full year to be between 100-250 basis points lower than last year. Despite this, demand is still growing, with the company selling a record 6.3 million pairs of shoes in the first half of the year. Shares fell 20% following the announcement, but CEO Kenny Wilson remains confident in meeting demand.

images.alt_text: A pair of Adidas Yeezy shoes seen in a store on the day Adidas terminated its partnership with the American rapper and designer Kanye West, now known as Ye, in Garden City, New York, US, October 25, 2022.
The HySpeed is McLaren's latest move in fashion to sell clothing and accessories that drum up hype for the supercar brand.
Benny Chee, co-founder of homegrown female footwear brand Anothersole at its Ngee Ann City outlet, which opened in September.

site_title: Energy security is the global priority for 2023
summary: The global energy crisis is shifting priorities, with climate change taking a backseat. Japan's rebranding of its state-owned natural resources company to focus on metals and energy security signals a new emphasis on energy security. The current energy trilemma – supply, affordability, and environment – is forcing governments to weigh priorities, with security and affordability making a comeback. Japan's leadership of the G7 in 2023 will likely prioritize energy security, and policymakers must balance security and environmental concerns, with renewable energy offering a solution to both.

images.alt_text: Tankers unload liquefied natural gas at the Eemshaven port in the Netherlands, Sept 2022. A central location and extensive pipeline links could make the Netherlands a lynchpin in securing Europe's independence from Russian imports. But the growing reliance on LNG has created unease.
As they stop promoting coal and oil, governments must keep up the momentum behind renewables.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) was welcomed by Indonesian President Joko Widodo at the start of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua, Bali on Nov 15, 2022.

site_title: Tesla opens floodgates for owners to test out automated driving
summary: Tesla has made its Full Self-Driving Beta (FSD) system available to customers in North America who have purchased the option, despite criticism over the product's performance and regulatory risks. The move comes as the US Justice Department and Securities and Exchange Commission investigate Tesla's self-driving claims, and a customer in California is seeking class action status for a lawsuit claiming the company deceptively marketed its driver-assistance systems. The company's deferred revenue balance is now at $2.8 billion, and analysts have questioned whether making FSD available to more customers will increase revenue.

images.alt_text: An employee drives a Tesla Motors Inc. Model S electric automobile, equipped with Autopilot hardware and software, hands-free on a highway in Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Monday, Oct. 26, 2015. Tesla started equipping the Model S with hardware -- radar, a forward-looking camera, 12 long-range sensors, GPS -- to enable the autopilot features about a year ago. Photographer: Jasper Juinen/Bloomberg via Getty Images

site_title: Hong Kong exchange carries out first carbon credit trades
summary: Hong Kong's Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) has carried out the first batch of carbon credit trades on its Core Climate platform, joining a handful of Asian exchanges in tapping opportunities from governments' push to achieve climate goals. The trades involved over 30 international projects and 20 participants, including Bank of China (Hong Kong) and CLP Holdings, between October 28 and November 24. The platform allows for both yuan and Hong Kong dollar settlement, different from Singapore's Climate Impact X, which trades in US dollars.

site_title: China's Covid infections hit record as economic outlook darkens
summary: China reported a record high of COVID-19 infections, with cities nationwide imposing localized lockdowns and curbs, casting doubt on easing its zero-Covid policy. The resurgence fuels frustration and darkens the outlook for the world's second-largest economy. Lockdowns are affecting residents and factory output, including the world's biggest iPhone plant, which has seen clashes between workers and security personnel. The economic impact is raising pressure on policymakers, with China's GDP growth expected to slow.

images.alt_text: A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: Marco Polo Marine H2 profit up 19% to S$10.5 million, no dividend proposed
summary: Marco Polo Marine reported a 19% increase in net profit to S$10.5 million for the second half of the fiscal year ended September, driven by higher average utilisation rates for its offshore vessels and tugboats. This brought the company's full-year profit to S$21.3 million, a 44% increase from the previous year. No dividend was proposed, citing a need to conserve cash for capital expenditure requirements.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Marco Polo Marine’s new vessel is based on a design co-developed by the group and Seatech Solutions International (S).
jymp29 - Docks owned by Marco Polo Marine##########jymp29##########Marco Polo Marine
This is the first quarter where contributions from recent acquisitions have positively impacted the group’s top and bottom line, said chief executive officer of Marco Polo Marine, Sean Lee.

site_title: China state banks pledge at least 270b yuan to builders
summary: China's state-owned banks have pledged at least 270 billion yuan (S$52 billion) in new credit to struggling property developers as part of efforts to ease the real estate market turmoil. This move is part of the government's push to provide at least 1 trillion yuan in funding to the sector by the end of 2022. The announcement came after regulators issued a 16-point plan to boost the real estate market, including measures to address liquidity crises and loosen down-payment requirements. Chinese developers rallied on the news, with some stocks surging over 10%.

images.alt_text: The central bank has cut the RRR 13 times since 2018, slashing the average reserve ratio to about 8 per cent from 15 per cent, pumping about 10.8 trillion yuan (S$2.1 trillion) in liquidity into the economy, PBOC governor Yi Gang said.

site_title: General Insurance Association raises concerns on Singapore’s proposed coverage for platform workers
summary: The General Insurance Association of Singapore (GIA) has expressed concerns over the government's proposal to introduce employee-like insurance coverage for ride-hailing drivers and on-demand delivery persons under the Work Injury Compensation Act (Wica). GIA chief executive Ho Kai Weng suggests that existing insurance products, such as MediShield Life and prolonged medical leave insurance, can provide adequate financial protection for platform workers. He argues that these solutions offer reduced disputes, wider scope of protection, and less effort required for claims, and that Wica-based coverage may have its downsides, including quantifying income loss across multiple platforms.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The Advisory Committee for Platform Workers took a nuanced, rather than broad-based approach.

site_title: STI down 0.1%, bucking regional gains boosted by Fed minutes
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,252.88 on Nov 24, despite regional gains. The decline came despite Federal Reserve officials showing support for slowing down interest rate hikes. In broader market, 287 advancers outpaced 199 decliners, with 1.2 billion securities worth S$918.1 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Gainers outnumber losers 79 to 22 after 27.3 million securities worth S$54.2 million change hands on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Nearly a third of financial claims involve fraud and scams: Fidrec
summary: Nearly a third of financial claims handled by the Financial Industry Disputes Resolution Centre (Fidrec) involved fraud and scams, accounting for 28.8% of 907 claims in FY2021. This represents an increase from 22% the previous year. About 52% of all claims were against banks and financial companies, with over half involving fraud and scams. Fidrec's free and non-binding mediation services aim to resolve disputes without adjudication.

images.alt_text: At least 28 victims collectively lost S$114,000 to banking-related phishing scams since the start of May, the police said.
The suspects aged between 16 and 86 are believed to be involved in more than 695 cases of scams.

site_title: Flying-taxi firms face reckoning with Airbus veterans in charge
summary: Flying-taxi firms Volocopter and Lilium are facing a reality check after hiring former Airbus executives, Dirk Hoke and Klaus Roewe, to lead their bids for commercial electric-powered flying taxis. Hoke has scaled back Volocopter's global ambitions and set a lower target for its first commercial flights. Meanwhile, Lilium's CEO Roewe has ordered a rethink of the company's PR strategy amid plummeting stock prices. Both companies are re-evaluating their strategies as they navigate the challenges of bringing flying taxis to market.

images.alt_text: As part of the launch, Volocopter, a German developer of electric vertical take-off and landing craft or eVTOLs, as flying taxis are known, carried out a flight integrated into conventional air traffic.
Volocopter aims to have electric air taxis in Singapore in 2024
An artists' impression of a Skyports cargo vertiport, in which joint feasibility studies will be carried out with Jurong Port to develop maritime drone delivery infrastructure.
Joby Aviation eVTOL aircraft.
Joby, in which Toyota has invested US$394 million, designs and builds all-electric vertical take-off and landing aircraft.
Supernal's eVTOLs, expected to start test flights in 2025, will be powered by both electric batteries and hydrogen fuel cells, which will give range as well as power density.

site_title: Celebrating the silver generation
summary: French photographer Jose Jeuland celebrates ageing in his latest exhibition, "Aging Singapore," featuring 12 individuals from Singapore who embody a positive and active approach to ageing. The exhibition, now open until Dec 14, showcases portraits, scents, and audio files that bring the seniors' stories to life. Jeuland aims to challenge the stigma surrounding ageing and encourage young people to learn from their seniors. The exhibition highlights individuals such as 83-year-old Rajalectiumee, who cycles regularly, and 95-year-old Teo Guak Wah, who exercises twice a week, inspiring viewers to age more gracefully.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Dr. Shravan Verma., chief executive officer of Speedoc said: "The most rewarding thing about serving the country during Covid-19 was also being able to hire people from different industries,."

site_title: Amazon to shut down online learning academy in India
summary: Amazon is shutting down its online learning platform, Amazon Academy, in India after less than two years of launch. The decision, made in a phased manner, prioritizes current customers. The platform, launched during the Covid-19 pandemic, offered coaching for high-school students on competitive exams. This move comes as multiple edtech firms, including Byju's, Unacademy, and Vedantu, have announced layoffs amid the reopening of schools and coaching centers in India. No reason was cited for Amazon's decision to discontinue the platform.

site_title: Hublot brings the World Cup experience to Singapore at pop-up exhibition
summary: Hublot brings the FIFA World Cup experience to Singapore with its "Hublot Loves Football" pop-up exhibition at VivoCity, featuring a pentagon-shaped space with football-themed areas, including a kick-off game and a photo opportunity with electronic football substitution boards. The exhibition showcases 14 unique football designs, Hublot watches worn by World Cup officials, and a VR experience. The pop-up aims to engage new audiences and promote Hublot's partnership with the FIFA World Cup for the fourth consecutive edition. The exhibition runs daily until November 27, 2022.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Keppel O&M receives US$160 million payment for delivery of first jackup rig
summary: Keppel O&M received a US$160 million payment for delivering the first jackup rig to ADNOC Drilling Company PJSC. The three rigs were part of a series built by Keppel Fels for Borr Drilling, which were later novated to ADNOC Drilling. Keppel O&M expects to receive at least US$352 million for all three rigs between 2022 and 2023, in addition to downpayments from previous customers. The novation agreement provides Keppel O&M with greater certainty and reduced financial exposure.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Keppel O&M’s state-of-the-art KFELS B Class rig (pictured)

site_title: The 14 best new spirits and wine for holiday entertaining
summary: The article highlights 14 new spirits and wines perfect for holiday entertaining, including a 2014 Iron Horse Stargazing Cuvée Brut, available in magnums, featuring a Pinot Noir and Chardonnay blend with lemony notes and supertiny bubbles. This exclusive wine is also notable for being served by the White House under seven consecutive presidential administrations, making it bipartisan. Available for $195, it's an ideal choice for a celebratory toast.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A glass of French red wine is displayed at the Chateau du Pavillon in Sainte-Croix-Du-Mont, France, July 29, 2019. REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/File Photo

site_title: Kimly posts 13.4% fall in full-year net profit to S$34 million
summary: Kimly, a CATALIST-listed coffeeshop operator, reported a 13.4% drop in full-year net profit to S$34 million, despite a 33.1% revenue jump to S$317.7 million. The decline was mainly due to lower non-taxable government grants and a S$73.5 million revenue contribution from newly-acquired Tenderfresh Group, offset by the closure of 11 underperforming food stalls. Kimly's earnings per share fell to 2.74 cents, and a final dividend of 1.12 cents per share was proposed.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
位于碧山的金味（Kimly）咖啡店。

site_title: Private equity gets CO2 warning from investors with US$11t
summary: Asset owners with over $11 trillion in investments are warning private equity firms to increase their climate ambition and avoid moving carbon-intensive assets into private hands, which could hinder decarbonization targets. The Net-Zero Asset Owner Alliance, representing major investors such as Aviva and California Public Employees' Retirement System, urges private managers to "raise their level of climate ambition" and avoid "greenwashing" by transferring high-emitting assets to private investors. The warning comes as publicly traded companies face greater scrutiny around their carbon emissions.

images.alt_text: An aerial view of the Johor Strait. A study by the NUS Business School’s Centre for Governance and Sustainability scoped out the top 50 listcos by market capitalisation across 13 Asia-Pacific jurisdictions, and found that the overall nature disclosure rate is 31.4 per cent.
Container ship operator Samskip is installing carbon capture systems of two of its ships.

site_title: UK’s largest fraud operation nets over 100 spoofing scammers
summary: The UK's Metropolitan Police Service shut down the global "spoofing shop" iSpoof, a website that scammed victims out of tens of millions of pounds by disguising phone numbers to trick people into giving personal details. Over 100 UK arrests were made in connection with the case, with losses estimated at around £48 million, believed to be much higher due to underreporting. International law enforcement agencies, including the FBI and Europol, worked together to bring down the operation, which earned £3.2 million over a 20-month period.

site_title: Yield for latest Singapore Treasury bill falls to 3.9% as more go for competitive bids
summary: The Singapore government's latest six-month Treasury bill (T-bill) auction drew a record S$11.9 billion in applications, with the yield falling to 3.9% due to a shift towards competitive bids. The T-bill emerged 2.5 times oversubscribed, with non-competitive applications accounting for 50.8% of the total allotment. The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced a delay in releasing the auction results due to the high volume of applications, and only 77.78% of applicants received their allotment. This shift towards competitive bids may lead to lower T-bill cut-off yields in future auctions.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
CPF could be on the brink of adjusting Special Account interest rates, as 10-year Singapore government bond yields have climbed to more than 3.1 per cent
CPF ordinary savings for fixed deposits at OCBC at 3.4 per cent per annum.
Due to overwhelming interest, the MAS put out a notice in the afternoon to announce the delay in publication of the results of the latest six-month Treasury bill auction.

site_title: Realising smarter, more secure healthcare
summary: Federated learning, a decentralized form of machine learning, is poised to revolutionize healthcare by enabling AI models to achieve clinical-grade accuracy without compromising sensitive patient data. This decentralized approach allows data to remain with the owner, while still being utilized to create global insights. Federated learning has already shown promise in detecting brain tumors and improving diagnosis, and its potential extends beyond healthcare to areas such as the Internet of Things and fintech. With robust data security strategies and hardware-based security solutions, organizations can harness the full potential of federated learning to drive breakthroughs in healthcare and beyond.

images.alt_text: Leaders of medtech companies must be agile enough to navigate turbulent markets via five key capabilities.

site_title: From hawker centres in shorts to the Audi boardroom
summary: Audi's new board member Hildegard Wortmann says the need for huge, expensive showrooms is over, and dealers must adapt to an era of evolving customer tastes and habits. According to Wortmann, customers will still visit showrooms but also expect a mix of physical and digital sales experiences. Audi is evolving its retail model to focus on "point-of-experience" spaces, where customers can interact with the brand and its products. The company aims to create immersive experiences that showcase its concept cars and electric vehicles, and Wortmann sees a role for dealers in this new model.

images.alt_text:
Bentley Continental GT Speed (L), Bentley Bentayga Speed (R).

site_title: Prime retail rents set to rise as Q3 vacancy eases to three-year low: Savills
summary: Singapore's retail vacancy rate eased to a three-year low of 7.8% in Q3 2022, driven by improved shopper traffic and a tightening of property supply. Prime retail rents are expected to rise amid a recovery in shopper traffic and a tightening of property supply, with increases predicted in 2023. Savills forecasts a 1-3% rise in prime Orchard Road retail rents and a 2-3% rise in prime suburban rents.

images.alt_text: According to a report by Propnex on Wednesday (Oct 26), the median rental for shophouses stood at S$5.65 psf per month in Q3, up from S$5.50 psf per month last quarter.
Savills Research expects Grade A CBD office rent to grow at 3 per cent for the whole of 2022 and increase by 2 per cent year-on-year in 2023.
While all three regions experienced a fall in secondary sales volume, the largest decline came from the Rest of Central Region (RCR), whose transaction volume fell 14.3 per cent q-o-q to 1,135 units.

site_title: Thailand to sell 60 billion baht of government savings bonds next month
summary: Thailand plans to sell 60 billion baht ($2.3 billion) of government savings bonds between December 7 and 20 to help finance a budget deficit. The bonds will offer coupons of 2.3%, 3.0%, and 2.9% for 3-, 7-, and 10-year terms, respectively. The government aims to keep its public debt to GDP ratio below 60.43% by the end of 2023.

site_title: Sarah Brightman to perform Phantom of the Opera hits with Christmas twist in new show
summary: Sarah Brightman, the world's best-selling soprano, will perform her Christmas show "A Christmas Symphony" in Singapore on Dec 5. The one-night show will feature a mix of her hits, including Phantom of the Opera songs, with a festive twist. Brightman, the original Christine Daaé in the West End and Broadway musical, will be accompanied by an orchestra and choir. The show, originally conceived during the pandemic, has become a successful tour, with proceeds going to charity. Tickets are now on sale, priced from S$128 to S$278.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Jim Jefferies played a sold out show in Singapore in 2019 and will return this December with The Moist Tour.
The musical will celebrate its 35th anniversary in January followed by a final Broadway performance on Feb 18.

site_title: China fashion tycoon to sell HK$500m prime Hong Kong office
summary: A Chinese fashion tycoon, Qiu Yafu, is selling a prime office property in Hong Kong's business district, Bank of America Tower, for HK$500 million. The 23rd floor and three car parking spaces are being sold, following a significant price drop from its 2018 sale price of nearly HK$702 million. Qiu's Shandong Ruyi Group, which attempted to build China's luxury powerhouse, is at the center of an unwinding involving major financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Chinese developers rallied on Thursday as more signs of government policy support emerged for the debt-ravaged sector.

site_title: Kopernik Global Investors no longer substantial shareholder of Golden Agri-Resources
summary: Kopernik Global Investors, a US investment management company, has ceased to be a substantial shareholder of Golden Agri-Resources, a palm oil player listed on the Singapore Exchange. Kopernik sold 37.3 million shares on November 3 at S$0.2934 each, reducing its deemed interest to 4.91% from 5.2%. The sale occurred after the investment manager became aware of the change in interest on November 22, with a notification to the listed issuer the same day. Golden Agri Resources shares finished the day flat at S$0.285.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Seeing Singapore’s development through its architecture
summary: A new book, "Everyday Modernism," showcases Singapore's development through its architecture, highlighting the country's transformation from a British colony to a modern city-state. The 352-page book, written by Chang Jiat-Hwee and Justin Zhuang, covers 32 essays on modernist buildings, structures, and everyday spaces, including pedestrian overhead bridges, lookout towers, and city council pools. The authors aim to provide a comprehensive understanding of Singapore's modern built environment, focusing on "ordinary modernism" rather than iconic landmarks. The book is accompanied by 200 archival images and drawings, and is available for purchase at NUS Press web store.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
IOI Central Boulevard Towers, a Grade A office development, under construction in Singapore's Central Business District.

site_title: China regulator’s new buzzword fuels buying spree in state firms
summary: China's securities chief, Yi Huiman, has introduced a "valuation system with Chinese characteristics" to support state-owned firms and companies aligned with national goals. The new term has sparked a buying spree in large state-owned enterprises (SOEs), with China Communications Construction, China Aluminum International Engineering, and CGN New Energy Holdings seeing significant gains. The move may signal a shift away from market-oriented reforms, but some investors caution that the rally in SOE stocks is unlikely to last, and may be driven by speculation rather than a fundamental shift.

images.alt_text: Chinese developers rallied on Thursday as more signs of government policy support emerged for the debt-ravaged sector.

site_title: Foxconn offers staff 10,000 yuan to leave after iPhone city violence
summary: Foxconn, Apple's main global production partner, has offered 10,000 yuan (approximately $1,926) to staff in China who choose to leave their jobs at the world's largest iPhone factory in Zhengzhou after violent protests. The incentive aims to smooth the journey home for employees who were protesting unpaid wages and fears of spreading infection. The plant resumed normal operations by Wednesday evening, amid a nationwide Covid Zero strategy that has weighed on the economy and global supply chain.

images.alt_text: The Foxconn situation serves up another reminder of the dangers for Apple of relying on a vast production machine centred on China at a time of unpredictable policy and uncertain trade relations.

site_title: World’s most expensive drug approved to treat haemophilia at US$3.5m a dose
summary: US regulators approved CSL Behring's haemophilia B gene therapy, Hemgenix, at a one-off dose of $3.5 million, making it the most expensive medicine in the world. The therapy, administered just once, cut bleeding events by 54% and freed 94% of patients from Factor IX infusions. While the price is high, experts believe it has the potential to be successful due to the need for effective treatments for haemophilia patients.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for GlaxoSmithKline is seen on it's offices in London, Britain, March 30, 2016. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Billionaire investor Ackman bets Hong Kong dollar peg can break
summary: Billionaire investor Bill Ackman has taken a public short bet against the Hong Kong dollar, predicting it will break its peg to the US dollar. Ackman claims the peg no longer makes sense for Hong Kong, citing the country's economic challenges, including faltering Chinese growth. This bet comes as US interest rates continue to rise, putting pressure on the Hong Kong dollar. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has maintained the peg through interest rate hikes and currency intervention, but Ackman's statement suggests the peg may eventually break, potentially destabilizing the currency system.

images.alt_text: Ackman, who had become Netflix’s most prominent backer when he said he bought 3.1 million shares in January, reacted quickly and boldly - selling everything.
'SPAC King' Palihapitiya to seek extension for pair of blank-cheque deals as sector reels

site_title: Sri Lankan central bank threatens administrative measures over high market interest rates
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank has threatened administrative measures to control high market interest rates, which it considers out of line with the inflation outlook. The Central Bank of Sri Lanka (CBSL) confirmed it will hold its two policy rates steady, citing a need to curb demand in the economy. The bank warned it may impose measures to prevent undue movements in market interest rates if rates do not adjust downward as expected. The move aims to lower the government's high borrowing costs and stabilize the economy, which has been struggling with soaring inflation and a financial crisis.

images.alt_text: A labourer carries a sack of flour at a market in Colombo on October 21, 2022.
P Nandalal Weerasinghe, governor of Sri Lanka central bank, says: “Budget has to look at what reforms are needed to ensure Sri Lanka remains stable and does not return to crisis.”

site_title: Musk floats ‘general amnesty’ of suspended Twitter accounts
summary: Elon Musk has proposed a "general amnesty" for suspended Twitter accounts, sparking concerns among government authorities and tech giants about his content moderation policies. A poll on the platform, which was used to reinstate former US President Donald Trump's account, suggests a majority of users support the move. However, experts warn that this could lead to further regulatory scrutiny and potential bans from app stores. Musk's decision comes as Twitter faces a staff exodus and struggles to maintain content quality following his acquisition.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk, who has already slashed Twitter’s workforce in half in sweeping job cuts that included much of the company’s management, is considering additional layoffs to begin as soon as Monday.
Elon Musk had already fired half of Twitter’s 7,500 staff, scrapped a work-from-home policy and imposed long hours, all while his attempts to overhaul the company face backlash and delays.
The coveted blue check mark was previously reserved for verified accounts of politicians, famous personalities, journalists and other public figures.
FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk photo and Twitter logo are seen through magnifier in this illustration taken November 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Elon Musk expressed willingness to actively invest in EV charging infrastructure in South Korea.

site_title: Anwar Ibrahim sworn in as prime minister after days of political impasse
summary: Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim was sworn in on November 24, 2022, after a five-day political impasse following the general election. Anwar, chairman of the Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition, formed a national unity government with opposition parties, including Umno and the East Malaysia bloc. The move is seen as a positive step for the country, bringing stability and paving the way for economic growth. Anwar has promised to test his majority by calling for a vote of confidence on December 19, and has invited all parties to join the government as long as they accept principles of good governance and no corruption.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's newly appointed Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (C) takes part in the swearing-in ceremony at the National Palace in Kuala Lumpur on November 24, 2022. (Photo by MOHD RASFAN / POOL / AFP)

site_title: Gold firms above US$1,750 an ounce as Fed signals slower rate hikes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,754.08 per ounce, surpassing the $1,750 threshold, following the US Federal Reserve's policy meeting signals of slower interest rate hikes. The Fed policymakers agreed to slow the pace of rate hikes, making gold more appealing compared to other interest-bearing assets. Physical gold demand in Asia remained soft, with premiums easing in China and higher domestic prices deterring buyers in India.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016.
