Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise, dollar slips as Federal Reserve signals softer rate hike pace
summary: Asian markets rose, with Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Shanghai in the green, following the Federal Reserve's signal to slow rate hikes. The dollar weakened, amid concerns over China's Covid cases and potential lockdowns. The minutes from the Federal Reserve's meeting showed smaller increases would be "likely soon" as the economy shows signs of weakness. This news provided a cushion against market concerns, with traders speculating authorities may revert to economically debilitating measures to fight the outbreak.

images.alt_text: Asian investors tracked their US counterparts in early trade on Wednesday.

site_title: Nintendo breaks sales record with new Pokémon games on Switch
summary: Nintendo's new Pokémon games, Scarlet and Violet, have broken the company's sales record with 10 million sales globally in their first three days. The games, released on November 18, also set a new domestic record in Japan with 4 million sales. This achievement comes as the Switch console, now five years old, relies on big game launches to maintain momentum in sales. Nintendo shares rose 1.9% following the announcement, despite the company's cautious forecast for the year ahead due to chip supply shortages.

site_title: Libor up to 14-year high amid year-end funding focus
summary: The three-month London interbank offered rate for dollars rose to its highest level since the 2008 financial crisis, climbing to 4.75729% amid year-end funding focus. The rate increase is attributed to expectations of Federal Reserve interest rate hikes, but also partly driven by commercial paper transactions to ensure funding for the end of the year. The spread of Libor over overnight index swaps widened to 33 basis points, indicating increased funding pressure.

site_title: China’s daily Covid-19 cases hit record high
summary: China reported its highest daily Covid-19 cases since the pandemic began, with 31,444 new local cases on November 23, including 3,927 symptomatic and 27,517 asymptomatic. The previous record was set on April 13. The country has also reported one death, pushing fatalities to 5,232. The cases are concentrated in major cities like Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Chongqing, with significant increases in symptomatic and asymptomatic cases.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Future of banking requires true digitalisaton (Ep 3)
summary: OCBC Bank's head of group digital business and digital transformation, Serene Koh, discusses the future of banking in a digital era. True digitalization requires understanding the customer of today and the future, and involves more than just technology. Challenges include building hyper-personalized digital experiences, addressing data privacy and security concerns, and distinguishing between necessities and nice-to-haves. Koh emphasizes the importance of a holistic approach to digital transformation, and highlights the need for banks to adapt to changing customer needs and expectations.

site_title: Luis Enrique backs Spain to stay hungry after historic 7-0 rout over Costa Rica
summary: Spain coach Luis Enrique expressed confidence that his team will stay focused and hungry despite their historic 7-0 win over Costa Rica in the World Cup. Enrique warned that too much praise can weaken a team's resolve, but he believes his side will maintain their spirit and compete hard against Germany in their next match, which they are expected to win. Enrique also hinted that he will make changes to his starting lineup, with several players, including Ansu Fati and Marcos Llorente, kept in reserve.

images.alt_text: France's Olivier Giroud celebrates scoring their second goal with Ousmane Dembele in their World Cup tie against Australia.
Doha, the capital of Qatar, which won its bid to host the 2022 Fifa World Cup 12 years ago. Criticism of the choice of host raises questions over how Western nations should deal with such regimes.

Soccer fans pack the Red Lion, a pub discreetly tucked inside a hotel, in Doha, Qatar, on Monday, Nov. 21, 2022. The Red Lion Pub is an oasis for World Cup fans who are hoping to get some beer while in Qatar.  (Erin Schaff/The New York Times)

Germany looked in total command but, with each missed chance, left the door open for Japan, who showed almost nothing in attack until a series of substitutions injected some energy in the second half.

site_title: Europe ponders policy on Ukraine
summary: Europe is set to face a tougher year in its support for Ukraine as the Russia-Ukraine conflict enters its 10th month. The EU has shown unity in launching sanctions packages on Russia, but internal divisions exist over longer-term goals. A 120-day renewal of the Black Sea grain agreement is expected to be brokered, allowing exports to resume from three Ukrainian ports. However, the economic pain of supporting Ukraine is increasing, with Europe's economy heading into recession and high inflation. The EU's resolve will be tested, and the scope for further measures against Russia may be limited by internal divisions and public support.

images.alt_text: The G20, which includes countries ranging from Brazil to India, Saudi Arabia and Germany, accounts for more than 80 per cent of the world’s gross domestic product, 75 per cent of international trade and 60 per cent of its population.

site_title: SGX, director and company secretary groups set standards for virtual general meetings
summary: SGX RegCo and its partners have issued standards for virtual general meetings, recommending that attendees be allowed to vote on resolutions with the option to amend their votes. Companies must deploy systems to register interest and verify identities virtually. The standards aim to engage companies effectively at hybrid or virtual meetings and fulfill shareholder voting requirements. The move comes after the Ministry of Law allowed entities to hold general meetings via electronic means during the Covid-19 pandemic, and the standards will be allowed until the Ministry revokes or amends the order.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Yongnam in talks to secure refinancing or investment as repayment dates loom
summary: Yongnam Holdings, a steel fabricator, is in talks to secure refinancing or investment to repay its borrowings, which total S$90.7 million and are due within the next year. Chief executive Seow Soon Yong says refinancing would help service borrowings, while securing an investor could involve negotiations with lenders and creditors. The company reported a net loss of S$18.2 million in its third quarter, with its borrowings more than doubling to S$90.7 million. Yongnam intends to secure either refinancing or an investor, but not both.

images.alt_text: Prices of steel rebar and flat steel are projected to decrease by 4.5 per cent and 3 per cent respectively from Q3 to Q4 2022, and this trend is expected to continue as iron ore prices drop across Asia, according to a report by Linesight published on Wednesday (Nov 2).

site_title: Japan’s Nov factory activity shrinks at quickest pace in 2 years
summary: Japan's manufacturing activity contracted at the fastest pace in two years in November, according to a business survey. The au Jibun Bank Flash Japan Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) fell to 49.4 from 50.7 in the previous month, marking the first monthly decline in 22 months. The contraction was attributed to worsening demand due to strong inflationary pressures. This development raises concerns over Japan's economic outlook, which relies heavily on trade with China and other nations for growth.

images.alt_text: Haruhiko Kuroda has repeatedly called for the BOJ to keep monetary policy ultra-loose.
BOJ could decide in 2026 whether to issue a digital currency after verifying issues for two years, such as whether there are problems with deposits and withdrawals from bank accounts.

site_title: Most Federal Reserve officials say slower rate hike pace appropriate ‘soon’
summary: Most Federal Reserve officials agree that a slower pace of interest rate hikes is likely to be appropriate "soon" to combat US inflation, which reached a 40-year high of 7.7%. The Fed has raised the benchmark borrowing rate six times this year, including a fourth consecutive three-quarter point hike in November. Policymakers are seeking to cool demand and bring down prices, amid concerns about the aggressive path taken to combat inflation.

images.alt_text: The US dollar index was broadly flat at 107.1, after shedding 0.65 per cent the previous day amid a pick-up in sentiment that supported riskier currencies.
New home sales rebounded 7.5 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 632,000 units last month, the Commerce Department said on Wednesday (Nov 23).
Initial unemployment claims increased by 17,000 to 240,000 in the week ended Nov 19, Labor Department data showed on Wednesday (Nov 23).

site_title: Keppel EGM to be held on Dec 8; directors recommend voting in favour of O&M merger
summary: Keppel Corporation will hold an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on Dec 8 to vote on the proposed merger of its offshore and marine (O&M) unit with Sembcorp Marine. Directors recommend voting in favor of both resolutions, which include the transfer of assets and the payment of fees. The merger, first announced in April 2022, involves Sembmarine acquiring Keppel O&M at a revised equity-value exchange ratio of 46:54, with Sembmarine owning 46% and Keppel holding 54%.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger
This revised deal is S$378 million lower than if the one-for-one share exchange option was pursued, as Keppel O&M was being valued at S$4.87 billion under the previous terms.
The projects involve the conversion of two Sevan cylindrical drilling vessels into floating liquified natural gas (FLNG) facilities.

Sembcorp, through the VSIP Group, has a portfolio of 11 large-scale developments across eight provinces in Vietnam, said Kelvin Teo (pictured), Sembcorp Development chief executive and co-chairman of VSIP Group.

Structural manager Muhammad Isa Sanusi wearing AR-enabled smart glasses at a Keppel shipyard. The  smart glasses can be use to view key information about a crane - weight of the load it is lifting and its maintenance condition.

site_title: Air pollution killed 238,000 Europeans prematurely in 2020: EEA
summary: Air pollution in the European Union led to 238,000 premature deaths in 2020, a slight increase from 2019. Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) from car exhausts and coal-fired power plants caused 238,000 deaths, while nitrogen dioxide (NO2) and ozone (O3) exposure led to 49,000 and 24,000 premature deaths, respectively. The EU aims to reduce PM2.5-related deaths by 55% by 2030. Overall, the EU's air pollution rate decreased by 45% from 2005 levels, potentially meeting the zero pollution action plan target before 2030.

site_title: UK's Hunt rules out 'move away' from Brexit trade deal with EU
summary: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt has ruled out changing the Brexit trade deal with the EU, stating it has never been the government's intention to compromise on regulations or freedom of movement. Hunt believes existing trade frictions can be reduced through better use of technology.

site_title: Amazon plans to invest US$1b a year in movies for theatres
summary: Amazon plans to invest over $1 billion annually in movie production for theatrical releases, aiming to release 12-15 films per year. This strategy places the company on par with major studios like Paramount Pictures. The move marks a significant shift for the online retailer, which has traditionally focused on streaming services. Amazon's plans come after a smaller theatrical release in 2022, and the company aims to increase its output over time.

images.alt_text: The robotic arm, tipped by a set of retractable suction devices, is called Sparrow.
The new drone, dubbed MK30, will go into service in 2024 and replace the existing MK27-2.

site_title: Global regulators to target crypto platforms after FTX crash
summary: Global regulators are targeting crypto platforms following the FTX crash, with Iosco, the global securities watchdog, setting out principles for regulating stablecoins. Iosco's new chair, Jean-Paul Servais, aims to draw on principles from other sectors to regulate crypto platforms, which have resisted new rules. Regulators will focus on "conglomerate" platforms, and the move is seen as a response to the FTX crash, which has injected urgency into regulating the crypto sector.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Microsoft snaps up huge clean power deal for Irish data hub
summary: Microsoft has signed a power-purchase agreement with Statkraft to provide 900 megawatts of clean energy from wind and solar projects in Ireland, powering a data centre. The deal, valued at 366 megawatts, is the second-largest corporate power-purchase agreement this year, following Amazon's 3.5 gigawatt deal in April. The agreement will start once the projects begin operating, with Statkraft funding and managing their construction. The move aims to reduce Microsoft's reliance on non-renewable energy sources and meet growing pressure from regulators to clean up its energy consumption.

site_title: UK police lift lid on largest ever counter-fraud operation
summary: UK police have concluded the largest ever counter-fraud operation, disrupting an international network targeting hundreds of thousands of victims in millions of spam phone calls. The operation, led by the Metropolitan Police, arrested over 100 people, including a London-based administrator, and shut down servers in the Netherlands and Ukraine. Organised crime groups linked to the iSpoof.cc website, which had tens of thousands of users, were behind the scheme, earning nearly £3.2 million in revenue. The investigation recorded £48 million in losses in the UK, with an estimated much higher figure due to under-reported cases.

images.alt_text: Back in August, Hodlnaut applied to the Singapore High Court to be placed under judicial management following the Terra-Luna collapse.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street following indications that the Federal Reserve may moderate interest rate hikes. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed to 3,269.84, with 79 gainers outnumbering 22 losers. Key gainers included CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, Keppel Real Estate Investment Trust, and ComfortDelGro, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose. The US stock market followed suit, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.3% and the S&P 500 advancing 0.6%.

images.alt_text: Apac Realty's ERA has been losing agents to rival real estate company PropNex, according to data from Huttons Asia.

site_title: Oil slides over 3% on Russian price cap talks, US petrol build
summary: Oil prices fell over 3% on Wednesday, with Brent futures for January delivery dropping $2.95 to $85.41 a barrel, and US crude falling $3.01 to $77.94 a barrel. The decline was attributed to the Group of Seven nations considering a price cap on Russian oil and a build in US petrol inventories. This volatile trading trend continues, with both contracts initially rising by over $1 a barrel before settling.

images.alt_text: Brent crude rose 91 cents, or 1 per cent, to settle at US$88.36 on Tuesday.

site_title: US jobless claims hit three-month high; business equipment orders up sharply
summary: US jobless claims rose to a three-month high of 240,000 in the week ended Nov 19, with continuing claims increasing by 48,000 to 1.55 million. Despite a rebound in business equipment orders, the data suggests the labor market may be cooling. The Federal Reserve's interest-rate hikes are likely to impact sectors like housing and construction, but the labor market remains robust. Technology companies, including Amazon and Meta, have announced job cuts, and FedEx is furloughing workers ahead of the busiest season.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 hits over 3-month highs; Credit Suisse drops after flagging hefty loss
summary: The Stoxx 600 index in Europe rose 0.6% to its strongest level since August 19, driven by gains in mining stocks, while Credit Suisse dropped 6.1% after estimating a pretax loss of up to 1.5 billion Swiss francs due to client withdrawals. Investors await policy meeting minutes for clues on future interest rate hikes, amidst a backdrop of slowing US and euro zone business activity.

images.alt_text: With the UK economy in recession and inflation running at four-decade highs, things may be set to get worse for UK retailers.
European Central Bank chief economist Philip Lane at an event in New York in September. He says the plan is to continue with steep interest rate rises in the next few months.

site_title: Japan come from behind to stun Germany 2-1
summary: Germany was stunned 2-1 by Japan in the World Cup, overcoming a 1-0 deficit to win with late goals by Ritsu Doan and Takuma Asano. Ilkay Guendogan's penalty in the 33rd minute was the only score before Doan equalized in the 75th minute and Asano sealed the win in the 90th minute. The result was a shocking turnaround for Japan, who showed little attacking threat until a series of substitutions in the second half.

site_title: Grinding inflation clouds ‘Black Friday’ shopping bonanza
summary: US retailers expect deep discounts on Black Friday, but consumers' confidence in spending is uncertain due to grinding inflation. A year ago, retailers faced product shortages; now, they face oversupply. Despite robust savings, consumers' excess savings have dwindled, and credit card debt has risen. Earnings reports from retailers show a mixed picture, with some predicting a weak holiday season and others expecting strong sales. Consumers are shopping carefully, looking for deals, and prioritizing essential items over discretionary spending.

images.alt_text: People shop for clothing at a Costco store in Monterey Park, California on November 22, 2022. - Analysts cited good results from Best Buy and some other retailers which offered hope that a resilient American consumer will keep spending during the critical shopping season that begins on "Black Friday." (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Coinbase debt was ‘canary in the coal mine’ for crypto meltdown
summary: Coinbase Global's junk bonds have seen a significant plunge in value, trading around 53 cents on the dollar, a level typically associated with distressed debt. The decline is attributed to the crypto winter and concerns about the company's debt, including a statement in May that clients could be treated as general unsecured creditors if the company went bankrupt. Industry analysts see the drop as a "canary in the coal mine" for the crypto meltdown, with some predicting a potential recovery in the debt if Coinbase demonstrates a commitment to a reasonable balance sheet.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of the cryptocurrency is seen in front of Coinbase logo in this illustration taken, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Hotels a bright spot for Singapore property groups, for now
summary: Singapore's hotel and serviced-apartment sector showed a strong positive outlook in the latest Real Estate Sentiment Index survey, with a +68% future net balance. This bodes well for property groups with significant exposure to the sector, such as CDL Hospitality Trusts, Far East Hospitality Trust, OUE Commercial Reit, and UOL Group. The sector's recovery reflects a rebound in the tourism industry, benefiting developers like UOL.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Singapore saw 816,758 international visitor arrivals in October, setting yet another monthly record since the start of the pandemic.
Higher progressive recognition of revenue from projects such as The Watergardens at Canberra contributed to an increase in property development revenue.
The revenue per available room for CDL Hospitality Trusts' six Singapore hotels, including W Singapore at Sentosa Cove, stood at S$199 in Q3 2022.

site_title: South Korean truckers go on strike, posing risk to supply chain
summary: South Korean truckers, unionized by the Cargo Truckers Solidarity Union, launched their second major strike in six months, threatening to disrupt manufacturing and fuel supplies. The strike aims to secure a permanent minimum-pay system and expand benefits for truckers, with the government initially agreeing to extend the scheme for three years. However, the union rejected this offer and warned that the strike could stop oil supplies and transport at major ports and industrial plants, posing a risk to the country's economy, which is the 10th-largest globally.

images.alt_text: A member of the Cargo Truckers Solidarity union stands next to a LPG lorry in Ulsan, South Korea, June 10, 2022. REUTERS/Byungwook Kim

site_title: BR Metals tops this year’s E50 Awards
summary: BR Metals, a precious metals recycling firm, topped the Enterprise 50 (E50) Awards 2022 with innovative solutions such as an automated bulk sampling system. Yeap Medical Supplies took second place with a diversification strategy, while Apro Asian Protection came in third for investing in digital systems. The awards, now in its 28th year, recognize 50 enterprising local privately-held companies contributing to Singapore's economic development. Minister of State Low Yen Ling emphasized the need for constant innovation and growth to stay ahead, with 64% of E50 companies capitalizing on international expansion to drive revenue growth.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Reachfield Security & Safety Management clinches top accolade at E50 Awards 2021

site_title: US dollar on edge ahead of Fed minutes, kiwi gains
summary: The US dollar index remained flat at 107.1 ahead of the release of Federal Reserve minutes, while the New Zealand dollar strengthened after a record rate hike to curb inflation. The New Zealand dollar gained 0.7% to a three-month high, and the euro rose 0.1% after eurozone business activity eased slightly. Sterling gained 0.4% despite a contraction in British economic activity. China's economy remains uncertain due to a spike in Covid-19 cases, and cryptocurrencies remained volatile.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, PropNex, Apac Realty, Singapore Medical Group
summary: Keppel Corp will hold an EGM to vote on a proposed merger of its O&M unit with Sembcorp Marine. Apac Realty's ERA has lost 640 agents to PropNex, while PropNex remains the largest agency in Singapore. Singapore Medical Group's closing date for a voluntary conditional general offer to take the company private has been extended to Dec 5. SMG's shares rose 1.3% after the announcement, while PropNex shares fell 0.6%.

images.alt_text: Photo by Yen Meng Jiin: Interior and exterior of Apac Realty (ERA)

site_title: US new home sales unexpectedly rise in October
summary: US new home sales unexpectedly rose 7.5% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 632,000 units in October, defying rising mortgage rates and house prices. Sales surged in the Northeast and South, but declined in the Midwest and West. This rebound was contrary to economists' forecasts of a decline to 570,000 units. The median new house price was $493,000, a 15.4% increase from last year, with 470,000 new homes on the market.

site_title: Apac Realty’s ERA losing agents to PropNex: media report
summary: Apac Realty, which holds the ERA regional master franchise rights, reported a 8.5% decline in earnings to S$23.9 million for the first three quarters of 2022. Over 700 ERA agents left Apac Realty for rival PropNex Realty, with at least 640 joining PropNex, while 209 agents moved from PropNex to ERA. PropNex reported a 21.9% increase in Q3 net profit to S$17.6 million, while Apac Realty's revenue fell 3% to S$527.5 million.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
PropNex's net profit for the 3 months ending Sep 30, 2022, rose to S$18.2 million from S$15.5 million in the year-ago period.
Total revenue for the first three quarters of the year fell 3 per cent year-on-year to S$527.5 million from S$543.8 million, said Apac Realty, which holds the ERA regional master franchise rights

site_title: Biden needs Trade Promotion Authority; Republicans should grant it
summary: US President Joe Biden needs Trade Promotion Authority (TPA) to negotiate trade agreements with confidence that they will be approved by Congress. With Republicans gaining control of the House of Representatives, passing TPA is now feasible. Since 1979, 14 free trade pacts have been approved under TPA, including the US-Singapore agreement, but none without it. Biden's administration is pushing for TPA to facilitate trade deals, particularly with key allies like India and Japan, as seen in the recent Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity launch event.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden speaks about the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity at the Izumi Garden Gallery in Tokyo.
The meeting this week also comes as relations with China have deteriorated further after House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan last month amid threats and opposition from Beijing.

site_title: US new vehicle sales to be flat in November amid high interest rate
summary: US new vehicle retail sales are expected to be flat in November, with 933,402 units sold, a 0.3% decrease from November 2021. High interest rates and loan payment pressures are moderating demand, despite strength in demand, transaction prices, and retailer profits. Average monthly finance payment in November is expected to be $712, a 7.2% increase from November 2021. The trend is expected to continue into 2023, with a seasonally adjusted annualised rate of 13.9 million units.

images.alt_text: The layoffs will affect about 300 employees; impacted workers will be offered three months severance pay and other benefits, according to the email.

site_title: PropertyBT: Does freehold always trump leasehold? (Ep 13)
summary: Leslie Yee discusses whether paying a premium for a freehold home or one with a longer leasehold tenure is worth it, considering the risk of land lease decay in older leasehold private homes and resale HDB flats. Experts weigh in on the pros and cons of buying a home with 50 years of land lease left and the en bloc prospects for older private leasehold developments. Ultimately, it's a matter of weighing the benefits of a freehold against the potential risks of land lease decay.

images.alt_text: What are the risks posed by weaker economic growth and the adoption of remote working to the Singapore office market?
What are the risks buying new uncompleted homes off plan?

site_title: Economists see monetary policy tightening ahead despite easing inflation in October
summary: Economists predict Singapore will continue to tighten monetary policy despite a drop in inflation in October, as core inflation remains above the official target. Headline inflation eased to 6.7% year-on-year, while core inflation decreased to 5.1%. Experts warn that inflation risks remain on the upside, and a further tightening by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is possible in April's review, with some predicting an off-cycle move in January 2023. The MAS has maintained its inflation outlook, citing "significant" imported inflation and "pass-through costs" from firms amid resilient demand.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Food prices bucks the trend with inflation inching up to 7.1 per cent, from 6.9 per cent in the previous month.
Singapore’s 2023 growth forecast at 0.5-2.5%; 2022 forecast narrowed to ‘around 3.5%’

Singapore's official full-year growth forecast has been narrowed to between 3 per cent and 4 per cent, with second quarter growth revised downwards to 4.4 per cent year on year, slower than the earlier advance estimate of 4.8 per cent.
Singapore's trade growth is expected to be flat or slightly negative in 2023.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower ahead of Fed minutes
summary: US stocks opened lower on November 23, 2022, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's November meeting minutes for clarity on monetary policy. The Dow Jones fell 6.5 points, or 0.02%, to 34,091.57, while the S&P 500 dropped 3.3 points, or 0.08%, to 4,000.3. Apple shares also declined, contributing to the market's downward trend.

site_title: Japan’s Mitsubishi UFJ to buy two Asia units of Home Credit for 600 million euros
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Finance Group plans to buy the Philippines and Indonesian units of Home Credit Group BV for approximately 600 million euros. The deal aims to boost Mitsubishi UFJ's business in Asia, capitalizing on growth in emerging markets. Ultra-low interest rates and an aging population limit opportunities at home. The acquisitions will be made through Thailand's Bank of Ayudhya, which is owned by Mitsubishi UFJ.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO : People walk past a branch of Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group's bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ (MUFG) in Tokyo, Japan, May 16, 2016. REUTERS/Thomas Peter/File Photo                      GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: China widens Covid curbs, iPhone factory unrest adds to economy worries
summary: China has tightened its COVID-19 curbs, imposing lockdowns and restrictions in multiple cities, further darkening the outlook for its economy. The measures, which include shutting malls and parks in Beijing, have fueled widespread discontent and disrupted production at manufacturers like Foxconn, Apple's largest iPhone supplier. Analysts warn that containment efforts may fail, leading to more lockdowns and unprecedented economic damage, with the IMF urging China to adjust its COVID-19 strategy and boost vaccination rates.

images.alt_text: The IMF says that while China has weathered the initial impact of the pandemic well, growth has since slowed and remains under pressure because of Covid, the property sector and weakening global demand.

site_title: Sunak faces first Tory revolt over UK housing targets
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak faces his first major rebellion as 47 Conservative MPs oppose the government's mandatory housebuilding targets, citing concerns about voter backlash in their rural areas. The rebels argue local communities should have more say over where homes are built, with one MP, Damian Green, stating that national averages are meaningless in the real world. Despite the opposition, Sunak remains committed to the government's target of building 300,000 homes a year, and the bill is set to return to the House of Commons for debate on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Sunak says Britain’s exit from the EU had helped bring more freedom on matters like migration and regulation and had secured “proper control” of the country’s borders.

site_title: First accounting firm with HQ in metaverse is sued over FTX meltdown
summary: Armanino and Prager Metis, the first accounting firm to operate its headquarters in the metaverse, are being sued over their role in the FTX cryptocurrency exchange's collapse. An investor claims the firms issued certified audit reports giving FTX clean bills of health in March, despite a pattern of racketeering. The lawsuit alleges a racketeering conspiracy involving Prager Metis, Armanino, FTX co-founder Sam Bankman-Fried, and others. John J Ray III, who oversaw FTX's bankruptcy, described the situation as a "complete failure of corporate controls" and "complete absence of trustworthy financial information".

images.alt_text: FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried speaks at the Crypto Bahamas conference in Nassau on April 27, 2022. FTX's collapse has left an estimated 1 million creditors facing losses totaling billions of dollars.
FTX and Alameda Research, both one time pillars of the crypto market, unravelled with astonishing speed this month.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: UK’s National World drops plans to buy British news publisher Reach
summary: National World, a UK-based news publisher, has scrapped plans to acquire British publisher Reach, which owns the Daily Mirror and Sunday Mirror newspapers. The decision comes after National World received financial support to fund the potential deal, but deemed unfavourable circumstances as a barrier to proceed. The company cited no specific reasons for the decision, stating that the circumstances were not aligned to move forward with the offer.

site_title: Three of China’s biggest banks to provide support for property developers
summary: China's three biggest commercial banks, Bank of Communications, Agricultural Bank of China, and Bank of China, have agreed to provide fundraising support to struggling property developers, including Vanke and Midea Real Estate Holding. The banks will offer loans, bonds, and other financial assistance to help the developers overcome a liquidity crisis. The move is part of efforts by Chinese regulators to ease pressure on the debt-laden property sector, which accounts for about a quarter of China's economy.

site_title: BOJ to conduct digital yen trial with Japan’s 3 megabanks, others
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) plans to conduct a trial with Japan's three megabanks and regional banks on a digital yen, a potential central bank digital currency (CBDC), starting next spring. The trial will last about a year and will help verify issues such as deposits and withdrawals from bank accounts. The BOJ could decide to issue a digital yen as early as 2026, following a two-year verification period. This move comes after Governor Haruhiko Kuroda expressed interest in providing a retail CBDC to secure a seamless and safe infrastructure in Japan.

site_title: European Parliament declares Russia a state sponsor of terrorism
summary: The European Parliament has designated Russia as a state sponsor of terrorism, citing its military strikes on civilian targets such as energy infrastructure, hospitals, and schools. This move is largely symbolic, as the European Union lacks a legal framework to back it. The US State Department currently names four countries as state sponsors of terrorism, but US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has refused to list Russia despite resolutions in Congress urging him to do so. Four EU countries have already designated Russia as a state sponsor of terrorism.

site_title: Fidelity to join mutual fund-to-ETF club with US$430m flip
summary: Fidelity Investments plans to convert six of its mutual funds into exchange-traded funds (ETFs), with assets totaling around $430 million, in a move expected to boost the US ETF market. The conversion is expected to be completed in June 2023 and will bring Fidelity's active equity ETF lineup to 15 funds. The new ETFs will have an expense ratio of 0.50%, significantly lower than the current mutual funds' 1% expense ratio. This conversion is part of a growing trend of mutual fund-to-ETF conversions, which could potentially bring over $1 trillion in assets to the US ETF market in the coming decade.

images.alt_text: currencies

site_title: Easing eurozone downturn offers hope of milder recession
summary: The eurozone's downturn in business activity eased slightly in November, offering hope that the expected recession may be shallower than feared. However, a cost of living crisis led to consumers cutting spending. The S&P Global PMI index rose to 47.8, but remains below the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. The eurozone's dominant services industry declined, while manufacturing activity slowed but increased headcount. The data suggests a milder recession than initially expected, but inflation remains high, with the European Central Bank expected to raise interest rates next month.

site_title: Little Christmas cheer for UK retailers as consumers cut back
summary: UK consumers are cutting back on Christmas spending amid soaring inflation and economic recession, with retailers expecting a tough holiday season. The FTSE 350 Retailers Index has dropped 32% this year, and analysts predict further earnings downgrades. Consumers are reducing discretionary spend, opting for cheaper retailers and shifting to cheaper gift options. However, some supermarkets and discount retailers may benefit from consumers' frugality, while traditional retailers face a bleak outlook.

images.alt_text: Shoppers in Oxford Circus in the heart of London's retail shopping area. The typical UK household will take a permanent 3.7 per cent hit to its income with the increase in personal taxes, says the Resolution Foundation.

site_title: News Corp-Fox merger plan faces opposition from major shareholder
summary: News Corp and Fox Corp merger plan faces opposition from major shareholder Independent Franchise Partners, citing a combination on its own would fail to realize the company's full value. This is the second shareholder to express dissent, following Irenic Capital's suggestion of a spin-off of News Corp's digital real estate business or Dow Jones. The opposition raises concerns about the potential impact on the companies' value and future prospects.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Rupert Murdoch, Executive Chairman of News Corp and 21st Century Fox, takes part as a judge during a global start up showcase at the Wall Street Journal Digital Live (WSJDLive) conference at the Montage hotel in Laguna Beach, California, October 20, 2015. REUTERS/Mike Blake/File Photo

site_title: Singapore platform workers set to get same levels of CPF, injury coverage as employees
summary: Singapore's government has accepted recommendations to provide the same levels of Central Provident Fund (CPF) and work injury insurance coverage to platform workers as employees. The voluntary regime for workers aged 30 and above will be phased in over five years, with the full CPF scheme only applicable to those under 30. Platform companies will also be required to insure workers to the same level as employees under the Work Injury Compensation Act. The changes aim to protect platform workers and are expected to impact the industry's competitive landscape.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
NTUC noted that platform workers generally have modest incomes and may have insufficient CPF funds.

site_title: Iras waives GST for voluntary carbon credits
summary: Singapore's Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has waived Goods and Services Tax (GST) on the issuance, transfer, and sale of voluntary carbon credits, effective Wednesday, November 23, 2022. This move aims to foster the development of carbon credit markets in the nation. The waiver applies to digital representations of carbon credits, including tokenized and blockchain-based credits. The exemption is seen as a supportive measure for companies to set ambitious climate targets and take action in reducing emissions, with industry leaders welcoming the move as a testament to the government's commitment to establishing Singapore as a carbon services hub.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

The paper’s authors, KPMG Singapore tax partner Mark Addy and principal consultant of indirect tax Gan Hwee Leng, said the lack of clarity around the GST treatment of the voluntary trade of carbon credits is hindering the young market’s uptake.
Carbon tax likely to be raised to S$10-15, but rate needs to be higher to drive change: watchers

site_title: Gig-economy players raise concerns as Singapore unveils new worker protections
summary: Singapore has introduced new worker protections for the gig economy, including requirements for companies to insure workers to the same level as employees and contribute to the Central Provident Fund (CPF). The Digital Platforms Industry Association (DPIA) disagrees with exclusions for street-hail taxis and certain logistics companies, citing potential price and market distortion. The new regulations do not recognize platform workers as employees, but instead classify them as a new category of workers. The government aims to mitigate increased costs by phasing in the changes over five years.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
The Advisory Committee for Platform Workers took a nuanced, rather than broad-based approach.
Platform companies like Grab will be affected by the new regulations in Singapore.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as Federal Reserve eyes slower rate hike pace
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive session on Wednesday, driven by Federal Reserve minutes signaling a moderation in interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.3% higher at 34,194.06, while the S&P 500 advanced 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index added 1.0%. The release came after solid economic data, including strong US manufactured goods orders and new home sales. Individual companies like Deere & Co jumped 5.0% on higher profits, while Autodesk slumped 5.7% due to lower-than-expected free cash flow.

images.alt_text: A Wall Street sign in New York on May 25, 2018. MUST CREDIT: Bloomberg photo by Michael Nagle.

site_title: CAD launches probe into crypto platform Hodlnaut, directors
summary: The Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) of Singapore has launched an investigation into crypto platform Hodlnaut and its directors for possible cheating and fraud offences. The investigation was sparked by multiple reports alleging false representations about the company's exposure to a digital token. Hodlnaut had applied to the Singapore High Court for judicial management in August following the Terra-Luna collapse. The investigation is under sections 417 and 424A of the Penal Code, and the outcome will determine the directors' and company's actions.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

The interconnected collapses of companies including hedge fund Three Arrows Capital (above) and platforms Zipmex, Hodlnaut and Vauld have highlighted the lack of extensive risk management rules for digital asset companies.
Crypto platform Hodlnaut gets MAS nod for Major Payment Institution licence

site_title: UK's Royal Mail makes 'final' offer of up to 9% pay hike to union
summary: Royal Mail, the UK's postal service, has made a "final" offer of up to 9% pay hike to the Communication Workers Union (CWU) over 18 months, following months of pay dispute. The revised offer includes making Sunday working optional, "more generous" voluntary redundancy terms, and no compulsory layoffs until the end of March. The CWU, which represents 115,000 postal workers, had previously rejected a 7% salary increase over two years. The union has announced additional 10 days of strikes, but the revised offer may help resolve the dispute.

site_title: Impasse continues in Malaysia as King to hold meeting with fellow rulers
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah will meet with fellow Malay rulers on Thursday to discuss the appointment of the next prime minister and the formation of a new government, amid an impasse after the 2022 general election. The King had previously met with leaders from Barisan Nasional (BN) and Gabungan Parti Sarawak (GPS), but no progress has been made. The King's decree aims to form a unity government, with BN expected to be part of it, but the coalition has yet to decide on its stance.

images.alt_text: King Al-Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah is in the spotlight as he considers who will be the next prime minister, after both Anwar and Muhyiddin missed his Tuesday afternoon deadline to put together an alliance.

site_title: US mortgage rates plunge for a second week, hit two-month low
summary: US mortgage rates dropped for a second week, reaching a two-month low of 6.67% as of November 18, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This decline, nearly a half percentage point in two weeks, is the largest since 2008. The drop in rates led to a 2.8% increase in home buying applications and a 2.4% rise in refinancing activity. The housing market has been impacted by rapid mortgage rate rises this year, but the recent rate decrease may provide some traction.

images.alt_text: Demand for any kind of credit is strongest from consumers with high credit scores.

site_title: Maybank Q3 earnings up 28.5% to RM2.2b on higher revenue
summary: Malaysian bank Maybank posted a 28.5% increase in net profit to RM2.2 billion in the third quarter, driven by higher revenue and interest income. The bank's loans and advances segment grew 7.2% to RM146 billion, while impaired loans fell 59%. Maybank's capital adequacy ratios remained strong, and the bank outlined its focus on driving loans growth in key business segments amidst a rising-rate environment. The bank also maintained its headline performance indicator of a return on equity of 9.5-10% for FY2022.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Maybank net profit continue to fall in the second quarter of 2022 due to higher net impairment losses.

site_title: Commercial vehicle COE price hits new high at S$81,802, small car premium nears record
summary: Commercial vehicle COE prices reached a new high of S$81,802, with a 7.2% increase, while COE premiums for smaller cars closed near an all-time high at S$90,589, a 3.8% increase. The spike is attributed to a rush to register electric and petrol light commercial vehicles ahead of tax incentives reduction. Speculators are also taking advantage of the smaller COE quota to push up the resale value of Early Turnover Scheme (ETS) papers.

images.alt_text: COE prices are hitting records as extensions of old cars over the past few years hold up the availability of new supply.

site_title: AusGroup applies for judicial management
summary: AusGroup, a Singaporean integrated service solutions provider, has applied to the Singapore High Court for judicial management following a series of restructuring plans, potential asset sales, and resignations. The company, which has seen its shares plummet to S$0.009, is seeking interim judicial managers to oversee its financial obligations. This move comes after a trading halt and suspension, with discussions on asset sales and a restructuring plan underway. The judicial management application aims to address the company's financial position and potential sale of assets.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Shane Kimpton, chief executive officer of AusGroup

site_title: Malaysia’s Mahathir will focus on writing after poll defeat
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 97, has announced he will focus on writing after losing his re-election bid, his first electoral defeat in over 50 years. Mahathir came fourth in the Langkawi constituency election and accepted his loss without ruling out a return to politics. He plans to write about Malaysia's history, including events during British rule, and mourned the death of Queen Elizabeth II, saying she was a good example of a constitutional monarch.

images.alt_text: This handout photo taken on November 19, 2022 and released on November 20 by Malaysia's Department of Information shows former Malaysia prime minister Mahathir Mohamad showing his inked finger after casting his vote at a polling station during the general election in Kuala Kedah district, Malaysia's Kedah state. (Photo by Handout / Malaysia's Department of Information / AFP) / -----EDITORS NOTE --- RESTRICTED TO EDITORIAL USE - MANDATORY CREDIT "AFP PHOTO / MALAYSIA'S DEPARTMENT OF INFORMATION" - NO MARKETING - NO ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS - DISTRIBUTED AS A SERVICE TO CLIENTS  -

Malaysian King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah will be meeting his fellow Rulers on Thursday morning to discuss about the appointment of the next prime minister and the formation of a new government.

site_title: Foxconn confirms 'violence' at China iPhone factory
summary: Foxconn, Apple's principal subcontractor, has confirmed an outbreak of "violence" at its Zhengzhou factory in central China, where hundreds of workers clashed with security personnel in protests over pay and conditions. The company denied housing new recruits with Covid-positive staff, contradicting earlier reports. The incident occurred after a surge in Covid-19 cases at the facility, leading to a "closed loop" bubble to contain the virus. Foxconn will continue to communicate with employees and the government to prevent similar incidents.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A person riding a scooter wears a mask amid the outbreak of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), while passing a Foxconn office building in Taipei, Taiwan, July 14, 2020. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo

site_title: European Central Bank risks economic overkill with steep rate hikes
summary: The European Central Bank is at risk of causing an economic overkill with its steep interest rate hikes, according to ECB chief economist Philip Lane. Lane warned that the plan to continue with rate rises in the next few months is driven by high inflation and slowing economic activity in Europe. Despite a credit crunch warning, the ECB is poised to raise rates again in December, which could hurt highly indebted nations and European corporations. The bank's actions may lead to a sharp recession, with some economists warning of a "serious credit crunch."

images.alt_text: Rescuers at work at the site of a hospital destroyed by a Russian missile attack, in Vilniansk, Zaporizhzhia region, Ukraine, Nov 23, 2022.
The OECD says global GDP is set to grow 3.1 per cent this year – nearly half the rate for last year, and the slide will continue next year.
Britain’s government is considering giving the FCA powers to directly regulate ESG ratings providers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economic growth forecast for 2023 has been downgraded to 0.5-2.5% by the government, a range considered low by private-sector economists. The country also upgraded its 2022 full-year trade forecasts for the third time this year, projecting negative to flat trade growth for 2023. Inflation eased to 5.1% in October, while nearly 10,000 flats were launched in the November BTO exercise. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% amid a regional market rebound.

site_title: Qatar World Cup critics are unprepared for the rest of this century
summary: Criticism of Qatar's 2022 FIFA World Cup hosting has raised questions about Western nations' moral compromises in dealing with less democratic regimes. The backlash reflects a shift from relativism to a universal conscience, making it unaffordable for Western nations to judge others. The author argues that this stance is psychologically unprepared for the rest of the century, where the centre of global power is likely to creep away from established democracies. A modus vivendi will be necessary, requiring Western nations to navigate complex moral and strategic grounds.

images.alt_text: Migrant workers in Qatar watch the Qatar vs Ecuador match, Nov 20, 2022. Fifa had confirmed support for a permanent International Labour Organization (ILO) office in Doha that would support and advise migrant workers.

In September, Germany defender Thilo Kehrer (left) and midfielder Jonas Hofmann presented the captain's armband - a symbol against discrimination and for diversity - that many teams were planning to wear at the Fifa World Cup, to express condemnation for Qatar's human rights abuses.

site_title: Aftershocks, heavy rain hamper Indonesia earthquake rescuers
summary: A 5.6-magnitude earthquake in Indonesia's Cianjur region has caused extensive damage and killed 268 people, with over 150 missing. Rescue efforts are hindered by heavy rain and landslides, which have disrupted rescue workers. Authorities have deployed over 1,000 police officers and are bringing in heavy machinery to clear landslides. Despite concerns about the survival chances of those trapped, rescue teams continue their efforts, with helicopters scheduled to drop emergency supplies to cut-off villages.

images.alt_text:
Islamic students look at houses collapsed during Monday's earthquake in Cianjur, West Java province, Indonesia, November 23, 2022, in this photo taken by Antara Foto. Antara Foto/Raisan Al Farisi via REUTERS

ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY. MANDATORY CREDIT. INDONESIA OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN INDONESIA.     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: STI down 0.1% amid rebound in regional markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.1% to 3,255.99 at the closing bell on Nov 23, despite a rebound in regional markets. The decline was attributed to selling pressure after the index reached a peak of 3,320, with technical conditions moderating from overbought levels. Advancers beat decliners 282 to 240 in the broader market, with 1.1 billion securities worth S$822.8 million changing hands.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Gainers outnumber losers 91 to 27 after 31.6 million securities worth S$50.8 million changes hands.

site_title: Russia relaunches production of Soviet-era Moskvich at ex-Renault plant
summary: Russia has relaunched production of the Soviet-era Moskvich car at a former Renault plant in Moscow, with Kamaz stating that 600 vehicles will be produced this year. The ultimate target is to produce 100,000 vehicles annually, significantly lower than the industry average. The revived Moskvich may use a Chinese carmaker's design and engineering platform. The relaunch comes after Renault sold its majority stake in Avtovaz to the Russian state for a reported one rouble, with an option to buy it back in six years.

site_title: TikTok on 'high alert' in Malaysia as tensions rise over inconclusive election
summary: TikTok is on high alert in Malaysia following an inconclusive general election, with authorities warning of rising ethnic tensions on social media. The platform has removed videos violating its guidelines, including those referencing the 1969 May 13 riot, and has "zero tolerance" for hate speech and violent extremism. Malaysian authorities have also urged social media users to refrain from posting provocative content, while opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim has condemned racist sentiments and rhetoric. The situation remains tense as Malaysia's king prepares to meet with hereditary sultans to discuss the country's future government.

images.alt_text: TikTok's downsized ambition reflects a pullback in marketing spending worldwide as companies and consumers tighten budgets and prepare to ride out a potential recession.

site_title: Xiaomi’s revenue dives 10% after smartphone demand tanks
summary: Xiaomi's revenue dropped 10% in the quarter, primarily due to a 11% decline in mobile device sales. The company reported a surprise net loss of 1.5 billion yuan, attributed to a writedown of almost 3 billion yuan on investment losses. Global smartphone shipments are expected to decline 2.9% next year, partly due to consumers holding onto existing phones and lack of innovation in new models. Despite this, Xiaomi managed to gain market share in Europe, and its CEO is optimistic about future growth, particularly in electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi Corp. Mi smartphones on display inside the AliExpress plaza retail store, operated by Alibaba Group Holding Ltd., in Barcelona, Spain, on Wednesday, Jan. 13, 2020. U.S. officials deliberated but ultimately decided against banning American investment in Alibaba and Tencent Holdings Ltd., a person familiar with the discussions said, removing a cloud of uncertainty over Asia’s two biggest corporations. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

site_title: Explainer: The fine print in Singapore’s new regulations for platform work
summary: Singapore's new regulations for platform work aim to provide employee-like protections for ride-hailing drivers and delivery riders. The Advisory Committee on Platform Workers recommends that platform workers pay 20% CPF contributions, with platforms also contributing 17% of wages. However, workers aged 30 and above will have the option to opt-in to the full CPF regime. The regulations also introduce similar levels of work injury insurance as employees, with platforms responsible for compensating workers across multiple apps. Additionally, platform workers will have the right to formal representation and will be excluded from the advisory committee for street-hail taxi drivers and logistics companies using self-employed workers.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Platform companies like Grab will be affected by the new regulations in Singapore.

site_title: Singapore’s official 2023 growth forecast gloomier than expected: analysts
summary: Singapore's official 2023 economic growth forecast has been downgraded to 0.5-2.5% due to external economic and geopolitical headwinds, including a global slowdown in major economies like the US and Eurozone. The forecast is lower than market expectations, reflecting a cautious outlook from the Ministry of Trade and Industry. Despite this, the authorities do not expect Singapore to enter a recession, but growth is expected to moderate significantly, with a possible dip into negative territory in some quarters.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Food prices bucks the trend with inflation inching up to 7.1 per cent, from 6.9 per cent in the previous month.
Singapore's trade growth is expected to be flat or slightly negative in 2023.

site_title: Seizing opportunities in the face of adversity, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A recent report predicts that approximately 5.3 billion cell phones will become waste this year, with the majority being discarded in developing countries. The discarded phones pose significant environmental concerns, including the extraction of toxic materials such as cobalt, copper, and gold. The report highlights the need for sustainable e-waste management practices to mitigate the environmental impact of the growing number of discarded cell phones. Many organizations are calling for extended producer responsibility and improved recycling infrastructure to address the issue. The global e-waste crisis is expected to worsen unless immediate action is taken.

site_title: US$2b project in New York City’s Queens approved amid housing crisis
summary: The New York City Council has approved a $2 billion project, Innovation Queens, which will add over 3,000 homes in Astoria, Queens. The project, spanning five city blocks, includes 1,400 affordable units, exceeding the initial 700 units proposed by developers. The approval comes after weeks of contentious negotiations, with local council member Julie Won initially opposing the plan due to concerns about affordability. The development is expected to create 2,500 units of affordable housing, but completion is not expected until 2030. The approval is seen as a win, with city officials and advocates praising the increased affordable housing and the city's efforts to address the housing crisis.

images.alt_text: Estate agents advertising signs ‘For Sale’ and ‘To Let’ outside properties at a housing development in London, UK, on Thursday, Nov. 17, 2022. Finding a rental property in London can feel like an impossible quest, with prices surging as demand vastly outpaces the number of available units.Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Development financing framework needs an overhaul to help poor countries cope with climate disasters
summary: Developed countries have failed to meet their pledge of $100 billion annually for climate finance to poor countries, and the actual need is now estimated to be $1 trillion annually by 2025 and $2.4 trillion by 2030. The recently concluded COP27 Climate Summit agreed to establish a "loss and damage" fund, but the size and financing details remain unclear. The report "Finance for Climate Action" emphasizes the need for developed countries and multilateral development banks to contribute $1 trillion of the funding, with the rest sourced domestically. The current macroeconomic backdrop makes securing this capital challenging, with many developing countries at risk of debt distress.

images.alt_text: In this picture taken on September 26, 2022, internally displaced flood affected people drink water from a puddle outside a makeshift camp in Jamshoro district of Sindh province. - Sindh has been worst-hit by the catastrophic flooding which put a third of Pakistan underwater, displaced eight million, destroyed or damaged two million homes, crippled 1,500 hospitals and clinics and caused an estimated $28 billion in damages. (Photo by Rizwan TABASSUM / AFP) / To go with 'Pakistan-Floods-Health-Children-Climate' FOCUS by Ashraf KHAN and Joe STENSON

site_title: Bankman-Fried says collateral crashed by US$51b as FTX fell
summary: Disgraced FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried revealed in a letter that the collapse of the crypto exchange led to a US$51 billion loss in collateral, which plummeted from US$60 billion to US$9 billion. A credit squeeze, market downturn, and "run on the bank" contributed to the collapse, leaving liabilities at US$8 billion by the time of bankruptcy. Bankman-Fried apologized for the collapse and acknowledged his failure to realize the magnitude of the risk, but the bankruptcy proceedings have raised concerns about the exchange's lax documentation and financial controls.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China needs to adjust Covid policy, support property: IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) advises China to adjust its COVID policy and support the property market to spur economic growth. China has weathered the initial pandemic impact well but growth has slowed due to COVID, the property sector, and weakening global demand. The IMF forecasts 3.2% growth this year and 4.4% in 2023 and 2024. To boost growth, China should recalibrate its zero-Covid strategy and complete unfinished property projects.

images.alt_text: The Biden-Xi meeting sent “a very significant message to the world that international cooperation is important for all of us,” IMF director Kristalina Georgieva said.
P Nandalal Weerasinghe, governor of Sri Lanka central bank, says: “Budget has to look at what reforms are needed to ensure Sri Lanka remains stable and does not return to crisis.”

site_title: Nearly 10,000 flats launched in November BTO exercise
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched 9,655 build-to-order (BTO) flats in November, its largest such offering in a single launch to date. The flats are spread across 10 projects in mature and non-mature estates, with 5,861 units in non-mature estates. Eligible first-time applicants can receive an Enhanced Central Provident Fund Housing Grant of up to S$80,000, and prices for four-room flats in non-mature estates are below S$400,000. The median waiting time for flats is 4.5 years, with the Tengah projects having the shortest waiting time of 3.3 years.

images.alt_text: The sales exercise will begin on Nov 23, with the Housing Board launching over 9,500 units.

site_title: Tesla’s Musk sees South Korea as a top investment candidate
summary: Elon Musk expressed interest in investing in Tesla's electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure and expanding the company's supply chain in South Korea. A meeting between Musk and South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol discussed potential investments, including the construction of another gigafactory in Asia. Musk also plans to significantly expand EV charging infrastructure and increase parts purchases from Korean companies, with a goal of at least $10 billion in parts purchases by 2023.

images.alt_text: Tesla recently upgraded its Shanghai factory to double capacity to about 1 million cars a year.

site_title: Glencore to sell Australian copper mine to SPAC for US$1.1b
summary: Glencore has agreed to sell its Australian copper mine, Cobar, to Metal Acquisition Corp (MAC) for US$1.1 billion, with amended payment terms of US$775 million in cash and up to US$100 million common equity. The deal includes Glencore receiving the original agreed payment amount, but with adjusted terms. MAC, a US-listed SPAC, will need to raise at least US$125 million to fund the cash component of the deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of commodities trader Glencore is pictured in front of the company's headquarters in Baar, Switzerland, November 20, 2012.   REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Asia: Markets rise on rate hopes but China Covid casts shadow
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday, with traders hopeful for a halt in sharp US interest rate hikes, but concerns over a surge in China's Covid cases casting a shadow. US retailer earnings boosted Wall Street, while data suggesting the US economy is slowing gave policymakers room to tone down their hawkishness. Asian markets, including Hong Kong and Shanghai, rebounded, while Tokyo was closed for a holiday. However, a Covid outbreak in China and fears of a global recession remain a concern, with analysts warning that a major slowdown in the Chinese economy could spark a global recession.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) logo is displayed atop a gong at the HKEX Connect Hall in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Most Hong Kong people were caught off-guard by Beijing's proposal of the national security bill. Executive Council Member and the Chairman of HKEX Laura Cha said she was also surprised but was convinced the bill would ensure clarity and stability of the city. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg

site_title: Goldman Sachs to pay US$4m SEC penalty in ESG fund case
summary: Goldman Sachs will pay a US$4 million penalty to settle claims from the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) that its asset-management unit failed to properly consider environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors in some investment products from 2017 to 2020. The SEC alleged that Goldman Sachs lacked written policies and procedures for ESG research and did not consistently follow them. The penalty resolves claims that the bank's unit did not properly complete ESG questionnaires on companies before selecting them for investment portfolios.

images.alt_text: Strategists from Goldman Sachs say that a peak in interest rates and lower valuations reflecting the recession are necessary before any sustained stock-market recovery can happen.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group takeover offer deadline extended to Dec 5
summary: The voluntary conditional general offer to take Singapore Medical Group (SMG) private has been extended to December 5, allowing the offeror, TLW Success, to acquire more shares. As of November 22, TLW Success had obtained valid acceptances representing 89.35% of SMG's total shares. The offer remains conditional upon the offeror and its concert parties holding more than 90% of the company at the offer's close. The extended deadline provides TLW Success with additional time to meet the condition.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Dr Beng Teck Liang, CEO of SMG said the revised offer price is in appreciation of shareholders' continued support and also in view of the prevailing market conditions and business environment
Beng Teck Liang, chief executive of Singapore Medical Group. Beng is one of the 3 owners of TLW Success which launched a S$0.37 per-share offer to take the company private.
SMG CEO Beng Teck Liang believes that privatisation will provide greater flexibility to execute long-term investments.
Singapore Medical Group net profit up 78.8% to S$15.6m in FY21

site_title: US FBI joins Continental cyberattack investigation
summary: The US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has joined the investigation into a cyberattack on German automotive supplier Continental in August. Continental had previously stated it was investigating the theft of company data, which hackers had put up for sale on the darknet for $50 million after the company declined to pay a ransom. German security authorities initially led the investigation, with the FBI being brought on board. Continental has declined to comment further on the incident.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sticker with the logo of German tyre company Continental is pictured on tyres in Bourbriac, France, February 18, 2022. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo

site_title: Asia-Pacific listcos struggle with biodiversity impact, nature reporting: NUS study
summary: A study by the NUS Business School's CGS found that the overall nature disclosure rate among top Asia-Pacific listed companies is 31.4%, with Singapore's at 27.1%. The study highlights conflicts between measures to cut emissions and those focusing on pushing back biodiversity loss. For example, hydropower may be cleaner but exposes companies to risks of drought and water shortage, affecting crops and raw materials. The study emphasizes the need for more comprehensive nature reporting among companies in the region.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
An aerial view of the Johor Strait.

site_title: FTX was run as ‘personal fiefdom,’ faces hacks, missing assets: attorneys
summary: FTX, a major cryptocurrency exchange, filed for bankruptcy after a sudden collapse, leaving an estimated 1 million creditors with potential losses totaling billions of dollars. Former CEO Sam Bankman-Fried's firm was run as a "personal fiefdom," with $300 million spent on real estate for senior staff. The company faces ongoing challenges, including cyberattacks and missing assets, and is being investigated for potential wrongdoing. Bankman-Fried is accused of working with regulators to undermine the US bankruptcy case and shift assets overseas, and FTX is seeking to sell off healthy business units.

images.alt_text: The shuttering of FTX’s largest competitor, Binance, in Singapore back in December 2021 saw Binance users in Singapore switching to FTX.
Most of FTX’s purchases were luxury beachfront homes, including seven condominiums in an expensive resort community called Albany, costing almost US$72 million.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
FTX and Alameda Research, both one time pillars of the crypto market, unravelled with astonishing speed this month.

site_title: Volkswagen reaches wage deal with German union
summary: Volkswagen has reached a two-year wage deal with the German union IG Metall, covering around 125,000 workers. The deal includes a 5.2% wage hike from June 2023 and another 3.3% from May 2024, as well as a lump-sum payment to help offset inflation. The agreement, which is similar to others in the metal engineering industry, aims to curb inflation's impact on workers. The wage increase is below inflation rates in Germany, which stood at 11.6% last month.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Volkswagen logo is pictured in a production line at the Volkswagen plant in Wolfsburg, Germany March 1, 2019. Picture taken March 1, 2019. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer//File Photo

site_title: Violent protests erupt at Apple’s biggest iPhone plant in China
summary: Violent protests erupted at Apple's largest iPhone plant in China, with hundreds of workers clashing with security personnel over unpaid wages and fears of spreading infection. The protests, which began overnight, saw workers streaming out of dormitories, jostling past guards, and forcing their way past barricades. Several workers were injured, and anti-riot police arrived to restore order. The incident highlights the dangers for Apple of relying on a vast production machine in China amidst unpredictable policy and uncertain trade relations.

images.alt_text: Customers in the US who placed an order on Tuesday (Nov 22) would get an iPhone 14 Pro delivered in New York on Dec 30, after Christmas.

site_title: New ‘Avatar’ film gets rare China release
summary: Avatar: The Way of Water will be released in China on December 16, marking a rare foreign film release in the country. This follows other recent releases, including the Minions franchise and Where the Crawdads Sing. Despite strict quotas and content restrictions, Hollywood blockbusters have struggled to gain clearance in China, with recent Marvel movies and Black Panther: Wakanda Forever being denied releases. The Chinese film market has been impacted by Covid-19 curbs, leading to a significant decline in box office revenue.

site_title: Credit Suisse suffers US$1.6b Q4 loss, cash exodus
summary: Credit Suisse reported a potential loss of up to 1.5 billion Swiss francs (S$2.2 billion) for the fourth quarter, citing subdued activity, market conditions, and continued outflows of customer assets. The bank also reported 6% net asset outflows, equivalent to approximately 84 billion Swiss francs, in its wealth and asset management divisions. Credit Suisse is undergoing a sweeping overhaul, including a capital raise and headcount reduction, as it seeks to restore trust after years of scandals and management missteps.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse’s biggest round of job cuts in China comes at an awkward time for the firm.
Credit Suisse, which predicts the transactions will be completed by mid-2023, added that it expects Apollo to hire the majority of SPG staff.

site_title: Gold inches higher as dollar weakens; Fed minutes on radar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,741.80 per ounce, boosted by a weaker US dollar. Investors await the release of US Federal Reserve minutes, which may indicate further interest rate hikes. The Fed's recent 75 basis-point rate hike aims to tame inflation, with Kansas City Fed president Esther George suggesting a higher interest rate level may be needed. Spot silver remained steady, while platinum and palladium also saw gains.

images.alt_text: High interest rates discourage investing in gold, which does not bear any interest.

site_title: India’s Data Protection Bill has a privacy problem
summary: India's new Data Protection Bill has raised concerns over its potential to enable mass surveillance, as it allows government agencies to collect and use personal data without restrictions. The law's exemptions for government instrumentalities and vague guidelines for data transfer to foreign countries have sparked criticism. Critics argue that the bill's provisions will drive a wedge between India and Western democracies, undermining the country's commitment to strong privacy protection. The bill's impact on the country's adequacy assessments for personal data transfer to the European Union is also uncertain, with experts warning that an independent data protection board may be ineffective.

images.alt_text: Minister in charge of coal Pralhad Joshi says fuel is an affordable source of energy and demand for it has yet to peak in India.

site_title: NTU scientists turn waste paper into battery parts
summary: Researchers from Nanyang Technological University (NTU) have developed a method to turn waste paper into a component of lithium-ion batteries, reducing environmental impact and cost. The process, called carbonisation, converts paper into pure carbon anodes, which can be charged and discharged up to 1,200 times, making them more durable. This innovation uses less energy and heavy metals compared to current industrial methods, potentially lowering the cost of manufacturing battery anodes.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
A new Emerging Enterprise (EE) Sustainability Award will be launched, in an extension of the existing category within the EE Awards, said OCBC head of global commercial banking Linus Goh.

A German offshore wind farm that Keppel has invested in. The floating hybrid renewable energy system in Singapore consists of integrating offshore floating solar panels with other renewable energy technologies.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH upgrades GoTo to ‘hold’ on reasonable valuations
summary: UOB Kay Hian analyst Stevanus Juanda upgraded his call on GoTo Group to "hold" from "sell", citing reasonable valuations, market leadership, and an improving outlook. GoTo reported a 216.6% year-on-year increase in revenue for its third quarter, with a positive trend towards profitability. The brokerage lowered its target price to 190 rupiah and estimated net loss to 27.6 billion rupiah in 2022, and 24.66 billion rupiah in 2023. Juanda expects the group to benefit from high revenue growth, increased take rate, and efficient operation expenditure management.

images.alt_text: The company recorded higher expenses in the period compared to the same period last year. Sales and marketing expenses, in particular, were up at 11.27 trillion rupiah, from 4.72 trillion rupiah.
Employees packing goods at Goto's e-commerce unit Tokopedia's warehouse in Jakarta.

site_title: In Qatar, beer-starved football fans go on a quest for the elusive beer
summary: During the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, English football fans faced a challenge when Qatari authorities abruptly banned beer sales near stadiums, forcing them to seek alternative drinking venues. Fans discovered the Red Lion pub, a discreetly located hotel bar, which offered a "boozy oasis" for beer-starved supporters. Many fans adapted to the new rule, drinking in bulk before the match, but lamented the sudden change, which interfered with their pre-match drinking rituals and socialization. The ban was seen as a necessary measure to respect Qatari culture, but fans missed the traditional drinking experience.

images.alt_text: “Our team fulfils our dreams!” and “Where is Messi? We beat him!”, the green-clad Saudis chanted over and over in the Lusail Stadium, on their feet and greeting every clearance from their defence with a deafening roar.
England's teenage star Jude Bellingham celebrates after scoring the opening goal in his team's 6-2 thrashing of Iran at the World Cup in Qatar on Nov 21, 2022.
The first Fifa World Cup to be held in the Middle East will feature 64 matches over 29 days.

site_title: Malaysian King tells BN to join unity government; seeks Council of Rulers to resolve election crisis
summary: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Ahmad Shah has decreed that the former ruling bloc Barisan Nasional (BN) must be part of a unity government, following a hung Parliament election. BN has two options: form a government with opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim or ex-PM Muhyiddin Yassin. A special meeting of the Council of Rulers is scheduled to discuss the formation of a new government, with the King expected to pick a new prime minister. The uncertainty over the election prolongs political instability in Malaysia, which has had three prime ministers in as many years.

images.alt_text: Pakatan Harapan chairman Anwar Ibrahim speak to the media after the audience with the King.
The Malaysian king will now have to appoint a prime minister he believes enjoys the confidence of the majority.

site_title: Partnering up to solve manufacturing problems
summary: Singapore's Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre (ARTC) partners with companies to develop technological solutions.
