Industry players approach ARTC with problem statements, rather than researchers pushing solutions to the market. Tru-Marine, a marine company, has developed a predictive maintenance app, TruCare, in partnership with ARTC, which helps vessel owners reduce maintenance costs and carbon footprint. Abrasive Engineering, a small and medium-sized enterprise, has developed machines that combine two industrial processes, improving component lifespan and efficiency. ARTC's "industry pull" approach aims to connect service providers with vessel owners and operators, with Tru-Marine aspiring to be the Alibaba of the marine industry for repair and refurbishment.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்

Lim Soon Hock, Deputy Chairman and Senior Advisor, Tru-Marine. Featuring two SME profiles that have benefitted by working with A*Star’s Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre (ARTC): Abrasive Engineering, a local manufacturing SME that has been working with A*Star’s ARTC since 2012, as well as Tru-Marine, homegrown global marine SME specialising in turbocharger MRO. The features are also in line with A*Star's 10th anniversary on Oct 5.

Tan Ser Hean, MD, Abrasive Engineering Pte Ltd. The features are also in line with A*Star's 10th anniversary on Oct 5.

Dr David Low, CEO, ARTC. Featuring two SME profiles that have benefitted by working with A*Star’s Advanced Remanufacturing and Technology Centre (ARTC): Abrasive Engineering, a local manufacturing SME that has been working with A*Star’s ARTC since 2012, as well as Tru-Marine, homegrown global marine SME specialising in turbocharger MRO. The features are also in line with A*Star's 10th anniversary on Oct 5.

site_title: Is a wealth tax Xi’s answer to fill China’s empty coffers?
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has sparked speculation about a wealth tax to address the country's fiscal deficit, which is its largest in decades. The government's "common prosperity" drive aims to narrow the wealth gap, but experts argue that a wealth tax may not be enough to fill the void left by the real estate crackdown. China's biggest fiscal deficit and mounting debt have led to a decrease in local government revenue, prompting Beijing to explore alternative sources of income, including a potential wealth tax.

site_title: Iron ore futures extend losses over rising Covid cases in China
summary: Iron ore futures extended losses for a third straight session due to rising Covid-19 cases in China, the world's top steelmaker. Benchmark December iron ore rose 1.7% on the Singapore Exchange, while Dalian iron ore futures declined 0.4% on China's Dalian Commodity Exchange. Mainland China reported 29,157 new Covid-19 cases, deepening concerns about the economy and dimming hopes for a quick reopening.

images.alt_text: Copper cathodes inside a warehouse at a port south of Shanghai. China's refined copper imports have surged over 70 per cent so far this year to 1.1 million metric tons, while demand from Chinese manufacturers was forecast to rise by up to 7 per cent.
FILE PHOTO: A man walks by an iron ore blending site at Dalian Port, Liaoning province, China September 21, 2018. Picture taken September 21, 2018. REUTERS/Muyu Xu/File Photo

site_title: Chinese lender BoCom to provide developer Vanke with 100b yuan credit line
summary: Chinese lender Bank of Communications (BoCom) has agreed to provide a 100 billion yuan credit line to developer Vanke, offering loans for property development, mortgage loans, and mergers and acquisitions. This move is part of China's efforts to support the struggling property sector, which accounts for about a quarter of the economy. The agreement is one of 16 measures announced by Chinese regulators to ease pressure on debt-laden developers and reverse the severe housing slump.

images.alt_text: Onewo’s drop in its first day of trade in Hong Kong gives an indication of how investors are responding to new share sales by firms tied to Chinese developers.
Vanke owns 62.9 per cent of Onewo and is its biggest customer, regulatory filings showed.

site_title: Singapore’s core inflation in October eases to 5.1%, MAS and MTI stick to outlook
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased to 5.1% in October, down from 5.3% in September, driven by slower price increases in electricity and gas, retail, and other goods and services. Food prices bucked the trend, rising to 7.1% year-over-year. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) maintained their inflation outlook, sticking to a full-year forecast of 6% for headline inflation and 4% for core inflation.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore’s 2023 growth forecast at 0.5-2.5%; 2022 forecast narrowed to ‘around 3.5%’

site_title: Tesla revamps China marketing strategy as rivals lure customers
summary: Tesla is revamping its marketing strategy in China amid fierce competition from domestic rivals and uneven demand, which puts its growth plans in the world's biggest electric-car market at risk. The company has extended insurance subsidies, reinstated a user referral program, and advertised on a local TV shopping channel to boost sales. Despite cutting prices across its Chinese lineup, Tesla's sales are still struggling, with wait times shrinking to as little as one week from 22 weeks earlier this year. The company's CEO Elon Musk faces pressure to meet his target of 50% annual global sales growth.

images.alt_text: The insurance incentive is a cash rebate offered to buyers to buy insurance from Tesla’s partner insurers.

site_title: In US, inflation sparks tough Thanksgiving meal sacrifices
summary: In the US, soaring inflation has led to a surge in food prices, particularly for Thanksgiving meals. With turkey prices 21% higher than last year and cubed stuffing mix 69% more expensive, many are forced to make sacrifices. Some consumers are opting for alternative meats, such as fried chicken, while others are cutting back on side dishes like ham and stuffing. The average Thanksgiving meal now costs 20% more than in 2021, with retailers like Walmart offering competitive pricing to offset the increase.

images.alt_text: Shoppers crowd a supermarket to buy food ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday in Chicago, Illinois, U.S. November 22, 2022. REUTERS/Jim Vondruska

site_title: China central bank adviser sees GDP growth above 5% in 2023
summary: China's central bank adviser, Wang Yiming, predicts the country's GDP growth will exceed 5% in 2023 if Covid disruptions end and the government implements policies to boost confidence and consumption. This estimate is higher than the 3.3% forecast for this year and 4.5-5% proposed by another state-linked expert. Wang attributes the growth to recent policies addressing the property downturn and Covid controls, and notes that the PBOC will have room to adjust monetary policy in the first half of 2023 if the US Federal Reserve slows its interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Despite the curbs, shipments to China of the US equipment to make chips is unlikely to fall to zero.

site_title: China buys fewer chip-making machines as US restrictions start
summary: China's purchases of machines to make computer chips fell 27% in October from a year earlier, amid US-imposed sanctions. Shipments to China from the US dropped, but not to zero, as companies can still sell equipment for older, less advanced chips. China is the world's largest importer of semiconductors, and the US restrictions may hinder its efforts to develop a domestic semiconductor industry.

images.alt_text: American entrepreneur Camden Hauge owns the Egg cafe in central Shanghai. "People are not going to flick a switch and go back to the way life was before," she said.

site_title: BYD increases price of EVs, hybrids on input costs, subsidy end
summary: Chinese EV giant BYD is raising prices of some cars by 2,000-6,000 yuan (S$385) due to changes in government subsidies and volatile raw material costs. The price hike affects models not sold before Jan 1, 2023, as customers who paid deposits before that date won't be affected. BYD cited the phase-out of Chinese subsidies for pure electric and hybrid vehicles at the end of the year. The move comes as Tesla cut prices of China-made models in October to intensify competition in the world's largest EV market.

site_title: South Korea looks to spur exports to overcome slump
summary: South Korea's President Yoon Suk-yeol announced the government's plan to aid companies in promoting exports to key regions like South-east Asia to counter slowing economic growth. The country's economy is facing strengthening headwinds due to cooling global demand and fading spending at home. The OECD slashed its forecast for South Korea's economic growth for next year to 1.8%, down from 2.2% earlier. The government aims to explore opportunities in regions like the Association of South-east Asian Nations (Asean), where South Korea is the second-largest trade partner.

images.alt_text: A truck drives between shipping containers at a container terminal at Incheon port in Incheon, South Korea, May 26, 2016.REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: Credit Suisse plans deep China job cuts months after expansion
summary: Credit Suisse is cutting at least one-third of its investment-banking workforce and 40% of research staff in China, as part of a global reduction of 2,700 jobs. The moves come just two months after the bank agreed to spend $160 million to take full control of its securities business in China. The job cuts are part of a broader restructuring effort for the Zurich-based lender, which is seeking approval to expand its operations in China.

images.alt_text: Credit Suisse, which predicts the transactions will be completed by mid-2023, added that it expects Apollo to hire the majority of SPG staff.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.8%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.8% at the open on Wednesday, mirroring US market gains ahead of the holiday shopping season. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 24.32 points to 3,283.88, with gainers outnumbering losers 91 to 27. Top gainers included Singtel, up 1.9%, and Yangzijiang Financial, up 2.9%. The US Dow Jones Industrial Average jumped 1.2% and European shares rose 0.7% as investors looked towards the holiday shopping season.

images.alt_text: Asset manager BlackRock Inc becomes a substantial shareholder of Keppel Corporation.

site_title: Economist who called China’s housing slump sees slow recovery
summary: China's housing market is slowly recovering from a severe slump, but a full recovery is still distant, according to economist Lu Ting. The government's 16-point rescue package has provided relief for struggling developers, but measures to boost consumer confidence and stimulate demand for home purchases are still lacking. Lu expects a soft landing for the housing market, but notes that it's a multi-year process, and the economic reopening is unlikely until at least March due to the ongoing Covid Zero strategy.

images.alt_text: A woman rides an electronic bike past the China Evergrande Group. Royal Peak residential development in Beijing, China, on Friday, July 29, 2022. A mild rally in Chinese developers’ dollar bonds appears to be losing momentum, as investors express disappointment that a top leadership meeting failed to unveil stronger policy support for the crisis-ridden industry. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: World’s worst-performing stocks have Vietnam investors on edge
summary: Vietnam's stock market has suffered its worst performance this year, with the benchmark VN Index declining 36% due to government crackdowns on real estate companies, corruption probes, and tightening credit. The crisis has led to a cycle of selling to meet margin loan requirements, worsening losses for remaining investors. Vietnamese retail investors, who make up 85% of turnover, are particularly affected, with 80-90% of brokers reporting suffering losses. Despite some foreign investors seeing a buying opportunity, the nation's retail investors have a bleak outlook, with expectations shifting from growth to reducing losses.

images.alt_text: Coal makes up about half of Vietnam’s energy supply, yet its 2,000 miles of coastline are seen as ideal for generating wind power.

The AVA team met their client Dinh Van Thang, site manager of Phuoc Minh Adani Solar (second from right), at a solar plant in Ninh Thuan, Vietnam in April. From left to right is AVA solution architect Yip Chok Meng, CEO Lee Wei Yik and technical manager Theodore Teo.

site_title: Singapore expects trade growth of -2% to 0% for 2023; full-year forecast for 2022 upgraded
summary: Singapore upgraded its 2022 full-year trade forecasts for the third time, projecting 19.5-20% growth in total merchandise trade and 6% growth in non-oil domestic exports (NODX). However, the country expects flat to negative trade growth of -2% to 0% in 2023, driven by easing electronics trade and lower oil prices. Analysts predict a decline in Q4 2022 and Q1 2023, with a potential boost from China's reopening.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
While analysts agree on the gloomy export outlook, their opinions on the impact of a China reopening vary
Stacks of containers sit in the Tanjong Pagar terminal port in Singapore on June 17, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Investors should watch inflation and regulatory impact amid Grab’s cost cuts
summary: Grab, a ride-hailing and delivery company, has narrowed its net loss to US$327 million in Q3, despite burning through US$783 million in cash from operations over the past nine months. The company plans to deepen cost cuts, including reducing its regional headcount and repurchasing a US$750 million term loan. However, investors should watch for the impact of inflation and new regulations on gig workers in Singapore and beyond, which could lead to higher operating costs and potentially affect consumer behavior.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Grab riders and taxi drivers in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam.
Maybank says Grab appears “fairly valued” at the higher target price of US$3.40.

site_title: Holland Rise GCB site up for sale again with S$106m asking price
summary: A land site in the Holland Rise GCB area has been put up for sale with an indicative price of S$106 million, representing a 55% jump in asking price from its previous sale in January 2021 for S$68 million. The site can be subdivided into two to three GCBs, with a land area of 52,992 sq ft. Knight Frank expects keen interest due to limited landed homes in prime districts and high demand from foreign ultra-high-net-worth families.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Indonesia quake survivors appeal for supplies as rescuers trawl rubble
summary: Rescue efforts in Indonesia's Cianjur region continue after a 5.6-magnitude earthquake killed at least 268 people, with survivors appealing for food, water, and medical supplies. Debris from landslides is being cleared ahead of heavy rains forecast, threatening another disaster. Authorities have dispatched tents and supplies, but shortages remain, with residents struggling to find basic necessities like clothes and medicine. The country's meteorology agency warns of a potential second disaster, including landslides, as the rainy season peaks in December.

images.alt_text: Firefighters work to rescue a person at the site of a collapsed 7-11 store after a magnitude 6.9 earthquake, in Yuli township, Hualien County, Sept 18, 2022.
Medical workers treat the victims outside the district hospital after an earthquake hit in Cianjur in Indonesia's West Java on Monday (Nov 21).

site_title: New Zealand delivers record rate hike, flags more to come
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand raised the official cash rate (OCR) by 75 basis points to 4.25%, its highest since 2009, as it tries to combat stubbornly high inflation. The central bank also increased its projected peak for the cash rate to 5.5% in September 2023, exceeding market expectations. The move is part of the bank's hawkish monetary tightening path, with the cash rate expected to remain high into 2024.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk near the main entrance to the Reserve Bank of New Zealand located in central Wellington, New Zealand, July 3, 2017. REUTERS/David Gray

site_title: Qantas boosts weeks-old profit forecast as air-travel rebound accelerates
summary: Qantas Airways has upgraded its profit forecast for the final six months of 2022, citing a rebound in air travel demand. The airline now expects underlying profit before tax to be between A$1.35 billion and A$1.45 billion, A$150 million higher than its initial forecast. Revenue is accelerating due to flight bookings on Qantas and its low-cost division Jetstar, with net debt expected to fall to between A$2.3 billion and A$2.5 billion by December 31. This improved outlook allows Qantas to consider future shareholder returns and further reduce its borrowings.

images.alt_text: Travelers prepare to board a passenger aircraft operated by Qantas Airways Ltd. at Sydney Airport in Australia. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore’s 2023 growth forecast at 0.5-2.5%; 2022 forecast narrowed to ‘around 3.5%’
summary: Singapore's economy is forecast to grow between 0.5% and 2.5% in 2023, down from a previous forecast of 3-5%, according to the Ministry of Trade and Industry. The 2022 forecast has been narrowed to around 3.5% due to a slowdown in external demand and a decline in the electronics and chemicals sectors. The growth outlook remains cautious, with downside risks including rising interest rates and geopolitical tensions. However, the aviation and tourism sectors are expected to remain buoyed by strong travel recovery, and the services sector is expected to provide an offset to manufacturing weakness.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
While analysts agree on the gloomy export outlook, their opinions on the impact of a China reopening vary
In 2023, Singapore's growth is likely to be dragged by the trade-related cluster amid weaker external demand., according to Monetary Authority of Singapore's half-yearly macroeconomic review.

Gross domestic product (GDP) in Q3 expanded 4.4 per cent year on year, but economists believe this is unlikely to be repeated in the coming quarters amid headwinds from tighter monetary conditions, high inflation and geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Former Meta exec joins Wavemaker as general partner
summary: Andy Hwang, a former Meta executive with 10 years of experience and over 60 personal investments in startups, has joined Wavemaker Partners as its new general partner. He will join the investment committee and work with managing partner Paul Santos to grow the organization, also sitting on the boards of portfolio companies. Hwang's background in Silicon Valley and his experience as an angel investor and startup coach will be an asset to Wavemaker Partners as it continues to grow and support innovative companies.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
L-R: Wavemaker Impact founding members Quentin Vaquette, Doug Parker, Marie Cheong, Paul Santos and Steve Melhuish.

site_title: Crypto ATM operator Coin Cloud discussed equity from Genesis
summary: Coin Cloud, a Bitcoin ATM operator with over 4,000 locations, is seeking additional capital from Genesis, a digital asset brokerage. Genesis had previously provided an unsecured loan of around $100 million and considered injecting equity into Coin Cloud. However, Coin Cloud's debt restructuring efforts are ongoing, and its rescuer's financial struggles may impact the deal. Genesis is also seeking $1 billion in fresh capital, warning potential investors it may file for bankruptcy if efforts fail. The situation highlights the challenges faced by digital asset companies amid market volatility.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, Genesis Global Capital suspended customer redemptions in its lending business.

site_title: FIS to cut thousands of jobs as new CEO targets costs
summary: Fidelity National Information Services (FIS) plans to cut thousands of jobs, with the goal of delivering at least $500 million in cost savings, as part of its new CEO Stephanie Ferris's strategy to win back investor confidence. The job cuts are expected to be gradual and may affect several thousand staffers and contractors, with a total of over 65,000 employees at the end of last year. Ferris aims to permanently reshape the company's cost structure through cost-reduction and containment initiatives, while also focusing on improving its e-commerce business.

images.alt_text: Beijing’s tech crackdown, which ensnared sectors from e-commerce to fintech and even education over a tumultuous year, spread to online gaming in August 2021.
Employees packing goods at Goto's e-commerce unit Tokopedia's warehouse in Jakarta.

site_title: Hong Kong loses top ranking for luxury shopping to New York
summary: Hong Kong has lost its top ranking as the world's most expensive retail district due to a downturn caused by strict Covid measures and a closed border with mainland China. Manhattan's Upper Fifth Avenue now holds the title, with average rents of $2,000 per square foot, a 14% increase from pre-pandemic levels. Hong Kong's Tsim Sha Tsui district comes second, followed by Italy's Via Montenapoleone in Milan.

images.alt_text: It was the third consecutive quarter of year-on-year contraction for Hong Kong’s GDP, and marked the worst contraction since the second quarter of 2020.

site_title: Battling inflation 'priority' as global growth slows: OECD
summary: The Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) has forecast global GDP growth to slow to 3.1% this year, down nearly half from last year, and further decline to 2.2% in 2023. The slowdown is attributed to decades-high inflation, driven by the largest energy crisis since the 1970s, and is expected to continue into 2024. The OECD recommends tightening monetary policy and targeted government support to combat inflation, which is expected to reach 8% in the fourth quarter of this year and 5.5% in 2024.

images.alt_text: A group of trucks parked as a protest at the Uiwang Inland Container Depot in Uiwang, South Korea, on Friday, June 10, 2022. Thousands of truck drivers who are seeking to prevent a change to wage rules have gone on strike at major ports and container depots, posing the latest threat to strained global-supply chains. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: Rolex plans major 1 billion Swiss francs expansion in Switzerland
summary: Rolex is planning a major 1 billion Swiss francs expansion in Switzerland, set to create approximately 2,000 new jobs. The new facility in Bulle, Switzerland, is expected to begin operations in 2029. This expansion follows the company's current production of around 1 million watches a year, generating sales of approximately 8 billion Swiss francs. An official deal for the acquisition of land is set to be signed next month, with Rolex remaining tight-lipped on the matter.

site_title: Germany to cap investment guarantees for China
summary: Germany plans to cap investment guarantees for Chinese companies, aiming to reduce its dependence on Beijing. The country's economy minister, Robert Habeck, announced the overhaul of the investment support programme, which would be subject to a quota and environmental and social standards checks. The limit would be around €3 billion (S$4.3 billion), after which companies would no longer receive taxpayer-backed guarantees. This move follows concerns over human rights and China's ties with Russia, and is seen as part of Germany's efforts to diversify its economic relationships.

site_title: FTX has US$1.24b cash balance ahead of  bankruptcy hearing
summary: FTX, a cryptocurrency exchange, has a total cash balance of $1.24 billion ahead of its bankruptcy hearing, exceeding previously thought amounts. The cash includes $400 million at Alameda Research and $172 million at FTX's Japan arm. This news comes as the collapse of FTX has left an estimated 1 million creditors facing billions of dollars in losses, with some firms, like Genesis, struggling to avert bankruptcy and others, like Gemini, continuing to work with FTX's partners.

images.alt_text: The shuttering of FTX’s largest competitor, Binance, in Singapore back in December 2021 saw Binance users in Singapore switching to FTX.

site_title: South Korea seen opting for smaller interest-rate hike on credit risks
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea (BOK), is set to deliver a smaller interest-rate hike to address inflation concerns without exacerbating credit risks, which threaten the nation's economic growth. Fifteen economists predict a 25 basis-point rate hike to 3.25%, down from previous expectations of a 50 basis-point increase. The move aims to maintain financial stability amid growing concerns about a liquidity crunch in the bond market and a slowdown in economic growth.

images.alt_text: Exports are poised to weaken further as China’s economy slows and global chip demand eases.

site_title: Global banking sector well capitalised amid  uncertainty, but China is still a risk factor for Apac players
summary: Global banks are well-capitalized and resilient in the face of macroeconomic risks in 2023, thanks to strong fundamentals and asset quality. Singapore banks, in particular, are expected to perform well due to their strong net interest margins and low-cost customer deposits. However, China's economic uncertainty and property market downturn will be a crucial factor determining the health of the Asia-Pacific banking sector, with potential risks to local banks' revenue and asset quality.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
CPF could be on the brink of adjusting Special Account interest rates, as 10-year Singapore government bond yields have climbed to more than 3.1 per cent
So far, government measures to help the property sector have largely been piecemeal and focused on getting under-construction homes completed, not helping developers meet debt obligations.
The Chinese equity market has largely priced in the negative economic environment and are over-sold.

site_title: US: Stocks rise as tech shares rally
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping nearly 400 points, or 1.2%, to 34,098.10. Tech shares, including Meta and Alphabet, drove the gains as retailers reported strong earnings ahead of the holiday shopping season. Best Buy surged 12.8% after beating expectations, while Dollar Tree fell 8% due to higher costs. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also advanced 1.4% each.

site_title: New York judge sets fraud trial date for Trump
summary: A New York judge set a trial date of October 2, 2023, for a civil lawsuit against Donald Trump and his three eldest children, accusing them of fraud in a case brought by the state's attorney general. The lawsuit alleges that Trump and his family members misstated the value of properties to enrich themselves. The trial date may complicate Trump's potential run for a second term in office, which he announced last week, and comes close to the start of primaries season for the 2024 Republican presidential nomination.

images.alt_text: Jack Smith, chief of the Department of Justice's Public Integrity Section, leads discussion of a mock trial session in Washington, Feb 27, 2014. On Nov 18, 2022, Smith was appointed as special counsel to helm the DOJ’s criminal investigations into Donald Trump’s role in events leading up to the Jan 6 attack on the Capitol and his handling of sensitive government documents.
President Biden riding along the beach at Kiawah Island, South Carolina earlier this year; as a society, the United States is ageing, and working until later in life

The defeat of many Trump-endorsed Republican candidates in the recent US midterms Donald spelt the third electoral loss to date for Donald Trump : he lost the last presidential election, and Republicans also failed to maintain control of the two chambers of Congress in 2020.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial, Heliconia team up to invest up to S$150 million in SMEs
summary: Yangzijiang Financial and Heliconia Capital have partnered to invest up to S$150 million in Singaporean and South-east Asian small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through the Heliconia Generation Fund Limited Partnership. Yangzijiang Financial will contribute S$80 million as the anchor limited partner, with investments in promising SMEs focusing on Singapore and Vietnam. The fund aims to catalyze more capital for these businesses, co-investing alongside other Heliconia funds.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Yangzijiang Financial Holding  executive chairman Ren Yuanlin.
DBS analyst Ho Pei Hwa believes that the market has "overlooked" Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's earnings growth potential and ESG transformation into the clean vessel space.

site_title: HP to cut up to 6,000 jobs over three years as PC demand falters
summary: HP plans to cut up to 6,000 jobs over three years due to a sustained downturn in PC demand, which has cut into profits. The company expects a 10% decline in computer sales in the fiscal year ending in October 2023. Earnings per share are forecasted at $3.20-$3.60, below analyst estimates. CEO Enrique Lores described the market environment as "challenging."

images.alt_text: Lenovo Group remained the top global PC maker, although its shipments fell around 15 per cent, according to Gartner.

site_title: US says G7 should soon unveil price cap level on Russian oil, adjust regularly
summary: The Group of Seven nations, including the US and EU, will soon announce a price cap on Russian oil exports, set to begin on December 5. The cap aims to reduce petroleum revenues for Russia's war machine while maintaining oil flows to global markets. Companies can provide services on Russian oil imports under the cap, and the US does not expect Russia to retaliate by withholding oil exports, as it's not in their interest. The price cap is meant to provide a relief valve to Western bans on Russian oil exports.

images.alt_text: Analysts say that fuel demand in China is unlikely to recover until after March 2023, limiting global oil price gains.
Brent crude rose 91 cents, or 1 per cent, to settle at US$88.36 on Tuesday.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Yangzijiang Financial, EC World Reit
summary: Asset manager BlackRock Inc became a substantial shareholder of Keppel Corporation after purchasing 87,600 shares for about S$650,000. This increased BlackRock's stake in Keppel to 5% from 4.99%. Yangzijiang Financial partnered with Heliconia Capital to invest in Singaporean and South-east Asian small and medium-sized enterprises, contributing S$80 million to the fund. EC World Reit's board of directors assessed that the trust will remain a going concern, with discussions underway to refinance loan facilities maturing by end-April 2023.

site_title: Oil rises 1% as Opec+ focus on supply cuts outweighs recession concerns
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Tuesday, with Brent crude settling at $88.36 and US West Texas Intermediate crude at $80.95, as Opec+ maintained output cuts despite recession concerns. Saudi Arabia denied reports of boosting output, while the European Union watered down its price cap proposal for Russian oil exports. Analysts cut forecasts for China's year-end oil demand, tempering price gains, but prices are expected to remain supported by Opec+ and US Federal Reserve interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures for January settled at US$87.45, shedding 17 cents.

site_title: Beijing shuts parks, museums as Covid cases spike
summary: China's capital, Beijing, has shut parks, malls, and museums due to a spike in COVID-19 cases, with 28,127 new domestically transmitted cases reported on Monday. The city's residents are being required to show proof of a negative test not older than 48 hours to enter public buildings. The measures are part of China's zero-COVID policy, which has been adjusted to target clampdown measures and avoid blanket lockdowns. The surge in cases has deepened concerns about the economy and dimmed hopes for a quick reopening, with some analysts predicting a slow growth rate for China's economy.

images.alt_text: American entrepreneur Camden Hauge owns the Egg cafe in central Shanghai. "People are not going to flick a switch and go back to the way life was before," she said.

site_title: Manchester United owner weighs sale of historic football club as Ronaldo exits
summary: The Glazer family, owners of Manchester United, are exploring strategic options that could lead to a full or partial sale of the historic English football club. The process, advised by The Raine Group and Rothschild and Co, aims to ensure the club's success and serve its fans. The sale, which could value the club at around £5 billion, comes after Cristiano Ronaldo's departure from the team due to a public spat with management. The move follows Chelsea FC's £4.25 billion sale in May and could attract big-name investors.

images.alt_text: Annual revenue at Manchester United, controlled by the American Glazer family and listed in New York, rose 18 per cent to £583 million (S$934.4 million) in the year to the end of June.

site_title: China’s Baidu beats Q3 revenue estimates as ad sales recover
summary: Baidu, China's search engine giant, reported a 2% revenue increase to 32.54 billion yuan in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company's ad sales recovered from lockdowns caused by strict zero-Covid policies, while its cloud and AI businesses grew 25% year-over-year. Baidu's operating income rose to 5.32 billion yuan, and the company's self-driving technology business, Apollo Go, operated over 474,000 rides during the quarter. The company's AI business is not significantly impacted by recent US chip export restrictions.

site_title: Diversification is underway, Scholz says as German business warns against hurting China ties
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz stated that businesses are diversifying and preparing for a more multi-polar world, avoiding a repeat of Germany's reliance on Russia. He emphasized that Germany is not damaging ties to China, its largest trading partner, despite a major industrial player warning against it. Scholz expressed confidence in the country's ability to adapt to a changing global landscape, citing the need to build ties with other markets and reduce dependence on a single country. This move aims to ensure Germany's economic stability and security in a more interconnected world.

site_title: Britain takes first step to regulate company ESG raters
summary: Britain's Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is considering giving itself powers to regulate ESG ratings providers. The FCA wants the sector to develop and follow a voluntary code of conduct, reflecting recommendations from IOSCO, to increase transparency and ensure good governance. This step aims to address concerns about greenwashing and over-inflated ESG claims. The code will apply to providers of ESG ratings, which have been used to guide trillions of dollars in sustainable investments globally.

site_title: iPhone delays weigh on Apple ahead of holiday season
summary: Apple's iPhone delays weigh on the company ahead of the holiday season, with wait times reaching record levels of 34 days due to Covid lockdowns at a Chinese plant. This could lead to analysts trimming their earnings estimates for the quarter, potentially pressuring Apple's stock price. The disruptions could result in flat iPhone revenue year-over-year, rather than the expected 2% growth, and may impact holiday sales. However, some analysts believe delayed orders could still be made, providing a potential silver lining for the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Apple iPhone 14 Pro is seen at the Apple Fifth Avenue store in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., September 16, 2022.  REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Nomura warns seven emerging economies face currency crisis danger
summary: Nomura has warned that seven emerging economies, including Egypt, Romania, Sri Lanka, Turkey, Czech Republic, Pakistan, and Hungary, are at high risk of currency crises due to rising risk scores. The bank's "Damocles" warning system, which assesses 8 key indicators, shows a sharp increase in scores, with 22 countries seeing a rise since May. The overall score has increased to 2,234, indicating a 64% chance of a currency crisis in the next 12 months for countries above 100.

site_title: Saudis stun Messi’s Argentina with 2-1 comeback win
summary: Saudi Arabia stunned Argentina 2-1 in a World Cup match, marking one of the biggest upsets in tournament history. Lionel Messi, seeking his only major World Cup title, scored a 10th-minute penalty but Saudi Arabia mounted a strong comeback in the second half, scoring two goals to secure the victory. The win was a surprise given Saudi Arabia's low ranking as the second-lowest team in the tournament, with the crowd of 88,012 fans enthusiastically chanting "Where is Messi? We beat him!"

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher as oil stocks rebound
summary: Europe's shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, rebounding from a previous session's decline, as oil stocks climbed 4.8% following a statement from top exporter Saudi Arabia reaffirming Opec+ output cuts. The Stoxx 600 index has nearly doubled from its September lows, driven by better-than-expected earnings and hopes of less-aggressive interest rate hikes from the US Federal Reserve. European Central Bank officials have mixed views on interest rate increases, with some favoring smaller hikes and others expecting more significant moves.

site_title: Developing countries win big at COP27 – but only in theory for now
summary: Developing countries at the COP27 climate conference have secured a historic moment with the creation of a loss-and-damage fund, allowing them to receive funding for permanent losses from extreme weather events. The fund, which was established after years of pushing by developing countries, aims to provide funding for countries most vulnerable to climate change. However, the actual disbursement of funds is expected to take several years, with negotiations on who pays, how it's disbursed, and sources of financing set to continue until COP28.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

Climate activists demonstrate calling upon the G20 conference to adhere to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius compared to pre-industrial levels, at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, during the COP27 climate conference, on November 16, 2022. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)

site_title: BlackRock becomes substantial shareholder of Keppel
summary: BlackRock, a global asset manager, has become a substantial shareholder of Keppel Corporation after acquiring 87,600 shares for S$650,000, lifting its stake to 5% from 4.99%. The acquisition brings BlackRock's total interest in Keppel to approximately 87.7 million shares. The shares of Keppel Corporation rose 0.4% to S$7.41 following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: UK investigating Apple, Google mobile browser dominance
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) launched an investigation into the dominance of Apple and Google's mobile browsers, following substantial support for a fuller investigation from UK businesses and web developers. The CMA aims to determine if Apple restricts cloud gaming through its app store and identify steps to improve competition and innovation. Google claims its Android mobile operating system offers users more choice and flexibility, while Apple says it will "constructively" engage with the CMA to explain its approach. The investigation is part of growing global scrutiny of tech giants' market power.

site_title: EC World Reit to remain a going concern, in discussions with lead loan lenders for repayment
summary: EC World Real Estate Investment Trust (EC World Reit) has assessed that it will remain a going concern despite facing loan repayment challenges. The Reit manager is in discussions with lead lenders to refinance the remaining loan facilities maturing by April 30, 2023. The company had previously announced an extension of the maturity date and a plan to repay at least 25% of the loan principal by the end of 2022, but the mandatory repayment remains to be completed.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
EC World Reit's manager says that "stringent" Covid-19 controls and holidays in October have caused delays in lenders’ internal approval processes for the transaction financing.
The manager of Suntec Reit says its stronger operational performance was weighed down by interest rate and exchange rate pressures.

Aims Apac Reit reported higher H1 FY2023 gross revenue and net property income.  This was supported by the acquisition of Australian supermarket and grocery chain Woolworths’ headquarters, and higher rental income and recoveries from the Singapore portfolio.
Goh Toh Sim, executive director and chief executive of the EC World Reit's manager, said the results are “consistent with the improving stability in China during the quarter”.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly up after mixed retailer earnings
summary: US stocks rose early Tuesday, November 22, as retailers reported mixed earnings before the holiday shopping season. Best Buy's earnings topped analyst expectations, driving its shares up 8%, while Dollar Tree fell 8% due to cost concerns. The Dow Jones Industrial Average increased 0.5% to 33,879.20, while the S&P 500 gained 0.3% to 3,961.85. Analysts predict increased sales during the holiday season, but with inflation rates at multi-decade highs, limiting discretionary purchases.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: US dollar cedes some ground, bitcoin hunkers down
summary: The US dollar retreated on Tuesday, losing some ground after rallying the previous day due to concerns about China's Covid flare-ups and fears of fresh contagion from the collapse of crypto exchange FTX. The euro rose 0.3%, sterling gained 0.46%, and the yen fell 0.6% against the US dollar. More cautious remarks from US Federal Reserve officials also contributed to the dollar's decline. Bitcoin fell to a two-year low of $15,479, while the eurozone's current account deficit narrowed in September.

site_title: Laboratory group LMS Compliance to raise S$3.6 million in Catalist listing
summary: LMS Compliance, a Malaysia-based provider of testing and certification services, has launched its initial public offering (IPO) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to raise S$3.64 million. The company aims to use the funds for acquisitions, joint ventures, and strategic alliances, as well as expanding its business segments. With a market capitalization of S$22.7 million and a price-to-earnings ratio of 12.4 times, LMS Compliance plans to increase its test range and expand into new sectors, including oil and gas, agriculture, and hotels.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi

site_title: Higher-yielding bond alternatives – with some guardrails for risk
summary: Global interest rates have risen as central banks combat inflation, increasing bond yields. In Singapore, the Singapore Overnight Rate Average (SORA) has risen, causing the yield on Singapore Government Securities (SGS) to increase. Investors are flocking to lower-risk T-bills and bonds, but alternatives like quasi-sovereign bonds and retail bonds offer yield pick-ups. Quasi-sovereign bonds, such as those from the Housing Development Board and Land Transport Authority, have government support and offer yields of 4.25% and 4.21% respectively. Retail bonds, like those from Astrea and Temasek, offer investment-grade ratings and quoted spreads above SGS bonds.

images.alt_text: Due to overwhelming interest, the MAS put out a notice in the afternoon to announce the delay in publication of the results of the latest six-month Treasury bill auction.

site_title: Indonesia’s Sirclo cuts 8% of staff
summary: Indonesia-based tech startup Sirclo has laid off 8% of its employees, citing "challenging macroeconomic conditions." The company, which acquired Warung Pintar in January, aims to focus on long-term growth by streamlining its business units targeting micro, small, and medium enterprises. Sirclo, backed by investors including East Ventures, has raised $85.9 million in equity funding. The move follows a wave of tech layoffs across the region, with companies like GoTo and Sea also cutting staff to conserve cash amid an economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Flash Coffee opens over 250 outlets across seven countries in two years after raising millions of dollars from investors.

site_title: China set to fine Ant more than US$1b
summary: Chinese authorities plan to impose a fine of over $1 billion on Ant Group, a financial technology firm, as part of a regulatory overhaul. The fine could be imposed in the second quarter of next year and marks a sign of the end of a years-long crackdown on the private sector. Ant has been restructuring its operations, including beefing up capital and curbing consumer lending, in preparation for a financial holding licence that would place it under similar restrictions as traditional banks.

images.alt_text: Alibaba, which runs China’s largest online marketplaces Tmall and Taobao and owns a wide range of businesses from logistics to cloud services, reported net loss attributable to shareholders of 20.56 billion yuan in the quarter.

site_title: Stars aligning for China’s recovery
summary: China is recalibrating its COVID controls and property market support measures, indicating a shift towards easing the two main drags on the economy and asset markets. The relaxation of COVID controls and property market policies signal a significant policy pivot, with the goal of increasing public confidence and boosting economic growth. If implemented effectively, these measures could lead to a stronger-than-expected 2023 GDP growth and a market recovery in the property sector, potentially lifting global risk appetite and boosting sentiment in Chinese assets.

images.alt_text: American entrepreneur Camden Hauge owns the Egg cafe in central Shanghai. "People are not going to flick a switch and go back to the way life was before," she said.

site_title: Australia may have to live with more volatile inflation, says RBA
summary: Australia's Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe says the country may have to live with more volatile inflation due to global supply shocks, making it harder to keep inflation within a 2-3% target range. Lowe suggests reviewing the target, citing trends such as trade restrictions, declining working-age populations, and climate change, which are adding to costs. Lowe reiterates that domestic inflation is too high and interest rates need to be increased to bring it down, but warns that monetary policy will be more challenging due to supply shocks.

images.alt_text: Australia’s high household debt and large share of mortgages on variable rates or resetting to them soon points to relatively strong transmission.

site_title: Malaysia King to decide on next PM as no coalitions secure majority support
summary: Malaysia's King will decide on the next Prime Minister after no coalition secured a majority support. The King met leaders of Pakatan Harapan (PH) and Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalitions, but neither secured 112 seats needed to form a government. PH has 82 seats, while PN holds 73 seats. The King will hold an audience with 30 BN MPs on Wednesday to help resolve the deadlock. Analysts predict possibilities include a new PM appointment, minority government, or a fresh election. The divided opinions within BN led to its decision not to support any coalition, leaving the King's decision crucial to forming a government.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian king will now have to appoint a prime minister he believes enjoys the confidence of the majority.

site_title: The COP jamboree desperately needs a reboot
summary: The COP27 climate conference in Egypt has concluded with widespread frustration among participants that the UN-sponsored events are no longer fit for purpose. Many agree that the system, which led to the 2015 Paris agreement, is not doing enough to meet its goal of cutting greenhouse gases. Veteran insiders, including Tom Rivett-Carnac, a former UN climate official, say the COPs need a reboot to focus on reducing emissions and implementing action. The conference's closing session was marked by fractious haggling, highlighting the need for a significant overhaul of the COP system.

images.alt_text: Egypt's Foreign Minister Sameh Shukri, heads the closing session of the COP27 climate conference, at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, on November 20, 2022. (Photo by JOSEPH EID / AFP)

site_title: The best time to sell a share
summary: A private investor argues that selling shares should be a last resort, as it may indicate a lack of confidence in the company's fundamentals or management team. The author, a buy-and-hold investor, believes that investors should focus on solid fundamentals, a strong management team, and dividend generation before selling shares. Key reasons to sell shares include financial need, finding better opportunities, and changes in the investment thesis or valuation. However, from a buy-to-hold perspective, these reasons are not good enough to justify selling shares, as investors should be confident in their initial investment decision.

images.alt_text: For much of the past decade, tech stocks have looked mighty expensive on the conventional earnings and book measures. Are tech prices now low enough for value investors to take a look?

site_title: SIA to ramp up flight frequencies in 2023 on expected demand surge
summary: Singapore Airlines plans to increase flight frequencies in 2023 as it anticipates a surge in travel demand to East Asia, South-east Asia, and Australia. The airline expects flight frequencies to reach pre-pandemic levels across East Asia and South-east Asia by March 2024. Key destinations include Busan, Seoul, Fukuoka, Nagoya, Osaka, and Taipei, with daily flights reinstated to some cities, including Hong Kong, Bangkok, and Phuket. The airline also plans to add daily services to Melbourne and Sydney, Australia.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplane / aircraft at Changi Airport, 20 June 2022.

site_title: Sony to expand Chinese game incubator in Microsoft head-to-head
summary: Sony plans to expand its Chinese game incubator, the China Hero Project, with a new funding program investing over 1 million yuan per game. The program will support small and large teams, with Sony publishing some games and supporting enrolled projects. The move aims to tap China's gaming market, where Sony has sold over 3.5 million PS4 consoles and 670,000 PS5 units since its launch in 2021. This expansion comes as Microsoft also tries to enter the Chinese market, following Sony's success with the hit game "Genshin Impact".

site_title: Bankman-Fried's FTX, parents bought Bahamas properties worth US$121m
summary: Bankman-Fried's FTX, his parents, and senior executives bought at least 19 properties worth nearly $121 million in the Bahamas over two years. Most were luxury beachfront homes, including seven condominiums in Albany, costing almost $72 million. The properties were intended as "residence for key personnel." Bankman-Fried's parents and Stanford University law professors Joseph Bankman and Barbara Fried signed deeds for a vacation home in Old Fort Bay. The source of funds used to buy the properties remains unclear.

images.alt_text: The shuttering of FTX’s largest competitor, Binance, in Singapore back in December 2021 saw Binance users in Singapore switching to FTX.
The FTX bankruptcy case will aid prosecutors in figuring out what documents exist to subpoena.
Two men were arrested in Estonia on suspicion of defrauding US$575 million from hundreds of thousands of people in a cryptocurrency scheme, Estonian police said.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts downgrade Nanofilm Tech as outlook declines
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian and DBS Group Research downgraded their calls on Nanofilm Technologies due to a worsening outlook, citing "sporadic lockdowns" in China that will negatively affect revenue. UOBKH dropped its call to "sell" to "hold" and lowered its target price to S$1.02, while DBS Group Research cut its target price to S$1.39. Both analysts expect poor demand in Nanofilm's industrial equipment business unit amid macroeconomic uncertainties.

images.alt_text: The company expects its efforts to expand its production facilities as well as business in green energy and hydrogen fuel to drive its revenue to S$500 million and its profit to S$100 million by 2025.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: People walk along Nanjing Pedestrian Road, a main shopping area, in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: China’s great reopening may come too late for many businesses
summary: China's reopening may come too late for many businesses, according to American entrepreneurs who have invested in the country's culinary tourism industry. Camden Hauge, owner of the Egg cafe in Shanghai, believes people won't return to pre-pandemic life, while food tour company Lost Plate, which has been operating in China since 2015, is shifting to South-east Asia instead of staying in the country. This decision is attributed to Hauge's pessimism about China's reopening, which may be too late to save businesses that have been impacted by three years of Covid-19 restrictions.

images.alt_text: Camden Hauge, who owns the Egg cafe, poses in her cafe in central Shanghai, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak in Shanghai, China, November 16, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: UK government borrows less than expected in October, but worse to come
summary: The UK government borrowed £13.5 billion in October, lower than expected. This is despite energy bill support measures and a slowing economy, which are expected to increase the budget deficit in the coming months. The Office for National Statistics reported the figure, contrary to a poll that predicted a higher reading of £22 billion. The UK economy continues to face challenges, with a second consecutive month of contraction.

images.alt_text: Tankers unload liquefied natural gas at the Eemshaven port in the Netherlands, Sept 2022. A central location and extensive pipeline links could make the Netherlands a lynchpin in securing Europe's independence from Russian imports. But the growing reliance on LNG has created unease.

A video grab from footage broadcast by the UK Parliament, showing Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer (finance minister) Jeremy Hunt making an autumn budget statement in the House of Commons in London on Thursday (Nov 17).

site_title: Musk demonstrates how to destroy a workplace
summary: Elon Musk's attempt to create a "hardcore" new Twitter culture by offering employees a choice between joining a new, high-intensity workplace or receiving severance pay backfired. Hundreds of employees opted for the severance package, and many more ignored the ultimatum due to its lack of legal force. The approach was deemed unreasonable and self-contradictory, failing to provide employees with a pragmatic reason to stay. The move may have instead destroyed Twitter's existing workplace culture, which was deemed healthy before Musk's arrival.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk photo and Twitter logo are seen through magnifier in this illustration taken November 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: China’s Covid resurgence delays oil demand recovery to after Q2 2023: analysts
summary: China's Covid-19 resurgence has delayed the recovery of oil demand, with analysts now forecasting fuel demand won't recover until after March 2023. The country's strict "zero-Covid" policy has led to renewed lockdowns and mobility curbs, forcing fuel demand to remain low. Global oil futures have fallen nearly $10 a barrel since the announcement of fresh curbs. Analysts expect China's oil demand to stay low year-on-year in Q1 2023 before increasing to 15 million barrels per day in Q2 2023.

images.alt_text: Security personnel in protective suits stand at the gate of a residential compound that is under lockdown as outbreaks of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) continue in Beijing, October 22, 2022. REUTERS/Thomas Peter

site_title: US presses China to ease up on Taiwan as defence chiefs meet
summary: US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin urged China to avoid "destabilizing actions" towards Taiwan during a meeting with Taiwanese Defense Minister Wei Fenghe in Cambodia. The meeting, the first face-to-face talks between the two since House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's visit to Taipei in August, aimed to restore communication and crisis management. US officials warned of "increasingly dangerous behavior" by Chinese military aircraft, while Chinese officials blamed the US for deteriorating ties. The two sides agreed to strengthen crisis management but did not resolve deep differences over Taiwan, human rights, and other issues.

images.alt_text: China's Defence Minister Wei Fenghe arrives for a meeting with his US counterpart Lloyd Austin in Siem Reap on Nov 22, 2022.

The encounter between the Chinese and Philippine officials in the South China Sea happened during US Vice-President Kamala Harris' visit in the country. Her trip included a stop on Palawan, an island on the edge of the South China Sea, to reaffirm the US' support for a 2016 tribunal ruling that invalidated China's claims on the disputed waterway.

site_title: Mazda unveils US$11b EV spending plan, considers investing in battery production
summary: Mazda Motor Corp has unveiled a $10.6 billion spending plan to electrify its vehicles, aiming for 25-40% of total global sales to be electric vehicles by 2030. The plan includes introducing battery-EV models in 2025-2027 and a full-scale launch of fully electric vehicles between 2028 and 2030. Mazda will work with partners to develop and produce electric drive units, and has reached a supply agreement with Envision AESC for batteries. The investment is part of a broader industry trend, with Deloitte expecting EV sales to make up 32% of total new car sales globally by 2030.

images.alt_text: This year’s facelift brought some suspension tweaks, and to the Mazda’s credit it rides firmly yet comfortably over most road surfaces, even on 19-inch wheels.

site_title: GSK to stop selling blood cancer drug Blenrep in United States
summary: GSK announced it will stop selling its blood cancer drug Blenrep in the United States due to a key study showing it failed to meet its main goal. The company had previously received FDA approval in 2020 for patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma. Blenrep's access in other countries, including the European Union, remains unaffected. GSK will continue trial programs and offer patients the option to enroll in continued access to the treatment, with the company working with the US FDA on a path forward.

images.alt_text: This is a second setback for GSK’s oncology portfolio this week, after the company on Monday revealed its blood cancer drug Blenrep failed to outperform an older therapy in a key study.

site_title: BN will not be part of Malaysia’s next government
summary: Malaysia's ruling coalition, Barisan Nasional, has decided not to support either Anwar Ibrahim's reformist group or ex-premier Muhyiddin Yassin's pro-Malay alliance to form a new government. The decision, announced after a deadline, leaves the search for a new prime minister uncertain. King Al-Sultan Abdullah will now have to appoint a prime minister he believes enjoys the confidence of the majority, according to the constitution. The move prolongs the uncertainty after the inconclusive vote and may impact Anwar's chances of becoming prime minister.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's King Sultan Abdullah Sultan Ahmad Shah (L) waves as he meets members of the media outside the National Palace in Kuala Lumpur on November 21, 2022. - In a bid to break the impasse after Malaysia's polls saw no party emerge with a clear majority of parliamentary seats, the palace asked the leaders of political parties to submit their preferred choice of coalition partners and for prime minister by 2pm (0600 GMT) on November 21. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP)

site_title: TDCX Q3 earnings up 2.3% at US$21.6 million; reiterates full-year guidance
summary: TDCX reported a 2.3% increase in earnings to US$21.6 million for its third fiscal quarter, driven by a 16.1% rise in revenue to US$120.5 million. Revenue contributions from new economy clients accounted for 93% of the group's revenue for the first nine months of the year. The company attributed its growth to a 13% rise in omnichannel CX solutions and a 32.2% jump in sales and digital marketing services. TDCX reiterated its full-year guidance.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Headquartered in Singapore, TDCX is a provider of digital customer experience solutions with a focus on new economy companies.
TDCX chief executive and founder Laurent Junique believes that the company's growth lies in its sales and digital marketing services segment.
TDCX supplied this image for file photo usage
CGS-CIMB cut its target price on digital customer experience solutions provider TDCX to US$18 from US$24 as it expects the company will face slower agent growth amid recent macro uncertainties.
TDCX chief executive Laurent Junique said growing geopolitical and economic instabilities may create headwinds for the business in the short term.

site_title: SkillsFuture Series of short courses refreshed to focus on emerging fields, Industry 4.0
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Series of subsidised short-training courses will be reorganised into four categories: the digital economy, care economy, green economy, and Industry 4.0, effective January 1, 2023. The reorganisation focuses on emerging fields and Industry 4.0, following the identification of three growth areas in the inaugural SkillsFuture Singapore report. The new categories include digital economy, care economy, and green economy, with a focus on skills in software development, human resource advisory, and green infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
SkillsFuture Singapore identifies 'priority skills' in digital, green and care economy

site_title: How one of America’s most storied CEOs destroyed his legacy
summary: Former GE CEO Jack Welch regretted his decision to choose successor Jeff Immelt, whom he believed was more of a "know-it-all" who didn't listen to others. Welch felt responsible for the company's decline, citing Immelt's poor financial decisions, such as selling NBC Universal too cheaply and overpaying for acquisitions. GE's market capitalization has shrunk to $95 billion, and the company is being dismantled into three separate entities. Welch's mistake in choosing Immelt over more qualified candidates, such as Jim McNerney or Robert Nardelli, has been cited as a major factor in GE's decline.

images.alt_text: Lack of legacy and succession planning can hurt businesses, family harmony
Jack Welch, who ran General Electric between 1981 and 2001, struck a thousand deals. In November 2021, GE announced plans to split in three.
Good governance could have saved GE

site_title: Pertamina’s shipping unit plans up to US$3b investment for vessels
summary: Pertamina International Shipping, a unit of Indonesia's state energy firm, plans to invest up to $3 billion over five years to rejuvenate its fleet and acquire vessels for liquefied natural gas (LNG) transportation. The company aims to reduce its average fleet age to 15 years from 20 years and is exploring partnerships with shipping companies, including Japan's Nippon Yusen Kaisha (NYK). The investment will focus on replacing old vessels and acquiring new ones for LNG transportation, which is expected to increase in demand.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn hires chip veteran formerly at TSMC and SMIC
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, has hired Chiang Shang-yi, a former top executive at TSMC and SMIC, as its semiconductor strategy officer. Chiang brings deep industry experience to the newly created role, providing valuable support and technical guidance for Foxconn's global semiconductor deployment strategy. The move is seen as Foxconn's growing push into the chip business, following recent investments in chip plants and joint ventures. Chiang's appointment is expected to help Foxconn diversify its business and compete in the rapidly evolving semiconductor industry.

site_title: Thailand telecom merger faces delay, Norway's Telenor says
summary: A planned merger of Thai telecom firms DTAC and True Corporation, aiming to create a new industry leader, faces a delay due to competition concerns. The merger, valued at $8.6 billion, was initially set to be completed by the end of this year, but Telenor's majority ownership has stated that it may still proceed in the first quarter of 2023. The delay comes after the parties failed to meet a one-year deadline for a voluntary tender offer.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man walks next to the logo of the DTAC Public Company Limited and the logo of True Corporation at a department store in Bangkok, Thailand, November 22, 2021. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: China’s ‘slow, painful’ reopening threatens more economic strain
summary: China's economy is bracing for a "protracted and costly" reopening due to a surge in coronavirus cases, threatening more economic strain. Economists predict a "lacklustre" release of pent-up demand as households have depleted their savings. Productivity is being hit as cities enforce regular testing, and businesses may experience disruptions, with Foxconn Technology Group's factory in Zhengzhou recently hit by a Covid outbreak. China's GDP growth is forecast to slow to 4.3% in 2023, lower than a median estimate of 4.9%, with policymakers cautious about easing curbs quickly due to concerns about potential Covid-led deaths among the elderly population.

images.alt_text: The latest wave is testing recent adjustments China has made to its zero-Covid policy.
FILE PHOTO: Woman holds U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US, China defence chiefs meet in Cambodia
summary: US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin met Chinese Defence Minister Wei Fenghe in Cambodia, marking the first meeting between the two since June. The meeting follows a series of high-level talks between the two countries, including a meeting between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Group of 20 summit in Bali. The aim is to lower tensions and maintain open communication to manage competition between the two nations.

site_title: Rocket Internet-backed Flash Coffee lays off staff across markets
summary: Flash Coffee, a Singapore-based coffee chain backed by Rocket Internet, has laid off staff across its markets, including Singapore and Indonesia, amid a weakening economy. The extent of the layoffs is unclear, but former employees have shared LinkedIn posts indicating regionwide retrenchments. Flash Coffee, which opened over 250 outlets across seven countries in two years, raised millions of dollars from investors including Global Founders Capital and White Star Capital. The company's CEO, David Brunier, had previously stated plans to expand to every 500 meters in major Asian cities.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: ‘The Menu’ serves fine dining on a skewer
summary: The film "The Menu" satirizes the elite world of fine dining, where wealthy patrons pay astronomical sums to be served by creative visionaries like chef Julian Slowik. The movie follows a group of people isolated on an island, subjected to a 10-course meal prepared by Slowik and his employees, who are trapped and exploited. The film's writers drew inspiration from real-life restaurants, including Noma and Eleven Madison Park, and consulted with chefs to ensure accuracy. The movie critiques the culture of fine dining, where chefs are expected to work long hours under pressure and are often subjected to verbal abuse and intimidation.

site_title: JD.com cuts salaries for about 2,000 managers by up to 20%
summary: JD.com, China's largest online retailer, is slashing salaries for about 2,000 managers by 10-20% to redirect funds towards employee benefits. The company, led by billionaire founder Richard Liu, will also set up a 10 billion yuan fund to support staff. Liu will donate 100 million yuan from his own wealth to staff welfare, amid China's push for "common prosperity" and a nationwide drive to distribute wealth among tech billionaires and companies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's SkillsFuture Series will be reorganised into three emerging areas and Industry 4.0, from January 1, 2023. The country's FTX users account for the second-highest share of web traffic, with 5% of the site's total traffic. Retailers along Orchard Road are stocking up for the festive season despite recession fears. Singapore Airlines plans to boost flight frequencies in 2023, while the STI closed higher on Tuesday, bucking regional declines. NoonTalk debuted on the Singapore Exchange at S$0.225, 2.3% above its IPO price.

site_title: AP Technologies, Lumos Labs, Speedoc are top winners of Emerging Enterprise Awards, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: AP Technologies, a leading medical device manufacturer, aims to dominate the global medical tubing market. The company has developed innovative, sterile tubing solutions for various medical applications, including dialysis and infusion systems. AP Technologies' focus on quality, reliability, and sustainability is expected to drive growth in the industry. The company's expansion plans and strategic partnerships are anticipated to further solidify its position as a leader in the medical tubing market, providing high-quality products to healthcare professionals worldwide. This could lead to improved patient care and outcomes.

site_title: The fossil fuel way to net zero
summary: The COP27 conference in Egypt emphasized the need for decarbonization, but the goal of achieving net zero emissions remains elusive. Despite this, companies are developing technologies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from shipping, including onboard carbon capture (OCC) systems. OCC has the potential to play a mid- to long-term role in maritime decarbonization, but its commercial viability and regulatory requirements must be addressed. Several companies, including Climeworks, Samskip, and Rotoboost, are investing in OCC technology, with some aiming to capture up to 30% of CO2 emissions. The cost and politics of OCC will determine its widespread adoption.

site_title: UK rental market crisis leaves Brits paying for rooms with household work
summary: A growing number of people in the UK are trading their labor for a place to stay due to unaffordable rents, particularly in London. Many are using agencies like Share and Care, which match homeowners with lodgers who pay a small rent and contribute hours of work in exchange. The demand for these services has increased by 50% in the past few months, with some homeowners earning up to £350 per month in exchange for their time. This trend is seen as a result of rising inflation and increasing rents, with consumer prices rising 10.1% in the past year.

images.alt_text: So far, government support measures such as grants for developers have done little to alleviate Dublin's supply squeeze.
Confidence is well below levels of a year ago, reflecting a jump in food and energy prices that’s squeezing living standards and driving the economy into recession.

site_title: Bracing for the long term with innovation, staff development , Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A recent initiative aims to provide security and stability in a region prone to conflict. The effort involves deploying a team of international security experts to establish a stable government and ensure law enforcement. The move is expected to bring peace and security to the area, allowing for economic growth and development. The initiative has been met with support from local leaders, who see it as a crucial step towards rebuilding their communities. The project is expected to be completed within the next two years, with long-term stability and security projected to be a lasting outcome.

site_title: Singapore unique FTX users average 240,000 a month to form second-highest group of visitors
summary: Singapore users accounted for 5% of FTX.com traffic, with an average of 241,675 unique users visiting the platform each month. This is the second-highest share, with South Korea holding 6.1% and 297,229 unique users. The significant increase in FTX users in Singapore follows the shuttering of Binance in the country in December 2021.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Deutsche Bank targets Asia, Middle East for wealth ambitions
summary: Deutsche Bank is targeting Asia and the Middle East for wealth management expansion, with a focus on markets such as Saudi Arabia and Indonesia. The bank plans to "significantly invest" in these regions, driven by strong tailwinds for wealth creation due to economic reforms, trade flows, and geopolitical considerations. This move is part of Deutsche Bank's ambitions to become the euro area's largest private bank, with international private banking reporting a 22% revenue rise in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Deutsche Bank logo in Frankfurt, Germany June 9, 2015. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: Why Visa and Mastercard have yet to face their Kodak moment
summary: Legacy credit card players Visa and Mastercard continue to thrive despite the rise of fintech disruptors, with Visa reporting annual net income of $15 billion and Mastercard trading close to record highs. The big difference is that fintechs are not disrupting the market, but rather slotting themselves into the existing payments architecture. However, some potential disruptors, including Elon Musk's plans to integrate Twitter into a payments engine, crypto, Alipay's expansion ambitions, Apple's payments services, and JPMorgan's plan to develop a rival pay-by-bank facility, may challenge the status quo in the payments sector.

images.alt_text: Visa and Mastercard dominate cross-border card payments, and Brussels hopes that IP, combined with reforms such as “open banking”, or fintechs using a customer’s bank data to offer a range of services, will boost competition.
Mastercard said spending on its network jumped 18 per cent as US consumers battle once-in-a-generation levels of inflation.

site_title: Taylor Swift’s Midnights returns to No 1 for a third week
summary: Taylor Swift's album 'Midnights' returns to No 1 on the Billboard album chart for a third week, with 2.4 million equivalent sales. The album, which had the biggest opening for an album this year, has 204,000 US sales, including 184 million streams and 60,000 copies sold. Swift also holds the top spot on the Billboard's Hot 100 singles chart, with her song 'Anti-Hero' notching its fourth week at No 1.

site_title: Asia: Markets struggle as China Covid-19 worries build
summary: Asia's markets are experiencing a downturn due to growing concerns over China's latest Covid-19 outbreaks, which may lead to the reintroduction of restrictive containment measures. China's first virus deaths in six months have rattled investors, who fear a return to lockdowns similar to those in Shanghai. Analysts predict a long road ahead for China's recovery from the crisis, with President Xi Jinping sticking to a zero-Covid strategy blamed for the country's economic troubles. Market volatility is expected to persist as investors await China's reopening plans.

site_title: South Korea warns of supply disruptions, economic damage if truckers strike
summary: South Korea's prime minister warned that a nationwide truckers' strike, scheduled to begin Thursday, could cause irreparable damage to the national economy. The strike, which would disrupt manufacturing and fuel supplies, coincides with a global slowdown and surge in inflation. The strike, led by the Cargo Truckers Solidarity Union, seeks a three-year extension of a "Safe Trucking Freight Rate" policy, which guarantees a minimum annual wage. The government and ruling party offered a compromise deal, but the union rejected it, citing the need to protect truckers from fuel price fluctuations and exploitation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A truck driver stands next to his truck as he gets ready to transport a shipping container at Pusan Newport Terminal in Busan, South Korea, July 1, 2021. Picture taken on July 1, 2021. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: LG Chem to invest over US$3b to build US battery cathode plant
summary: LG Chem plans to invest over $3 billion to build a battery cathode factory in Tennessee, creating over 850 jobs and producing 120,000 tonnes of cathode materials annually by 2027, enough to power 1.2 million electric vehicles. The move aims to meet US demand for EV components and comply with the Inflation Reduction Act, which requires 40% of critical minerals to be sourced from the US or an American free-trade partner. The plant will supply cathode materials to Ultium Cells, a joint venture between General Motors and LG Chem.

images.alt_text: Lowering costs and making sufficient electric car (EV) batteries is key for Prime Planet amid rising raw materials prices.

site_title: Singapore shares buck regional declines; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.3% on Tuesday, driven by a stronger Straits Times Index (STI) to 3,259.56 points, despite regional declines. Advancers beat decliners 297 to 274 in the broader market, with 1.7 billion securities worth S$871.9 million changing hands. Hong Kong and South Korea's indices fell 1.3% and 0.6%, respectively, while Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index lost 0.5%.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Musk says Twitter to hold off relaunching blue check verification
summary: Elon Musk has delayed the relaunch of Twitter's blue check verification service, initially set for November 29, citing concerns over impersonation. The service, which was introduced as a paid option to help Twitter grow revenue, was paused after fake accounts proliferated. Musk stated that he will use a different color check for organizations than individuals and is holding off on the relaunch until he has high confidence in stopping impersonation.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk had already fired half of Twitter’s 7,500 staff, scrapped a work-from-home policy and imposed long hours, all while his attempts to overhaul the company face backlash and delays.

site_title: Crypto lender Genesis says no plans to file bankruptcy imminently
summary: Crypto lender Genesis has no immediate plans to file for bankruptcy, according to a spokesperson. The company suspended customer redemptions after the collapse of FTX, and had sought a US$1 billion emergency loan from investors. Genesis is in talks with creditors and has approached private equity firm Apollo Global Management for capital assistance. Despite struggling to raise fresh cash for its lending unit, Genesis aims to resolve the current situation consensually without a bankruptcy filing.
