images.alt_text: On Wednesday, Genesis Global Capital suspended customer redemptions in its lending business.

site_title: Aviation executives worry about demand as post-pandemic honeymoon ends
summary: Aviation executives are concerned about declining demand as the post-pandemic travel boom ends and a recession looms. European airlines posted soaring profits this summer, but executives warn of a slowdown in Europe and Britain, particularly as inflation and mortgage rates rise. Airlines are bracing for a tough 2023, with Virgin Atlantic's CEO Shai Weiss predicting a decline in bookings and a downturn in demand. Industry leaders are shifting focus from pandemic recovery to global economic concerns, with some airlines taking measures to stimulate demand through pricing.

images.alt_text: Carriers are expected to post a collective deficit of US$9.7 billion this year.

site_title: IBM sues Micro Focus for copying its software
summary: IBM has filed a lawsuit against Micro Focus, alleging that the UK-based firm copied its software for nearly two decades to create a competing product, Micro Focus Enterprise Suite. IBM claims that Micro Focus had access to its software, including the Customer Information Control System Transaction Server, and copied its architecture and design to create a similar product. The lawsuit seeks unspecified damages for claims of copyright infringement and breach of contract.

images.alt_text: IBM's 433-qubits Osprey quantum processor, with more than three times the qubits of the IBM Eagle processor.

site_title: Hedge fund Hestia wants Pitney Bowes to review capital spend, e-commerce segment
summary: Hestia Capital Partners, which owns a 6.9% stake in Pitney Bowes, has urged the company to review its capital allocation and e-commerce strategy. The hedge fund, known for its "deep value assets" approach, believes Pitney Bowes' stock price is undervalued and has suggested a possible sale of an underperforming segment, including the Global Ecommerce segment. Hestia's CEO Kurt Wolf has proposed creating a board committee focused on capital allocation and strategic planning, and has recommended focusing on cash-generating segments like Presort Services and SendTech Solutions.

site_title: Get the popcorn : Welcome to the Republican crack-up
summary: Donald Trump's potential presidential run for 2024 has sparked a Republican "crack-up" as centrist GOP figures challenge him. Despite his electoral losses, including the 2020 presidential election and the 2022 midterms, Trump remains popular among his base, particularly rural voters. However, without the support of middle-class Republicans, Trump faces significant challenges. Several Republican figures, including Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, New Hampshire Governor Chris Sununu, and former Vice President Mike Pence, are expected to run against him in the primaries. Trump's chances of winning the Republican nomination and the presidency remain uncertain, but a fractured opposition could still allow him to emerge as the winner.

images.alt_text: Former U.S. President Donald Trump announces that he will once again run for U.S. president in the 2024 U.S. presidential election during an event at his Mar-a-Lago estate in Palm Beach, Florida, U.S. November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst

site_title: Platinum deficit expected in 2023 after bumper surpluses, WPIC says
summary: The World Platinum Investment Council (WPIC) expects a 303,000-ounce platinum deficit in 2023 due to a surge in demand from automakers and industry, driven by rising vehicle production and stricter emissions regulations. Despite a bumper surplus this year, the availability of platinum has been tight due to China's 2.5 million-ounce imports since early 2021. Demand is forecast to rise 19% to 7.77 million ounces, with purchases of platinum bars and coins expected to increase by 49% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Lease rates for platinum peaked at around 10 per cent in May, higher than at the peak of the pandemic.

site_title: Beijing shuts parks, museums as China’s Covid cases rise
summary: China has shut parks and museums in Beijing amid a fresh nationwide spike in Covid-19 cases, with 28,127 new local cases reported on Monday. The country is testing its zero-Covid policy, which has been adjusted to be more targeted, but still has some of the world's strictest restrictions. Two new deaths attributed to Covid-19 were reported, and investors worry about the economy. Despite recent easing measures, analysts caution that a full reopening may not happen until March next year, and policymakers may be reluctant to make further changes.

images.alt_text: Some delivery services have experienced delays after residents of the sprawling Chaoyang district, home to nearly 3.5 million people, were urged to stay home during the weekend.

site_title: Hmlet to launch first hotel in first quarter of 2023
summary: CO-LIVING startup Hmlet plans to launch its first hotel, Owen House by Hmlet, in early 2023, in partnership with TCRE Partners and JMD Group. The 106-room hotel, located near Farrer Park MRT station, features an island bar and will be part of Hmlet's business model to expand into new markets and living segments. The launch coincides with Singapore's tourism recovery and the residential leasing market's upswing.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Gold ticks up as dollar pauses advance; focus on Fed minutes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,740.56 per ounce, edging up after a 1% retreat in the previous session, as the dollar eased. The focus shifted to the US Federal Reserve's latest meeting minutes for clues on future rate hikes. Investors preferred the dollar's safety amid fresh Covid-19 curbs in China, fueling concerns over the global economic outlook.

images.alt_text: High interest rates discourage investing in gold, which does not bear any interest.

site_title: The false promise of America’s Chips Act
summary: The US Congress recently approved the Chips and Science Act, allocating over $50 billion to strengthen the semiconductor industry. However, experts argue that the law is flawed, with a majority of funds going towards physical plant construction rather than research and development. Building manufacturing facilities will not accelerate chip development, and foreign companies are better positioned to provide the complex machines required. The law's reliance on industrial policy and government management may not achieve the US's technological lead in chips. A more effective approach would be to support the global industry, encourage competition, and increase resources for R&D.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden signs into law H.R. 4346, known as the CHIPS and Science Act of 2022, in a ceremony held on the South Lawn of the White House in Washington on Tuesday, Aug. 9, 2022. The landmark bill will provide $52.7 billion in subsidies for U.S. semiconductor production and research and boost efforts to make the United States more competitive with China's science and technology efforts. (Pete Marovich/The New York Times)

site_title: At 1.5b euros, England squad is most valuable at the World Cup: study
summary: England's 26-man World Cup squad is valued at approximately 1.5 billion euros, making it the most valuable at the tournament, according to a study by the Swiss research group CIES Football Observatory. England's teenage star Jude Bellingham tops the list with a transfer value of 202 million euros. England's squad is also ranked as the most insurable, with an estimated value of £3.17 billion. England is predicted to win the World Cup, with analysts forecasting knockout victories over Senegal, France, Spain, and Brazil.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Group B - England v Iran - Khalifa International Stadium, Doha, Qatar - November 21, 2022
England's Jude Bellingham celebrates scoring their first goal REUTERS/Paul Childs     TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Boeing, Southwest defeat class actions over 737 MAX safety
summary: A US appeals court dismissed class-action lawsuits against Boeing and Southwest Airlines, accusing them of covering up a fatal flaw in the 737 MAX 8 plane's design. The 3-0 decision ruled that plaintiffs could not prove they were harmed by overcharging on nearly 200 million tickets, and that the companies did not deceive the FAA during testing and certification. The court found that plaintiffs lacked standing due to the lack of physical harm and that they may actually be better off financially if the MAX 8 had been grounded sooner.

site_title: Tiny IPOs return even with regulators poised to step up scrutiny
summary: US regulators are poised to step up scrutiny on small initial public offerings (IPOs) following unusual trading patterns, with lawyers warning of potential civil or criminal proceedings against "bad actors." Despite this, the wave of small IPOs onto US exchanges resumed in force this month, with regulators acknowledging the trend in a public statement. The enforcement is seen as a response to aggressive trading in small IPOs, and the SEC or Department of Justice are likely to take action.

images.alt_text: Finra said criminals also try to entice people to invest in these IPOs through texting or social media.

site_title: Moya loses free float, to delist after offer secures 79.6% valid acceptances
summary: MAINBOARD-LISTED water treatment operator Moya Holdings Asia has lost its free float and will be delisted after a majority of its shareholders accepted an exit offer by Tamaris Infrastructure, securing 79.56% valid acceptances. The exit offer, made in September at S$0.092 per share, represents a 41.5% premium over the last traded price. With the passing of a delisting resolution, trading of Moya shares will be suspended, and the offer remains open until Dec 5.

images.alt_text: Moya Asia said the privatisation offer would provide an opportunity for shareholders to realise their investments amidst low trading liquidity, allow for greater management flexibility and save costs of maintaining listing.

site_title: Ireland rents surge as much as 24% in fastest gain on record
summary: Ireland's rental property market has seen its largest-ever surge in rents, with a 14% increase in the third quarter from a year earlier, according to daft.ie. The surge is attributed to a housing crisis and insufficient investment, with the Irish economy expected to underperform due to the sector. The country is only building about half the 50,000 homes needed annually, and construction costs are rising, threatening a pipeline of new properties. Rents in Dublin rose 24%, and the number of rental units dropped 26% from a year ago to 1,087 homes.

images.alt_text: While housing markets are cooling across the world with fewer transactions taking place, price declines have yet to begin in a number of countries.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Phillip Securities initiates coverage on Sats with ‘accumulate’
summary: Phillip Securities analyst Terence Chua initiates coverage on Sats with an "accumulate" call and target price of S$3.02. Chua expects air travel recovery to drive Sats towards breaking even in 2H FY2023 and profitability in FY2024. The analyst attributes funding clarity for Sats' acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services as a positive factor, which will alleviate stock overhang. Chua also notes Sats' diversified revenue streams, strong cash flow generation, and defensive balance sheet, placing the group "well above its peers".

images.alt_text: The inflight caterer and ground handler on Wednesday announced its 1.3 billion euro (S$1.9 billion) deal to acquire Paris-based air cargo handler Worldwide Flight Services.
SATS shares have fallen more than 30 per cent from the closing price of S$3.87 on Sept 27, before the proposed acqusition was announced.
Investors fear Sats will raise funds through a deeply discounted rights issue, and that the purchase of WFS will not boost its profitability as much as it implicitly claims

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 3,270.73 on Tuesday, bucking Wall Street losses due to concerns over China's latest Covid-19 wave. Gainers outnumbered losers 77 to 38, with top gainers including Singtel, Suntec Reit, and the trio of local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB. The US markets finished lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing 0.1% lower, as investors expect subdued trading during the week due to the Thanksgiving holiday.

images.alt_text: Dasmond Koh, executive director and chief executive of NoonTalk – which begins trading on the Singapore Exchange today.

site_title: Stocks to watch: NoonTalk Media, Halcyon Agri
summary: NoonTalk Media, a Singaporean media entertainment company, begins trading on the Singapore Exchange today after its IPO of 22 million shares at S$0.22 apiece was 1.2 times subscribed, raising S$4.8 million. Halcyon Agri, a natural rubber supplier, reported a Q3 FY2022 operating loss of US$2.2 million due to declining rubber prices and a mandatory general offer from a Chinese rubber company.

images.alt_text: 午言媒体创办人、本地艺人许振荣。

site_title: Jollibee foods plans China expansion with focus on smaller stores
summary: Jollibee Foods plans to expand its presence in China with a focus on smaller stores, aiming to open at least 100 new locations in the country next year. The company expects half of its sales to come from overseas stores by 2027 and aims to be among the top five restaurant companies in the world. CEO Ernesto Tanmantiong sees China as a "pillar market" and will focus on existing brands such as Yonghe King, Tim Ho Wan, and Hong Zhuang Yuan. The expansion is seen as a way to drive growth despite pandemic restrictions and elevated inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The name sign of the first Jollibee restaurant in the UK is seen, in London, Britain October 20, 2018. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls - RC173A8C8F10/File Photo

site_title: Zoom’s sales growth slows even as enterprise business stays steady
summary: Zoom Video Communications reported its slowest quarterly sales growth on record, with revenue increasing 5% to $1.1 billion, slightly below analyst estimates. The company reduced its full-year revenue forecast to $4.38 billion from $4.4 billion, citing currency fluctuations and deal scrutiny. Despite this, Zoom produced profit above expectations and raised its full-year earnings forecast, indicating its enterprise business remains steady. The company aims to reverse growth slowdown by expanding its business tools, including email and calendar services.

images.alt_text: zoom Photographer: Tiffany Hagler-Geard/Bloomberg

site_title: US consumers are still applying for credit cards despite higher rates
summary: US consumers continued to apply for credit cards despite rising interest rates, with a 27.1% application rate in October, a "robust" level. Demand for credit is strongest among consumers with high credit scores, while mortgage refinancing rates plummeted to 6.7% in October 2022. The Fed's rate hikes have cooled the economy and housing market, with mortgage rates near 7% and refinancing levels near pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: MasterCard, VISA and Maestro credit cards are seen in this picture illustration taken June 9, 2016. REUTERS/Maxim Zmeyev/Illustration

site_title: Airlines still see return to profit next year in first since 2019
summary: Airlines are expected to return to profit in 2023 for the first time since 2019, according to International Air Transport Association (IATA) director general Willie Walsh. Despite a collective deficit of $9.7 billion this year, Walsh expects airlines to achieve positive earnings in 2023 due to high employment levels and growth in key economies. Passenger traffic is expected to continue recovering into 2023, with a return to pre-Covid levels in 2024, driven by strong demand in North America and a gradual recovery in Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Over 40 countries including Germany, the UK and New Zealand have asked the United Nations body that sets aviation standards to help make single-pilot flights a safe reality.

site_title: Virgin CEO slams Heathrow curbs, pushes for own terminal
summary: Virgin Atlantic CEO Shai Weiss expressed concern over Heathrow's capacity limits, urging regulators to ensure the airport returns to full capacity by summer 2023. Weiss linked his support for a third runway to measures that boost competition, such as Virgin's own dedicated terminal, like British Airways. The airline will offer full backing for a third runway only if growth plans prioritize competition, not just at the expense of airlines.

images.alt_text: Virgin Atlantic hasn’t operated any passenger flights to Hong Kong since December, after the city banned all flights from the UK during the depths of Covid.

site_title: US prosecutors opened probe of FTX months before its collapse
summary: US federal prosecutors began investigating FTX months before its collapse, focusing on compliance with the Bank Secrecy Act. The probe, led by the Southern District of New York, aimed to determine whether the cryptocurrency exchange operated in accordance with US regulations, particularly regarding customer assets. FTX's bankruptcy case will aid in the investigation, which may lead to further scrutiny of the company's operations and potential wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Goldman Sachs strategists say bear market will last till 2023
summary: Goldman Sachs strategists predict a bear market will persist until 2023, citing a peak in interest rates and lower valuations as necessary for a sustained stock market recovery. They estimate the S&P 500 will end 2023 at 4,000 index points, a 0.9% increase from the current level. European stocks are also expected to rise, but at a slower pace. The strategists warn of a volatile and potentially downward path for equity markets, with a big decline in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The Goldman Sachs company logo is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., July 13, 2021.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: US banks are tightening lending standards, raising the risk of a recession
summary: US banks are tightening lending standards, raising the risk of a recession. Commercial banks have increased restrictive lending practices for medium and large businesses and commercial real estate, similar to levels seen during recessions. The Federal Reserve's rate hikes have also led to stricter lending standards for credit cards and consumer loans. Economists predict a high probability of a recession (75%) with a potential downturn in the third quarter of 2023, potentially raising the unemployment rate to 5.6%.

images.alt_text: Strategists from Goldman Sachs say that a peak in interest rates and lower valuations reflecting the recession are necessary before any sustained stock-market recovery can happen.

site_title: NoonTalk debuts 2.3% higher before ending day at IPO price of S$0.22
summary: NoonTalk, a media entertainment company, made its Singapore Exchange (SGX) debut on November 22, 2022, at an IPO price of S$0.22, 2.3% higher than its initial price. The company, led by CEO Dasmond Koh, raised S$4.8 million in gross proceeds and has a market capitalization of S$43.6 million. Koh aims to strengthen regional partnerships and expand into Malaysian, Thai, and Chinese markets, with plans to devote 47.1% of gross proceeds to regional expansion. NoonTalk also plans to pay out 20% of net profit to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
NoonTalk is led by executive director and chief executive officer Dasmond Koh, a Singaporean actor, television host and radio personality.

site_title: Oil prices ease to near 2-month lows on China demand fears, dollar strength
summary: Oil prices fell to near two-month lows on Monday, with Brent crude futures dipping 0.6% to $87.10 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures sliding 0.9% to $79.40 a barrel. The decline was driven by concerns over fuel demand from China and the strengthening US dollar, as well as a rebound in interest rates and economic recessionary scenarios in major countries.

images.alt_text: Oil gained support from official figures showing US crude stocks fell by a bigger than expected 5 million barrels in the latest week.

site_title: Coinbase hits record low as crypto contagion anxiety intensifies
summary: Coinbase's stock plummeted 9% on Monday, hitting a record low of $40.61, amid rising investor anxiety over the potential fallout from FTX's insolvency. The drop follows a 10.3% decline on Friday and a 65% decline in Bitcoin's value. Other crypto-related shares also fell, with Marathon Digital Holdings and MicroStrategy dropping 10%. Analysts predict Bitcoin's price may break the $15,500 level, leading to further declines. Coinbase has 14 buy, 12 hold, and 6 sell ratings, with Bank of America downgrading the stock to neutral.

images.alt_text: In June, Coinbase announced it would lay off 18 per cent of its workforce, the equivalent of roughly 1,200 employees.

site_title: TLDR: The mindblowing scale of Qatar’s World Cup preparations
summary: Qatar's preparations for the 2022 FIFA World Cup have been massive, with a total investment of US$220 billion, surpassing its annual GDP of US$180 billion. The tournament marks several firsts, including the first World Cup held at the end of the year to avoid heat, the first in the Middle East, and Qatar's first appearance. It will also be the last to feature 32 teams, with the next tournament featuring a record 48 teams. The event started on November 20, with Qatar losing its opening game to Ecuador, and will conclude on December 18.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan

site_title: USA draw a ‘great point’ for Wales hero Bale
summary: Wales secured a 1-1 draw with the US in their World Cup match, with Gareth Bale scoring his first goal of the tournament in the 88th minute to level the score after a 1-0 deficit at halftime. The draw is considered a great point for Wales, who showed character and determination in the second half. Wales boss Rob Page praised the team's reaction to a poor first half and their ability to follow a similar start to their Euro 2020 campaign, where they qualified second in their group.

site_title: Oil rebounds from early plunge after Saudis deny Opec+ output report
summary: Oil prices rebounded after Saudi Arabia denied a report of discussing an oil supply increase with Opec and its allies, citing sticking to output cuts. Brent crude futures settled at $87.45, shedding 17 cents, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 35 cents. The report's denial halted losses after early plunges to 10-month lows, driven by weak Chinese fuel demand and a strong US dollar.

images.alt_text: A Pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, stands silhouetted against the sun at an oil plant operated by Moravske Naftove Doly (MND) AS in Damborice, Czech Republic, on Friday, Jan. 8, 2016. Oil capped the biggest two-year loss on record in 2015 as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries effectively abandoned output limits amid a global glut. Photographer: Martin Divisek/Bloomberg

site_title: Halcyon Agri reports operating loss of US$2.2m in Q3 amid lower rubber prices
summary: Halcyon Agri Corporation reported a Q3 operating loss of US$2.2 million, despite core earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) increasing to US$10.2 million year-over-year. Revenue rose 17.9% to US$709.8 million, and gross profit increased 13.3% to US$39.1 million. The company attributes its sales volume growth to its global market position and vertically integrated capabilities, despite margin compression due to lower rubber prices. The company remains optimistic about its prospects, citing potential demand resurgence in China upon its reopening.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Halcyon rubber processing factory in Palembang, Indonesia.
Workers at Halcyon Agri faciliy in Palembang, Indonesia. Natural rubber is formed into blankets as part of the process of making Standard Indonesian Rubber.
Workers at Halcyon Agri faciliy in Palembang, Indonesia. Natural rubber is formed into blankets as part of the process of making Standard Indonesian Rubber.

site_title: Shell to evaluate £25b UK investments on windfall tax
summary: Shell plans to evaluate its £25 billion UK investment plans due to the expanded windfall tax, which was recently announced by the UK government. The tax, which increased to 35% and will be extended to 2028, aims to shore up public finances. Shell's chairman, David Bunch, expressed concerns that the tax could reduce the company's disposable income and investment capabilities. He called for a mechanism to adjust the levy if oil and gas prices change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Shell logo is seen on a pump at a Shell petrol station in London January 30, 2014. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett/File Photo

site_title: Malaysia’s stock market, ringgit under pressure as Anwar, Muhyiddin tussle to form government
summary: Malaysia's stock market and ringgit faced pressure after the country's first hung parliament, following the 15th general election that saw none of the major coalitions secure a majority. The benchmark FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 1.2% to 1,447.96 points. Top losers included brewery and gaming companies. The fight to form the next government continues, with Pakatan Harapan and Perikatan Nasional engaging in deal-making. Market analysts expect regulatory risks to rise, particularly in the sin sectors, and warn of negative share price reactions.

images.alt_text: The Malaysian ringgit fell as much as 0.7 per cent to almost RM4.59 per dollar on Monday (Nov 21), after the weekend’s election resulted in a hung parliament.

site_title: Disney seeks old magic in return of ex-CEO Iger
summary: Disney has rehired former CEO Bob Iger for a two-year contract amid a 40% slump in its share price. Iger's return comes as the company struggles to turn a profit from its Disney+ streaming service, which burned through $4 billion in just 12 months. Despite Disney+ gaining 164 million subscribers, the financial burden weighs heavily on other sectors, including theme parks and merchandising. Analysts warn that Iger's legacy is at stake, and the company faces pressure from activist investors seeking quick results, with some predicting that immediate success is not guaranteed.

site_title: Emerging Enterprise Awards go regional, Sustainability Award expanded, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: G8 Subsea, KoolLogix, and Nanosun have been recognized as top winners at the Emerging Enterprise Awards. The awards celebrate innovative and forward-thinking businesses. G8 Subsea took home the award for Subsea Engineering Company of the Year, while KoolLogix won the award for Engineering and Manufacturing Company of the Year. Nanosun received the award for Technology Company of the Year. These awards acknowledge the companies' achievements in their respective industries, highlighting their innovative approaches and contributions to the business sector. The awards ceremony recognized the companies' hard work and dedication to excellence.

site_title: England prove 'doubters' wrong as they launch World Cup bid with 6-2 trashing of Iran
summary: England kicked off the World Cup with a 6-2 victory over Iran, silencing doubters and proving their capabilities. Jude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka led the charge, with Bellingham scoring his first international goal and Saka scoring twice after a penalty nightmare in Euro 2020. Manager Gareth Southgate praised the team's performance but urged caution, as they face tougher opponents like the US and Wales in Group B. Despite conceding twice, England's win sets a positive tone for their World Cup campaign.

site_title: Two arrested in Estonia over US$575m cryptocurrency fraud
summary: Two men, Sergei Potapenko and Ivan Turogin, were arrested in Estonia on suspicion of defrauding US$575 million from hundreds of thousands of people in a cryptocurrency scheme. The suspects allegedly invited people to invest in their token but failed to develop it, with the stolen funds laundered through real estate purchases and shell companies. A joint operation involving Estonian police and the FBI resulted in the arrests, with the US requesting extradition of the two men. This is considered one of the largest fraud cases in Estonia.

site_title: US: Energy shares, China Covid-19 cases weigh on Wall Street; Disney jumps
summary: US stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.1% to 33,700.28, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.4% to 3,949.94. The decline was driven by concerns over China's Covid-19 resurgence, which has raised global growth concerns. In contrast, Disney shares surged 6.3% after the company ousted its CEO and announced Bob Iger's return. Investors are also awaiting the release of the Federal Reserve meeting minutes and economic data, including durable goods orders for October, ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Raindrops hang on a sign for Wall Street outside the New York Stock Exchange in Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., October 26, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 subdued; defensive stock gains offset commodities gloom
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index closed little changed, despite gains in defensive sectors like healthcare and food, offsetting declines in commodity stocks due to concerns over China's Covid-19 cases. The benchmark index marked its fifth straight weekly advance, but was down 0.06% at close. Defensive sectors rose 1-1.2%, while mining, travel, and industrial goods fell 0.2-1.5%. Oil prices slid, and ECB chief economist Philip Lane said the central bank will raise rates again in December, adding to recession worries.

site_title: Meta sued in UK to stop personal data collection for ads
summary: Meta Platforms Inc is facing a UK lawsuit demanding it stop harvesting personal data for targeted advertisements. Campaigner Tanya O'Carroll claims Facebook violates data protection regulations by processing her personal data for ads. Meta has built tools for privacy check-ups and ad preferences, but has yet to file its defense papers. A win could set a precedent for millions of UK and EU users who have been forced to accept invasive surveillance and profiling to use digital platforms.

site_title: Crypto investors should look in the mirror when apportioning blame
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reiterated that trading in cryptocurrencies is "highly hazardous" amid the FTX implosion. Retail investors are advised to assess if crypto investing is for them. Some investors blame MAS for their losses, citing the "banning" of Binance, which led them to FTX. However, MAS has not banned Binance, and investors are urged to take responsibility for their decisions. The MAS's warning serves as a reminder of the risks involved in crypto investing.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
FILE PHOTO: Representations of virtual cryptocurrencies are placed on U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken November 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: PM Sunak says Britain will not pursue trade ties that rely on EU alignment
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak stated that Britain will not pursue any trading relationship with the EU that relies on alignment with EU laws. This decision comes after a newspaper reported that his government was pursuing closer ties. Sunak credited the UK's exit from the EU with bringing more freedom on matters like migration and regulation, securing "proper control" of the country's borders.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz meets Chinese President Xi Jinping in Beijing on Nov 4. A document by Germany's foreign ministry is proposing measures to reduce the country's dependency on China.

site_title: Rivals PH, Umno join hands to form Perak, Pahang state governments
summary: Malaysia's rival political parties, Pakatan Harapan (PH) and Umno-led Barisan Nasional (BN), have formed state governments in Perak and Pahang, ending an impasse in both states. PH, led by Anwar Ibrahim, supplied numbers needed to form a government in Perak, while backing a BN menteri besar candidate. In Pahang, BN's total of 24 seats is more than required to form a simple majority. The agreements set the stage for possible cooperation between the two coalitions at the federal level, with PH and BN leaders meeting to explore possible cooperation in forming a federal government.

images.alt_text: PAS, a member of Muhyiddin’s PN, emerged as the largest party in Parliament with 44 MPs after Saturday’s election, and has long espoused Islamist views that critics say infringe on personal freedoms.
The Malaysian ringgit fell as much as 0.7 per cent to almost RM4.59 per dollar on Monday (Nov 21), after the weekend’s election resulted in a hung parliament.

site_title: Orchard Road retailers stock up, widen festive offerings for busier year-end season
summary: Retailers along Singapore's Orchard Road are stocking up and expanding their festive offerings ahead of the holiday shopping season, despite recession fears. Footfall and spending are expected to rise by 5-10% compared to October, with some retailers already surpassing pre-pandemic sales. The annual Christmas light-up festivities are taking place in person and at full scale for the first time since the pandemic, with tourists returning and contributing to increased sales. However, concerns about economic uncertainty and inflationary pressures may impact spending, and footfall is unlikely to recover to pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
2022年乌节圣诞装饰。“乌节圣诞大街欢”于11月12日举行亮灯仪式，乌节路3.1公里的路段上会有171支灯柱披上圣诞装，一路上两旁的104棵树会由较节能的LED打造白色圣诞灯饰。走道上有各式各样营造佳节氛围的圣诞村，还有工作坊和街头演唱等活动。

site_title: Merck to buy Imago for US$1.35b to gain bone marrow drugs
summary: Merck & Co agreed to purchase Imago BioSciences for US$1.35 billion, gaining therapies for bone marrow conditions. The deal includes a mid-stage drug, bomedemstat, for conditions affecting platelet and red blood cell production. The acquisition is part of Merck's search for cancer and rare disease treatments, with CEO Robert Davis stating it strengthens the company's presence in hematology. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter of next year.

site_title: Dell gains after beating sales estimates on demand for tech services
summary: Dell Technologies reported quarterly results that beat analyst estimates, with sales slipping 6% to $24.7 billion and profit excluding items reaching $2.30 a share. The company attributed the beat to strong demand for its technology infrastructure services, despite a 17% decline in personal computer sales. Dell's Infrastructure Solutions Group saw a 12% increase in sales, while server and networking sales rose 14% and storage revenue gained 11%. The company's stock gained 2% in extended trading.

images.alt_text: Global PC shipments dropped more than 19 per cent in the third quarter, according to Gartner, the steepest decline since the industry analyst began tracking the metric in the mid-1990s.

site_title: Bill Gates-led fund backs pulsed-power technology to clean up mining
summary: A climate fund backed by Bill Gates' Breakthrough Energy Ventures has invested $16.99 million in a technology that uses high-intensity bursts of electricity to streamline mining processes. The I-ROX pulsed-power technology aims to reduce energy usage and carbon emissions at mines, particularly for metals like copper and nickel. The investment is part of efforts to meet growing demand for metals in the transition away from fossil fuels. By reducing energy-intensive crushing and grinding processes, the technology can help producers achieve carbon-reduction targets and gain industry acceptance for expansions.

site_title: Indonesia quake kills more than 160, injures hundreds and destroys homes
summary: A 5.6-magnitude earthquake in Indonesia's West Java province killed over 160 people, injured hundreds, and destroyed homes, with rescuers struggling to reach survivors trapped under rubble. The epicentre was in the town of Cianjur, 75 km south-east of Jakarta. The disaster is part of Indonesia's high seismic activity, with over 1,770 houses damaged and nearly 3,900 people displaced. Aftershocks have been recorded, and officials are concerned about potential landslides and further damage.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is one of the most disaster-prone nations on Earth.
Firefighters work to rescue a person at the site of a collapsed 7-11 store after a magnitude 6.9 earthquake, in Yuli township, Hualien County, Sept 18, 2022.
Motorists maneuvering next to a damaged building following an earthquake in Bangued, Abra province, Philippines, July 27, 2022.

site_title: Germany to tighten rules for firms highly dependent on China: document
summary: Germany's foreign ministry plans to tighten rules for companies heavily dependent on China, aiming to reduce the country's economic reliance. The proposed measures, part of Chancellor Olaf Scholz's new business strategy, include mandatory disclosure of information and stress tests for geopolitical risks. Companies in the chemicals and car industries will be targeted, as the government seeks to change the incentive structure to encourage reducing export dependency. The goal is to make it more attractive for German companies to diversify their supply chains and reduce their reliance on China.

images.alt_text: High demand for electric cars amid supply chain shortages has allowed European carmakers to raise EV prices and focus more on retail clients, rather than customers such as car rental firms that have traditionally been less profitable for them.

site_title: E-scooters on Island of the Gods demonstrate Asia’s green shoots
summary: Japan's Honda Motor aims to roll out at least 10 electric motorcycle models worldwide by 2025. This follows a trend of Asian countries, particularly Indonesia and Vietnam, embracing electric two-wheelers due to their affordability and suitability for crowded cities. McKinsey & Co partners Vivek Lath and Rahul Gupta predict that electric two-wheelers could make up 50% of the motorbike market in South-east Asia by 2030, driven by companies like Grab and Gojek shifting to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: A group of tuk tuks pass by the Democracy Monument in Bangkok on Nov 15, 2022. Thailand is hosting the APEC Summit this week.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open lower as China Covid cases tick higher
summary: The US stock market opened lower on November 21, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite falling 9.1 and 55.1 points, respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 14.6 points. Concerns about slowing growth in China, driven by rising Covid-19 cases, contributed to the decline. In contrast, Disney's shares jumped following Bob Iger's surprise return as CEO, supporting the Dow.

images.alt_text: A specialist trader works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Bonds more attractive now than ever before, says Capital Group chair of fixed income
summary: Capital Group's chair of fixed income management committee, Mike Gitlin, expects 2023 to be a year of reinvestment in fixed income, driven by attractive yields and moderating inflation expectations. Despite a challenging 2022, Gitlin believes the market is now poised for a rebound, with a possible yield of 7.5% from a portfolio of investment-grade and high-yield bonds. He also notes that the technology sector is becoming less dominant, and other sectors like industrials and healthcare are gaining traction. Gitlin forecasts $1 trillion in inflows to fixed income, reversing the outflows seen in 2022.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

site_title: Why COP27 was one step forward, two steps back
summary: COP27, the 27th Conference of the Parties to the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, concluded with a last-minute agreement on the "loss and damage" agenda, a significant success for the Global South. However, the overall deal fell short, failing to make progress on cutting greenhouse gases and increasing climate ambition. The agreement did not include a commitment to phase out all fossil fuels, and vague language on the 1.5°C warming target may be a step backward. The UN Secretary-General emphasized the need for drastic reductions in emissions and a quantum leap in climate ambition. The future of the COPs themselves is being questioned, with calls for a leaner, more focused forum to address key issues, and the need for transformative change in the economy and society to avoid worst-case scenarios.

images.alt_text: German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock says: “It is more than frustrating to see overdue steps on mitigation and the phase-out of fossil energies being stonewalled by a number of large emitters and oil producers.”

site_title: China’s Sinopec signs long-term LNG supply deal with Qatar
summary: China's Sinopec has signed a 27-year long-term liquefied natural gas (LNG) supply deal with Qatar Energy, marking the country's longest LNG supply agreement to date. The deal, worth four million tonnes per year starting in 2026, aims to bolster China's energy security and meet its growing energy needs. The agreement is also seen as a strategic move to diversify China's energy sources, as the country seeks to reduce its reliance on imports.

images.alt_text: A move by China to secure its own LNG supply could drain shipments to Europe and exacerbate the region’s energy crunch in the case of a cold winter.

State-controlled CNPC and Sinopec are expected to invest a 5 per cent stake each in 2 separate export trains, part of the nearly US$30 billion North Field expansion project, the 3 sources with knowledge of the discussions told Reuters.

site_title: Qatar signs world's 'longest' gas supply deal with China
summary: QatarEnergy signed a 27-year natural gas supply deal with China, dubbed the "longest" in the history of the LNG industry, with 4 million tonnes of liquefied natural gas to be sent annually from its North Field East project to China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation (Sinopec). The deal strengthens Qatar's ties with Asia as European countries scramble for alternative sources. This marks a significant milestone in Qatar's expansion of its liquefied natural gas production, with North Field set to produce 126 million tonnes by 2027.

images.alt_text: The global LNG market has more than doubled in size since 2011, ushering in dozens of new entrants and the expansion of smaller players in Asia.

site_title: China urges banks to maintain stable property financing
summary: China's financial regulators have urged banks to maintain stable property financing, supporting the "reasonable" extension of existing real estate development loans and trust loans. The move aims to turn around the real-estate crisis and bolster economic growth, with measures including expanding medium- and long-term lending and improving regulatory support for housing project delivery. The call follows a 16-point package of actions taken by the government to address the property market slump, which has dragged down China's economic growth and local government income.

images.alt_text: This month’s property rescue package will mainly benefit private developers that have yet to default.
Chinese authorities over the weekend rolled out a sweeping package to help the embattled sector.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Binance, a major cryptocurrency exchange, was placed on Singapore's Investor Alert List after receiving complaints about its activities between January and August 2021. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is investigating the exchange. Meanwhile, A*Star and RVAC Medicines have agreed to set up a joint laboratory to develop mRNA vaccines. In the job market, hiring activity has slowed in the tech and manufacturing sectors, with demand for technology roles decreasing in the fourth quarter. The Singapore stock market also fell 0.7% on Monday, following regional declines.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A representation of cryptocurrency is seen in front of Binance logo in this illustration taken, March 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Media entertainment company NoonTalk public offer 1.2 times subscribed
summary: NoonTalk Media's public offer tranche of its initial public offering (IPO) was 1.2 times subscribed, raising S$4.8 million. The company, specializing in artiste and talent management, multimedia production, and event conceptualization, will list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on November 22. NoonTalk's market capitalization is expected to be around S$43.6 million post-offering, with anchor investors including Union Energy Corporation, Sheng Siong Group, and Citic Envirotech.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
午言媒体创办人、本地艺人许振荣。

site_title: US dollar jumps as China Covid worries spur safe-haven buying
summary: The US dollar surged against major currencies on Monday, driven by concerns over rising Covid-19 cases in China, which have led to new restrictions and weighed on global investor sentiment. The dollar rose 0.98% against the yen and 0.83% against the euro, its highest since November 11. Analysts attribute the dollar's rebound to its status as a safe-haven asset, as well as recent weakness in the currency. The dollar index remains 12% higher for the year, despite a sharp fall in recent weeks, and investors will be closely watching the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions for guidance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. one hundred dollar notes are seen in this picture illustration taken in Seoul February 7, 2011.   REUTERS/Lee Jae-Won/File Photo

site_title: Binance placed on alert list after complaints; all crypto exchanges can fail: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority (MAS) placed Binance on its alert list after receiving complaints about the exchange soliciting users in Singapore and potentially breaching the Payment Services Act. Binance had been actively soliciting Singapore users, offering listings in Singapore dollars, and accepting local payment modes, prompting MAS to investigate. In contrast, FTX, which collapsed in November, was not placed on the alert list as it did not solicit users in Singapore and did not offer trades in local dollars. MAS warned that dealing in cryptocurrencies is hazardous and that investors can lose all their money, even with well-managed exchanges.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

FILE PHOTO: Representation of cryptocurrency Binance Coin, the native token of the cryptocurrency exchange, is seen in this illustration taken November 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Sweden’s housing market rout deepens in showcase for world
summary: Sweden's housing market is experiencing a severe downturn, with home prices dropping by 14% from a peak earlier this year. This marks the country's most significant housing slump in three decades, fueled by soaring inflation and central bank efforts to curb price increases. The decline is unusual in Sweden, where previous corrections have been shallow and short-lived. For seven straight months, households are being squeezed by rising living costs, highlighting the potential for a global housing downturn.

images.alt_text: US single-family homebuilding dropped to an annualised 855,000 rate, the lowest since May 2020.

site_title: Muhyiddin sends support letters to King as Anwar seeks out Zahid
summary: Malaysia's King has extended the deadline for a new government to be formed, pushing it back to 2pm on Tuesday, as parties struggle to reach a consensus. Perikatan Nasional (PN) claims to have sent statutory declarations of a majority of MPs, while Pakatan Harapan (PH) and Barisan Nasional (BN) are in talks over a possible coalition. Anwar Ibrahim, PH chairman, is seeking support from BN, but Umno leaders are divided, with some calling for Zahid Hamidi to resign. The formation of a government remains uncertain, with the fate of Malaysia's first hung Parliament hanging in the balance.

site_title: China regulator plans to improve balance sheets of 'good quality' developers
summary: China's securities regulator plans to improve the balance sheets of "good quality" property developers struggling with a cash crunch, which accounts for roughly a quarter of the economy. Chairman Yi Huiman stated that the regulator needs to closely monitor the difficulties faced by the property industry. This move comes as Beijing steps up support measures for the embattled sector, which is facing a deepening debt crisis.

images.alt_text: Residental buildings in Huaian, in China's eastern Jiangsu province. The authorities support the “reasonable” extension of existing real estate development loans and trust loans, said a statement on the website of the People's Bank of China.

site_title: Vopak, Petronas sign MOU on carbon capture and storage for Singapore industrial emissions
summary: Vopak, a Dutch tank storage company, has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Petronas, Malaysia's oil and gas company, to develop a carbon capture and storage (CCS) value chain in Southeast Asia. The agreement aims to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from industries in Singapore. Vopak will transport CO2 from its terminal to Petronas' storage hubs, and the companies will commission a feasibility study to aggregate emissions from various emitters in the region. The partnership supports the transition to a low-carbon future, with both companies committing to invest in CCS solutions.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong leads losses on fresh China’s Covid fears
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday as China's first Covid death in six months sparked fears of reimposed restrictions, leading to losses in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Sydney, and other cities. The news cast a shadow over investor hopes for a gradual reopening, with Beijing having eased virus-fighting measures earlier this month. The death of an 87-year-old man in Beijing, along with rising infections, has raised concerns about the economic impact of stricter measures, affecting regional investors and global markets.

site_title: Money conversations, growing up
summary: A family in the English-language drama "Growing Up" learns the importance of authentic money conversations, starting early and being honest about financial decisions. David, the third child, lies to his mother about giving her only 40% of his money, but eventually repents and reconciles with his father. The family's experiences highlight the need for open discussions about money, including saving and investing, spending below one's means, and showing filial piety. These conversations can help children understand the value of money and its impact on relationships, and can lead to better financial decisions and a stronger sense of gratitude towards parents.

images.alt_text: house, car, family

site_title: Twitter’s head of France quits, says ‘It’s over’ amid staff exodus
summary: Twitter's head of France, Damien Viel, has quit the company, stating "It's over" in a tweet ahead of potential additional layoffs, which may begin as soon as Monday. Viel led the Paris office for about seven years, and the company is considering cutting more jobs, focusing on sales and partnerships. The move comes after Elon Musk's sweeping job cuts, including the departure of much of the management team. Several brands have already paused advertising on the platform, including General Motors and Volkswagen, amid concerns over content rules and Musk's leadership.

site_title: Malaysia Smelting Corp sinks into the red with RM31.3m loss in Q3
summary: Malaysia Smelting Corp (MSC) reported a net loss of RM31.3 million in its third quarter ended Sep 30, 2022, despite revenue growth to RM344.1 million. The loss was attributed to a longer-than-expected furnace outage, higher operating costs, and a sharp drop in tin prices. Tin prices fell 26% to RM104,700 per tonne, dragging down MSC's smelting and mining businesses. Despite the loss, MSC's CEO Patrick Yong remains optimistic about tin's long-term prospects due to its role in emerging technologies, including lithium-ion batteries for electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Ipoh, the capital city of Malaysia's Perak state, houses one of the world's biggest tin mining communities.

site_title: Good that SMEs have a place in Singapore bourse
summary: SGX's chairman emphasizes the exchange's focus on serving as a platform for efficient investment channeling, rather than saving SMEs. Despite welcoming SME listings, SGX recognizes its limitations in competing with US exchanges due to Singapore's small market size. The exchange has struggled to attract equities, especially home-grown SMEs, since its formation in 2000. Recent SME listings on SGX's junior board Catalist have raised hopes, but the exchange must balance its growth with its original mission.

site_title: Cathay Pacific to lift pay by 3.3%, offer bonus: CEO
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways will increase base pay by 3.3% in 2023 and offer bonuses equivalent to one month's salary to Hong Kong-based staff meeting performance targets. The airline aims to hire 4,000 staff over the next 18-24 months to rebuild capacity cut during the pandemic. CEO Augustus Tang expressed gratitude for staff efforts in a message, marking the airline's transition from "survival" to "recovery".

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific carried over five times more passengers in October than last year, although the figure was still 85.4 per cent lower than pre-pandemic levels in 2019.
Travel industry groups have warned Hong Kong will not see a meaningful return of visitors until the three-day monitoring period and most other restrictions are lifted.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid regional declines; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.7% to 3,250.62, with 355 losers outpacing 184 gainers. The decline mirrored regional losses, attributed to fears over China's surging Covid cases and potential lockdowns. Japan's Nikkei 255 bucked the trend, edging up 0.2%. Key performers included Jardine Matheson, which rose 1.6%, while Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust and Singapore's banking trio, OCBC, DBS, and UOB, fell 3.5%, 0.8%, and 0.7%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
On Monday morning, losers outnumbered gainers 53 to 64 after 35.5 million securities worth S$64.8 million changed hands on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: China denies using force to retrieve rocket debris in South China Sea
summary: China has denied using force to retrieve a piece of a rocket's payload fairing in the South China Sea, after a Philippine military commander accused a Chinese coastguard ship of "forcefully retrieving" the object by cutting a line. China's foreign ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning attributed the object to debris from a Chinese rocket, contradicting the Philippine's account. US Vice-President Kamala Harris visited the Philippines to reaffirm US support for a 2016 tribunal ruling invalidating China's claims on the disputed waterway.

images.alt_text: The visit, scheduled for next Tuesday, will make Kamala Harris the highest-ranking American official to visit the Philippine islands of Palawan adjacent to the Spratly Islands.

site_title: Eva Air to shrink Airbus single-aisle fleet in push for big jets
summary: Taiwan's Eva Air plans to shrink its Airbus single-aisle fleet, replacing some 24 A321ceo jets with Boeing 787-9s and -10s over the next two years. The airline aims to use wide-body planes to seat more passengers, prioritizing the delivery of 11 new 787s. Eva Air will also gradually withdraw its 12 Airbus 330 wide-body aircraft from 2029. The airline expects passenger capacity to return to 80% of pre-pandemic levels in 2023, with plans for more flights to Europe and North America.

images.alt_text: Matti Lehmus, Neste's chief executive, says the SAF plant in Singapore is able to support a number of different markets, including the European and American markets.
Hong Kong’s main carrier, also one of the world’s biggest cargo airlines by capacity, is mulling purchasing either Airbus A350 freighters or Boeing 777-8F jets, the people said.

site_title: China stocks slide as Covid flare-ups dent optimism
summary: China's stock market slid 2% in its fourth consecutive decline, erasing the month's 22% rally, as reported Covid deaths and tightened restrictions dampened investor optimism. The Hang Seng Index fell, and the onshore yuan weakened against the US dollar. Analysts predict a slow reopening due to the high number of cases and winter approaching, with some strategists remaining bullish on the market. China's government has issued new guidelines to optimize Covid restrictions, but the path to reopening remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: Some delivery services have experienced delays after residents of the sprawling Chaoyang district, home to nearly 3.5 million people, were urged to stay home during the weekend.

site_title: StanChart sees Asia, Middle East as bright spots in weak global economy
summary: Standard Chartered predicts Asia and the Middle East will outperform other regions in the weak global economy, driven by growth in transaction banking and financial markets businesses. CEO Simon Cooper sees economies in these regions continuing to thrive, despite Western countries facing contraction. StanChart has seen a 40% rise in pre-tax profit in the third quarter and raised its income growth forecast, citing rising rates and supply-chain shifts. Cooper highlights India as a beneficiary of these shifts, and notes that StanChart's focus on growth markets positions the bank for success.

images.alt_text: StanChart mainly relies on capturing trade flows between its key markets of Asia, Africa and the Middle East but it lacks the heft of larger rivals in commercial banking and investment banking.
Lye, a former Mediacorp actor, brings over 20 years of banking experience to Standard Chartered.
The Awwa School students, aged 15-16, were introduced to various job roles at the bank’s newly revamped flagship branch at Six Battery Road, such as that of a sales and services manager.

site_title: BT, UOB partner to launch Sustainability Impact Awards, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The Statista and TIA (The Infocomm Media Development Authority) of Singapore are set to award the Top Fintech Companies for 2026. This year's awards recognize and celebrate the outstanding contributions of Singapore's fintech industry. The award ceremony will honor companies that have demonstrated exceptional innovation, growth, and impact in the fintech sector. The winners will be chosen based on their achievements in areas such as financial inclusion, digital payments, and financial technology. The awards aim to promote Singapore's fintech ecosystem and foster a culture of innovation and excellence. The winners will be announced in 2026.

site_title: ‘Wakanda’ extends its box-office reign in North American theatres
summary: Disney and Marvel's 'Black Panther: Wakanda Forever' continued its box-office dominance in North American theatres, earning an estimated $67.3 million for the second consecutive weekend. Despite being below industry expectations, the film's global total stands at $546 million. The film outperformed its closest competitor, 'The Menu', by seven times, while 'The Chosen Season 3: Episodes 1 & 2' and 'Black Adam' took third and fourth place respectively. The film's success reinforces its position as a box-office leader despite a relatively slow start.

images.alt_text: “Wakanda Forever” revolves around grief, loyalty, vengeance and territorial security, and its music – both the “inspired by” album and a separate “Original Score” album by Goransson – is largely somber, even ominous.

site_title: Elton John bids farewell to America with 'emotional' Los Angeles concert
summary: Elton John bid farewell to his US fans with a "very special, very emotional" concert at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, marking the final US stop of his farewell tour. The 75-year-old musician, who has a long-standing love affair with the city, performed a career-spanning set featuring hits like "Goodbye, Yellow Brick Road" and "Tiny Dancer." The sold-out show, live-streamed on Disney+, was attended by 55,000 fans, many dressed in elaborate costumes. John announced he will spend more time with his husband and two sons after the tour.

images.alt_text: John, 75, was ranked the ranked the top solo artist in US chart history in Billboard’s 2019 list of the Greatest Artists of All Time and third overall behind The Beatles and The Rolling Stones.
Elton John has Covid, postpones US tour dates

site_title: Whistling in the dark: Hunt’s autumn statement
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt warned of a severe financial crisis in his autumn statement, echoing concerns about the country's economic woes. The crisis was exacerbated by the pandemic, political instability, and a mini-budget that caused panic. Hunt's statement aimed to calm the markets and reassure the public, but its severity was seen as a sign of the government's struggles to address the economic issues. The statement comes as the UK is awaiting the outcome of the general election in 2024, with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hoping to last until then.

images.alt_text: epa10307958 British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt departs his home in London, Britain, 16 November 2022. Hunt is set to announce his Autumn Statement to parliament on 17 November, with tax rises and government cuts expected.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: GoTo 9M net loss widens to 20.32 trillion rupiah
summary: GoTo Group, an Indonesian tech giant, reported a net loss of 20.32 trillion rupiah (S$1.8 billion) for the nine-month period ended Sep 30, widening from 11.58 trillion rupiah a year earlier. Higher expenses, particularly sales and marketing, drove the increase. Despite this, net revenue rose to 7.97 trillion rupiah from 3.4 trillion rupiah.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
从一家只有20名电单车出租司机团队，到现在拥有食品外卖、包裹快递、支付等20多项服务的东南亚科技巨头，Gojek今天的成功，凸显了数码化趋势带来的巨大潜力。 （GoTo提供）

site_title: Crypto markets sag as funds drained from FTX switch out of Ether
summary: Crypto markets experienced a decline on Monday, with Bitcoin shedding 4% and Ether falling 7% over two days. Speculation surrounds funds drained from FTX, with some being transferred out of Ether, possibly to cash out. FTX administrators discovered $3.1 billion owed to top creditors, raising concerns about the stability of other digital-asset outfits. Experts warn of the need for regulatory clarity and caution against hype and speculation, with some predicting potential blowups in the crypto market.

images.alt_text: The bankruptcy of FTX potentially caused billions of dollars in losses for millions of account holders and sparked investigations into allegations of wrongdoing.

site_title: What will Russia without Putin look like? Maybe this
summary: A group of Russian opposition figures, including well-known politicians and local representatives, met in Poland to devise a plan to transform the country without Vladimir Putin. They propose an "act on peace" to demobilize the army, end the occupation of Ukraine, and create a joint investigation group for war crimes. They also aim to dismantle the security services' influence, create a new parliamentary democracy, and grant greater sovereignty to regions. However, the congress's legitimacy is questioned, and its economic plans are vague, lacking a strong social safety net and discussion of transitioning Russia's economy away from energy exports.

images.alt_text: epa10298067 Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulates personnel and veterans of the Russia's Interior Ministry agencies on their professional holiday, in Moscow, Russia, 10 November 2022.  EPA-EFE/MIKHAIL METZEL / KREMLIN POOL / SPUTNIK MANDATORY CREDIT

site_title: HSBC hires former Citi head to front wealth and personal banking business
summary: HSBC Singapore has appointed Ashmita Acharya as its head of wealth and personal banking, effective January 18, 2023. Acharya, former retail banking head for Singapore at Citibank, will oversee the bank's retail banking, wealth management, insurance, asset management, and global private banking services. She replaces Anurag Mathur, who is leaving for external opportunities. Acharya's extensive experience is expected to help HSBC's wealth and personal banking strategy, with a focus on mass and emerging affluent and high net worth segments in Singapore, a global wealth and sustainability hub.

images.alt_text: Ashmita Acharya, new HSBC Singapore head of wealth and personal banking with effect from Jan 18, 2023.

site_title: The EU’s trillion-euro question
summary: The European Union is facing a severe economic and political crisis due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which has led to soaring gas, fuel, and electricity prices. The EU's energy system has been vulnerable for years, and the crisis has highlighted the need for greater resilience and solidarity among member states. The EU's 160-180 billion euro annual budget and lending initiatives are insufficient to address the crisis, and a new 1 trillion euro financing mechanism is proposed to increase EU-wide solidarity, encourage investment, and bolster economic security. The mechanism would include three pillars: an emergency fund, a sovereignty fund, and a geopolitics fund, to support investments in renewable energy, technological development, and critical infrastructure in Ukraine and beyond.

images.alt_text: The planned phase-out will take place despite Germany’s July decision to reactivate coal-fired power plants and to extend the lifespans of those already operating.

site_title: Paying rent in the interim makes sense for would-be first time home buyers
summary: For potential first-time home buyers, paying rent in the interim can be a rational choice, especially in a turbulent market with rising home rental rates. This allows individuals to build up savings and earn power while also avoiding significant transaction costs associated with buying and selling homes. The study found that 66% of Singaporeans between 22-29 years old chose to rent over buying due to lack of savings. For those eligible to buy HDB flats, paying rent can be beneficial as it allows them to secure the right unit while building up their savings, which can be used to fund the purchase of a home.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
HDB rents for October increased by 1.8 per cent from the previous month, with mature and non-mature estate rents rising by 1.6 per cent and 2.1 per cent respectively.

site_title: Yoma to buy Telenor’s stake in Wave Money for US$40m instead of US$53m
summary: Yoma Strategic's subsidiary will acquire Telenor's 51% stake in Wave Money for US$40 million, down from the initial US$53 million. The deal, which includes 510,000 ordinary shares and 17.9 million redeemable preference shares, remains unchanged in terms of other material aspects. The parties agreed on the revised consideration after reassessing their business strategies and economic outlook. Yoma Strategic is confident the financial services pillar will contribute to the company's business performance over the next three to five years.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Yoma reports 17.7% lower Q1 revenue but says profitability improved
Yoma to acquire controlling interest in Wave Money via US$53m deal

site_title: Hung parliament weighs on Malaysia’s ringgit
summary: The Malaysian ringgit fell 0.7% to almost RM4.59 per dollar on Monday, Nov 21, after a hung parliament resulted from the weekend's election. The currency's decline is expected to continue if party leaders cannot form a stable government, with technicals suggesting a possible return to RM4.75. A weak ringgit may add to challenges facing the new administration due to higher import costs and price pressures, driven by global oil prices and China's slowing growth, as well as a hawkish Federal Reserve.

site_title: Sequoia-backed WeLab seeks funds at US$2b value: sources
summary: WeLab, a Hong Kong-based fintech firm backed by Sequoia Capital and billionaire Li Ka-shing, is seeking a new funding round valued at approximately $2 billion. The company aims to raise $200-250 million to accelerate growth plans, following a 1.5 times year-on-year growth in its loan balance since the COVID-19 pandemic. WeLab operates consumer-credit platforms and virtual lenders, with over 50 million individual users and 700 enterprise customers. The fundraising is ongoing, with existing and new investors being considered.

images.alt_text: WeLab founder and CEO Simon Loong said the company is focused on enhancing cross-country collaboration with partners.

site_title: Indonesia 2023 GDP growth may slow to 4.4%: central bank
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Perry Warjiyo, has predicted the country's annual economic growth may slow to 4.37% in 2023 due to domestic monetary tightening. This forecast is lower than the previous 2022 GDP growth forecast of 4.5-5.3%. The central bank maintained a headline inflation forecast of 6.11% for end-2022 and 3.61% for end-2023. This adjustment is attributed to the impact of monetary policy tightening and global economic volatility.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia (BI) raised the 7-day reverse repo rate to 5.25 per cent, as expected by the majority of economists polled by Reuters.

site_title: Updated industry digital plans will offer more integrated digital solutions for SMEs
summary: Singapore's 20 refreshed industry digital plans (IDPs) will provide more integrated digital solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), particularly in the food services sector. The updated IDPs include a new roadmap on cybersecurity and data protection measures, and will focus on assisting SMEs to overcome rising labor costs and address trends such as digital ordering and e-commerce. Four new solution categories unique to the food services sector were added, including connected business suites and smart central kitchen management systems. The IDPs aim to help SMEs deepen their digital capabilities and remain relevant in a post-Covid world.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

ST20221121-202205359452-Lim Yaohui-Osmond Chia-ocplan21/

Minister of State for Trade and Industry, Ms Low Yen Ling and Senior Minister of State for Communications and Information, Mr Tan Kiat How; looking at a Service Delivery Robot at Heavenly Wang, a company which has benefitted from the IDP, at Changi Airport Terminal 2 on Nov 21, 2022. 

Heavenly Wang has deployed 2 service delivery robots at its T2 outlet. There is a separate back kitchen for heavy duty cooking and washing; and a front kitchen for light cooking and food plating. The service delivery robots can transport heavy food, trays and crockery between the two kitchens (30 to 50m). Each service robot can transport up to 50kg of food each time, relieving staff from laborious activity.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

site_title: Tourism rebound aiding Thailand’s economic recovery
summary: Thailand's economy expanded at the fastest pace in over a year, with its GDP rising 4.5% in the July-September quarter. This growth is attributed to a rebound in tourism, which accounts for 12% of the economy and 20% of jobs. The country's travel sector is expected to continue growing, with foreign tourist arrivals forecast to reach 23.5 million in 2023. This growth is expected to support the country's current account surplus and is seen as a positive sign for the central bank's decision on monetary policy tightening.

images.alt_text: Thailand is seeking to lure more foreign visitors in the post-Covid period by promoting itself as a world-class destination for medical treatment.

site_title: Geo Energy says it has enough funds to stay in coal mining, may acquire assets
summary: Singapore-listed Geo Energy Resources, led by CEO Tung Kum Hon, has sufficient funds to continue its coal mining operations. Despite funding being scarce for coal companies due to banks' caution, Geo Energy has a 20-30% margin if coal prices fall to US$28 per tonne and enough cash reserves to be an acquirer if asset prices come down. Its cash reserves, high liquidity, and debt-free balance sheet position it advantageously compared to peers.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Golden Energy and Resources had on Nov 9 sounded its intention to give shareholders an option of cash, or a combination of cash and shares, to delist from SGX.
The series of proposals come as Gear seeks to reduce its exposure to energy coal by shifting away from its existing energy coal business currently conducted by Gems through the proposed distribution.
While robust coal demand and high prices are helping to prop up companies’ earnings now, some coal producers are already taking steps to diversify their business and revenue streams.
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources
Higher average selling price of energy and metallurgical coal have sweetened Golden Energy and Resources' (GEAR) earnings

site_title: Airlines push for lone pilot flights to cut costs despite safety fears
summary: Airlines and regulators are pushing for single-pilot flights to reduce costs and alleviate crew shortages, but pilots and some regulators express concerns about safety. Over 40 countries, including Germany, the UK, and New Zealand, have asked the UN aviation standards body to make single-pilot flights a safe reality. The European Union Aviation Safety Agency aims to allow solo flights by 2027, with automation and remote assistance to replace the expertise of a second pilot. However, pilots worry about the psychological and technical barriers, and the impact on crew training, medical requirements, and mental health.

images.alt_text: An airplane prepares to land at Cointrin airport in Geneva, Switzerland December 5, 2017. REUTERS/Pierre Albouy

site_title: Chinese carmakers target more European sales with five-star EVs
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers are targeting European sales with five-star EVs, aiming to overcome concerns over the quality of Chinese-made cars. Several Chinese EVs have received top safety ratings, including the Xpeng P7 sedan and Great Wall Motors' WEY Coffee 01 hybrid SUV. Chinese EV makers believe safety is crucial for sales, particularly in the corporate fleet market. With supply chain shortages, European carmakers are focusing on retail clients, creating an opportunity for Chinese EV makers to gain market share. Chinese brands are expected to represent 12.5-20% of Europe's fully-electric vehicle market by 2030.

images.alt_text: An Xpeng Inc. P7 performance electric car is seen outside the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) ahead of the Chinese company's IPO trading under the stock symbol "XPEV" in New York, U.S., August 27, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: Financing the climate transition is ‘the responsible thing to do’, but that cannot be leapfrogged: panellists
summary: A panel at the Bloomberg New Economy Forum discussed financing the climate transition, with CEOs from financial services companies emphasizing the need for gradual, time-based transition to renewable energy. While a blanket ban on fossil fuels may hurt developing economies, transitioning from dirtiest to cleaner fuels and eventually to renewable power is considered responsible. However, ongoing development of the oil and gas sector is still necessary to avoid stifling growth opportunities. The panel also highlighted the growth potential of Asia and improving US-China relations, with optimism for a more positive and earlier rebound in sentiments around Asia in 2023.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. Picture taken July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

From left: Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Mark Carney, co-chair of the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, and Hiro Mizuno, UN Special Envoy on Innovative Finance and Sustainable Investments.
Few would question the urgency of climate action. The harder nut to crack is how to make the transition an inclusive one.

site_title: Hiring activity cools in tech, manufacturing amid broader caution by employers
summary: Hiring activity in tech and manufacturing has cooled globally, with companies restructurating and manufacturers facing slowing demand for goods. Despite this, demand for tech talent remains strong across other industries, particularly in emerging areas like greentech and medtech. Recruiters expect tech solutions to remain essential for business transformation, but hiring growth is expected to slow down and balance salary growth expectations. Meanwhile, sectors like aviation, hospitality, and retail are seeing increased demand for frontline roles, driven by the upcoming festive season and reopening tailwinds.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Singapore employment rises 75,600 in Q3 but momentum may be easing

Overall unemployment rate slid to 1.9 per cent in August; resident unemployment, to 2.7 per cent and citizen unemployment rate, to 2.8 per cent, according to the Ministry of Manpower's monthly unemployment situation report.
(Above) People having lunch at Waterway Point in October. Some starting salaries of F&B staff have risen by more than a fifth in recent months.

site_title: Malaysia assets decline amid deepening political instability
summary: Malaysia's stocks and ringgit declined after the country's first-ever hung parliament was formed, prolonging political instability. The benchmark KLCI Index fell 1.4% amid a broader Asia slump. Rising living costs and a fragile economy have fueled discontent. Veteran leaders Anwar Ibrahim and Muhyiddin Yassin are competing to form the next government, with investors largely unfazed by the result. Analysts predict markets may take the outcome in stride, focusing on sectors like travel and tourism, consumer goods, and commodities.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's economy recorded double digits growth in Q3 2022, driven by strong domestic consumption and robust exports.

site_title: PropertyGuru’s Q3 earnings reverses into the red at S$7.4m
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singapore-based online property portal, reported a net loss of S$7.4 million for the third quarter of 2022, reversing its profit-making performance from the previous quarter. The company's revenue increased by 47% to S$34.6 million, driven by growth in all markets and segments. Adjusted Ebitda was positive at S$5.7 million, while loss per share stood at S$0.05. The company anticipates a full-year revenue of between S$134 million and S$138 million due to global inflationary pressures and governmental counteractions.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
