site_title: Toyota-Panasonic’s battery venture looking for new coastal site
summary: Prime Planet Energy & Solutions, a joint venture between Toyota and Panasonic, is searching for a new domestic manufacturing site with a seaport and clean energy access to expand its electric vehicle battery production. The company aims to lower production costs by 60% by 2025 and slash prices to remain competitive in the market. With rising raw materials prices, Toyota has committed 4 trillion yen to electrify its product lineup, and Prime Planet plans to adopt Toyota's kaizen process to increase productivity and speed up production.

images.alt_text: The world’s No 1 automaker pioneered mass-market hybrid vehicles with the debut of the Prius in 1997 and contends that the technology still has a long way to go.

site_title: Japan’s Mitoma ready to torment Germany at World Cup
summary: Japan's Kaoru Mitoma, a winger for Brighton & Hove Albion, is set to face Germany in the World Cup opener. Mitoma, 25, has impressed with his talent, causing havoc with his runs and scoring goals in the Premier League. He has also shown his worth for Japan, notching a brace against Australia to secure their World Cup spot. Mitoma is confident he will be "100 per cent" ready for the match despite arriving late due to illness.

images.alt_text: The first Fifa World Cup to be held in the Middle East will feature 64 matches over 29 days.
The ticket prices in Qatar are the most expensive ever for World Cup games in the last 20 years.
Qatar had previously said that alcohol will be available in designated “fan zones” outside stadiums, and other hospitality venues.
Long before the final whistle at the spectacular Bedouin tent-inspired Al Bayt Stadium, the host nation’s fans among the 67,372 crowd had started heading for the exits.
Ecuador players celebrate their 2-0 lead during the Fifa World Cup 2022 match between Qatar and Ecuador at Al Bayt Stadium in Al Khor, Qatar, Nov 20, 2022.

Migrant workers in Qatar watch the Qatar vs Ecuador match, Nov 20, 2022. Fifa had confirmed support for a permanent International Labour Organization (ILO) office in Doha that would support and advise migrant workers.

site_title: Buy cheap or pay for reliability?
summary: A global economic downturn, driven by economic warfare, climate change, and supply chain disruptions, is prompting companies to reevaluate their purchasing decisions. Instead of focusing on cost, companies should consider the purpose and target market of their products, as the answers depend on purpose, not means. Redefining a product's purpose can lead to new growth opportunities, but it requires significant changes and can be a difficult path to climb. Companies must be prepared to adapt and handle change effectively to remain competitive in a rapidly changing world.

images.alt_text: I was 13 when an old Polish soldier, living out the war as a refugee in Britain, taught me how to plough. He showed me that aiming for the “Tree on the other side of the Field” would achieve a straight furrow, and all subsequent furrows would follow the line of the first. Ever since then I have known each morning, when rising from bed, where my Tree is.
We all shape our own life patterns within the constraints and opportunities we are given.
The world has never been so connected, and the connections are dynamic and ever-changing.

site_title: ESR’s Ara to establish US$1b infrastructure fund in partnership with China
summary: ARA, a subsidiary of ESR Group, is partnering with the Export-Import Bank of China (Exim) to establish a US$1 billion infrastructure fund, the China-Asean Investment Cooperation Fund II (CAF II). The fund will focus on infrastructure, energy, and IT with a strong emphasis on sustainability and ESG standards. CAF II is ESR's first infrastructure fund and the largest Asean-focused private infrastructure fund. The partnership aims to enhance connectivity, trade, and investment between China and Asean countries, capitalizing on growing demand for renewable energy and resilient infrastructure assets.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sun Electric's Chief Executive Officer Matthew Peloso (L) walks along rows of rooftop solar panels, operated under the company's SolarSpace energy retail programme at a factory in Singapore February 29, 2016. Singapore on Monday began retail distribution of power generated from rooftop solar panels, potentially shaking up the country's state-controlled power market that charges some of the highest prices in the world for electricity. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: Disney boots CEO, brings back Bob Iger to lead company
summary: Disney ousted CEO Bob Chapek and brought back former CEO Bob Iger, effective immediately, as the company embarks on industry transformation. Iger, who led Disney for 15 years, will return for at least two years. The move comes after Disney's stock has fallen 41% this year due to concerns over rising expenses. Iger previously led the company from 2005 to 2020, increasing market capitalization five-fold. The change follows Iger's return to the company after a falling out with Chapek, who had handled the "Don't Say Gay" law in Florida.

images.alt_text: The move comes after Disney misses Wall Street estimates for quarterly earnings on Tuesday as the entertainment giant racks up more losses from its push into streaming video,
Disney plans to sail the ship internationally.

site_title: Chinese banks maintain lending rates as PBOC signals caution
summary: Chinese banks maintained benchmark lending rates for a third month as the People's Bank of China (PBOC) signals caution about the inflation outlook. The one-year loan prime rate (LPR) remained at 3.65% and the five-year rate at 4.3%, indicating limited scope for further monetary policy easing. The PBOC warned of accelerating inflation as the economy picks up, following recent steps to address the property crisis and stabilize liquidity conditions. Economists expect no change in LPRs by the end of 2022, citing the recent relaxation of Covid controls and surging cases.

images.alt_text: The world’s second largest economy grew just 3 per cent in the first three quarters of this year, well below the annual target of around 5.5 per cent.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Ascott Reit, EC World Reit
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Real Estate Investment Trust (Ascott Reit MTN) issued S$165 million of 5% notes to refinance existing borrowings. The notes are part of its S$2 billion multi-currency debt issuance program. Meanwhile, EC World Real Estate Investment Trust's transaction financing for its divestment properties has been delayed due to "stringent Covid-19 controls" and events in China, potentially affecting the completion of the proposed divestment by Dec 31.

site_title: The case for sharing how much you earn at work
summary: Sharing salary and benefits with industry peers can improve equity and promote career advancement. Discussing and comparing notes can aid decision-making for raises or job changes. However, it's essential to consider who to share this information with, such as colleagues or subordinates, and not with those who may feel resentful or undervalued. Companies should also be transparent about their executive salaries to align with global standards and promote fairness. Disclosing salary to prospective employers can compromise negotiation power, so it's crucial to approach these conversations strategically.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
If you work for a listco your family controls, does pay incentivise you the way it would for an outsider?
Lian Beng says the disclosure of the employees' remuneration might result in challenges in a highly competitive business environment with a limited talent pool.
Nearly every company will be required to include salary ranges for job postings that are shared on public sites and on internal bulletin boards.

A review of corporate governance disclosures by KPMG in Singapore, published in September, found only 35 per cent of companies disclosed the actual remuneration of directors on a named basis, while 18 per cent did so for CEOs.
Should I disclose my salary?
Progressive wages should promote productivity, career progression: MOM, SNEF

site_title: BT launches Thrive newsletter for young adults
summary: BT launches Thrive, a newsletter and community initiative focused on providing young adults with money, career, and personal development advice. The weekly newsletter and Instagram page will offer bite-sized pieces on topics such as investing, mental health, and balancing career and well-being. Dedicated events and webinars will also be held to facilitate honest conversations. The initiative aims to provide trustworthy and accessible guidance to fresh graduates and first-jobbers navigating the challenges of rising prices and uncertain economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Tee Zhuo

site_title: EC World Reit flags potential asset sale delay due to transaction financing hiccups
summary: EC World Reit's divestment of 2.03 billion yuan (S$392.7 million) in properties may be delayed due to delays in lenders' internal approval processes for transaction financing. The Reit's manager cited "stringent" Covid-19 controls and holidays in October as the cause. The transaction financing long-stop date has lapsed, potentially pushing the divestment past the Reit's deadline to repay a portion of its outstanding loans by December 31.

images.alt_text: Goh Toh Sim, executive director and chief executive of the EC World Reit's manager, said the results are “consistent with the improving stability in China during the quarter”.
Ascott Reit MTN, a wholly-owned subsidiary of CapitaLand Ascott Reit's trustee, has issued S$165 million of 5 per cent notes due May 18, 2026.

site_title: What you need to know about layoffs and retrenchment
summary: Layoffs and retrenchments are becoming more prevalent in Singapore, with tech behemoths like Twitter and Meta leading the charge. The Ministry of Manpower requires companies with 10 employees to notify retrenchments within five days, but there is no mandatory retrenchment payment regime. Employees who have worked at least two years may be eligible for benefits, but these are typically negotiated between the employer and employee. Disguised retrenchments, such as "quiet firing" or mischaracterizing a retrenchment as a sacking for misconduct, are also common. Employees can seek support and recourse through the Tripartite Advisory and various dispute resolution bodies.

images.alt_text: Hiring weakness has been spotted in sectors like manufacturing and infrastructure, said recruiters.
Employees packing goods at Goto's e-commerce unit Tokopedia's warehouse in Jakarta.
The departures include many engineers responsible for fixing bugs and preventing service outages, raising questions about the stability of the platform amid the loss of employees.
Andy Jassy has been trying to reduce expenses amid slowing growth in several areas of Amazon’s business.
Offices for Twitter in San Francisco, on Oct. 6, 2022.
There will be plenty of pain, not just for companies and their investors, but also for laid-off employees and retail investors.

site_title: Younger Chinese are spurning factory jobs that power the economy
summary: Younger Chinese are rejecting factory jobs due to low pay, long hours, and risk of injuries, contributing to a deepening labor shortage. Over 80% of Chinese manufacturers face labor shortages, equivalent to 10-30% of their workforce. China's Ministry of Education forecasts a shortage of nearly 30 million manufacturing workers by 2025. Younger Chinese prefer alternative jobs with better wages and working conditions, with many adopting a "lying flat" lifestyle, and record numbers applying for postgraduate studies. Manufacturers struggle to balance the need for younger workers with the risk of eroding their competitive advantage.

images.alt_text: Some delivery services have experienced delays after residents of the sprawling Chaoyang district, home to nearly 3.5 million people, were urged to stay home during the weekend.

Driving the confidence among sell-side analysts are the surprise policy shifts in recent weeks, from easing rigid Covid controls to stronger remedies for real estate woes and efforts to improve ties with the US.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Monday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 5.4 points to 3,277.63, tracking Wall Street gains. Despite 64 losers and 53 gainers, 35.5 million securities worth S$64.8 million changed hands. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data, which may influence investor sentiment on interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Ascott Reit MTN, a wholly-owned subsidiary of CapitaLand Ascott Reit's trustee, has issued S$165 million of 5 per cent notes due May 18, 2026.

site_title: How workplace coaching unlocks potential, builds antifragility
summary: A distinctive coaching framework, the Pearls Coaching Framework, introduced by "Think. Coach. Thrive!", offers people leaders a powerful business model to unlock human talents and develop antifragility in organisations. Antifragility refers to a characteristic in individuals and teams that thrive in spite of stressors, bouncing back even stronger. The framework strengthens self and teams by unlocking purpose, mastery, and autonomy, generating motivation and positive energy towards key outcomes. By adopting a systems-thinking approach and embracing double-loop learning, organisations can build resilience and thrive in uncertain environments.

images.alt_text: Performance management must change for hybrid work to work

site_title: G7 demands tougher sanctions on North Korea after latest salvo
summary: The G7 nations condemned North Korea's "reckless" launch of a new intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) with a potential range to hit the US mainland. The missile, dubbed "Hwasong Gun 17," was test-fired on Friday, marking the 30th missile launch this month. The G7 demanded tougher sanctions and called for a united response from the international community, including significant measures from the UN Security Council to halt the tests. The G7 reiterated demands for North Korea's nuclear program to be verifiably dismantled and stated the nation "will never have the status of a nuclear-weapon state."

images.alt_text: Japan says the missile, which is capable of flying as far as 15,000 km, flew to an altitude of about 6,000 km with a range of 1,000 km, before landing in the sea roughly 200 km west of Oshima-Oshima Island in Hokkaido.
An intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) is launched in this undated photo released on Nov 19, 2022 by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency.

North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, with his wife Ri Sol Ju and their daughter, speaks on the day of the launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) in this undated photo released on Nov 19, 2022 by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency.

site_title: Banks are raising interest rates even as investors have been piling into stocks – what happens now?
summary: Interest rates continue to rise, eroding the attractiveness of stocks, with investors seeking higher returns in savings and fixed deposit accounts. Major banks, including OCBC, DBS, and UOB, have raised fixed home loan interest rates to above 4% to position themselves for a long period of higher interest rates. The 10-year Singapore government bond yield has nearly doubled to 3.1%, potentially leading to a review of Central Provident Fund (CPF) interest rates. Despite a recent market rally, investors should be cautious of the Fed's hawkish stance and consider positioning themselves for higher interest rates and weaker economic growth.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
DBS continues to have a home loan specially for home owners of public housing flats at 2.6 per cent a year – similar to the current HDB concessionary interest rate.
CPF ordinary savings for fixed deposits at OCBC at 3.4 per cent per annum.

site_title: Gold stalls for central bank interest rate cues
summary: Gold prices stalled at around $1,750 per ounce on Monday, marking its worst week in five, as traders awaited central bank interest rate cues. Spot gold fell 1.2% last week, its worst weekly performance since October, due to institutional investors' wariness of further gains. The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates by half a percentage point at its December meeting, which could discourage investing in gold, which doesn't bear interest.

site_title: Qatar become first World Cup hosts to lose opener with 2-0 defeat to Ecuador
summary: Qatar became the first World Cup host team to lose its opening match, falling 2-0 to Ecuador at Al Bayt Stadium on November 20, 2022. Enner Valencia scored twice, including a penalty, for Ecuador, while Qatar struggled to find its footing despite a large crowd of 67,000. The defeat leaves Qatar in a precarious position, needing to avoid defeat in its next match against Senegal to avoid elimination.

images.alt_text: epa10316343 Players of Ecuador celebrate the 2-0 lead during the FIFA World Cup 2022 group A Opening Match between Qatar and Ecuador at Al Bayt Stadium in Al Khor, Qatar, 20 November 2022.  EPA-EFE/Noushad Thekkayil

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Lessons learnt from 2022 (Ep 131)
summary: Kelvin Tay, UBS' regional CIO, shares insights on lessons learned from 2022 in a podcast episode. The year was marked by punishing losses for investors, but key takeaways include adapting to changing market conditions, focusing on risk management, and diversifying portfolios. Tay emphasizes the importance of understanding market trends and adjusting investment strategies accordingly. He also highlights the potential for growth in alternative investments, such as structured notes, and the resurgence of gold as a safe-haven asset. These insights aim to provide valuable financial tips for investors heading into 2023.

site_title: UK must focus on growth as well as inflation: Business lobby
summary: The UK government must focus on growth to improve long-term prospects, according to the Confederation of British Industry (CBI). Director General Tony Danker says the government needs to unlock private investment, change rules to overcome political barriers, and allow more migration to fill job vacancies. While fiscal credibility has been restored, businesses must also show greater ingenuity to drive growth, as 15 years of low growth and flatlining productivity are not sustainable. The CBI emphasizes that growth is essential to overcome the impact of austerity measures and avoid a repeat of low growth.

images.alt_text: Members of the public visit Turbine Hall A on the opening day of Battersea Power Station in south London on October 14, 2022. - With its four huge white chimneys Battersea Power Station has dominated the London skyline for decades, making it one of the British capital's most distinctive landmarks. Now, nearly 40 years after it was finally decommissioned, it is set to reopen as an office, shopping and restaurant hub plus apartments, in the latest major redevelopment of former industrial sites. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / AFP)

site_title: A*Star and RVAC Medicines to set up joint lab to develop mRNA vaccines
summary: A*Star and RVAC Medicines have signed a master research collaboration agreement to develop mRNA vaccines in Singapore. They will set up a joint laboratory at A*Star's Bioprocessing Technology Institute to manufacture mRNA vaccines and therapeutics. The collaboration aims to aid in preclinical asset development and enable local innovators and global manufacturers to access the manufacturing platform. The partnership combines A*Star's expertise in biotherapeutics and RVAC's capabilities in mRNA and vaccine technologies, with the potential to advance the development of mRNA vaccines and therapeutics.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
BioNTech expects the facility to create more than 100 jobs by 2024.

site_title: Signs indicate more downside likely for USDJPY
summary: The Japanese yen is expected to experience a deeper retracement against the US dollar due to technical observations, including a bearish crossover of the 20-day exponential moving average (20 EMA) below the 50-day EMA and a bear pennant pattern on the daily chart. The Relative Strength Index (RSI) and Moving Average Convergence Divergence (MACD) also indicate a bearish sentiment. Immediate support levels are at 139 and 137.7, with potential targets at 135.5 and 130.82 if prices break down further.

site_title: Ukraine nuclear plant shelled; UN warns: 'You're playing with fire!'
summary: The Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine, under Russian control, was shelled on Sunday, Nov 20, drawing condemnation from the UN nuclear watchdog. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) reported over a dozen blasts, with no critical nuclear safety and security systems damaged. The IAEA head, Rafael Grossi, warned that such attacks risk a major nuclear disaster, stating "you're playing with fire!" Moscow and Kyiv both blamed each other for the shelling, with the IAEA calling for immediate action to stop the attacks.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian refugees leaving a Polish language class organised by the aid group We Support Ukraine Together in Lodz, Poland on Nov 8, 2022. Poland gave millions of people fleeing the war in Ukraine a warm welcome.

site_title: Empty seats tell story as Qatar World Cup party falls flat
summary: Thousands of empty seats at Qatar's Al Bayt Stadium told the story of a disappointing World Cup debut, with fans starting to leave before the final whistle. Despite initial excitement, the crowd dwindled as Ecuador took the lead in the second half. The largely empty stadium was a stark contrast to the festivities and optimism earlier that day, with security forces on high alert due to concerns over the host nation's suitability for the tournament.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Group A - Qatar v Ecuador - Al Bayt Stadium, Al Khor, Qatar - November 20, 2022
Empty seats are seen during the match REUTERS/Dylan Martinez

site_title: TSMC founder says US welcomes its Arizona plant plan
summary: TSMC founder Morris Chang stated that the US welcomes the company's Arizona plant plan, despite the potential 50% higher cost of chip production compared to Taiwan. Vice-President Kamala Harris has welcomed the decision, and a ceremony for the $12 billion plant is planned for next month. Chang sees the US plant as "very important" and "very much needed" for the country.

site_title: Indonesia caps minimum wage increase at 10% for 2023
summary: Indonesia has set a minimum wage increase of 10% for 2023, falling short of labor unions' demand for a 25% increase. The increase will be computed using a new formula, and provinces and cities will have until November 28 and December 7 to decide on minimum wage levels. The move aims to maintain people's purchasing power and boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: Morning commuters in Jakarta, Indonesia.Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong leader tests positive for Covid on return from Apec
summary: Hong Kong leader John Lee tested positive for Covid-19 on his return from an APEC summit, where he met with Chinese President Xi Jinping and other heads of state. Lee's office said he is undergoing quarantine and will continue to work from home during his isolation period. This marks his first overseas trip since the pandemic and his first since taking office as Hong Kong's chief executive in July. The trip aimed to revive Hong Kong's status as a regional financial hub.

site_title: Investors in 2023 seek ESG ugly ducklings that are ready to blossom: Morgan Stanley
summary: Asia-Pacific investors are expected to shift towards owning "ESG improvers" in 2023, focusing on companies that are improving their environmental, social, and governance metrics, rather than only "best in class" stocks. China is seen as an "attractive market for ESG" due to its dominance in ESG stocks in the region, according to a Morgan Stanley Research report. This trend is expected to benefit mainly China, with investors seeking companies that are "ready to blossom" in terms of ESG performance.

site_title: ChariTrees raises S$600,000 for its beneficiaries
summary: Over 50 Christmas trees lit up the Marina Bay Waterfront Promenade, raising S$600,000 for its beneficiaries in the 12th annual ChariTrees event. President Halimah Yacob attended the event, which has seen a 1.5-fold increase in funds raised compared to the last two years. The event supports causes such as disability support and suicide prevention, with new beneficiaries including SPD and Samaritans of Singapore.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
ChildAid 2022 promises a show of thrills and top-flight performances, on par with its pre-pandemic 2019 stage spectacle (pictured).

site_title: Memiontec eyes doubling market cap by 2026 with sights set on regional expansion
summary: Memiontec, a Singapore-based water treatment company, aims to double its market capitalization to S$500 million by 2026. The company's CEO, Tay Kiat Seng, plans to grow Memiontec through diversified services, including the operation and maintenance of water treatment plants, the sale and distribution of water treatment systems, and "sales of water" projects in Indonesia. Memiontec has secured a S$56.6 million contract with the Public Utilities Board and has a revised strategy to make strategic investments in recurring income. The company is also exploring new markets, including Vietnam, and plans to scale up project sizes and increase its footprints in existing markets.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
SGX RegCo issues Trade with Caution alert on Memiontec Holdings

site_title: FTX mayhem fails to scare futures exchanges away from crypto
summary: Futures exchanges are not backing down from crypto trading despite the collapse of FTX, with CME Group and Cboe Global Markets reaffirming their commitment to digital assets. Executives cite concerns about FTX's business model and the need for trust in markets, but express confidence in the industry's ability to recover. Regulators are probing FTX's collapse and pushing for greater oversight of the crypto industry, with some seeing potential opportunities for reputable companies to fill the gap left by FTX.

images.alt_text: The exchange owes about US$1.45 billion to its top 10 creditors, it said in a court filing on Saturday (Nov 20), without naming them.

site_title: Upset Taylor Swift says she was told Ticketmaster could handle demand
summary: Taylor Swift expressed frustration after being told Ticketmaster could handle demand for her Eras tour, but fans faced hours of waiting and being repeatedly kicked off the website during presales. Swift's team had been assured of Ticketmaster's ability to handle surge in demand, but technical issues arose. The US Justice Department is investigating whether Ticketmaster parent Live Nation Entertainment abused its power in the live music industry. Ticketmaster apologized and is working to improve its technology to meet future demand.

site_title: As Biden turns 80, Americans ask ‘What’s too old?’
summary: President Joe Biden turned 80 on November 20, 2022, marking the first time an octogenarian has held the office. As the US ages, concerns about his age have risen, with 68% of people surveyed saying he may not be up for the challenge two years from now. Biden's supporters argue that his age has not impacted his duties, citing his successful legislative record and ability to adapt. A Reuters/Ipsos poll found 46% of Democrats and 26% of Republicans believe Biden may not be up for the challenge due to his age, while 86% of Americans support an upper age limit for federal officeholders.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump on Tuesday vowed to prevent US President Joe Biden from being re-elected in 2024. Biden responded by saying the Republican “failed” his country while in office.

site_title: Investing opportunities in the carbon credit market
summary: Venture capitalists see significant opportunities in the carbon credit market, which holds promise despite its infancy and uncertainty. Carbon markets allow companies to offset their carbon footprint by buying tradable credits from projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The voluntary carbon market has grown in recent times, driven by national-level net zero commitments and corporate pledges. However, it faces challenges such as a lack of capabilities to scale the supply of offsets and wide variations in credit quality. Despite these limitations, demand for carbon credits is expected to grow, driven by shifting consumer sentiments and regulatory incentives.

site_title: Wall Street’s chorus of buy China calls is getting louder
summary: Wall Street analysts are increasingly optimistic about China's shares, driven by surprise policy shifts and a remarkable November stock rebound. Morgan Stanley lifted its targets for the MSCI China Index, predicting a 14% gain by the end of next year. Other major banks, including Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, have turned tactically positive on China, citing improved ties with the US and efforts to address real estate woes. However, market watchers caution that execution of policies is key, and some investors may still be cautious due to uncertainties surrounding China's domestic politics and COVID-19 strategy.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for November 18, 2022, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. Capesize rates declined throughout the week, with the Capesize 5TC falling to $9,305, while Panamax rates also decreased, albeit with minor corrections. Ultramax and Supramax markets were unexciting, with the Atlantic remaining positional and the US Gulf seeing some strengthening. Handysize rates were subdued, with limited fresh enquiry and downward pressure across the board. The VLCC market continued its firmer trend, with rates improving significantly on all Baltic Exchange routes. The Suezmax market saw further gains in the West, while the Aframax market in the US-Caribbean region saw a significant improvement due to tight tonnage and delays at terminals.

images.alt_text: An undated photo of a VLCC (Very Large Crude Carrier) manufactured by the Universal Shipbuilding Corporation sailing off the coast of Japan. Source: Universal Shipbuilding Corporation via Bloomberg News.

site_title: In Dublin, it's Elon Musk versus the housing market
summary: Elon Musk's Twitter office in Dublin faces a housing crisis as employees struggle to find affordable housing due to the city's chronic undersupply of new homes and mass exodus of private landlords. Despite government support measures, prices have reached a peak not seen since 2007, making it impossible for employees to simply move to Dublin and work from the office. Musk has clarified that employees are allowed to work from home, but the issue remains a significant challenge for the tech firm.

images.alt_text: Despite the recent liquidity-boosting measures, some bankers say developers continue to face credit risks given the uncertain outlook.

site_title: It was a bad week for billionaires with delusions of saving the world
summary: Billionaires have criticized their own class, highlighting how their wealth skews the public agenda towards change that benefits them, rather than addressing systemic issues. This criticism comes from prominent billionaires, including Jeff Bezos, who have long cultivated an image of benevolence. The article suggests that billionaires' vast wealth and influence are maintained by myths about their generosity, genius, and renegade spirit, and that collective action can enact policies to limit their power. This shift in narrative may lead to more meaningful social change.

site_title: UK opposition leader plans to abolish House of Lords: report
summary: UK opposition leader Keir Starmer plans to abolish the House of Lords and replace it with an elected upper chamber if Labour wins office, according to a report. The proposed chamber would continue to scrutinise legislation and amend laws. A consultation on the proposed chamber's composition and appointments process will be held, with final proposals included in Labour's next election manifesto. This reform aims to "restore trust in politics."

images.alt_text: People walk along the River Thames during sunset, with the Houses of Parliament seen in the distance, in London, Britain, October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls

site_title: The rise of retail: Empowering the ESG transition in Asia
summary: In Asia, ESG investing has seen significant growth, with cumulative flows reaching a record $260 billion over the last five years. However, challenges remain, including greenwashing and the need for standardized sustainability metrics. Technology and regulatory innovation are key to overcoming these hurdles, enabling better data aggregation and collaboration among stakeholders. Regulatory frameworks are being developed to facilitate dialogue and meaningful interactions, and emerging platforms like Singapore's ESGenome aim to standardize ESG data. As the retail investor segment becomes increasingly sophisticated, demands for greater choice and influence will drive further momentum for ESG investing in Asia.

images.alt_text: Water-stressed region in the Middle East. Concern about climate change has raised demand for ESG/sustainable investments, but globally, rules around fund labelling remain fluid and in some calses, unclear.

A study by Clarity AI found that close to 20 per cent of the 750 Article 9 funds it analysed have more than 10 per cent exposure to companies “that have violations” of United Nations Global Compact principles or the OECD Guidelines for multinational enterprises. Its research also shows that 40 per cent of the funds studied have more than a 5 per cent exposure to such violations.

site_title: COP27 approves last-ditch deal for historic climate damage fund
summary: COP27 climate talks in Egypt resulted in an early-hours deal to create a fund to pay poorer countries for climate change damage. The landmark agreement acknowledges richer nations' responsibility for harm caused by rising temperatures. However, the summit exposed fault lines on transitioning away from fossil fuels, failing to advance last year's Glasgow ambitions to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. German Foreign Minister Annalena Baerbock expressed frustration over the stonewalling of mitigation steps by large emitters and oil producers.

images.alt_text: With several other sticking points dogging this year’s UN climate talks, host country Egypt said a final deal was still not expected before the weekend.

site_title: Reluctant buyers pose main threat to Beijing's property revival efforts
summary: China's property sector, a key pillar of the economy, is struggling to recover despite recent liquidity-boosting measures. Elusive buyers, weighed down by protracted Covid-19 curbs, falling home prices, and rising unemployment, are hindering demand. Analysts say supportive measures only address supply problems, with the demand recovery still a concern. China's cash-strapped developers face credit risks, and experts predict a "largely flat trend" in new home sales in 2023, with home prices unlikely to rise significantly.

images.alt_text: This month’s property rescue package will mainly benefit private developers that have yet to default.

site_title: Collapsed FTX owes nearly US$3.1b to top 50 creditors
summary: FTX, a cryptocurrency exchange, has filed for bankruptcy protection in Delaware, owing nearly US$3.1 billion to its 50 largest creditors. The exchange owes approximately US$1.45 billion to its top 10 creditors, without naming them. FTX's bankruptcy filing affects an estimated one million customers and investors facing total losses in the billions of dollars. The company has launched a strategic review of its global assets, preparing for the sale or reorganization of some businesses.

site_title: Gabungan Parti Sarawak will back Barisan Nasional, PN, GRS to form Malaysian government
summary: Malaysia's Gabungan Parti Sarawak (GPS) has announced its support for Barisan Nasional (BN), Perikatan Nasional (PN), and Gerakan Rakyat Sarawak (GRS) to form the Malaysian government. The decision is contingent on conditions, including upholding the Federal Constitution and Sarawak's sovereignty. GPS president Johari Openg also agreed to support PN chairman Muhyiddin Yassin as the coalition's prime minister candidate, following a closely fought general election that resulted in a hung parliament.

images.alt_text: Pakatan Harapan supporters at Dorsett Grand Subang, where party leaders were gathering early on Nov 20, 2022.

site_title: China Covid cases steady as many Beijing businesses, schools shut
summary: China reported 24,435 new Covid-19 infections on November 19, near April peaks, with many shops and restaurants in Beijing's Chaoyang district closed and schools moving online. An 87-year-old Beijing man became China's first official Covid-19 fatality since May 26, raising the death toll to 5,227. The fatality may test China's tolerance for its strict zero-Covid policy, which has led to economic disruption and frustration among residents. Despite this, Chinese equities have rebounded on optimism around President Xi Jinping's policy pivots.

images.alt_text: China will build more hospitals that specialise in treating moderate and severe Covid patients, and ensure that intensive care units account for 10 per cent of all hospital beds to tend to the most vulnerable patients.

site_title: Back to the Future star and Parkinson’s activist Fox gets honorary Oscar
summary: Michael J. Fox, the actor best known for his role in the "Back to the Future" trilogy, was awarded an honorary Oscar for his campaign to fund Parkinson's research. Fox, 61, has been living with the neurodegenerative disease since his diagnosis in 1991, and has dedicated himself to raising over $1 billion for research. Despite recent health issues, including multiple broken bones and surgery on his shoulder, Fox walked to and from the stage to accept the award, which is the 12th time the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award has been given to a film industry figure.

images.alt_text: Six things to watch for at the Oscars

site_title: Banks woo savers for fixed deposits as mortgage rates climb
summary: Singapore banks are competing to attract savers with higher fixed deposit rates as mortgage rates rise. OCBC offers 3.4% per annum for CPF ordinary account savings, while UOB has a range of 3.55-3.95% for 12-36 months. DBS offers rates up to 4.25% per annum for 2-5 years. Analysts expect higher funding costs for banks, but Gerald Wong notes that consumers should balance short-term liquidity needs with long-term investment goals. The uptrend in fixed deposit rates follows accelerating home loan rates, with rates exceeding 4% for the first time.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Ry-Anne Lim
CPF ordinary savings for fixed deposits at OCBC at 3.4 per cent per annum.
DBS raised the maximum interest rate on the Multiplier account to 4.1 per cent a year, up from 3.5 per cent previously.
DBS continues to have a home loan specially for home owners of public housing flats at 2.6 per cent a year – similar to the current HDB concessionary interest rate.

site_title: A tight Malaysia election produces results, but very few answers
summary: Malaysia's general election resulted in a hung parliament, with no single party or alliance able to secure the 112 seats needed to take power. The Pakatan Harapan (PH) alliance won 82 seats, while the Perikatan Nasional (PN) alliance secured 73 seats. Despite a clear rebuff to the Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition, a coalition of parties, including Gabungan Parti Sarawak (GPS) and Gabungan Rakyat Sabah (GRS), will join PN to form a stable federal government. The future of Malaysia's politics remains uncertain, with many questions still unanswered.

images.alt_text: Pakatan Harapan supporters at Dorsett Grand Subang, where party leaders were gathering early on Nov 20, 2022.
Malaysians are also frustrated with recent political instability that they think has taken politicians’ focus away from economic development.

site_title: Voting closed in Malaysia as counting begins; 70% turnout as of 4pm
summary: Voting in Malaysia's 15th general election closed on November 19, with 70% of eligible voters casting ballots. The counting process began, and 220 parliament seats are up for grabs. Three major coalitions - Barisan Nasional, Perikatan Nasional, and Pakatan Harapan - are competing for a simple majority of 112 seats to form a government. The results are expected to be announced, but no official timeline has been set, with many Malaysians prepared for an all-night wait.

images.alt_text: Over thousands of people were affected by the floods due to heavy downpour this week, the affected victims most likely will not cast their votes on Saturday’s polls.

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits ride on pent-up travel demand and the return of events in Q3 2022
summary: Realty Investment Trusts (REITs) in Singapore's hospitality sector experienced significant growth in Q3 2022, driven by the return of large-scale events and pent-up travel demand. CDL Hospitality Trusts, CapitaLand Ascott Trust, and Far East Hospitality Trust reported improved occupancy rates and revenue per available room (RevPAR), with some trusts seeing a 43.7% increase in net property income for the first nine months of 2022. The sector's recovery is expected to continue, with Singapore's Mice industry and events driving growth, and potential pent-up demand in Japan following border reopenings.

images.alt_text: Aims Apac Reit reported higher H1 FY2023 gross revenue and net property income.  This was supported by the acquisition of Australian supermarket and grocery chain Woolworths’ headquarters, and higher rental income and recoveries from the Singapore portfolio.

site_title: 737 MAX crash victim families press US on Boeing settlement
summary: US Justice Department lawyers met with families of 737 MAX crash victims to discuss a 2021 settlement that allowed Boeing to escape criminal prosecution. The families, who are now considered "crime victims," argue the US government "lied and violated their rights" and are seeking to rescind Boeing's immunity from prosecution. The Justice Department opposes reopening the deal, citing it would impose hardships on Boeing and victims who have received compensation, while Boeing argues it has been complying with the agreement for nearly two years.

images.alt_text: In its final report, Indonesia’s National Transportation Safety Committee (KNKT) pointed to several factors that contributed to  a deadly plane crash last year that killed all 62 passengers and crew.

A Boeing 737 Max aircraft during a display at the Farnborough International Airshow in Farnborough, Britain in July. China used to take a quarter of these cash-cow jets that the US plane-maker built each year, until a pair of fatal crashes, the global pandemic and soured US-China ties came along.

site_title: US to help Thailand develop small nuclear reactors
summary: The US will assist Thailand in developing small nuclear reactors as part of its Net Zero World Initiative to combat climate change. Vice-President Kamala Harris announced the plan during a visit to Thailand, which does not currently have nuclear power. The reactors, known as small modular reactors, are considered safer and more portable than traditional nuclear reactors. US experts will provide technical assistance to deploy the technology, which aims to support Thailand's goal of going carbon neutral by 2065.

images.alt_text: Power supply has been further hit in recent weeks as the FNME-CGT union has been staging rolling strikes over wages at some nuclear power plants.

The water, used to cool reactors in the aftermath of the 2011 nuclear disaster, is being stored in huge tanks in Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear power plant, and amounted to more than 1.3 million tonnes by July.

site_title: Third Japanese cabinet minister in a month resigns in blow to PM
summary: Japan's Internal Affairs Minister Minoru Terada has resigned after acknowledging that a support group submitted funding documentation signed by a dead person. This is the third cabinet minister to leave in less than a month, dealing a significant blow to Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's already shaky support. The scandal comes amid concerns over ties between ruling politicians and the Unification Church, a group critics label as a cult. Kishida's approval ratings have sunk following the July assassination of former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, exacerbating the crisis.

images.alt_text: Total fiscal spending in the package will be 39 trillion yen, Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said, but the smaller size of the extra budget suggests part of the spending will come from already available funds.

site_title: Will any music stars perform in Qatar?
summary: Several music stars have refused to perform at the Qatar World Cup, citing human rights concerns, particularly regarding LGBT rights. Rock legend Rod Stewart and singer Dua Lipa have confirmed their absence. Shakira's team has also announced she will not perform, although her reason is not specified. In contrast, K-pop star Jungkook of BTS and US rapper Lil Baby are considered likely participants, with Lil Baby releasing an official sponsorship song for the event.

images.alt_text: The first Fifa World Cup to be held in the Middle East will feature 64 matches over 29 days.
Young contestants wait with their falcons during a junior falconry competition in Ras Laffan, some 80 km north of Doha.
A billboard featuring France's striker Kylian Mbappe (L) and Argentine's captain Lionel Messi in Doha on Nov 8, 2022, ahead of the Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup football tournament.
The ticket prices in Qatar are the most expensive ever for World Cup games in the last 20 years.
Qatar had previously said that alcohol will be available in designated “fan zones” outside stadiums, and other hospitality venues.

site_title: Twitter fate in doubt as employees defy Musk ultimatum
summary: Elon Musk's ultimatum to Twitter employees to affirm their commitment to the new Twitter by Thursday or face job loss has led to hundreds of employees choosing to leave the company. The move comes amid concerns over the platform's moderation and content, with regulators and advertisers expressing concerns about the site's ability to operate safely and securely. Musk has reinstated banned accounts, including comedian Kathy Griffin's, but has not welcomed back former US President Donald Trump. The future of Twitter remains uncertain, with Musk claiming the site is "more alive than ever" despite the exodus of key employees.

images.alt_text: Tesla investor Ross Gerber, a strong supporter of Musk, said on Tuesday that Tesla needed to find a deputy for its multitasking CEO.
The luxury carmaker wants to hire about 800 workers for jobs in areas including autonomous driving, artificial intelligence, data science and machine learning.
It is unclear whether the tweets by Bankman-Fried, who is facing questioning by everyone from the Department of Justice to regulators in the Bahamas, will help or hinder his legal defence.
The departures include many engineers responsible for fixing bugs and preventing service outages, raising questions about the stability of the platform amid the loss of employees.

site_title: North Korea’s Kim reveals daughter at ballistic missile test
summary: North Korean leader Kim Jong Un revealed his daughter for the first time in public, accompanying him during the launch of the country's largest ballistic missile, the Hwasong-17, on November 18, 2022. The girl, whose existence had never been publicly confirmed, was seen in photographs in a white puffy coat holding hands with her father as they inspected the missile. The move marked a rare glimpse into Kim's personal life, with no name provided for the girl.

images.alt_text: Japan says the missile, which is capable of flying as far as 15,000 km, flew to an altitude of about 6,000 km with a range of 1,000 km, before landing in the sea roughly 200 km west of Oshima-Oshima Island in Hokkaido.
An intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) is launched in this undated photo released on Nov 19, 2022 by North Korea's Korean Central News Agency.

site_title: Wall Street rebuffs soft-landing dream as 92% bet on stagflation
summary: Wall Street investors overwhelmingly believe the US economy will experience stagflation, with 92% of respondents in a Bank of America survey predicting an economic downturn with still-hot price pressures. Despite recent inflation data suggesting prices may be peaking, major investment firms like BlackRock, Citigroup, and Invesco are betting on stagflation, with some recommending selling stocks and buying bonds. The Federal Reserve's efforts to achieve a soft landing are being dismissed, with many officials predicting continued interest rate hikes to curb inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Raindrops hang on a sign for Wall Street outside the New York Stock Exchange in Manhattan in New York City, New York, U.S., October 26, 2020. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Singapore home prices are soaring, but new launches still sell well. What are the factors at play?
summary: Singapore's condominium market continues to experience price surges, with recent launches selling for above S$2,100 per square foot. Several factors contribute to this trend, including higher costs and risks for developers due to global supply chain disruptions and inflation, a supply squeeze, and strong demand from local and foreign buyers. The government's property cooling measures have also increased costs and risks for developers, leading them to raise prices. Despite expected easing of price growth in the coming years, analysts predict prices will remain stable, with some buyers getting priced out by loan restrictions and the annual holiday lull in house-buying approaching.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
Mass market condo sales expected to remain firm despite softening demand from HDB upgraders
Condo resale prices for the rest of the central region (RCR) and the core central region (CCR) were up 1.3 per cent and 1.1 per cent, respectively, on a month-on-month basis.
Investors should therefore not assume that Singapore property prices are a one-way street and will continue to rise unhindered.
The Singapore government first started enacting property cooling measures in 1996.

The supply of new ECs will remain limited, according to real estate agency OrangeTee & Tie. Apart from the newly launched North Gaia (pictured) at Yishun Close, most ECs are completely sold or have a handful of balance units.

site_title: US autonomous delivery vehicle startup Nuro cuts staff by 20%
summary: US autonomous delivery vehicle startup Nuro is laying off about 300 employees, approximately 20% of its workforce, due to rapid hiring in the past year being a mistake. The layoffs come after the company doubled its team in under two years and significantly increased operating expenses, despite an impending US recession and energy crises. Nuro's co-founders, Dave Ferguson and Jiajun Zhu, will offer three months severance pay and other benefits to impacted workers.

images.alt_text: Mark MacGann, founder of Moonshot Ventures and the senior executive behind the Uber Files holds a news conference at the Web Summit, Europe's largest technology conference, in Lisbon, Portugal, Nov 2, 2022.
Didi Chuxing's app was taken down from China's app stores in 2021 after regulators ruled that it had illegally collected users' personal data.

site_title: Malaysia votes in general election, Anwar expected to lead tight race
summary: Malaysia holds a general election, with opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's coalition forecast to win 82 seats, but failing to secure a majority. The result may not end years of political instability, as no clear winner is expected. The country faces slowing economic growth and rising inflation, with uncertainty likely to persist. Anwar's Pakatan Harapan coalition is competing against blocs led by Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob and former premier Muhyiddin Yassin, with the outcome still uncertain.

images.alt_text: Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's opposition leader, greets his supporters as he arrives at a campaign rally in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Tuesday, Nov. 15, 2022. As Malaysians head to the polls on Nov. 19, rising costs of living and a weaker currency will likely influence how they cast their ballots. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

site_title: Hung parliament in Malaysia; parties must submit name of lawmaker with majority support by 2pm on Monday
summary: Malaysia's 15th general election resulted in a hung parliament, with no single coalition securing a majority. The Pakatan Harapan (PH) and Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalitions claim to have obtained majority support, but must submit the name of a lawmaker with majority support by 2 pm on Monday. The king can appoint a new prime minister if he feels a certain lawmaker can command a majority in parliament. PH secured 82 seats, while PN secured 73, and the Barisan Nasional coalition won just 30 seats.

images.alt_text: Over thousands of people were affected by the floods due to heavy downpour this week, the affected victims most likely will not cast their votes on Saturday’s polls.

site_title: Qatar’s tarnished World Cup is too big for brands to boycott
summary: Qatar's hosting of the World Cup is expected to attract a global audience of 5 billion viewers, despite human rights concerns and corruption scandals surrounding the tournament. Brands will likely pay to reach this massive audience, despite some boycotting the event due to Qatar's human rights record and labor practices. Organiser Fifa is recovering from corruption scandals, and Sepp Blatter has expressed regret over Qatar being chosen as host.

images.alt_text: The first Fifa World Cup to be held in the Middle East will feature 64 matches over 29 days.
The ticket prices in Qatar are the most expensive ever for World Cup games in the last 20 years.
A billboard featuring France's striker Kylian Mbappe (L) and Argentine's captain Lionel Messi in Doha on Nov 8, 2022, ahead of the Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup football tournament.

FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football - World Cup - Asian Qualifiers - Group A - United Arab Emirates v South Korea - Al-Maktoum Stadium, Dubai, United Arab Emirates - March 29, 2022
 South Korea's Min-Jae Kim in action with United Arab Emirates' Harib Abdalla Suhail
 REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo

site_title: Sunshine Insurance receives HKEX approval for US$1b IPO: sources
summary: Sunshine Insurance Group, a Beijing-based company, has received Hong Kong stock exchange approval for a potential US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO). The company may start taking investor orders by the end of this month. Founded in 2004, Sunshine Insurance operates businesses including life and health insurance, property and casualty insurance, and asset management. Deliberations are ongoing, and the IPO details are subject to changes, with the listing hearing still potentially being delayed.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after falling for two days
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, November 18, 2022, after a two-day decline. The Dow Jones rose 60.3 points, or 0.18%, to 33,606.59, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also increased, with gains of 19.8 points and 112.0 points, respectively. Investors seemed to shrug off hawkish comments from a top Federal Reserve official, focusing instead on past economic data. The strong opening marked a reversal of the previous day's losses.

site_title: Museum of London packs up for £250 million move
summary: The Museum of London is preparing to move to a new location in the "cultural mile" of London, with a £250 million project set to begin on December 5. The museum, which houses over six million artefacts, will relocate to a giant disused market building and is expected to double or triple its visitor figures. The move will involve carefully packing and transporting over 20,000 human remains, Charles I's execution vest, and other delicate objects, with the new museum set to open in 2026.

images.alt_text: The London museum Director of content Finbarr Whooley looks at a glass case displaying a set of ceramics objects at the Museum of London, in London, on November,8 2022. - King Charles I's execution vest and 20,000 human remains are among the objects that need to be packed up as the Museum of London makes a daunting £250 million ($260 million) move. The museum tells the story of one of the world's great cities through more than six million artefacts -- the largest urban history collection in the world. But it has long been hampered by its location, tucked away among the glass towers of London's ever-expanding financial centre, The City. (Photo by Justin TALLIS / AFP)

Each capsule will feature original and replacement stereo systems, complete with reel-to-reel tape decks. The bathrooms are back in their original state. Also included: a mini fridge, a built-in desk and bed.

site_title: Dyna-Mac CEO adds to stake at S$0.188 per share
summary: Dyna-Mac CEO Geoff Howie increased his stake in the company by buying 1,194,141 shares at S$0.188 per share. Institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ending Nov 17, with S$139 million of net inflows. This brings the 2022 year-to-date net institutional inflows to S$1.2 billion. The Straits Times Index gained 3.6%, while the Hang Seng Index and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI also saw gains.

images.alt_text: Overall, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ended Nov 10, with S$277 million of net inflows.

site_title: Crypto whistleblowers in line for multimillion-dollar payouts
summary: US regulators are urging crypto whistleblowers to come forward for potential multimillion-dollar payouts. The head of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC), Kristin Johnson, said the appeal is "very broadly" intended and not just for FTX, which filed for bankruptcy last week. Whistleblowers can receive awards of 10-30% of penalties collected from cases, with one individual receiving nearly $200 million in 2022. The CFTC is investigating FTX's mishandling of customer funds and relationships with other crypto companies.

images.alt_text: Advisers are working to rebuild balance sheets for FTX entities from the bottom up, John J Ray III, FTX’s new CEO said.
It is unclear whether the tweets by Bankman-Fried, who is facing questioning by everyone from the Department of Justice to regulators in the Bahamas, will help or hinder his legal defence.

FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in front of displayed FTX logo and decreasing stock graph in this illustration taken November 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
FTX collapsed after its founder Sam Bankman-Fried used US$10 billion in client funds to prop up his hedge fund Alameda Research.

site_title: American Airlines, JetBlue alliance will harm travellers, US argues
summary: The US Justice Department argues that an alliance between American Airlines and JetBlue will harm travelers, citing nearly $700 million in extra annual costs to consumers. The alliance, announced in 2020, coordinates flights and pools revenue, leading to reduced competition and higher prices. Lawyers for the airlines counter that the alliance has expanded flights and made them more competitive with Delta and United Airlines on northeast routes, without raising fares or cutting flights. A US District Judge will decide on the case after another hearing.

site_title: US says immunity for crown prince ‘nothing to do’ with Saudi ties
summary: The US government denied any connection between granting immunity to Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and improving bilateral ties, saying the decision was unrelated to the case of journalist Jamal Khashoggi's 2018 murder. The White House stated that the immunity was granted based on a legal determination and had no bearing on the bilateral relationship with Saudi Arabia, which is currently tense due to Riyadh's recent oil output decrease. The move was criticized by Amnesty International as a "deep betrayal" and a "sickening, total, deep betrayal" of human rights.

images.alt_text: International banks JP Morgan Chase & Co (above), HSBC Holdings and Citigroup Inc have also been increasing their presence in the oil-rich kingdom.

site_title: Global ESG-linked bond market faces its first set of penalties
summary: The global ESG-linked bond market is facing its first wave of financial penalties as European energy policy's revival of fossil fuels threatens to derail climate commitments. Public Power Corp (PPC) in Greece may struggle to meet its end-of-year emissions target, potentially triggering penalties on its sustainability-linked bonds. This is a test case for the market, with regulators and investors agreeing on crisis policies that delay utilities' phase-out of lignite coal production. The outcome could raise demand for bonds and impact the market's credibility.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknote is seen in this picture illustration taken May 3, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: New Trump probe overseer is veteran war crimes prosecutor
summary: US Attorney General Merrick Garland appointed Jack Smith, a veteran war crimes prosecutor, as special counsel to oversee investigations into former President Donald Trump's role in the January 6 Capitol attack and handling of sensitive government documents. Smith has a reputation for impartiality and has led complex war crimes probes in Kosovo and the Netherlands. He vowed to conduct the investigations independently and thoroughly, without pause or flagging, to determine the facts and law.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump on Tuesday vowed to prevent US President Joe Biden from being re-elected in 2024. Biden responded by saying the Republican “failed” his country while in office.
Supporters of US president Donald Trump stormed the US Capitol Building in Washington, on Jan 6, 2021, in protest of the 2020 election results.
Trump’s announcement came as little surprise to investors, as the former president had said he might run again for some time.

site_title: Philippines says Saudi Arabia to pay Filipino workers owed wages
summary: The Philippines has announced that Saudi Arabia will pay 10,000 Filipino domestic workers who lost their jobs years ago and are still waiting for their salaries. The compensation package of 2 billion riyals ($532 million) was agreed upon during a meeting between Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman and Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos at the Asia-Pacific summit in Bangkok. The payment is expected to "help our displaced workers," according to Philippine Migrant Workers Secretary Susan Ople.

images.alt_text: Arsenio Balisacan,  Economic Planning secretary, says: “We are monitoring also the developments closely so we can also deploy our monetary tools like the interest rate, for example, and how we can intervene in the financial market to tame the depreciation of the peso.”
The Philippines remains among Asia’s bright spots, as rising borrowing costs and a cost-of-living crisis dim the global economic outlook.

site_title: Experience BT’s new homepage
summary: The Business Times has revamped its homepage, featuring a new 'hamburger' sidebar menu and improved story displays. The redesign aims to enhance user experience, making it easier for readers to access award-winning journalism. Key changes include a streamlined navigation bar, dropdown menus for secondary topics, and the addition of categories for Singapore and International coverage. The updated homepage will also be reflected in the app for Android and iOS users.

images.alt_text: Tee Zhuo

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 jumps more than 1% to end week higher
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index jumped 1.2% to its best one-day performance in over a week, driven by retailers and automakers. The index has gained 5.1% in November, despite concerns of a recession in the euro zone. The European Central Bank's policy meeting minutes are due on November 24, with policymakers signaling a need for high interest rates to combat inflation. The Stoxx 600 is down 11% this year, but the latest rally suggests underlying momentum is better than expected.

images.alt_text: A man walks through the lobby of the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain August 25, 2015. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett

site_title: Lagarde says rates to rise more, may need to become restrictive
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says interest rates may need to rise to restrict economic expansion to combat soaring inflation, which has exceeded five times the official target. The risk of a recession has increased, but a downturn alone won't be enough to tame prices. Lagarde expects to raise rates to 2% or more next month and further hikes may be needed to bring inflation back down to the medium-term target.

images.alt_text: With four weeks to go before the ECB’s final decision of the year on Dec 15, officials still have plenty of time to make up their minds.

site_title: Elizabeth Holmes sentenced to 11 yrs in prison for Theranos fraud
summary: Elizabeth Holmes, former CEO of Theranos, was sentenced to 11 years and 3 months in prison for defrauding investors in her now-defunct blood-testing startup. A US federal judge handed down the sentence after a jury convicted Holmes on three counts of investor fraud and one count of conspiracy in January. The prosecution recommended 15 years in prison, while the defense urged no prison time. Holmes, 38, will serve her sentence following her conviction in the saga of the now-defunct blood testing start-up.

images.alt_text: Jurors found Ramesh “Sunny” Balwani guilty on all 12 fraud counts charged by federal prosecutors, said a spokesperson at the courthouse in the Silicon Valley city of San Jose.

site_title: COP27 climate talks hurtle towards overtime, countries mull EU offer of fund
summary: COP27 climate talks have entered overtime with several sticking points remaining unresolved, including financing for countries affected by climate change and the establishment of a loss and damage fund. The European Union has proposed backing the G77's demand for a fund to help countries cope with climate-driven disasters, but it's unclear if all countries will accept the EU's offer of a fund to aid only the most vulnerable countries. The final deal is expected to be adopted on Saturday, but delegates are awaiting responses from the US and China, the world's two biggest polluters.

images.alt_text: The aftermath of heavy monsoon rains in Pakistan's Balochistan province, August 2022. As climate disasters such as Pakistan’s catastrophic flooding wreak havoc, we believe developing nations are right to demand reparations and climate justice.

site_title: Pofma correction directions to be issued over false claims about government fiscal surpluses
summary: The Protection from Online Falsehoods and Manipulation Act (Pofma) Office will issue correction directions to Yeoh Lam Keong and The Independent Singapore for making false claims about the government's fiscal surpluses. Yeoh previously stated on Facebook that the government had a $30 billion structural fiscal surplus, but no clear spending plans. The Independent Singapore reproduced Yeoh's statement in two articles. This is the second Pofma correction direction to be issued to Yeoh in five weeks, following a previous correction direction on November 7.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 17, 2016 shows an employee typing on a computer keyboard at the headquarters of Internet security giant Kaspersky in Moscow. Silicon Valley on February 20, 2020 was mourning a pioneering computer scientist whose accomplishments included inventing the widely relied on "cut, copy and paste" command. "The inventor of cut/copy & paste, find & replace, and more was former Xerox researcher Larry Tesler," the company tweeted. (Photo by Kirill KUDRYAVTSEV / AFP)

site_title: Unit of CapitaLand Ascott Reit trustee issues S$165m of 5% notes due in 2026
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Reit trustee has issued S$165 million of 5% notes due May 18, 2026. The net proceeds will be used for refinancing existing borrowings of CapitaLand Ascott Reit and its subsidiaries. The notes are issued under a multicurrency debt issuance programme and are unconditionally guaranteed by DBS Trustee. The issuance does not affect the stapled group's units, which closed at S$0.96 on Friday.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Indonesia’s GoTo cuts 1,300 jobs, including in Singapore, as tech layoffs deepen
summary: Indonesia's GoTo Group has cut 1,300 jobs, including in Singapore, as part of a cost-cutting measure to reach financial self-sufficiency in a volatile global economic environment. The layoffs, amounting to 12% of its workforce, are aimed at reducing costs and improving the company's financial stability. GoTo, a major ride-hailing, e-commerce, and fintech player in South-east Asia, will also focus on streamlining operations to achieve its goals.

images.alt_text: Formed through a merger of ride-hailing provider Gojek and e-commerce firm Tokopedia, the company went public in early 2022.

site_title: Oil slides 2%, posts second weekly decline as supply fears recede
summary: Oil prices dropped 2% on Friday, logging a second weekly decline, due to concerns about weakened demand in China and further interest rate hikes in the US. Brent crude fell to $87.62 a barrel and WTI crude to $80.08 a barrel, with both benchmarks posting weekly losses. The decline in oil prices is attributed to a stronger US dollar and a shift in market structure, as supply concerns wane and contango conditions become more prevalent.

images.alt_text: An oil pumping jack, also known as a nodding donkey, operates in an oilfield operated by Bashneft PAO near Ufa, Russia, on Wednesday, Sept. 28, 2016. Bashneft distributes petroleum products and petrochemicals around the world and in Russia via filling stations. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Stocks edge up as markets work to shrug off Fed concerns
summary: US stocks rose 0.6% and 0.5% on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average closing at 33,745.69 and the S&P 500 at 3,965.34. Despite concerns about further interest rate hikes and a potential recession, the market attempted to shrug off hawkish Federal Reserve talks. Retailers such as Gap and Foot Locker reported positive results, while Amazon slipped after announcing 10,000 job cuts. Analysts believe the Fed may pivot and cut rates by the end of next year, supporting market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Qatar to ban alcohol sales in World Cup stadiums
summary: Qatar has banned the sale of alcohol within World Cup stadiums, reversing a previous decision that allowed Anheuser-Busch InBev to sell Budweiser beer in designated fan zones outside stadiums. The move will likely result in moving concession stands serving alcohol further away from the stadiums. This decision comes after Qatar's Supreme Committee on Delivery and Legacy initially promised alcohol would be available in designated fan zones and considered allowing beer to be consumed inside venues. The tournament begins on November 20 with the hosts taking on Ecuador.

images.alt_text: The Belgian brewer of Budweiser and Stella Artois is trying to reduce its debt on a loan to fund its acquisition of SAB Miller in 2016.

Budweiser, a major World Cup sponsor with exclusive rights to sell beer at the tournament, will serve beer within the ticketed perimeter surrounding each stadium, but not in the stadium stands or concourse, the source said.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover to recruit fired Twitter and Facebook workers
summary: Jaguar Land Rover plans to hire about 800 workers from companies such as Meta and Twitter, citing digital and engineering vacancies in areas like autonomous driving, AI, and data science. The luxury carmaker will recruit in the UK, US, Ireland, India, China, and Hungary. The move comes as tech companies like Meta and Twitter face staff cuts and sluggish hiring due to higher interest rates and consumer spending. The positions will fill existing gaps in JLR's workforce, allowing the company to expand in emerging technologies.

site_title: Billions of dollars flee to crypto’s decentralised roots after FTX collapse
summary: Investors are fleeing to decentralized finance (DeFi) after the collapse of FTX, with trading volumes on DeFi exchanges reaching $62 billion, a 11% increase from last month. DeFi apps, such as lending protocols Aave and Compound, are seeing strong user and transaction growth. Ethereum co-founder Vitalik Buterin believes the FTX collapse validates the benefits of decentralized systems, while other executives, like Coinbase's CEO, predict a shift towards DeFi. However, concerns remain about the security and accessibility of DeFi solutions, with hackers having stolen $3 billion in crypto assets from DeFi protocols in 2022.

images.alt_text: While legislations tend to lag behind innovations, the role of regulators cannot be overlooked especially with rising risks in the cryptocurrency space, said speakers at a panel on how regulators are responding to innovation, at the Abu Dhabi Finance Week 2022.
Hackers have become adept at exploiting weaknesses in the security, coding and structure of DeFi marketplaces.

Top executives at financial institutions expect the use of blockchain technology to be a game changer in improving processes and paving the way for more services and types of assets for end-customers.

After dumping its holdings of FTX’s native coin and triggering an exodus of users from the rival bourse, Changpeng Zhao's Binance, the world’s biggest cryptocurrency exchange, is acquiring FTX in a rescue deal.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's resale private home market saw a 10.5% decline in Q3 sales, following a rebound in the second quarter. The Rest of Central Region had the largest decline, with a 14.3% drop in transaction volume. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Lee emphasized the need for free and open trade in the face of uncertain global economic conditions. The UAE is being urged to give oil and gas players a larger role at the COP28 climate conference, while a financial firm has received an in-principle nod for capital market custodial services.

images.alt_text: While analysts agree on the gloomy export outlook, their opinions on the impact of a China reopening vary.

site_title: COP27 draft deal published, no proposal yet on 'loss and damage' funding
summary: The United Nations climate agency has published a draft negotiating text of the COP27 deal, but it does not include a proposal for 'loss and damage' funding for developing countries affected by catastrophic climate events. The draft reaffirms the Paris Agreement's temperature goal and key points from COP26, but talks on 'loss and damage' remain stalled. The European Union has made a proposal aimed at resolving the impasse, but progress has been slow. Delegates are still seeking consensus on the matter, which has long divided developed and developing nations.

images.alt_text: The aftermath of heavy monsoon rains in Pakistan's Balochistan province, August 2022. As climate disasters such as Pakistan’s catastrophic flooding wreak havoc, we believe developing nations are right to demand reparations and climate justice.

site_title: China's JD.com shares up as revenue beats estimates
summary: JD.com, a Chinese e-commerce firm, reported an 11.4% rise in third-quarter revenue, beating analyst estimates. The company's focus on building its logistics network helped it deal with transport disruptions caused by Covid-19 lockdowns in China. This shift to online shopping led to increased retail spending, with JD.com's US-listed shares rising about 3% in trading. Despite Chinese retail spending sagging this year due to strict government policies, JD.com's strong performance suggests its efforts to adapt to the market are paying off.

images.alt_text: Alibaba, which runs China’s largest online marketplaces Tmall and Taobao and owns a wide range of businesses from logistics to cloud services, reported net loss attributable to shareholders of 20.56 billion yuan in the quarter.

site_title: Singapore stocks track Wall Street declines; STI down 0.4 per cent
summary: Singapore stocks declined 0.4% on Friday, following Wall Street declines and Federal Reserve officials' hawkish comments on interest rate hikes. The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 13.81 points to 3,272.23, with losers beating gainers 281 to 260. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 0.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index down 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Also troubling to Fed officials is that outside of petrol, price growth in the economy is rampant and widespread.

site_title: Will taxing the windfall profits of oil giants fix countries’ economies?
summary: Major oil and gas companies have earned record-breaking profits, with Shell, BP, and TotalEnergies reporting billions of dollars in earnings. In response, the British government has announced a new windfall tax to capture energy companies' excessive profits and use the funds to defray the cost of energy bills. The move is seen as a way to help households struggling with high energy prices. However, experts debate whether the tax will worsen the problem by discouraging suppliers from producing more energy or encourage consumers to use more.

images.alt_text: Exxon posted the highest profit in its 152-year history, while Chevron announced its second-best quarterly result as natural gas demand and prices surged.
Joe Biden criticised major oil companies that are bringing in big profits while Americans, weary of inflation, pay a tidy sum to fill up their cars.
Oil executives, under pressure on emissions and years of poor returns, are in no mood to back down.

site_title: Thawing of US-China relations gives Apec Summit a timely boost
summary: The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) summit in Thailand has reached a breakthrough, with ministers agreeing to a joint statement on Friday. The statement welcomed the Bangkok Goals on the bio-circular green (BCG) Economy and reiterated a commitment to a free and open trade environment. The development comes as tensions between the US and China have eased, with US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping meeting at the G20 Summit in Bali earlier this week. The APEC leaders are set to convene on Saturday to discuss the Russia-Ukraine war and other regional issues.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong meeting Thai Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha at the 29th APEC Economic Leaders' Meeting in Bangkok on Nov 18, 2022.
