Thai police arrested at least 10 protestors who were among 350 demonstrators opposed to the Apec summit and Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha.
China’s President Xi Jinping is attending the summit, while the United States is being represented by US Vice-President Kamala Harris.

site_title: Cathay Pacific expects annual loss despite second-half improvement
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways forecasts a "substantial" annual loss despite a second-half improvement in travel demand. The airline carried over 5 times more passengers in October than last year, but still 85.4% lower than pre-pandemic levels in 2019. Cathay expects an annual net loss of HK$3.8 billion, down from a HK$5.5 billion loss in 2022. The company aims to operate at up to one-third of pre-pandemic passenger flight capacity by the end of 2022 and return to full capacity by 2024.

images.alt_text: Travel industry groups have warned Hong Kong will not see a meaningful return of visitors until the three-day monitoring period and most other restrictions are lifted.
Hong Kong’s main carrier, also one of the world’s biggest cargo airlines by capacity, is mulling purchasing either Airbus A350 freighters or Boeing 777-8F jets, the people said.
Along with its subsidiaries, the company had 20,800 employees globally by Jun 30, after cutting thousands of roles during the pandemic.
Cathay Pacific has held a recruitment drive in Hong Kong on Friday (Oct 7); the airline is also adding passenger aircraft and freighters.

site_title: Best foot forward
summary: Japanese entrepreneur Kohei Hamada, director of global expansion for SNKRDUNK, is a self-proclaimed sneakerhead with a passion for collecting sneakers. He has over 80 pairs, with many still unworn, and buys a new pair almost every month. Hamada credits his love for sneakers to their unique designs and silhouettes. He started collecting sneakers after working at a brokerage firm and later founded Monokabu, Japan's second-largest sneaker operator, before it was acquired by Soda Inc. Hamada recommends starting with shoes that collectors like, and notes that he would never tire of collecting sneakers, much like a collector of handbags.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
For The Collectors series, Kohei, a sneaker collector

site_title: Rediscovering rum at The Bar at 15 Stamford
summary: The Bar at 15 Stamford, a luxury bar at The Capitol Kempinski Hotel, aims to redefine the perception of rum through its refined offerings. Bar manager Edriane Lim seeks to educate patrons about the spirit, showcasing its complexity and diversity beyond the typical party vibe. The bar features a curated selection of 300 labels with less sugar and undergoes proper ageing and blending. Lim recommends exploring high-ABV rums from distilleries like Foursquare, which produces rums with oaty notes and tropical flavors.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
The Other Room's cocktail menu is divided by era, with the Merry Go Round falling within the 1929-2019 section of the timeline.
Named after a famous racehorse, the Secretariat cocktail at Farrer Horse draws inspiration from the equine diet with a hay bourbon base and apple puree.

site_title: Abu Dhabi Ports makes acquisition to further global expansion
summary: Abu Dhabi Ports Group has acquired Spanish logistics firm Noatum for US$680 million, its second acquisition this month. The deal expands AD Ports' global presence in the Mediterranean and offers access to port facilities in Spain and Turkey. The acquisition is part of AD Ports' strategy to build a strong international logistics brand, following its recent purchase of 80% of Global Feeder Shipping for US$800 million. The deal is expected to be funded through a new loan and will further boost the group's handling of 45 million tonnes of general cargo volumes last year.

images.alt_text: Cranes and trucks offload containers during the commercial opening day of Khalifa port phase 1, about 80 kms south west of Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, Saturday, Sept. 1, 2012. Khalifa Port has the first semi-automated container terminal in the region and has an annual capacity for 2.5 million containers. (AP Photo/Kamran Jebreili)

site_title: COP27 gets chaotic with mysterious draft text, elusive president
summary: The COP27 climate summit in Sharm El-Sheikh, Egypt, has become chaotic due to a mysterious 20-page document circulated by the presidency, which has sparked frustration among delegates and observers. The document, intended as a collection of proposals, was mistaken for the final declaration and lacks key demands by some countries, including a reference to phasing down oil and gas. Developing nations are also upset over the lack of a compensation mechanism for loss and damage. The presidency's hands-off approach and lack of direction have added to the frustration, with some delegates questioning the Egyptian presidency's ability to deliver an ambitious outcome.

images.alt_text: The aftermath of heavy monsoon rains in Pakistan's Balochistan province, August 2022. As climate disasters such as Pakistan’s catastrophic flooding wreak havoc, we believe developing nations are right to demand reparations and climate justice.
The proposal, set out by EU climate chief Frans Timmermans, came after days of sluggish talks in Sharm El-Sheikh.
European Union climate-policy chief Frans Timmermans says the first draft of the deal hammered out at the COP27 summit leaves a lot to be desired.

site_title: Middle-class England set for shock as taxes rise, wages stagnate
summary: Britain's middle-class households are set for a significant hit to their income due to tax increases and stagnant wages. The typical UK household will experience a permanent 3.7% income drop, with the cost of living squeeze affecting those on median earnings the most. Real disposable incomes are predicted to fall by 7% over the next two years, a record low since 1963, and households will be 30% worse off than expected. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's £55 billion tax and spending cuts aim to fill a hole in public finances, but critics argue the measures will disproportionately affect the middle class.

images.alt_text: A video grab from footage broadcast by the UK Parliament, showing Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer (finance minister) Jeremy Hunt making an autumn budget statement in the House of Commons in London on Thursday (Nov 17).
Intentions among consumers to spend on larger items like furniture or electrical goods fell again in October.
Some 16 per cent of homeowners between ages 16 and 34 will be trapped in so-called “negative equity” in 2023 if house prices drop by 7.9 per cent, as predicted by Lloyds Banking Group

A pedestrian walks past resdiential properties displayed for sale in the of an estate agents' in London on September 30, 2022. - The plan for top-to-bottom tax cuts, financed by a borrowing spree, have unnerved financial markets, alienated the International Monetary Fund and caused tensions with the Bank of England (BoE). Most immediately for UK voters, it is driving up costs including for home mortgages, as market interest rates surge in the middle of the worst cost-of-living crisis in generations. (Photo by ISABEL INFANTES / AFP)

site_title: Peanuts, Charles Schulz’s cartoon, probed the human condition
summary: Charles Schulz's iconic comic strip "Peanuts" explored the human condition through its relatable characters, including Charlie Brown's self-doubt, Linus's philosophical approach, and Snoopy's psychological depth. Schulz's bleak worldview was shaped by his childhood and career interruptions, but his characters' vulnerabilities and flaws made them endearing and universal. With over 17,897 strips, "Peanuts" became a global phenomenon, influencing art, literature, and popular culture, and cementing Snoopy's status as a beloved and iconic character.

images.alt_text: In today's age of AI, the eerie central conceit of Pinocchio – the talking, walking puppet, lively yet not wholly alive, and the attendant issue of what makes a “real boy” – has never been more pressing or more provocative.

site_title: No economy can be fully self-sufficient; trade flows should stay free and open: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of free and open trade flows, stating that no economy can be fully self-sufficient, citing the COVID-19 pandemic as an example. He urged Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) members to promote sustainable and inclusive growth amidst uncertain global economic conditions, highlighting the risks of geopolitical tensions, inflation, and supply chain disruptions, particularly affecting lower-income households and small and medium-sized enterprises.

images.alt_text: China’s President Xi Jinping is attending the summit, while the United States is being represented by US Vice-President Kamala Harris.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index ends lower on profit-taking
summary: The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo closed 0.11% lower on Friday, ending at 27,899.77, as investors took profits and awaited fresh market cues. The broader Topix index remained slightly positive, inching up 0.04% to 1,967.03.

site_title: Europe: Equities open higher
summary: Europe's stock markets opened higher on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index rising 0.2% to 7,364.21 points, following a 1.5% slump in September. UK retail sales rebounded 0.6% in October, lifting stocks. The Paris CAC 40 index rose 0.5% and Frankfurt's DAX 0.3%, despite a harsh UK budget that slashed spending and hiked taxes, admitting the economy has plunged into recession.

images.alt_text: A man walks through the lobby of the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain August 25, 2015. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett

site_title: Singlife with Aviva appoints new group deputy CIO
summary: Singlife with Aviva has appointed Allen Kuo as its new group deputy chief investment officer, overseeing the implementation of the company's sustainable investment strategy. Kuo brings over two decades of investment and risk management experience to the role, having previously held senior positions at ING Investment Management and the University of California's pension and endowment arm. His appointment reinforces Singlife's drive to champion environmental, social and corporate governance (ESG) mandates and champion sustainability in financial services.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Singlife with Aviva strategic review aims to expand offerings and client base
Aviva Singlife's Walter de Oude to step down from executive roles
Azalea launches its first sustainability fund

site_title: Rival ride-hailing apps challenge Didi’s dominance in China
summary: Rival ride-hailing apps, including those backed by tech giants like Tencent, are challenging Didi Chuxing's dominance in China's $30 billion ride-hailing market. Despite being taken down from China's app stores in 2021 due to data collection issues, Didi remains the largest player, but its market share has fallen to 70% from 90% in 2017. Chinese companies such as AutoNavi Holdings, Meituan, and Tencent Holdings are eating into Didi's market share, making the market increasingly competitive.

images.alt_text: Tencent has no need to raise funds nor a timeline for such divestments, a spokesperson said.
FILE PHOTO: Drivers of food delivery service Meituan are seen in Shanghai, China June 25, 2018. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Golden Mile Tower’s S$650m en bloc tender launched
summary: Golden Mile Tower, a 22-storey commercial development in Singapore, has been launched for collective sale at an indicative price of S$650 million. The 99-year leasehold building comprises 405 strata lots, 251 retail units, 152 office units, a cinema, and a carpark. With a plot ratio of 4.46, the asking price translates to S$1,550 per square foot per plot ratio. The tender closes on December 19, with no restrictions on foreign ownership or additional buyer's stamp duty.

site_title: Malaysia’s polls likely to end in ‘unity government’ with no coalition gaining majority
summary: Malaysia's general election is likely to result in a unity government with neither the Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition nor Pakatan Harapan (PH) gaining a majority. The election, which began on November 19, will see close to 950 candidates contesting 222 parliamentary seats, with three-cornered fights in over 200 of these. Analysts predict that BN will secure a majority, but this may lead to a "same old" model with less structural reforms. The Islamic party PAS, part of the Perikatan Nasional (PN) alliance, is open to collaborating with BN, while PH may join forces with PN to form a stronger majority.

images.alt_text: Over thousands of people were affected by the floods due to heavy downpour this week, the affected victims most likely will not cast their votes on Saturday’s polls.

site_title: With tax hikes and spending cuts, UK’s Conservative Party out to regain support from disenchanted voters
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt's Autumn Statement imposed the highest taxation since WWII, with £25 billion in tax increases to placate financial markets. The statement included £30 billion in spending cuts, but they have been delayed until after the 2024 general election. Despite this, markets reacted relatively calmly, with the pound fluctuating against major currencies. The statement aims to regain support from disenchanted voters amid a sharp decline in living standards.

images.alt_text: The British capital’s FTSE 100 index fell 0.2 per cent to 7,338.89 points, as Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt readied a budget that will hike taxes and slash spending.

A video grab from footage broadcast by the UK Parliament, showing Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer (finance minister) Jeremy Hunt making an autumn budget statement in the House of Commons in London on Thursday (Nov 17).

site_title: Londoners fight for flats in hot rental market
summary: Londoners face a tight rental market as surging mortgage rates keep potential homebuyers out of the market. Demand for rentals has more than tripled from early 2021 levels, while the number of available properties has fallen 9% in October. Long-term tenants are staying put to avoid rent increases, further exacerbating the shortage. The city's upscale areas, such as Kensington and Chelsea, are particularly affected, making it an "impossible quest" to find a rental property.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s prime rents fell for the first time in two years as the mass exodus left landlords struggling to find tenants. Still, while rents are falling in Hong Kong, it remains the world’s most expensive city for expats.

A row of residential properties stand in front of the City of London financial district in London, U.K., on Monday, April 3, 2017. U.K. house prices fell for the first time in almost two years in March, according to the latest report from Nationwide Building Society. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

epa10213780 A row of semi-detached houses in Holmfirth, Britain, 29 September 2022. The fall of the value of the pound following Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng’s mini-budget has resulted in banks withdrawing mortgage deals, with interest rates expected to rise to nearly six percent.  EPA-EFE/ADAM VAUGHAN

site_title: Power company China Three Gorges warns of solar slowdown on Covid curbs
summary: China Three Gorges Renewables Group, a state-owned clean energy developer, warned that solar installations will slow due to high module prices and Covid disruptions. The company cited rising polysilicon costs and lockdowns in regions with projects as reasons. Despite this, wind turbine costs in China have decreased, making it more cost-effective than solar. Analysts predict China can still add 85 GW in 2022, with many projects in north-west China offering decent returns.

images.alt_text: The idea of connecting power plants and customers across Asia has been pursued for decades but stymied by issues including lack of government coordination and infrastructure funding.
China Energy coal-fired plant in Shenyang. Work on at least 165 gigawatts of plants powered by coal is expected to begin by end of 2023.

site_title: Looming layoff? No fear!
summary: Elon Musk's recent changes at Twitter have led to widespread layoffs, with reports suggesting over half of the platform's global headcount may have been let go. However, Musk is not the only tech giant shedding staff, with Meta, Tencent, Amazon, and others also cutting thousands of jobs or implementing hiring freezes. To prepare for a looming layoff, experts recommend maintaining a strong work ethic, getting finances in order, updating a resume, starting to look for new job opportunities, and practicing self-care.

images.alt_text: Tee Zhuo

site_title: German industrial workers get 8.5 per cent pay rise due to labour deal
summary: German industrial workers will receive an 8.5% pay rise due to a labour deal between the IG Metall union and the Gesamtmetall employers' association. The agreement includes two rounds of wage increases, with a 5.2% raise next year and a 3.3% increase in 2024. Additionally, workers will receive 3,000 euros in tax-free bonus payments to counter inflation. The deal aims to compensate for soaring living costs and avoid strike action, which had affected around 900,000 workers.

images.alt_text: Verdi, which represents some 5 million public-sector workers in Germany, has also called for wage hikes in other sectors, such as the financial industry and airport staff.
Energy prices continue to drive inflation, but food and imported industrial goods all pushed prices sharply higher.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher as investors unfazed by hawkish Fed
summary: The Australian market ended 0.2% higher, despite a hawkish US Federal Reserve, with investors seemingly unfazed by interest rate comments. BHP Group's A$9.6 billion bid for OZ Minerals lifted sentiment, and heavyweight financials rose 0.6%. The market remains cautious, with investors assessing if it's a good time to start buying, and inflation still above the RBA's target range.

images.alt_text: Data also showed Australia’s net employment rose better than expected in October, raising speculation that the Reserve Bank of Australia might continue with rate hikes.

site_title: Indonesia’s GoTo joins global tech cuts in slashing 1,300 jobs
summary: GoTo Group, Indonesia's largest internet company, is cutting 1,300 jobs, approximately 12% of its workforce, in an effort to reduce expenses and address investor concerns over mounting losses. This move follows similar layoffs by tech giants like Apple and Meta Platform, as companies prepare for a deteriorating economic climate and increased focus on profitability. The job cuts are part of a broader trend in the tech industry, with job losses nearing levels seen during the early stages of the Covid-19 pandemic.

images.alt_text: GoTo is gauging the interest of early backers including Alibaba and SoftBank for a managed sale of some of their shares to new investors.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank upgrades Grab to ‘hold’ on stronger profitability prospects
summary: Maybank Securities has upgraded its rating on Grab to "hold" from "sell" after the company exceeded expectations with its third-quarter financials. The upgraded rating reflects stronger profitability prospects, particularly in Grab's mobility segment, where demand and driver supply are recovering. Analyst Kelvin Tan sees Grab as "fairly valued" at a revised target price of US$3.40, with the company expected to turn free-cash-flow positive in FY2024 and reach breakeven in adjusted Ebitda by FY2025.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Platforms like Grab and foodpanda have rolled out welfare initiatives, but these cannot match national job protections.
As the Advisory Committee on Platform Workers prepare their recommendations, it is clear that platform workers would want one of their own as their representative to both companies and authorities.
“We’re firing on all cylinders to improve our profitability trajectory,”  said Grab CEO Anthony Tan.
Chief operating officer Alex Hungate, has spearheaded a push away from low-margin business lines as Grab races to turn profitable.

site_title: Recovering paradise lost: A new tech-enabled biodiversity protection model
summary: A new tech-enabled biodiversity protection model, Rebalance Earth, aims to value and monetize natural assets to combat climate change. The International Monetary Fund estimates that a single forest elephant contributes US$2.6 million worth of carbon sequestration services, highlighting the importance of biodiversity conservation. Rebalance Earth's ecosystem services credit offering, supported by blockchain technology, allows users to track the specific animal linked to a token, as well as disburse funds to local communities. The model seeks to integrate biodiversity impact assessment into business operations, promoting data transparency and trust in the financial sector.

images.alt_text: There is strong rationale and opportunity for the global market response to valuing natural capital to be led out of the Asia-Pacific, says Guy Williams, Deloitte Asia Pacific & Global Nature lead. (Photo: Deloitte)
The economic value of the global ocean is equivalent to that of the world's seventh largest economy in GDP terms.
The value of our natural environment does not appear as an asset on our national accounts or corporate balance sheets; nor does pollution or diminishing biodiversity appear as costs.
A study of 18,600 glaciers at 50 World Heritage sites – covering around 66,000 sq km– found that glaciers at a third of the sites were “condemned to disappear”.

site_title: COP27 must follow through towards a just transition
summary: Developing nations are pushing for a just transition to a net-zero world, with a focus on addressing loss and damage from climate change. The COP27 conference in Egypt saw positive steps, including Denmark's commitment to loss and damage funds and the US and EU's support for talks on the issue. However, a loss and damage response fund remains a sticking point, and climate finance remains a significant gap. Investors are urged to integrate social factors into their capital allocation and stewardship activities, and to invest in social bonds to support a just transition and climate adaptation in vulnerable communities.

images.alt_text: Few would question the urgency of climate action. The harder nut to crack is how to make the transition an inclusive one.

strait15 - Ships officer Cleo Bierneza is hoping for a Just Transition to zero carbon.

credit, source Cleo Bierneza
Indonesia, home to the world’s third-largest rainforest, pledges to be carbon-neutral by 2050, 10 years earlier than previously planned, and to almost double its renewable energy generation by 2030.

site_title: Seoul: Shares post fourth weekly gain as IT, chipmaker stocks shine
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.58 points or 0.06% to 2,444.48, posting a fourth weekly gain led by IT and chipmaker stocks. The Kospi index gained 5.7% for the week, its sharpest gain since early January. Technology giant Samsung Electronics rose 0.65%, SK Hynix gained 0.8%, and LG Energy Solution advanced 0.17%. The Korean won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield fell, attracting more foreign buying.

images.alt_text: The benchmark KOSPI fell 34.55 points, or 1.39 per cent, to close at 2,442.90.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Markets remain sensitive to Fed-speak (Ep 21)
summary: Markets remain sensitive to the Federal Reserve's hawkish stance, with investors reacting cautiously to recent monetary policy announcements. The Fed's continued emphasis on inflation control has led to increased uncertainty and volatility in global markets. Analysts predict that markets will remain volatile until the Fed's stance is clarified. As a result, investors are advised to exercise caution and closely monitor market developments.

site_title: The US is 'here to stay', says Vice-President Kamala Harris to Asian leaders
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris has reaffirmed the country's commitment to the Asia-Pacific region, stating "The United States is here to stay" during the Apec summit in Bangkok. Harris emphasized the US's role as a "proud Pacific power" and highlighted the region's prosperity thanks to the US network of security alliances. This message comes as China expands its influence, prompting doubts about the US's engagement in the region. Harris's comments were made in a bid to reassure Asian leaders and counter China's growing presence.

images.alt_text: China’s President Xi Jinping is attending the summit, while the United States is being represented by US Vice-President Kamala Harris.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks kick off with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 1.50% to 18,316.36, driven by a tech sector rally. The Hang Seng Index rose 270.70 points, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also gained marginally. The gains followed a two-day drop, with investors shrugging off concerns over US-China trade tensions and focusing on sector-specific momentum.

site_title: Gold faces weekly dip as recent rally subsides on hawkish Fed
summary: Gold prices are expected to fall this week due to the recent rally subsiding as US Federal Reserve officials suggest interest rates will continue to rise, discouraging investment in the non-interest-bearing metal. Spot gold remains steady at $1,761.29 per ounce, while US gold futures are flat at $1,763.40 per ounce, leading to a predicted weekly decline of about 0.6%. The Fed's hawkish stance and limited effects on inflation on observed inflation have analysts warning that further gains could be elusive.

site_title: Is this the end of crypto?
summary: Cryptocurrency's reputation has taken a severe hit following the collapse of FTX, the third-largest cryptocurrency exchange. FTX's founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, was once hailed as a financial genius, but his company's bankruptcy has exposed the industry's history of scandals and failure. The collapse has dealt a catastrophic blow to the industry, with many creditors left furious and numerous regulatory and criminal probes underway. As the market value of cryptocurrencies has plummeted, the question remains whether crypto can ever be useful beyond scams and speculation, or if genuine innovators will be driven off by the industry's increasing untrustworthiness.

images.alt_text: FTX collapsed after its founder Sam Bankman-Fried used US$10 billion in client funds to prop up his hedge fund Alameda Research.

FTX’s scandal has notable parallels with what befell Enron. Both were led by messianic figures in Sam Bankman-Fried and Jeff Skilling who dazzled faithful with feats of technical wizardry. Both bathed in near-universal adoration from the press and the financial establishment.

site_title: China should set 2023 economic growth target no lower than 5%: central bank adviser
summary: China's central bank adviser, Liu Shijin, recommends setting the 2023 economic growth target no lower than 5% due to the country's slow growth, which reached 3% in the first three quarters of this year. This is below the annual target of around 5.5%. Full-year growth is expected to be just over 3%. Liu emphasized the need for China's economic growth to return to a normal track or a reasonable range.

site_title: EU tries to break COP27 deadlock with offer on loss and damage fund
summary: The European Union proposed a plan to break the deadlock at COP27 climate negotiations in Egypt, offering a loss and damage finance facility for vulnerable countries in exchange for a pledge to phase down oil, gas, and coal. The proposal, made by EU climate chief Frans Timmermans, includes a commitment to establish a new loss and damage response fund and examine debt, with countries agreeing to peak global emissions by 2025 and phase down fossil fuels. The offer was met with mixed reactions, with some countries expressing skepticism about the EU's willingness to follow through on its commitments.

images.alt_text: EU Executive Prime Minister Frans Timmermans delivers a speech at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, during the COP27 climate conference on November 15, 2022. (Photo by AHMAD GHARABLI / AFP)

site_title: UAE should give oil and gas players bigger role at COP28, panellist says
summary: The UAE's COP28 conference, set to take place in 2023, may play a key role in incorporating the oil and gas industry into climate change discussions. Experts, including Chuka Umunna and Nili Gilbert, suggest that the UAE's prominent oil production and rapid diversification efforts position it to reach resolutions on the sustainable finance agenda. However, the Middle East and North Africa region remains in a "business-as-usual scenario" when it comes to climate change action, and SMEs are struggling to adopt sustainability strategies due to complex and expensive solutions.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

FILE PHOTO: View of a COP27 sign on the road leading to the conference area in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh town as the city prepares to host the COP27 summit next month, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sayed Sheasha/File Photo

At the Abu Dhabi Finance Week 2022, panellist discuss how big banks drive innovation. Speakers at the panel include Zul Javaid, CEO of UAE Trade Connect; Tan Bin Ru, South-east Asia CEO of OneConnect Financial Technology; Raheel Ahmed, CEO of Rakbank; and Gabrielle Inzirillo, head of ecosystem development at Abu Dhabi Global Market’s Financial Services Regulatory Authority.

Changpeng Zhao, who was speaking at the Abu Dhabi Finance Week, noted that FTX’s fallout has shaken confidence in the industry, and industry players would need to be more transparent to rebuild that confidence.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end lower
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 0.29% to 17,992.54, as forecast-beating US data and Fed comments fueled interest rate hike fears. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with losses of 0.58% and 0.48%, respectively. The decline is attributed to the recent US data and Fed officials' comments on interest rate hikes, casting a shadow on the market.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) logo is displayed atop a gong at the HKEX Connect Hall in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Most Hong Kong people were caught off-guard by Beijing's proposal of the national security bill. Executive Council Member and the Chairman of HKEX Laura Cha said she was also surprised but was convinced the bill would ensure clarity and stability of the city. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai Exchange boosts surveillance to restore investor confidence
summary: Thailand's Stock Exchange of Thailand plans to tighten market supervision to restore investor confidence after unusual trading in the mid-size stock More Return led to regulatory sanctions against two local brokerages. The stock was suspended after an unanticipated "rare fraud incident" involving an investor who defaulted on paying for shares worth over $111 million. The Securities & Exchange Commission is probing transactions and assessing weaknesses to prevent a repeat. Authorities are also investigating a separate case involving Asia Wealth Securities, which was temporarily suspended for allegedly using clients' funds without their consent.

images.alt_text: “Foreign investors, who are reluctant to invest directly in Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, can invest in those equities through ETFs and DRs on Thai stock exchange,” said Pakorn Peetathawatchai, the exchange’s president.

site_title: Slump in home sales is next hurdle for rebounding China developers
summary: China's property developers are experiencing a rebound in shares and bonds following government support measures, with a Bloomberg index of Chinese builders rising 10% this week. However, a report by Moody's Investors Service predicts a 10-15% decline in contracted property sales by the end of next year, citing a gradual recovery. The government's property rescue package mainly benefits private developers yet to default, with Country Garden Holdings being the first to take advantage through a share placement.

images.alt_text: China will build more hospitals that specialise in treating moderate and severe Covid patients, and ensure that intensive care units account for 10 per cent of all hospital beds to tend to the most vulnerable patients.
Four China's government advisers told Reuters they had drafted recommendations for next year’s annual economic growth targets, ranging from 4.5 per cent to 5.5 per cent.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise but caution over rate outlook dulls sentiment
summary: Asia markets rose on Friday, but caution over the Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook tempered sentiment. Despite soft inflation data, policymakers warned that more rate hikes may be needed to curb inflation, fueling fears of a recession. The St Louis Fed's James Bullard and Minneapolis Fed's Neel Kaskari expressed concerns that underlying demand is not cooling, while Kansas City Fed chief Esther George said it's unclear how to douse inflation without slowing the economy.

images.alt_text: In early trade, Hong Kong lost more than 2 per cent, hit by profit-taking after a 14 per cent surge between Friday and Tuesday, while there were also losses in Shanghai.

site_title: North Korea fires suspected intercontinental ballistic missile, lands near Japan
summary: North Korea fired a suspected intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) on November 18, 2022, which landed near Japan. The missile, capable of flying 15,000 km, reached an altitude of 6,000 km and a range of 1,000 km before landing 200 km off Japan's Oshima-Oshima Island. The launch comes after North Korea warned of "fiercer military responses" to the US increasing regional security presence. US Vice President Kamala Harris is set to discuss the incident with leaders from Japan, South Korea, and other countries at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit.

images.alt_text: Last week North Korea fired more than 80 missiles, including its latest short-range ballistic missiles (SRBMs) and a new variant of intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM), by far its highest number of launches in such a short period.

site_title: The tenacity of ESG investing
summary: ESG investing has defied expectations, with sustainable funds remaining resilient during this year's market downturn. Despite a decline in investor appetite, $139 billion flowed into ESG funds by September, compared to $643 billion in net outflows from the broader market. This is largely due to the long-term focus of ESG investors, who prioritize social and environmental values over short-term returns. In contrast, fossil fuel firms have outperformed, highlighting the distinction between ESG and non-ESG investing strategies.

images.alt_text: The report, based on a survey of fund managers in Asia, found that less than half of respondents conduct ESG due diligence on every deal, while 46 per cent did so on most deals.

investors are asking ESG-related questions relating to businesses – referring to sustainability ratings and metrics when assessing an organisation’s suitability for inclusion in their investment portfolios.

site_title: Tencent wins first major game approval as crackdown eases
summary: Tencent Holdings has won approval for its first major game title, Metal Slug: Awakening, since Chinese regulators resumed licensing in April. This approval comes as Beijing's crackdown on the mobile entertainment industry eases. The game was among 70 domestic titles approved for November by the National Press and Publication Administration. Tencent's shares increased 3.7% in Hong Kong trading, and NetEase also won approval for its title Journey to the West. The approval is a sign that the tech giant's major games will be released soon, following a major step forward in October.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Drivers of food delivery service Meituan are seen in Shanghai, China June 25, 2018. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: McLaren Artura: Right on track
summary: The McLaren Artura, a plug-in hybrid supercar, is showcased at the Sepang International Circuit in Malaysia, offering a unique driving experience. Despite Singapore's strict traffic laws, the Artura's impressive performance and handling make it an ideal choice for driving enthusiasts. With its 680 horsepower and 720 Nm of torque, the car can reach speeds of 330 km/h and complete a 0-100 km/h sprint in just 3 seconds. McLaren Singapore plans to host at least three track days next year, providing customers with the opportunity to experience the car's capabilities in a safe and controlled environment.

site_title: US mortgage rates post biggest drop since 1981, falling to 6.61%
summary: US mortgage rates dropped to 6.61% for a 30-year fixed mortgage, the lowest level in almost two months, following a decline in yields for 10-year Treasuries. The rate decrease reflects a change in Freddie Mac's methodology, which uses data from its automated underwriting system to calculate average rates. The decline offers relief for homebuyers, but inflation remains elevated, and the Federal Reserve is likely to keep interest rates high, potentially leading to a rebound in rates before the end of the year.

images.alt_text: US single-family homebuilding dropped to an annualised 855,000 rate, the lowest since May 2020.

site_title: Goldman’s JV with ICBC raises US$21m in maiden China wealth product
summary: Goldman Sachs' majority-owned joint venture with ICBC Wealth Management raised US$28.8 million in its maiden China wealth product, which invests in equities and adopts quantitative strategies. The product was exclusively distributed by ICBC from October 31 to November 15, during which China's stock and bond markets experienced volatility. This is the fourth foreign institution to set up a joint venture with a local asset management partner to sell wealth products in China, following Amundi, BlackRock, and Schroders. The fundraising was significantly smaller than BlackRock's China wealth management venture.

site_title: Thai police fire rubber bullets to disperse protest over Apec summit
summary: Thai police fired rubber bullets to disperse a protest against the APEC summit in Bangkok, arresting 10 protesters. About 350 demonstrators opposed to the summit and Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-ocha clashed with police, with protesters throwing projectiles and charging at officers. The protesters, mostly youth activists, claim the summit is "greenwashing" environmental resolutions and demand strong action against climate change. The protests are part of a broader push for democratic reforms and the release of political prisoners.

images.alt_text: China’s President Xi Jinping is attending the summit, while the United States is being represented by US Vice-President Kamala Harris.

site_title: Society of solidarity for Ukrainian refugees in Poland
summary: Poland has granted almost the same rights to its 1.5-2 million Ukrainian refugees as Polish citizens, offering them free psychological support, food aid, and healthcare. The Polish society has shown exceptional solidarity, with 70% of adults involved in helping refugees, and many offering their homes and contributing financially. Ukrainians are entitled to cash benefits, education, and employment opportunities, with 60% finding jobs. The Polish government has also liberalized laws regarding the employment of Ukrainians and set up a system for them to access social benefits and education.

images.alt_text: A model of the natural gas pipeline is seen in front of displayed Bulgarian and Russian flag colours in this illustration taken April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, VCPlus
summary: Sembcorp is acquiring a 45.3% stake in a Chinese renewable energy company for 1.1 billion yuan (S$204 million), expected to be accretive to earnings. VCPlus' subsidiary received in-principle approval to provide custodial services for capital market products, shifting focus to fintech.

images.alt_text:
sbess26 - South-east Asia's largest energy storage system being installed on Jurong Island. With a capacity of 200 megawatts, the system will be operational in November 2022. 



Credit : Sembcorp Industries

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher despite US losses
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Friday, November 18, despite US losses, as investors weighed concerns over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes and potential US recession. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.24% and the Topix index climbed 0.37%, driven by positive sentiments in Europe and Asia.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians reflected on an electronic stock board outside a securities firm in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, June 9, 2017. Photographer: Noriko Hayashi

site_title: Amazon CEO says job cuts will continue into 2023
summary: Amazon CEO Andy Jassy announced that the company will continue to cut jobs into 2023 as it adjusts to business conditions. The cost-reduction plans, which were first reported to wipe out around 10,000 jobs, are aimed at prioritizing customer needs and long-term business health. Employees in various departments, including devices and books, and the "People, Experience and Technology" organization, were offered voluntary buyouts or 60-day notice periods. Jassy stated that the annual planning process will extend into 2023, leading to more role reductions, and that impacted employees will be notified early in the year.

site_title: World Cup tickets in Qatar most expensive ever: study
summary: A study by Keller Sports reveals that World Cup tickets in Qatar will be the most expensive ever, with an average price of £684 (S$1,116) for a seat, a 59% increase from four years ago. This is significantly higher than the 2018 edition in Russia, where fans paid an average of £214 for a seat. The high ticket prices are attributed to the massive infrastructure development costs of the World Cup in Qatar, estimated to be around $3 billion.

images.alt_text: A billboard featuring France's striker Kylian Mbappe (L) and Argentine's captain Lionel Messi in Doha on Nov 8, 2022, ahead of the Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup football tournament.

site_title: Are tech stocks now good value?
summary: Tech stocks have seen significant declines, with the Nasdaq down by nearly a third and major companies like Amazon, Netflix, and Meta shedding 48%, 58%, and 70% of their value, respectively. This plunge is attributed to poor third-quarter earnings. However, some value investors are now considering tech stocks as potentially undervalued. Warren Buffett's quote suggests that buying quality merchandise at a discount is preferable to buying cheap merchandise. The question remains whether the current discounts make tech stocks a good deal.

images.alt_text: Stocks like Meta, Microsoft, Amazon and Apple have suffered staggering losses this year, but is this a good time to buy?
Offices for Twitter in San Francisco, on Oct. 6, 2022.

site_title: Apac insurance premiums set to rise 2.2% in 2023 and 2024: Swiss Re
summary: Insurance premiums in the Asia-Pacific region are projected to increase by 2.2% in 2023 and 2024, reversing the 0.2% contraction in 2022, according to Swiss Re. This growth is attributed to rising interest rates and inflation, which will offset inflationary pressures. Life insurance premiums in Apac are expected to grow 2% over the next two years, reversing a five-year average decline of 1.7%. Non-life real premiums in Apac are also expected to recover to 2.3% in 2023 and 2024, driven by a growing middle class and emerging markets.

images.alt_text:
ST20221101-202253546871-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/
