Experts warn of increased due diligence and scrutiny of opaque offshore entities in the future.

images.alt_text: FTX US and BlockFi are closely tied.
Genesis is suspending redemptions and new loan originations at its lending business after facing what it described as “abnormal withdrawal requests.”

site_title: Gold flat as geopolitical tensions ease; focus on future Fed path
summary: Gold prices hit a three-month peak of US$1,786.35 per ounce on Tuesday after news of Russian missiles killing two people in Poland near the Ukraine border. However, as fears of a wider Ukraine crisis subsided, prices became flat on Thursday, remaining unchanged at US$1,773.40 per ounce. Traders are focusing on the US Federal Reserve's interest rate strategy, with a 93% probability of a 50 basis-point rate hike at the December meeting. Rising interest rates are expected to dull gold's appeal.

images.alt_text: Rising interest rates tend to dull bullion’s appeal as the metal pays no interest.

site_title: Perennial-led consortium secures S$3b real estate green loan
summary: A consortium led by Perennial Holdings has secured a S$3 billion green loan to finance the redevelopment of 8 Shenton Way, set to become Singapore's tallest building, aiming for the top sustainability standard, Green Mark Platinum certification.

images.alt_text: Landscaped terraces are a main feature of SOM's 8 Shenton Way.
AXA Tower in Shenton Way.
An expansive landscaped lobby and terrace creates an indoor-outdoor gathering and workspace for building occupants at 8 Shenton Way.

site_title: Hot stock: Halcyon Agri surges 34.5% to two-year high after acquisition offer
summary: Halcyon Agri, a Singapore-listed rubber producer, surged 34.5% to a two-year high after receiving a US$180.9 million acquisition offer from China Hainan Rubber Industry Group to acquire a 36% stake in the company. The counter traded near its intraday high of S$0.39, with nearly 11.2 million shares changing hands. This marks the first time the counter traded near such levels since June 2020.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Workers at Halcyon Agri faciliy in Palembang, Indonesia. Natural rubber is formed into blankets as part of the process of making Standard Indonesian Rubber.

site_title: Hong Kong: Market opens lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.01% in the opening minutes of trading on November 17, 2022, following a recent surge and tracking a drop on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index dropped 18,071.60 points to 184.88. Meanwhile, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, losing 0.29% each. The decline was attributed to profit-takers and investors reacting to market uncertainty.

site_title: No direct exposure to cryptocurrencies, says Temasek
summary: State investor Temasek said it has no direct exposure to cryptocurrencies despite investing $275 million in FTX, a cryptocurrency exchange. The investment was made in two rounds, with Temasek holding a 1% minority stake in FTX International and 1.5% stake in FTX US. Temasek's due diligence process focused on regulatory risks and cybersecurity, but the company's founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, appears to have misled them. The investment was written down to zero after FTX's bankruptcy filing, with Temasek acknowledging that no investment can eliminate all risks.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Temasek is now preparing to write off the entire amount, one of the people said, asking not to be identified as the matter is private.
Temasek is in talks with troubled crypto exchange FTX after it signed a non-binding letter of intent with rival Binance for a full acquistion.
FTX’s collapse marks a stunning reversal of fortunes for the company and its founder Sam Bankman-Fried.

site_title: Surprise 5.6% fall in Singapore exports in October; first decline in two years
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted by 5.6% year-on-year in October, marking the first decline in two years. Electronic exports fell 9.3% and non-electronic exports declined 4.5% due to sharp drops in gold and pharmaceutical exports. Economists warn that the decline may be an early warning sign of a potential 2023 recession, with global headwinds and reopening tailwinds offsetting each other. Total trade was up 8.6% year-on-year, but fell 5.1% seasonally-adjusted.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Exports to Singapore’s top 10 markets fell as a whole in September, dragged by a 33.8 per cent year-on-year contraction in shipments to China, compared the previous month’s 18.2 per cent decline.
Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) in September grew 3.1 per cent year on year, down from the 11.4 per cent expansion in the previous month, data from Enterprise Singapore showed.
The Purchasing Managers’ Index dipped a further 0.2 point to post a second straight month of contraction at 49.7 in October, the lowest reading since June 2020.

“Many semiconductor companies operating in Singapore have manufacturing processes and products that rely on US technology, which may be subject to export controls imposed by the US government,” said Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens lower after US losses
summary: The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo opened lower, dipping 0.20% to 27,971.31, following US losses as a major retailer warned of a softer holiday season. This came after the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty and tariff fog. The broader Topix index edged up 0.04%.

site_title: Blizzard to suspend game services in China as NetEase licences end
summary: Blizzard Entertainment's game development and publishing unit will suspend most game services in mainland China once its current licensing agreements with NetEase end in January. The decision comes after Beijing tightened its oversight of the gaming industry, limiting play time for teens and reducing the number of gaming licenses given out. This move affects Activision Blizzard's Chinese operations, which have been heavily impacted by Beijing's efforts to regulate the gaming sector.

images.alt_text: Smartphone game Diablo Immortal was Activision’s big release for the first half of the year.

site_title: SoftBank Group unit seeks up to US$215m in Paytm stake sale
summary: SoftBank Group is selling up to $215 million in Paytm shares, seeking to reduce its stake in the Indian digital payments company. The stake sale comes as Paytm's shares have plummeted 72% since its initial public offering (IPO) last year. SoftBank, along with Alibaba Group Holding and Ant Group, will hold around 12.9% of Paytm after the sale. This move follows a slump in market value for several Indian startups, including Paytm, Zomato, and Nykaa, which have seen significant losses since their IPOs.

images.alt_text: Paytm reiterated that it expects to reach operating profitability by the quarter ending September 2023 amid continued revenue growth.

site_title: Brokers’ take: UOBKH downgrades First Resources to ‘hold’, says positives priced in
summary: UOB Kay Hian downgraded First Resources to "hold" from "buy", citing the higher share price due to strong Q3 results. The research house recommends holding the stock for its "good" dividend yields of 6-8% between FY2022 and FY2024. First Resources raised its dividend payout ratio to 50% and lifted its earnings forecasts for FY2022-2024 by 39-23%.

images.alt_text: First Resources posts a surge in Q3 profit due to stronger palm oil prices and the resumption of palm oil exports in Indonesia.

site_title: Vietnam nears US$11b deal to shift economy from coal
summary: Vietnam is set to sign a climate financing package worth up to $14 billion to shift its economy away from coal and boost renewable energy. The deal, led by the European Union and the UK, includes $5-7 billion in public loans and grants, with the rest coming from private sources. The package aims to decarbonize Vietnam's power sector and reach carbon neutrality by the middle of the century, with technical assistance on renewable regulations also included. The agreement comes after similar deals for Indonesia and South Africa, and is part of a series of energy transition packages for coal-reliant countries.

images.alt_text: Power-generating windmill turbines are pictured at a wind park in Bac Lieu province, Vietnam, July 8, 2017. REUTERS/Kham

site_title: S-Reits’ Q3 results a preview of the potential horror show at the next earnings season
summary: S-Reits' Q3 results show a potential "horror show" at the next earnings season, with 9 out of 24 S-Reits reporting a decline in distributable income due to higher interest rates and foreign exchange woes. Frasers Centrepoint Trust's 2.8% decline in distributable income for the second half ended September is a notable example. The decline is expected to worsen before improving, with S-Reits facing increased financing costs and currency fluctuations.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
The manager of Suntec Reit says its stronger operational performance was weighed down by interest rate and exchange rate pressures.

site_title: Cisco’s revenue forecast points to steady technology spending
summary: Cisco Systems reported a 4.5-6.5% revenue increase for the quarter ending in January, beating analyst expectations, and announced a plan to cut 5% of its workforce and reduce office space to adapt to changing business conditions amid an uncertain economic climate. The company will incur $600 million in pretax charges for severance and other costs. Despite job cuts, Cisco's management remains optimistic about the demand for its gear, citing strong orders and the ability to meet customer demand.

images.alt_text: Cisco's project is part of the so-called Perte plan of government subsidies for semiconductor research and development using the European Union’s pandemic relief funds.
Cisco’s Jeetu Patel, head of Security & Collaboration, said the company aims to be the hardware platform for a wide range of conferencing software platforms.

site_title: Nvidia sales beat estimates as data-centre business fuels growth
summary: Nvidia posted quarterly sales that topped analysts' estimates, driven by its data-centre business, which saw a 31% increase. The company's gaming business declined 51% in the same period. Despite a revenue decline of 17% to $5.93 billion, Nvidia's shares gained 2% in late trading, beating expectations. The company's fourth-quarter forecast was slightly light, but its data-centre sales and partnership with Microsoft to build a cloud AI computer helped alleviate investor fears.

images.alt_text: The AI computer will operate on Microsoft’s Azure cloud, using tens of thousands of graphics processing units (GPUs), Nvidia’s most powerful H100 and its A100 chips.
Data centres rely on graphics chips like Nvidia’s to handle AI tasks and process huge sets of information.

site_title: Singapore stocks buck global losses at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% to 3,279.57 on Thursday, bucking global losses, with gainers outnumbering losers 71 to 52. Top-performing counters included Singtel, Halcyon Agri, and 9R, driven by announcements of new investments and acquisitions. The US markets closed lower, with the Dow Jones, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Indexes experiencing declines, amid concerns over consumer spending and the holiday season.

images.alt_text: A Chinese company is acquiring a 36 per cent stake in Halcyon Agri, triggering a mandatory conditional cash offer for all the latter's shares.

site_title: New Zealand population growth starts to climb as border reopens
summary: New Zealand's population growth has increased by 8,000 or 0.2% in the three months through September, the largest quarterly gain in two years. This growth was driven by a net inflow of 4,600 migrants, the first since 2020. The estimated population now stands at 5,127,400, with natural increase contributing 3,400. The recovery in population growth is still below pre-pandemic levels, indicating ongoing labor market tightness.

site_title: As recession looms, Airbnb CEO wants your home to make money
summary: Airbnb CEO Brian Chesky aims to refocus the company on its core business of helping people make money through hosting properties, rather than expanding into new sectors. With a looming recession, the company wants to encourage more hosts and provide affordable pricing options. To attract reluctant hosts, Airbnb is introducing a new feature offering advice from experienced "superhosts" and expanding user identity requirements. The company also announced the launch of anti-party screening technology and increased insurance coverage. Chesky plans to revive the "experiences" sector in the long term, but acknowledges it will take time to match supply and demand.

images.alt_text: Brian Chesky, co-founder and chief executive officer of Airbnb Inc., listens during the 2015 Fortune Global Forum in San Francisco, California, U.S., on Wednesday, Nov. 4, 2015. The forum gathers Global 500 CEO's and innovators, builders, and technologists from some of the most dynamic, emerging companies all over the world to facilitate relationship building at the highest levels. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Brian Chesky

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Capitalising on blockchain to future proof (Ep 2)
summary: Heng Koon How from UOB discusses the potential of blockchain technology in the finance industry, citing "blockchain shock waves" that are transforming the sector. He highlights the benefits of capitalising on blockchain, including increased efficiency and transparency. The conversation focuses on future-proofing the financial industry through the adoption of blockchain technology, but no specific events or conclusions are mentioned in this article.

images.alt_text: UOB  sees three major blockchain related shockwaves hitting the banking system in the years to come. These will fundamentally change clients’ payment experience, the capital markets landscape and the investible assets space.

site_title: Crypto lender BlockFi plans bankruptcy filing within days in FTX fallout
summary: Crypto lender BlockFi plans to file for bankruptcy within days amid the FTX fallout, citing uncertainties and pausing client withdrawals. BlockFi had previously stated it had adequate liquidity but is now exploring options with outside advisers. The company's close ties to FTX US, a subsidiary of the now-defunct FTX, have contributed to its financial struggles. A representative for BlockFi declined to comment on the matter. The bankruptcy filing is expected to be announced in the coming days.

site_title: Sea seeking replacement tenant for its 200,000 sq ft of space in Buona Vista
summary: Sea Ltd, parent company of e-commerce player Shopee, is seeking a replacement tenant for its 200,000 sq ft of office space at CapitaLand's Rochester Commons development in Singapore. The tech conglomerate had signed a long lease in 2021 but is now looking for a new tenant due to aggressive spending and hiring in the past. The decision is reportedly a result of the company's need to show a clear path to profitability amid investor caution. Sea is expected to lease out most of the office space in tandem with its growth.

images.alt_text: Sea’s gaming segment remains the sole weak spot in the group’s latest set of financial results, notes CGS-CIMB.
E-commerce and other services pushed Sea's Q3 2022 revenue up to US$3.2 billion, but losses only dipped 0.3 per cent to US$569.3 million.
This is at least the third round of job cuts Shopee has made this year.

site_title: Japan’s trade gap persists as weak yen squeezes purchasing power
summary: Japan's trade gap persists, driven by a record 2.16 trillion yen deficit in October. Exports grew 25.3% year-on-year, led by car, chip, and electronics shipments, but imports surged 53.5% due to crude oil, coal, and liquefied natural gas, mainly affecting resource-poor Japan. This has raised concerns among policymakers about the impact of a weak yen on the economy, already weakened by a shrinking GDP in July-September. The trade deficit adds upward pressure to costs of living and doing business, exacerbating the struggle of households to make ends meet.

images.alt_text: Compared with a year earlier, Japan's core orders, a highly volatile data series regarded as a leading indicator of capital spending in the coming six to nine months, grew 2.9 per cent.
“My hope is to have this meeting lead to a constructive and stable relationship” between Japan and China, Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida said.
The Nikkei 225 index dipped 0.20 per cent, or 56.99 points, to 27,971.31 at the open on Wednesday.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 drops 1% on Mercedes drag; Target outlook weighs on retailers
summary: The Stoxx 600 index in Europe closed 1% lower on Wednesday, snapping a four-day winning streak, due to losses in Mercedes Benz and Target Corp. Automobile stocks tumbled 3.7% and retailers dropped 3.4% as Target forecast a surprise drop in holiday-quarter sales. British inflation hit a 41-year high, and a euro zone inflation report is due on Thursday. Shares of some defense companies rose, while the Stoxx 600 has dropped 11.8% this year amid concerns of a euro zone recession.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index advanced just 0.1 per cent to 7,378.54 points, also weighed down as data showed UK inflation spiked to a 41-year peak in October.

site_title: Opt in for 'intensity' or take severance, says Musk to Twitter staff
summary: Elon Musk told Twitter staff they had until Thursday to decide whether to work "long hours at high intensity" or take a severance package. Employees who did not confirm their desire to stay by Thursday evening would be considered to have quit. Musk emphasized the need for "exceptional performance" and a more engineering-driven approach to the company. The move comes after Twitter slashed half its workforce earlier this month, and Musk has criticized the company's spending and work culture.

images.alt_text: Tesla investor Ross Gerber, a strong supporter of Musk, said on Tuesday that Tesla needed to find a deputy for its multitasking CEO.

site_title: UK blocks Chinese-led buyout of biggest microchip factory over national security
summary: The UK has blocked a Chinese-led buyout of Newport Wafer Fab, the country's biggest microchip factory, due to national security concerns. The decision, made under the UK's National Security and Investment Act, comes after the site was acquired by Nexperia Holding, a Dutch subsidiary of Wingtech Technology, in July 2021. The UK government cited the potential reintroduction of compound semiconductor activities and the site's importance to UK capabilities as factors in the decision. Nexperia has stated it will appeal the decision, which marks the first retrospective rejection of a deal under the new act.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices rose by 11.1 per cent in annual terms last month, the highest reading since October 1981 and a big jump from 10.1 per cent in September, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said.

site_title: ECB officials may favour slower rate hiking with half-point move
summary: European Central Bank officials may consider a slower interest-rate hike, potentially a 50 basis-point increase, at their final decision on December 15. Initial discussions suggest a lack of momentum for another 75 basis-point move, citing recession risks, weakening consumer-price pressures, and the prospect of reaching a neutral interest rate. Policymakers are also weighing the need to balance-sheet reduction. A half-point move to 2% deposit rate could be seen as near-neutral, no longer stimulating the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the European Central Bank (ECB) building, in Frankfurt, Germany, July 21, 2022. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Best rally in decades for Asia to cool once reality sets in
summary: Asia's rally, with the MSCI Asia-Pacific Index jumping 13% in November, appears precarious as analysts caution that the rally may be driven by tentative optimism rather than firm grounds. The rally is built on bets for a softer Federal Reserve tightening and China's pivot away from Covid Zero, but some analysts warn that the gains may cool unless the Fed lives up to hopes and Chinese authorities relax virus restrictions. Economists see a higher risk of a global recession, and Asian emerging-market equities may face volatility as traders navigate these risks.

images.alt_text: currencies

site_title: US Federal Reserve official open to slower rate hike in December
summary: US Federal Reserve governor Christopher Waller expressed openness to slowing down interest rate hikes in December due to easing inflation pressures and a slowing US economy. The latest data showed annual inflation rate at 9.1% in June, its highest in four decades. Waller suggested considering a 50-basis-point hike instead of a 75-basis-point increase, while still acknowledging more rate increases are needed to bring inflation down. This shift in stance could indicate a potential slowdown in the Fed's aggressive campaign to rein in surging prices.

images.alt_text: FILE Ñ People walking through New YorkÕs Soho neighborhood on Oct. 27 2022. Retail sales rose last month, and several retailers reported strong earnings but discounts seemed to drive a significant portion of purchases. (Amir Hamja/The New York Times)

site_title: Travel with Tetsuya Wakuda to Okinawa
summary: Chef Tetsuya Wakuda visits Okinawa to source ingredients for his restaurants, exploring the sub-tropical islands' culinary bounty, known for its nutrient-rich seafood, meat, and vegetables. He samples local produce, including acerola cherries, and discovers the health benefits of the Okinawan diet. This trip is part of Wakuda's efforts to find the best artisanal suppliers for his Japanese restaurants.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment extends year’s decline as rates rise
summary: US homebuilder sentiment declined in November, reaching its lowest level in a decade, with the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo gauge falling 5 points to 33. This marks the longest stretch of declines since 1985, extending a year of weakening sentiment. The decline is attributed to rising borrowing costs, which have impacted the housing market.

site_title: Malaysia’s Petronas reports fire at SSGP pipeline
summary: A fire at Malaysia's Sabah-Sarawak Gas Pipeline (SSGP) near Lawas killed one person and injured two others. The incident is believed to have involved a third-party contractor performing work unrelated to pipeline operations. A police report has been lodged by Petronas, the state energy company. The 512-kilometre pipeline transports gas from the Sabah Oil and Gas Terminal to Petronas' liquefied natural gas complex. This incident follows a force majeure declaration by Petronas in October due to a pipeline leak at the same pipeline.

site_title: Russian software disguised as American finds its way into US Army, CDC apps
summary: US Army and CDC apps have been found to contain code from a Russian software company, Pushwoosh, disguised as an American company. The company, based in Siberia, claims to provide code and data processing support for software developers, but its true origins were revealed after a Reuters investigation. The CDC removed the code from its apps due to security concerns, and the US Army also removed an app containing Pushwoosh code in March. The company's business with US government agencies and private companies could violate laws and trigger sanctions. Pushwoosh has denied any malicious intent and claims to store user data in the US and Germany, but cybersecurity experts say this does not prevent Russian intelligence agencies from accessing the data.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration shows the logo of cryptocurrency FTX, reflected in its website on a laptop screen in Washington, DC, on November 13, 2022. - The new chief executive of troubled cryptocurrency platform FTX said on November 12, 2022, the company was making "every effort to secure all assets" following unauthorized transactions potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Additionally, the platform's chief executive, 30-year-old Sam Bankman-Fried, once considered a star in the freewheeling cryptocurrency world, resigned. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)
An empty chair set aside for Myanmar's delegation at the Asean Summit in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The Myanmar crisis dominated the first day of a summit.

site_title: Samsung customers seek chip ‘second source’ on geopolitical risk
summary: Samsung Electronics' head of corporate planning, Sim Sang-pil, stated that the global technology industry is seeking alternative sources for advanced semiconductors due to rising geopolitical risks. The company aims to increase its foundry capacity by 3.3 times by 2027 to compete with Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC) and supply the US market. This move follows the US government's legislation to subsidize domestic chip manufacturing. With investments in new technology, such as Gate All Around (GAA), and a new fab in Texas, Samsung is positioning itself as a second source for customers concerned about geopolitical risks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Samsung Electronics is seen at its headquarters in Seoul, South Korea, April 4, 2016. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Cash investors trigger US$29b spike in ESG-lite funds
summary: US investors have poured nearly US$29 billion into ESG-lite funds, known as Article 8 funds, in October, reversing a nine-month trend of outflows. The shift is driven by UK pension managers reallocating funds in response to economic shock, primarily seeking ultra-safe liquidity. Critics argue Article 8 funds lack transparency, with EU regulators acknowledging shortcomings and working to close gaps. This trend is expected to favor Article 8 funds over more stringent ESG category Article 9.

images.alt_text: ESG issues are no longer seen as 'soft' and outside the scope of considerations for a serious investor. Asset managers have a fiduciary duty to consider ESG factors as part of long-term drivers of value.

site_title: Stock to watch: Halcyon Agri
summary: A Chinese company is acquiring a 36% stake in Halcyon Agri, triggering a mandatory conditional cash offer for all its shares. The acquisition price is US$0.315 per share. Halcyon Agri has requested to lift its trading halt, which started on November 14. The move may impact the company's shares, which closed at US$0.29 on November 11.

images.alt_text: Workers at Halcyon Agri faciliy in Palembang, Indonesia. Natural rubber is formed into blankets as part of the process of making Standard Indonesian Rubber.

site_title: Oil falls as Druzhba pipeline reopens, China’s Covid-19 worries stay at the fore
summary: Oil prices fell as the Druzhba pipeline to Hungary reopened, with Brent crude futures settling 1.1% lower at $92.86 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures dropping 1.5% to $85.59 a barrel. Rising Covid-19 cases in China and weak Chinese economic data also weighed on sentiment. The International Energy Agency forecasts demand growth to slow to 1.6 million bpd in 2023, while Iraq plans to raise its production capacity to 7 million barrels a day by 2027, subject to Opec coordination.

images.alt_text: An oil pump jack at the New Harmony Oil Field in Grayville, Illinois, US, on Sunday, June 19, 2022. Top Biden administration officials are weighing limits on exports of fuel as the White House struggles to contain gasoline prices that have topped $5 per gallon. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg

site_title: UK budget set to deliver more economic pain
summary: The UK is set to unveil a fresh era of austerity, with finance minister Jeremy Hunt triggering tax rises and spending cuts to combat a 41-year high inflation rate of 11.1%. The measures, worth £54 billion, aim to protect long-term economic growth while being "compassionate" towards the most vulnerable. The move comes after the short-lived tenure of prime minister Liz Truss, who unleashed a package of unfunded tax cuts that caused panic on financial markets. The government's plan is expected to worsen the cost-of-living crisis and may lead to further industrial action, including strikes by nurses, firefighters, and postal staff.

images.alt_text: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt is set to announce tax hikes and spending cuts in the UK budget on Thursday (Nov 17).
Downing Street said the planned meeting between the 2 leaders was cancelled due to scheduling issues, while China said it had no information to share.
Consumer prices rose by 11.1 per cent in annual terms last month, the highest reading since October 1981 and a big jump from 10.1 per cent in September, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said.
Newport Wafer Fab makes silicon wafers on which microchips are etched.

site_title: S-Reits’ Q3 results mixed as higher financing costs, currency headwinds dampen distribution growth
summary: S-Reits, Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts, reported mixed Q3 results as higher financing costs and currency headwinds dampened distribution growth. 28 out of 34 S-Reits saw an improvement in topline figures, while 6 reported declines, mostly due to overseas assets. Despite stronger operational performance, higher interest rates and exchange rate pressures reduced distributable income to unitholders. Nearly all S-Reits reported positive rental reversions, but more than a third saw a decline in distributable income.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
VivoCity shopping mall

site_title: Crypto brokerage Genesis suspends withdrawals at lending arm
summary: Genesis, a digital-asset brokerage, has suspended redemptions and new loan originations at its lending business due to "abnormal withdrawal requests." The move comes as a counterparty to many in the sector, and its financial health has been closely watched for signs of industry strength or potential contagion. Gemini, a crypto exchange that has partnered with Genesis, has also halted redemptions from its yield product targeting retail investors. The move is seen as fallout from the collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried's crypto empire.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of virtual cryptocurrencies are placed on U.S. dollar banknotes in this illustration taken November 28, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US: Stocks slump on retailer warning despite resilient data
summary: US stocks declined on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 0.1% to 33,553.83, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes dipping 0.8% and 1.5%, respectively. A weaker-than-expected earnings report from Target and a gloomy outlook for the holiday season contributed to the slump. Despite resilient retail sales data, investors remain cautious about the strength of consumer spending amid high inflation and interest rates. Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller expressed caution about the pace of interest rate hikes, citing easing inflation and a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: The value of overall retail purchases climbed 1.3 per cent last month after stagnating in September, Commerce Department data showed on Wednesday (Nov 16).

site_title: China's Xi confronts Canada's Trudeau at G20 summit over leaks to media
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping publicly criticized Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau over alleged leaks of their G20 summit meeting, with Xi stating, "If there is sincerity, we can communicate well with mutual respect, otherwise the outcome will not be easy to tell." The exchange occurred in a video footage, with Xi expressing annoyance over the leak, saying "That is not appropriate, and we didn’t do it that way." The incident highlights tensions between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin speaking to China's President Xi Jinping during the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) leaders' summit in Samarkand on September 16, 2022.. Both leaders are expected to attend the upcoming G20 summit in Bali.

site_title: US retail sales rise most in 8 months as consumers hold on
summary: US retail sales rose 1.3% in October, the largest increase in eight months, as consumers continued to hold on to demand for goods despite high inflation and economic uncertainty. This is in line with economists' median estimate of a 1% increase. Key sectors such as auto dealers, grocery stores, and restaurants saw gains, while gas stations and clothing stores were exceptions. Retailers are still feeling the impact of inflation, with many offering discounts to clear inventory for the holiday season.

images.alt_text: There are more signs that inflationary pressures are beginning to ease as the producer price index advanced 8 per cent from a year ago, the smallest annual gain in more than a year.

site_title: Lockheed gets Microsoft classified cloud to speed work with Pentagon
summary: Lockheed Martin has secured a three-year deal with Microsoft to use the company's classified cloud, enabling faster collaboration with the Pentagon. The partnership allows Lockheed to share information securely and streamline IT processes, saving time and money. Microsoft's classified cloud, built over seven years, will be used for virtual testing of military systems and technologies, as well as identifying cyber threats. The deal is expected to speed up the process of setting up new government projects, reducing repetitive security compliance processes. No estimated cost was provided for the project.

site_title: Inflationary pressures in Canada hit their broadest since 1991
summary: Canada's inflation rate has stabilized at 6.9% in October, better than expected, but price pressures remain broad, with over 85% of subcategories exceeding the Bank of Canada's 2% target. This is the highest proportion since 1991, sparking concerns about the central bank's ability to control inflation. Food price gains slowed to 10% but grocery stores still face significant price pressure. The Bank of Canada may consider further interest rate hikes to address the issue, with markets predicting a 25-50 basis point increase at its next policy decision on December 7.

images.alt_text: In video footage published by Canadian broadcasters, Xi and Trudeau can be seen standing close to each other and conversing via a translator.

site_title: Grab’s Q3 net loss narrows to US$327m; deliveries segment hits positive adjusted Ebitda ahead of guidance
summary: Grab narrowed its Q3 net loss to US$327 million, a significant improvement from US$970 million a year ago, driven by revenue growth of 143% to US$382 million. The deliveries segment achieved positive adjusted Ebitda for the first time, three quarters ahead of guidance, thanks to optimization of incentive spend and contributions from Jaya Grocer. Grab's management continues to focus on cost-cutting, with plans to reduce regional headcount and repurchase up to US$750 million of its term loan to preserve cash.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
gasometer, berlin, tightrope walker
Revenue for the quarter surged 79 per cent to hit an all-time high of US$321 million.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover CEO Bollore resigns after two years
summary: Jaguar Land Rover CEO Thierry Bollore is resigning after two years due to personal reasons. Bollore cited the company's transformation towards a sustainable future as a reason for his departure, despite plans for electrification and the introduction of electrified variants. Adrian Mardell, a 32-year Jaguar Land Rover veteran, will take over as interim CEO. The company faces industry-wide supply chain issues and struggles to ramp up production, but Bollore's exit comes as the company is making progress towards its sustainability goals.

site_title: Chinese rubber producer to acquire 36% of Halcyon Agri at US$0.315 per share
summary: China Hainan Rubber Industry Group is acquiring 36% of Halcyon Agri Corporation at US$0.315 per share, resulting in a total cash consideration of US$180.9 million. The acquisition represents a 50.3% premium over Halcyon Agri's last trading price of S$0.29. This deal triggers a mandatory conditional cash offer for all shares in the Singapore-listed company, with China Hainan Rubber owning more than 30% of Halcyon Agri.

images.alt_text: Venga (எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்)
Workers at Halcyon Agri faciliy in Palembang, Indonesia. Natural rubber is formed into blankets as part of the process of making Standard Indonesian Rubber.
Revenue of natural rubber supplier Halcyon Agri climbed 18.9 per cent to US$617.3 million in Q1 on the back of higher sales volume and higher average selling prices, it said on Friday.

site_title: Thai bourse to boost ETFs, depository receipts on foreign firms
summary: Thailand's Stock Exchange of Thailand plans to boost ETFs and depository receipts on foreign companies to attract international investors. The move aims to promote the Thai exchange as a trading center for overseas stocks. Foreign investors can invest in equities from Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia, and Vietnam through these products, bypassing direct investment restrictions in these countries. The plan is part of efforts to attract international investors, particularly those interested in tourism, restaurant, hotel, and healthcare shares, despite Thailand's uneven economic recovery.

site_title: US factory output barely rises after tepid gains in prior months
summary: US factory output rose 0.1% in October after downward revisions to prior months, a slower pace than expected. This followed a revised 0.2% advance in September. Manufacturing output was boosted by motor vehicles, electrical equipment, and aerospace transportation, but excluding autos, factory production stagnated. The decline in factory production, combined with a 0.1% fall in total industrial output, marks the second decline in three months.

images.alt_text: The value of overall retail purchases climbed 1.3 per cent last month after stagnating in September, Commerce Department data showed on Wednesday (Nov 16).

site_title: Panel says there’s room to potentially tokenise all assets, given benefits of blockchain
summary: A panel discussion at the Abu Dhabi Finance Week 2022 suggests that blockchain technology could potentially tokenise all investment instruments, increasing liquidity, access, and efficiency. Experts, including Securrency's Dan Doney and HSBC's Chan Xian, agree that universal tokenisation could reduce market fragmentation and increase liquidity, while also making investment access more accessible to retail and institutional investors. Tokenisation is expected to benefit both investors and asset managers, with potential applications including non-fungible tokens and fractional ownership of real assets.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Singapore’s Temasek to write down over US$200m in FTX
summary: Temasek International, a Singaporean state-owned investor, is preparing to write off its entire US$200-300 million investment in FTX, a cryptocurrency firm that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Sequoia Capital and SoftBank Group also face significant losses on their investments. Despite this, Temasek's overall financial standing is unlikely to be impacted, as it managed S$403 billion in assets as of March 31. The firm had previously expressed confidence in the long-term performance of its portfolio companies, including FTX, but now faces a significant writedown.

images.alt_text: FTX’s stunning downfall in a matter of days has shone a spotlight on the personality-driven nature of the crypto world and the intermediary risks of using platforms like FTX, whose businesses are far more complex than traditional exchanges.

site_title: Deliveroo ends food deliveries in Australia
summary: Deliveroo has ended its operations in Australia after seven years, citing strong competition and a disciplined approach to capital allocation. The decision comes three months after exiting the Netherlands and following its departure from Spain. With 14,000 self-employed riders, Deliveroo cited a highly competitive market with four global players and concerns over the economic downturn affecting discretionary spend on takeaways. The move follows a troubled stock market debut in London last year, where its share price tumbled by nearly a third.

site_title: China’s fiscal revenue, expenditure pick up growth in October
summary: China's fiscal revenue and expenditure growth accelerated in October, with fiscal revenue growing 15.7% year-over-year and fiscal expenditure rising 8.7% year-over-year. This growth was driven by the easing of value-added tax (VAT) credit rebates and an infrastructure push. Fiscal expenditure rose 6.4% to 20.6 trillion yuan in the first 10 months, while fiscal revenue grew 5.1% year-over-year, exceeding the 4.1% gain in the first nine months.

site_title: Nvidia says it is working with Microsoft to build ‘massive’ cloud AI computer
summary: Nvidia is collaborating with Microsoft to build a massive cloud AI computer, utilizing tens of thousands of graphics processing units (GPUs), including Nvidia's H100 and A100 chips. The AI computer will operate on Microsoft's Azure cloud, marking a significant step in AI adoption for enterprise use cases. Nvidia declined to disclose the deal's worth, but sources estimate the A100 chip costs between $10,000 to $12,000, with the H100 being more expensive. The partnership aims to cater to growing demand for AI services in the enterprise.

site_title: G20’s moral case would be weakened if it did not condemn Russia’s actions in Ukraine: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the G20's moral case would be weakened if it did not condemn Russia's actions in Ukraine. The G20 issued a joint declaration condemning the war, with most members "strongly condemning" the conflict. Lee said the declaration allowed Russia to realize the "weight of the international community's opinion." The G20 also issued a joint statement with Nato and the G7 countries, condemning Russia's missile attacks on Ukrainian cities. Meanwhile, a historic meeting between US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping aimed to stabilize relations and avoid conflict.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
ST Engineering performed strongly after the company announced that it had secured a new contract to modernise New Jersey's tolling infrastructure.
A group of tuk tuks pass by the Democracy Monument in Bangkok on Nov 15, 2022. Thailand is hosting the APEC Summit this week.

Andrzej Duda, Poland's President, says: “From the information that we and our allies have, it was an S-300 rocket made in the Soviet Union, an old rocket and there is no evidence that it was launched by the Russian side.”

site_title: Bank-fintech ventures benefit consumers, enhance competition: US Treasury
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen says partnerships between banks and fintech companies can benefit consumers and enhance competition when done responsibly. Regulators can utilize existing authorities to encourage competition and protect consumers. These bank-fintech relationships have led to new products targeting specific communities, which traditional financial institutions have not previously catered to.

site_title: AMD chip to power auto supplier Aisin’s new automated car parking system
summary: AMD's micro processor, the Zynq UltraScale+ MPSoC, will power a new automated car parking system developed by Aisin, a major automotive supply company. The system uses four cameras and 12 ultrasonic sensors to parallel park and back into spaces, with a human driver deciding if the spot is in a no-parking zone. Production is expected to start in 2024 for Toyota and Lexus models. The chip's reconfigurability allows for software and hardware updates after the car is sold, making it a cost-effective solution for automakers.

site_title: Musk’s all-nighters at Twitter raise concern for Tesla investors
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk's prolonged work hours at Twitter have raised concerns among investors, with some worrying he's devoting too much time to the social media platform. Musk has been working all-nighters, sleeping at Twitter's San Francisco headquarters, amid the platform's post-acquisition struggles. Tesla investors, including Ross Gerber, are calling for a deputy to manage the company, citing Musk's multitasking and the potential impact on his role as CEO. Musk's focus on Twitter has led to a 50% drop in Tesla shares since April, adding to the pressure on the company amid growing challenges.

images.alt_text: An information security team at Twitter that oversees sharing of user data with advertisers and research partners was laid off after the takeover.

site_title: Binance CEO: Company expects to gain from industry growth; crypto world can learn from traditional finance sector
summary: Binance CEO Zhao Changpeng expects the company to benefit from industry growth, given its size and market share. He notes that the crypto space should adopt traditional financial practices to build trust and ensure transparency, particularly after FTX's bankruptcy. Zhao welcomes regulations to manage fraud but emphasizes their limitations. He also highlights the importance of education and technology, such as proof of reserves and Merkle trees, to become more transparent. Binance plans to grow the industry, with Zhao spending time talking to heads of states and regulators to expand its reach.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Changpeng Zhao, CEO of Binance, said that Binance is seeking to set up the recovery fund to assist otherwise strong projects that are facing a liquidity squeeze.

site_title: Budweiser maker buying back US$3.5b bonds to cut huge debt pile
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the Belgian brewer of Budweiser and Stella Artois, plans to spend up to $3.5 billion buying back dollar and pound denominated bonds to reduce its debt pile. The company aims to cut its debt, which stood at $76 billion as of June, amid soaring borrowing costs and a crunch from higher raw material costs. This move is part of Anheuser-Busch InBev's efforts to reduce its debt burden since its acquisition of SAB Miller in 2016.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cans of Budweiser beer are displayed amid others on a supermarket shelf in Shanghai, China February 24, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: India’s SBI sees 14%-15% corporate credit growth in FY23
summary: State Bank of India (SBI) expects corporate loans to grow at 14%-15% in FY23, driven by improved capacity utilisation and higher working capital. The bank has seen a 21% increase in corporate credit in the July-September quarter. This growth is attributed to a shift in demand from bond markets to bank loans, as well as a small extent, by the shift in demand from bond markets to bank loans. SBI Managing Director Swaminathan Janakiraman made the statement on November 16.

site_title: Trump's 2024 presidential bid a fresh wrinkle for markets
summary: Former US President Donald Trump announced his bid for the 2024 presidential election, confirming the "worst kept secret" among investors. Despite a disappointing midterm election showing for Republicans, Trump's entry into the race is unlikely to have a significant impact on markets, which are currently driven by macroeconomic concerns and Federal Reserve policy. Investors view Trump's candidacy as a low priority, and his potential presidency may even exacerbate divisions within the Republican party.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump on Tuesday vowed to prevent US President Joe Biden from being re-elected in 2024. Biden responded by saying the Republican “failed” his country while in office.

site_title: US dollar slips on easing tensions over Polish missile strike
summary: The US dollar slipped on Wednesday, November 16, as tensions over a missile strike on Poland eased, reversing a flight to the safe-haven greenback. The euro rose 0.67% to US$1.04205, closing in on a four-and-a-half month peak of US$1.0481. This increase was driven by below-expectations US producer price inflation data, which reinforced bets that US inflation is slowing, potentially allowing the Federal Reserve to slow rate hikes and easing pressure on the US dollar.

images.alt_text: US dollars and Euro bills are pictured on September 6, 2022 in Brest, western France. - The euro sunk below $0.99 on September 5, 2022 a 20-year-low, following the announcement the previous week that Russia would cut off gas deliveries to Germany via the Nord Stream pipeline. (Photo by FRED TANNEAU / AFP)

site_title: Progressive wages should promote productivity, career progression: MOM, SNEF
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower and the Singapore National Employers Federation emphasized the importance of progressive wages in promoting productivity and career progression. Senior Minister of State Zaqy Mohamad stated that businesses should focus on increasing employee productivity to justify higher costs, rather than solely relying on wage rises. The dialogue also addressed concerns over government support, administrative compliance, job redesign, and foreign labor, with tripartite partners agreeing to tackle these issues and find solutions to ensure the sustainability of progressive wages.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
The National Wages Council calls on employers to reward their staff with wage increases that are fair, in line with economic growth and the improvement in labour productivity.

ST20221101-202253546871-Lim Yaohui-pixgeneric/

Generic photograph of office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 1, 2022.

Can be used for stories on money, population, property, land, commercial, office, invest, budget, income, bank, finance, financial, CBD, URA, population, economy, and development.

(ST PHOTO: LIM YAOHUI)

Some 19,000 full-time retail workers will benefit from the retail progressive wage model, which aims to lift wages, enhance training and improve the productivity of full-time, lower-wage retail workers.

site_title: IMF’s Georgieva says Biden-Xi meeting ‘constructive’ signal for trade
summary: IMF Director Kristalina Georgieva described the Biden-Xi meeting as "very constructive" and a "strong call" for an end to Russia's war in Ukraine. The meeting may ease trade tensions between the US and China, and Georgieva warned that a fragmented world could reduce global GDP output by $1.4 trillion to $3.5 trillion. The IMF has called for increased international cooperation, predictability in debt restructuring, and calibrating interest rate hikes to avoid spillovers to other countries.

site_title: G20 breathes new life into UN climate talks
summary: The G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia, has breathed new life into UN climate talks in Egypt, with leaders pledging to pursue the most ambitious target of limiting global warming to 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels. The final communique also addresses the issue of loss and damage, urging parties to make progress on funding to help developing countries cope with climate change impacts. Analysts and campaigners welcomed the positive signals, while others criticized the statement for not amounting to significant progress.

images.alt_text: Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard (R) and US climate envoy John Kerry hold a press conference on the sidelines of the COP27 conference in Sharm el-Sheikh, on Nov 12, 2022.

site_title: Lula offers to host UN climate talks in Brazil’s Amazon
summary: Brazil's President-elect Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva has pledged to host future UN climate talks in the Amazon rainforest, aiming to make Brazil the host of COP30 in 2025. Lula, a leftist who won his third term in office, seeks to restore environmental policies that were eroded under his predecessor, Jair Bolsonaro. He aims to put the venue in the Amazon rainforest, rather than the more populous coastal region, to engage with those defending the Amazon and the climate. This move is seen as a positive step for international climate talks, which Lula has energized with his first international visit since being elected.

images.alt_text: Climate activists demonstrate calling upon the G20 conference to adhere to limit global temperature rise to 1.5 degrees Celsius compared to pre-industrial levels, at the Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city of the same name, during the COP27 climate conference, on November 16, 2022. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)

Every island in the Maldives – freshwater (and) lands have been depleted and contaminated by saltwater intrusion, said Maldives' environment minister Aminath Shauna, at the COP27 climate meeting in Egypt.
Enshrined in the Paris Agreement is the goal to limit global warming to well below 2.0 deg C from pre-industrial levels, and preferably the safer ambition of 1.5 deg C.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the role of digital innovations in boosting trade and financial inclusion during the G20 Summit in Bali. OCBC Bank introduced fixed deposit placements for CPF ordinary account savings at 3.4% per annum. Meanwhile, APEC leaders in Bangkok will discuss ways to accelerate the global economy's recovery, amid low expectations due to the global geopolitical climate.

site_title: Japan’s Kishida hopes meeting Xi will help build stable relations
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida hopes a meeting with Chinese leader Xi Jinping will lead to a "constructive and stable relationship" between the two countries. The meeting is scheduled on the sidelines of an Asia-Pacific summit in Bangkok, following the recent US-China summit aimed at thawing tensions between the world's two largest economies. Kishida acknowledged "various opportunities and challenges" in Japan-China relations, expressing his desire for a more stable partnership.

site_title: Global connections are evolving, not retreating
summary: Global connections are evolving, not retreating, despite disruptions to global supply chains. The world is more connected than ever, with the fastest-growing types of global flows relating to the digital revolution, knowledge, and know-how. Data flows grew at nearly 50% annually, and Singapore is well-positioned to capitalize on these trends. However, there are risks associated with interdependency, particularly where products are concentrated in their origins. To manage these risks, companies and governments must harness the benefits of connection while diversifying and finding new growth opportunities.

images.alt_text: Big changes are afoot in world trade, none of which need imply widespread deglobalisation.

site_title: Chinese authorities call on retired soldiers to help Foxconn iPhone plant
summary: Chinese authorities in Henan province are urging retired soldiers and government workers to take stints at Foxconn's iPhone factory in Zhengzhou, amid discontent over government-mandated Covid-19 measures. The calls come after the plant's production is expected to slump by up to 30% in November due to worker departures. Retired workers will receive their current salary, wages, and bonuses from the factory, with additional bonuses of up to 3,000 yuan. Foxconn declined to comment on the hiring schemes and manufacturing status, with Apple last week lowering its forecast for iPhone 14 shipments.

site_title: Record inflation spells trouble for banks, governments: European Central Bank
summary: The European Central Bank warned of rising stability risks for lenders, governments, and households due to record inflation and worsening economic growth prospects. The cost-of-living squeeze is hurting debt servicing, while corporate profits are threatened. The bank expects potential dangers to public finances, downward pressure on equities, and peaking house prices. To combat inflation, the ECB has embarked on its most aggressive interest-rate increase cycle, with further hikes expected. Risks to financial stability have increased, and officials express concern about potential problems in derivatives markets and higher bad loans for banks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The European Central Bank (ECB) logo in Frankfurt, Germany, January 23, 2020. REUTERS/Ralph Orlowski/File Photo

site_title: Tech bubble bursting exposes unsustainable business models
summary: A tech bubble is bursting, exposing unsustainable business models and questionable investments. Venture capital poured $30 billion into the crypto and Web3 space, but companies with flawed governance and lack of business fundamentals are collapsing. Examples include FTX, Grab, GoTo, and Sea, which have seen significant declines in valuation and are laying off employees. The correction highlights the importance of sound business fundamentals and corporate governance, and the painful process will weed out bad companies, potentially paving the way for long-term growth.

images.alt_text: Sea’s e-commerce arm Shopee is axing more employees as its parent company Sea faces pressure to turn profitable.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 2.16 points to 1,448.38. 2.319 billion lots worth RM1.712 billion changed hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 493 to 351.

images.alt_text: Traders monitor electronic boards showing stock movements at a private stock exchange in Kuala Lumpur on February 24, 2020. - Malaysian politics were in turmoil on February 24 after leader-in-waiting Anwar Ibrahim denounced a "betrayal" by coalition partners he said were trying to bring down the government, two years after it stormed to victory. (Photo by Mohd RASFAN / AFP)

site_title: Indonesian regulator gives banks green light to invest in fintech
summary: Indonesia's financial regulator has given banks the green light to invest in fintech companies, with a maximum limit of 35% of their capital. The new regulation, effective immediately, also requires banks to establish a formal risk management procedure. This move aims to balance capital injections with risk management to ensure the banks' sustainability. The decision comes as Indonesia's fintech sector continues to grow, with outstanding loans from fintechs reaching 48.73 trillion rupiah (S$4.3 billion) as of September, a 77% increase from the same period last year.

site_title: America deserves better than Donald Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump has announced his candidacy for the 2024 presidential election, sparking concerns about the integrity of American democracy. Trump's supporters stormed the US Capitol Building in 2021, and his refusal to accept election results has become a defining feature of his movement. Critics argue that Trump is unfit for public office due to his incompetence, self-dealing, and willingness to resort to violence. To counter his candidacy, lawmakers must pass a bill overhauling the Electoral Count Act and Republicans must reclaim their party's commitment to the rule of law.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A mob of supporters of U.S. President Donald Trump fight with members of law enforcement at a door they broke open as they storm the U.S. Capitol Building in Washington, U.S., January 6, 2021. REUTERS/Leah Millis/File Photo

site_title: Micron launches mass output of advanced chip in Japan
summary: Micron Technology has launched mass production of its high-capacity low-power 1-beta dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips in Japan, marking a significant milestone in the country's efforts to revive its semiconductor industry. The production comes as Japan seeks to strengthen its semiconductor supply chains with the US, amid growing trade friction between the US and China. The move is seen as a key step in bolstering national security and reducing reliance on China. The ceremony was attended by US Ambassador Rahm Emanuel and Japanese officials, highlighting the growing political importance of semiconductors.

site_title: G20 pledges to calibrate pace of interest rate hikes, limit spillovers
summary: G20 leaders pledged to calibrate interest rate hikes to limit spillovers, ensuring monetary policy tightening is data-dependent and clearly communicated. They also reaffirmed their commitment to avoiding excessive exchange-rate volatility and limiting global temperature rise to 1.5°C, requiring meaningful and effective climate actions from all countries. Additionally, the leaders recognized the need to accelerate efforts towards phasing down unabated coal power and supporting just transitions.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is in Bali for the G20 Summit.
Indonesia, home to the world’s third-largest rainforest, pledges to be carbon-neutral by 2050, 10 years earlier than previously planned, and to almost double its renewable energy generation by 2030.

site_title: Siemens Energy scraps dividend due to wind division turmoil
summary: Siemens Energy is scrapping its dividend due to a widening net loss of 647 million euros, largely attributed to its struggling wind turbine division Siemens Gamesa. The company owns 67% of Siemens Gamesa and has launched a 4.05-billion-euro bid to buy the remaining shares, aiming to integrate the division and fix quality issues. This move comes as Siemens Gamesa faces quality issues with its next-generation turbine model.

images.alt_text: The surge in power prices, along with threats to supply, is affecting businesses from China to Germany to the US. It jacks up costs and threatens margins, while also sucking money out of their customers’ pockets, destroying demand.
The loss meant Siemens had to cut its full year earnings per share guidance to 5.33 to 5.73 euros per share, from 8.70 to 9.10 euros previously.

site_title: Barclays cuts 2023 global growth forecast, expects weakest growth in four decades
summary: Barclays has cut its global economic growth forecast for 2023 to 1.7% due to inflation unlikely to fall quickly, forcing monetary policy to be restrictive. The brokerage expects advanced economies to enter a recession, with the US and Euro area likely to contract in the third and fourth quarters of 2022, respectively. The UK is expected to enter recession in the third quarter of 2022. Despite this, Barclays forecasts 3.8% growth for China and over 5% growth for India in 2023.

images.alt_text: C S Venkatakrishnan, CEO of Barclays, says: “We aim to hire more than 1,000 more people in coming weeks to improve that capacity.”

site_title: China advisers say they’ll recommend modest growth target for 2023
summary: China's government advisers have drafted recommendations for next year's annual economic growth targets, ranging from 4.5% to 5.5%. This marks a modest pickup from this year's growth, which was depressed by Covid-19 and other challenges. The Central Economic Work Conference in December is expected to prioritize stimulus over reform, aiming to jump-start growth in the world's second-largest economy. The conference will chart the policy course, including economic targets, to address a slumping property market and slowing global growth. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Chinese national flag is pictured, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China, October 14, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: NTUC calls for more support for platform workers if CPF is introduced
summary: The National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) is calling for greater support for platform workers in Singapore, particularly if the country implements Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions for this group. NTUC notes that platform workers generally have modest incomes and insufficient savings, and urges for adequate support during the transition period and long-term financial assistance. The labour movement also calls for better injury coverage, union representation, and fair structures to protect the livelihoods of platform workers.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

peekture - left to right: Michelle Low, deputy news editor of The Business Times; Executive Director of Singapore National Employers Federation, Mr Sim Gim
Guan; Senior Minister of State for Manpower Koh Poh Koon; committee chairperson Goh Swee Chen; committee vice-chairperson Prof Danny Quah and Yeo Wan Ling, Advisor to National Taxi Association and National Private Hire Vehicles Association

Credit to MINISTRY OF MANPOWER

site_title: Purpose at the core of doing good
summary: OCBC Bank has launched several initiatives under its #OCBCCares programme, including the OCBC Arboretum at the Singapore Botanic Gardens and a food delivery programme, Masak Lah!, which empowers women from low-income households to prepare meals for other families in need. The bank also provides a stipend and financial support for the women, who have set up their own catering services. Additionally, OCBC has a #OCBCCares Environment Fund, which has disbursed over $300,000 to support 18 sustainability projects. The bank was named a Champion of Good by the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre for its efforts to support the community and tackle climate change.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

msnvpc12 - P&G Pro Bono School on Sales, 2019.



Credit: Empact

site_title: Sunak-Xi meeting at G20 cancelled: Downing Street
summary: Britain's Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and Chinese President Xi Jinping's planned meeting at the G20 summit has been cancelled due to scheduling issues, according to Downing Street. The meeting, initially announced on Tuesday, would have been the first between the two leaders in nearly five years. China stated it had no information to share, while Downing Street cited scheduling issues as the reason for the cancellation.

images.alt_text: Hands notes that Britain and Taiwan are both centres for global technology, and  the “flourishing” island is a “vital partner” for the UK as it seeks new trade in the Pacific after Brexit.

site_title: OCBC appoints bank veteran Noel Gerald DCruz as group chief risk officer effective Jan 1
summary: OCBC appoints 33-year veteran Noel Gerald DCruz as group chief risk officer (CRO) effective January 1, 2023. Current CRO Vincent Choo will remain as an adviser. DCruz has led the bank's credit risk management structure reorganisation and has been acting CRO in Choo's absence. OCBC's CEO Helen Wong praises DCruz's talent and experience, stating the promotion reflects the bank's strong talent pool.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan

OCBC's head of global commercial banking Linus Goh said the bank is seeing some “good momentum” in the take-up of sustainable financing from SMEs, signalling a growing adoption of sustainability into business strategies and operations beyond mere awareness.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall amid mixed regional showing; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% on Wednesday, closing at 3,266.17, amid mixed regional performance. US stocks tumbled overnight due to reports of a Russian missile crossing into Poland, with US officials suggesting it was fired by Ukrainian forces. In the broader market, gainers beat losers 292 to 271, with ST Engineering being the strongest performer, gaining 2.3%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also declined.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

ST Engineering says TransCore will replace the existing tolling infrastructure with its own flagship toll collection system that integrates automatic vehicle identification and vehicle classification.

site_title: Tencent to distribute US$20b Meituan stake as dividends; posts Q2 revenue fall
summary: Tencent is distributing over 958 million Class B shares in Meituan as a special dividend to existing shareholders, valued at approximately $19.9 billion, as part of its efforts to reduce its extensive holdings and shift focus to gaming and social media operations. The move follows a Q2 revenue fall of 2% and comes as China's internet industry adapts to a new era of sedate growth, with regulators easing up on their campaign against tech. Tencent's exit from Meituan marks another milestone in its evolution as a more focused and cost-conscious company.

images.alt_text: China Unicom said the joint venture was formed to fulfil the company’s “strategic need to comprehensively foray into the digital economy”.

site_title: UK housing market is getting desperate once again
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a downturn, with buyer cancellations and weekly sales per site down, according to Persimmon and other industry reports. House prices are expected to fall, with the RICS survey showing a record drop in house price rises. Falling mortgage approvals and increasing interest rates are contributing to the decline. Sellers are also cutting prices, with around 7% of houses on the market seeing a 5% price cut. Experts warn that the current market conditions are not as favorable as those in the past, with mortgage rates unlikely to drop as much as they did in previous crises.

images.alt_text: The surge in overseas interest offers some respite for London’s prime housing market.

site_title: Warm start to winter leaves more gas next year for Europe: Goldman Sachs
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts Europe's gas inventories will be near 30% full at the end of March, exceeding initial expectations due to mild winter weather and weak Chinese LNG imports. This provides more room for Europe to rebuild gas inventories during the summer for the next winter, easing concerns about a potential energy crisis. Goldman Sachs has also cut its European natural gas price forecast for summer to 180 euros per megawatt hour, down from a previous outlook.

images.alt_text: S&P Global’s final composite Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) for the eurozone, regarded as a good guide to economic health, fell to a 23-month low of 47.3 in October.
High imports of liquefied natural gas means even more fuel is being injected into brimming storage sites.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall for third straight session as financials drag
summary: Australian shares fell for a third straight session, dragged by declines in financials amid global equities weakness. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.3% lower at 7,122.20, amid fears of heightened geopolitical tensions following a Russian-made missile strike in Poland. Financial stocks fell 1%, while mining stocks rose 0.8% on iron ore gains. The benchmark has lost 0.5% so far this week, with market participants exercising caution due to concerns of an approaching economic downturn.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ends 0.1 per cent lower at 7,141.6.

site_title: China’s bond selloff resumes with yield rising to one-year high
summary: China's 10-year government bond yield rose to 2.8525%, its highest since December, amid improving economic outlook. Demand for haven assets declined as China's Covid policies eased and property sector support measures fueled optimism. Rising interbank rates also weighed on the debt market, prompting stop-loss selling and liquidation of bonds. The People's Bank of China injected over 1 trillion yuan of cash into the financial system to calm concerns. Experts expect upward trend in yields, with the impact of support measures expected to be lasting beyond short-term risk sentiment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of a giant display of stock indexes, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China October 24, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Binance chief Zhao says much interest in crypto recovery fund
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao announced plans to set up a crypto industry recovery fund to assist strong projects facing liquidity squeezes. This move comes as the crypto market continues to recover from the FTX exchange collapse. Zhao also secured another licence in Abu Dhabi, marking the latest development in Binance's expansion efforts. Investor interest in the recovery fund is reportedly high, indicating a potential boost for the struggling crypto sector.

site_title: Petronas interested to join Abadi LNG project: Indonesian regulator
summary: Malaysian state oil and gas company Petronas has expressed interest to participate in Indonesia's takeover of Shell's 35% stake in the Abadi liquefied natural gas (LNG) project. The Indonesian government, in collaboration with state-owned energy firm Pertamina and the Indonesia Investment Authority, will acquire Shell's stake. Petronas chairman Dwi Soetjipto stated that the company is interested to join the consortium and work with Pertamina to replace Shell. This move aims to secure Indonesia's energy interests and potentially strengthen regional energy ties.

images.alt_text: A total of four wells are expected to be drilled in Block 2K and four other ultra-deepwater blocks off the coast of Sabah in 2022 and 2023.
Petronas CEO Tengku Taufik said Petronas would continue its efforts to offset any impact on Japanese customers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall after three-day surge
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.47% to 18,256.48 after a three-day surge, amid concerns over a deadly missile strike in Poland and investor spookedness. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined. The losses come after a significant rally in the previous three trading days.

site_title: Liftoff! Nasa successfully launches mega moon rocket
summary: NASA successfully launched the most powerful rocket ever built, the Space Launch System (SLS), on its journey to the moon. The uncrewed Orion spacecraft, attached to the rocket, will test propulsion, navigation, and power systems before completing one-and-a-half orbits around the moon. The mission, part of NASA's Artemis program, aims to establish a sustained presence on the lunar surface, potentially sending the first woman and non-white person to the moon by the mid-2020s.

images.alt_text: SpaceX dominates the market for commercial space launch.

site_title: Zurich Insurance sets more ambitious financial targets
summary: Zurich Insurance Group has set more ambitious financial targets for the next three years, aiming to raise its business operating profit after tax return on equity (BOPAT ROE) to above 20% by 2025 and generate compound organic growth in earnings per share of 8% per year. The targets are higher than previous ones and reflect the benefits of the new IFRS 17 accounting standard. Zurich also aims for cumulative cash remittances in excess of $13.5 billion and a Swiss Solvency Test ratio of at least 160%.

images.alt_text: Integrated shield plans remain a priority health insurance product, says Life Insurance Association, Singapore.

site_title: China banks face 1.5t yuan in losses from property, UBS says
summary: China's banking system faces estimated losses of up to 1.5 trillion yuan ($291 billion) due to the country's property slump. Despite this, experts believe the banking system can absorb the losses due to strong earnings and high reserves. Chinese authorities have rolled out a 16-point plan to support the embattled sector, which includes measures to address liquidity issues and loosen down-payment requirements. The Swiss bank UBS expects a low rate recovery on unsecured loans and bonds, but warns that stalled property projects could lead to further losses for banks.

images.alt_text: The existing-home market fared worse, down 0.47 per cent, the steepest decline since 2014.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index ends higher
summary: The Nikkei 225 index in Tokyo ended higher, up 0.14% or 38.13 points, at 28,028.30, following a statement from the US saying it was "unlikely" a missile that hit Poland was fired from Russia. This reassured investors, contributing to the rebound. The broader Topix index edged down 0.05%.

site_title: Japanese chipmaker Rohm mulls joining consortium for Toshiba buyout
summary: Japanese chipmaker Rohm is considering joining a consortium led by Japan Industrial Partners (JIP) to buy out Toshiba in a 2.2-trillion-yen acquisition. Rohm plans to invest up to 300 billion yen, with the consortium also including Suzuki Motor, Chubu Electric Power, and Taisei. The deal would see over 10 Japanese companies invest a total of one trillion yen, with the rest financed by banks and others holding no voting rights. The acquisition is aimed at consolidating JIP's proposal and maintaining Japan's strength in the power management chip industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Toshiba Corp. is seen at the company's facility in Kawasaki, Japan February 13, 2017.  REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: UK inflation hits 41-year high of 11.1% as Hunt readies budget
summary: UK inflation surged to a 41-year high of 11.1% in October, the highest reading since 1981, driven by surging household energy bills and food prices. This marks a significant jump from 10.1% in September, exceeding economists' forecasts of 10.7%. The data comes ahead of Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt's budget announcement, which is expected to include tax hikes and spending cuts to control price growth. The UK economy has also contracted for the second month in a row, adding to the economic challenges facing the country.

images.alt_text: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt is set to announce tax hikes and spending cuts in the UK budget on Thursday (Nov 17).
Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt walks outside his house in London, Britain, October 18, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville

site_title: Shell, Chinese partner to drop off-shore wind farm project in France
summary: Shell and Chinese energy company CGN dropped plans for a floating wind power project off France's Brittany coast due to inflation, supply chain problems, and increasing costs. The project, co-financed by a regional public investment bank, was intended for the island of Belle-Ile. The companies cited "technical, commercial and financial challenges" in their joint statement, citing strong constraints in terms of inflation and supply chain issues.

site_title: Foreign visitors in Japan surge after tourism reopening
summary: Foreign visitors to Japan surged to 498,600 in October, more than doubling from September and surging 2,155% from the previous year, as the country fully reopened to overseas visitors after two years of Covid restrictions. This marks the first month of significant tourism after Japan ended its strict border controls. Despite a record 1.52 million foreign visitors this year, the government's goal of 40 million in 2020 remains unmet, and major gains may be difficult until Chinese tourists return.

site_title: Toyota unveils new Prius, betting hybrids will stick around
summary: Toyota has unveiled the new Prius, its fifth generation, which boasts bigger wheels and a sportier design. The car offers three hybrid powertrain options and will go on sale starting this winter, with pricing expected to be "affordable for everybody." Toyota is betting on the longevity of hybrids despite Tesla and other electric vehicle manufacturers claiming the era of electric vehicles has arrived.

images.alt_text: Car giants such as Ford Motor and Toyota Motor say the government should loosen the terms of the US$430 billion Inflation Reduction Act to allow manufacturers to source EV components from more places.

site_title: Outlook 2023: Asia’s rapid disinflation and growth outperformance
summary: Asia's inflation trajectory is less intense than other regions, with growth expected to rebound to 5% by 2023.
