The region's rapid disinflation will be driven by fading cost-push inflation, deflation in goods demand, and below-average wage growth. Most Asian central banks are expected to end their rate-hike cycles by mid-2023, with China's reopening from the spring of 2023 boosting growth expectations. Despite external risks, Asia's domestic demand is supported by reopening and easing financial conditions, with growth expected to outperform globally.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: People walk along Nanjing Pedestrian Road, a main shopping area, in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Thai government spending to target low-income groups
summary: Thailand's Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith announced that the government's economic stimulus policies will focus on low-income households, with growth expected to reach 3.4% this year and 3.8% in 2023. Despite global headwinds, tourist arrivals are expected to reach 10 million this year. The central bank expects the economy to reach pre-pandemic levels by the end of this year or early next year, with inflation expected to be moderate.

images.alt_text: Thailand is seeking to lure more foreign visitors in the post-Covid period by promoting itself as a world-class destination for medical treatment.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades Sea to ‘add’ as losses narrow
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded its call on Sea Ltd to "add" from "hold" due to the narrowing of losses in its gaming and e-commerce segments. The group's Q3 losses came in narrower than forecasted, driven by a significant reduction in losses at Shopee and SeaMoney. The brokerage lifts its target price on the stock to US$75, citing a higher FY2023 price-to-sales ratio for the e-commerce segment. However, Sea's gaming segment remains a weak spot, with lower guided bookings and a 26% quarter-on-quarter decline in Q4 at the mid-point.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Sea is now dealing with an economic slowdown and surging inflation, as well as intensifying competition and a broader tech selloff.
Sea’s e-commerce arm Shopee is axing more employees as its parent company Sea faces pressure to turn profitable.
Shopee’s parent company, Sea, has taken massive cost-cutting steps in recent months as it battles increasingly uncertain macroeconomic conditions.
Sea's e-commerce arm, Shopee was one of the bright spots in its results, reporting an improved adjusted Ebitda loss per order for Q2 2022.

Shopee chief executive Chris Feng wrote to employees that “in light of the current elevated macro uncertainty,” the company needed to “focus resources on core operations” and had decided to concentrate on a cross-border model in Mexico, Colombia and Chile.

A spokesperson for Sea told Reuters the company had “made some changes to improve efficiency in our operations that impact a number of roles”, saying it would focus on the “long-term strength of our ecosystem”.

site_title: Polish president says missile that killed two was probably Ukrainian air defence
summary: Poland's President Andrzej Duda says a missile that killed two people was likely fired by Ukrainian air defense, not Russia. The S-300 rocket, made in the Soviet Union, was found with elements of a Ukrainian missile. The US and NATO also suspect it was a stray Ukrainian missile, easing concerns of a wider conflict. Poland may not need to activate Article 4 of the NATO treaty, and the incident's cause is now widely believed to be a Ukrainian air defense system.

site_title: A Sino-American détente? Don’t hold your breath
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping held a three-hour meeting in Bali, Indonesia, on November 14, 2022, sparking hopes for a Sino-American détente. Despite rising tensions, Biden insisted that there didn't need to be a new Cold War, and emphasized the need for peaceful competition. The meeting was seen as a positive development, with both leaders projecting a friendlier tone. However, the Republican-controlled House of Representatives is likely to pressure Biden to take a tougher stance on China, particularly regarding Taiwan, which could undermine efforts to mend the relationship.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and his delegation (left) face ) China's President Xi Jinping and his team on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Monday (Nov 14).

Even from the point of view of national security, “an economically interdependent world and an economically interdependent US and China is also in national security’s interest”, said Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam (centre).

site_title: Europe: Stocks struggle at open
summary: European stocks opened with losses, with London's FTSE 100 index advancing 0.1% to 7,378.54 points, while the Paris CAC 40 and Frankfurt's DAX indexes flatlined and dropped 0.2%, respectively. Investors were spooked by a deadly missile strike in Poland near the Ukraine border, despite a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks. UK inflation spiked to a 41-year peak of 11.1% in October, weighing on the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man shelters under an umbrella as he walks past the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain, August 24, 2015. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett/File Photo

site_title: Apec leaders in Bangkok to discuss ways to accelerate recovery of global economy
summary: APEC leaders are set to meet in Bangkok on Nov 18, focusing on accelerating the global economy's recovery through balanced growth, trade, and investment. The summit, the first in-person meeting since 2018, will address pressing regional concerns such as food and energy security, supply chain disruptions, and reopening borders. However, expectations for significant progress are low due to the divisive global geopolitical climate, with US President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin absent. The leaders will discuss innovative approaches like the Bio-Circular-Green Economy Model, which has been endorsed by Thailand as a national agenda.

images.alt_text: Protesters in tuk tuks take part in a convoy against Thai prime minister and Thailand’s hosting of APEC 2022 in front of Democracy Monument in Bangkok on November 15, 2022. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Use digital innovations to boost trade, enhance financial inclusion, PM Lee tells G20 leaders
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the role of digital innovations in boosting trade and enhancing financial inclusion during the G20 Summit in Bali. He highlighted opportunities for "win-win international cooperation" in digital transformation, citing the need for improved interoperability of cross-border rules and data frameworks. This, he said, would facilitate easier business operations and help achieve the world's sustainable development goals.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov arrives at the G20 dinner in Bali on Nov 15, 2022. He was welcomed by Indonesia's Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) was welcomed by Indonesian President Joko Widodo at the start of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua, Bali on Nov 15, 2022.

site_title: Mercedes slashes China EV prices by up to US$33,000 as sales lag
summary: Mercedes-Benz has slashed prices on two electric car models in China by up to $33,000, citing disappointing sales. The luxury automaker reduced prices on the EQE and EQS models, effective immediately, to boost sales in the country's largest EV market. The moves come as foreign brands, including Tesla, struggle to compete with local automakers like BYD, which sold nearly 220,000 EVs in October. Mercedes' sales have been disappointing, with deliveries dropping to as low as 100 cars per month, prompting the company to reposition its models in the market.

images.alt_text: Mercedes-Benz Russia said shares in the local subsidiaries would be sold to car dealer chain Avtodom.

site_title: Helping Vietnam’s solar players improve quality, not just speed of growth
summary: Singapore-based Advanced Vision Analytics (AVA) is helping Vietnam's solar players improve the quality of their solar panels by using drone technology and data analytics to detect defects and optimize performance. The company's chief executive, Lee Wei Yik, notes that Vietnam's solar industry prioritizes speed over quality, but AVA's solutions can address this issue. The Vietnam segment now accounts for more than half of AVA's revenue, driven by the country's fast-evolving renewable energy market. By innovating and developing new solutions, AVA aims to stay ahead of the competition and serve a wide range of clients in Vietnam and other Southeast Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

site_title: South Korea: Shares end lower on geopolitical worries
summary: South Korea's Kospi index fell 2.88 points or 0.1% to close at 2,477.45 on November 16, amid geopolitical worries. The benchmark index initially dropped 1.4% before recovering on a report that a missile explosion in Poland was likely fired by Ukraine, not Russia. Technology giant Samsung Electronics rose 0.5%, while peer SK Hynix slipped 0.1%. The market ended with a marginal change after two sessions of reduced volatility.

site_title: Americans cash in strong dollars to scoop up luxury London homes
summary: US buyers are capitalizing on the weak pound to purchase luxury London homes, with Charles McDowell Properties reporting six sales to American clients in the last six months. The surge in overseas interest offers relief for London's prime housing market, which saw a 38% increase in bids for top-end properties. Americans now account for 14.5% of all overseas prime London property purchases, up from 6.2% in the previous six months, and are driving the market in the £5 million or more bracket.

images.alt_text: The more favourable exchange rate has pushed buyers from Singapore to invest further in prime central London properties.

site_title: South Korean apartment prices drop at steepest pace in two decades
summary: South Korea's apartment prices dropped 1.20% in October, the steepest decline in at least 19 years, due to rising mortgage rates and a souring demand. The national index for apartment transaction prices fell 7.13% in the first nine months of the year, on track for the biggest annual decline since 2006. The Bank of Korea is expected to slow its interest rate hikes, with analysts predicting only one or two more hikes this year and next. The decline in housing prices is seen as a sign of an economic slowdown, with household debt-to-GDP ratios at a record 102.2%.

images.alt_text: The nation’s housing market has continued dropping in recent weeks after the worst monthly decline since the global financial crisis in August.

site_title: Renewables not enough? Cut demand to meet net zero, says energy management specialist
summary: Vietnam's green energy transition is being slowed down by supply-side factors, prompting renewable energy players to focus on demand-side measures to meet net zero targets. Energy management specialist Hoe Boon Chye of Barghest Building Performance suggests that energy efficiency is key to reducing overall demand, with companies typically needing to buy carbon credits to meet remaining targets. BBP's solution helps optimize cooling system settings to save up to 40% of energy costs for clients, with annual savings ranging from $100,000 to $5 million. The company aims to tap Vietnam's growing industrialization and expand its business in the country.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Despite Vietnam’s exponential pace in solar capacity building in the last four years, the country’s transition to using clean energy has taken place much more slowly.

The AVA team met their client Dinh Van Thang, site manager of Phuoc Minh Adani Solar (second from right), at a solar plant in Ninh Thuan, Vietnam in April. From left to right is AVA solution architect Yip Chok Meng, CEO Lee Wei Yik and technical manager Theodore Teo.
Food makes friends, said food distributor L'earth Vietnam's co-founder and director Teri Teo, as he explained his passion in introducing more Singapore F&B brands to Vietnam.

The Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park's (VSIP) decision to not exit despite the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis likely helped  co-developer SembCorp Development to "score points" and gain trust from its Vietnamese partners, VSIP co-chair Kelvin Teo said.
Industry watchers said companies used to a more structured and predictable way of doing business, like the way it is in Singapore, would also be in for a culture shock.
Now that international borders have reopened, more Singapore companies are heading to Vietnam in search of business opportunities, industry watchers told The Business Times.

site_title: ‘So much worse this time’: FTX wreck a bitter pill for long-time crypto investors
summary: FTX, one of the world's largest crypto exchanges, has filed for bankruptcy after a stunning downfall in a matter of days. The collapse has left thousands of investors, including Singaporeans, with billions of dollars in assets stuck on the platform. FTX's founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, had lent billions of dollars in customer funds to its affiliate trading firm, Alameda Research, to bankroll risky bets. The incident has highlighted the complexity and opaqueness of crypto exchanges, and regulators are calling for tougher measures to safeguard customer interests.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
The cruel irony of FTX’s collapse is that some investors had parked their holdings there because they perceived it as a relatively safe option.
International coordination and cooperation on the regulatory front could motivate the larger crypto players to behave better and deter some unscrupulous activity.

site_title: Indonesia proposes to Canada setting up Opec-like group for nickel
summary: Indonesia has proposed establishing an Opec-like group for nickel-producing countries, including Canada, to optimize the global nickel supply chain and counter protectionist trade policies. The proposal aims to attract investment in metal processing and EV battery production. Indonesia has been utilizing its nickel reserves since 2020, when it banned exports of unprocessed nickel ore, sparking a trade dispute with the European Union. The proposal is seen as a way to ensure a stable and sustainable supply of nickel for the electric vehicle industry.

images.alt_text: The Canadian government ordered the divestiture after “rigorous scrutiny” of foreign firms by Canada’s National Security and Intelligence Community, Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said in a statement.
Earlier this year, CATL announced a US$6 billion power battery project in Indonesia, in partnership with Indonesian companies.
Indonesia, home to the world’s third-largest rainforest, pledges to be carbon-neutral by 2050, 10 years earlier than previously planned, and to almost double its renewable energy generation by 2030.

site_title: Asia: Stocks swing as Ukraine fears offset inflation hopes
summary: Asian stocks fluctuated on Wednesday, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Wellington, and Taipei slightly higher, while Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Manila, and Jakarta dipped. A positive US inflation report and China's support for its struggling property sector initially boosted markets, but concerns over Ukraine and a reported Russian-made missile strike in Poland offset the gains. The news sparked fears of a potential escalation of the nine-month war, but US President Biden's comments eased concern, and markets defered to a wartime mistake.

images.alt_text: The flags of China, right, and the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR) fly near an electronic screen displaying the Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong, China, on Tuesday, March 15, 2022. Chinese stocks suffered another deep selloff on Tuesday as concerns about the country’s ties with Russia and persistent regulatory pressure sent shares on a downward spiral. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

site_title: Biden says ‘Trump failed America’ after ex-president announces will run again
summary: US President Joe Biden responded to Donald Trump's announcement of another presidential run by saying "Donald Trump failed America." A video compilation was released, highlighting Trump's actions during his presidency, including rigging the economy, attacking healthcare and women's rights, and inciting violence. Biden made the statement while attending the G20 summit in Bali, and was met with a brief glance from French President Emmanuel Macron, who remained silent.

site_title: Falconers hope to draw World Cup fans to Qatar heritage
summary: Falconers in Qatar are hosting junior falconry competitions ahead of the World Cup to showcase their heritage and preserve the traditional practice. Young contestants, aged 8-18, are participating in the competitions, which involve training and hunting with their falcons. The event aims to introduce visitors to this ancient tradition, which has been passed down through generations. The "Little Falconers" are dressed in traditional white robes, and their falcons are trained to hunt in a controlled environment, highlighting the skill and patience required for this ancient practice.

images.alt_text: Qatar wants to use the World Cup to showcase its rapid expansion from a small pearl-diving enclave to Gulf metropolis and expects it to add as much as US$17 billion to its economy.

site_title: Silicon Valley VC close to investing in Singapore water startup
summary: DCVC, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm, is close to investing in a Singaporean water startup that uses novel technology to produce water out of air. Managing Partner Zachary Bogue declined to name the startup due to the deal's unfinalized status. This investment aligns with DCVC's focus on climate technology and follows their co-investment in climate tech startups such as Pivot Bio and Samsara Eco. The investment will support the development of sustainable water production methods, furthering DCVC's commitment to climate-specific funding.

site_title: Japan’s Sept core machinery orders fall 4.6% m-o-m
summary: Japan's core machinery orders fell 4.6% in September from the previous month, lower than the 0.7% expected by economists. However, compared to a year earlier, core orders grew 2.9%, indicating a slight improvement. The government reduced its assessment of machinery orders, citing a stalling pickup movement, which may signal a slower economic recovery.

site_title: Is ethical AI no longer important?
summary: Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter has led to the elimination of the company's AI ethics team, sparking concerns about the future of responsible AI practices. Despite this, experts argue that ethics do matter in AI, citing the need for governance, standardization, and accountability to prevent harm. Governments and companies are taking steps to address AI ethics, such as the US White House's AI Bill of Rights and Singapore's AI governance framework. Establishing a solid ethical framework, using tools like ethical checklists, and promoting transparency and accountability are crucial to ensuring responsible AI practices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk's photo is seen through a Twitter logo in this illustration taken October 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The Biden administration’s move comes at a time when the EU is moving towards regulating high-risk systems while the US has not come close to a comprehensive law to regulate AI.
A focus on the more dire consequences of AI threats can sometimes distract from the more mundane, though no less risky, dangers.

site_title: Australia economy set to slow amid downside risks: IMF
summary: Australia's economy is forecast to slow to 1.7% in 2023/2024 due to higher interest rates, persistent inflation, and weakening export demand, according to the IMF. The agency recommends continued monetary and fiscal policy tightening to contain inflation. The Reserve Bank of Australia has already raised rates to a nine-year high of 2.85%, and more is needed. The IMF also advises against major cost of living support and suggests a shift towards indirect taxation, infrastructure spending, and boosting housing supply. An economy-wide carbon price is seen as the most effective way to achieve emission reductions.

site_title: Fierce peso defence shows 1997 crisis still haunting Philippines
summary: The Philippines' peso has rebounded 3% to 57.21 from its record-low of 59 per dollar in late September, amid aggressive intervention by the central bank to stem currency declines. Authorities are concerned that a weaker peso could fuel inflation and social unrest, echoing the lessons of the 1997 Asian financial crisis. The central bank has spent $8 billion of its foreign-exchange reserves and raised benchmark interest rates to prevent a currency collapse, with forecasts predicting a potential slump of 8% to 62 by June.

images.alt_text: The tax measure, which needs to be approved by the Senate before a reconciled Bill is sent to President Marcos for signature, is expected to raise to raise 9.3 billion pesos in revenues annually.
“The BSP is committed to bringing inflation back to within target range over the medium term,” governor Felipe Medalla said.
The Philippines remains among Asia’s bright spots, as rising borrowing costs and a cost-of-living crisis dim the global economic outlook.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks edge down at Wednesday’s open
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, with the Nikkei 225 index down 0.04% and the Topix index down 0.10%, amid geopolitical risks linked to the war in Ukraine. This curbs the recent rallies on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS raises Yangzijiang Shipbuilding target price on ESG advances
summary: DBS Group Research has raised its target price for Yangzijiang Shipbuilding to S$1.70 from S$1.40, citing the company's record order book value and ESG transformation into the clean vessel space. Analyst Ho Pei Hwa expects Yangzijiang's net profit to grow at a compound annual growth rate of 19% between FY2022 and FY2024, driven by higher revenue from new order wins. The analyst also predicts returns on equity of 17-18% for FY2023 and FY2024, and values the shipbuilder at 1.7 times the price-to-book ratio.

images.alt_text: Two 24,000 TEU (20-foot equivalent unit) containerships under construction in the dry dock at Yangzijiang Shipbuilding's Xinfu Yard. The group has secured its first GTT (Gaztransport & Technigaz) Mark III LNG (liquefied natural gas) carrier order.

Yangzijiang Shipbuilding noted that it has delivered 51 vessels in total as of end-September, 
It is therefore on track to achieve its FY2022 delivery target of 70 vessels.

site_title: Investor TCI urges Alphabet to cut excessive headcount, costs
summary: TCI Fund Management, an investor with a $6 billion stake in Alphabet, has urged the company to cut costs by reducing its headcount and losses in its Waymo self-driving unit. The fund cited Alphabet's high employee salaries and rapid hiring as contributing factors to its financial struggles. TCI called for the company to disclose operating profit margin targets and reduce Waymo's operating losses by at least 50%. Alphabet has been struggling with advertisers cutting back on spending, and the company plans to cut hiring by more than half.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Letters spell the word "Alphabet" as they are seen on a computer screen with a Google search page in this photo illustration taken in Paris, France, August 11, 2015. REUTERS/Pascal Rossignol/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks dip at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Wednesday, tracking a Wall Street retreat after reports of a missile strike in Poland. The Straits Times Index (STI) dipped 0.1% to 3,272.84, with ComfortDelGro and Sembcorp Marine being the top traded counters. The US stock market had closed higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 gaining 0.2% and 0.9% respectively, amid signs of slowing inflation and good earnings reports.

images.alt_text: Keppel Infrastructure is investing about 30 million euros (S$42.6 million) to take a 49.9 per cent stake in a new joint venture with Swiss-based energy company Met Group.

site_title: China home prices fell most in seven years before sector rescue
summary: China's home prices fell 0.37% in October, the largest decline in seven years, amid a prolonged downturn. Existing-home prices dropped 0.47%, the steepest decline since 2014. The real estate slump is a major drag on the country's economy, with cash-strapped developers and households hoarding savings. Authorities have taken steps to rescue the sector, including a 16-point plan and easing lending restrictions. Despite efforts, homebuyer sentiment remains weak, with sales down 23% from last year and property investment slumping 16%. A turnaround is seen as key to reviving the industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: People walk along Nanjing Pedestrian Road, a main shopping area, in Shanghai, China May 5, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
The PBOC injected 850 billion yuan (S$165 billion) via its medium-term lending facility at a steady rate of 2.75 per cent.

site_title: EV maker VinFast plans US IPO as soon as January: sources
summary: VinFast, an electric vehicle (EV) maker backed by Vietnam's richest man, is planning to hold its US initial public offering (IPO) as soon as January 2023, according to sources. The IPO could raise at least $1 billion, with potential for more, depending on interest. VinFast has secured $1.2 billion in incentives for its North Carolina factory and has about 73,000 global EV reservations. The company has filed confidentially for the US IPO in April and is considering factors such as market conditions in determining the IPO timing.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares open on back foot
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 0.95% on Nov 16, 2022, following a 10% gain since Thursday's close. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 18,169.21 after Poland's army was put on alert following a Russian-made missile hitting a village, killing two people. The Shanghai Composite Index remained flat, while the Shenzhen Composite Index eased slightly. The decline came after a three-day rally sparked by investors' concerns over the US-China trade tensions and potential Federal Reserve actions.

site_title: Australian wages jump by most in a decade as inflation lingers
summary: Australia's Wage Price Index jumped 1% in the third quarter, the fastest gain since 2012, with wages growing 3.1% year-over-year. The increase was driven by private sector wage growth, which outpaced public sector growth. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) sees this growth as relatively contained, but warns of the risk of a "price-wage spiral" if wages continue to rise. The RBA has raised interest rates to 2.85% and may consider a pause, as the labor market remains tight and wages may fuel inflation.

images.alt_text: Australia’s high household debt and large share of mortgages on variable rates or resetting to them soon points to relatively strong transmission.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's stock market opened lower on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 7.56 points or 0.52% to 1442.98. The market saw 132.07 million lots traded worth RM57.52 million, with 173 losers outnumbering 119 gainers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, ST Engineering, Bukit Sembawang, Delfi, Second Chance
summary: Keppel Infrastructure is investing S$42.6 million to take a 49.9% stake in a new joint venture with Swiss-based energy company Met Group. This investment is part of a deal where Keppel Infrastructure sells half of its 20% interest in Met Group to the company's CEO for 31.9 million euros. Meanwhile, ST Engineering has been awarded turnkey tolling system contracts worth S$1.47 billion in New Jersey, with no expected impact on its net tangible assets or earnings.

site_title: Thai startup Beam raises US$2.5m for one-click payments
summary: Thai startup Beam has raised US$2.5 million in seed funding to expand its one-click payment services in Thailand and across South-east Asia. The funds will be used to increase hiring and grow merchant acquisition. Beam's one-click checkout feature allows for fast and secure payments via various options, aiming to improve the online transaction experience and optimize platform fees. The startup's co-founders believe social commerce is on the rise in the region, and their solution can help brands go direct-to-consumer and cultivate shopper loyalty.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Australia: Financials drag shares lower; geopolitical concerns weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 7,137.0, led by a 0.7% drop in financials, with top banks losing between 0.3% and 2.4%. The decline was partly due to concerns over interest rate hikes and geopolitical tensions, including reports of Russian missiles killing two people in Poland. However, cooling US inflation numbers raised hopes for a potential easing of interest rate hikes. The Australian Securities regulator also suspended the license of FTX's local arm amid global regulatory scrutiny.

site_title: Apple prepares to get made-in-US chips in pivot from Asia
summary: Apple is preparing to source device processors from a plant in Arizona, reducing its reliance on Asian production. CEO Tim Cook announced the plan during an internal meeting in Germany, stating that the Arizona plant is expected to start production in 2024. Additionally, Cook mentioned that Apple may expand its chip supply from European plants, marking a shift towards domestic production. This move aims to diversify Apple's supply chain and reduce its dependence on Taiwan-based TSMC plants.

images.alt_text: In addition to trying to bolster MacBook Pro sales, Apple could be looking to clear out some inventory before new models appear.

site_title: Climate leaders call for ‘Paris agreement’ for nature
summary: Climate leaders, including former French foreign minister Laurent Fabius and UN climate chief Christiana Figueres, are calling for a new 'Paris Agreement' for nature to be adopted at a UN biodiversity meeting in Montreal next month. The agreement aims to protect animals and plants from human destruction and prevent a sixth mass extinction event. The leaders urge leaders to deliver a strong framework capable of securing a nature-positive world by 2030, with a goal of limiting global warming to well below 2.0°C and preferably 1.5°C.

images.alt_text:
strait15 - Ships officer Cleo Bierneza is hoping for a Just Transition to zero carbon.

credit, source Cleo Bierneza
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) was welcomed by Indonesian President Joko Widodo at the start of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua, Bali on Nov 15, 2022.
Entrance to Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, venue of the COP27 summit; Nov 15, 2022.

site_title: Gold firms on Fed slowdown hopes, latest Russia jitters
summary: Gold prices held steady near a three-month peak at $1,776.50 per ounce on Wednesday, driven by hopes of smaller US interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The US producer price index (PPI) increased 8.0% in October, slightly beating expectations, and a report of Russian missiles killing two people in Poland led to demand for safe-haven assets. Despite this, Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic expressed skepticism about the Fed slowing rate hikes, and the dollar rose 0.2% against its rivals, limiting gold's advance.

images.alt_text: While gold is considered a hedge against inflation, rising interest rates tend to dull bullion’s appeal as the metal pays no interest.

site_title: JPMorgan seeks to grow in buyouts after rivals lost billions
summary: JPMorgan Chase is seeking to expand its leveraged finance business after avoiding billions of dollars in losses by cutting back on risk in 2022. The bank has been cautious in committing to funding high-profile transactions, opting for "best efforts" deals that give it less exposure to market fluctuations. JPMorgan's decision has allowed it to maintain a relatively low level of debt exposure, currently around $35.98 billion, compared to the estimated $40 billion of debt held by other major banks. The bank's strategy is expected to help it gain market share in leveraged financing.

images.alt_text: Most South-east Asia economies are forecast to grow more than 4 per cent in 2023 as economies fight inflation and continue to rebound from the pandemic.

site_title: Europe: Tech, commodity stocks help Stoxx 600 close higher for fourth day
summary: The Stoxx 600 index in Europe rose 0.4% on Tuesday, logging its fourth-straight session of gains, driven by technology and commodity stocks. Softer-than-expected US inflation data boosted hopes of less-aggressive Federal Reserve interest rate hikes. The index is still down 11.3% for the year due to recession worries, but eurozone inflation data for October is due on Thursday. European Central Bank policymaker Francois Villeroy de Galhau expects interest rate hikes above 2%, but at a more flexible pace.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dipped 0.1 per cent to 7,375.39 points.

site_title: OCBC offers fixed deposit placements for CPF ordinary account savings at 3.4% a year
summary: OCBC bank has launched a 12-month fixed deposit promotion for CPF ordinary account savings at 3.4% per annum, exceeding the 2.5% interest rate for savings beyond the first S$20,000. This is the first such promotion by OCBC, while UOB and DBS do not offer similar promotions. CPF members must set aside S$20,000 in their Ordinary Account or S$40,000 in Special Account before investing. Early withdrawal penalties apply, and other charges include a fee of up to S$2.50 per transaction.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
DBS raised the maximum interest rate on the Multiplier account to 4.1 per cent a year, up from 3.5 per cent previously.

Despite the record-high interest rates being offered, the present issuance of Singapore Savings Bond should have a higher first-year interest rate, if not for the intention to step up returns over its 10-year tenor.
CPFboard.jpg

site_title: Australia should keep tightening policy to cool demand, IMF says
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommends that Australia continue to tighten monetary and fiscal policy to cool domestic demand and manage inflation expectations. With high household debt and a large share of mortgages on variable rates or resetting, the IMF suggests more monetary policy tightening is needed to keep inflation expectations in check.

images.alt_text: australia house Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: India’s Tata to open 20 ‘beauty tech’ outlets, in talks with foreign brands
summary: Tata Group plans to open 20 "beauty tech" stores in India, using virtual makeup kiosks and digital skin tests to sell premium cosmetic products. The stores will cater to young, affluent shoppers aged 18-45 who prefer foreign brands like Estee Lauder's M.A.C and Bobbi Brown. Tata is in talks with over 20 companies to supply exclusive products, and the stores will have 70% skincare and makeup products. The technology aims to provide an immersive shopping experience, with features like virtual try-on and skin analysis.

images.alt_text: Tata Consumer Products, which sells the popular Tata Salt, Himalayan mineral water and runs a joint venture with Starbucks in India, said profit rose 22.4 per cent to 3.28 billion Indian rupees in the quarter.

iPhones on display at the new Apple Inc. store, due to open to the public on Thursday, in the Knightsbridge district of London, UK, on Tuesday, July 26, 2022. Apple is set to report earnings this week against the backdrop of an economic downturn and a plan to slow hiring. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

Tata Motors, India’s third-largest carmaker, has doubled its market share in passenger vehicles to about 14 per cent over the past two years, according to data from Federation Of Automobile Dealers Associations.

site_title: SpaceX is in funding talks that would value it at over US$150b
summary: SpaceX is in talks to raise funding valued at over US$150 billion, surpassing its previous valuation of US$125 billion. The company, led by Elon Musk, is discussing shares at roughly US$85 apiece. This funding round could include a private placement or tender offer, and would make SpaceX the most valuable closely held company, potentially leapfrogging ByteDance. SpaceX dominates the market for commercial space launch and is building a constellation of Starlink satellites to provide broadband internet coverage.

images.alt_text: SpaceX uses a constellation of Starlink satellites to beam broadband Internet from space to paying users who also have to buy terminals from the company.

site_title: Broadcom seeks EU approval for US$61b VMware takeover
summary: Broadcom has formally sought EU approval for its proposed $61 billion takeover of cloud-computing company VMware, with regulators setting a December 20 deadline to clear the deal or open an in-depth review. The transaction, if approved, would be the largest technology deal in history and bolster Broadcom's software offerings. Analysts expect a potential in-depth review due to concerns over Broadcom's increased market power, but say the deal may still be completed in its fiscal year 2023.

images.alt_text: Announced in May, the deal is the second biggest globally so far this year and marks Broadcom’s attempt to diversify its business into enterprise software.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher amid signs of slowing inflation
summary: US stocks closed higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2% to 33,592.92, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index gaining 0.9% and 1.5% respectively. The news was driven by further signs of slowing inflation, including a slowdown in the producer price index, and strong earnings reports from retailers like Walmart and Home Depot. However, a missile strike in Poland sent stocks lower before recovering at the closing bell.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 219.2 points, or 0.65 per cent, at the open to 33755.94.

site_title: Canadian home prices fall again, now down 10% from peak
summary: Canadian home prices fell 1.2% in October to C$756,200, marking the smallest monthly decline since May, and a 10% decline from the February peak. The market is adjusting to higher interest rates, but economists are cautiously optimistic that the slowdown may be winding down. The number of newly listed properties edged up 2.2% in October, while sales rose 1.3% for the first time since February.

images.alt_text: The spending package unveiled by Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland in a fiscal update on Thursday (Nov 3) is relatively modest in scope and builds on existing federal stimulus measures and payouts to consumers promised by Canada’s 10 provinces, but it has raised concerns about stimulating an already-hot economy

site_title: DBS opens representative office in Bangladesh
summary: DBS Group has opened a representative office in Dhaka, Bangladesh, expanding its international presence to 19 markets globally. The move aims to support client expansion plans in the region and tap into intra-regional trade opportunities. Tahsina Banu, with over 20 years of experience, has been appointed as the chief representative. The office will facilitate project investments and provide further impetus to DBS' activities, enhancing market connectivity for global customers.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Indian singer, businessman Shael Oswal sells Sentosa villa for S$32m, below 2012 S$39m purchase price
summary: Indian singer and businessman Shael Oswal sold his seafronting bungalow in Sentosa Cove for S$32 million, or S$2,009 psf, marking an 18% loss from his 2012 purchase price of S$39 million. The 15,930 sq ft property has a 99-year leasehold tenure. The sale is part of a trend of foreign buyers, including Chinese citizens, seeking to buy properties in Sentosa Cove, driven by the government's relaxation of border controls. The sale price is lower than a nearby sea-fronting villa sold for S$21 million in April but higher than a pair of adjoining bungalows sold for S$1,941 psf in February.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

krpic - House along White House Park

Demand for Sentosa Cove bungalows mirrors buzz in luxury housing market
Transaction volumes at Sentosa Cove may moderate after ABSD hike

site_title: Brookfield to invest up to US$700m in US recycling firm
summary: Brookfield Asset Management is investing up to US$700 million in US recycling firm Circular Services through its sustainability fund. The investment includes a US$200 million minority stake and an additional US$500 million in growth opportunities. The new entity, formed from the merger of five Closed Loop Partners portfolio companies, will handle various materials in seven US states, becoming the largest closely held recycling company in the US.

site_title: Beyonce-Adele rematch set to dominate 2023 Grammys
summary: Beyonce leads the pack with nine Grammy nominations for her album Renaissance, while Adele follows closely with seven nods for her album 30. Kendrick Lamar and Brandi Carlile also received eight and seven nominations, respectively. The 2023 Grammys will honor the industry's best on February 5, with Beyonce poised to tie Jay-Z and Georg Solti for the most nominations and wins by any artist. The event also features notable performances and categories, including Album of the Year and Song of the Year.

images.alt_text: Simon Cowell is partnering with TikTok to give users access to new unnamed songs by famous producers through the service StemDrop

Dolly Parton, who has operated a foundation that’s distributed books to children globally, says: “I’ve always said, I try to put my money where my heart is, and I think you do the same thing. I will do my best to do good things with this money. Thank you Jeff.”

site_title: Walmart expects smaller drop in annual profit, announces US$20b share buyback
summary: Walmart forecasts a 6-7% decline in fiscal 2023 adjusted earnings per share, lower than its previous 9-11% decline, due to resilient grocery sales and increased foot traffic in stores. The company also raised its full-year net sales expectations and announced a $20 billion share buyback plan, resulting in a 5% share price increase in premarket trading.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A shopper leaves a Walmart store in Bradford, Pennsylvania, U.S. July 20, 2020. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices settle higher on Druzhba oil pipeline disruption
summary: Oil prices rose on Tuesday after a disruption to the Druzhba oil pipeline, which supplies Hungary, temporarily suspended due to a fall in pressure. Brent crude futures rose 72 cents to US$93.86 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose US$1.05 to US$86.92. The US dollar index fell, making greenback-denominated oil less expensive for other currency holders. The European Union's ban on seaborne Russian crude, set to start on Dec 5, also supports oil prices.

images.alt_text: An oil pumping jack, also known as a 'nodding donkey,' stands in an oilfield operated by Bashneft PAO in the village of Otrada, 150kms from Ufa, Russia, on Saturday, March 5, 2016. Bashneft is an upstream and down stream oil & gas provider which explores, produces and refines its own oil and gas which it extracts from brownfield reserves in the Russian Federation. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: Allowing international issuers on Stock Connect brings opportunities for Asean companies: HKEX CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) CEO Nicolas Aguzin says the planned inclusion of international issuers on the Southbound Stock Connect will bring opportunities for companies in South-east Asia, allowing them to tap into both international and mainland China investors. This is a "major breakthrough" that could benefit companies by accessing a diverse investor base. Currently, 106 companies from the region are listed in Hong Kong, and the new regime will enable them to access the domestic investor base in mainland China.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
HKEX posted a 30 per cent drop in third-quarter profit on Wednesday (Oct 19), beating analyst expectations for a steeper fall.
The China Securities Regulatory Commission will push for inclusion of more such companies in the Stock Connect programme without specifying the timing for the rules change.

site_title: China’s Tencent Music results beat estimates as paying users rise
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment reported third-quarter revenue and profit that beat analyst estimates, driven by a recovery in advertising sales and a rise in paying users to 85.3 million. Total revenue fell 5.6% to 7.37 billion yuan, but the company expects to break even on gross margin basis for its long-form audio content by the end of next year. Despite a decline in revenue this year, the company aims to achieve positive revenue growth and profitability next year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Tencent logo is seen at its booth at the 2020 China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: US producer prices cool by more than forecast on heels of CPI
summary: US producer prices cooled in October, advancing 8% from a year ago, the smallest annual gain in over a year. This follows a smaller-than-expected monthly increase in the consumer price index. The core PPI, excluding food and energy, remained unchanged. The decline in producer prices, combined with easing cost pressures, suggests inflationary pressures are easing. This may lead to the Federal Reserve slowing interest rate hikes, but officials remain committed to taming inflation.

images.alt_text: An employee works at the BMW manufacturing plant in Greer, South Carolina, U.S., October 19, 2022.   REUTERS/Bob Strong

site_title: Norman must quit LIV role to end stalemate, says McIlroy
summary: Golf world number one Rory McIlroy says LIV Golf CEO Greg Norman must step down to end the stalemate between their tours. LIV Golf has lured top players away with large sums of money, leading to a feud with the PGA Tour. The tours are locked in a lawsuit, and McIlroy believes "nothing will happen" until it's resolved. He calls for Norman to exit his position to facilitate a resolution and allow for a more constructive dialogue.

site_title: Asia-Pacific dividends rise in Q3, led by Taiwan and HK
summary: Asia-Pacific dividends rose 14.6% in Q3 2022 to US$91.7 billion, driven by increases in Taiwan and Hong Kong. On an underlying basis, dividends grew 18.7% year-over-year. The growth is attributed to companies in the region paying more dividends, with Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Singapore among the top contributors.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Mining company Rio Tinto delivered the third highest dividends in the world.

First-quarter dividends in Asia Pacific, including
Japan and emerging Asia, rose 8.1 per cents to a total of
$33.9bn, the fourth consecutive quarter of growth from this region, according to the report by Janus Henderson

site_title: Hong Kong could turn Covid Zero into money
summary: Hong Kong is considering a full-fledged central bank digital currency, despite being stuck with Covid Zero policies due to Beijing's approval. The city is also exploring a novel idea to turn rapid antigen test (RAT) results into a digital currency, replacing the current vaccine pass. This concept aims to simplify the health verification process, reduce tracking and surveillance measures, and potentially serve as a testing ground for mainland China's pivot away from costly lockdowns. The proposal seeks to return Hong Kong to normalcy while showcasing its financial prowess.

images.alt_text: It was the third consecutive quarter of year-on-year contraction for Hong Kong’s GDP, and marked the worst contraction since the second quarter of 2020.

site_title: Climate vulnerable nations seek funds, but caught in red tape
summary: Climate vulnerable nations, such as the Maldives, are struggling to secure climate resilience funding despite rising temperatures and threats to their existence. The country's environment minister, Aminath Shauna, expressed frustration with the "very minimal" pledges received from rich countries, citing the need for an estimated US$8.8 billion for coastal adaptation projects. Experts warn that damage from a warming world is outpacing funding for efforts to forestall catastrophes, with the UN estimating actual needs are 5-10 times greater than provided finance.

images.alt_text: Get hands-on experience planting corals with experts at Sheraton Maldives Full Moon Resort & Spa.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure to enter joint venture with Swiss energy firm
summary: Keppel Infrastructure is investing 30 million euros in a 49.9% stake in a joint venture with Swiss energy company Met Group. The investment is funded by the sale of half of its 20% interest in Met Group to its CEO, Benjamin Lakatos, for 31.9 million euros. Keppel Infrastructure initially acquired its stake in Met Group in 2019. The joint venture's aggregate book value and net tangible asset value stood at 4.6 million euros as of September 30.

images.alt_text: A worker stands in front of the Floatel Triumph, a semi-submersible accommodation rig operated by Floatel International Ltd. and developed by Keppel Offshore & Marine Ltd.'s deep water technology group, during a media tour in Singapore, on Friday, March 11, 2016. Keppel Corp., parent company of Keppel Offshore & Marine, is the world's biggest builder of oil rigs. Photographer: Nicky Loh/Bloomberg

site_title: Six-figure income needed to buy a typical US home
summary: US homebuyers need a six-figure income to afford the median-priced home, with a monthly mortgage payment of $3,288, according to Redfin Corp. The required annual income has increased 46% to $107,281, making homeownership unaffordable for those earning less than $100,000. This trend is attributed to rising mortgage costs above 7% for a 30-year fixed mortgage, pushing home prices out of reach for first-time buyers and even experienced buyers in some areas.

images.alt_text: Extell Development is seeking to spur sales at two of its buildings – just 57 per cent of the 814 units in One Manhattan Square have sold after seven years on the market.

site_title: Kamala Harris to visit Philippine islands at edge of South China Sea dispute
summary: US Vice-President Kamala Harris will visit the Philippine islands of Palawan on the edge of the disputed South China Sea, marking the highest-ranking American official to do so. The trip, scheduled for next Tuesday, aims to show the administration's commitment to upholding the rules-based international maritime order and supporting the Philippines' maritime livelihoods. Harris' visit comes after a face-to-face meeting between US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, and may be interpreted by Beijing as a rebuke.

images.alt_text: epa10305947 US Vice President Kamala Harris responds to a question from the news media following her participation in the ceremonial swearing-in of Candace Bond to be the US Ambassador to Trinidad and Tobago in the Vice President's ceremonial office in Washington, DC, USA, 14 November 2022.  EPA-EFE/SHAWN THEW

site_title: Data analytics – the tool that will drive growth in smart construction
summary: Singapore's construction sector has bounced back from the COVID-19 pandemic, with a projected demand of $27-32 billion in 2022. However, challenges such as high material costs, labor shortages, and workplace accidents persist. To overcome these obstacles, technology is playing a crucial role, particularly data analytics, which is seen as a key factor in driving growth and innovation in the sector. With 65% of Singapore respondents planning to introduce Big Data solutions, the future of construction is shifting towards "offence" rather than "defence", with data-driven insights enabling better business decisions and improved project outcomes.

images.alt_text: Travellers look at information regarding their flights in the departure hall at Changi International Airport in Singapore on December 2, 2021. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Investing in proptech and other innovations for a sustainable future
Weakening property market sentiment could be a harbinger of flagging construction demand.

site_title: Regulators need to stay agile to control risks that come with fintech innovation: panel
summary: Regulators must stay agile to control the risks associated with fintech innovation, particularly in the cryptocurrency space. Panellists at the Abu Dhabi Finance Week 2022 emphasized the need for regulators to be adaptable and leverage their experiences to address emerging risks. They highlighted the importance of striking a balance between regulation and innovation, with regulators needing to incorporate lessons learned from experience and innovative channels. The panellists also stressed the need for regulators to ensure that new financial activities, such as cryptocurrencies, are brought within the regulatory perimeter and held to the same standards as other financial firms.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

At the Abu Dhabi Finance Week 2022, panellist discuss how big banks drive innovation. Speakers at the panel include Zul Javaid, CEO of UAE Trade Connect; Tan Bin Ru, South-east Asia CEO of OneConnect Financial Technology; Raheel Ahmed, CEO of Rakbank; and Gabrielle Inzirillo, head of ecosystem development at Abu Dhabi Global Market’s Financial Services Regulatory Authority.
MAS reiterates the hazards of cryptocurrency trading for the general public in its response to queries on FTX's operations in Singapore.

site_title: Bukit Sembawang unit wins Bukit Timah Link site with bid of S$200m
summary: Bukit Sembawang Estates, a subsidiary of Bukit Sembawang, won a tender for a 99-year leasehold site in Bukit Timah Link with a bid of S$200 million (S$14,457 per square meter). The 4,611.1 sq m site can have a maximum GFA of 13,834 sq m and is expected to be developed into a 20-storey residential development with 160 apartments. The project aims to create a "cosmopolitan village lifestyle" and is expected to be funded by internal resources and bank borrowings.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: UK to build five new frigates to counter Russia threat
summary: The UK is set to spend £4.2 billion on five new City Class Type 26 frigates from BAE Systems to bolster security against Russian threats. The frigates, expected to be completed by mid-2030s, will sustain 4,000 jobs. This purchase follows Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's condemnation of Russia's invasion of Ukraine and comes as the company ramps up earnings guidance due to the "elevated threat environment".

images.alt_text: Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg said the alliance has started dialogue with industry and allies on how to boost production and replenish weapons stocks.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has put the blame on the US and its allies for the lack of communique at the 18-nation East Asian Summit, saying on Sunday (Nov 13) they “insisted on absolutely unacceptable language regarding the situation in Ukraine”.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as data points to cooling inflation
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 219.2 points, or 0.65%, to 33,755.94, following a lower-than-expected rise in US producer prices, boosting expectations of smaller interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose, with the S&P 500 increasing 49.2 points, or 1.24%, to 40,006.41, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 278.6 points, or 2.49%, to 11,474.82.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 11, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Purpose-bound money, still searching for its purpose
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has expressed skepticism about the need for retail central bank digital currencies (CBDCs), citing the existing prevalence of electronic payments in the country. A recent test of "purpose-bound digital Singapore dollars" at the Singapore Fintech Festival revealed limitations in the user experience, including complexity and lack of interoperability. The MAS is exploring the potential use of digital currencies to streamline payment processes for businesses, particularly smaller ones, but notes that extra care must be taken to avoid disenfranchising vulnerable groups.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

The real value in the crypto industry comes not from speculating in cryptocurrencies, but from tokenising assets for use cases that increase economic efficiency or enhance social inclusion, said Ravi Menon.
While MAS deems the case for a retail CBDC in Singapore as “not compelling for now”, the authority said it continues to actively explore good use cases for digital currencies.

site_title: Enviro-Hub maintains optimism on glove business despite weakened sentiment
summary: Enviro-Hub, a Singapore-listed company, maintains optimism on its glove business despite a weakened market due to the Covid-19 pandemic and excess manufacturing capacity. The company diversified into glove making last year through the acquisition of Malaysian manufacturer Pastel Glove for S$46.8 million. Despite a 52% decline in its share price, Enviro-Hub's management remains confident that its decision will serve shareholders well in the medium term.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Enviro-Hub to open 25 retail pharmacies in Malaysia by end-2022
Raymond Ng, executive chairman of Enviro-Hub Holdings, has acquired taxi firm Premier Taxis.

site_title: Pound surges past US$1.20 as fresh data adds to dollar slump
summary: The British pound surged 2.3% to a three-month high against the US dollar, reaching US$1.2028, breaking the US$1.20 level for the first time since mid-August. Fresh data on US factory-gate inflation and consumer prices suggest the Federal Reserve's aggressive rate-hiking may be nearing its end, boosting the pound. Growing optimism around China is also curbing interest in the US dollar, offering relief for stocks and emerging-market assets. The pound's gains may continue if UK inflation figures show price pressures building, but could sell after the government's Autumn Statement on Thursday.

site_title: Pay rise to surpass pre-Covid-19 levels; inflation to eat into wages
summary: Singapore's average pay rise is expected to reach 3.75% in 2023, surpassing pre-Covid-19 levels. However, inflation is projected to eat into real wages, with a 2.95% decrease in 2022. The logistics industry offers the highest pay rises, while the real estate sector provides the lowest. Companies are focusing on total rewards communication and increasing wages of lower-income employees to combat inflation. The survey also found that only 22% of organizations are increasing salary budgets to combat rising inflation, with 54% adopting a wait-and-see approach.

images.alt_text: The National Wages Council calls on employers to reward their staff with wage increases that are fair, in line with economic growth and the improvement in labour productivity.

site_title: Amazon starts virtual health referral service linking patients to doctors
summary: Amazon launches Amazon Clinic, a virtual health referral service connecting patients to doctors for conditions like acne, hair loss, and allergies. The service, available in 32 US states, allows patients to select providers and complete an intake questionnaire before a virtual visit. Amazon Clinic is the company's latest foray into healthcare, following its online pharmacy and acquisition of One Medical. The service doesn't yet accept insurance, marking a new direction for Amazon in healthcare.

site_title: Euro, sterling and Swedish krona jump 1% after slew of economic data
summary: The euro, sterling, and Swedish krona rose 1% against the US dollar after a slew of economic data, including UK and eurozone job figures and German economic sentiment. The euro surged to its highest since early July at US$1.0406, driven by a rebound in the German ZEW index. Analysts attributed the positive sentiment to mild winter heating and well-filled gas stores, easing concerns about a deep recession.

images.alt_text: A stack of ten euro banknotes sit on a pile of U.S. dollar bills in this arranged taken photograph inside a Travelex store, operated by Travelex Holdings Ltd., in London, U.K., on Monday, Jan. 12, 2015. The euro approached a nine-year low against the dollar as European Central Bank officials fueled speculation the institution will start a program of government-bond buying as early as next week to stave off deflation. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Innovation is two-way street between fintechs and  traditional banks, say panellists
summary: Panellists at the Abu Dhabi Finance Week forum argue that innovation in the financial services space is a two-way street between traditional banks and fintech start-ups. Rakbank's CEO Raheel Ahmed notes that big banks are rapidly innovating and contributing to the sector's innovation. Fintech companies, such as OneConnect Financial Technology and UAE Trade Connect, support the idea that collaboration between traditional banks and fintechs is increasing. They emphasize that banks should adopt fintech solutions and not necessarily innovate their own solutions, fostering a symbiotic relationship between the two sectors.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Diesel demand could shrink next year, IEA says
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) forecasts a small decline in diesel and gasoil demand next year due to persistently high prices fueling inflation and economic pressure. High diesel prices are adding pressure on the global economy and world oil demand, affecting economic activity that relies heavily on diesel.

images.alt_text: CO2 emissions are on course to increase by nearly 300 million tonnes to 33.8 billion tonnes this year, a far smaller rise than their jump of nearly 2 billion tonnes in 2021, IEA said.

site_title: Transparency and innovation are key in climate ambition
summary: The world's nations must collectively work to limit global temperature increase to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Technology and decarbonizing energy systems will be crucial. Singapore, hosting COP27, aims to establish itself as a global carbon trading hub, building on last year's Paris Agreement rules. The country is bringing together major efforts to drive emissions down in an efficient and transparent manner, ensuring the robust health of the carbon market.

images.alt_text: The consequences of the world’s failure to curb emissions are catastrophic, and not just for the Pacific islands. Climate-related disasters are proliferating; Florida in September suffered its deadliest hurricane since 1935.

The city skyline of Cairo beyond horse riders on the Giza pyramid complex in Giza, Egypt. Leaders around the world will gather in Sharm el-Sheikh for the annual UN Climate Change conference, known this year as COP27.
Displaced people on a flooded highway following rains and floods during the monsoon season in Sehwan, Pakistan, in September.

site_title: Medical tourism to Thailand gets a boost with new one-year visas
summary: Thailand has approved a new one-year visa for foreign patients seeking medical treatment, allowing them to fly in and out of the country and stay for up to 90 days at a time. The visa fee has been reduced to 5,000 baht (S$192.72) from 6,000 baht, and applicants must provide evidence of a hospital appointment, health insurance, and proof of financing for treatments covering at least 800,000 baht. The move aims to promote Thailand as a world-class destination for medical tourism, with hospital operators such as Bangkok Dusit Medical Services and Bumrungrad Hospital leading the efforts.

images.alt_text: epa10285736 Tourists walk along the popular tourist area of Khaosan Road in Bangkok, Thailand, 04 November 2022. Over 3 million tourists visited Thailand in the month of October according to figures from the Transport Ministry, doubling the number of tourists arriving in the country in September, with the bulk of the tourists arriving by air. Thailand's tourism is experiencing a boost after the country lifted all COVID-19 restrictions measures in October.  EPA-EFE/DIEGO AZUBEL

site_title: White House says more infrastructure spending coming, rejects inflation link
summary: The White House announced it has disbursed $185 billion in funding under the bipartisan infrastructure law, with an additional $185 billion or more to follow in 2023. The funding aims to repair bridges and roads, expand broadband internet access, and support domestic semiconductor production. National Economic Council director Brian Deese denied the funding would fuel inflation, citing improved efficiencies and reduced supply chain pressures. The administration has announced nearly 7,000 projects reaching 4,000 communities, with 3,500 workers hired to implement the law, and plans to launch more major projects by the end of the year.

site_title: Continental investigates cyberattack after report says data up for sale
summary: Continental, a tyre and automotive parts manufacturer, is investigating a cyberattack that resulted in stolen data, with reports suggesting the information has been put up for sale. The company stated its investigation is moving ahead with the highest priority, but declined to comment on the media reports. Continental initially reported the cyberattack in August, stating some data was stolen. The company is taking the incident seriously and is working to resolve the issue.

site_title: Crypto billionaires with US$96b loss add distance from FTX
summary: Crypto billionaires, including Cameron Winklevoss and Brian Armstrong, are distancing themselves from FTX following the collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried's crypto empire. Winklevoss emphasized Gemini's lack of exposure to FTX, while Armstrong reshared a 2018 article highlighting Coinbase's commitment to legitimacy. Both billionaires have suffered significant losses in 2022, but are seeking to maintain their credibility in the industry. Their moves come as the crypto world grapples with the fallout from FTX's demise.

images.alt_text: This photo illustration shows the logo of cryptocurrency FTX, reflected in its website on a laptop screen in Washington, DC, on November 13, 2022. - The new chief executive of troubled cryptocurrency platform FTX said on November 12, 2022, the company was making "every effort to secure all assets" following unauthorized transactions potentially worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Additionally, the platform's chief executive, 30-year-old Sam Bankman-Fried, once considered a star in the freewheeling cryptocurrency world, resigned. (Photo by Stefani Reynolds / AFP)

site_title: Meta’s India public policy chief, WhatsApp’s India boss quit
summary: Meta's India public policy chief, WhatsApp's India boss, and Meta Platforms' director for public policy in India, Rajiv Aggarwal, have all resigned. Abhijit Bose, WhatsApp's India head, and Ajit Mohan, Meta's India head, previously quit. The exits are unrelated to the recent massive layoffs announced by Meta, which cut over 11,000 jobs. The company has appointed Shivnath Thukral as the new director for public policy in India and will look for a replacement for Bose. This follows regulatory challenges in India and WhatsApp's push to expand its payments service.

site_title: Sustainability is key amid Asean reopening
summary: Business activity in South-east Asia is picking up, with the S&P Global Asean Manufacturing PMI hitting an 11-month high in September. Travel-related businesses have seen a rise in growth, driven by "revenge travel" and the resumption of meetings and conferences. This trend is also linked to increasing awareness and support for the net-zero agenda, accelerating the growth of green businesses. Governments in the region are also playing a key role in supporting this growth, with many lifting or relaxing Covid-19 restrictions.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Panel discussion, titled 'Asean’s Moment: Uncovering Opportunities in Disruptive Times' ( L-R) Takeshi Sasaki, Partner (Asia), Advantage Partners; Geoff Howie, Market Strategist, Singapore Exchange ; Anita Gabriel, Senior Correspondent, The Business Times; Khairul Anwar, Director for Southeast Asia, Enterprise Singapore; Gregory Seow, Head of Global Banking Singapore, Maybank.
As governments begin to focus more on solar panel supply chain diversification, South-east Asia could emerge as an important player in sustainable energy production.

site_title: Thinking linearly in investments can be costly
summary: Investing in the stock market can be costly due to the difficulty in dealing with uncertainty. A long-term investment plan helps to reap the benefits of compounding, which can significantly increase wealth over time. Research by the author illustrates the potential costs of delaying investment, with returns varying greatly depending on the timing of entry. The key takeaway is that trying to time the markets is not a good idea, and focusing on long-term compounding can lead to substantial wealth accumulation.

images.alt_text: money, profit, finance

site_title: Russia in ‘no hurry’ to lower inflation: central bank chief
summary: Russian central bank governor Elvira Nabiullina stated that the economy is undergoing a "massive structural transformation" due to Western sanctions, leading to a likely prolonged period of high inflation. Currently, inflation is at 12.5%, exceeding the bank's target of 4% by 2024. Nabiullina emphasized that the central bank is gradually lowering inflation but is not in a hurry, as the restructuring process may lead to elevated price growth for some time.

site_title: Delfi Q3 Ebitda more than doubles to US$13.7m
summary: Delfi Ltd reported a significant increase in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) to US$13.7 million for the third quarter, more than doubling from the same period last year. Revenue rose 28.7% to US$112 million, driven by growth in Indonesia and regional markets. The company's gross profit margin also increased 270 basis points to 29.7%. Delfi expects to maintain positive growth momentum for the rest of the year, despite macroeconomic challenges.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Revenue growth was driven by the Indonesian segment which rose by 16.1 per cent to US$167.2 million; and also from regional markets improving by 18.9 per cent to US$79.1 million.

site_title: Two Chinese property developers plan to raise 35 billion yuan in debt
summary: Chinese property developers Longfor Group Holdings and Midea Real Estate Holding plan to raise a total of 35 billion yuan (S$6.8 billion) in debt to ease a liquidity crunch in the property sector. Longfor has completed registration for 20 billion yuan, while Midea has submitted an application to raise 15 billion yuan. The move comes after Chinese regulators announced support measures to help cash-strapped developers tap fresh funding to finish projects and pay suppliers.

images.alt_text: Apartment buildings at the Phoenix City residential project, developed by Country Garden Holdings in Shanghai.. Country Garden shares surged on Monday on expectation that Beijing would launch a rescue package to ease developers' liquidity strains and revive home purchases.
Royal Peak, a residential development in Beijing, is being built by the ailing Evergrande Group. Beijing is trying to rescue the property market.
China’s property sector, once a pillar of growth, has slowed sharply this year as the government sought to restrict excessive borrowing by developers.

site_title: Mass lay-offs in Big Tech are an old-guard mistake
summary: Big Tech companies, including Twitter, Meta, and Amazon, are facing criticism for mass lay-offs, a strategy that has been deemed "deeply risky" by historians. This approach, popularized in the 1980s, involves slashing payrolls to boost profits, but has been shown to have negative long-term consequences, including decreased employee morale and productivity. Studies have found that mass lay-offs can lead to a decline in corporate profitability and even result in the downfall of executives who pursue this strategy. As these companies continue to downsize, experts warn that they may be repeating a historical pattern that has proven to be detrimental to their long-term success.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms Inc. signage during the virtual Meta Connect event in New York, US, on Tuesday, Oct. 11, 2022. Mark Zuckerberg unveiled his company's newest virtual-reality headset, the Meta Quest Pro, the latest foray into the world of high-end VR devices that Meta Platforms hopes will entice creators and working professionals to adopt its vision for a virtual future. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg
This is at least the third round of job cuts Shopee has made this year.
FILE PHOTO: A Tencent logo is seen at its booth at the 2020 China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

Vishal Garg, chief executive and founder of Better.com, in a photo taken in April 2007. In a letter to employees dated Dec 7, 2021, Garg apologised for the way he laid off about 900 employees over Zoom the week before, saying that he "blundered the execution".
The e-commerce giant is planning to lay off about 10,000 people in corporate and technology jobs, the New York Times reported.

site_title:
Platform worker protections to be unveiled 
next week could include new worker category, CPF
summary: Singapore's advisory committee on platform workers is set to release recommendations next week, which could include a new worker category and mandatory contributions to the Central Provident Fund (CPF) scheme. The committee, formed after last year's National Day Rally, has been studying job protections for platform workers, including cabbies, on-demand riders, and drivers. The recommendations may differentiate treatment based on income, hours worked, or age, and will be implemented in phases to prevent a shock to the industry. The move aims to strengthen protections for platform workers, who are not considered typical self-employed persons due to company control.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
Platforms like Grab and foodpanda have rolled out welfare initiatives, but these cannot match national job protections.

site_title: Book review: Essential reading for investors in an ESG-driven, post-Covid world
summary: Businesses can gain a long-term competitive advantage by prioritizing environmental, social, and corporate governance (ESG) goals alongside profit. According to Harvard Business School professor George Serafeim, purpose-driven firms that improve performance on material ESG issues outperform their competitors by over 3% annually. The Covid-19 pandemic has accelerated the importance of ESG factors, and asset managers now have a fiduciary duty to consider them. Companies must identify financially material ESG issues relevant to their industry and focus on them to achieve success.

images.alt_text: The report, based on a survey of fund managers in Asia, found that less than half of respondents conduct ESG due diligence on every deal, while 46 per cent did so on most deals.

site_title: Majority of G20 nations strongly condemn Russian invasion of Ukraine: draft declaration
summary: The G20 summit in Bali has concluded with a draft declaration strongly condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine, calling it a "destructive" war that's causing immense human suffering and exacerbating global economic fragilities. Most G20 nations, including the US, China, and France, have expressed their opposition to Russia's actions, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy urging leaders to stop the war. Despite Russia's absence, the summit has seen various agreements, including a pledge by nine nations to raise $20 billion to help Indonesia transition away from coal and reach carbon neutrality by 2050.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Fifa president Gianni Infantino said the month-long World Cup, which starts in Qatar on Sunday, offered a unique platform for peace.

The G20, which includes countries ranging from Brazil to India, Saudi Arabia and Germany, accounts for more than 80 per cent of the world’s gross domestic product, 75 per cent of international trade and 60 per cent of its population.
Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) was welcomed by Indonesian President Joko Widodo at the start of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua, Bali on Nov 15, 2022.

site_title: Second Chance to sell Lucky Plaza Units for S$13.39m
summary: Mainboard-listed Second Chance Properties announced that the Lew Foundation has exercised the option to purchase four units in Lucky Plaza for S$13.39 million, exceeding the total consideration. The Lew Foundation, founded by businessman Lew Chee Beng, had been granted the option to purchase the units, which would have expired on August 1. An option fee of 1% of the sale price was paid to the company. The shares of Second Chance closed flat at S$0.24 after the announcement.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Few shoppers at Lucky Plaza on May 16, 2021.

site_title: Malaysians abroad scramble to meet voting deadline amid late ballot deliveries
summary: Over 50,000 overseas Malaysians are set to cast their ballots in the upcoming polls, with many facing a tight deadline due to late ballot deliveries. Despite efforts to speed up the process, some voters have yet to receive their ballots, leaving them worried about meeting the November 19 deadline. Global Bersih, an international movement of overseas Malaysians, has received over 100 complaints, citing issues with courier companies and long delivery times. The Election Commission has acknowledged the problem and is relying on volunteers to collect and deliver ballots.

images.alt_text: No single coalition is expected to win a simple majority in parliament.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: China's easing of COVID-19 curbs has boosted stocks in travel and China-focused businesses in Singapore. This move could benefit companies like Singapore Airlines and China's Sinopec. Meanwhile, Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for collective action to address climate change, which poses a long-term threat to food and energy security. New home sales in Singapore fell to a two-year low in October, and Sembcorp Marine reduced its second-half guidance due to higher labor costs and slower project improvement. Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on improved market sentiment.

site_title: South Korea urges bigger China role in curbing North Korea weapons tests
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol urged China to play a bigger role in curbing North Korea's nuclear and missile provocations during his first face-to-face meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the Group of 20 conference in Bali. Yoon expressed concerns over North Korea's escalating tension and called for China to be more active in the UN Security Council.
