Xi agreed to deepen cooperation with South Korea, including high-tech manufacturing, and the two leaders also discussed speeding up negotiations on a bilateral free-trade agreement.

images.alt_text: epa10306547 South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol (L) poses for a photo with his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping (R) during their meeting on the sidelines of the G20 Leaders' Summit in Bali, Indonesia, 15 November 2022. The 17th Group of Twenty (G20) Heads of State and Government Summit runs from 15 to 16 November 2022.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT

site_title: SIA flies 2.3m passengers in October; group capacity at 71% of pre-Covid levels
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) carried 2.3 million passengers in October, a 6.2% increase from the previous month, with a 71% capacity reach of pre-Covid-19 levels. The group's passenger load factor was 86.4%, while cargo operations had a load factor of 52.6%, down 34.6 percentage points from the previous year. SIA has resumed flights to two destinations and now serves 76 destinations, while Scoot has reintroduced flights to several points in Indonesia and mainland China.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Travel industry groups have warned Hong Kong will not see a meaningful return of visitors until the three-day monitoring period and most other restrictions are lifted.
Singapore Airlines continues to offer codeshare flights on 64 routes covering 31 destinations on Virgin Australia’s network.

site_title: New UK government still troubled by Truss tenure
summary: The UK government, led by Chancellor Jeremy Hunt, is set to announce tax hikes and spending cuts totaling £50-60 billion in the upcoming budget, amid a post-2015 austerity period. Hunt's decision comes after the Truss government's emergency fiscal statement in September, which led to the resignation of Chancellor Kwasi Kwarteng and Prime Minister Liz Truss. The UK economy appears weak, with a 0.2% contraction in the third quarter, and the government faces a challenging political context, with growing support for rejoining the EU.

images.alt_text: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt walks outside his house in London, Britain, October 18, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville

site_title: E-commerce and credit business push Sea’s Q3 2022 revenue up 17.4%; 2022 guidance revised down
summary: Sea Ltd reported a 17.4% increase in Q3 2022 revenue to $3.2 billion, driven by e-commerce and credit business growth. However, net loss worsened slightly to $571 million. The company revised its 2022 guidance down to $2.6-2.8 billion and will not provide 2023 guidance. Sea has reduced headcount, tightened travel policy, and reduced spending on computer hardware to achieve self-sufficiency and profitability. Digital entertainment revenue dropped 18.8% due to softening bookings, but the e-commerce and other services segment saw a 50.9% surge.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
FILE PHOTO: A person stands in front of a signage of Southeast Asian e-commerce and gaming group Sea Ltd's, at their office in Singapore March 5, 2021. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo

site_title: China's Tencent starts new round of layoffs
summary: Tencent Holdings, a Chinese tech giant, has begun a new round of layoffs targeting its video streaming, gaming, and cloud businesses. The job cuts affect three out of six business divisions, including platform and content, gaming, and cloud. The company has already cut jobs earlier this year and is focusing on cutting costs and shuttering non-core businesses. The layoffs come amid a regulatory crackdown and economic headwinds in China, with analysts expecting Tencent to report flat revenues or a small contraction in its third-quarter results.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Tencent logo is seen at its booth at the 2020 China International Fair for Trade in Services (CIFTIS) in Beijing, China September 4, 2020. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: ST Engineering unit wins contracts worth S$1.5b to modernise New Jersey toll collection systems
summary: ST Engineering's subsidiary TransCore has won contracts worth S$1.47 billion to modernize New Jersey's toll collection systems. The 10-year contract with the New Jersey Turnpike Authority and 12-year contract with the South Jersey Transportation Authority will replace existing tolling infrastructure with TransCore's flagship toll collection system, integrating automatic vehicle identification and classification. The system also features video capture and recognition, digital video audit, and real-time revenue traceability. The contracts are expected to have a minimal impact on ST Engineering's financials.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
ST Engineering booth at the Singapore Airshow 2022 on February 17, 2022.

site_title: US, Philippines to start building military facilities in 2023
summary: The US and Philippines will start building military facilities in 2023, including training facilities and warehouses on two military bases and an airport base station. The projects, worth $66.5 million, aim to boost mutual defense ties and modernize the Philippine military. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr seeks to strengthen ties with the US amid a territorial dispute with China over the South China Sea. The Philippines reiterates its commitment to accelerating defense projects under the Enhanced Defence Cooperation Agreement.

site_title: Europe: Stocks mixed at open
summary: European stocks opened mixed on Tuesday, November 15, following gains in Asia. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.1% to 7,375.39 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices rose 0.3% each. The mixed performance was attributed to China's efforts to boost its economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker shelters from the rain under a Union Flag umbrella as he passes the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain, October 1, 2008.  REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Oct new home sales at two-year low as fewer projects launched
summary: Singapore's new home sales dropped to a two-year low in October, with 312 private homes sold, a 68.4% decline from September and 65.8% year-over-year. This is the lowest number of newly-launched units in four years. The decline is attributed to fewer projects being launched, despite the popularity of new products such as the Copen Grand.

images.alt_text: According to poll findings by the National University of Singapore Real Estate, majority of real estate senior executives expect the benchmark of S$2,000 per square feet for private homes in the OCR to persist over the next one to two years.

site_title: Australia PM hails Xi meeting as a step towards stabilising ties
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese hailed a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping as a step towards normalizing ties, marking the first face-to-face meeting in almost three years. The meeting comes after years of deteriorating relations due to the COVID-19 pandemic and trade sanctions. Despite diplomatic tensions, the two countries maintain a close economic relationship, with China being Australia's largest trading partner. Albanese said the meeting was an important step towards stabilizing the relationship, with "many steps yet to take."

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden with China's President Xi Jinping in their meeting on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Bali on Monday (Nov 14).

site_title: OCBC’s SME sustainable financing loan book on track to overtake S$3b by end-2022
summary: OCBC's SME sustainable financing loan book is on track to reach over S$3 billion by the end of 2022, a 50% growth from its initial target. The bank has seen a three-fold rise in SMEs taking up sustainable financing, with Singapore SMEs making up 80% of the total. The growth signals a growing adoption of sustainability beyond mere awareness, with the bank refining its framework to broaden access to sustainable finance. OCBC plans to partner with industry players to extend self-help emissions measurement and reporting tools to SMEs, enabling them to capture data and benchmark.

images.alt_text: Linus Goh, Head of global commercial banking, OCBC Bank.

site_title: Rich nations target US$20b to wean Indonesia off coal
summary: Rich nations, including the US, Japan, Canada, and six European countries, pledged $20 billion to help Indonesia transition away from coal and reach carbon neutrality by 2050, 10 years earlier than planned. In return, Indonesia committed to doubling its renewable energy generation by 2030 and becoming carbon-neutral by 2050. The deal includes $10 billion in public sector finance and $10 billion in private funding over three to five years, with financing options including grants, loans, and investments.

images.alt_text: Coal is loaded onto a barge in Kutai Kartanegara, East Kalimantan, Indonesia. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: The revolt of the “normies”
summary: US midterms signal a return to the political centre, with Republican Kevin McCarthy poised to become Speaker if his party gains control of the House. However, he faces resistance from the right flank due to a poor midterm showing. This shift marks a departure from the polarized politics seen in recent years, with "normies" (mainstream voters) re-emerging as a key demographic.

images.alt_text: Georgia's secretary of state Brad Raffensperger at a press conference at the Georgia State Capitol on Nov 11, 2022. The Republican, who defied Trump over election denialism, won by a wide margin on Nov 8.
Governor Ron Desantis addressing supporters in Tampa on Tuesday night, Nov 8, 2022. DeSantis coasted to re-election, defeating his Democratic challenger, Charlie Crist.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 13.46 points to 1,450.54, marking a decline. The index saw 2.781 billion lots traded worth RM1.677 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 541 to 332.

site_title: Fifa boss Infantino urges World Cup ceasefire in Ukraine
summary: FIFA president Gianni Infantino called for a temporary ceasefire in the Ukraine war during the upcoming World Cup, which starts in Qatar on Sunday. Infantino urged all sides to use the tournament as a "positive trigger" to work towards a resolution. He proposed humanitarian corridors or dialogue resumption as a first step towards peace. Infantino's plea came during a lunch with Group of 20 leaders on the Indonesian island of Bali.

site_title: Schroders APAC chief Susan Soh to retire, Chris Durack appointed
summary: Schroders APAC chief Susan Soh is retiring at the end of 2022 after 17 years with the firm. She will continue in a senior advisor role. Chris Durack, who previously stepped down as Asia co-head, is rejoining and succeeding Soh as APAC CEO. Durack will be based in Singapore and oversee a series of leadership changes, including Amy Cho's departure and the appointment of Gopi Mirchandani as head of strategy and Chin Szu Yi as head of distribution for Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Schroders Capital has invested more than US$1 billion in over 30 transactions since the onset of Covid-19.

Schroders, Britain's biggest listed asset manager, said on Wednesday it would back a swathe of shareholder resolutions at Amazon, Meta and Google-owner Alphabet concerning workers' and digital rights.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end up more than 4%
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 4.11% on Nov 15, driven by Chinese moves to ease Covid-19 restrictions and positive talks between President Xi Jinping and US counterpart Joe Biden. The Hang Seng Index jumped 723.41 points to 18,343.12, extending its rally into a third day. Other Chinese indices, such as the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index, also rose, with gains of 1.64% and 2.05%, respectively.

site_title: Tone down expectations post-Party congress, but hold on to hope in a slower-growing China
summary: China's growth may slow, but its market still offers scale and room for private enterprise to thrive, according to Leslie Yee. Despite investors' pessimism, President Xi Jinping's new top team may offer enough room for private enterprise to grow. This could be a more optimistic outlook than expected, as China's market still has potential for growth and reform can help advance the economy.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee

Zhong Shanshan, whose listed companies are water bottler Nongfu Spring and vaccine developer Beijing Wantai Biological Pharmacy Enterprise, took first place on the Hurun Rich list with a fortune of US$65 billion.
Li Qiang, 63, was born in Wenzhou, a coastal city in Zhejiang province that emerged as a hotbed of China’s private-sector economy in the 1980s.

site_title: UK budget predicted to be a nightmare for households
summary: The UK is expected to unveil a budget on Thursday, Nov 17, which will hike taxes and slash public spending, signaling a return to austerity despite a cost-of-living crisis. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is predicted to unveil fiscal consolidation totaling between $58.7 billion and $70.5 billion, with more people being dragged into higher tax brackets. The move is seen as a necessary step to tackle sky-high inflation and recession, but critics, including the opposition Labour party, argue it will only worsen the economic situation, particularly for low-income households.

images.alt_text: Measures recommended by the Confederation of British Industry include being more flexible on immigration for occupations dogged by labour shortages, and adding student and graduate visa routes and visas linked to specific economic projects.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on improved market sentiment from US-China talks; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, driven by improved market sentiment following US President Joe Biden's meeting with China's President Xi Jinping at the G-20 summit. The Straits Times Index climbed 14.48 points to 3,275.28, with DFI Retail Group being the strongest performer. Regional markets, including Japan and South Korea, also saw gains. Despite this, Sembcorp Industries fell 3% and UOB rose 0.2%. Market sentiment appears to have improved after Biden's reassurance that there need not be a new Cold War between the US and China.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

US President Joe Biden and his delegation (left) face ) China's President Xi Jinping and his team on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Monday (Nov 14).

site_title: Sri Lanka must implement budget proposals to avoid return to crisis
summary: Sri Lanka's central bank governor, P Nandalal Weerasinghe, urges the government to implement budget proposals to stabilize the economy and avoid a return to crisis. The island nation's economy can recover by the end of 2023 if budget policies, including those beyond IMF recommendations, are followed. President Ranil Wickremesinghe also expressed confidence in the economy's recovery, citing a stable but low situation. Implementing reforms and earning foreign exchange are crucial to stabilizing the economy, according to Weerasinghe.

images.alt_text: A rice stall at the Narahenpita Economic Centre in Colombo, Sri Lanka. The country's government plans to reduce debt to less than 100 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) over the medium term, and achieve economic growth of 7 per cent.

site_title: Singapore stocks in travel, China business stand to benefit from mainland’s reopening
summary: China's easing of Covid curbs has sparked optimism among Singapore-listed stocks with exposure to the country, potentially benefiting from a mainland reopening. Analysts, including UOB Kay Hian and Phillip Securities, have identified several stocks, including property groups, retail companies, and commodities suppliers, that could ride on the upturn. China was Singapore's top source of tourists before the pandemic, and a revival of tourism is expected to boost stocks related to travel and tourism, such as Singapore Airlines and ComfortDelGro Corp. However, the upcoming winter season poses a risk due to the spread of the Omicron variant.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Royal Peak, a residential development in Beijing, is being built by the ailing Evergrande Group. Beijing is trying to rescue the property market.
China’s property sector, once a pillar of growth, has slowed sharply this year as the government sought to restrict excessive borrowing by developers.
The initiatives in the rescue package range from addressing the liquidity crisis faced by developers to a “temporary” easing of a signature restriction on bank lending.
China’s financial policymakers are stepping up efforts to arrest the slump in the country’s property sector, after measures from interest rate cuts to subsidies failed to revive growth.
Sembcorp's acquisition of the 3 solar projects in China through its joint venture with Beijing Energy will bring the mainboard-listed company's total solar capacity to 7.9 gigawatts.

site_title: How fear robs investors of opportunities and returns
summary: Investors are often driven to panic sell due to fear, rather than rational analysis, resulting in missed opportunities. This is due to the way humans process information, with System 1 (intuitive) thinking often overwhelming System 2 (reflective) decision-making. Removing daily stock movements from portfolio trackers, setting guardrails, and writing an investing journal can help mitigate System 1 biases. Keeping a long-term perspective, focusing on the "Even Bigger Picture," and avoiding undue influence of current problems can also help investors stay invested and achieve gains.

images.alt_text: Many economists expect a reopening in China only after March next year, when the political reshuffle is finally completed.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower on fears of more rate hikes
summary: Australian shares closed 0.1% lower at 7,141.6 on Tuesday, November 15, amid concerns of further interest rate hikes by the Reserve Bank of Australia. Minutes from the central bank's November 1 meeting showed increased expectations for rate hikes. Mining and energy stocks fell due to China Covid concerns, while financial stocks rose after Commonwealth Bank of Australia reported better-than-expected cash earnings.

images.alt_text: A bell used for official ceremonies hangs from a wall inside the Australian Securities Exchange (ASX) in Sydney, Australia, March 17, 2016. Australian bourse operator ASX Ltd said Elmer Funke Kupper, its chief executive officer, has quit to focus on unspecified potential investigations relating to his former role as head of gambling company Tabcorp Holdings Ltd. REUTERS/David Gray

site_title: Brilliance Asset Management suffers big loss after bets on Li Auto
summary: Brilliance Asset Management, a Hong Kong-based hedge fund, reported a 16% loss in October due to a decline in Chinese stocks, including a significant drop in Li Auto shares. The fund's flagship Brilliant Partners Fund fell 40% for the year to October, compared to an average decline of 21% for other funds using the long/short playbook in Chinese stocks. The loss is attributed to increased concerns about China from a top-down perspective and worsening auto sales for Li Auto. The fund's assets under management have fallen to $2.7 billion, down from $4.9 billion in February.

images.alt_text: Many economists expect a reopening in China only after March next year, when the political reshuffle is finally completed.

site_title: New Zealand house prices see biggest fall since the 1990s
summary: New Zealand's house price index saw its largest drop in 30 years, falling 10.9% from October last year, and median house prices dropped 7.9%. The decline is attributed to rising mortgage rates, with many economists expecting further falls as the cash rate is forecasted to rise higher. Experts predict house prices could drop 20% from their peak, erasing gains made since the pandemic. Falling house prices are expected to knock confidence and drag on spending in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The internal review, which looked at how the Reserve Bank of New Zealand made decisions about monetary policy in the past five years and what lessons could be learned, found monetary policy decisions were consistent with the data available at the time, while worst case scenarios were avoided.

site_title: Govt reduces incentives for commercial vehicle schemes, announces extension till Mar 31, 2025
summary: The Singapore government has reduced incentives for commercial vehicle schemes, including a rebate for electric models. The incentive for electric commercial vehicles in Band A will be reduced from S$30,000 to S$15,000, while those in Band B will receive a S$5,000 rebate. The scheme has been extended until March 31, 2025. The changes aim to encourage a gradual transition to cleaner vehicles while addressing industry concerns about higher upfront costs.

site_title: Djokovic to get visa for 2023 Australian Open: media reports
summary: Novak Djokovic will be granted a visa to play in the 2023 Australian Open, according to local media reports. The decision overturns a three-year ban after his ejection from the country ahead of this year's tournament. The Australian government has decided to grant the unvaccinated Serb a visa for the Grand Slam contest, following a high-stakes legal battle over his visa status.

images.alt_text: Switzerland's Roger Federer leaves the sport with 20 Grand Slams, including eight Wimbledons, 103 titles and more than US$130 million in prize money alone.

site_title: UK jobless rate rises, vacancies fall again
summary: The UK's unemployment rate rose to 3.6% in the July-to-September period, exceeding economists' expectations. Employment fell by 52,000, and job vacancies declined to 1.23 million, its lowest since late 2021. Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt's plans to raise taxes and cut spending may deepen an expected recession. The Bank of England fears a shrinking labor market will add to inflation pressures, prompting interest rate hikes. Wages excluding bonuses rose 5.7%, but adjusted for inflation, wages are down by almost 4%.

site_title: Pavilion Energy, Gasum, CNOOC sign agreement to strengthen LNG bunker supply
summary: Pavilion Energy, Gasum, and CNOOC Gas and Power Group signed a heads of agreement to strengthen the global LNG bunker supply network in Singapore, north-west Europe, and coastal areas in China. The partnership aims to improve efficiency and operational flexibility, leveraging each company's local expertise and logistics capabilities. CNOOC's participation is expected to boost industry alliances and encourage the uptake of LNG as a cleaner marine fuel, in line with the maritime industry's decarbonisation efforts. This agreement follows Pavilion Energy's extended partnership with Gasum in October 2020 to develop an LNG bunker supply network.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Looking for a ‘Just Transition’ to net zero
summary: The global shipping industry is launching a "Just Transition" to net zero carbon emissions by mid-2030s, with a 10-point action plan to retrain 1.89 million seafarers. The Maritime Just Transition Task Force, established by industry and union representatives, recommends strengthening global training standards, establishing advisory national maritime skills councils, and ensuring a health-and-safety-first approach. The plan aims to address the need for carbon upskilling as the industry transitions to alternative fuels and green technologies. The initiative, which includes shipowners, seafarers' unions, and UN organizations, is seen as a global first in a tripartite framework.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: View of a COP27 sign on the road leading to the conference area in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh town as the city prepares to host the COP27 summit next month, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sayed Sheasha/File Photo

site_title: Economic interdependence between US and China aids national security too: Tharman
summary: Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam of Singapore stated that economic interdependence between the US and China is in national security interest, as a decoupled world poses a greater threat. This comes after the US imposed semiconductor export controls targeting China. Tharman emphasized the need for some restrictions on economic activity to ensure national security, while also highlighting the benefits of interdependence in maintaining a safer and more stable global economy.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

US President Joe Biden and his delegation (left) face ) China's President Xi Jinping and his team on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Monday (Nov 14).

site_title: Top Federal Reserve regulatory official signals greater crypto oversight
summary: The US Federal Reserve's top banking official, Michael Barr, has signaled greater oversight for crypto activity, calling for firms to face similar regulatory safeguards as other financial services providers. This comes after the collapse of cryptocurrency platform FTX, which filed for bankruptcy last week. Barr warned that lax regulation can facilitate risk-taking and put consumers, businesses, and the economy in danger. He emphasized the need for effective oversight to protect investors and prevent systemic issues between the crypto and traditional financial systems.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin dropped 23 per cent  last week, its worst tumble since June, at the same time as the S&P 500 Index rose 5.9 per cent.
Crypto.com’s Kris Marszalek said Crypto.com had 70 million individual customers worldwide, and had made revenues of a billion US dollars in 2021 as well as in 2022.
The cruel irony of FTX’s collapse is that some investors had parked their holdings there because they perceived it as a relatively safe option.
Cash-strapped FTX filed for bankruptcy Friday (Nov 11) after Binance scrapped a takeover bid, sending chills across the cryptocurrency world.

site_title: China state media reinforce Covid Zero as cases jump in cities
summary: China's state media reaffirmed the country's commitment to Covid Zero despite a surge in new cases, with 17,298 cases reported nationwide on November 14. The majority of cases were in Guangzhou, where lockdowns were extended in three districts. Officials swiftly moved to quash speculation of a shift in pandemic response, and state media publication the People's Daily stated that China is sticking to Covid Zero, amid a sweeping overhaul of the country's Covid framework, including shorter quarantine and ending flight bans.

images.alt_text: Travellers into China will be required to spend five days in a hotel or government quarantine facility, followed by three days confined to home.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close slightly higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed slightly higher on Tuesday, Nov 15, as the Nikkei 225 index rose 0.10% to 27,990.17, while the Topix index added 0.37% to 1,964.22. The gains were driven by purchases of shares with sound corporate earnings, offsetting the negative impact of US falls and weak Japanese GDP data.

site_title: Seoul: Shares end marginally higher on China policy hopes
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index rose 5.68 points or 0.23% to 2,480.33, tracking firmer Chinese equities amid subdued data that raised hopes for policy support. China's weak October factory and retail sales data sparked hopes for more policy easing, while profit-booking pressure limited gains. The Korean won strengthened, and the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net sellers of shares worth 265.1 billion won, while tech giants Samsung and SK Hynix rose, while battery makers LG Energy Solution and Samsung SDI lost.

images.alt_text: epa10250048 An electronic signboard in the dealing room of Hana Bank in Seoul, South Korea, 18 October 2022, shows the benchmark Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) having advanced 30.24 points, or 1.36 percent, to close at 2,249.95. South Korean stocks ended sharply higher, as institutions and foreigners picked up issues ahead of corporate earnings of major companies this week.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT

site_title: Credit Suisse to sell bulk of Securitized Products Group to Apollo
summary: Credit Suisse has finalized the sale of its Securitized Products Group (SPG) to US buyout fund Apollo Global Management for an undisclosed price. The sale, expected to be completed by mid-2023, will reduce SPG assets to $20 billion from $75 billion. Apollo is expected to hire most SPG staff, and Credit Suisse will provide financing for a portion of the transferred assets. The deal is part of Credit Suisse's efforts to revamp and shift its focus towards high-net-worth clients.

site_title: G20 summit opens in Bali with a plea for unity as Ukraine war tops agenda
summary: The G20 summit in Bali kicked off with a focus on unity and addressing global concerns, including the ongoing Ukraine war. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy urged leaders to end the war "justly and on the basis of the UN Charter and international law." The G20 nations, which account for 80% of the world's GDP, 75% of international trade, and 60% of its population, gather to discuss global issues such as inflation, food, and energy security.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and his delegation (left) face ) China's President Xi Jinping and his team on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Monday (Nov 14).
President Joe Biden speaks at a news conference following his meeting with President Xi Jinping of China in Bali on Monday (Nov 14). The two leaders also discussed North Korea.

Even from the point of view of national security, “an economically interdependent world and an economically interdependent US and China is also in national security’s interest”, said Senior Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam (centre).
A load of corn is poured into a tractor with grain sleeves, temporary grain storage solution, in the village of Kozyn in Kyiv region, Ukraine Nov 9, 2022.

site_title: Property portal Mogul.sg raises S$9m Series A funding
summary: Mogul.sg, a Singapore property portal, has raised S$9 million in Series A funding led by Nech Capital. The platform has seen 20% growth in users since 2022 and plans to add features such as indoor mapping, navigation, and mortgage applications. The funds will also enhance data and improve user experience. Mogul.sg aims to add value to property transactions and expand its offerings to buyers, sellers, agents, and developers.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: UK property firm Landsec slips to half-year loss amid fall in valuations
summary: UK property firm Landsec reported a half-year loss due to falling property valuations amid surging interest rates and inflation. The company attributed the decline to reduced transaction volumes and pricing adjustments. Aggressive interest rate hikes are snuffing out a tentative recovery in the commercial property sector, which had shown signs of improvement from pandemic lows. The company cited a slowdown in global and UK property markets during the half-year period.

site_title: UK housing meltdown threatens £9.5b dividend bonanza
summary: The UK housing market is facing multiple headwinds, including rising borrowing costs, inflation, and a threatened recession, which are curtailing demand for new homes. As a result, the four largest UK homebuilders are under pressure to reassess their capital return policies, with Persimmon's announcement to review its policy potentially marking the end of a period of bumper payouts. This could impact UK income funds, which rely on dividend income, and may lead to lower payments from other homebuilders.

images.alt_text: The property-search website Rightmove said asking prices fell 1.1 per cent this month, after a 0.9 per cent gain in October.

site_title: DBS, OCBC, UOB raise fixed home loan rates to up to 4.5%: What home buyers need to know
summary: DBS, OCBC, and UOB have raised their fixed home loan rates to up to 4.5% in Singapore. UOB's two-year fixed-rate package is at 4.5% a year, while DBS offers packages at 4.25% a year with tenors of 2 to 5 years. Despite exceeding the 4% medium-term interest rate floor, borrowers are not overly concerned as the banks are using higher rates to calculate the maximum loan amount, ensuring monthly instalments meet the debt servicing ratio threshold. Homeowners can consider shorter-duration fixed-rate loans or hybrid packages for partial protection.

images.alt_text: Ling anticipates that the latest round of cooling measures may not have a large impact on the two companies overall, given the “strong supply pipeline” of new launches in 2023.

he Dubai Financial Services Authority (DFSA) said the fine on the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) branch of Bank of Singapore was reduced from US$2 million, as the bank had offered the regulator an “enforceable undertaking” to remediate the failings and agreed to settle the matter

site_title: EV battery makers race to develop cheaper cell materials, skirting China
summary: US and European startups are racing to develop cheaper battery materials, such as sodium and sulphur, to reduce China's battery dominance and alleviate supply bottlenecks. Western producers are struggling to keep up with Asian rivals, and carmakers expect supply shortages by the middle of the decade. New battery chemistries, like sodium ion and lithium sulphur, could be up to two-thirds cheaper than current lithium ion cells, but overcoming technical limitations is crucial. Over a dozen startups have attracted millions of dollars in investment to develop new batteries, with some aiming to supply major automakers by the end of the decade.

site_title: Moet Hennessy is running out of champagne as demand surges
summary: Moet Hennessy, a leading champagne brand, is facing a shortage of its top champagnes due to surging demand. According to CEO Philippe Schaus, some top champagnes are running out of stock, with the current period dubbed the "Roaring 20s" internally. However, replenishment is expected in the new year, alleviating concerns.

images.alt_text: Though LVMH posted stellar third-quarter results, risks are growing even for such luxury giants.
The Business Times rewarded its subscribers recently with a shochu masterclass.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades ComfortDelGro on lower margins
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded ComfortDelGro to "hold" from "add" with a lower target price of S$1.30 due to lower margins in Q3 FY2022, despite revenue and profit increases. Analysts attributed the downgrade to "inflationary pain" and higher costs offsetting ridership recovery gains. They expect cost pressures to continue narrowing margins in the second half of the year, with ComfortDelGro's recovery expected to come only in FY2023.

images.alt_text: ComfortDelGro head office located along Braddell Road on Nov 25, 2021.

site_title: ECB will probably keep raising rates beyond 2% level: Villeroy
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is likely to continue raising interest rates beyond 2% to combat inflation, according to French central bank Governor Francois Villeroy de Galhau. The ECB has already increased rates by 200 basis points in three months, reaching 1.5%, and aims to reach the "normalisation range" of around 2% by December. Villeroy stated that while rates will continue to rise, "jumbo" rate hikes will not become a new habit, indicating a more flexible approach to future rate adjustments.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei opens flat on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index opened flat on Tuesday at 27,960.62, down 0.01% or 2.85 points, following Wall Street's retreat after recent rallies fueled by hopes of easing interest-rate hikes. The broader Topix index was up 0.23% or 4.52 points at 1,961.42.

site_title: Climate change is longer-term threat to food and energy security: PM Lee
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for collective acceleration of net-zero ambitions to combat climate change, a long-term threat to food and energy security. At the G20 Summit in Bali, he shared Singapore's systematic approach to reaching net-zero by 2050 through measures such as carbon taxes and a National Hydrogen Strategy. Lee also stressed the importance of strengthening the multilateral trading system and scaling up sustainable financing to support decarbonization efforts.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Cambodia’s Prime Minister Hun Sen said in a Facebook post that he tested positive for Covid-19 on arrival in Indonesia for a G20 summit, but was not experiencing any symptoms.
A load of corn is poured into a tractor with grain sleeves, temporary grain storage solution, in the village of Kozyn in Kyiv region, Ukraine Nov 9, 2022.
The flags of G20 member nations are flown in Bali, the venue for this year's summit.

site_title: Gold hovers near 3-month high on hopes of smaller Fed hikes
summary: Gold prices hovered near a three-month high on Tuesday, reaching $1,770.70 per ounce, as US Federal Reserve officials signaled a potential slowdown in interest rate hikes. Fed vice chair Lael Brainard stated the central bank still had more work to do, but indicated a less aggressive approach. A stronger dollar kept gains in check, while speculators cut net short positions in gold.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: China injects enough cash in system to help snap bond slump
summary: China injected 850 billion yuan (S$165 billion) into its financial system via a medium-term lending facility at a 2.75% interest rate to halt the worst government bond selloff in six years. The move, combined with worse-than-expected economic data, capped the spike in the benchmark bond yield. The operation, described as liquidity neutral, aims to maintain ample cash levels and support financial institutions, helping to stabilize market sentiment.

images.alt_text: China's retail sales fell 0.5 per cent in October, the first fall since May when Shanghai was under a city-wide lockdown. Analysts had expected retail sales to rise 1.0 per cent, slowing from a 2.5 per cent gain in September.

site_title: Credit Suisse cuts senior bank jobs in Asia as overhaul begins
summary: Credit Suisse has started cutting senior bank jobs in Asia as part of its plan to reduce global headcount by 9,000. Three managing directors and several other bankers have been let go, including Johnson Chui, head of equity capital markets in Asia-Pacific, and Ee-lin Tan, head of ratings advisory. The bank aims to shave 2.5 billion francs off its cost base and has already cut 2,700 jobs in the fourth quarter. The moves come after dealmaking in China, one of its biggest growth markets, slumped and the bank posted mark-to-market losses in its financing group.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Swiss bank Credit Suisse is seen at an office building in Zurich, Switzerland September 2, 2022. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Estée Lauder nears Tom Ford acquisition, licencing deals
summary: Estée Lauder Cos is close to acquiring US luxury brand Tom Ford, with licensing agreements for eyewear and apparel businesses to other brands. The deal could value Tom Ford at about $2.8 billion, making it the largest ever for Estée Lauder. The company, which owns MAC lipstick and Clinique moisturizers, has a long-term licensing agreement with Tom Ford for beauty and fragrance products. Estée Lauder's market value fell 3.3% after the news, now at $79 billion.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians wearing masks walk past a Tom Ford International LLC retail store on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills, California, U.S., on Tuesday, May 19, 2020. Photographer: Patrick T. Fallon/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s factory output, retail sales miss forecasts, economy losing steam
summary: China's factory output grew 5.0% in October, missing expectations, while retail sales fell 0.5%, the first decline since May, due to protracted Covid-19 curbs and a property downturn. Industrial output, fixed asset investment, and new bank lending also slowed. Property investment fell 8.8% year-on-year in January-October, and hiring remained low. Analysts expect China's economy to miss its annual growth target of 5.5% and forecast a 3.2% growth in 2022. China's strict Covid-19 policy continues to weigh on economic activity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk along a main shopping area during the Alibaba's Singles' Day shopping festival in Shanghai, China November 11, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks edge up at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, extending their rally as investors focused on easing Covid restrictions in China. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.26%, or 46.09 points, to 17,665.80, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.07%. This comes as investors brushed off losses on Wall Street, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Freehold Ming Arcade put up for sale, asking for over S$140m
summary: Ming Arcade, a freehold commercial complex in Singapore, has been put up for sale by public tender with a price tag of over S$140 million. The site, completed in 1982, offers a plot ratio of 4.54 and can be redeveloped into a luxury hotel, retail, office, and residential space. The sale is expected to attract Asian ultra-high-net-worth buyers and family offices, given its prime location in the Orchard enclave. The public tender closes on December 15.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's share prices opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.76 points or 0.39% to 1458.24. Volume reached 157.96 million lots worth RM63.91 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 167 to 112.

site_title: Brokers’ take: RHB upgrades Golden Agri to ‘buy’ on lower tax rates
summary: RHB upgraded its call on Golden Agri-Resources to "buy" from "neutral" due to strong earnings growth, driven by a two-month tax levy holiday and increased fresh fruit bunches sales. The research house raised its earnings estimates to US$836 million and target price to S$0.33. Analysts described the company's valuation as "attractive" and "inexpensive," trading at a lower price-to-equity multiple compared to peers. However, Golden Agri will face reinstated taxes and potential losses, which could impact Q4 earnings.

images.alt_text: palm oil, oil, palm

site_title: Fake Twitter account spurs unexpected scrutiny of insulin prices
summary: A fake Twitter account impersonating Eli Lilly sparked a backlash against the pharmaceutical company, drawing attention to high insulin prices in the US. The parody account, which claimed insulin was being made available for free, was shut down after the company issued an apology, but not before triggering a wave of scrutiny and calls for reform. Advocacy groups and lawmakers are now demanding action to stop "insulin price-gouging," citing a study that shows insulin costs eight times more in the US than in 32 comparable countries.

images.alt_text: The billionaire recently cut half of Twitter’s staff and introduced dramatic changes to its subscription rules.
“To combat impersonation, we’ve added an ‘Official’ label to some accounts,” Twitter’s support account – which has the “official” tag – tweeted on Friday.
An information security team at Twitter that oversees sharing of user data with advertisers and research partners was laid off after the takeover.

site_title: Nestle still bullish on plant protein despite dip in demand
summary: Nestle remains bullish on plant protein, despite a recent dip in demand due to inflation. The company's chief technology officer, Stefan Palzer, notes that the initial hype surrounding plant protein consumption was similar to the craft beer market, where demand initially dropped but eventually grew back. Palzer expects a more sustainable growth trajectory for plant protein, with the segment potentially accounting for 30-40% of the global protein market. This growth is expected to be driven by a more realistic understanding of consumer preferences.

images.alt_text: Nestle, which has already pledged to source all its coffee sustainably by 2025, said it is now also aiming, by that date, for 20 per cent of its coffee to be grown using ‘regenerative’ agricultural practices.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.3% to 3,270.99, driven by a mix of local and global market trends. Gainers included Golden Agri-Resources, Singtel, and Thai Beverage, while ComfortDelGro and UOB fell. The US market ended lower on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6%, amid concerns over interest rate hikes and policymaker comments.

images.alt_text: Despite acquiring new orders and completing key projects, Sembcorp Marine says that earnings will not offset “residual” Covid-19-related costs such as higher labour expenses.

site_title: Cambodian PM Hun Sen says positive for Covid-19 after hosting Asean summit
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen announced he tested positive for Covid-19 upon arrival in Indonesia for a G20 summit, despite not experiencing symptoms. He hosted multiple world leaders, including US President Joe Biden, before testing positive. Hun Sen will return home and miss meetings with Chinese President Xi Jinping and French President Emmanuel Macron at the Apec summit due to safety reasons. He expressed relief that he arrived late and missed a dinner with other leaders, calling it a "lucky" circumstance.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong (left) was welcomed by Indonesian President Joko Widodo at the start of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua, Bali on Nov 15, 2022.
The agreement benefits more Singapore-based companies through more facilitative rules in trade in goods, among others.

site_title: Sea e-commerce arm Shopee cuts jobs in third round of layoffs this year, including in Singapore
summary: E-commerce giant Shopee has cut jobs in its third round of layoffs this year, affecting teams in human resources and learning and development in Singapore. This is part of Shopee's parent company Sea Limited's efforts to achieve profitability. The layoffs come after previous rounds in September and earlier this year, following poor macroeconomic conditions. The exact number of affected employees is unclear, with some reports suggesting it could be significant.

site_title: Australia: Miners, energy stocks drag shares lower as investors assess Fed comments
summary: Australian shares fell 0.1% to 7,136.60, weighed down by miners and energy stocks, despite solid gains in banking and healthcare. Investors assessed US Federal Reserve comments on interest rate hikes, which hinted at slowing down, improving global risk sentiment. The G20 summit between Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Chinese President Xi Jinping is also on investors' radar.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.3 per cent to 7,181 by 2313 GMT, their highest level since June 7.

site_title: Japan’s economy unexpectedly shrinks as hot inflation, global slowdown take toll
summary: Japan's economy unexpectedly contracted at an annualized rate of 1.2% in the third quarter, driven by hot inflation, a global slowdown, and a weak yen. This is the first contraction since the second quarter. Despite this, demand remains positive, with consumption, capital expenditure, and exports growing. The global economy teeters on the brink of recession, posing risks to Japan's outlook. Policymakers and citizens are bracing for a potential eighth wave of the Covid-19 pandemic, adding to the economic gloom.

images.alt_text: The global chip shortage has prompted calls for the Japanese government and businesses to secure semiconductor supplies for the country's economic security, as geopolitics become increasingly volatile.

Wage inflation, which has long lagged policymakers expectations, is set to again take centre stage during pay talks next spring and should determine how successful Japan would be in spurring a virtuous cycle of demand-led economic and price growth.

site_title: Buffett bets US$5b on chipmaking with new stake in TSMC
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has invested approximately $5 billion in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSMC), a leading chipmaker. The investment, made in the third quarter, includes a 60 million American depository receipt (ADR) stake. TSMC produces semiconductors for clients like Nvidia and Qualcomm, and is the exclusive supplier of Apple's custom Silicon chips. The move marks a shift in Buffett's investment strategy towards the tech industry, which is expected to experience sustained growth in the coming years.

images.alt_text: TSMC posted on Thursday an 80 per cent on-year surge in profit for the July-September period of 2022, the strongest growth in two years.

site_title: Fed vice chair says ‘appropriate soon’ to slow rate hike
summary: Federal Reserve Vice Chair Lael Brainard said it's likely "appropriate soon" for the US central bank to slow the pace of interest rate increases, amid signs of easing inflation. Despite fears of a recession, the Fed has raised the benchmark lending rate six times this year to lower demand and bring inflation closer to its 2% target. Brainard acknowledged the rapid rate hikes and called for a more deliberate approach, allowing for better data assessment and adjustment of interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The U.S. Federal Reserve building is pictured in Washington, March 18, 2008. REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

site_title: Three out of four bitcoin investors have lost money: study
summary: A study by the Bank of International Settlements found that roughly three-quarters of bitcoin investors have lost money, based on data from 95 countries between 2015 and 2022. The price of bitcoin rose from $250 to nearly $69,000, but it is now trading at around $16,500. The study also found that retail investors were more likely to buy in during price increases, while larger holders sold, making a return at the expense of smaller investors. The majority of new investors were young men under 35, seen as risk-seekers.

site_title: Russia faces blame as G20 tackles Ukraine war, soaring food prices
summary: The G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia, will focus on the global economic impact of the Russia-Ukraine war, with leaders blaming Vladimir Putin for soaring food and fuel prices. US and allies will pressure Russia to end the war, while China, a key ally of Russia, has expressed opposition to nuclear threats. Ukraine's leader, Volodymyr Zelensky, will address G20 leaders via video message, and a deal allowing Ukraine to export grain through the Black Sea is set to expire. Despite Putin's absence, French President Emmanuel Macron will try to extend an olive branch, and US allies hope for a joint statement on finding a way forward.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden and his delegation (left) face ) China's President Xi Jinping and his team on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua on the Indonesian resort island of Bali on Monday (Nov 14).
President Joe Biden speaks at a news conference following his meeting with President Xi Jinping of China in Bali on Monday (Nov 14). The two leaders also discussed North Korea.

A Boeing 737 Max aircraft during a display at the Farnborough International Airshow in Farnborough, Britain in July. China used to take a quarter of these cash-cow jets that the US plane-maker built each year, until a pair of fatal crashes, the global pandemic and soured US-China ties came along.

site_title: Corporate America cuts thousands of jobs as recession looms
summary: Corporate America is cutting thousands of jobs as the US economy prepares for a potential recession. Major companies such as Amazon, Meta, Citigroup, and Microsoft are laying off employees in various departments. The job cuts total 33,843, the highest since February 2021, according to a report. The layoffs are part of companies' restructuring efforts to navigate inflation and a weak advertising market.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest online retailer has spent much of this year adjusting to a sharp slowdown in e-commerce growth as shoppers resumed pre-pandemic habits.

Meta Platforms Inc. signage during the virtual Meta Connect event in New York, US, on Tuesday, Oct. 11, 2022. Mark Zuckerberg unveiled his company's newest virtual-reality headset, the Meta Quest Pro, the latest foray into the world of high-end VR devices that Meta Platforms hopes will entice creators and working professionals to adopt its vision for a virtual future. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Stocks slide, closing lower after last week’s rally
summary: US stocks closed lower on Monday, falling 0.6% to 33,536.70 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, 0.9% to 3,957.25 on the S&P 500, and 1.1% to 11,196.22 on the Nasdaq Composite Index. Despite last week's rally fueled by hopes of easing interest rate hikes, fresh comments from Fed Vice Chair Lael Brainard failed to reassure markets, citing still-high inflation and additional work to be done. Investors await earnings reports from major retailers, including Walmart, Target, and Home Depot.

site_title: Embracing data sharing will be key to the success of Healthier SG
summary: Singapore's Healthier SG initiative aims to reform the country's healthcare system by shifting towards preventive care and empowering individuals to take charge of their health. However, concerns around data privacy and security, as well as a lack of knowledge on how to interpret and share data, are major barriers to its success. To overcome these challenges, education and training for patients and healthcare professionals are crucial, as well as a unified operational framework that democratises data and builds public trust.

images.alt_text: thermometer, medications, tablets

site_title: Amazon plans largest-ever layoffs, targeting devices, retail, HR
summary: Amazon plans to cut approximately 10,000 jobs, its largest-ever headcount reduction, as it braces for slower growth and a possible recession. The layoffs will target the devices group, retail divisions, and human resources, according to people familiar with the matter. CEO Andy Jassy has vowed to streamline operations, citing slowing sales growth and economic uncertainty, and has been implementing cost-cutting measures in recent months. The move comes as Amazon faces a sharp slowdown in e-commerce growth and shoppers resume pre-pandemic habits.

images.alt_text: The robotic arm, tipped by a set of retractable suction devices, is called Sparrow.
Amazon's drone delivery programme is hit by crashes and safety concerns

site_title: Apple offers rare MacBook deal to businesses to spur holiday quarter sales
summary: Apple is offering a rare 10% discount on its 14-inch and 16-inch MacBook Pros with M1-based chips to small businesses that buy in bulk, aiming to boost holiday quarter sales. The deal, which runs through December 24, is a significant markdown for small and midsize businesses, typically receiving 8% to 10% off. The move is unusual for Apple, which is trying to clear out inventory before new MacBook models with M2 Pro and M2 Max chips are released in 2023.

images.alt_text: Foxconn plans to boost the workforce at its Tamil Nadu plant in southern India to 70,000, by adding 53,000 more workers over the next two years.

site_title: RBA prepared to pause or return to outsized hikes, minutes show
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is prepared to adjust its interest-rate hike cycle, potentially pausing or increasing rates further, if the economy requires it. In recent months, the RBA has raised rates by 2.75 percentage points in seven months to combat the fastest inflation in over three decades, peaking at 8% late this year. The central bank aims to return inflation to its 2-3% target, with Governor Philip Lowe expected to continue with smaller increments to maintain flexibility in the tightening cycle.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker pushing a trolley walks with pedestrians past the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) head office in central Sydney, Australia, March 7, 2017. Picture taken March 7, 2017.   REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: Apple-Epic app store legal battle worries US antitrust enforcers
summary: The US Justice Department is defending Apple's App Store business model against Epic Games' claim that it is anticompetitive. The DOJ argues that a lower-court judge's ruling last year was flawed, potentially weakening its hand in future enforcement actions against big tech companies. The case, which began in 2020, centers on Apple's 30% fee on in-app purchases. The DOJ will present its concerns at a hearing on Monday, which may impact its investigations into Apple's and Google's business practices.

site_title: Bezos to give away most of US$124b wealth during lifetime
summary: Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder, announced plans to give away most of his $124 billion wealth during his lifetime. He and his partner Lauren Sanchez are building the capacity to donate the majority of his wealth, with a focus on climate change and nature protection through the Bezos Earth Fund. Bezos has already committed $10 billion to the fund and has given away $100 million through the "Bezos Courage & Civility Award" to philanthropist Dolly Parton.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembmarine, Golden Agri, ComfortDelGro, Bumitama, Silverlake Axis
summary: Sembcorp Marine, Golden Agri-Resources, ComfortDelGro, Bumitama Agri, and Silverlake Axis reported financial updates, with Sembcorp Marine citing Covid-19-related costs affecting earnings, and Golden Agri Resources and Bumitama Agri experiencing significant revenue increases. ComfortDelGro posted a 32.9% profit increase, while Silverlake Axis saw a 64% profit boost. Shares of Sembmarine and ComfortDelGro closed lower, while Bumitama Agri rose 2.5%, and Silverlake Axis remained flat.

images.alt_text: Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger

site_title: ADDX raises US$20m in funding round led by S Korea’s KB Securities
summary: Private market exchange ADDX has raised US$20 million in a funding round led by KB Securities, a subsidiary of South Korea's KB Financial Group. The company, which has raised a total of US$140 million in funding, plans to use the capital to grow its wealth management platform and expand globally. ADDX's CEO, Choo Oi Yee, notes that the funding demonstrates the momentum behind the company and its mission to give individual investors greater access to private market deals.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Choo Oi Yee, CEO of private market platform ADDX.
Choo Oi Yee, chief executive of ADDX, said blockchain allows assets to be liquid for both public and private markets.

site_title: HSBC’s Ranojoy Dutta wants to give customers a ‘bank in their pockets’
summary: HSBC's Ranojoy Dutta, head of retail products and journeys, aims to provide a 'bank in their pockets' for customers relocating. Dutta, who has worked in four countries over 28 years, oversees the banking experience for expats. In his role, he helps customers navigate the banking system during relocation. Dutta joined HSBC in 2019 from HSBC Hong Kong, where he was head of regional growth. His goal is to simplify the banking experience for customers worldwide.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
Donald MacDonald was appointed group data office head in June 2022 – a new role created to drive the bank’s data strategy.
Kevin Lam, head of TMRW and group digital banking at UOB, believes that having an open mind and being ready for new ideas is key in the ever-changing banking industry.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 ekes out gains in a start to data-heavy week; Roche slides
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Monday, near 11-week highs, driven by positive updates from companies like Infineon and Informa. The pan-European STOXX 600 index hovered near its highs, despite a 4% drop in Roche Holding AG after its Alzheimer's drug candidate failed to show significant results. Investors await data on inflation and GDP, and expressed caution after Federal Reserve policymaker Christopher Waller warned against a pivot in monetary policy.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index gained 0.3 per cent to 7,341.83 points.

site_title: Adidas seeks cash from rare bond deal after Yeezy split
summary: Adidas is seeking €1 billion (S$1.4 billion) from its debt sale, marking its first public debt sale in Europe since 2020. The move comes after the company dropped its lucrative Yeezy partnership and slashed profit expectations for the fourth time. The partnership's end is expected to leave a €1.8 billion hole in Adidas' income, with nearly half of its profits coming from the brand. The debt sale is seen as a bid to revive the company's fortunes, with newly appointed CEO Bjorn Gulden set to take over in January.

images.alt_text: now expects currency-neutral revenue for the year to grow at a low-single-digit rate, down from a previous target of mid-single-digits. It also trimmed its forecast for this year’s operating margin to 2.5 per cent, from 4 per cent.

A pair of Adidas Yeezy shoes seen in a store on the day Adidas terminated its partnership with the American rapper and designer Kanye West, now known as Ye, in Garden City, New York, US, October 25, 2022.

site_title: Sembmarine paints less rosy picture in H2, cites higher labour cost, slower improvement in repairs and upgrades
summary: SembCorp Marine, a leading offshore and marine giant, has revised its second-half guidance downward due to higher labor costs, slower-than-expected improvements in repairs and upgrades, and delays in securing projects. The company expects similar losses in the second half of FY22 as the first half, with overall business volumes expected to pick up in FY23 after its planned merger with Keppel Corp's O&M unit. Despite this, Sembmarine remains optimistic about its green solutions sector, with 34% of its net order book allocated to renewable energy projects.

REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo             GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD      SEARCH GLOBAL BUSINESS 30 OCT FOR ALL IMAGES

site_title: Nike to open its own virtual sneaker store and trading platform
summary: Nike is launching its own virtual sneaker store and trading platform on the .Swoosh platform, allowing users to collect and showcase digital products. The platform will include tie-ins, unlock physical items, and provide access to events. Registration opens November 18, with a six-city tour to educate shoppers on web3 and blockchain technology. Nike has invested heavily in the metaverse, earning nearly $200 million from NFT products, and will offer a safe environment for members to engage with virtual goods. The platform will feature storefronts from athletes and allow individual creators to co-create products with Nike.

site_title: Google to pay US$391 million over ‘crafty’ location tracking
summary: Google has agreed to pay US$391.5 million to 40 US states to resolve a probe into its location-tracking practices, which were found to be "crafty and deceptive". The company had secretly recorded users' movements and provided the data to advertisers, even after users believed they had turned off location-tracking. As part of the deal, Google will "significantly improve" its location-tracking disclosures and user controls starting next year.

images.alt_text: Genoa launches at a time when rival Intel’s latest data centre chip, code named Sapphire Rapids, has struggled with delays.
“We want to make the car an intelligent object that learns, and one that can be upgraded over the air like a mobile phone,” Renault chief executive officer Luca de Meo said in an interview.
MAS, KPMG and Google Cloud will shortlist up to 15 finalists by January 2023 for the six-week climate finance accelerator, which is now open to climate fintech firms and startups.

site_title: Morgan Stanley sees rough ride for US stocks in 2023
summary: Morgan Stanley strategist Michael Wilson predicts US stocks will end 2023 almost unchanged from their current level, with a "volatile path" to the 3,900 S&P 500 base-case target. Wilson expects a short-term rebound after good inflation data, followed by a decline as earnings estimates come down, before rebounding in the second half of the year. He warns of uncertainty and potential "twists and days/weeks of remorse" for investors.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.6 per cent to close at 33,536.70 on Monday.

site_title: Opec cuts oil demand growth forecast again as economic challenges mount
summary: OPEC has cut its forecast for 2022 global oil demand growth for a fifth time since April, citing mounting economic challenges. Oil demand in 2022 is expected to increase by 2.55 million barrels per day (2.6% growth), down 100,000 barrels per day from the previous forecast. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) attributed the downgrade to high inflation and rising interest rates, indicating a period of significant uncertainty in the fourth quarter of 2022.

site_title: As Vietnam’s coffee exports surge, supply issues remain the biggest threat
summary: Vietnam's coffee exports have surged, with over 1.1 million tonnes shipped overseas in the first seven months of 2022, a 17.2% increase from last year, valued at US$2.56 billion. Despite this growth, supply issues remain a major threat, including a lack of modern infrastructure, unsustainable farming techniques, and climate change. The industry's reliance on robusta coffee, which accounts for 95% of exports, is driving growth but may present difficulties in meeting demand by 2023. Vietnam's Ministry of Industry and Trade aims to double coffee exports to US$6 billion by 2030, but the country must address its persisting shortcomings to maintain its current record growth.

images.alt_text: The exterior of Trung Nguyen Legend Group's first store in China, located in Shanghai. The store opened in September 2022.
South-east Asia's favourable climate and fertile soil make it a major crop grower. The region is home to key producers of  palm oil, rice and dried beans.

site_title: FTX collapse blows a hole in crypto’s decentralised promise
summary: FTX's collapse has exposed the decentralized promise of cryptocurrencies as a facade, highlighting the need for stricter regulatory standards. The exchange's collapse was triggered by revelations of poor governance, including a lack of hedging policies, overleveraging, and conflicts of interest. Investors, including big-name backers, were caught off guard, and the exchange's founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, was found to have built his confidence on fragile foundations. The incident serves as a reminder that the crypto industry must adapt to higher regulatory standards to achieve mainstream relevance.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower after hawkish Fed comments
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday after a hawkish US Federal Reserve official tempered hopes of toning down its aggressive monetary policy approach. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 85.8 points, or 0.25%, to 33662.05, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. The comments added to market uncertainty, despite recent record highs.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., November 11, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: Nordic Group bags contracts totalling S$76.5 million
summary: Nordic Group has secured S$76.5 million in new contracts from Singapore, Malaysia, and China. The contracts, won by various divisions, include capital, maintenance, and ad-hoc projects for companies in the marine, offshore oil and gas, petrochemical, semiconductor, and infrastructure industries. The new wins are expected to boost Nordic's order book, now at S$232.7 million, and are not expected to significantly impact the company's earnings per share. Shares rose 2.2% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Chang Yeh Hong, executive chairman of Nordic Group

site_title: Net zero is in fashion, but clothing giants struggle to cut emissions
summary: Fashion giants, including H&M, Zara, and Nike, have pledged to cut emissions by half by 2030 and reach net zero by mid-century, but meeting this goal remains a challenge due to complex supply chains and high energy consumption in manufacturing. Industry insiders admit that greening the entire supply chain and introducing climate-friendly standards is a monumental task, with certification bodies lacking in some regions. The fashion sector, responsible for 4% of global emissions in 2018, is under pressure to slow down the wasteful trend of fast fashion, which uses massive amounts of water and produces hazardous chemicals.

images.alt_text: Shein taps on technology across its operations, giving it cost savings and lower overheads said Leonard Lin, country general manager, Singapore, Shein.
With online operations in about 200 countries, Zara’s products are already among the most resold brands on the web.
Circular fashion is apparel that is designed, sourced and produced with the intention of being used and circulated responsibly and effectively in society for as long as possible.

A shopper at the Shein pop-up store in New York Oct 28, 2022. The breakneck supply chain pioneered by Shein is allowing a new swathe of brands to make the most of operating in the colossal retailer’s slipstream.

site_title: Asian Pay TV Trust posts Q3 DPU of 0.25 Singapore cent; profit after income tax almost triples
summary: Asian Pay Television Trust (APTT) has posted a Q3 distribution per unit (DPU) of 0.25 Singapore cent, unchanged from the previous year, and a profit after income tax of S$13.5 million, almost tripling from the previous year. Revenue dropped 5.7% to S$71.2 million, but the broadband segment rose 11.1% to S$16.4 million. APTT has reaffirmed a distribution guidance of 0.25 Singapore cent per unit for the fourth quarter and expects a 5% increase in distribution for 2023.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Ant’s consumer finance unit to more than double capital to 18.5 billion yuan
summary: China's Ant Group is increasing the registered capital of its consumer finance unit, Chongqing Ant Consumer Finance, to 18.5 billion yuan, from 8 billion yuan. Ant will invest 5.25 billion yuan to retain its 50% stake, while new investors Hangzhou Jintou Digital Technology Group and Transfar Zhilian will also join, bringing in 1.85 billion yuan and 1 billion yuan, respectively. The move aims to address regulatory pressure and revamp the unit, which has been under scrutiny since its US$37 billion attempt at a dual listing was derailed in 2020.

site_title: Binance pledges redress fund amid FTX fallout
summary: Binance has pledged to establish a liquidity fund to mitigate the sector's fallout from FTX's bankruptcy filing. The move comes after Binance scrapped a takeover bid, sending shockwaves through the cryptocurrency world. Bitcoin's value rose 2.5% to $16,773 in response. FTX's collapse has led to a 20% decline in bitcoin's value since November 6, when FTX's troubles began to weigh on markets. The liquidity fund aims to help projects in a liquidity crisis, and further details will be released soon.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Binance and FTX logos are seen in this illustration taken, November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Dasin Retail Trust 9M revenue falls 7.8% on China Covid-19 curbs, higher rental rebates
summary: Dasin Retail Trust reported a 7.8% drop in revenue to S$70.7 million for the 9 months ended September 2022, primarily due to China's Covid-19-related restrictions and higher rental rebates. Net property income slipped 8.3% to S$55.2 million. The trustee-manager attributes the decline to "stifling spending in China's consumer market" and weak consumer sentiments. Dasin Retail Trust is working towards refinancing exercises, including asset disposal and strategic investments, to mitigate its gearing ratio of 40.4%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Funan The IT Mall was one of the three properties in the IPO portfolio of Singapore's first Reit, CapitaLand Mall Trust (now known as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust) in 2002.

site_title: US dollar surges as traders say markets overreacted to US inflation data
summary: The US dollar surged 0.4% to 107.14 against a basket of six major currencies, rebounding from multi-month lows, as traders reassessed expectations of a less aggressive Federal Reserve interest rate hike following modest US inflation data. Market overreaction to the data led to a decline in the euro and sterling, with the euro falling 0.6% against the US dollar. The US dollar's gain was attributed to senior Fed officials downplaying the inflation print, while ECB officials emphasized the need to keep raising rates without overtightening.

site_title: Trump set to officially launch 2024 comeback bid
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is set to officially launch his 2024 presidential comeback bid on Tuesday, despite the Republican party's calls to fade away after the party's underperformance in the 2022 mid-term elections. Trump's announcement comes after a year of speculation, with his advisors predicting a "very professional, very buttoned up" speech. A 2024 White House bid would be Trump's third presidential campaign, and he is expected to face investigations into his conduct before, during, and after his presidency, which could result in his disqualification.

site_title: Old Chang Kee H1 net profit falls 22% to S$2.6 million despite higher revenue
summary: Old Chang Kee, a Singapore-based curry puff maker, reported a 22% drop in net profit to S$2.6 million for the six months ended September, down from S$3.4 million in the previous year. Despite a 13.3% increase in revenue to S$43.7 million, mainly due to higher sales amid the reopening of Singapore's economy, the company attributed the decline to the absence of Job Support Scheme grants. The company also closed 9 outlets due to infrastructural developments and will continue to reduce costs and improve operations to overcome manpower shortages.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
An Old Chang Kee outlet

site_title: Media entertainment company NoonTalk to raise over S$4.8m in SGX IPO
summary: Media entertainment company NoonTalk plans to raise over S$4.8 million in an initial public offering on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). Led by executive director and CEO Dasmond Koh, NoonTalk is offering 22 million shares at S$0.22 each, comprising 17.5 million placement shares and 4.5 million public offer shares.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
NoonTalk is proposing to raise funds for regional expansion in film and drama production, and investment in multimedia technology.

site_title: Oil settles US$3 lower on China’s Covid-19 surge and firmer dollar
summary: Oil prices settled US$3 lower on Monday, with Brent crude futures falling 3% to US$93.14 a barrel, due to a firmer US dollar and rising coronavirus cases in China. Despite China's initial easing of Covid-19 measures, the surge in cases and lockdowns derailed hopes of a swift economic reopening. The US dollar also rose, making dollar-denominated commodities more expensive and weighing on oil prices. OPEC cut its forecast for global oil demand growth, citing economic headwinds, while US domestic supply continues to rise.

site_title: Microsoft’s Xbox publishes first transparency report on content moderation
summary: Xbox has released its first transparency report on content moderation, detailing how the gaming giant moderates its 3 billion global players. In the first six months of 2022, Xbox took action on 1 million accounts for profanity, 814,000 for adult sexual content, and 759,000 for harassment or bullying. The company increased its proactive moderation nine times compared to the same period last year, with 65% of actions taken through artificial intelligence or human moderators. Xbox joins other gaming providers, such as Twitch and Discord, in releasing transparency reports to crack down on toxicity and abuse.

images.alt_text: A Microsoft Xbox One video game controller. Photographer: Michael Ciaglo/Bloomberg

site_title: Singtel, StarHub lack clear enterprise strategy to drive longer-term performance
summary: Singapore's two major telecommunications companies, Singtel and StarHub, face challenges in driving long-term performance due to stiff competition in consumer services. Despite profitable consumer operations, margins have been shrinking, and returns are expected to come from the enterprise segment. Both companies have invested heavily in 5G networks and other enterprise-grade technologies, but lack clear strategies to monetize them at scale, casting doubt on their ability to boost shares.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan

China will temporarily suspend additional 25 per cent tariffs on US-made vehicles and auto parts starting Jan 1, 2019, the finance ministry said on Friday, following a truce in a trade war between the world's two largest economies.

site_title: Sri Lanka announces budget aimed at clinching IMF deal, expects recovery by end-2023
summary: Sri Lanka's government has announced a budget aimed at clinching an International Monetary Fund (IMF) deal, with plans to reduce debt to less than 100% of gross domestic product (GDP) and achieve 7% economic growth by the end of 2023. The budget includes measures to reduce the government's deficit and persuade the IMF to provide a bailout package. President Ranil Wickremesinghe also aims to increase public revenue to 15% of GDP by 2025 and achieve US$3 billion in exports and foreign direct investment over the medium term.

images.alt_text: “Food insecurity in Sri Lanka has increased dramatically due to two consecutive seasons of poor harvests, foreign exchange shortages, and reduced household purchasing power,” the UN statement said.
Sri Lanka defaulted on its foreign debt for the first time in May. Japan, India and China are Sri Lanka’s largest bilateral creditors.

site_title: UK pledges £1b to fight Aids, tuberculosis and malaria
summary: The UK government has pledged £1 billion (S$1.6 billion) to the Global Fund to combat Aids, tuberculosis, and malaria, exceeding its initial six-week delay in making a commitment. This move comes after other world leaders committed $14.3 billion at the UN General Assembly in September. The pledge was welcomed by Andrew Mitchell, Britain's minister for development, who said it gives hope and opportunity to millions suffering from these diseases.

site_title: ‘Like-minded’ Singapore and Germany must work together to tackle challenges in Asia, Europe: PM Lee
summary: Singapore and Germany have endorsed a joint declaration, "Partners for a Resilient and Sustainable Future", outlining further bilateral cooperation on climate change, defence, and the economy.
