The declaration aims to strengthen partnerships and reduce dependencies between the two countries, particularly in the Indo-Pacific region. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz discussed regional and international issues, including the Russia-Ukraine war and the risk of polarisation in the region. The joint declaration supports ongoing negotiations for the EU-Singapore Digital Partnership and cooperation in areas such as renewable energy, research, and innovation.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Although the US-China relationship is the most consequential, other countries also have agency and can collectively shape developments in the region and the world, said DPM Wong at APK 2022.

site_title: Singapore stocks extend recent gains amid mixed regional showing; STI up 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1% to 3,260.80, driven by gains in the property sector. Investors focused on China's relaxed COVID-19 curbs and state support for the Chinese property market. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and South Korea's Kospi declining. Local stocks such as Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust and UOB Bank rose, while DFI Retail Group fell.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
The initiatives in the rescue package range from addressing the liquidity crisis faced by developers to a “temporary” easing of a signature restriction on bank lending.

site_title: Boeing hopes Biden-Xi Talks lead to a China reopening
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping held a three-hour meeting in Bali, Indonesia, calling for a cooling of tensions and pledging to continue talks on various issues. The meeting includes a commitment from Biden to send US Secretary of State Antony Blinken to China for a visit, and a promise to address China's economic practices. Boeing hopes that the improved relations will lead to increased aircraft sales, particularly for the 737 Max, which has been grounded in China since 2018 due to fatal crashes. The company projects Chinese airlines will require 8,485 new planes over the next two decades, worth $1.5 trillion.

images.alt_text: Comac’s C919, the recently certified homegrown rival to the popular Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX narrowbody families, was in the show’s flying display for the first time on Tuesday.
Airbus booked 177 sales in October after securing only 13 in September.
Boeing is concerned about Indonesia's ability to finance the jets, with Jakarta insisting on paying in installments.

site_title: Indonesia to set up US$2b EV fund with China’s CATL, CMB International
summary: The Indonesia Investment Authority (INA) is setting up a US$2 billion green electric vehicle (EV) fund with China's battery maker CATL and CMB International. The fund aims to invest in the EV value chain in Indonesia, where the market is expected to grow rapidly. Indonesia's own EV market is projected to reach 2.1 million electric motorcycles and 400,000 electric cars by 2025, driven by the country's pledge to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The partnership aims to capture this opportunity and develop Indonesia's own EV and battery industries.

site_title: Philippines lower house approves bill taxing single-use plastics
summary: The Philippines' lower house of Congress approved a bill taxing single-use plastics, aiming to raise 9.3 billion pesos annually to fund solid waste management projects. The tax measure, requiring Senate approval, targets firms for every kilogram of single-use plastics produced or imported, with a tax of 100 pesos (S$2.41) increasing by 4% annually. The move aims to reduce plastic usage and protect the environment, as the Philippines contributes a third of global ocean plastic pollution.

site_title: Aztech Global unit to acquire manufacturing facility in Malaysia for RM66.8m
summary: Aztech Global's wholly-owned Malaysian subsidiary, IOT Manufacturing, has acquired a 300,000 square feet manufacturing facility in Johor for RM66.8 million (S$20 million). The acquisition expands the group's manufacturing capacity for IoT devices and data-communication products in Malaysia, aiming to meet demand from existing and potential new customers. Operations are expected to commence in the second quarter of 2023, funded by IPO proceeds and bank borrowings.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Michael Mun, chairman and CEO of Aztech Global (right) says the group will continue to stay vigilant and nimble to manage the myriad of headwinds ahead.

site_title: World leaders gather in Bali for fraught G20 summit overshadowed by Ukraine war
summary: World leaders gathered in Bali for the G20 summit, overshadowed by the ongoing Russia-led war in Ukraine and looming economic recession. The summit, led by Indonesia, focused on climate change, food security, and rising tensions in the Taiwan Strait and South China Sea. Russian President Vladimir Putin sent his foreign minister Sergei Lavrov in his place, and Ukraine attended as an observer, with President Volodymyr Zelenskiy expected to address leaders virtually. A joint communique was uncertain due to divisions over Ukraine, with Indonesia likely to issue a chair's statement instead.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has put the blame on the US and its allies for the lack of communique at the 18-nation East Asian Summit, saying on Sunday (Nov 13) they “insisted on absolutely unacceptable language regarding the situation in Ukraine”.

site_title: Golden Agri’s Q3 earnings more than double to US$285m on higher palm oil prices
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 148% increase in Q3 earnings to US$285 million, driven by higher palm oil prices rising 23% in the 9-month period. This brought 9-month earnings up 151% year-over-year to US$675 million, with underlying profit growing 88% to US$726 million.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
CPO futures contracts on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives market are up 6.6 per cent since the beginning of the year. But since late April, the commodity is down about 33.3 per cent.

site_title: What’s behind China’s falling corporate bond yields
summary: China's corporate bond yields have fallen, contradicting expectations, due to the country's struggling property market and weak fiscal revenues. Local government funding vehicles (LGFVs) are affected, with some bonds trending lower in yield despite China's overall corporate bond market being at historically tight levels. This is attributed to the significant liquidity in China's interbank system and the People's Bank of China's easy monetary policy. Foreign investors are turning to the offshore LGFV bond market, which offers higher yields, but require local knowledge and credit differentiation to access.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Surveillance cameras are seen near residential buildings under construction in Shanghai, China July 20, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Roche’s Alzheimer’s drug fails to meet goal in long awaited trial
summary: Roche's Alzheimer's drug candidate, gantenerumab, failed to meet its main goal in two long-awaited trials, showing a 6-8% relative reduction in clinical decline compared to a placebo. The drug was designed to remove brain amyloid plaques, but results were not statistically reliable. The failure is a setback for Roche and a boost for rivals Biogen and Eisai, who are developing rival treatments. Roche shares fell 4.4%, while Biogen and Eli Lilly shares rose 3.8% and 2.3%, respectively.

site_title: UK home sellers slash asking prices after mortgage rates jump
summary: UK home sellers have reduced asking prices by 1.1% this month, the largest decline since August, amid a surge in mortgage costs and a looming recession. This follows a 0.9% gain in October. The slowdown is attributed to rising borrowing costs, with the average spend for first-time buyers increasing to £1,300 per month. Demand plummeted by 26% compared to the previous year, and 8% of unsold properties saw price reductions in October. The exceptional price growth of the last two years is unsustainable against economic headwinds and growing affordability constraints.

images.alt_text: The survey showed enquiries from new buyers fell for the sixth month running and buyer demand was negative across the country for the second month in a row.
The UK housing market is hit by surging inflation and high interest rates.

site_title: Silicon Valley chip startup Cerebras unveils AI supercomputer
summary: Silicon Valley startup Cerebras unveiled its AI supercomputer, Andromeda, capable of performing 1 exaflop of AI computing, or one quintillion operations per second, with a precision of 16-bit floating point format. Built by linking 16 Cerebras CS-2 systems, Andromeda is available for commercial and academic research and is designed to compete with high-performance computing systems like the Frontier at Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Cerebras CEO Andrew Feldman stated that Andromeda is a more affordable option, costing around $35 million compared to the $600 million Frontier system.

site_title: Phrygian caps to be Paris 2024 Olympic Games mascots
summary: The Paris 2024 Olympic and Paralympic Games have chosen Phrygian caps as their mascots, aiming to celebrate the French Revolution's spirit. The red caps, available in two versions, were chosen over animals, which have traditionally been the mascots for other Olympics. The decision was made to convey a message of sport changing everything and deserving a prominent place in society. The mascots will be featured during the games, which will take place from July 26 to August 11 for the Olympics and August 28 to September 8 for the Paralympics.

images.alt_text: The marathon route unveiled on Wednesday (Oct 5) was modelled on the path of the October 1789 Women’s March on Versailles

As part of the launch, Volocopter, a German developer of electric vertical take-off and landing craft or eVTOLs, as flying taxis are known, carried out a flight integrated into conventional air traffic.

site_title: Biden, Xi clash over Taiwan, but military action seen as unlikely
summary: US President Joe Biden met with Chinese President Xi Jinping in Bali, Indonesia, where they discussed various issues, including Taiwan, North Korea, and the South China Sea. Biden assured Xi that the US would enhance its security position in Asia if China fails to rein in North Korea's weapons development programs. Xi reiterated that Taiwan is a "red line" that must not be crossed, but Biden downplayed the possibility of an imminent invasion. The two leaders also agreed to establish a mechanism for more frequent communications and set up a follow-up meeting between US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Chinese officials.

images.alt_text: President Joe Biden speaks at a news conference following his meeting with President Xi Jinping of China in Bali, Indonesia, Nov. 14, 2022. Amid growing disputes over Taiwan, Ukraine, technology and divergent visions of the world order, the leaders of the two superpowers are held their first face-to-face presidential talks. (Doug Mills/The New York Times)

site_title: Britain progresses towards cashlessness, but not everyone embraces it
summary: Britain is leading the way in moving away from cash in everyday payments, with 57% of people rarely or never using cash, according to a YouGov survey. However, more than two-thirds of Britons want to maintain access to cash. This trend contrasts with countries like Germany, France, and the US, where people are more reluctant to abandon traditional forms of money. The UK is also lagging behind in cryptocurrency adoption, with 65% of surveyed individuals stating they have never bought crypto assets.

images.alt_text: A customer enters their pin number as they make a chip and pin payment via a Verifone Systems Inc. credit card payment device at a restaurant in London, U.K., on Friday, May 22, 2015. Credit and debit cards that can be used by tapping the reader are gaining users, and mobile apps are set to further boost the popularity of contactless paying. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: ComfortDelGro Q3 Patmi up 33% to S$34.3 million on higher revenue
summary: ComfortDelGro, a transport operator, reported a 32.9% increase in third-quarter profit after tax and minority interests to S$34.3 million, driven by 10.1% higher revenue to S$969.5 million. Revenue growth was mainly due to post-Covid reopening and higher fuel prices. The company attributed challenges, including China's zero-Covid policy and inflation, to continued uncertainty. Operating costs rose 10.5% to S$815.8 million, with no government relief provided.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
ComfortDelGro currently operates in six states and territories in Australia.

site_title: German upper house blocks landmark welfare reform
summary: Germany's conservative opposition blocked a landmark welfare reform, halting its implementation. The overhaul aimed to address skilled worker shortages and replace the Hartz IV system with a more generous "citizens' money" benefit. The reform, which raised payments for unemployed individuals and helped them gain new skills, passed the lower house but was blocked in the upper house. Labour Minister Hubertus Heil plans to call for a committee to mediate a resolution, potentially allowing the reform to take effect from January 1.

site_title: SpaceX buys ad campaign on Twitter for Starlink, Musk says
summary: Elon Musk announced that SpaceX has purchased a small ad campaign on Twitter for its Starlink satellite internet service. This move comes as Twitter faces an exodus of advertisers due to concerns over changes to content moderation rules. Musk stated that the ad package was used to test Twitter's advertising effectiveness in Australia and Spain, and he aims to use the platform to promote truth and reduce fake accounts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket with the Dragon capsule launches from Pad-39A on the Crew 5 mission carrying crew members commander Nicole Mann, pilot Josh Cassada,  Roscosmos cosmonaut Anna Kikina and Mission Specialist Koichi Wakata from the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) to the International Space Station from NASA's Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Florida, U.S. October 5, 2022. REUTERS/Joe Skipper/File Photo

site_title: Biden-Xi meeting signals mutual aim to cool tensions
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping met in Bali, Indonesia, for the first in-person talks since the pandemic, lasting three hours. Both leaders called for reduced tensions between the world's largest economies. They agreed on several key issues, including a nuclear war never being fought and opposing the use of nuclear weapons in Ukraine. The US and China will resume talks on climate change, economic stability, and other global issues. The meeting marked a thaw in relations, with Secretary of State Antony Blinken set to travel to China.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden with China's President Xi Jinping in their meeting on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in Bali on Monday (Nov 14).
The flags of G20 member nations are flown in Bali, the venue for this year's summit.

US. President Joe Biden speaks virtually with Chinese leader Xi Jinping from the White House in Washington, US, Nov 15, 2021.  Over the last three years, the rivalry between China and the United States has intensified sharply as Beijing has become more powerful and more assertive.

site_title: National Wages Council urges employers to raise pay for lower-wage workers by 5.5-7.5%
summary: The National Wages Council in Singapore has recommended that employers give lower-wage workers a built-in wage increase of 5.5-7.5% or at least S$80 to S$100, whichever is higher. The guidelines apply to employees earning up to S$2,200 per month and aim to ensure fair wage increases in line with economic growth and productivity improvements. The council also urges employers to implement flexible wage systems and invest in employee training to support sustainable wage growth.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
National Wages Council recommends built-in pay rise of 4.5 to 7.5% for lower-wage workers

site_title: Plan to shield people from climate disasters unveiled at COP27
summary: At the COP27 UN climate summit, a "Global Shield" plan was unveiled to shield people from climate disasters. The plan, proposed by Germany and other G7 countries, aims to provide swift international help to disaster-hit poorer countries by launching a "mosaic" of protection and disaster response finance. The shield would complement a proposed "loss and damage" finance facility, but some wealthier countries are positioning it as a substitute. The initiative has raised $200 million in new funding and will be operational by January 2023, but critics argue that insurance cannot keep up with rising climate-related losses.

images.alt_text: Emissions from oil, fuelled by the continuing rebound in aviation, will likely rise more than 2 per cent compared to last year, while emissions from coal – thought by some to have peaked in 2014 – will hit a new record, according to a study.

World Bank's report warned that temperatures in the Philippines will continue to rise and rainfall could become more intense due to climate change, putting at risk the country’s ability to meet its development goals.
The severe drought in the Horn of Africa has pushed people to the brink of starvation says the head of the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO).

site_title: Silverlake Axis posts 64% increase in Q1 profit after tax on higher revenue
summary: Silverlake Axis posted a 64% increase in profit after tax for its Q1 FY2023, reaching RM57.6 million, driven by a 23% year-on-year revenue growth to RM188 million. The company's SaaS and cloud computing segments contributed 7% and 9% to total revenue, respectively. Total expenses rose 20% to RM51.1 million, mainly due to marketing and business development expenses. The group has a RM2.1 billion pipeline of deals and plans to maintain revenue growth and form new partnerships to expand its banking and insurance solutions.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

Silverlake Axis, which provides digitalisation and core banking solutions, will also benefit from rising competition from digital banks, which will drive spending on core banking systems investments or upgrades. , CGS-CIMB said.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended lower on Monday, closing at 1,464 points, down 4.21 points or 0.29%. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index saw 2.79 billion lots traded worth RM1.56 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 445 to 431.

site_title: Yuan ends at 2-month high on firmer guidance, policy support for property sector
summary: China's onshore yuan reached a 2-month high at 7.0378 per dollar on November 14, following the central bank's firmer guidance and policy support for the property sector. The move coincides with easing of Covid-19 prevention controls and improved market sentiment. The yuan's rally is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy, but uncertainties around economic recovery remain. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 7.0899 per dollar, its strongest since September 2005.

images.alt_text: The Chinese yuan finished the domestic trading session at its strongest level since late-September, as investors cheered the government’s decision to ease some of the country’s strict Covid-19 prevention controls.
Yi Gang, governor of the People’s Bank of China (PBOC), said China will continue to deregulate its domestic market, improve the business environment, and protect intellectual property rights.
The signs of funding stress underscore the pressure on the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) to keep liquidity ample when 1 trillion yuan of medium-term lending facility matures on Nov 15

site_title: Tesla denies malfunction to blame for deadly crash caught on video in China
summary: Tesla denies a malfunction as the cause of a fatal crash in China, where a motorcyclist and high-school student were killed in an accident involving a Model Y sports utility vehicle. Data from the car showed no evidence the brake pedal was applied before the crash, and the brake lights remained off. The accelerator was heavily engaged in the lead-up to the accident. Tesla will assist the police investigation, which may involve a third-party investigator, and claims the incident was not caused by a malfunction.

site_title: China property stocks, bonds extend rally on new rescue measures
summary: China's property sector sees a rally after Beijing announces a 16-point rescue package aimed at easing developers' liquidity strains and reviving home purchases. The package includes measures to address liquidity crisis and loosen down-payment requirements for homebuyers. Shares of top developer Country Garden Holdings surged 46% and dollar bonds of other developers rose at least 5 cents on the dollar. The moves lift sentiment across Chinese markets, with a gauge of Chinese stocks listed in Hong Kong up 1.9% and the offshore yuan rising 1% against the dollar.

images.alt_text: Royal Peak, a residential development in Beijing, is being built by the ailing Evergrande Group. Beijing is trying to rescue the property market.

Residential buildings under under construction in Shanghai. Ongoing challenges in China's property market and property bonds raise concerns over bonds issued by China's local government funding vehicles.

site_title: FTX implosion: Crypto’s value should not be quoted in dollars
summary: FTX, the second-largest crypto exchange, has filed for bankruptcy after a stunning collapse, marking the largest and quickest drop in net worth in history. The exchange's CEO, Sam Bankman-Fried, lost $20 billion in a day after Binance discovered "irregularities" in FTX's balance sheet. FTX's assets were largely its own FTT tokens, which were not valued in dollars. The collapse highlights the risks of unregulated exchanges and the dangers of speculation in crypto markets. Customers are likely to lose all their assets, and the incident serves as a cautionary tale for investors, emphasizing the need for regulation to protect consumers.

images.alt_text: MAS reiterates the hazards of cryptocurrency trading for the general public in its response to queries on FTX's operations in Singapore.
The implosions and scandals of the past few months have laid waste to the key arguments of crypto boosters, and all but obliterated the notion of Bitcoin as safe haven in turbulent times.

site_title: Who will China's Xi meet this week, and what's at stake?
summary: China's President Xi Jinping arrived in Bali for the G20 summit, marking his second overseas trip since 2020. Following his norm-breaking third term as Communist Party leader, Xi will meet US President Joe Biden, as well as other powerful dignitaries. The meetings come as China's GDP growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers. Xi's overseas appearances are seen as an effort to boost his international image and address global concerns. The outcomes of his meetings with Biden and other leaders will be closely watched for their implications on China's relationships with major world powers.

images.alt_text: The flags of G20 member nations are flown in Bali, the venue for this year's summit.
Russian President Vladimir Putin’s no-show risks further isolating a country already battered by unprecedented Western sanctions.

site_title: The Business Times subscribers enjoy exclusive shochu masterclass
summary: The Business Times rewarded its subscribers with a shochu masterclass at Workhorse Izakaya on Oct 29, exclusively for subscribers. Twelve readers, who answered a simple question, attended the event with a companion. This is part of the publication's efforts to engage subscribers beyond news, following previous exclusive access to events like Mark to Market 'Live' in 2022.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan
Learn what goes into the making of a Lange timepiece at The Mechanical Masters exhibition.

site_title: Crypto.com says balance sheet strong, exchange not in trouble
summary: Crypto.com CEO Kris Marszalek reassured investors that the platform is financially stable, despite recent concerns, and will continue operating as usual. The exchange has 70 million individual customers and made revenues of $1 billion in 2021 and 2022. Marszalek denied allegations of irresponsible lending practices and confirmed that a balance sheet audit will be published within weeks. The exchange had previously transferred $400 million worth of ether tokens to another exchange, but recovered the funds and returned them. Marszalek acknowledged the industry's reputation has been damaged following the FTX collapse, but vowed to rebuild trust.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried, the chief executive of FTX, during a conference this year. FTX's fall from grace ranks as the largest and quickest drop in net worth in history as SBF lost 20 billion tokens in a day.
Bitcoin dropped 23 per cent  last week, its worst tumble since June, at the same time as the S&P 500 Index rose 5.9 per cent.
MAS reiterates the hazards of cryptocurrency trading for the general public in its response to queries on FTX's operations in Singapore.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s Kuroda vows to continue monetary easing for now, focuses on wage
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda has vowed to continue monetary easing to support the economy and achieve sustainable and stable inflation accompanied by wage growth. He expects wage inflation to take center stage in pay talks next spring, which could determine Japan's success in spurring a virtuous cycle of demand-led economic growth. The BOJ will maintain ultra-low interest rates to support the economy, with consumer inflation expected to accelerate to around 3% this fiscal year.

images.alt_text: This picture taken on November 5, 2022 shows people walking near the head office (C) of Japanese automaker Nissan Motor in Yokohama. - The automaker is expected to announce second quarter results on November 9, 2022. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Japan’s biggest bank Mitsubishi UFJ reports 70.5% slump in Q2 profit
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Finance Group, Japan's largest lender, reported a 70.5% slump in Q2 profit to 117.41 billion yen, due to an one-off loss related to the sale of its US unit. The bank maintained its full-year profit forecast of 1 trillion yen, a 12% drop from the previous year. Despite this, its outlook is in line with analyst estimates.

site_title: What happens when a cascade of crises collide?
summary: A global polycrisis is unfolding, characterized by the intersection of multiple crises such as the coronavirus pandemic, climate change, economic inequality, and authoritarianism. The likelihood of these crises being a coincidence is low, as they are deeply entangled and exacerbating each other. This entanglement is driven by factors like resource consumption, pollution, and increased connectivity among economic and social systems. A worldwide scientific collaboration is proposed to identify causal mechanisms and develop practical interventions to address the polycrisis, which could ultimately lead to the collapse of the global order if left unchecked.

images.alt_text: Demonstrators march during a "For our Children” protest against pollution in Belgrade, on November 13, 2022. (Photo by OLIVER BUNIC / AFP)

site_title: Europe: Stock markets rise at open
summary: Europe's stock markets rose at the open on Monday, November 14, 2022. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.3% to 7,341.83 points, while Frankfurt's DAX index rose 0.6% to 14,306.59 points. The Paris CAC 40 advanced 0.3% to 6,616.54 points. The gains followed a mixed start to the week in Asia, with mining and healthcare stocks driving the rally.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man shelters under an umbrella as he walks past the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain, August 24, 2015. REUTERS/Suzanne Plunkett/File Photo

site_title: London loses its status as biggest European stock market to Paris
summary: London has lost its title as Europe's largest stock market to Paris, with the combined market capitalisation of primary listings in Paris surpassing that of the UK capital in US dollar terms. This shift is attributed to domestic-focused UK shares slumping due to economic growth concerns, while French luxury goods-makers have been boosted by optimism over China's easing of Covid-Zero policies. The pound's decline against the US dollar has also contributed to Paris' favour, with the FTSE 250 index trading at a 30% discount to the MSCI World benchmark.

images.alt_text: A FTSE share index board in the atrium of the London Stock Exchange Group Plc's offices in London, UK, on Friday, Aug. 12, 2022. London Stock Exchange Plc Chief Executive Officer Julia Hoggett said the IPO pipeline in London remains robust, despite a slowdown this year that’s been felt at many exchanges globally. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

site_title: Indonesia and ADB launch first coal power plant retirement deal
summary: Indonesia, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and a private power firm have teamed up to refinance and prematurely retire a coal-fired power plant, the first under a groundbreaking carbon emissions reduction programme. The 660-megawatt Cirebon 1 power plant in West Java will be refinanced in a $250-$300 million deal, potentially eliminating 30 million tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions over 15 years. The agreement is the first under the ADB's Energy Transition Mechanism, which aims to eliminate decades of future carbon emissions by altering the economics of coal plant operations.

images.alt_text: As governments begin to focus more on solar panel supply chain diversification, South-east Asia could emerge as an important player in sustainable energy production.

Indonesian officials are also working with representatives of the US and other wealthy countries on a “just energy transition package” set to include millions of dollars in funding to support a move away from coal.
The Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, on the first day of the COP27 climate summit, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city, on November 6, 2022

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The National Wages Council recommends employers provide wage increases of 5.5-7.5% or at least S$80 to S$100 for lower-wage workers, in line with economic growth and improved productivity. This guideline aims to ensure fair compensation for staff.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Monday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 1.70% to 17,619.71, extending a rally of over seven per cent from the previous day. The gain was driven by a series of measures announced by China to support the struggling property sector. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index declined slightly. The rally came despite ongoing US-China trade tensions and uncertainty over the US Federal Reserve's monetary policy.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts upgrade UMS to ‘buy’ on Q3 earnings beat
summary: Maybank Securities and UOB Kay Hian upgraded UMS Holdings, a semiconductor manufacturer, to "buy" from "hold" due to its Q3 FY2022 earnings beating expectations. Analysts raised their price targets to S$1.34 and S$1.38, respectively, citing a strong order backlog and expansion plans. The upgrades are attributed to UMS' robust outlook, attractive valuation, and potential for diversification through a new customer.

images.alt_text: UMS revenue for the third quarter rose 48 per cent on-year to S$100.1 million, the first time its quarterly revenue has crossed the S$100 million mark
Manufacturing expectations still pessimistic, services sector less upbeat: surveys
Semiconductors represent the biggest source of income for the South Korean economy.

site_title: Collaboration and growth opportunities between Germany and Singapore remain, despite headwinds: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong of Singapore emphasized the importance of collaboration and growth opportunities between Germany and Singapore despite economic and geopolitical headwinds. The two countries, both export-oriented economies, can strengthen their ties in areas like sustainability, and Germany is keen on diversifying its economic ties in the Asia-Pacific region. Wong also highlighted the potential for the EU and Asean to work together, with Singapore aiming to be a "neutral core" for cooperation in the region.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
(from left) Germany Federal Minister for Economic Affairs and Climate Action Robert Habeck and Singapore's Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran signed the FSI on Sunday.

site_title: Britain and France sign deal to boost cooperation on illegal migration
summary: Britain and France signed a 72.2 million euro deal to boost cooperation on illegal migration. The agreement aims to stop the growing number of migrants crossing the English Channel in small boats, with over 40,000 people making the perilous journey so far this year. The deal will increase French gendarme patrols and improve coordination between UK and French officers, as well as invest in surveillance technology and reception centers. British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said the agreement will "make a difference," but warned that reducing the numbers won't happen overnight.

images.alt_text: Detainees inside the Manston short-term holding centre for migrants, wave to members of the media outside, near Ramsgate, south east England on November 3, 2022. - British immigration minister Robert Jenrick on Tuesday vowed "more radical" policies to counter illegal migration as record numbers make the treacherous crossing of the Channel in small boats. Jenrick accepted that conditions at the Manston migrant processing centre in Kent, southeast England, were "poor", and that people had been sleeping on the floor on mats. "The problem is that thousands of people are crossing the Channel illegally every day," he added. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: China lets developers access pre-sale funds to ease cash crunch
summary: China has allowed quality property developers to access 30% of pre-sale funds held in escrow accounts, provided they have bank guarantees. This move aims to ease a cash crunch in the real-estate sector, which has been affected by the housing slump and Covid Zero policies. The funds can be used to pay for project construction and repay debts, but not for new investments or repaying shareholder loans. The policy is voluntary and limited to better-off developers, with some analysts questioning its effectiveness.

site_title: Singapore stocks start Monday stronger; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,236.19 points on Monday, driven by a strong global market performance. Gainers outnumbered losers 82 to 42, with Sembcorp Marine and UMS leading the gainers. The US S&P 500 and Nasdaq rose sharply, while European shares reached an 11-week high. Asian markets also followed Wall Street rallies, with Tokyo's Nikkei index up 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries is acquiring three solar projects in northern China, and an independent power producer in India.

site_title: US Democrats celebrate Senate win over distraught Republicans
summary: US Democrats won the Senate in the midterm elections, securing a crucial majority of 50 seats to hold control of the upper chamber. The victory is seen as a major triumph for President Joe Biden, who will have a strong base of support to keep his policy agenda on track. The result comes despite predictions that Democrats would lose by a wide margin, and is a blow to former President Donald Trump's efforts to ride a "red wave" and capture both houses of Congress. Republicans are now left to consider what went wrong, with some calling for a change in leadership style.

images.alt_text: Officials overseeing vote counting in the Arizona and Nevada (top) Senate races, where Democratic incumbents are trying to fend off Republican challengers, say it could take until next week to tally uncounted mail-in ballots.
Democrats now control the Senate, which is split 50-50 between the two parties, because of Vice President Kamala Harris’s ability to break tie votes.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower
summary: Tokyo shares closed lower on Monday, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 1.06% and the Topix index falling 1.05%, due to a decline in SoftBank Group, which plummeted 12.7% after reporting a net loss of 129 billion yen. Analysts attributed the decline to traders locking in profits after a positive session on Friday, when US stocks surged on hopes for less aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was up 0.13 per cent, or 36.37 points, at 28,299.94 in early trade on Monday.

site_title: UK needs to make politically unpopular reforms to boost growth: business group
summary: The UK's Confederation of British Industry (CBI) has urged the government to implement politically unpopular reforms to boost economic growth. The CBI recommends increasing flexibility in immigration policies for labor-shortage occupations, adding student and graduate visa routes, and streamlining the planning system to speed up decision-making for major developments. These measures, along with spending cuts and tax rises, are necessary to tackle labor shortages and productivity issues, and avoid a decade of no growth, according to CBI Director-General Tony Danker.

site_title: How data can enable high-quality carbon credits for a sustainable Singapore
summary: Singapore is stepping up its efforts to create a sustainable economy by leveraging data to enable high-quality carbon credits. The market for carbon credits is plagued by issues such as a lack of data and digital infrastructure, leading to double-counting and greenwashing. To address these issues, Singapore is investing in research and development of a digital registry for emissions data, utilizing blockchain technology to provide transparency and traceability. This will enable companies to monitor and report their emissions accurately, prevent double-counting, and enhance the overall effectiveness of carbon markets in reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

images.alt_text: A geothermal power plant in the Philippines. As part of the research initiative, CNCS researchers will work with other universities, government agencies and corporations to establish monitoring plots at various natural habitats across South-east Asia.

site_title: Dollar extends fall after inflation data knock
summary: The US dollar fell 3.8% against a basket of currencies over two sessions, its largest two-day percentage loss since March 2009, following signs that US inflation is cooling. The dollar's decline was driven by investor favoring riskier currencies, with the Australian and New Zealand dollars advancing 1.4% and 1.6% respectively. The dollar's long rally was also affected by the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, which are expected to ease as inflation cools, according to survey data showing a decline in US consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: A slower pace of rate hikes could curb the dollar’s rally this year which has weakened its Group-of-10 currency peers.

site_title: Cathay won't return to pre-pandemic capacity until 'end of 2024'
summary: Cathay Pacific expects to return to pre-pandemic capacity levels by the end of 2024, despite Hong Kong's ongoing travel restrictions. The airline has already achieved its target of operating one-third of its pre-pandemic capacity levels by the end of 2022 and aims to reach 70% capacity by the end of 2023. However, travel industry groups warn that a meaningful return of visitors to Hong Kong will not occur until the three-day monitoring period and most other restrictions are lifted, including the border with the Chinese mainland.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign of Cathay Pacific is seen at its  headquarters Cathay City in Hong Kong, China October 21, 2020. REUTERS/Lam Yik//File Photo
Subhas Menon, director general of the Association of Asia-Pacific Airlines (AAPA), told reporters that airlines underestimating pent-up demand had led to higher ticket prices.

site_title: Australian PM hails ‘constructive’ talk with China’s Li
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese met with Chinese Premier Li Keqiang at the Asean summit in Phnom Penh, marking the first in-person encounter between the two leaders since 2019. Albanese described the meeting as "positive" and "constructive," aiming to improve Canberra's frosty relationship with Beijing. The two discussed the 50-year anniversary of their diplomatic ties and cooperation areas, with Li stating Beijing is ready to meet Canberra halfway. Albanese hopes to secure a meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the upcoming G20 summit in Bali.

images.alt_text: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has put the blame on the US and its allies for the lack of communique at the 18-nation East Asian Summit, saying on Sunday (Nov 13) they “insisted on absolutely unacceptable language regarding the situation in Ukraine”.

US. President Joe Biden speaks virtually with Chinese leader Xi Jinping from the White House in Washington, US, Nov 15, 2021.  Over the last three years, the rivalry between China and the United States has intensified sharply as Beijing has become more powerful and more assertive.

site_title: Asian fund managers lag global peers in ESG due diligence on deals: poll
summary: Asian fund managers are lagging behind global peers in conducting environmental, social, and governance (ESG) due diligence on deals, according to a report. Less than half of respondents conduct ESG due diligence on every deal, while 46% do so on most deals. Only 62% of funds in Asia have an ESG committee, and fewer than a quarter have a dedicated ESG professional. Fund managers must incorporate ESG considerations into investment decision-making, rather than treating it as a compliance issue, to drive value and manage enterprise risk.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Relatively newer sustainable bond markets around the globe are increasingly complementing sustained growth in more seasoned markets such as China, according to Moody's ESG Solutions.

site_title: Less than half of SEA businesses confident they will survive if a recession occurs
summary: A global recession is increasingly likely, with South-east Asia countries such as Singapore and Thailand at high risk due to trade dependence. Despite this, 70% of businesses in the region believe it's essential to prepare for a recession, with 70% having taken steps to do so. Countries in the area are advised to shore up their defenses now to mitigate potential economic impact.

images.alt_text: SME leaders need to shift their focus to holistic business transformation rather than just digital transformation, with an emphasis on transforming people and processes too.
The Asia Pacific co-location data centre market is projected to be worth US$28 billion by 2024, surpassing North America to become the largest worldwide over the next decade.

site_title: Bitcoin splits from global markets to slide all on its own
summary: Bitcoin plummeted 23% last week, its worst decline since June, while the S&P 500 Index rose 5.9% and the Nasdaq hit its widest performance gap with Bitcoin since 2020. The cryptocurrency's correlation with global markets is weakening, with major cryptocurrencies failing to lift broader market sentiment despite gains. Investors are losing confidence in Bitcoin, with massive losses from FTX's collapse and a 70% drop in total market value since its record peak. The asset class's influence on global markets may be diminishing, and its role in diversified portfolios is fraying.

images.alt_text: The implosions and scandals of the past few months have laid waste to the key arguments of crypto boosters, and all but obliterated the notion of Bitcoin as safe haven in turbulent times.
“Bitcoin’s price has been illogically stable in recent weeks given volatility in other markets,” said analysts at Morgan Stanley in a note on Friday Nov 11.
Most crypto players remain bullish about the long term, but are braced for further falls in the near future.

site_title: Time for a Sino-American ceasefire
summary: The US has imposed extensive export controls on advanced semiconductors to China, seen as a formal declaration of Cold War II. The move aims to slow China's emergence as a global economic and technological superpower, particularly in telecom infrastructure. The Biden-Xi meeting at the G20 summit in Bali marked a positive milestone in repairing bilateral relations, which have hit a 50-year low. The two leaders signalled openness to repairing the relationship, but tensions over Taiwan, trade, and human rights remain, increasing the risk of a costly confrontation between the US and China.

images.alt_text: US. President Joe Biden speaks virtually with Chinese leader Xi Jinping from the White House in Washington, US, Nov 15, 2021.  Over the last three years, the rivalry between China and the United States has intensified sharply as Beijing has become more powerful and more assertive.

site_title: Asia: Most markets extend global rally on China hopes
summary: Asian markets extended a global rally on Monday, driven by hopes of China's loosening of Covid rules and plans to support its struggling property sector. The news, following a drop in US inflation, eased rate hike fears and lifted the dollar. Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, and Manila rose, while Tokyo fell due to profit-taking. Analysts see a possible shallower recession in China or an averted one, with the yen, pound, and euro holding gains against the dollar. Traders await a meeting between US President Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping, seeking to ease tensions.

images.alt_text: Taipei jumped 3.5 per cent, Seoul was up 2.8 per cent and Sydney climbed 2.6 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut target prices for IReit Global on leasing slowdowns
summary: Analysts at RHB Research and DBS Group Research have lowered their target prices for IReit Global by 3.45% due to expected leasing slowdowns and interest rate hikes. The real estate investment trust's distribution per unit projections for FY2023 and FY2024 have been lowered by 6% and 2% respectively, citing lower occupancy rates at one of its properties and adjusted financing costs. This downward pressure is expected to impact IReit Global's portfolio revaluation in December.

images.alt_text: Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands
Funan The IT Mall was one of the three properties in the IPO portfolio of Singapore's first Reit, CapitaLand Mall Trust (now known as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust) in 2002.
IReit Global inked a 6-year lease extension for the entire Bonn Campus in Q2.
The brokerage has initiated coverage on Europe-focused real-estate trust IReit Global with an “accumulate on weakness” rating at a target price of S$0.69

site_title: Emerging markets raise voice at COP27
summary: At the COP27 climate summit, emerging markets have made a significant voice, pushing for key issues like "loss and damage" and climate finance. Developing countries, particularly in Africa, Asia, and South America, are leading the way in climate security, with many adopting low-carbon growth and development strategies. Mexico, for example, has announced plans to cut emissions by 35% by 2030, doubling its clean energy investments and expanding protected forest areas. The Global South is also pushing for a formalized funding process for loss and damage, with several countries committing to increase their climate finance goals.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. Picture taken July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo
Madelena Mohamed, director of Bank Negara Malaysia's sustainability unit, at the Malaysia pavilion at the COP27 climate summit.

site_title: Australia: Shares reverse course to end lower as investors book profits
summary: Australia's shares closed 0.2% lower on Monday, reversing earlier gains, as investors took profits from financial stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to its highest level since June 7 earlier in the day, but was pressured by a 1% drop in financial stocks, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia's 0.7% drop leading the decline. The index was boosted by commodity-related stocks after China eased some Covid-19 curbs, with heavyweight miners BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group rising 3.3% to 10.1%.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.3 per cent to 7,181 by 2313 GMT, their highest level since June 7.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.78 points or 0.33% to 1463.43. The decline followed a 5-day rally in Singapore's stocks. The number of gainers outweighed losers 164 to 145.

site_title: Hot stock: Best World surges as much as 38% after trading resumes following lengthy suspension
summary: Best World International shares surged 38% on their first trading day after a 3.5-year suspension due to regulatory concerns over its business model in China. The company's shares closed at S$1.82, up 33.8% from their last price before suspension. Conditions for trading resumption included an independent review, which the company completed in 2020. Despite lower revenue and net profit for the nine months ended Sep 30, 2022, they remain above FY2018 levels, with a net asset value per share of S$1.0179.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

site_title: Singapore Fintech Festival draws largest turnout since inception
summary: The Singapore Fintech Festival drew a record 62,000 participants from over 115 countries, the largest turnout since its inception in 2016. The event featured over 850 speakers and 570 exhibitor booths, including a new ESG Fintech Zone showcasing net-zero technological solutions. Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong opened the festival, and a closed-door roundtable was held with nearly 1,200 leaders discussing topics such as sustainable finance and digital banking. The festival's success led MAS to look forward to a "continued collaboration" for SFF 2023, scheduled for November 13-17, 2023.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Tampines EC draws over 5,000 visitors on launch weekend; prices start from S$1.1m
summary: The Tenet EC executive condominium project in Tampines drew over 5,000 visitors on its launch weekend, exceeding expectations. Prices start at S$1.1 million for a three-bedroom unit, with 618 units available across 11 tower blocks. The project features unique communal facilities and is designed for a "staycation experience for families." Eligible buyers can submit e-applications until November 28. The strong demand is promising, with the developer expecting another successful weekend.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
Developers in Singapore sold a total of 987 units excluding executive condominiums (ECs), with more than 913 units launched in September.
Private home prices grow at slower pace in Q1 after cooling measures; Q2 could remain relatively subdued
Market for new ECs a bright spot after cooling measures
Latest GLS tenders see firm land prices, keener interest from developers

site_title: Regulations cannot protect consumers from losses in crypto markets, says MAS
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has reiterated that regulations cannot protect consumers from losses in crypto markets, warning Singapore users to exercise utmost caution when trading in cryptocurrency. Despite FTX not operating in Singapore, users can still access the platform. MAS has clarified that it did not ban Binance, and listing FTX on the Investor Alert List was not necessary. Singapore users have a choice to deal with FTX or Quoine, with Quoine currently exempt from licensing. MAS is conducting a public consultation on measures to reduce consumer risks from cryptocurrency trading, concluding on Dec 21.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
MAS intends to first issue a set of guidelines for crypto service providers after this consultation, and later legislate them.

The real value in the crypto industry comes not from speculating in cryptocurrencies, but from tokenising assets for use cases that increase economic efficiency or enhance social inclusion, said Ravi Menon.
FTX’s collapse marks a stunning reversal of fortunes for the company and its founder Sam Bankman-Fried.

site_title: US may skirt recession in 2023, Europe not so lucky: Morgan Stanley
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts the US economy will avoid a recession in 2023, while Britain and the euro zone economies are likely to enter a recession. The global economy is forecasted to grow 2.2% next year, lower than the IMF's 2.7% estimate. China's reopening after COVID-19 curbs is expected to lead a recovery in its economy and emerging Asian markets.

images.alt_text: Measures recommended by the Confederation of British Industry include being more flexible on immigration for occupations dogged by labour shortages, and adding student and graduate visa routes and visas linked to specific economic projects.
Sterling rose 0.2 per cent to US$1.1730, after hitting its highest since Aug 26 at US$1.1766.

A report released last week showing slower than expected inflation in October was “good news,” but was “just one data point” that would have to be followed with other similar readings to show convincingly that inflation is slowing, Federal Reserve Gov. Christopher Waller said.

site_title: Reits can withstand debt costs resetting to much higher levels
summary: Singapore's Reits, a major segment of the local bourse, face challenges due to rising interest rates. Despite this, high-quality Reits can withstand debt costs resetting to higher levels, with some offering yields 260-240 basis points higher than the five-year Singapore government bond yield. Reits can mitigate the impact by focusing on asset enhancements, such as renovations, and generating better net income from properties. With the sector turning 20, Reit managers can still be hopeful if they are assiduous and creative in addressing the twin threats of higher borrowing costs and capitalisation rates.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Within Q3 2022, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit announced two acquisitions in Singapore across the industrial and logistics sub-segments, totalling purchase consideration of S$296.7 million.

site_title: BioNTech acquires site from Novartis for mRNA facility, regional headquarters
summary: BioNTech has acquired a manufacturing site from Novartis Singapore to establish a regional headquarters and mRNA facility in the country. The facility, expected to create over 100 jobs by 2024, will produce mRNA-based vaccines and therapeutics. The move is part of BioNTech's plans to expand its Asia footprint and is fully integrated into the company's global manufacturing network. The facility will initially manufacture authorized vaccines and product candidates, with plans to produce several hundred million doses annually.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Why Putin is staying away from G20
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin skipped the G20 summit in Bali, marking his first absence from the global gathering in eight years. The move is seen as an attempt to avoid public humiliation, but risks further isolating Russia, which is already under unprecedented Western sanctions. Putin's absence comes as the country faces setbacks in Ukraine, with the Kremlin unable to secure concessions from the West. Observers believe Putin's refusal to attend reflects a "sense of a dead end" over Ukraine, and that he is seeking to deepen ties with neutral states and build an "anti-Western coalition."

images.alt_text: epa10298067 Russian President Vladimir Putin congratulates personnel and veterans of the Russia's Interior Ministry agencies on their professional holiday, in Moscow, Russia, 10 November 2022.  EPA-EFE/MIKHAIL METZEL / KREMLIN POOL / SPUTNIK MANDATORY CREDIT

site_title: Hot stock: Oceanus hits two-month high as trading volume surges
summary: Oceanus Group, a mainboard-listed seafood supplier, has seen its trading volume surge with 132.6 million shares changing hands on Monday, making it the top-traded security by volume. The company's counter rose 6.3% to S$0.017, reaching a two-month high. This comes after a similar surge on Friday, when it closed at S$0.016 after 107 million shares were transacted. The recent trading activity has raised concerns about "unusual volume movements" in the company's shares, prompting a query by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in June.

site_title: Inequitable for advanced economies to dictate pace of energy transition for Asean: Bank Negara director
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia's director, Madelena Mohamed, says advanced economies are dictating the pace of energy transition for emerging markets in Southeast Asia without working together, citing the proposed carbon border adjustment mechanism as an example. This approach is seen as unfair, as it would disproportionately affect small and medium-sized enterprises in emerging markets. Climate Bonds Initiative's CEO, Sean Kidney, disagrees, stating that companies need to sprint ahead in their energy transition, but governments should support workers who will be left behind.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. Picture taken July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: View of a COP27 sign on the road leading to the conference area in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh town as the city prepares to host the COP27 summit next month, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sayed Sheasha/File Photo

site_title: Weaker sterling sends Singapore buyers hunting for prime London property
summary: Weaker sterling sends Singapore buyers hunting for prime London property. With the British pound trading near historic lows against the Singapore dollar, Singapore buyers are taking advantage of the attractive discounts, leading to increased inquiries and sales in prime central London properties. Prices of prime central London properties are considerably lower now for Singapore buyers, with a £1.5 million home requiring nearly S$1 million less than it did in 2015. The more favourable exchange rate is expected to attract international interest, with real estate agencies reporting increased activity in prime districts such as Chelsea and Belgravia.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

UK mortgage rates have surged close to peaks last seen in the 2008 financial crisis. The cost of a two-year fixed-rate mortgage is now 6.48 per cent, near the highest in 14 years and up from 2.34 per cent in December, according to Moneyfacts Group.
The mortgage lender Halifax said prices fell 0.4 per cent last month, the third decline in four months. The annual rate of growth fell to 8.3 per cent, from 9.8 per cent.
The cost of key UK mortgages remains close to a peak last seen in the 2008 financial crisis, which is reducing the number of people who can afford to buy property.
London properties would face the biggest loss of value with 13 months of capital gains wiped out in this scenario.
A surge in borrowing costs triggered by interest rates from the Bank of England are likely to quell activity in the months ahead.

site_title: KKR leads US$48 million Series C round in Privy
summary: KKR is leading a US$48 million Series C funding round in Indonesian digital trust platform Privy, with existing investors and new investors participating. Privy offers services such as digital identity and document management, and has over 30 million verified users and 1,800 enterprise customers. The funding will be used to expand Privy's market position in Indonesia and support the development of new products and services for consumers and businesses. The platform aims to leverage the Indonesian government's push for digital transformation to expand to overseas markets.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Private equity firms are facing tumbling valuations, higher borrowing costs and a slowdown in asset sales as recession concerns weigh on the macroeconomic picture.
FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., Aug. 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo
Founded in 2001, NetSPI is a provider of penetration-testing and attack-management services for clients including Microsoft and the US Air Force, according to its website.

site_title: UK recruiters plan record pay rises but real wages lag inflation: CIPD
summary: UK employers plan record pay rises, with 4% average increase and up to 5% in the private sector. However, real wages are expected to grow slower than inflation, with most people facing a real-terms pay cut. The Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development's survey found 69% of employers plan to hire in the next quarter, indicating the UK's jobs boom has yet to peak.

images.alt_text: Sterling rose 0.2 per cent to US$1.1730, after hitting its highest since Aug 26 at US$1.1766.

Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt is reportedly looking at changing income tax brackets, to raise more revenue from high earners, and impose strict curbs on government spending for years to come as inflation hits double digits.

Measures recommended by the Confederation of British Industry include being more flexible on immigration for occupations dogged by labour shortages, and adding student and graduate visa routes and visas linked to specific economic projects.

site_title: Golden Mile Tower to be launched for en bloc sale at indicative price of S$650m
summary: Golden Mile Tower, a 99-year leasehold commercial development, will be launched for en bloc sale on Nov 18 with an indicative price of S$650 million. The building, completed in 1974, features a Brutalist style and distinctive spiral staircase. Located between Nicoll Highway and Beach Road, its sale follows the successful collective sale of neighbouring Golden Mile Complex in May for S$700 million.

images.alt_text: Situated between Nicoll Highway and Beach Road, Golden Mile Tower was completed in 1974, one year after its sister building, Golden Mile Complex.
Golden Mile Tower was constructed in the Brutalist style, and has a striking spiral staircase that is frequently featured on Instagram.
Golden Mile Tower's Instagram-friendly spiral stairs viewed from the bottom.
View out of one of Golden Mile Tower's distinctive capsule-shaped windows.
Golden Mile Tower's 22nd floor office lobby.
Golden Mile Tower's carpark also sports the building's signature capsule-shaped designs, though they are now obscured by another building.

site_title: Thai monetary policy to be measured, support recovery: central bank
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput stated that the Thai economy is expected to grow 3.3% this year and 3.8% next year, maintaining an earlier forecast. The economy is recovering gradually, with support from consumption and tourism, and is expected to reach pre-pandemic levels later this year or early next year. Monetary policy will be "measured and gradual" to support economic recovery, and it is not necessary to aggressively increase rates to manage inflation, as it has already peaked in the third quarter this year.

site_title: Oil prices extend gains on China demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose 0.9% to $96.86 a barrel, extending gains from the previous session, as China eased COVID-19 protocols, boosting economic activity and demand. Brent crude futures rose 87 cents, and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 80 cents. Despite a firmer dollar, the market is hopeful for further easing of restrictions, with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stating India can buy Russian oil at prices above a G7-imposed cap.

site_title: When Singapore burns hydrogen, prices go boom
summary: Singapore's planned switch to low-carbon hydrogen from natural gas could lead to electricity prices doubling to tripling, according to experts Chan Siew Hwa and Justin Payne. Infrastructure costs, including import terminals and distribution networks, would be required to facilitate the transition. A low-carbon hydrogen cost of US$6.60 per kg is estimated to drive up prices. The experts' analysis assumes existing domestic infrastructure for hydrogen-compatible use.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Decarbonising the power sector is key in the city state’s race to net zero by 2050 as the sector currently contributes about 40 per cent of Singapore’s total carbon emissions.
Wong Kim Yin, chief executive of Sembcorp, said the partnerships align with the company’s move to transform its portfolio from “brown to green”.

MOU signing ceremony between Keppel Infrastructure and Greenko. Standing: Keppel's chief executive officer Loh China Hua (first from left), Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong (second from right), High Commissioner of India to Singapore, Periasamy Kumaran, (third from left), Greenko's joint managing director and founder Mahesh Kolli (fourth from left). Seated: Keppel Infrastructure's CEO Cindy Lim (left) and Greenko's chief executive and founder Anil Kumar Chalamalasetty (right).
Sembcorp's cogeneration plant on Banyan, Jurong Island.
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger

site_title: Climate policies ‘often out of sync’ with 2030 targets: FTSE Russell
summary: FTSE Russell reports that climate policies in G20 countries are often out of sync with their 2030 targets, with many emerging economies' nationally-determined contributions implying lower ambitions than their current policies. Discrepancies were found in Russia (0.6°C) and Turkey (0.3°C), while advanced economies like Canada are "significantly off track" against their 2030 targets. The report also highlights a 2.7°C level of warming, short of the 2°C limit set by the Paris Agreement, and notes rising natural disaster losses and increasing climate-related risks, particularly in drier regions and regions with rapid temperature shifts.

images.alt_text: Mexican Foreign Minister Marcelo Ebrard (R) and US climate envoy John Kerry hold a press conference on the sidelines of the COP27 conference in Sharm el-Sheikh, on Nov 12, 2022.
As the world races toward net zero, it's also important to consider the impact of these efforts on developing countries.

site_title: Fall of the world’s hottest stock costs Sea founders US$32b
summary: Sea Ltd, the maker of the popular battle royale game Free Fire, has seen its stock plummet 87% from its peak, wiping out the fortunes of its founders and CEO Forrest Li. The company, which operates the e-commerce platform Shopee, is now dealing with an economic slowdown, surging inflation, and intensifying competition, leading to job cuts and reduced expenses. Analysts estimate Sea's quarterly loss will widen, and the company's ability to achieve profitability and drive growth in its gaming segment is uncertain.

images.alt_text: While layoffs are painful, not all is lost. Retrenched tech workers now carry with them valuable experience.
Philippine's consumers called for a boycott of Shopee after Filipina actress and singer Toni Gonzaga, who hosted campaign rallies for Marcos, was named its new brand ambassador.

site_title: Q&M Dental’s Q3 profit down 62% on lower revenue
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 62% decrease in net profit to S$3.6 million for the third quarter, primarily due to lower revenue from its medical laboratory and dental equipment and supplies businesses, which fell 82% to $3.3 million. The decline was attributed to decreased demand for Covid-19 testing in Singapore following the economy's reopening and reduced test prices to maintain competitiveness. The group has not declared a third-quarter dividend, citing the need to conserve cash for corporate activities and future expansion.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Q&M Dental Group subsidiary, Acumen Diagnostics, won a tender from the Ministry of Health to operate a joint testing and vaccination centre.

site_title: Australia’s ANZ to pay A$42m to settle consumer credit insurance lawsuit
summary: ANZ Banking Group will pay A$42 million to settle a class action lawsuit filed by Slater & Gordon in 2020 over the sale of three consumer credit insurance products. The lawsuit alleged that ANZ and other defendants made customers believe their policy payments were "compulsory or provided value," and provided misleading advice. The settlement contribution is covered by a provision held as of September 30, 2022. The other defendants, QBE Insurance, OnePath Life, and OnePath General Insurance, have not commented on the matter.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei index opens higher on Monday
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 index opened higher on Monday, rising 0.13% or 36.37 points to 28,299.94, driven by Wall Street rallies and hopes for slower interest rate hikes. The broader Topix index fell 0.18% or 3.60 points to 1,974.16. The gains came despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions.

site_title: Australia: Shares hover at 5-month high; miners soar as China eases curbs
summary: Australian shares reached a five-month high, gaining 0.3% to 7,181 on Monday, driven by gains in mining stocks following China's easing of Covid-19 rules. The S&P/ASX 200 index had not reached this level since June 7. Improved investor sentiment, fueled by cooler-than-expected US inflation data and speculation of the Federal Reserve easing its tightening path, contributed to the surge.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Frasers Property, First Resources, SBS, UMS
summary: Sembcorp Industries is acquiring three solar projects in northern China and an independent power producer in India. The deals are valued at 15 million yuan (S$3 million) and 27.8 billion rupees (S$474 million), respectively. Sembcorp shares rose 0.7% to close at S$3.04 on Friday. Frasers Property posted a 12.4% increase in net profit to S$871.4 million for the full year ended Sep 30.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp Industries is staring at S$54 million in fines and civil claims for its water-treatment joint venture in China's illegal discharge of wastewater.

site_title: Consumer giant IFF’s Nourish unit hopes to cook up a storm in Asia
summary: IFF's Nourish unit, a division created after the US$26 billion merger with Dupont's nutrition & biosciences unit, is gaining momentum in Asia, where it had been impacted by pandemic-led travel curbs. The division aims to capitalize on its expertise in food flavors and fragrances, probiotics, enzymes, and food protection. Following a brand identity reset in February last year, Nourish is poised to engage its teams and partners across the region to unlock its full potential, marking a significant step for the consumer giant in the global value chain for consumer goods and commercial products.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Justin Chou, co-founder of Glife Technologies.
Put your money where your mouth is: vegetarian and vegan investing

site_title: First Resources underlying net profit surges 120.1% in Q3
summary: First Resources, a palm oil producer, reported a 120.1% surge in its underlying net profit for the third quarter to US$116.3 million, driven by stronger palm oil prices and the resumption of exports in Indonesia. Sales rose 15.2% to US$361.9 million due to improved average selling prices amid challenging market conditions. The company remains optimistic about demand for palm oil, despite expecting the export levy to be reimposed in November.

images.alt_text: First Resources and Golden Agri-Resources were among the potential winners named by CGS-CIMB.
Indonesia is currently conducting a road test for biodiesel with 40 per cent palm oil content, known as B40.
CPO futures contracts on the Bursa Malaysia Derivatives market are up 6.6 per cent since the beginning of the year. But since late April, the commodity is down about 33.3 per cent.
Owners of Malaysia palm oil plantations are experiencing falling earnings as palm oil fruit are left unharvested due to a lack of manpower.

site_title: China issues 16-point plan to rescue ailing property sector
summary: China has unveiled a 16-point plan to rescue its struggling property sector, addressing liquidity crises, easing bank lending restrictions, and supporting developers with loans, bonds, and trust financing. The measures aim to promote property market stability and a "soft landing" after recent data showed improvement. Key initiatives include extending developer borrowings, supporting bond issuance, and providing additional funding for project completion and acquisitions. The plan is seen as a comprehensive effort to bail out the real estate market, with central bank governor Yi Gang expressing optimism about a successful outcome.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector, once a pillar of growth, has slowed sharply this year as the government sought to restrict excessive borrowing by developers.
China is stepping up efforts to salvage the residential property market as consumer and business confidence has been battered by lockdowns.

site_title: Biden and Xi centre stage as G20 gathers in Indonesia
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping are set to meet at the G20 summit in Indonesia, amidst rising tensions between the two nations. The summit comes as the world grapples with issues such as food and fuel prices, the Ukraine conflict, and the threat of nuclear war. Biden aims to establish "red lines" with Xi to prevent competition from escalating into confrontation. However, Xi is seen as buoyed by his recent re-election and may be unwilling to make concessions. The meeting is expected to be tense, with other leaders struggling to agree on a joint communique, and Russia's absence due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (2nd from left) with PM Lee Hsien Loong (3rd from left) as Philippine President Ferdinand 'Bongbong' Marcos Jr (left) and Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha look on; Biden signalled during the meeting that he would keep communication lines with Beijing open and ensure that US competition with China – which he stated would be vigorous – does not veer into conflict.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov has put the blame on the US and its allies for the lack of communique at the 18-nation East Asian Summit, saying on Sunday (Nov 13) they “insisted on absolutely unacceptable language regarding the situation in Ukraine”.

site_title: Outcome of China’s application to join CPTPP trade pact not yet known: PM Lee
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong stated that the country supports China's interest in joining the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) in principle. However, China must meet the high standards expected of all members, which will be established and worked out between China and the existing members. The outcome of China's application is not yet known, and a consensus among all partners is required for the accession process to proceed.

images.alt_text: Promoting international trade : Less visible, but equally important, is the role of the CPTPP as a policy benchmark for trade agreements.

site_title: Gear’s break-up and delisting lowballs minority investors and does nothing for the environment
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear) shares plummeted after the company rationalized its break-up and privatisation with an ESG narrative, potentially lowballing minority investors. The move could support the development of new businesses not facing ESG pressures, driven by elevated profitability at Gear's thermal coal unit. This strategy may provide relief for the company, but critics argue it fails to address environmental concerns.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul

Sembcorp Industries should not stop accounting for the emissions of its Indian coal power business after selling that asset because it will provide financing for the buyer, non-profit Anthropocene Fixed Income Institute says.

From left: Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Mark Carney, co-chair of the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, and Hiro Mizuno, UN Special Envoy on Innovative Finance and Sustainable Investments.
The palm oil plantation is in talks with certain shareholders, including shareholder Indra Widjaja, regarding a potential deal.
Golden Energy and Resources had on Nov 9 sounded its intention to give shareholders an option of cash, or a combination of cash and shares, to delist from SGX.
Higher average selling price of energy and metallurgical coal have sweetened Golden Energy and Resources' (GEAR) earnings
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources
While robust coal demand and high prices are helping to prop up companies’ earnings now, some coal producers are already taking steps to diversify their business and revenue streams.

site_title: Philipp Lahm says ‘mistake’ for Qatar to host World Cup
summary: Philipp Lahm, Germany's 2014 World Cup-winning captain, has expressed regret over Qatar's selection as the 2022 World Cup host, calling it a "mistake." He criticized Qatar's human rights record, including treatment of foreign workers and restrictions on women's and LGBTQ rights. Lahm stated that he won't attend the tournament and will instead watch on TV, citing concerns over the tournament's atmosphere and its potential to "damage football." FIFA's decision to award the tournament to Qatar, Lahm believes, has harmed the sport.

site_title: BT Podcast: How global equities fit into your style-neutral portfolio
summary: Robert Hinchliffe from PineBridge Investments discusses the role of global equities in a style-neutral portfolio. Despite global equities declining 21% in the first half of 2022, Hinchliffe argues they can still be a valuable addition. He emphasizes the importance of considering differentiated and style-neutral portfolio allocations, as well as ESG-compliant opportunities, to safeguard wealth. Hinchliffe also notes that global equities can provide long-term alpha generation and future-proof portfolios.

images.alt_text: Omar Slim, Managing Director, Portfolio Manager, Fixed Income at Pinebridge Investments discusses with correspondent Howie Lim why there are still opportunities in the Asia IG bond space.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Hunting for beaten down stocks - A love story (Ep 25)
summary: Match Group, a leading dating app company, is experiencing a resurgence in value, making it a potential stock bargain. Senior Correspondent Ben Paul analyzes the company's portfolio of dating apps, including Tinder, OkCupid, and Hinge, and finds that they may be due for a comeback.
