Paul suggests that investors look into Match Group's stocks as a potential opportunity for returns. With a broad portfolio of brands and a strong presence in the online dating market, Match Group is worth considering for investors seeking growth potential.

images.alt_text: Tinder contributed nearly US$1.7 billion to Match's total revenue of US$3 billion in 2021
How will SATS deal with the negative market reaction to its acquisition? Ben Paul finds out.
Now that Frasers Hospitality Trust has failed to privatise, what's to happen next?

site_title: UK warns of budget pain to come this week
summary: The UK government is set to unveil an emergency budget statement on Thursday, warning of impending tax hikes, especially for high earners, to repair economic havoc caused by former Prime Minister Liz Truss. Chancellor Jeremy Hunt plans to change income tax brackets and impose strict government spending curbs to combat soaring inflation, which has hit double digits. Hunt expects the pain to fall disproportionately on the wealthy, but also acknowledges the need for sacrifices from all, particularly on the lowest incomes.

images.alt_text: Consumer spending and business investment both fell during the quarter, UK Office for National Statistics said.

site_title: Citi charity golf tournament raises S$550,000 for ChildAid
summary: Education Minister Chan Chun Sing presented a cheque of S$550,000 to ChildAid representatives, raised through the Citi charity golf tournament. The event, held on November 11, marked a record-breaking year for Citi Singapore, with over S$832,000 raised in total. The funds will support The Business Times Budding Artists Fund and The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund, benefiting disadvantaged children. Since 2005, Citi Singapore has raised more than S$7.93 million for these charities, solidifying the bank's commitment to serving the community.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for November 11, 2022, reveals a mixed market for tankers and dry bulk vessels. The Panamax market continued its sell-off, with rates dropping to $12,807, while the Capesize market saw a brief surge in value before settling at $12,807. The Transatlantic C8 and Transpacific C10 indices narrowed their premium gap. The Handysize market lost traction, with little activity on the period front. The VLCC market remained firm, with rates increasing for Middle East Gulf to China and US Gulf to China. The Suezmax market rebounded, with rates recovering lost ground. The Aframax market in the US-Caribbean region fell, while the Mediterranean market remained busy.

images.alt_text: The average of the 5 Capesize time charter routes closed the week at $11,139, slipping $2,713 week on week.

site_title: King Charles leads Remembrance Day silence for first time as British monarch
summary: King Charles led Remembrance Day commemorations in London on November 13, 2022, for the first time as monarch, following the death of Queen Elizabeth in September. He was joined by Prince William and Camilla, the queen consort. The ceremony had an "additional poignancy" due to the queen's passing, according to Chief of the Defence Staff Tony Radakin. Charles laid a newly designed wreath after a two-minute silence at The Cenotaph war memorial, marking a significant moment in his reign as the British monarch.

images.alt_text: Charles, 73, takes the throne at a time when opinion polls show that support in Britain for the monarchy has slipped to its lowest level, and that - despite a jump since he became king - he is much less personally popular than his mother.

site_title: Unicorns versus cockroaches
summary: A downturn in startup funding has led to a shift away from the "unicorn era" of excessive valuations and towards a more conservative approach. This change is driven by the need for startups to build strong foundations, prioritize low-cost entry points, and focus on sustainable business models. The article suggests that a "crashproof construction" approach, emphasizing prototyping, simplicity, and customer feedback, can help startups navigate the current climate. The author likens this approach to that of cockroaches, which are scrappy and adaptable, and argues that startups can survive and thrive by taking a more deliberate and intentional approach to building and developing their products and ecosystems.

images.alt_text: Developers in Singapore sold 487 private homes last month, falling nearly 48 per cent from the 932 units moved in September, and 36 per cent lower than the 761 units they booked in October last year.
While layoffs are painful, not all is lost. Retrenched tech workers now carry with them valuable experience.
The crypto industry had been riding high before the crash.
A slowdown in funding for Indonesian startups is giving founders a taste of a downturn, and potentially giving rise to companies that will make an impact
Rachel Lau, managing partner at RHL Ventures
The startup funding party has ended with the onset of tough macroeconomic conditions

site_title: Free World Cup screenings at 65 public locations including community clubs
summary: Singapore fans have 65 free viewing options for the World Cup, including community clubs and sports centers. The tournament kicks off on November 20 with Qatar hosting Ecuador, and the final will take place on December 18. Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong aims to bring people together to experience the excitement of watching the matches on a big screen. Fans are advised to check the schedule before heading to a screening location, as not all matches will be shown at all venues.

site_title: Sembcorp unit to acquire Indian renewable energy producer for 27.8b rupees
summary: Sembcorp Industries has agreed to acquire Vector Green Energy, an Indian renewable energy producer, for 27.8 billion rupees (S$474 million). The acquisition will increase Sembcorp's gross renewable energy capacity to 8.5 GW, including 795 MW of solar assets in China. Vector Green's portfolio includes 495 MW of solar capacity and 24 MW of wind capacity. The deal is expected to be accretive to earnings and is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2023.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: Federal Reserve may cut size of hikes, but not ‘softening’ fight against inflation: Waller
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said the US may consider slowing the pace of rate increases but emphasizes the Fed's commitment to lowering inflation, not a "softening" of its stance. Despite slower-than-expected inflation in October, Waller notes the 7.7% annualized increase is still "enormous." The Fed's next meeting may see a slower pace of rate hikes, but the endpoint of inflation reduction is still uncertain, depending on future inflation readings.

images.alt_text: epa10123384 A customer looks at products at a Walmart in Washington, DC, USA, 15 August 2022. Walmart Inc. will report fiscal second quarter earnings this week. While inflation in the United States dropped in July to 8.5 percent from 9.1 percent in June, some data show prices of food and other products to be rising.  EPA-EFE/MICHAEL REYNOLDS

site_title: Premature to say greenback has peaked
summary: The US Dollar Index (DXY) has seen a 15% year-to-date gain, fueled by the Federal Reserve's hawkish moves, but it's unclear if the greenback has peaked. The DXY continued to be volatile after the FOMC meeting, where Fed chair Jerome Powell indicated that interest rates would remain high and a pause in rate hikes was premature. The November FOMC meeting and NFP report showed a stronger US job market, but the dollar took a whiplash before heading lower. Despite this, the DXY is forming a bullish flag pullback formation, suggesting the greenback may retain leadership in the forex market.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies, the dollar was down about 3.8 per cent over two sessions.

site_title: G-20 statement in doubt as US, Russia fail to agree at Asean
summary: The US and Russia failed to agree on language for a joint statement at the 18-nation East Asian Summit in Cambodia, casting doubt on a G-20 consensus in Indonesia. Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov blamed the US and its allies for the impasse, citing "absolutely unacceptable language" regarding Ukraine. The disagreement highlights the ongoing tensions between Russia and the West, with the US and its allies pushing for Russia to end its invasion of Ukraine. Indonesia's efforts to bridge the gap between Russia and the G-7 nations are now uncertain, with a chair's statement instead of a joint communique likely.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden (2nd from left) with PM Lee Hsien Loong (3rd from left) as Philippine President Ferdinand 'Bongbong' Marcos Jr (left) and Thailand's Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha look on; Biden signalled during the meeting that he would keep communication lines with Beijing open and ensure that US competition with China – which he stated would be vigorous – does not veer into conflict.

site_title: Thailand’s U-turn on land-for-foreigners plan leaves property sector unruffled
summary: Thailand has scrapped its plan to allow foreigners to buy land, just two weeks after announcing it, amid opposition and concerns from the business community. The proposal, which would have granted foreigners the right to purchase up to one rai (0.16 hectares) of land, was met with criticism that the government was "selling off the country." The plan's withdrawal is seen as a temporary setback, with many in the property sector welcoming any legislative changes that make it easier to sell or lease properties to foreigners.

images.alt_text: Critics have argued the investment sum was too small and that the policy could drive up property prices, crowding out local ownership.
The tussle revolves around an opposition-led proposal to liberalise the production and sale of liquor and beer, which is tightly regulated in Thailand.
“Capital flows remain normal despite a weakening in the baht currency,” said Bank of Thailand's assistant governor Chayawadee Chai-Anant in a statement.

site_title: War, inflation slowing ESG projects: Deutsche CEO
summary: Deutsche Bank CEO Christian Sewing stated that the war in Ukraine and global inflation have delayed clients' environmental, social, and governance (ESG) projects, despite the long-term shift to sustainability being "irreversible". ESG financing decreased 16% to $410 billion in 2022, with Deutsche Bank arranging 3.4% of the funding. The Europe is leading on sustainable finance, with Asia grappling with its reliance on coal and the US facing ESG politicization.

images.alt_text: A study by Clarity AI found that close to 20 per cent of the 750 Article 9 funds it analysed have more than 10 per cent exposure to companies “that have violations” of United Nations Global Compact principles or the OECD Guidelines for multinational enterprises. Its research also shows that 40 per cent of the funds studied have more than a 5 per cent exposure to such violations.

site_title: Big investors are giving up on crypto markets going mainstream
summary: Big investors are giving up on mainstream adoption of cryptocurrencies, citing the recent implosions and scandals that have laid waste to the notion of Bitcoin as a safe haven. The downfall of Sam Bankman-Fried's FTX.com has permanently damaged the prospects of cryptocurrencies in institutional portfolios. Professional money managers now view the market as too risky and the losses too great, making it unlikely for cryptocurrencies to be included in mainstream asset allocation. Many industry die-hards remain, but the case for crypto as a diversifier or digital gold has been "debunked."

images.alt_text: “Bitcoin’s price has been illogically stable in recent weeks given volatility in other markets,” said analysts at Morgan Stanley in a note on Friday Nov 11.

site_title: Stable geopolitical environment needed; Xi-Biden meeting would set the tone: PM Lee
summary: US President Joe Biden and Chinese President Xi Jinping are set to meet at the G20 Summit in Indonesia, aiming to improve relations and prevent conflict between the two nations. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore emphasized the need for a stable geopolitical environment, stating that the meeting will set the tone for the region's prosperity. Biden signaled his commitment to keeping communication lines with Beijing open, while also ensuring that US competition with China does not veer into conflict. The meeting comes amid heightened US-China rivalry and Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which has threatened stability.

images.alt_text: A statement published by the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs after PM Lee and President Li met last Friday (Nov 11) mentioned that PM Lee had said that Singapore supports China’s accession to the CPTPP.

site_title: Indonesia sees swift passage of sweeping financial reform
summary: Indonesia is poised to swiftly pass a sweeping financial reform bill, which would amend outdated laws governing the financial sector, including the capital market, banking, and insurance. The bill, first introduced in 2020, aims to expand Bank Indonesia's mandate and pave the way for debt monetization during crises. The finance minister, Sri Mulyani Indrawati, assured that the central bank's independence would be maintained to ensure monetary policy credibility. The bill's swift passage is seen as a positive move for Indonesia's economy, which is expected to end the year with a lower budget deficit due to strong tax revenues.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati speaks during the launching of the pandemic fund, ahead of the G20 Summit in Nusa Dua, Bali, Indonesia, November 13, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: China regulators urge more financing support for property firms: sources
summary: China's regulators have urged financial institutions to extend more support to struggling property developers, including loan repayment extensions and financing for projects. The move aims to ease the liquidity crunch in the sector, which has slowed sharply this year due to government restrictions on excessive borrowing. The support package includes deferring loan repayments for up to a year and providing financing for projects such as rental housing construction and mergers and acquisitions. The measures come as cash-strapped developers struggle to tap funding sources, and policymakers have recently ramped up support for crash-strapped developers.

images.alt_text: After replacing builders as the biggest buyers of land earlier this year, the nation’s so-called local government financing vehicles have now become the main purchasers of half-finished projects of defaulters including China Evergrande Group.

site_title: Industrial S-Reits see resilience despite macro challenges
summary: Singapore's industrial S-Reits have reported steady performance despite macroeconomic challenges. Aims Apac Reit, EC World Reit, Mapletree Industrial Trust, and Mapletree Logistics Trust reported higher gross revenue and net property income, driven by acquisitions and leasing momentum. Average portfolio occupancy rate remained steady at 95.4%, while average gearing ratio was 37.2%. Despite a slowing GDP growth outlook, the industrial segment's resilience is attributed to long-term demand for logistics, manufacturing, and biomedical sectors.

images.alt_text: Within Q3 2022, CapitaLand Ascendas Reit announced two acquisitions in Singapore across the industrial and logistics sub-segments, totalling purchase consideration of S$296.7 million.

site_title: When your layoff has a hashtag
summary: Tech companies like Twitter and Meta, known for promoting workplace transparency, are facing public criticism from laid-off employees who are using their own tools to share their experiences. Employees are taking to social media platforms to vent about their former employers, mirroring the same openness that helped create the culture of transparency. This phenomenon is being fueled by the fact that many of these companies are now reducing their workforces, leaving former employees to process their emotions online.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk fired half of the 7,500 employees of the California company a week ago, ten days after buying the site and becoming its sole owner.
The billionaire recently cut half of Twitter’s staff and introduced dramatic changes to its subscription rules.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on October 23, 2019 Facebook Chairman and CEO Mark Zuckerberg testifies before the House Financial Services Committee on "An Examination of Facebook and Its Impact on the Financial Services and Housing Sectors" in the Rayburn House Office Building in Washington, DC. - Facebook-parent Meta put out word to employees on September 29, 2022 that it will freeze hiring to cut costs as it endures tough economic times, The Wall Street Journal reported. Meta chief Mark Zuckerberg revealed a planned pause in hiring during a weekly all-hands meeting, the Journal reported, saying the move came as the social media titan planned to cut expenses by at least 10 percent. (Photo by MANDEL NGAN / AFP)

Meta Platforms Inc. signage during the virtual Meta Connect event in New York, US, on Tuesday, Oct. 11, 2022. Mark Zuckerberg unveiled his company's newest virtual-reality headset, the Meta Quest Pro, the latest foray into the world of high-end VR devices that Meta Platforms hopes will entice creators and working professionals to adopt its vision for a virtual future. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Malaysia evacuates thousands as monsoon-season flash floods hit
summary: Malaysia is evacuating over 1,800 people from flood-affected areas as the monsoon season brings flash floods to various states. The floods have sparked renewed criticism of the government's decision to hold an early election on November 19, during the monsoon season. The move comes after last year's floods, the nation's worst in decades, left dozens dead and caused an estimated RM6.1 billion in losses. The government has set up over 6,000 temporary shelters nationwide to accommodate over a million people.

site_title: Vietnam’s clean energy transition slowed by inadequate regulation and grid despite solar boom
summary: Vietnam's clean energy transition has been hindered by inadequate regulation and grid infrastructure, despite a significant increase in solar capacity over the past four years. The country now leads ASEAN in solar energy generation, with 4,750 megawatts of capacity, but its transition to a clean energy future is slow. Experts attribute this to underdeveloped regulations and grid inadequacy, hindering the efficient use of clean energy. Vietnam's solar boom has been exponential, but the country's clean energy transition has taken place at a slower pace.

images.alt_text: Sharon See

Hoe Boon Chye, chief executive of Barghest Building Performance, believes the Vietnam segment of his business has the potential to grow 40 per cent year on year, given the country's rapid industrialisation.

The AVA team met their client Dinh Van Thang, site manager of Phuoc Minh Adani Solar (second from right), at a solar plant in Ninh Thuan, Vietnam in April. From left to right is AVA solution architect Yip Chok Meng, CEO Lee Wei Yik and technical manager Theodore Teo.
Food makes friends, said food distributor L'earth Vietnam's co-founder and director Teri Teo, as he explained his passion in introducing more Singapore F&B brands to Vietnam.

The Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Park's (VSIP) decision to not exit despite the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis likely helped  co-developer SembCorp Development to "score points" and gain trust from its Vietnamese partners, VSIP co-chair Kelvin Teo said.
Industry watchers said companies used to a more structured and predictable way of doing business, like the way it is in Singapore, would also be in for a culture shock.
Now that international borders have reopened, more Singapore companies are heading to Vietnam in search of business opportunities, industry watchers told The Business Times.

site_title: Crypto markets take a breather as FTX heist unfurls
summary: Crypto markets experienced a brief stabilization on Saturday, Nov 12, after FTX.com filed for bankruptcy, with Bitcoin and Ether remaining largely unchanged at $16,800 and $1,260, respectively. Dogecoin surged 10% following Elon Musk's Twitter Spaces conversation, while Solana and Serum, backed by FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried, declined 5% and 9%, respectively. Analysts at Morgan Stanley attributed Bitcoin's stability to limited spillover to broader equity markets, with US$12,500 seen as a potential support level.

images.alt_text: FTX’s scandal has notable parallels with what befell Enron. Both were led by messianic figures in Sam Bankman-Fried and Jeff Skilling who dazzled faithful with feats of technical wizardry. Both bathed in near-universal adoration from the press and the financial establishment.
Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao has tweeted that it has stopped FTT deposits to prevent potentially questionable additional supplies affecting the market.

BlockFi on Twitter said it will pause client withdrawals, citing “a lack of clarity” over the status of onetime saviour FTX US as well as the uncertainty afflicting FTX.com and sister trading house Alameda Research.

site_title: Jeff Bezos gives Dolly Parton US$100m in latest award
summary: Dolly Parton has received the latest Courage and Civility award from Jeff Bezos, with a $100 million donation to direct to any charities she chooses. Parton, a philanthropist and advocate for literacy and vaccination, has operated a foundation that distributes books to children globally. Bezos, the world's fourth-richest person, has previously awarded $100 million to chef Jose Andres and Van Jones, and has increased his philanthropic efforts since stepping down as Amazon CEO. Parton expressed gratitude and vowed to use the donation to do "good things."

images.alt_text: RAPPER Eminem is among the performers who will be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame this year, organizers said on Wednesday (May 4).

site_title: SGX Cares Bull Charge raises S$3m for beneficiaries
summary: The SGX Cares Bull Charge Charity Run has raised approximately S$3 million for its beneficiaries, surpassing its initial target. The hybrid event, which included a virtual run and an in-person 5km mass run and 3.5km Chief Challenge, attracted 6,500 participants. The event aimed to promote physical activity and raise funds for various charitable causes, with proceeds supporting beneficiaries in need.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang
At least 2,500 of the bank’s employees will be deployed to run some 800 workshops at DBS/POSB branches.

site_title: Bankman-Fried: From crypto king to king of tech bubble’s losers
summary: Sam Bankman-Fried's crypto empire, FTX, collapsed after a whirlwind week of events, leaving behind a trail of financial mismanagement and regulatory weaknesses. The company's downfall, which resulted in the bankruptcy of FTX and over 130 other companies, bears striking parallels with the Enron and WorldCom scandals. Easy money, wishful thinking, and hubris led to the implosion, as the Federal Reserve's aggressive tightening cycle exposed the vulnerabilities of the crypto market. Experts warn that the collapse is a harbinger of a broader economic cycle, with the tech industry serving as a posterchild for the boom-overbuild-bust cycle.

images.alt_text: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao has tweeted that it has stopped FTT deposits to prevent potentially questionable additional supplies affecting the market.
“Bitcoin’s price has been illogically stable in recent weeks given volatility in other markets,” said analysts at Morgan Stanley in a note on Friday Nov 11.
FTX files for bankruptcy on Friday (Nov 11) after a rush of customer withdrawals earlier this week.
FTX’s collapse marks a stunning reversal of fortunes for the company and its founder Sam Bankman-Fried.
FTX is facing regulatory probes as investors mark down their shares to zero.

BlockFi on Twitter said it will pause client withdrawals, citing “a lack of clarity” over the status of onetime saviour FTX US as well as the uncertainty afflicting FTX.com and sister trading house Alameda Research.
FTX is scrambling to raise about US$9.4 billion from investors and rivals as the exchange urgently seeks to save itself after a rush of customer withdrawals.
Binance backed out of plans to acquire FTX, the company said on Wednesday (Nov 9).

site_title: Binance halts FTT deposits, CEO says
summary: Binance has halted FTT deposits to prevent potentially questionable additional supplies affecting the market, according to CEO Changpeng Zhao. The move follows FTX's bankruptcy filing and detection of unauthorized access, which led to the movement of hundreds of millions of dollars in assets. Zhao stated that FTT contract deployers have moved all remaining FTT supply worth $400 million, which should be unlocked in batches. Binance will monitor the situation, urging other rival exchanges to follow suit.

site_title: US hotels reel from China Covid curbs amid travel boom
summary: US hotel operators face challenges due to China's strict Covid-19 lockdowns, which have halted construction of luxury properties and impacted travel to the country. The lockdowns have pressured room growth and hospitality revenue in China, with Marriott International's RevPAR from Greater China down 20% year-over-year. The hotel chain lowered its gross room growth forecast for 2022, citing uncertainty over China's reopening. Experts warn of a delayed recovery in outbound travel from China, which could further impact the travel industry.

images.alt_text: Travellers into China will be required to spend five days in a hotel or government quarantine facility, followed by three days confined to home.

site_title: Singapore, Germany sign framework for sustainability and innovation
summary: Singapore and Germany signed a framework for sustainability and innovation, deepening their economic cooperation. The Germany-Singapore Framework for Sustainability and Innovation (FSI) was signed by Minister-in-charge of Trade Relations S Iswaran and Germany Federal Minister for Economic Affairs and Climate Action Robert Habeck. The signing was held during the 17th Asia-Pacific Conference for German Business in Singapore. The move strengthens ties between the two countries, with Singapore being Germany's largest goods trading partner and fourth-largest services trading partner in the European Union.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

site_title: New York City developer hunts for homebuyers squeezed by borrowing costs
summary: New York City developer Extell Development is offering to pay down the mortgage rate for homebuyers at its buildings, One Manhattan Square and Brooklyn Point, in an effort to spur sales amidst skyrocketing borrowing costs. The offer, which includes a 2 percentage point annual rate reduction during the first three years of a loan, is intended to add to the developer's competitive advantage in the market. With 57% of One Manhattan Square's units and 66% of Brooklyn Point's units still unsold, the offer is seen as a motivating factor for potential buyers, with some developers citing it as a way to address affordability concerns.

images.alt_text: “Beginning in June and continuing through today, we have seen a moderation in housing demand caused by significant increases in mortgage interest rates and general economic uncertainty,” DR Horton's chairman Donald R Horton said in a statement.

site_title: Musk’s lawyer calms Twitter staff fearing jail risk for FTC lapses
summary: Elon Musk's lawyer, Alex Spiro, has reassured Twitter staff that they will not face jail time if the company is found in violation of a Federal Trade Commission (FTC) consent decree. Following the takeover, an information security team was laid off, and concerns arose about staff liability for security lapses. Spiro stated that the company's obligation, burden, and liability are its own, and employees will not be held personally responsible. This move aims to calm heightened concerns among Twitter staff.

images.alt_text: “To combat impersonation, we’ve added an ‘Official’ label to some accounts,” Twitter’s support account – which has the “official” tag – tweeted on Friday.

site_title: NASA sticks to plan to launch Moon rocket Wednesday
summary: NASA plans to launch its uncrewed mission, Artemis 1, to the Moon on Wednesday, as scheduled, despite minor damage from Hurricane Nicole. Inspections revealed no major issues, and teams have access to the launch pad. The launch is set for 1:04 am local time, with a two-hour launch window, marking a step closer to returning astronauts to the Moon five decades after humans last walked on the lunar surface.

images.alt_text: The celestial target of the Dart flight was an egg-shaped asteroid named Dimorphos.

site_title: Malaysia’s political parties enter enemy territory to win votes
summary: Malaysia's main political parties are intensifying their campaigns ahead of the November 19 general election, with Pakatan Harapan (PH) and Perikatan Nasional (PN) attacking each other's strongholds and traditional Barisan Nasional bastions. Opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim's PH launched a whirlwind one-day campaign in Pahang, a traditional PN stronghold, while Muhyiddin Yassin's PN has been targeting PH strongholds. The fierce campaigning is expected to lead to a tight race, with the election outcome uncertain.

images.alt_text: Pakatan Harapan's supporters wave the party's flags during a campaing rally ahead of Malaysia's general election, in Tambun, Perak, Malaysia November 5, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain

site_title: Democratic senator Mark Kelly edges out Blake Masters in Arizona
summary: Democratic Senator Mark Kelly has won re-election in Arizona, defeating Republican Blake Masters. Kelly's victory, despite high inflation and President Biden's low approval ratings, was attributed to strong fundraising and his ability to separate himself from Biden on key issues. Kelly's significant fundraising advantage, $73 million to Masters' $9.7 million, and outside Democratic support contributed to his win. The victory helps Democrats maintain control of the Senate, with Vice President Kamala Harris's ability to break tie votes.

images.alt_text: Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer (pink) was re-elected in the “blue wall” state of Michigan.

site_title: Disney plans to freeze hiring, cut some jobs
summary: Disney plans to freeze hiring and cut some jobs amid economic uncertainty as it strives to move the Disney+ streaming service to profitability. The move comes after the company missed Wall Street estimates for quarterly earnings, with losses mounting from its push into streaming video. CEO Bob Chapek has established a task force to manage costs, with some staff reductions anticipated, while hiring will be limited to critical positions.

images.alt_text: The company beat expectations for streaming subscriber additions in the period, signing up 12.1 million new customers for its flagship Disney+ service alone.

site_title: Tokyo's iconic Capsule Tower cubes get a new lease of life
summary: Tokyo's iconic Capsule Tower, a 13-storey building of 140 interlocking grey cubes, was dismantled earlier this year. However, nearly two dozen capsules are being restored in a warehouse outside the city, featuring original and replacement stereo systems, mini fridges, built-in desks and beds, and restored bathrooms. Former resident Tatsuyuki Maeda, 55, is preserving the building's legacy, cube by cube, with the goal of allowing more people to experience the unique capsules.

images.alt_text: Today, at 50, Trellick is viewed as an icon of brutalist architecture, with a striking design that connects a thin service tower — housing laundries, elevator shafts and a garbage chute — to the main block at every third floor by “sky bridges”.

site_title: Guardiola says Man City tenure will be his longest
summary: Pep Guardiola stated that he doesn't think he could manage another club for as long as he has been at Manchester City, which is seven years. He cited the support of the club's chairman, sporting director, and staff as key factors in his long tenure. Guardiola's current contract is set to expire in the summer of 2023, and he is open to discussing a renewal when the time is right, but has stated that everything is "under control" and a decision will be made together with the club.

images.alt_text: Manchester City's star striker Erling Haaland (second from right) in action against Southampton in the English Premier League last weekend. The Norwegian has scored 15 times in just nine league games.

site_title: As tech industry cuts jobs, these are some of the worst ways to get fired
summary: Tech industry layoffs have sparked controversy, with some companies, like Twitter and Meta Platforms, facing backlash for their handling of mass firings. Poorly executed layoffs can damage an employer's brand and morale, as seen in cases like Better.com, which laid off 900 employees via Zoom, and Bird, which fired 400 employees in a one-way Zoom call. Experts, such as professor Wayne Cascio, emphasize the importance of handling layoffs with empathy and transparency. Five particularly ignominious layoffs include the use of text messages, fire alarms, and automated robotic voices, highlighting the need for more compassionate and considerate approaches to downsizing.

images.alt_text: Hung Truong, who remembers feeling relieved after sharing online about his layoff from Lyft at the start of the pandemic, at his home in Seattle on Nov 8, 2022. As Twitter, Meta and other companies that helped create a culture of more workplace transparency slash their work forces, some laid off employees are very publicly using those social media platforms to critique their former employers.

site_title: Asean free trade agreement with Australia and New Zealand upgraded for times of crisis
summary: ASEAN member states Australia and New Zealand have upgraded their free trade agreement to include new features to ensure the continued flow of essential goods during times of crisis. The upgraded agreement, AANZFTA, will benefit more Singapore-based companies through facilitative rules in trade in goods and services. New commitments include sterilisation support, education services cooperation, and a standalone chapter on trade and sustainable development. The agreement aims to promote a more conducive environment for businesses and position the AANZFTA well to deal with future crises and challenges.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
shaking hands, handshake, hands

site_title: Alibaba keeps Singles Day sales tally under wraps for first time
summary: Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba has kept its sales figures for its annual Singles Day event under wraps for the first time, citing a cooling economy and demand. Last year's sales reached 540.3 billion yuan ($76.1 billion), but this year's sales were reportedly "in line" with last year's despite macro challenges and COVID-impact. The event, which has been a benchmark for global e-commerce sales, has seen a muted performance in recent years due to regulatory crackdowns and waning state media coverage.

images.alt_text: In recent years, pre-sales were headlined by Li Jiaqi and Viya, known respectively as China’s livestreaming sales king and queen who sold everything from lipstick to rocket launchers on Taobao Live, Alibaba’s livestreaming channel.

site_title: When tech stocks sputter, the entire stock market sinks
summary: Tech stocks have significantly declined this year, with companies like Meta, Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple suffering staggering losses. Their stock market values have plummeted, with Meta losing nearly three-quarters of its value. This decline is a result of the broader market's shift due to inflation, rising interest rates, and plunging asset prices. As the Federal Reserve holds interest rates at high levels, a recession becomes more likely, affecting the appeal of high-growth tech investments.

images.alt_text: Stocks like Meta, Microsoft, Amazon and Apple have suffered staggering losses this year, but is this a good time to buy? (Thomas Fuchs/The New York Times) -- FOR EDITORIAL USE ONLY WITH NYT STORY SLUGGED TECH STOCKS ADV13 BY JEFF SOMMER FOR NOV. 12, 2022. ALL OTHER USE PROHIBITED. --

site_title: At least US$1 billion of client funds missing at failed crypto firm FTX: sources
summary: FTX, a failed crypto exchange, filed for bankruptcy on November 11 after a surge in customer withdrawals. At least $1 billion of customer funds have vanished, with one source estimating the missing amount at $1.7 billion. FTX's founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, secretly transferred $10 billion of customer funds to his trading company Alameda Research, with a significant portion now unaccounted for. The exact amount missing remains unclear, but it is believed to be between $1 billion and $2 billion.

images.alt_text: FTX’s collapse marks a stunning reversal of fortunes for the company and its founder Sam Bankman-Fried.

site_title: Trump sues Jan 6 committee to block subpoena for testimony
summary: Former US President Donald Trump has filed a lawsuit to block a subpoena for his testimony issued by the special congressional committee investigating the Jan 6 assault on the US Capitol. Trump claims "absolute immunity" and that the subpoena is "unlawful" due to a lack of a "valid legislative purpose." The committee, set to expire at the end of the congressional term, may be unable to extend its investigation if Republicans take control of the House in the upcoming midterm elections.

images.alt_text: The cover of NewsCorp’s New York Post depicted Donald Trump on a precarious wall as “Trumpty Dumpty” who “had a great fall” in the vote, blaming him for the failure of Republicans to sweep past Democratic rivals in the vote.

site_title: Biden to warn Xi North Korea's path could prompt bigger US military presence
summary: US President Joe Biden will warn Chinese President Xi Jinping that North Korea's pursuit of nuclear bomb testing will lead to an enhanced US military presence in the region. The US is concerned that North Korea plans to resume nuclear bomb testing for the first time since 2017. Biden's warning comes as the US believes China and Russia have leverage to persuade North Korea not to proceed with nuclear testing. The meeting aims to limit deterioration of US-China ties while addressing US concerns, including Taiwan and human rights.

images.alt_text: People watch a television screen showing a news broadcast about a North Korean missile test in Seoul, Nov 2, 2022. In October, North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile farther than ever before, sending it soaring over Japan for the first time in five years.

site_title: Europe: Stocks clock best week in nearly eight months
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index ended at an 11-week high, up 0.1% on Friday, driven by bets on smaller US interest rate hikes and easing COVID-19 curbs in China. Financial services, mining, and retail stocks led gains, with luxury goods retailers like Hermes and Kering jumping 2.4-2.8% and Richemont soaring 10.5%. The index marked a 3.7% weekly gain, as investors welcomed looser COVID-19 rules in China and upbeat earnings season.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 jumped 2.8 per cent, notching its biggest percentage gain in five weeks.

site_title: ‘Wakanda Forever’ forges international alliances on a somber soundtrack
summary: The soundtrack for "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" features a diverse array of artists and musicians from Africa, Mexico, and the US, reflecting the film's international themes and undersea setting. The album, which includes Rihanna's hit single "Lift Me Up," combines somber and ominous tracks with danceable and uplifting ones, showcasing a range of genres and styles. The soundtrack's collaborations highlight the cultural exchange and representation that the Black Panther franchise aims to promote, with contributions from artists such as Burna Boy, Stormzy, and Foudeqush.

images.alt_text: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, which arrives in theatres this week, scored a 94% positive rating on Rotten Tomatoes.

site_title: FTX to start US bankruptcy proceedings, CEO resigns
summary: Cryptocurrency exchange FTX is starting US bankruptcy proceedings after a liquidity crisis prompted intervention from regulators worldwide. CEO Sam Bankman-Fried is stepping down, following a wave of withdrawals that threatened the company's collapse. FTX and its affiliated companies, including Alameda Research, have commenced voluntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in Delaware, affecting approximately 130 other companies. The collapse marks a stunning reversal of fortunes for the company and its founder.

images.alt_text: FTX is facing regulatory probes as investors mark down their shares to zero.

BlockFi on Twitter said it will pause client withdrawals, citing “a lack of clarity” over the status of onetime saviour FTX US as well as the uncertainty afflicting FTX.com and sister trading house Alameda Research.
FTX is scrambling to raise about US$9.4 billion from investors and rivals as the exchange urgently seeks to save itself after a rush of customer withdrawals.

site_title: US consumer inflation expectations rise in Michigan survey
summary: US consumer inflation expectations have risen to 3% over the next 5-10 years, the highest in five months, according to a University of Michigan survey. Expectations for short-term inflation (next year) increased to 5.1% from 5%. The sentiment index dropped to 54.7, a four-month low, amid rising borrowing costs.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 end sharply higher, fueled by inflation optimism
summary: US stocks ended sharply higher on Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq experiencing their largest weekly gains since June and March, respectively. The rally was fueled by optimism over soft inflation, which raised hopes the Federal Reserve would ease interest rate hikes. The S&P 500 rose 0.9% to 3,993.05 points, while the Nasdaq gained 1.9% to 11,323.33 points, with Amazon, Apple, and Microsoft driving the gains.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 82.38 points, or 0.24 per cent, at the open to 33,797.75.

site_title: Towards standardised impact evaluation
summary: Singapore's social enterprises face challenges in securing funding due to the lack of standardised impact evaluation metrics. This makes it difficult for funders to assess and compare the organisations, leading to varying evaluation requirements. Standardised metrics could increase funding applications, benefiting both social purpose organisations and impact funders. Implementing such standards would require collaboration among stakeholders, evidence-based research, and avoiding conflicts of interest. This could lead to the creation of impact investing marketplaces, increasing exposure for organisations and providing funders with a wider pool of projects to assess and fund.

images.alt_text: Illustration for the article "Investing for impact"

site_title: Nearly half Meta job cuts were in tech, executives say
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, has slashed 13% of its workforce, the first mass layoffs in its 18-year history, with 54% of the 11,000 cut jobs being business roles. The remaining 46% were in technology, including the recruiting team. The company is exiting its Portal smart display business and will discontinue smartwatch work. CEO Mark Zuckerberg acknowledged the layoffs were due to lower-than-expected revenue, with advertisers and consumers pulling back on spending amid rising costs and interest rates.

images.alt_text: Zuckerberg is also expected to be questioned about the Facebook-parent’s strategy for its VR business.

site_title: Wilmar chair presses on with open market acquisitions
summary: Singapore stocks rose 2.3% over the five sessions from Nov 4-10, driven by institutional net inflows of S$277 million. UOB, OCBC, DBS, CapitaLand Investment, and Singtel led the net institutional inflows, while Sats, Jardine Matheson Holdings, Keppel Reit, Nanofilm Technologies International, and Frasers Logistic & Commercial Trust led the outflows. Share buybacks totaled S$15.1 million, with Sembcorp Industries and Acesian Partners conducting significant transactions. Wilmar International's chairman, Kuok Khoon Hong, increased his stake to 13% after acquiring shares through his company, HPRY Holdings.

images.alt_text: Overall, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks for the five sessions ending Nov 3, with S$290 million of net inflows. This brought the 2022 year-to-Nov-3 net institutional inflows to just over S$750 million.

site_title: Thomson Reuters to buy tax software provider SurePrep for US$500m
summary: Thomson Reuters is acquiring tax software provider SurePrep for $500 million in cash, with the deal expected to close in the first quarter of 2023. The partnership has been in place since April and has seen SurePrep generate $60 million in revenue in 2022, with annual growth projected at over 20%. The acquisition aims to deliver end-to-end tax automation solutions to customers, addressing their pain points.

site_title: Best World to resume trading after 3.5-year suspension
summary: Best World International, a beauty products distributor, will resume trading on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) on November 14 after a 3.5-year suspension due to regulatory concerns over its business model in China. The company has submitted several trading resumption proposals and received approval from the frontline market regulator. Despite a decline in revenue and net profit in the latest quarter, Best World's financials have continued to grow, with revenue more than doubling to S$580 million in FY2021. The company's share price has fallen nearly 60% since its suspension, and investors may be cautious about the stock's performance after such a lengthy hiatus.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Best World noted the conditions by SGX RegCo for it to resume trading.
On Jun 16, Best World had also received an improved audit opinion from its independent auditor for its audited financial results for the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2021.
Best World International headquarters at Tai Seng

site_title: Oil settles higher, posts weekly loss as China eases Covid-19 curbs
summary: Oil prices rose on Friday, settling up 1.1% from the previous session at $95.99 a barrel, but fell 2.6% on the week due to easing Covid-19 curbs in China, which raised hopes for improved economic activity and demand. The easing includes shorter quarantine times and eliminating penalties on airlines for infected passengers. A weaker US dollar also supported oil prices, while rising US oil inventories and lingering fears of capped fuel demand in China contributed to the decline.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled 1.1 per cent higher at US$93.67 on Thursday, a US$1.02 gain.

site_title: Alec Baldwin files lawsuit in deadly 'Rust' shooting
summary: Alec Baldwin filed a lawsuit against armorer Hannah Gutierrez-Reed and three other crew members in connection with the 2021 "Rust" shooting that killed cinematographer Halyna Hutchins. Baldwin's cross complaint alleges negligence and seeks damages for "immense grief." The lawsuit claims the crew members failed to properly check the gun and were reckless in their handling of live ammunition. Baldwin denies pulling the trigger, and an FBI forensic test found the revolver functioned normally without being pulled. The case is one of several pieces of litigation stemming from the tragedy, also under criminal investigation.

images.alt_text: Baldwin said has reached a civil settlement with the family of the woman he fatally shot with a prop gun on a film set last year.

site_title: Ex-Goldman banker Ng, convicted in 1MDB case, sues ex-boss Leissner for US$130 million
summary: Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker convicted of conspiring to violate an anti-bribery law and commit money laundering in the 1MDB case, has sued his ex-boss Tim Leissner for over $130 million, alleging fraud. Ng claims Leissner repeatedly lied to steal his investments in Celsius Holdings and Sentient Technologies, which were worth millions. Leissner's thefts, Ng alleges, included a $1.25 million Celsius stake now worth over $130 million, to cover his own defense costs in a related case.

site_title: China proposes new rules on banking sector bankruptcy
summary: China's banking and insurance regulator, the CBIRC, proposes new rules on banking sector bankruptcy to reduce financial risk and support industry development. The draft amendments would allow banks to apply to a court for bankruptcy, outline takeover procedures, and provide specific guidance for regulators. The rules also aim to tighten data security, restricting overseas access to business-related documents and prohibiting domestic investigations without authorization. These changes follow high-profile scandals in the sector, including the 2019 takeover of Baoshang Bank.

site_title: Five debutants to watch out for at the World Cup
summary: Five debutants to watch out for at the World Cup include Alphonso Davies of Canada, known for his speed and strength, Takefusa Kubo of Japan, who has been compared to Lionel Messi, Christian Pulisic of the US, a Champions League winner, Kim Min-jae of South Korea, nicknamed the "Monster" for his precise tackling, and Almoez Ali of Qatar, a striker who has scored in three different continental championships.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football - UEFA Nations League - Group A - Denmark v Croatia - Parken, Copenhagen, Denmark - June 10, 2022
Denmark players pose for a team group photo before the match
Liselotte Sabroe/Ritzau Scanpix via REUTERS/File Photo

ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE WAS PROVIDED BY A THIRD PARTY. DENMARK OUT. NO COMMERCIAL OR EDITORIAL SALES IN DENMARK.

The server room at the International Broadcast Center in Doha; Fifa’s revenue from selling global rights to the World Cup has nearly doubled in the last 20 years. Rights for the 2002 World Cup netted Fifa US$1.69 billion. In 2018, it collected slightly over US$3 billion.
A signage of Qatar 2022 on display in Doha, Qatar, where the Fifa World Cup will be staged from Nov 20 to Dec 18.

site_title: US Senate control still a toss-up, Republicans inch toward House majority
summary: The US Senate control remains uncertain, with Republicans inching closer to a majority, while Democrats are trying to fend off challengers in Arizona and Nevada. Officials in these states warn that tallying uncounted mail-in ballots could take until next week. Meanwhile, Republicans are on track to capture a House majority, with 211 of the 218 seats needed. President Biden maintains hope for a Democratic House victory, despite the odds, while the Republican leader, Kevin McCarthy, has announced his intention to run for speaker if Republicans take over.

images.alt_text: The cover of NewsCorp’s New York Post depicted Donald Trump on a precarious wall as “Trumpty Dumpty” who “had a great fall” in the vote, blaming him for the failure of Republicans to sweep past Democratic rivals in the vote.

site_title: Apple supplier Foxconn plans to quadruple workforce at India plant: sources
summary: Foxconn, an Apple supplier, plans to quadruple its workforce at its Indian plant in Tamil Nadu to 70,000 over the next two years, adding 53,000 workers. The move comes as the company faces disruptions in China, prompting Apple to lower its forecast for iPhone 14 shipments. The expansion aims to shift production away from China, with the Indian plant already manufacturing products for other global tech firms.

images.alt_text: Taiwanese contract manufacturer Foxconn told Reuters on Wednesday (Nov 9) its massive Zhengzhou plant in central China will maintain so-called closed-loop operations.

Taiwan’s Foxconn, the world’s largest contract electronics manufacturer, has ramped up investment in EVs and semiconductors in recent years, announcing deals with US startup Fisker and Indian conglomerate Vedanta.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on Fed optimism
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, Nov 11, following soft inflation data that supported expectations of smaller interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 82.38 points, or 0.24%, to 33,797.75. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with the S&P 500 gaining 7.35 points, or 0.19%, and the Nasdaq Composite rising 10.60 points, or 0.10%. The gains extended from the previous session and reflected optimism about the Fed's future policy decisions.

site_title: Billionaire Hinduja brothers call truce on bitter family feud
summary: The Hinduja brothers, billionaire owners of a UK-based conglomerate, have called a truce on a bitter family feud. The dispute, which included accusations of funding and misappropriation, threatened the future of the business empire. The family patriarch, Srichand Hinduja, who suffers from dementia, was days away from being transferred to a government-run NHS hospital, prompting criticism from a London judge. The brothers have agreed to halt litigation across Europe, ending the feud for now.

images.alt_text: Gautam Adani (left) and Mukesh Ambani are profiting from a surge in global commodity prices triggered by Russia's invasion of Ukraine, burnishing their fossil-fuel credentials even as Asia's richest men publicly push their pivots toward greener energy.

site_title: Twitter restores ‘official’ label; US$8 blue check mark option vanishes
summary: Twitter has reinstated the "official" label on some accounts, but the US$8 blue check mark subscription option, introduced by Elon Musk, has been removed. The move comes after a surge in fake accounts on the platform. The label aims to combat impersonation, but its disappearance coincides with the removal of the paid verification option, which allowed users to pay $8 for the blue check mark. The change is a reversal of the previous decision, which was made just days ago.

site_title: SNB ready to take “all measures necessary” to tame inflation: chairman
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) is prepared to take "all measures necessary" to bring inflation back down to its 0-2% target range, chairman Thomas Jordan said. The SNB is considering interest rate hikes, currency purchases, and sales to steer policy towards its goal. Despite easing inflation to 3.0% in October, Jordan warned that a speedy and effective response is required to prevent an inflationary environment from becoming entrenched. The SNB is also facing challenges, including weakening business activity and energy shortages.

site_title: China yuan’s long-term strengthening trend will not change: state media
summary: China's yuan finished its domestic trading session at its strongest level since late-September, amid easing of Covid-19 prevention controls. State-run media outlet Economic Daily stated the yuan's long-term strengthening trend won't change, citing sound economic fundamentals and low inflation. The currency has still lost 10.7% against the US dollar this year, its biggest annual decline since 1994. Market analysts expect continued volatility, with "two-way volatilities" normal, and the yuan has room for appreciation.

site_title: Singapore boards need to strengthen corporate governance practices
summary: Singapore-listed companies need to strengthen their corporate governance practices, particularly in board renewal, remuneration disclosure, and director training. A survey found that 35% of respondents have independent directors serving over nine years, with 67% intending to put them up for shareholder vote. Disclosure of executive remuneration remains an issue, with 70 companies not disclosing individual director and CEO remuneration. Regulators are consulting on changing the rule to include a hard limit on directors' tenure and have expressed concerns over companies' attitudes towards long-serving independent directors.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

A review of corporate governance disclosures by KPMG in Singapore, published in September, found only 35 per cent of companies disclosed the actual remuneration of directors on a named basis, while 18 per cent did so for CEOs.
SGX RegCo's stiffening regulatory attitude is unlikely to be popular among corporate boards
SGX RegCo will review market feedback before making a decision, including whether the hard tenure limit will be set at 9 years or some other number.

site_title: GSK's oncology business suffers fresh blow with Zejula setback
summary: GSK's oncology business has suffered another setback with the restriction of its ovarian cancer drug Zejula in the US as a second-line treatment option, citing safety concerns. The move comes after the company's blood cancer drug Blenrep failed to outperform an older therapy in a key study. Zejula's use will be limited to patients whose tumors carry certain mutations, and the company has withdrawn its use in certain ovarian cancer patients who had previously undergone multiple chemotherapy regimens.

images.alt_text: The British drugmaker reported third-quarter adjusted profit of 46.9 pence per share on sales of about £7.83 billion

site_title: UMS Q3 net profit jumps 181 per cent to S$42.5 million
summary: UMS Holdings, a semiconductor company, reported a 181% increase in net profit for the third quarter to S$42.5 million, driven by stronger revenue of 48% to S$100.1 million. Revenue for the first nine months rose 48% to S$271.4 million, beating last year's sales. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.01 per share. CEO Andy Luong expressed confidence in the group's performance, citing a robust outlook for the next six months despite a lower forecast from a key customer.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Maybank Securities noted in its Wednesday market report that the strong earnings posted by semiconductor-related stocks in Q3 might not hold in the longer term.
Analysts expect demand to slow as consumers tighten their wallets going amid a weaker macroeconomic environment.

site_title: Frasers Property full-year earnings up 12.4% to S$871.4 million on easing of Covid-19 restrictions
summary: Frasers Property reported a 12.4% increase in full-year net profit to S$871.4 million, driven by the resumption of international travel and residential projects in Singapore and Thailand. Revenue rose 3% to S$3.88 billion, with the hospitality segment seeing a 62% jump. The company also reported a 40.4% year-on-year increase in six-month net profit to S$741.8 million. Frasers Property remains cautiously optimistic about the long-term growth potential of the hospitality sector, despite bumpy recovery prospects.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Artist's impression of Sky Eden@Bedok, the first residential launch in Bedok Town Centre in 10 years.

site_title: PM Lee urges Asean to stay united amid escalating geopolitical tensions
summary: Singapore's Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong urged Asean nations to remain united amid escalating geopolitical tensions, including the Russia-Ukraine conflict. He emphasized the importance of upholding Asean centrality and championing a rules-based world order. Lee warned that deep strategic mistrust between the US and China could lead to an "escalatory spiral" and called for Asean to maintain peace and stability in the South China Sea. The bloc also launched talks to upgrade the Asean-China Free Trade Area and discussed the East Asia Summit, a platform for major powers to discuss developments and deepen cooperation.

images.alt_text: An empty chair set aside for Myanmar's delegation at the Asean Summit in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. The Myanmar crisis dominated the first day of a summit.
Indonesian President Joko Widodo wants Asean to create a dialogue involving armed ethnic groups, the junta and supporters of deposed civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi.

site_title: India's Indo-Pacific Economic Framework membership will strengthen the region, says Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that India's membership in the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF) will strengthen the region by making supply chains resilient between the US and India. Yellen emphasized strong trade, investment, and people-to-people ties as critical elements of the bilateral economic and financial relationship. She also highlighted the US desire to deepen economic ties with India, citing the need for democracies to address global economic challenges. Yellen proposed goals for India's leadership of the G20 group, focusing on boosting investment, debt restructuring, and digital economy access.

images.alt_text: ESM Goh Chok Tong at the launch of 'Asean and India: The Way Forward' at the National Library on 12 October 2022.

site_title: Strong or Volcker? The Fed and global financial stability
summary: The US Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary tightening has disrupted global financial stability, with US securities markets suffering substantial losses. However, the US economy and financial system remain relatively solid. The Fed's policies have historically had significant cross-border implications, and its decisions may impact countries holding large amounts of dollar-denominated debt. Two historical scenarios, Ben Strong's accommodation in the 1920s and Paul Volcker's tightening in the 1980s, highlight the complexities of the Fed's actions. The current US political atmosphere prioritizes domestic concerns, leading to a likely Volcker-esque approach, which may have severe consequences for vulnerable nations.

images.alt_text: money, profit, finance
The pound initially slid by as much as 1.7 per cent against the US dollar after the BOE’s statement and dropped against the euro before recovering some ground.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 18.47 points to 1,468.21. A total of 3.436 billion lots worth RM2.428 billion changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 667 to 275.

site_title: Thai Airways to name new CEO as early as Jan 2023, acting head says
summary: Thai Airways has begun the process to name a new permanent CEO as early as January 2023, with nearly 50 applicants responding to the airline's September application process. The new CEO will oversee the airline's restructuring plan, which includes bankruptcy protection, the shedding of half its workforce and aircraft fleet. The airline is undergoing a pandemic-driven transformation to ensure its long-term sustainability.

site_title: SBS Transit Q3 net profit up 23.4% on higher revenue
summary: SBS Transit reported a 23.4% increase in net profit for Q3 FY2022, reaching S$17.1 million, driven by higher revenue and improved ridership. This is a significant improvement from the S$13.9 million in the year-ago period, which included Covid-19 government reliefs. The company's operating profit for Q3 FY2022 stood at S$19 million, higher than the S$14.1 million in the year-ago period.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Net proft after tax for Q1 2022 fell despite an increase in revenue by 8.5 per cent from the corresponding quarter last year.

site_title: EU says recession is here and inflation shock will linger on
summary: The European Union's officials in Brussels have predicted a recession in the eurozone, with the economy expected to shrink and contract during the first quarter. They also forecast barely any growth next year and raised projections for consumer prices to double digits. The move comes as the region faces high energy price pressures, erosion of households' purchasing power, and a weaker external environment, according to the European Commission. The forecast is seen as a grim winter for the eurozone amidst ongoing double-digit inflation and war in nearby regions.

site_title: Wall Street is hiring more and more bankers outside London to cut costs
summary: Wall Street firms are expanding outside London, targeting cheaper costs and skilled graduates. Companies like Citigroup, Bank of America, and Goldman Sachs are hiring hundreds of staff in cities such as Birmingham, Manchester, Chester, and Glasgow. The move is driven by factors like rising property prices in London, Brexit-related operational challenges, and the availability of local talent. Analysts say this trend could boost regional economies, create a business ecosystem that attracts more jobs, and help address the post-Brexit decline of front-line banking business.

site_title: Are smartwatches too much of a good thing?
summary: Smartwatches have become increasingly sophisticated, tracking various aspects of a user's life, including stress levels, oxygen, and menstrual cycles. However, this capability can be a double-edged sword, potentially exacerbating stress and orthosomnia (an obsession with perfect sleep) due to constant monitoring and notifications. Some users find it difficult to disconnect from the watch, leading to a loss of control over symptoms and a sense of dependence on the device. Experts warn that over-reliance on wearable technology can lead to a loss of autonomy and potentially negative consequences for mental health.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

site_title: Sembcorp’s JV with Beijing Energy to buy 3 solar projects in China
summary: Sembcorp Industries has acquired three solar projects in northern China through a joint venture with Beijing Energy International Investment. The acquisition will increase Sembcorp's global renewables portfolio to 7.9 gigawatts. The initial equity consideration is 15 million yuan (S$3 million), with a future capital injection of up to 1,148 million yuan. The deal is expected to complete in the first quarter of 2023, subject to regulatory approvals, and is expected to be accretive to earnings.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Sembcorp to acquire 658MW of wind, solar assets in China for 3.3b yuan

site_title: Germany, India in escalating tussle over cancelled LNG cargoes
summary: Germany and India are in a diplomatic dispute over cancelled liquefied natural gas (LNG) cargoes from a German state-backed company, Securing Energy for Europe (SEFE). The dispute began in May when Russia's sanctions on SEFE made it impossible to source LNG from Russia. SEFE has cancelled 17 cargoes, leaving India with a significant shortage. Diplomats are working to resolve the issue, with pre-arbitration talks taking place between SEFE and GAIL India. The global energy crunch is exacerbating the situation, with India paying record amounts for replacement supplies.

images.alt_text: Minister in charge of coal Pralhad Joshi says fuel is an affordable source of energy and demand for it has yet to peak in India.
European countries have filled storage tanks to around 90 per cent of their capacity after Russia cut gas supplies in response to Western sanctions imposed over its invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Crypto lender BlockFi suspends withdrawals in FTX contagion
summary: BlockFi, a US-based crypto lender, has suspended client withdrawals due to uncertainty over the status of FTX US and sister trading house Alameda Research, amid the FTX contagion crisis. The company cited a lack of clarity and asked customers to refrain from depositing funds into their wallets or interest accounts. BlockFi's total deployable client assets amount to US$3.9 billion, with the majority of assets not yet moved to FTX for custody. The US Securities and Exchange Commission and Commodity Futures Trading Commission are investigating FTX.com for customer fund mishandling.

images.alt_text: FTX is scrambling to raise about US$9.4 billion from investors and rivals as the exchange urgently seeks to save itself after a rush of customer withdrawals.
The government has asked the company to submit a business improvement plan by Nov 16.
Crypto markets have come under intense pressure this year, as rising interest rates prompt investors to ditch risky or speculative assets.

FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried has told employees in a internal memo that he was exploring all options to avoid a collapse that analysts have said could trigger a meltdown in the entire crypto industry.

site_title: Philippine central bank governor sticks to 75 bps rate hike plan
summary: Philippine Central Bank Governor Felipe Medalla reiterated his plan to raise interest rates by 75 basis points at the upcoming monetary policy meeting on November 17. This move aims to combat soaring inflation, which reached a near 14-year high of 7.7% in October. Medalla stated that the rate hike will also help maintain the peso's value against the US dollar by preventing interest rate differentials from narrowing significantly. The decision is aimed at bringing inflation back within the target range over the medium term.

site_title: Daimler Truck says supply chain woes continue, as Q3 unit sales jump
summary: Daimler Truck reported a 27% increase in Q3 unit sales to nearly 135,000, despite ongoing supply chain issues. Chief Financial Officer Jochen Goetz attributed the shortages to underinvestment in other parts of the supply chain, affecting components like nuts, bolts, and tires. Goetz described the supply chain as "broken" and noted that investments made in the past have hindered the ability of smaller suppliers to ramp up production quickly. The company's goal of reducing fixed costs by 15% by 2025 remains challenging in an inflationary environment.

images.alt_text: New Mercedes trucks and vans at a Daimler truck centre in Kalbach, Germany, on Thursday, Feb. 4, 2021.
China is the world’s biggest market for heavy trucks, with around 1.5 million units sold in 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks surge as US inflation begins to slow; STI up 1.7%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.7% on Friday, closing at 3,228.33, as Asian markets rallied following lower-than-expected US inflation data. The STI finished 3.1% higher for the week, extending its winning streak for the sixth straight session. Winners outnumbered losers 443 to 180, with 2.14 billion securities worth S$1.93 billion traded. Key Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Japan, and South Korea, also closed higher, with some indices rising between 3% and 7.7%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
pixgeneric/ generic picture of SGX Centre along Shenton Way ,  taken on 24 Feb 2022.

site_title: Sterling edges up against weakening dollar after UK GDP data
summary: The British pound rose 0.2% to US$1.1730 against a weakening dollar, its highest level since August 26, after UK GDP data showed the economy shrank by less than expected 0.2% in the three months to September. The data suggests the start of a lengthy recession, but investors are cautiously optimistic ahead of the government's budget announcement on November 17, which may impact the economy further. The Bank of England may need to raise interest rates further, even with the economy in recession.

images.alt_text: The US dollar has surged more than 16 per cent this year but has lost some steam over the past few weeks.

site_title: Boustead Singapore H1 net profit climbs 6% despite lower revenue
summary: Boustead Singapore reported a 6% increase in net profit for the first half of 2023, reaching S$22.6 million, driven by increased interest income, currency exchange gains, and reduced overheads. Revenue declined 27% to S$246.9 million, mainly due to decreased contributions from the energy engineering and real estate divisions. The company declared an interim dividend of S$0.015 per share and maintained a healthy net cash position of S$372.2 million. The group's CEO cited a strong order backlog and new contracts as encouraging signs for the remainder of 2023 and 2024.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Boustead Projects' net profit for the 6-months ended Sep 30, 2022, rose to S$7.7 million from S$5.9 million in the year ago period.

site_title: China sovereign fund CIC posts 14.27% overseas investment return in 2021
summary: China's sovereign fund CIC posted a 14.27% net return on overseas investments in 2021, beating its performance target. The fund's total assets reached US$1.35 trillion, with net assets of US$1.25 trillion. CIC's unit Central Huijin managed 5.58 trillion yuan (S$1,080.5 billion) worth of state-owned financial assets, a 7% increase from the start of 2021. This marks the fund's annualized accumulative net investment return for the decade ending 2021 at 8.73%.

site_title: Qatar World Cup set to defy controversy and break revenue record
summary: Qatar's upcoming World Cup is expected to generate record revenue for FIFA, potentially exceeding $5.4 billion, despite controversies surrounding the host nation's human rights conduct. The one-month tournament has pre-sold broadcasting rights, hospitality packages, and tickets, with marketing sales exceeding the budgeted $1.8 billion. Sponsorships from major brands like Adidas and Coca-Cola are also contributing to the expected revenue. The event is seen as a showcase for Qatar's rapid expansion from a small pearl-diving enclave to a Gulf metropolis, with an estimated economic boost of up to $17 billion.

images.alt_text:

Denmark players pose for a team group photo before the match

“It is too small of a country. Football and the World Cup are too big for it,” Fifa's former president Sepp Blatter said of Qatar, the first country in the Middle East to host the tournament.
Unite said on Friday (Nov 4) that 700 workers will strike for three days, starting from Nov 18.

site_title: Taiwan electric scooter firm Gogoro delays China expansion
summary: Taiwanese electric scooter firm Gogoro is delaying its expansion plans in China due to geopolitical and economic uncertainty. The company, which aims to replace petrol-powered scooters with electric two-wheelers, is instead focusing on India and Indonesia. Gogoro's chief financial officer cited China's slowing economy and trade disputes with the US as reasons for the delay. The company expects to diversify internationally and generate significant revenue from India and Indonesia by 2024 and beyond.

site_title: Asean agrees in principle to admit Timor-Leste as 11th member
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) has agreed in principle to admit East Timor, also known as Timor-Leste, as its 11th member. Timor-Leste will be granted observer status at high-level Asean meetings, with a "road map for full membership" to be submitted at next year's summit. The decision comes after regional leaders met in Phnom Penh to discuss the issue, following Timor-Leste's independence from Indonesia in 1999 and its recognition by the United Nations in 2002.

site_title: Asean leaders struggle for answers to Myanmar crisis
summary: Asian leaders at the Asean Summit in Phnom Penh demanded Myanmar's junta take action to implement a peace plan aimed at quelling the country's escalating bloodshed. The plan, agreed upon in April last year, has been ignored by the junta, leading to frustration among other Asean countries. The bloc has agreed on a 15-point decision plan, which includes expanding a ban on junta figures attending Asean meetings and opening contacts with opposition groups in Myanmar. US President Joe Biden will attend the summit on Saturday, amid growing pressure on the junta to act.

images.alt_text: People walking outside the Sokha Hotel, the venue of the Asean Summit in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

site_title: Cortina Holdings H1 net profit up 49% on higher revenue
summary: Cortina Holdings reported a 49% increase in net profit for its first half, driven by higher revenue and improved sales margin. The luxury watch retailer's net profit rose to S$37.9 million, with revenue increasing 25.3% to S$406.9 million. The company aims to grow its customer base and improve customer experience, with plans to expand in Malaysia and Thailand. Its net asset value per share rose to S$1.977, unchanged from the end of its financial year in March 2022.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close up 7.7%
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 7.74% on Friday, Nov 11, with the Hang Seng Index closing at 17,325.66, driven by lower US inflation data and Beijing's relaxation of Covid-19 restrictions. The China Enterprises Index also rose 8.31%. This follows a rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a 5-day gain ahead of GDP data, and a strong performance in the US, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals set a new post-Covid record of 816,758 in October, surpassing the 1.5 million visitors recorded in September 2019. Meanwhile, Malaysia's economy expanded 14.2% in Q3, exceeding economists' forecasts, driven by strong domestic demand and robust exports. The STI climbed 1.7% to close at 3,228.33, following lower-than-expected US inflation. Keppel Infrastructure's unit is exploring green projects in Indonesia, and Centurion has halted its US sale process due to uncertain market conditions.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure unit in tie-up to explore green projects in Indonesia
summary: Keppel New Energy, a subsidiary of Keppel Corporation, has partnered with Pertamina Power Indonesia and Chevron New Energies International to explore green hydrogen and green ammonia projects in Indonesia. The project aims to develop a geothermal-powered green hydrogen facility producing 40,000 tonnes of hydrogen per year, contributing to Indonesia's goal of achieving net-zero emissions by 2060. This is Keppel Infrastructure's second green energy partnership in two months, following a collaboration with Indian renewable energy company GreenKo in October.

images.alt_text: COP27 must set higher targets for all forms of renewable energy.
In Singapore, steps have been taken to facilitate solar energy deployment and support a future where solar energy forms a greater portion of the country's energy mix.

A German offshore wind farm that Keppel has invested in. The floating hybrid renewable energy system in Singapore consists of integrating offshore floating solar panels with other renewable energy technologies.
Sembmarine is poised to become a much bigger and more competitive entity with a sharp renewables focus post merger

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS upgrades local property plays amid rosy industry outlook
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded its calls on PropNex and Apac Realty to "hold" from "fully valued", citing a resilient property market with a strong pipeline of new launches and stable prices. DBS analyst Ling Lee Keng raised target prices for PropNex to S$1.61 and Apac Realty to S$0.59, despite anticipating weaker performance in the next two quarters due to cooling measures. The analysts expect growing dominance for PropNex in the local market and a strong supply pipeline of new launches in 2023.
