site_title: Seoul: Won marks fastest daily gain vs dollar since 2009
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index rose 3.37% to 2,483.16 on Friday, its largest daily gain since April 2009, amid the US inflation report sparking hopes for a Federal Reserve interest rate hike slowdown. The won closed 4.5% firmer in onshore trade, its biggest daily gain since 2009. The index also surged 5.74% for the week, its sharpest weekly gain since January 2021.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi falls 22.18 points or 0.91 per cent to close at 2,402.23.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rise at open
summary: European stocks rose at the open on November 11, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.1% to 7,378.76 points. The eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices also increased, with gains attributed to slowing US inflation. The UK's economy is likely at the start of a prolonged recession, according to data. Despite the UK's economic concerns, European markets continued to rise, following gains in Asia and on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker shelters from the rain under a Union Flag umbrella as he passes the London Stock Exchange in London, Britain, October 1, 2008.  REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Xi will attend G20 summit
summary: President Xi Jinping will attend the G20 summit in Indonesia from November 14 to 17, where he will meet US President Joe Biden and French counterpart Emmanuel Macron. Following the G20, Xi will travel to Thailand to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec) summit from November 17 to 19. This meeting with Biden marks their first in-person talks since Biden took office, and comes after Xi's recent re-election as leader of the Chinese Communist Party.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin will not attend a gathering of leaders from the G20 nations in Bali next week, an Indonesian government official said.

site_title: FTX’s assets frozen by regulators as probes begin
summary: Regulators have frozen FTX's assets amid investigations into potential securities rule violations by founder Sam Bankman-Fried. The US Securities and Exchange Commission is probing FTX Digital Markets, while the Bahamas froze assets of a local trading subsidiary. FTX US has resumed withdrawals, but FTX.com remains closed. The company is scrambling to raise $9.4 billion from investors to avoid bankruptcy, with some crypto lenders pausing withdrawals due to FTX's implosion. Investors have marked their FTX investments to zero, including Softbank and Sequoia Capital.

images.alt_text: BlockFi on Twitter said it will pause client withdrawals, citing “a lack of clarity” over the status of onetime saviour FTX US as well as the uncertainty afflicting FTX.com and sister trading house Alameda Research.

FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried has told employees in a internal memo that he was exploring all options to avoid a collapse that analysts have said could trigger a meltdown in the entire crypto industry.
FTX is scrambling to raise about US$9.4 billion from investors and rivals as the exchange urgently seeks to save itself after a rush of customer withdrawals.

site_title: Indonesia proposes ban on Myanmar junta beyond Asean summits
summary: Indonesian President Joko Widodo has proposed that Myanmar's military representatives be barred from Asean functions beyond summits, amid growing frustration over the lack of progress in ending violence in Myanmar since the 2021 coup. Indonesia also wants to create a dialogue involving armed ethnic groups, the junta, and supporters of deposed leader Aung San Suu Kyi. This move comes after leaders debated the issue, marking a significant step towards addressing the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.

images.alt_text: People walking outside the Sokha Hotel, the venue of the Asean Summit in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.

site_title: Credit Suisse trims eight jobs in South-east Asia, part of regional cuts: sources
summary: Credit Suisse has cut eight jobs in its South-east Asia investment banking and capital markets team, part of a larger 2,700 global headcount reduction of 5% announced earlier. The cuts were less than expected, with teams not impacted by managing directors. The Swiss bank is restructuring as it shifts focus from investment banking to rich clients and raises 4 billion Swiss francs from investors to recover from scandals.

site_title: Vietnam’s tipple may strengthen social bonding but harm health
summary: Vietnam's high rate of alcohol consumption, with per capita consumption of 8.3 liters in 2016, poses health concerns and challenges for the government. The country's culture associates drinking with masculinity and social bonding, with beer being the most consumed beverage, accounting for 91% of recorded alcohol consumption. The government has introduced regulations to control production and consumption, with a new law aimed at reducing the risks associated with excessive drinking. Despite efforts to curb consumption, the country's culture of drinking persists, with traditional practices and social norms contributing to the high rate of alcohol use.

images.alt_text: The government sees 2023 inflation at about 4.5 per cent, compared to 4 per cent this year.
The tussle revolves around an opposition-led proposal to liberalise the production and sale of liquor and beer, which is tightly regulated in Thailand.

site_title: The markets have lost their bearings
summary: The global financial markets have lost their bearings due to the end of the era of administered rate markets, where central banks provided clear guidance on their asset purchase programs and interest rate intentions. As central banks tighten monetary policy, the markets are becoming more efficient, but investors have lost their compass, relying on uncertain macroeconomic forecasts and inflation expectations. The terminal rate of central banks remains uncertain, and the risk of inflation persisting at high levels in the coming years is not being fully incorporated into market prices, leading to complacency among investors.

images.alt_text: Shanghai street scene, October 2022; China's strict zero-Covid policy was a factor in the IMF's downgrade of Asia's economic growth prospects in the near term.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits slipped 1,000 to a seasonally adjusted 217,000 for the week ended Oct 29, the Labor Department said on Thursday (Nov 3).

site_title: The fiscal cost of quantitative easing
summary: The European Central Bank has raised its deposit rate to 1.5% after years of negative rates, marking a shift in policy as inflation surges. Central banks' massive bond holdings accumulated during quantitative easing (QE) have resulted in significant losses, as the cost of financing has exceeded long-term bond yields. Economists view QE as a quasi-fiscal policy, where monetary authorities finance purchases by issuing short-term reserves, but rising inflation has forced central banks to increase policy rates, revealing the fiscal risks of bond-buying programs.

site_title: Fleshing out the invisible hand
summary: A new book, "For Profit," by William Magnuson explores the complex relationship between private enterprises and public interest. The author argues that while corporations initially prioritize the public good, their pursuit of profit inevitably leads to excessive greed, egomania, or the abuse of power. Magnuson examines the history of corporations from ancient Rome to Silicon Valley, highlighting examples such as the Union Pacific Railroad and Facebook, to illustrate how public interests can be compromised. The book concludes that corporations cannot sustainably prioritize public interest over profit and that their pursuit of profit can have negative consequences for society.

images.alt_text: Starbucks expects to return US$20 billion to investors via share buybacks and dividends from fiscal 2023 to 2025.
Tesla, which was briefly a part of the trillion-dollar valuation group, currently has a market capitalisation of about US$650 billion.

Musk’s US$44 billion takeover of Twitter is an individual buying something for himself that 240 million people around the world use regularly. He will have absolute control over the fate of the social media platform.

site_title: China eases quarantine, flight bans in Covid Zero pivot
summary: China has eased its Covid-19 quarantine and flight bans, marking a significant shift in its zero-tolerance policy. Travellers will now spend 5 days in quarantine facilities, followed by 3 days at home, down from 10 days. Close contacts of infected people will also be subject to the shortened quarantine. The changes, announced on November 11, 2022, are seen as a pivot towards living with the virus, with international travel links expected to benefit. The easing comes as Covid cases surge nationwide, reflecting a change in President Xi Jinping's stance.

images.alt_text: A man gets tested for Covid-19 at a nucleic acid testing site, following an outbreak in Shanghai, China, Nov 9, 2022.
There have been some recent signs Beijing may be looking into how it may approach easing border curbs, yet the situation within China is yet to really shift.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares rebound amid global rallies
summary: Japan's Nikkei 225 index rose 2.98% to 28,263.57, driven by global rallies amid hopes for less aggressive US Fed rate hikes due to slowing US inflation. The broader Topix index also rose 2.12%. The global rally followed strong performances on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: SoftBank Vision Fund loses US$7.2b on tech writedowns
summary: SoftBank's Vision Fund arm reported a $7.2 billion quarterly loss due to plunging startup valuations, marking the latest setback for the company's efforts to replicate its early success in backing tech startups. The Vision Fund's net valuation losses totaled $1.19 trillion on its public holdings, with major write-downs of investments in companies like China's SenseTime Group and US food delivery firm Doordash. SoftBank's billionaire founder Masayoshi Son plans to become more cautious on new investments and has passed the role of quarterly results announcements to the CFO.

images.alt_text: Masayoshi Son has repeatedly talked internally about taking SoftBank private.

site_title: Toshiba reports 75% plunge in Q2 operating profit, cuts full-year outlook
summary: Toshiba Corp reported a 75% slump in Q2 operating profit to 7.54 billion yen, citing an appraisal loss for its printing business. The company cut its full-year earnings outlook to 125 billion yen from 170 billion yen. This move may impact potential buyers, including a consortium led by Japan Industrial Partners, as Japanese banks are cautious about financing a buyout deal. The earnings outlook could also influence the success of a potential buyout bid.

site_title: The fever is breaking
summary: The US election of 2022 marked a shift away from performative populism, with an anti-Trump majority emerging. The phenomenon of populist fury, exemplified by Donald Trump and Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, began to subside. Establishmentarian leaders, such as Governor Mike DeWine and Senator Ron Wyden, performed well, while Trump's influence waned. The election results indicate a shift in voter theory, with Americans seeking practical change over histrionic politics. The Democratic Party restrained their extreme tendencies, while Republicans failed to do so, leading to a partial victory for the anti-Trump majority.

images.alt_text: Governor Ron Desantis addressing supporters in Tampa on Tuesday night, Nov 8, 2022. DeSantis coasted to re-election, defeating his Democratic challenger, Charlie Crist.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit five-month high on hopes of less aggressive Fed
summary: Australian shares rose 2.8% to a five-month high on Friday, driven by cooler-than-expected US inflation data and hopes of less aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,158, marking its third straight weekly gain. The data pushed the annual US inflation rate below 8% for the first time in eight months, strengthening signs of slowing inflation.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose as much as 2.7 per cent to 7,152.50 points by 2343 GMT on Friday, its highest level since June 8.

site_title: US, Japan-led climate pact set to offer Indonesia US$15b
summary: The US, Japan, and other countries are finalizing a climate finance deal worth at least $15 billion to help Indonesia shift away from coal and towards renewable energy. The deal, known as a "just energy transition partnership," aims to accelerate the closure of excess coal power generation capacity and limit new coal power projects, hindering the development of renewable energy. Indonesia has set a goal of reaching net-zero by 2060 and has recently increased its emissions reduction targets, with the US-led pact expected to support its efforts.

images.alt_text: Indonesia has been enjoying an export boom for more than a year due to high commodity prices, with 2022 export earnings expected to be the country’s largest ever.

site_title: BT Market Focus: A good week for Singapore markets (Ep 20)
summary: Singapore markets had a good week, with Claressa Monteiro analyzing the market drivers and movements in the podcast. Key highlights include: SGX's wrap for the week, insight from BT's newsdesk, and what markets should consider and note. The podcast also covers company-focused news and provides general information on market trends.

images.alt_text: How have markets reacted this week to central banks' interest rate hikes?
How did markets do this week and what drove them?
Have rising interest rates fears dampened markets? Claressa Monteiro finds out.

site_title: Centurion halts sale process for US assets citing uncertain market conditions
summary: Centurion Corp halted the sale process of its US asset portfolio due to uncertain market conditions and interest rate environment. The sale process began in April for the Centurion US Student Housing Fund, which Centurion Corp owns a 28.7% stake in. The fund's portfolio has high occupancy and healthy rental reversions for the 2022/23 academic year, with continued strong market demand expected for the 2023/24 academic year. The sale process will now expire on November 19, 2024, with investors approving a two-year extension.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Australia’s largest lender CBA weighs Indonesia unit sale
summary: CBA, Australia's largest lender, is considering selling its Indonesian unit, PT Bank Commonwealth, to raise cash and exit a non-core market. The sale, if pursued, could value the assets at several hundred million dollars and attract interest from regional lenders seeking to expand in Indonesia. CBA first opened a representative office in Indonesia in 1992 and has since expanded its operations, with total assets of 20 trillion rupiah as of 2021. A sale would follow CBA's disposal of its life insurance arm, which was sold to FWD Group Holdings in 2018 for A$426 million.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Lim & Tan Securities initiates coverage on Wing Tai with ‘accumulate’
summary: Lim & Tan Securities has initiated coverage on Wing Tai with an "accumulate" call and a target price of S$1.95, citing the company's recurring income streams from retail and investment properties as a shield against market volatility. Despite headwinds in Singapore's property market, the analysts believe Wing Tai's developments will experience limited impact due to strong demand for its projects. The company's low net gearing and strong cash buffer also provide a competitive advantage.

images.alt_text: The acquisition of Winnoma by WTC "is not expected to have any material impact on the group's net asset value", SGX-listed Wing Tai said.
Wing Tai Holdings, which has Uniqlo as one of its apparel brands in Singapore,

site_title: GoTo plans to cut more than 1,000 jobs in bid to reach profit: sources
summary: GoTo Group, Indonesia's largest internet company, plans to cut over 1,000 jobs, approximately 10% of its workforce, as it aims to trim costs and reach profitability. The job cuts are part of the company's efforts to balance spending on growth with its goal of becoming profitable. This move comes as the tech industry faces a global economic downturn, with GoTo's publicly traded peers such as Sea and Grab Holdings also experiencing declining valuations due to economic slowdown and rising interest rates.

site_title: Cool to be just
summary: A global shift to green energy and decarbonization poses challenges for certain countries and communities, particularly those heavily reliant on fossil fuels. The transition could lead to job losses, such as in the automotive sector, and unequal access to renewable energy, like solar power in India's slums. Estimates suggest that shutting coal mines in South-east Asia could depress wages by billions of dollars. The need for an inclusive transition is sparking conversation about better ways to manage the economic impact of climate action.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

From left: Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Mark Carney, co-chair of the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, and Hiro Mizuno, UN Special Envoy on Innovative Finance and Sustainable Investments.

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. Picture taken July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

The Sidrap wind farm, the first in Indonesia and the largest in the region. The just transition goal is to decarbonise the region without creating undue harm related to energy security, economic and social equity and equality.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Friday, rising 12.35 points or 0.85% to 1462.09. Volume reached 456.76 million lots worth RM188.50 million, with gainers outnumbering losers 395 to 71.

site_title: Chris Rock to be first comedian to perform live on Netflix
summary: Netflix to announce live performance by comedian Chris Rock, marking the first live streaming event on the platform. This follows his previous Netflix stand-up special "Chris Rock: Tamborine" in 2018. The live special will air in 2023 and is expected to include discussions about Rock's 2022 Oscars incident with Will Smith. Netflix plans to roll out more live streaming options, starting with unscripted series and stand-up specials.

images.alt_text: “Google and Netflix account for more than a third of domestic traffic ... It befits global companies to review the issue more proactively,” South Korea's lawmaker Hong Suk-joon said during the hearing.
As TV’s audience shrinks, it becomes less attractive for advertisers – and a plum target for Netflix to disrupt.

site_title: FTX scrambles for funds as regulators take action
summary: FTX, a major cryptocurrency exchange, is scrambling to raise $9.4 billion from investors and rivals as regulators freeze assets and investigate the firm's chief executive, Sam Bankman-Fried, for potential securities law violations. The firm's token FTT plummeted 27% and bitcoin fell 4% after a run on the exchange and failed takeover deal by Binance. Regulators in the US, Bahamas, and Japan have taken action, and lawmakers are calling for new laws to govern the sector. FTX's solvency problems worsen, with losses totaling 89% for the month, and the firm's credibility has been severely damaged.

images.alt_text: Crypto markets have come under intense pressure this year, as rising interest rates prompt investors to ditch risky or speculative assets.
Binance backed out of plans to acquire FTX, the company said on Wednesday (Nov 9).
The government has asked the company to submit a business improvement plan by Nov 16.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge 6% at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 6% at the open on Friday, following a positive session on Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 6.08% to 17,059.44, driven by lower US inflation expectations and a dimmed threat of aggressive Fed interest-rate hikes. This followed a 1.73% gain in the Shanghai Composite Index and a 1.71% increase in the Shenzhen Composite Index.

site_title: As Singapore rents soar, expats in Hong Kong bag bargains
summary: Hong Kong's prime rents have fallen for the first time in two years, but the city remains the world's most expensive city for expats. In contrast, Singapore's prime rents have surged, with a 31% increase in September compared to the previous year. The exodus of Hong Kong residents, partly due to the city's crackdown on Covid-19 and civil liberties, is expected to be a key source of rental demand in Singapore. As a result, Singapore's rental market is expected to remain strong for at least six to nine months before an increase in home supply brings relief next year.

images.alt_text: Hong kong city Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Japan government backs major firms in next-gen chip project
summary: Japan's government has pledged $500 million to support a new project, Rapidus, which aims to develop and mass-produce next-generation microchips by 2027. Eight major Japanese companies, including Sony and Toyota, have joined forces for the venture, seeking to secure semiconductor supplies for the country's economic security amid global chip shortages and volatile geopolitics.

images.alt_text: Speculation has been building that the BOJ may start to withdraw its decade-old monetary stimulus next year as the yen’s fall driven by its policy helps accelerate inflation.
The dollar fell sharply as US consumer prices rose less than expected in October. The Japanese yen at one point climbed by its biggest single-day rise since 2008, hitting 140.9350 to the dollar.

site_title: Amazon’s new warehouse robot could one day replace humans
summary: Amazon has developed a robot called Sparrow, capable of identifying and handling individual items, marking a significant milestone in the company's efforts to reduce reliance on human order pickers. In demonstrations, Sparrow autonomously grabbed items of different sizes and textures, and is designed to handle millions of different products. This development comes after years of stumping Amazon roboticists, who have struggled to automate tasks that require dexterity and intuition, currently handled by warehouse workers.

images.alt_text: The new drone, dubbed MK30, will go into service in 2024 and replace the existing MK27-2.
Most big tech companies are hitting the brakes on hiring plans, but Amazon is dealing with an especially severe pandemic hangover.

site_title: Free banking in the crypto world
summary: Binance backed out of its plans to acquire FTX, a cryptocurrency exchange, amid the value of FTT, a digital token, crashing after Binance's CEO CZ liquidated holdings. The move led to a liquidity crunch at FTX, causing a significant market impact. This incident highlights the risks associated with crypto exchanges' asset holdings, which could lead to a broader crisis. Experts warn that stablecoins and exchanges will eventually be fully backed, but the timing remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: The acquisition will reshape the more than US$1 trillion industry that is already dealing with a prolonged market downturn.
While crypto might seem like a niche corner of finance, the saga between two of its top players has upended the crypto ecosystem and is likely to have far-reaching repercussions.
Zhao (right) and Bankman-Fried have been trading barbs on Twitter in the past few months, feuding over issues ranging from lobbying US politicians to allegations of frontrunning trades.

site_title: Britain’s ex-finance minister Kwarteng told Truss to ‘slow down’ tax cuts
summary: Former UK Finance Minister Kwasi Kwarteng revealed in an interview that he warned Prime Minister Liz Truss to "slow down" her tax cuts, which triggered economic turmoil and led to her downfall. Kwarteng made unfunded tax cut announcements in September, causing market panic and inflation warnings. He said Truss was "very much of the view" that the UK needed to move fast, but Kwarteng believed it was too quick. Truss was sacked in October, and Kwarteng regrets the disruption caused by the budget announcements, but does not apologize.

images.alt_text: Sunak wants to reset ties and described his meeting with Macron as great and an opportunity to work closely with France and other countries to tackle illegal migration.
British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt exits a car outside Downing Street in London, Britain October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls
Supermarket chain J Sainsbury is giving its temporary Christmas staff free food during their shifts for the first time.
The Bank of England indicated it wanted to sell the long-dated state bonds purchased during the market turbulence caused by the last UK government’s mini budget.

site_title: Malaysia’s prime minister candidates in upcoming poll
summary: Malaysia is set to hold a highly competitive election on November 19th, with three major coalitions vying for the top job. Incumbent Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob, long-time opposition leader Anwar Ibrahim, and former premier Muhyiddin Yassin are the top contenders. No single coalition is expected to win a simple majority in parliament, as votes are likely to be split among the three blocs and smaller parties, making a coalition government possible. The election outcome will determine Malaysia's future leadership and direction.

images.alt_text: Zafrul Aziz's entry into the Malaysia's volatile political arena as BN candidate for Kuala Selangor, is hoped will bring fresh energy in a landscape where old faces rule
The official campaigning of Malaysia's 15th general election has started since Nov 5, with 945 candidates competing for 222 parliament seats.

site_title: Asia: Shares surge as investors cheer slower US inflation
summary: Asian markets surged on Friday, with Taipei up 3.5%, Seoul up 2.8%, and Sydney up 2.6%, after the US consumer price index showed lower-than-expected inflation of 7.7% in October, down from 8.2% in September. The gains followed a strong US session, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. The lower inflation rate reduced expectations of aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes, boosting investor confidence and driving global rallies.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Jakarta and Taipei marlets were all trading lower on Thursday.

site_title: Australian telecom firms fined A$33.5m for false Internet speed claims
summary: Australian telecom firms Telstra, TPG Telecom, and Optus have been fined A$33.5 million for making false claims about internet speeds. The Australian Federal Court ordered Telstra to pay A$15 million, TPG to pay A$5 million, and Optus to pay A$13.5 million. The firms admitted to making false statements about 50 Mbps and 100 Mbps fibre plans, affecting nearly 120,000 customers. The false claims were made for at least 12 months in 2019 and possibly extended to 2020, related to the National Broadband Network.

site_title: Singapore tourist arrivals hit new post-Covid record of 816,758 in October
summary: Singapore's international visitor arrivals reached a new post-Covid record of 816,758 in October, surpassing the previous record of 1.5 million visitors in September 2019. However, experts anticipate that growth momentum may moderate in early next year due to rising costs and potential dents in business and consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
关闭两年的樟宜机场第二搭客大厦（T2）于2022年5月26日和27日试行运作，为重新迎接旅客做好准备。翻新后的樟宜机场第二搭客大厦空间更大，南侧抵境厅的自动通关通道从原本的八个增至34个，包括六个特别通道。

site_title: Kitchen Culture redesignates vice-chairman Lau Kay Heng as non-independent chairman
summary: Kitchen Culture has redesignated vice-chairman Lau Kay Heng as non-independent chairman, citing the need for the chairman to lead the company in a challenging business climate and shareholders' issues. Current non-executive chairperson Hao Dongting will become a non-executive and non-independent director. The move comes amid an ongoing boardroom tussle with shareholders seeking to remove five directors, including Lau.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. Its largest shareholder Ooway Group together with seven individuals are requisitioning to remove five of the company's six directors.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture. The embattled kitchen systems provider reminds shareholders that an extraordinary general meeting intended to be held by requisitioners seeking to remove five of its six directors will not be proceeding.

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture.  The group is urging its shareholders not to attend a Nov 1 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) proposed by requisitioners, as it deems notices for the EGM defective and invalid.

site_title: Japan cracks down on FTX unit, freezing exchange activity
summary: Japan's government has ordered FTX.com's local subsidiary to suspend client services until Dec 9, citing a lack of structure to offer cryptocurrency exchange services. The company must submit a business improvement plan by Nov 16. Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki stated that the move aims to protect the interests of FTX Japan's users, describing the situation as "extremely regrettable."

images.alt_text: FTX logo is seen in this illustration taken, November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: China’s Singles Day shopping spree enters final stretch
summary: China's Singles Day shopping spree entered its final stretch on November 11, with sales potentially exceeding a record 1 trillion yuan (S$193.6 billion). The holiday, originally conceived by Alibaba, has grown to encompass much of China's retail sector, despite a struggling economy and Beijing's strict zero-Covid strategy. Merchants are offering varying discounts, with Alibaba and JD.com combined gross sales possibly surpassing last year's total. The event's celebrity endorsements have been dampened due to scandals and tax probes, but Alibaba believes it can make a big difference for retailers struggling with supply-chain disruptions and inflation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: New Politburo Standing Committee members Xi Jinping and Li Qiang arrive to meet the media following the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China October 23, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo

Zhong Shanshan, whose listed companies are water bottler Nongfu Spring and vaccine developer Beijing Wantai Biological Pharmacy Enterprise, took first place on the Hurun Rich list with a fortune of US$65 billion.
Jack Ma, billionaire founder of Alibaba Group, embodies China’s entrepreneurial spirit.
Many economists expect a reopening in China only after March next year, when the political reshuffle is finally completed.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Friday after US rebound
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index increasing 1.43% to 27,839.42, driven by hopes for slower US Fed rate hikes due to slowing US inflation. The broader Topix index also rose 1.31%. The rally follows positive US market performances, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite ongoing trade tensions.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday’s open; STI up 1.9%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 1.9% at the opening of trading on Friday, following sharp gains on Wall Street, where consumer price data raised hopes of less aggressive interest rate hikes. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 61.14 points to 3,234.32. Gainers outnumbered losers 168 to 18, with shares of local companies such as Genting Singapore, Thai Beverage, Singtel, and DBS rising. The Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 3.7% in the US, while European shares hit an 11-week closing high.

images.alt_text: Keppel O&M has signed bareboat charter contracts for two jackup rigs to be deployed in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Malaysia’s economy expands 14.2% in Q3, exceeding economists’ forecasts
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded 14.2% in the third quarter of 2022, exceeding economists' forecasts, driven by strong domestic consumption and exports. The growth rate is an improvement from the 8.9% expansion in the second quarter. All economic sectors registered positive growth, with services and manufacturing sectors driving the growth. The central bank expects growth in Q4 to moderate but remain robust, with full-year GDP growth potentially exceeding 6.5-7%. Bank Negara governor Nor Shamsiah also expects headline inflation to average 3.3% in 2022.

images.alt_text: Malaysia inflation rate in September 2022 moderated to 4.5 per cent, lower than 4.7 per cent in August, due to slower increase in food inflation.

The central bank is under pressure to keep inflation in check while supporting growth. Nearly 80 per cent of respondents in a recent survey said that the government’s priority should be either restoring and boosting the economy, or combating poverty and managing living costs.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut Singtel target prices on earnings miss
summary: Singtel's half-year results fell short of analysts' expectations, with core net profit rising 2.2% year-on-year to $1 billion, but below forecasts. Analysts CGS-CIMB and RHB Research cut their target prices to $3 and $3.30, respectively, due to lower associate earnings and foreign exchange weakness. Despite the earnings miss, the analysts maintained "add" and "buy" ratings, citing positive momentum in Singtel's mobile revenue recovery and a diversified portfolio with 93% of debt hedged.

images.alt_text: 291 Serangoon Road is on the market through an EOI, which closes on Feb 21.

site_title: Japan says it is closely watching foreign exchange moves, ready to respond
summary: Japan's top currency diplomat, Masato Kanda, stated that the country is closely watching foreign exchange market moves and ready to respond if necessary. Following weaker-than-expected US consumer price data, the Japanese yen rose sharply, reaching its biggest single-day gain since 2008, hitting 140.9350 to the dollar. Kanda emphasized the need for the yen to stabilize at a reasonable level, but did not rule out intervention if needed. The US Treasury Department also stated that no major trading partner manipulated exchange rates to gain an unfair competitive advantage.

images.alt_text: Some Bank of Japan policymakers are slowly becoming more open to the possibility of an eventual withdrawal of the radical monetary stimulus deployed by Governor Haruhiko Kuroda nearly a decade ago, a summary of opinions showed on Tuesday.

In the Reuters poll of 495 large companies, in which 247 firms responded on condition of anonymity, many voiced concerns about the yen’s weakness driving up import costs and about prolonged chip shortages weighing on car output and risks from overseas.
Speculation has been building that the BOJ may start to withdraw its decade-old monetary stimulus next year as the yen’s fall driven by its policy helps accelerate inflation.

site_title: Gold inches lower; set for weekly gain on hopes of less aggressive Fed
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.1% to $1,751.87 per ounce, but are poised for a weekly gain as inflation data showed slowing inflation, lifting hopes of less aggressive Fed rate hikes. US consumer prices rose less than expected in October, pushing the annual increase below 8% for the first time in eight months. A weaker dollar makes gold more appealing to overseas buyers, supporting a 4.2% weekly gain.

images.alt_text: Rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion while lifting returns on other yielding assets.

site_title: China’s Covid-19 curbs intensify as cases surge to highest since Shanghai lockdown
summary: China's Covid-19 cases surged to a record high of 10,535 new locally transmitted cases on Nov 10, with Beijing and Zhengzhou reporting record daily cases. Authorities have intensified lockdowns and curbs, including mandatory PCR tests and hard lockdowns in some areas. China's zero-tolerance policy, reaffirmed by President Xi Jinping, aims to save lives, particularly among the elderly. Despite being small compared to global standards, the surge has prompted China's top leadership to maintain strict measures, with no relaxation in sight.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect global recession risks and China’s disruptive Covid curbs will further drag on exports in coming months, dashing hopes for an economic rebound this quarter.
In Guangzhou, home to about 19 million people, cases hit more than 2,000 for a third straight day and officials have launched mass testing.
There have been some recent signs Beijing may be looking into how it may approach easing border curbs, yet the situation within China is yet to really shift.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists loses free float; offer turns unconditional
summary: Asian Healthcare Specialists has lost its free float after Labrador Park secured 90.63% valid acceptances for its privatization offer. The offer, initially conditional, is now unconditional. Shares held by the public now stand at 9.37%, below the 10% requirement. Labrador Park will compulsorily acquire remaining shares until Dec 15, 2022, at S$0.188 per share, valuing the company at S$109 million.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
The closing date for Labrador Park's offer to take Asian Healthcare Specialists private will be extended to 5.30pm on Dec 15, 2022, from the same time on Dec 1.
This brings the total irrevocable undertakings obtained by offerer Labrador Park to 87.16 per cent, or 504,101,246 shares.

Apart from garnering no less than 90 per cent of the total shares to make this offer a deal, Labrador Park also requires that all clearances, waivers and approvals must be secured from the landlords of the premises leased by the Asian Healthcare Specialists group.
Asian Healthcare Specialists H2 profit up 56.4 per cent to S$2.45m

site_title: Billionaire CEO buys multiple Riviera villas for more than 130m euros after Covid gains
summary: Gilles Martin, CEO of Eurofins Scientific, and his brother Yves-Loic have purchased four luxury villas in Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, France, for a total of over 130 million euros. The villas, valued at 59 million euros, 51.8 million euros, 9.8 million euros, and 10.5 million euros, were acquired between 2021 and this year through a series of companies controlled by the Martins. The purchase comes as the Riviera's real estate market sees a post-pandemic revival, with prices rising as new clients flock to the area.

images.alt_text: Prices in prime central London are now seeing its fastest rate of growth since Q1 2015.

krpark -  House in Belmont Park area

Source: BT Reader
Copyright: BT Reader
For BT editorial use only.
Ultra-luxury condominium Les Maisons Nassim

The landed property market looks set to continue at the current pace for the rest of 2022 as global geopolitical uncertainties persist. Total demand for landed homes could reach around 2,000 units and the URA price index for landed homes could gain some 10 per cent for the whole year, according to List Sotheby’s International Realty.

GCB land prices have continued to soar in 2022, rising 8.9 per cent between H1 21 and H1 22, to average S$1,839 per square foot (psf) according to JLL. This reflects a recovery of 25.3 per cent from the Covid trough of S$1,468 psf in H2 20.

One of the 3 bungalow properties along Nassim Road.




Copyright: Realstar Premier

site_title: FTX debacle sparks investor rethink of battered crypto market
summary: Crypto markets are under intense pressure due to rising interest rates, prompting investors to ditch risky assets. The collapse of FTX, a major cryptocurrency exchange, has raised concerns about the sector's viability. The exchange's CEO, Sam Bankman-Fried, was racing to find finance to prop up the company after a rival's bailout plan was scrapped. The FTX debacle has sparked an investor rethink of the battered crypto market, which has already been weakened by the bitcoin bubble bursting and closures of other key players.

images.alt_text: Most crypto players remain bullish about the long term, but are braced for further falls in the near future.

site_title: China’s bank loans lowest since 2017 as economy slows
summary: China's bank loans saw their lowest level since 2017 in October, with aggregate financing reaching 908 billion yuan, down from 1.6 trillion yuan in the same month last year. The slowdown is attributed to stricter coronavirus curbs, a housing slump, and a liquidity trap. Financial institutions made 615 billion yuan in new loans, down from 775 billion in the same month last year. Authorities may consider cutting the reserve requirement ratio or reducing banks' loan prime rate to boost credit growth. The economic recovery faltered in October, with factory and services activity contracting, and exports and imports both falling for the first time in over two years.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect global recession risks and China’s disruptive Covid curbs will further drag on exports in coming months, dashing hopes for an economic rebound this quarter.

site_title: Consumers expect businesses to lead on sustainability
summary: Consumers in the Asia Pacific region expect businesses to prioritize sustainability, with 1/3 of residents believing companies should behave sustainably. The region is projected to be the world's wealthiest by 2030, but climate change poses significant risks to socio-economic progress. Singapore, a leader in sustainability, is introducing a package to help other countries go green, and businesses are urged to mainstream sustainability efforts, create affordable products, and clearly communicate their initiatives to consumers.

images.alt_text: Joyce Orallo Lim, owner of Chokmah, which sells handcrafted homeware made from a sustainable material called jesmonite.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit five-month high on hopes of Federal Reserve pivot
summary: Australian shares reached a five-month high on Friday, rising 2.7% to 7,152.50 points, driven by gains in mining and financial stocks amid speculation that the Federal Reserve may ease its aggressive rate hikes following cooler-than-expected US inflation data. This is the highest level since June 8, with the benchmark index up 3% for the week, its best weekly jump in a month.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index slips 0.5 per cent to 6,964 at the close of trade.

site_title: CO2 pollution from fossil fuels to hit all-time high in 2022
summary: Carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels are projected to reach an all-time high in 2022, rising 1% to 2% compared to last year. Emissions from oil, driven by the rebound in aviation, are expected to rise over 2%, while coal emissions, which some thought had peaked in 2014, will hit a new record. The increase is attributed to the recovery from COVID and events in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Warhol’s Campbell’s Soup screen prints, produced in the 1960s, remain one of the most recognisable symbols of the American pop art movement.

From left: Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Mark Carney, co-chair of the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, and Hiro Mizuno, UN Special Envoy on Innovative Finance and Sustainable Investments.
Consumers expect businesses to lead on sustainability

site_title: ASML launches 12b euro buyback, upgrades 2025 forecast
summary: ASML, a leading supplier of chip manufacturing equipment, announced a 12 billion euro share buyback program to be completed by 2025. The company now forecasts 2025 revenue of 30-40 billion euros, up from 24-30 billion euros. ASML expects a decade of growth and plans to expand capacity, including increasing production of its flagship EUV machines to 90 annually by 2026. This move follows the company's strong order book and comes after a 9.7% increase in shares following the announcement.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: ASML logo is seen in this illustration taken February 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Oil prices settle 1% higher on tepid US inflation data
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Thursday, ending a three-day decline, as US inflation data was weaker than expected, supporting investor hopes for lower interest rates and oil demand. Brent crude settled at US$93.67, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 0.8% to US$84.67. A weakening US dollar also contributed to the price gains. However, concerns about renewed Covid-19 curbs in China and Russia's withdrawal from Ukraine kept prices in check.

images.alt_text: West Texas Intermediate lost 3.5 per cent to settle near US$86 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Citigroup, funds in talks to end lawsuit over errant US$500m Revlon payment
summary: Citigroup is in talks to settle a lawsuit over mistakenly paying $500 million to hedge funds and investment firms related to a loan owed by Revlon. The bank had used its own money to pay off a $894 million loan three years early in 2020. The parties requested a three-week extension to discuss a potential settlement, which was granted by US District Judge Jesse Furman. The case had previously been returned to Furman after a federal appeals court ruled that the asset managers' payments were improper. A settlement may be forthcoming, according to the parties' request.

images.alt_text: Third-quarter investment-banking fees plummeted 64 per cent at Citigroup and were down 45 per cent at Barclays.
Citigroup will use the licence in order to continue offering institutional services after it exits consumer, small-business and middle-market banking in the country.

site_title: China’s new leaders back a more targeted, ‘decisive’ Covid Zero
summary: China's top leaders have reaffirmed the need to stick with the Covid Zero policy, urging officials to be more targeted with their restrictions to curb the spread of the virus and resume normal life and production as soon as possible. The policy, which has dragged on the world's second-largest economy, is expected to be optimized with a more precise approach to Covid tests, vaccine shots, and patient transfers. Experts predict that China will eventually reopen, but the pace is likely to be cautious, with a piecemeal approach, possibly within the next six-to-nine months.

images.alt_text: In Guangzhou, home to about 19 million people, cases hit more than 2,000 for a third straight day and officials have launched mass testing.
Analysts expect global recession risks and China’s disruptive Covid curbs will further drag on exports in coming months, dashing hopes for an economic rebound this quarter.

site_title: Singapore’s latest 6-month Treasury bill auction draws record 92,000 bids totalling S$14.2b
summary: Singapore's latest 6-month Treasury bill auction saw a record 92,000 bids totaling S$14.2 billion, an oversubscription rate of 3.2 times. The auction, which ended with a cut-off yield of 4%, was delayed for over five hours due to the high interest. This is a record high for the auction, surpassing previous bids. The Monetary Authority of Singapore attributed the oversubscription to "overwhelming interest."

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Investors are buying government-guaranteed Treasury bills in a volatile market, even as the yield is lower than inflation.

Despite the record-high interest rates being offered, the present issuance of Singapore Savings Bond should have a higher first-year interest rate, if not for the intention to step up returns over its 10-year tenor.
CPFboard.jpg

site_title: Twitter bankruptcy a possibility, Musk tells staff of the social network
summary: Elon Musk has told Twitter employees that bankruptcy is a possibility as the company struggles with a significant debt burden from its $44 billion acquisition. Musk recently cut half of Twitter's staff and introduced changes to its subscription rules, which have led to concerns among advertisers. He also warned employees of "difficult times ahead" and ended remote work unless personally approved. The company's ability to keep its platform secure and comply with regulatory rules has raised concerns, particularly with the departure of top executives. Musk aims to make Twitter's $8 subscription product, Twitter Blue, a viable option for users.

images.alt_text: Twitter has been under Musk’s leadership for close to two weeks, in which time he has dismissed roughly half its workforce and most of its executive suite.
Twitter's increased debt load means it will have annual interest payments approaching US$1.2 billion, up from below US$100 million in the pre-Musk era.

site_title: Commodities slide may signal surprise inflation downturn in early 2023
summary: Global commodity prices are signaling a potential downturn in inflation, with cyclical commodities such as copper, iron ore, and wheat experiencing significant declines. The drop in prices, which has been fueled by central bank monetary tightening and interest rate hikes, suggests that inflation may start to fall in the first quarter of 2023. Analysts warn that a global recession could be factored into commodity prices, leading to further declines and potential supply disruptions, which could cause periodic rallies in the market.

images.alt_text: Iron ore’s advance also came after data showed iron ore exports by Brazil fell 13 per cent in October from a year earlier.
Exxon posted the highest profit in its 152-year history, while Chevron announced its second-best quarterly result as natural gas demand and prices surged.

site_title: Amazon surges the most since February on cost-cutting review
summary: Amazon shares surged 12% on news that CEO Andy Jassy is reviewing expenses as part of the company's annual operating plan. The review aims to trim costs amid a slowing economy, following a 48% year-to-date decline in shares. Amazon has already paused new hiring and is reviewing corporate divisions for potential cuts. The company remains confident in its overall operations and initiatives, despite taking aggressive steps to reduce expenditures.

images.alt_text: The world’s largest online retailer has spent this year adjusting to a sharp slowdown in e-commerce growth as shoppers resumed pre-pandemic habits.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Corp, Nio, Genting Singapore, F&N, Sasseur Reit
summary: Keppel O&M signed bareboat charter contracts for two jackup rigs to be deployed in Saudi Arabia, expected to generate revenue of S$155 million. Nio reported a net loss of S$801.4 million for its third quarter, despite a 44.9% increase in total revenue.

images.alt_text: Keppel sky sign taken at Ocean Financial Centre.

site_title: Powerful Murdoch media dumps on Trump
summary: Conservative media mogul Rupert Murdoch's outlets, including the Wall Street Journal, New York Post, and Fox News, have largely turned against Donald Trump, labeling him a "loser" with "increasingly poor judgment" after the midterm elections. Fox News praised Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, seen as Trump's top rival, as the "biggest winner" of the elections. This shift in coverage could impact public views ahead of the 2024 presidential race, where Trump is expected to announce his candidacy next week.

images.alt_text: Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer (pink) was re-elected in the “blue wall” state of Michigan.
Governor Ron Desantis addressing supporters in Tampa on Tuesday night, Nov 8, 2022. DeSantis coasted to re-election, defeating his Democratic challenger, Charlie Crist.
Joe Biden’s Democrats are facing a struggle to hold on to control of Congress, after a race that he has cast as a defining moment for US democracy.
Former US President Donald Trump speaks during an event at Mar-a-Lago, Palm Beach, Florida on Nov 8, 2022.

site_title: Apple limits file-sharing for Chinese iPhone users after anti-government protest
summary: Apple has limited file-sharing for Chinese iPhone users through its AirDrop function, restricting users to only receiving files from non-contacts during a 10-minute window. The update comes after reports of protesters using AirDrop to share anti-government leaflets in China. The change affects only iPhones sold in China, with those sold outside the mainland not impacted. Apple has faced criticism for alleged concessions to Beijing, including opening a data center and removing a pro-democracy app. The update is seen as a response to China's increasing repression and a move to protect the company from boycotts.

images.alt_text: epa10291972 People look at i-Phone 14 models at an Apple store at a mall in Beijing, China, 07 November 2022. China's Foxconn iPhone facotry in Zhengzhou was working to resume its production that had been hit by COVID-19 curbs, according to a company statement released on 07 November.  EPA-EFE/WU HAO

site_title: Twitter security chief resigns as Musk sparks ‘deep concern’
summary: Twitter's new security chief, Lea Kissner, has resigned following Elon Musk's revamp of the platform, which led to a surge in fake accounts. The move comes amid criticism of Musk's chaotic launch of new features, including the Twitter Blue subscription service. The Federal Trade Commission has expressed "deep concern" over Twitter's recent developments, warning that no company is above the law. Musk's recent layoffs and changes to work-from-home policies have also raised concerns among employees.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An image of Elon Musk is seen on a smartphone placed on printed Twitter logos in this picture illustration taken April 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Dollar suffers biggest plunge since 2009 as CPI smacks Fed bets
summary: The US dollar experienced its largest single-day decline since 2009, falling 2% after the US inflation report showed slower growth in consumer prices, exceeding expectations. The Federal Reserve may slow down interest rate hikes, which has weakened the dollar against its Group-of-10 peers. The dollar's rally could be curbed, and other currencies, such as the yen and euro, are expected to gain against it. Market expectations now suggest a 50-basis-point rate hike in December, rather than a 75-basis-point move, leading to a decrease in the dollar's value.

images.alt_text: The US dollar has surged more than 16 per cent this year but has lost some steam over the past few weeks.

site_title: US consumer prices increase less than expected in October
summary: US consumer prices increased 0.4% in October, less than expected, and underlying inflation appears to have peaked, potentially allowing the Federal Reserve to ease interest rate hikes. The core CPI, excluding volatile food and energy components, rose 0.3% and 6.3% year-over-year. Petrol prices increased after three straight monthly declines, but goods inflation is slowing due to a shift in demand to labour-intensive services and recovering global supply chains. This suggests the US central bank may be nearing an inflection point in its fight to lower inflation to its 2% target.

images.alt_text: Food prices were 11.9 per cent higher than a year ago in September, while energy prices have spiked 20.3 per cent.

site_title: Bank of England to sell bonds purchased after mini budget turmoil
summary: The Bank of England plans to sell long-dated state bonds purchased after the 2022 mini budget turmoil, sparked by the UK government's debt-fuelled, tax-slashing policies. The sale will begin on November 29 and be done in a demand-led way to ensure an orderly process. The move aims to unwind the portfolio purchased during the market turbulence caused by the mini budget, which spooked markets and caused UK borrowing rates to soar. The sale is intended to prevent renewed dysfunction and maintain financial stability.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak sought to emphasise his credentials as a former chancellor of the exchequer.

The British pound is already heading for its worst year since 2008 and investors see little upside for sterling in coming months. Some are betting on another fall below US$1.10 by the end of the year.
FILE PHOTO: A general view of the Bank of England building, in London, Britain, August 4, 2022. REUTERS/Maja Smiejkowska/File Photo

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts 0.4% rise in Q3 DPU to S$0.01838
summary: Sasseur Reit posted a 0.4% year-over-year rise in its third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.01838, its highest Q3 distribution in four years. The increase is mainly attributed to an income tax refund of S$2.1 million related to Chongqing Liangjiang Outlets. Despite a 2.1% year-on-year decline in EMA rental income to S$30.8 million, the Reit's distributable income rose 1.2% to S$23.5 million.

site_title: 100,000 civil servants latest to join UK strikes
summary: 100,000 civil servants in the UK, mostly from the Public and Commercial Services (PCS) union, voted to strike, exceeding the 50% threshold. The strike is in response to the cost-of-living crisis and demands a 10% pay rise to match inflation. The union, led by Mark Serwotka, claims the government has "treated its workers with contempt" and warns of a "prolonged programme of industrial action" if demands are not met.

images.alt_text: Thursday’s walkout on the so-called London “tube” network left travellers struggling to catch buses or find alternative ways to get to work in the city of around nine million people.
Unite said on Friday (Nov 4) that 700 workers will strike for three days, starting from Nov 18.

site_title: Coinbase cuts 60 jobs in latest ‘crypto winter’ layoff
summary: Coinbase, a US digital-asset trading platform, has cut 60 jobs in its latest move to reduce costs amid a prolonged slump in cryptocurrencies. This move follows previous layoffs, including a 1,200-employee cut in June, as the crypto market continues to decline. The company plans to reduce recruiting and institutional onboarding groups, citing the need to ensure cost savings. Shares rose 11% on the news, but the stock is still down 80% this year.

images.alt_text: Robinhood shares tanked 14 per cent, while Coinbase dropped 9.5 per cent to a record low.

Investors’ interest in speculating in the tokens has dimmed since prices tumbled sharply from their peak, slashing Coinbase’s revenue to US$590.3 million in the third quarter, less than half what it was a year earlier.

site_title: US: Stocks end with steep gains amid optimism on lower inflation
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average jumping 3.7% to 33,715.37 and the S&P 500 rising 5.5% to 3,956.37, amid optimism over slowing US inflation. The tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index surged 7.4% to 11,114.15. The gains were attributed to investors seizing on the data showing a slowdown in US inflation, sparking a rally.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo Traders work during the opening bell at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on March 19, 2020, at Wall Street in New York City. - Wall Street stocks rose early April 8, 2020 as markets weighed the latest figures on the coronavirus against the prospects for additional measures to prop up the economy.About five minutes into trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average stood at 22,903.26, up 1.1 percent.The broad-based S&P 500 gained 1.0 percent to 2,686.75, while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 1.2 percent to 7,983.68. (Photo by Johannes EISELE / AFP)

site_title: Half a million UK workers drop out of workforce, citing long-term illness
summary: Half a million UK workers dropped out of the workforce between 2019 and August 2022, citing long-term illness or mental health problems. This represents a 25% increase from the pre-pandemic rate of 25% in 2020. The Office for National Statistics attributed the rise to long-term sickness, with 28% of non-working, non-job-seeking individuals citing this reason. The increase in long-term sickness has raised concerns among the Bank of England, which seeks to tame inflation, now at a 40-year high.

site_title: US: Wall St opens sharply higher after October inflation data
summary: US stocks opened sharply higher on November 10, driven by data showing lower-than-expected October inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 749.97 points, or 2.31%, to 33,263.91. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained, with the S&P 500 up 111.32 points, or 2.97%, and the Nasdaq up 515.99 points, or 4.98%. The strong opening was fueled by hopes that the Federal Reserve may scale back interest rate hikes, boosting investor confidence.

site_title: Amazon unveils smaller delivery drone that can fly in rain
summary: Amazon unveiled a new delivery drone, the MK30, capable of flying in light rain and making less noise. Replacing the existing MK27-2, the MK30 will go into service in 2024, boasting a longer range, improved temperature tolerance, and enhanced safety features. Amazon's drone programme has faced delays, crashes, and high turnover, but the new drone is part of efforts to demonstrate safe commercial drone deliveries. The Federal Aviation Administration is expected to approve drone deliveries in the future, with Amazon competing against other companies to convince regulators of the technology's safety.

images.alt_text: An Amazon delivery drone Source: Amazon

site_title: How should a director respond to a criminal investigation?
summary: A director of a listed company in Singapore who is under investigation by authorities should familiarize themselves with the investigation process and seek legal advice and representation. They should cooperate fully and provide truthful answers to investigators, while refraining from discussing the matter with other witnesses and coordinating with them. The director may need to inform other companies of their involvement in the investigation, and the board of the listed company may consider issuing a public announcement. Ultimately, the director's ability to discharge their duties may be impaired, prompting consideration of stepping down or appointing an alternate director.

images.alt_text: The critical issue is not whether the director will be convicted or acquitted, nor what is best for them. Rather, the focus of the NC and the board should be on charting a course for the best of the company and its shareholders.
It depends on whether the investigation is for activities done inside or outside the company, to begin with.

site_title: Apac sees rising demand for sustainable aviation fuel but lack of refuelling points for airlines a pain point
summary: Singapore is poised to become an SAF hub, with demand for sustainable aviation fuel in the Asia-Pacific region rising. However, the limited availability of refuelling points for airlines is a major pain point. Major players like Shell, BP, ExxonMobil, and Neste are racing to build up SAF production and supply capabilities. The European and American markets are expected to benefit from the Singapore-based SAF plant, which can support multiple markets. As countries and companies invest in SAF, Singapore's position as a key player in the region's aviation fuel market is expected to grow.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Singapore receives 15 recommendations on creation of a sustainable air hub
The SAF will be supplied by Neste, produced from used cooking oil and waste animal fats, then blended with refined jet fuel at Exxon Mobil’s facilities in the city-state.
BP has not disclosed what volume it plans to produce.
The oil major was selected in February as the fuel supplier for the pilot programme launched by the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore, Singapore Airlines and Temasek.
Bombardier's Singapore Service Centre at Seletar Aerospace Park is expected to support more than 2,000 business jet visits annually.
The airline industry requires huge investments in so-called sustainable aviation fuels (SAF), which are currently in short supply and far more expensive than conventional jet fuels.
The agreement to accelerate the development of a sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) industry in Australia is in line with Qantas’ target of using 10 per cent SAF in its fuel mix by 2030.
Neste Oil produces renewable diesel from more than 10 different feedstocks, many of which are waste- or residue-based.​
In conjunction with World Environment Day, Malaysia Airlines has operated its first passenger flight using Neste MY SAF on flight MH603 from Kuala Lumpur to Singapore.
The industry is currently producing only 200,000 tonnes or 240 million litres of SAF a year: less than 0.1 per cent of the jet fuel consumed a year.

site_title: UK firms take desperate measures to tackle staff shortage
summary: The UK is experiencing a severe staff shortage, with businesses taking desperate measures to attract workers. Supermarkets like J Sainsbury and restaurants like The Giggling Squid are offering incentives such as free food and accommodation. The five-star Cliveden Hotel is providing £2,000 sign-on bonuses for kitchen staff. The tight labour market is constraining growth, with 217,000 vacancies in the health and social work sector, and nearly half of British businesses unable to fulfill orders due to staffing shortages. The UK government's approach to immigration has been criticized for exacerbating the problem.

images.alt_text: Hiring of temporary workers stagnated and wage growth for permanent new staff was Britain's weakest in a year and a half, a survey showed.

site_title: Paris opens flying taxi hub targeting flights for 2024 Olympics
summary: Paris has opened a hub for testing electric air taxis, with the goal of introducing the world's first commercial service by 2024 for the Summer Olympics. The hub, operated by Aeroports de Paris and Skyports, combines a terminal, take-off and landing area, and hangar, and is backed by the transport ministry and Ile-de-France region. Volocopter, a German developer, successfully integrated a flight into conventional air traffic during the launch. The project aims to develop multiple use cases, including health and logistics applications, and marks a new step in the development of electric air mobility.

site_title: Wynn Resorts to open Gulf Arab’s first casino at Ras Al Khaimah resort
summary: Wynn Resorts plans to open a casino at its luxury resort in Ras Al Khaimah, United Arab Emirates, marking the first casino in the Gulf Arab region. The casino, set to be completed in 2026, will be larger than Wynn Las Vegas and will be the only casino operator in the market for a period of time. This move comes as the UAE competes with Saudi Arabia to become a top destination in the region, diversifying its economy away from oil. The casino component is expected to be a significant draw for tourists and business travelers.

images.alt_text: Casino operator Wynn plans resort with gaming facilities in UAE

site_title: Inflation dampens festive spirit as German retail faces slump
summary: German retail is expected to experience its strongest slump in Christmas sales since 2007 due to double-digit inflation weighing on consumer purchasing power. Inflation rose to 10.4% in October, its highest in about seven decades. Retail sales are forecast to drop by 4% year-on-year in November-December, with only 5.4% growth in nominal terms. The HDE retail association attributed the decline to soaring energy and food bills, as well as uncertainty in Europe and a war close to Germany.

site_title: US dollar climbs ahead of inflation data; cryptos crumble
summary: The US dollar rose 0.56% to 110.96 against major peers, driven by anticipation of US inflation data and a mid-term election result. Cryptocurrencies, particularly FTX, fell under pressure after Binance scrapped rescue plans, boosting the US dollar. Economists expect the inflation rate to have cooled in October, but core reading may remain elevated, affecting the Federal Reserve's future interest rate hikes. The euro slid below parity, while sterling recovered slightly.

site_title: OCBC unit’s Dubai branch fined US$1.12m for anti-money laundering lapses
summary: The Dubai Financial Services Authority (DFSA) has fined the Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) branch of Bank of Singapore (BOS) US$1.12 million for anti-money laundering (AML) lapses. The fine was reduced from US$2 million after BOS offered to remediate the issues and settle the matter. The bank was found to have inadequate systems and controls, shortfalls in AML practices, and unauthorized dealings in investments. BOS has agreed to remedy the deficiencies and engage an external compliance expert to ensure compliance.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

Interview with Jeffrey Chua, partner and managing director at the Boston Consulting Group As part of the advanced manufacturing feature package. We are profiling Boston Consulting Group (BCG) as one of the players in advanced manufacturing and how a management consultant is also getting into the game. 

BT_11.04.2017_1709702688

 Kelvin Chng



Address: 50 Raffles Place, 44-02/03

site_title: Crypto markets slump as FTX seeks to raise new funds
summary: Cryptocurrency markets plummeted on Thursday, with Bitcoin near a two-year low, as investors fretted over the fallout from the collapse of FTX, a crypto exchange seeking new funds to plug a $6 billion hole in its finances. FTX's native token, FTT, fell 90% this week, and Bitcoin fell below $16,000 for the first time since 2020. Investors are bracing for further falls in the near future, with some warning of potential contagion spreading beyond the crypto sector.

images.alt_text: FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried has told employees in a internal memo that he was exploring all options to avoid a collapse that analysts have said could trigger a meltdown in the entire crypto industry.
Sequoia told LPs it ran “rigorous due diligence” on FTX at the time of its investment and its exposure to the company is limited.

site_title: Market watchers say Golden Energy exit offer unfair, results for shareholders uncertain
summary: Golden Energy & Resources has proposed an exit offer to delist from the Singapore Exchange (SGX), allowing shareholders to choose between cash or a combination of cash and shares. Market watchers say the deal terms may be unfavorable, with the offer price below the "sum of the parts" of the company. Analysts predict shareholders may be disappointed, and the offeror is likely relying on the lack of large institutional investors and retail investor apathy to secure approval.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources

site_title: Boustead Projects posts 30% rise in H1 net profit to S$7.7 million
summary: Boustead Projects reported a 30% increase in H1 net profit to S$7.7 million, driven by higher interest income and a higher share of profit from associates and joint ventures. Revenue fell 34% to S$117.7 million due to lower engineering & construction business revenue. The company's real estate business contributed to the increase in revenue. Net asset value per share rose to S$1.265, and no interim dividend was declared.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The latest contract, awarded by a Fortune 500 corporation, is the group’s largest project on record, Boustead Projects said.

site_title: EU proposes tighter vehicle pollution emission standards
summary: The European Commission proposed tighter vehicle pollution emission standards, including new limits for trucks and cars, with the goal of reducing 70,000 premature deaths annually. The proposed Euro 7 standard will apply to cars and vans from 2025 and to buses and trucks two years later, with stricter limits on nitrogen oxides and particulates. However, some industry groups, such as the European auto manufacturers association, criticized the proposal, arguing it would increase costs with limited environmental benefits.

site_title: Europe: Stocks scale 11-week high after soft US inflation data
summary: European stocks reached an 11-week high, with the Stoxx 600 jumping 2.8% after the US reported slower-than-expected inflation data. This strengthened hopes for less aggressive interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. Technology and real estate sectors led the gains, with their best day in over two years. The market's optimism is driven by the potential for reduced interest rate hikes, which could boost economic growth.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.5 per cent to 7,263.45 points.

site_title: Cisco to open new chip design centre in Barcelona
summary: US tech giant Cisco Systems plans to open a new semiconductor chip design centre in Barcelona, Spain, as part of the European Union's Perte plan, which allocates up to 12 billion euros for semiconductor research and development. The project aims to reduce Europe's dependence on US and Asian supply chains and reinforce its own chip industry, with Spain aiming to reach 20% of the global chip market by 2030. The announcement follows a similar 10 billion euro project by Volkswagen's Spanish unit Seat to make electric vehicles and batteries in Spain.

site_title: Russian carmaker Sollers to buy out Mazda’s stake in Vladivostok plant
summary: Russian carmaker Sollers will acquire Mazda's 50% stake in a Vladivostok plant, with all necessary approvals granted. The deal is worth one euro, allowing Mazda to buy back the asset for the same amount within three years. Mazda had previously announced plans to cease production at the plant due to its actions in Ukraine. Sollers plans to restart the plant next year with a new model line-up, increasing the plant's annual production capacity to 50,000 cars.

site_title: FTX suspends addition of new clients, withdrawals
summary: FTX, a cryptocurrency exchange, has suspended onboarding new clients and withdrawals until further notice, following a failed rescue deal with rival Binance. The company, led by CEO Sam Bankman-Fried, is exploring options to avoid a collapse that could trigger a meltdown in the crypto industry. FTX US, its US unit, is unclear if it is included in the move. The company has asked clients to avoid depositing funds and has not responded to requests for comment. Analysts have warned of a potential meltdown in the entire crypto industry if FTX collapses.

images.alt_text: FTX logo is seen in this illustration taken, November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: Listed firms should lead SMEs to be part of green value chain: Bursa Malaysia CEO
summary: Bursa Malaysia CEO Muhamad Umar Swift urges big corporations to lead local SMEs into the green value chain, rather than cutting them off when they fail to meet targets. The exchange plans to launch its Voluntary Carbon Market by auction in December, enabling companies to buy carbon credits to offset emissions. The market will use the Verified Carbon Standard to ensure integrity, with potential revenue estimates ranging from $5 billion to $50 billion by 2030. Swift emphasizes the importance of investments in sustainable projects to drive a sustainable supply of carbon credits.

images.alt_text: Bursa Malaysia building in Kuala Lumpur . (Bloomberg)

site_title: Brookfield gathers US$125b war chest as CEO sees recession
summary: Brookfield Asset Management has launched a fundraising campaign for its opportunistic credit fund, targeting over US$16 billion. The firm has already secured US$125 billion in deployable capital, citing a challenging market environment that has led to dislocation in financial markets. Despite a decline in earnings due to volatile markets, Brookfield expects its biggest year of fundraising ever, driven by its existing funds totaling US$21 billion and US$17 billion. The company's CEO, Bruce Flatt, believes the firm is well-positioned to navigate the current economic downturn.

images.alt_text: The investment is an expansion of an agreement signed by Intel and Brookfield in February to explore finance options to help fund new Intel manufacturing sites.

site_title: Nio Q3 net loss widens to 4.1 billion yuan despite higher vehicle sales
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, reported a wider net loss of 4.1 billion yuan (S$801.4 million) in Q3 FY2022, despite delivering a record-breaking 31,607 vehicles. This represents a 44.9% year-on-year increase and a 50.9% increase from Q2 FY2022. Total revenue rose to 13 billion yuan, up from 9.8 billion yuan in Q3 2021.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Nio was also forced to suspend production in April after Covid curbs caused many of its supplier partners to stop work.
The Nio ET5., for which the company plans to start mass production and delivery in late September.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) plans to spend S$15 million on carbon credit research in South-east Asia, following research showing the region's highest concentration of profitable carbon projects. Meanwhile, online life insurance purchases have surged to 40.7% of new policies, but agents still dominate high-premium sales. Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong attended the 40th and 41st Asean Summits in Cambodia, where the Myanmar crisis was a major agenda item.

site_title: China year-end export bounce in doubt as global demand falters
summary: China's year-end export surge is uncertain due to weak global demand, exacerbated by global recession risks and China's ongoing Covid curbs. Exports fell unexpectedly in October for the first time since May 2020, and analysts expect a decline in the November-December period. This dashes hopes for an economic rebound this quarter, as China's economy continues to face challenges from lockdowns, a frozen property sector, and ebbing domestic consumption.

site_title: China new bank lending stumbles as Covid flare-ups hit demand
summary: China's new bank lending fell sharply in October, with 615.2 billion yuan extended, a quarter of the 2.47 trillion yuan in September. The decline was attributed to Covid-19 outbreaks and a property sector downturn, underscoring concerns about credit demand. This marks a reversal from analysts' expectations of 800 billion yuan in new loans. The data also showed a 11.8% growth in broad M2 money supply from a year earlier.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: F&N full-year earnings down 11.1% to S$124.9m despite higher revenue
summary: Fraser and Neave (F&N) reported an 11.1% drop in net profit to S$124.9m for the financial year ended Sep 30, despite a 6.6% year-on-year increase in revenue to S$2 billion. The company attributed the revenue growth to its beverages segment, which saw higher beer and soft drinks volumes and prices. However, its publishing and printing revenue fell due to poor first-half performance. F&N's board recommended a final dividend of 3.5 cents per share, and the company expressed a cautiously optimistic outlook for the food and beverage industry for the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Range of F & N drinks, in Singapore, on Wednesday, August 28, 2013. Photographer: Munshi Ahmed/Bloomberg

site_title: SMIC reports 35% rise in Q3 revenue, warns of impact from export controls
summary: SMIC reported a 34.7% rise in Q3 revenue to US$1.91 billion, surpassing expectations. Gross profit rose 58.6% to US$742.2 million.
