Despite this, the company warned of the impact of US export controls on its fourth-quarter results, citing "adverse effects" on production and operations. SMIC revised its capital expenditure plan to US$6.6 billion from US$5 billion. The company remains behind in leading-edge technology and faces challenges from export controls and competition from Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation.

site_title: Indonesians march for justice after deadly soccer stampede
summary: Thousands of football fans in Indonesia's East Java protested on November 10, demanding a further investigation into police conduct at a stampede that killed 135 people after a match in October. The human rights commission blames police firing of tear gas as the main trigger for the fatal stampede. Six people, including police and match organizers, are facing criminal charges. Protesters, including Andi Irfan, call for "all actors" behind the tragedy to be arrested, citing a banned crowd control measure and inadequate action against top-ranking officers.

site_title: France orders poultry indoors, raises bird flu risk level to ‘high’
summary: France has raised the risk level of bird flu to "high" due to a surge in outbreaks, prompting the agriculture ministry to order poultry farms to keep birds indoors. This move aims to contain the spread of the disease, which has already led to the culling of about 22 million birds. The EU's second-largest poultry producer has detected 49 outbreaks in the past months, with a significant rise in domesticated fowl cases and wild bird infections. The government aims to strengthen preventive measures to avoid contamination of poultry farms and potential human transmission.

images.alt_text: Bird keepers will also be required to disinfect clothing, footwear, equipment and vehicles and keep mortality records.
Prices for turkey hens are nearly 30% per cent higher than a year ago and 80 per cent above pre-pandemic costs.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q3 net profit more than doubles to S$135.8 million as travel recovery continues
summary: Genting Singapore's Q3 net profit more than doubled to S$135.8 million, driven by a 96% increase in gaming revenue to S$382 million and a 144% rise in non-gaming revenue to S$137.3 million. The company attributes the growth to the recovery of regional travel markets and more affluent customers staying longer. Despite challenges from labor shortages and cost pressures, Genting remains confident about its growth opportunities in Singapore, with expansion projects proceeding as planned.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Net profit for the 6 months ended Jun 30, 2022 stood at S$84.4 million, compared with a net profit of S$88.2 million posted the same period a year ago.
Downside factors that may affect Genting Singapore’s performance include bad debts, particularly as gambling debts are not enforceable in China and the Chinese accounts for the majority of VIPs.

site_title: Musk’s first email to Twitter staff ends remote work
summary: Elon Musk emailed Twitter staff on November 9, 2022, warning of "difficult times ahead" and announcing that remote work would no longer be allowed unless personally approved. The new rules, effective immediately, require employees to work in the office for at least 40 hours per week. This comes as Musk has dismissed roughly half the workforce and most of the executive suite since taking over the company. He also aims to make subscriptions account for half of Twitter's revenue and has eliminated "days of rest" from staff calendars.

site_title: Vicom posts 2% rise in Q3 earnings to S$6.5 million
summary: Vicom, a vehicle inspection and technical testing services provider, posted a 2% increase in Q3 earnings to S$6.5 million, driven by higher operating profit and interest income. Revenue rose 4% year-over-year to S$27.4 million, mainly from its non-vehicle testing business. The company's vehicle inspection business remained stable, but faced lower demand due to low Certificate of Entitlement quotas and microchip shortages. Vicom's shares closed 0.5% lower at S$1.90.

images.alt_text: The increase comes on the back of higher demand for the group’s services in tandem with the improving Singapore economy.

site_title: NTT, Kioxia to invest in new Japan-backed logic semiconductor firm
summary: NTT and Kioxia will invest in a Japan-backed logic semiconductor firm that aims to mass-produce next-generation logic semiconductors. Other companies, including Toyota Motor, Sony Group, SoftBank, and Denso, will also invest 1 billion yen each. Japan's government will establish a research centre by the end of 2022 to develop sub 2-nanometre semiconductors, led by a former Tokyo Electron president. The investment aims to advance Japan's semiconductor industry and stay competitive globally.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.55 points to 1,449.74. A total of 3.478 billion lots worth RM1.454 billion were traded, with losers outnumbering gainers 468 to 344.

site_title: WeWork to exit 40 locations in US to cut costs
summary: WeWork to exit 40 US locations to cut costs, reducing 41,000 workstations and impacting revenue. The move is part of the company's effort to pare back expenses and reduce debt load and lease obligations, contributing approximately $140 million to annual adjusted core earnings. The closures aim to reduce costs and improve financial stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A WeWork logo is seen outside its offices in San Francisco, California, U.S. September 30, 2019.  REUTERS/Kate Munsch/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks buck Asia rout to extend rally; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% to 3,173.18, extending its five-session rally. Despite Asian markets falling, the STI outperformed due to gainers edging out losers 257-251. DFI Retail Group was the top gainer, while Sats was the biggest loser after reporting a net loss. The rally comes ahead of US inflation figures, with risk sentiment taking a hit due to the US midterms and crypto turmoil.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Jakarta and Taipei marlets were all trading lower on Thursday.

site_title: Emirates airline back in profit after Covid losses
summary: Emirates airline has reported a US$1.1 billion profit and a record US$1.2 billion half-year profit for the Emirates Group, driven by a 131% surge in revenues to 50.1 billion dirhams (S$19.1 billion) in the first half of the financial year. The airline's recovery from pandemic losses, which included a US$5.5 billion loss in 2020-2021, is attributed to easing travel restrictions. Emirates expects full-year group profits for the current financial year, but faces challenges from inflationary costs and macro-economic headwinds.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways has been named the world’s best airline at the Skytrax World Airline Awards 2022.

Global passenger numbers are projected to hit 83 per cent of pre-Covid levels this year. However, airline capacity has yet to return to pre-crisis levels, which means passengers end up paying a premium for airfares in the name of revenge travel – something they seem perfectly willing to do, flush with accumulated savings over the last 2 years.

site_title: Restoring St James Power Station, one brick at a time
summary: The St James Power Station, a 100-year-old building, has been restored to its former glory after a four-year conservation project. W Architects and Studio Lapis worked together to preserve the building's fair-faced brick facade, original soaring ceiling, and heritage elements. A new central atrium was created to allow natural light to flow in, and the interiors were restored to their original state. The restoration project received a distinction award for conservation and innovation at this year's Architectural Heritage Awards, recognizing the team's sensitive and innovative approach to preserving the building's heritage.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
WY-TO Singapore has designed six flats in Tiong Bahru, including this one.

site_title: Singapore to kick off S$15m carbon credit research in South-east Asia
summary: Singapore is launching a S$15 million research initiative, Carbon Integrity SG, to further carbon credit research in South-east Asia. The project, spanning five years, aims to establish monitoring plots at various natural habitats and use tools like light detection and ranging technology to estimate carbon storage potential. The research will help inform policy and investment decisions, contributing to Singapore's ambition to be a global hub for climate-related services. The project builds on earlier research that found Asia-Pacific's carbon projects have the potential to avoid 835 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent each year.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

FILE PHOTO: View of a COP27 sign on the road leading to the conference area in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh town as the city prepares to host the COP27 summit next month, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sayed Sheasha/File Photo

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the eligibility criteria for international carbon credits will “minimally reference” the Corsia standards for now, given that the carbon market is nascent and growing.

Smoke rises from an illegally lit fire in an Amazon rainforest reserve, south of Novo Progresso in Para state, Brazil, in 2020. Among items on the agenda at Cop27 climate change summit, which convened on Sunday (Nov 6), is a push by delegates to speed action to protect forests between now and 2030.

site_title: Volvo Car unveils flagship electric SUV in push to ditch engines
summary: Volvo Car unveiled the EX90, its first flagship electric SUV, as the automaker aims to go all-electric by 2030. The vehicle features lidar sensors and a range of up to 600 km, succeeding the popular XC90. Volvo plans to introduce several new battery models, including a smaller SUV in 2023, to reach annual sales of 1.2 million by mid-decade. The company faces competition from manufacturers like Mercedes-Benz and Tesla, and is under pressure to deliver on its electrification plan. The EX90 is built on Volvo's new dedicated electric vehicle platform.

site_title: Discovering the speedy side of Bentley
summary: Bentley's high-performance models, such as the Continental GT Speed and Bentayga Speed, showcase the brand's ability to deliver a fast grand touring driving experience. The Continental GT Speed can reach 335 km/h, while the Bentayga Speed reaches 306 km/h. Despite their large size, the Bentayga Speed handles well in the wet, thanks to its advanced technology, including adjustable air suspension and electric anti-roll bars. Bentley's motorsport chief, Paul Dickinson, emphasizes that the brand's Speed cars are designed for everyday driving, not just racing, and offer a luxurious experience.

images.alt_text: The latest Audi S8 has a flashy new grille and redesigned bumpers.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.70% on Thursday, Nov 10, following the decline of US and European markets due to inconclusive US midterm election results and inflation fears. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 16,081.04, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.39% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dropped 0.98%. The decline was attributed to market uncertainty and concerns over inflation.

site_title: BMW i7 review: Ostentation on wheels
summary: BMW's new flagship, the i7 xDrive60, is a luxurious and technologically advanced vehicle. The car features a 31-inch, 8K screen in the back seat and a 5.5-inch touchscreen in each rear door, allowing passengers to control climate and entertainment settings. The i7 boasts impressive performance, reaching 0-100 km/h in 4.7 seconds and has an estimated range of up to 625 km. With a starting price of S$631,888, the i7 is a symbol of excess and ostentation, embodying the essence of luxury. Its unique features and impressive capabilities make it a standout in the market.

images.alt_text:
steering5 - 

Source: BMW AG
Copyright: Free for editorial
Credit: BMW AG

site_title: Go clay crazy at 4 pottery markets this November
summary: Singapore is witnessing a surge in pottery-making, with a sharp increase in the number of ceramicists due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The island now has around 300 active potters making and selling wares, alongside thousands of hobbyists. Four ceramics exhibitions will take place across the island this November, including the Clay Makers' Market, Ceramix, Taking Roots // To Rise, and Ceramics Loft. The boom in pottery-making is attributed to social media's influence, with "clay influencers" on Instagram and TikTok popularizing the art form. The ceramics scene is expected to continue booming, with prices for handmade items lower than those for other decorative ornaments, making it an attractive option for consumers.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
"A Painting about Nothing and Everything" by Lester Lee won the UOB Painting of the Year (Singapore).

The 7th edition of the Singapore Biennale is set to open on 16 Oct 2022, with works by more than 50 artists spread over 13 locations. 




Credit : SINGAPORE ART MUSEUM
Brian Gothong Tan's series of NFTs includes this work titled Cosmic Embryo.

site_title: China auto sales rise at slowest pace in five months in October
summary: China's auto sales rose 6.9% in October to 2.51 million units, the slowest pace in five months. The increase was attributed to weak base sales and the lingering effects of zero-Covid policies, which kept consumers away from showrooms. The slowdown followed a 25.7% increase in September. This marks a sharp decline from the rapid growth seen in previous months, indicating a slowdown in the country's auto market.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop at open, before US inflation data
summary: European stocks dropped at the start of trading on Thursday, November 10, due to investors' anticipation of key US inflation data. London's FTSE 100 index fell 0.5% to 7,263.45 points, while Frankfurt's DAX index and Paris CAC 40 lost 0.4% and 0.5% respectively.

site_title: Buyer interest matches financial crisis lows: UK estate agents
summary: UK estate agents report a 19-point drop in buyer interest, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' index measuring sentiment from new buyers hitting minus 55% in October, matching lows from the financial crisis. Rising borrowing costs have led to a sixth consecutive month of declining inquiries, with 12-month price expectations plummeting to minus 42%. Experts predict a downward recalibration of property prices, with house prices already stalled or falling in some areas, amid a 14-year high interest rate hike by the Bank of England.

images.alt_text: The survey showed enquiries from new buyers fell for the sixth month running and buyer demand was negative across the country for the second month in a row.

site_title: Months after its IPO, Porsche needs its wizards more than ever
summary: Porsche has reached a milestone by producing its 100,000th electric car, the Taycan, just over three years after its launch. The 100,000th car, a blue Taycan Turbo S, is headed to a buyer in the UK. This surpasses the company's initial target of 20,000 units in 2020. The Taycan has outsold the 911, Porsche's legendary sportscar, last year. Porsche's strong sales and optimistic outlook for electric cars have contributed to a 20% surge in its stock price since its market debut in September, making it Europe's most valuable carmaker.

images.alt_text:
jubentley10


Credit: Porsche AG
Porsche, which was listed in Frankfurt on Sep 29, stuck to its outlook for the full year of a 17-18 per cent return on sales.

site_title: Seoul: Shares snap four-day rally on US inflation caution
summary: South Korean shares snapped a four-day rally on Thursday, closing 0.91% lower at 2,402.23 due to caution ahead of US inflation data. The benchmark Kospi index fell 22.18 points, with foreigners turning net sellers amid concerns over US inflation. The won currency weakened, while bond yields fell. Clean energy shares rose, driven by Democrats' better-than-expected performance in the US midterm elections.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Kospi rises 25.37 points, or 1.06 per cent, to close at 2,424.41.

site_title: Latest London Underground strike paralyses network
summary: A strike by members of the Rail, Maritime and Transport (RMT) and Unite unions paralyzed London's Underground network on Thursday, affecting millions of Londoners. The latest industrial action followed a long-running dispute over job cuts, pensions, and working conditions. The strike, which left most lines and city centre stations closed, was the latest in a series of walkouts this year. The RMT union said a conditional offer to suspend the strike failed, and pickets were held at numerous stations, including King's Cross.

images.alt_text: A spokesperson for the government’s health department said over a million NHS workers were being given a pay rise of at least £1,400 this year, in addition to 3 per cent last year.

site_title: France’s economy seen dodging onset of recession this year
summary: The French economy is expected to avoid a recession this year, with a "very slightly positive" fourth-quarter growth rate, according to a Bank of France survey. The economy is resisting the energy crisis, with supply constraints easing and inflationary pressures expected to decline. However, businesses expect the energy crisis to intensify in the next three months, and cash positions are deteriorating to very low levels. The central bank's governor, Francois Villeroy de Galhau, emphasized the need for vigilance and caution amid uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower after US falls
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on November 10, 2022, following falls on Wall Street amid US election results and crypto upheaval. The Nikkei 225 index lost 0.98% to 27,446.10, while the Topix index ended down 0.66%. The losses came as traders digested US election results and crypto market fluctuations.

site_title: Emperador reports 11% rise in 9M revenue but net profit slightly down
summary: Philippine liquor giant Emperador reported an 11% year-on-year revenue growth to 42.6 billion pesos in the first nine months of 2022, driven by whisky segment growth. The whisky segment saw a 16% increase due to higher sales of single malts and the return of travel retail. However, net profit was marginally lower at 7.2 billion pesos due to rising inflation and higher input and logistics costs. Emperador attributed the decline to the impact of inflation on its brandy segment, where prices are more accessible.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
drink, glass, alcohol

site_title: Asia air travel rebound buoyed by 2023 forward bookings
summary: Asian air travel is rebounding in 2023 due to strong forward bookings, according to Subhas Menon, director-general of the Association of Asia-Pacific Airlines (AAPA). Airlines underestimated pent-up demand, leading to higher ticket prices, but supply is now catching up. However, airlines face cost headwinds from oil prices and higher interest rates. Travel in the Asia-Pacific region recovered more slowly than other parts of the world due to prolonged border closures, but recent reopenings in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Japan have boosted demand.

site_title: Indonesia blames 2021 jet crash on mechanical issues, pilot complacency
summary: Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee (KNKT) has blamed mechanical issues and pilot complacency for a 2021 plane crash that killed 62 people. The Sriwijaya Air Boeing 737-500 crashed just minutes after takeoff on January 9, 2021, from Jakarta. Investigators identified mechanical issues as a primary factor, while pilot complacency was also cited. The report is the latest in a long line of investigations into the crash.

images.alt_text: epa10297508 Indonesia's National Transportation Safety Committee (KNKT) investigator Nurcahyo Utomo holds a Boeing 737 model as he speaks during a press conference on the final report of the Sriwijaya Air flight SJ-182 crash investigation in Jakarta, Indonesia, 10 November 2022. A problem on the automatic engine throttle system, which the pilot failed to anticipate, caused the Sriwijaya Air 737-500 jet to crash into the Java Sea in January 2021, killing 62 people on board, the final report said.  EPA-EFE/MAST IRHAM

site_title: China amends rules for management of insurance bailout funds
summary: China has amended rules for the management of state-run bailout funds, aiming to promote the insurance industry's healthy development, prevent financial risks, and maintain financial stability. The new rules, set to take effect on Dec 12, allow the China Insurance Security Fund to formulate risk disposal plans and enable it to provide support to troubled insurers. The rules also require cooperation from shareholders and management in liquidating insurance companies. The move aims to mitigate financial risks amid China's economic slowdown, which has been impacted by the Covid-19 restrictions and property crisis.

images.alt_text: After replacing builders as the biggest buyers of land earlier this year, the nation’s so-called local government financing vehicles have now become the main purchasers of half-finished projects of defaulters including China Evergrande Group.

site_title: Ipoh hor fun gets the Singapore touch at Small Tables
summary: Small Tables, a Singapore eatery, serves mega bowls of Ipoh-style noodles and other dishes on tiny tables, blending a kopitiam mentality with Chinese restaurant pricing. Despite the cramped dining space, the restaurant offers more than decent food, including curry mee, hor fun, and white coffee. Standout dishes include the curry mee, shredded chicken hor fun, and juicy pork belly satay. The eatery's menu features a variety of options, but the tiny tables may deter some customers. With a rating of 6, Small Tables shows promise but needs to grow to achieve its full potential.

images.alt_text: Breads are the real star at Sonder.

site_title: An apartment filled with surprising French inventions
summary: A French-themed exhibition, "Iconic!", at the Alliance Francaise de Singapour showcases French inventions that have changed daily life, including the Kelly bag by Hermes, bikini, Lacoste polo shirt, four-hole button, parachute, pencil sharpener, and neon lights. The exhibition aims to highlight lesser-known French innovations that have had a significant impact on modern society.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

Philippe Starck made his name as an interior decorator for Paris nightclubs in the 1970s, before landing a dream commission to refurbish the Elysee Palace apartments for President Francois Mitterrand in 1983.

site_title: More buying life insurance online, but agents still preferred: LIA
summary: The Life Insurance Association, Singapore (LIA) reported that online life insurance purchases rose to 40.7% of new policies in the first nine months of 2022, but agents still accounted for the bulk of high-premium policies. Direct online purchases contributed only 2.7% of weighted new business premiums, while bank representatives ranked as the preferred channel for high-premium policy purchases. The industry saw a 4.8% year-to-date increase in employment, with 1.5 million new policies taken up, and a 12.8% year-to-date increase in premium sales, despite a 5.9% fall in weighted new business premiums.

images.alt_text: Investing and saving on your own, outside a bundled insurance plan, gives you more flexibility.
Lower-risk options are now more attractive due to higher interest rates, but inflation remains a risk.
Using smart technology to facilitate the insurance purchase process can help reduce current protection gaps in Singapore.
Single-premium products are seeing sustained growth and remain popular among Singaporeans.
Life insurance sales in Singapore up 38% in first 9 months of 2021

site_title: At Chile wine gala, climate change and water use in focus
summary: Chilean winemakers are adapting to climate change and drought by shifting production to regions with more rainfall or building reservoirs to reduce reliance on rainfall. At the Catad'or World Wine Awards in Santiago, industry insiders noted that producers are moving south to regions with better weather conditions, such as the Maule Valley. The move is also driven by a desire to maintain wine quality and quantity. Winemakers, including Vina Undurraga, are prioritizing sustainability and diversifying their production to ensure the long-term viability of the industry.

site_title: Australia: Shares snap winning streak ahead on US inflation data
summary: Australia's shares slipped 0.5% to 6,964 at close, snapping a four-day winning streak, amid fresh Covid-19 curbs in China and anticipation of US inflation data. Energy stocks fell 2.1% and mining stocks declined 1.3% due to concerns over fuel demand. Tech stocks dropped 1.9% and financials fell 0.9% with the "Big Four" banks losing between 0.3 and 2.2%. A top Australian central banker suggested domestic interest rates might be paused soon, but more evidence is needed to confirm demand is slowing.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was down 0.5 per cent at 6,954.8 points, as of 2340 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: PM Lee heads to Cambodia for Asean Summit, with Myanmar crisis high on the agenda
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong is attending the 40th and 41st Asean Summits in Cambodia, where leaders will discuss the ongoing Myanmar crisis, South China Sea disputes, regional trade, and climate change. US President Joe Biden is also present, focusing on peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and addressing human rights concerns. Chinese Premier Li Keqiang is attending the summit, marking his first overseas trip since the Covid-19 pandemic. The four-day gathering aims to promote cooperation and address pressing regional issues.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES
Most South-east Asia economies are forecast to grow more than 4 per cent in 2023 as economies fight inflation and continue to rebound from the pandemic.

The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: London’s Battersea Power Station regains its energy
summary: The Battersea Power Station in London has reopened to the public after a new lease of life, reviving its iconic status as a major electricity producer in the city. Initially built in 1929 and 1933, the power station generated electricity for notable landmarks, including Buckingham Palace and Wimbledon. After being decommissioned, the site has been transformed into retail spaces, restaurants, and cafes, offering a new experience for the public. The reopening marks a new chapter for the historic power station.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
WY-TO Singapore has designed six flats in Tiong Bahru, including this one.

site_title: Saudi Aramco to ship full oil contract volumes to Asia in December
summary: Saudi Aramco will ship full contract volumes of crude oil to Asia in December, despite Opec+ output cuts, amid weaker demand in the region. The company lowered the December OSP for Arab Light crude sold to Asia by 40 US cents a barrel. This move maintains Saudi Arabia's steady supply to Asia, potentially preserving its market share as a price cap on Russian oil is set to kick in on Dec 5. Saudi Aramco raised OSPs for European customers and kept US prices unchanged.

images.alt_text: The company’s free cash flow rose to US$45 billion from US$28.7 billion a year earlier.

site_title: China certifies Embraer jet that could take on homegrown model
summary: China's aviation regulator has certified Embraer's E190-E2 regional jet for operations in the country, allowing it to compete against China's homegrown ARJ21 regional jet. The E190-E2 can seat up to 114 passengers and was previously certified in Brazil, the US, and Europe in 2018. The certification is a significant move, as China had been slow to certify Western jets, and Embraer expects it to bring more business opportunities in China. The company is also seeking Chinese certification of the larger E195-E2, which can seat up to 146 passengers.

images.alt_text: The C919 is China’s rival to the popular Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX narrowbody jet families, as the country looks to become more self-sufficient.
Asia has been slower than the rest of the world to open up its borders following the pandemic, with China still largely closed to outsiders.

site_title: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust posts lower H2 DPU
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) posted a lower distribution per unit (DPU) of 3.77 Singapore cents for the second half-year, a 2.8% fall from 3.88 cents. The trust's adjusted net property income fell 10.6% to S$162.1 million, while revenue decreased by 9.7% to S$214.5 million, due to the divestment of Cross Street Exchange and weaker exchange rates. DPU for FY2022 is 7.62 cents, 0.8% lower than the previous year.

images.alt_text: Some S$171.7 million has been committed for a forward-funding L&I acquisition in the UK.

site_title: Crypto markets face ‘cascade’ of margin calls: JPMorgan
summary: Crypto markets are experiencing a "cascade" of margin calls following the crisis at FTX.com, potentially leading to the bankruptcy of the exchange and contagion to other crypto outfits. JPMorgan strategists predict Bitcoin could fall to US$13,000, a level that could see a significant drawdown in the cryptocurrency market. The team cites Bitcoin's production cost, currently at US$15,000, as a key factor in determining its future price.

images.alt_text: Sequoia told LPs it ran “rigorous due diligence” on FTX at the time of its investment and its exposure to the company is limited.
Sam Bankman-Fried’s acknowledgement of his firm’s deep financial hole and limited options reflects the uncertain fate of FTX and its clients.
Temasek is in talks with troubled crypto exchange FTX after it signed a non-binding letter of intent with rival Binance for a full acquistion.
While crypto might seem like a niche corner of finance, the saga between two of its top players has upended the crypto ecosystem and is likely to have far-reaching repercussions.

site_title: Airbus sees Asia demand for big jets leading post-Covid recovery
summary: Airbus expects a post-Covid recovery in demand for its big jets in Asia-Pacific due to growing air travel in the region. Despite borders remaining closed in China, destinations like Singapore and Thailand have reopened, and India's domestic market has recovered quickly. Airbus predicts a 5.1% annual increase in passenger traffic and 4.1% annual growth in freighter traffic in the 20 years to 2041, driven by fundamental demand and structural growth. The demand is not just for replacing old aircraft but also for fleet expansion.

site_title: Philippine economy shows unexpected strength as demand holds
summary: The Philippine economy showed unexpected strength in the third quarter, with GDP growing 7.6% year-over-year, beating expectations. Consumer spending rose 8% from a year ago, driven by a strong demand recovery. Despite inflation exceeding the central bank's target, the nation is on track to achieve its 2022 growth target of 6.5-7.5%. The central bank is set to tighten monetary policy further to contain inflation, with Governor Felipe Medalla signaling openness to matching the Federal Reserve's rate hike.

images.alt_text: Philippine Photographer: Veejay Villafranca/Bloomberg
“The risks to the inflation outlook appear to be tilted to the upside for 2022 and 2023 but are seen to be broadly balanced for 2024,” the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) said in a statement.

site_title: Credit Suisse revamps Asia-Pacific wealth management team
summary: Credit Suisse has revamped its Asia-Pacific wealth management team, simplifying its structure to be more agile and responsive to global trends. Regional wealth head Benjamin Cavalli made the decision after recent senior departures in the group. The bank promoted executives, including Balakrishnan Kunnambath as vice-chairman and strategic client lead for South-east Asia and India, and Puneet Matta as market group head for India and NRI, subject to regulatory approval. The changes aim to improve the bank's ability to respond to global trends and capitalize on emerging opportunities in the region.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cavalli, Head of Private Banking South Asia and CEO Singapore, Credit Suisse

site_title: Putin will not attend G20 summit in Bali: Indonesian official
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin will not attend the upcoming G20 summit in Bali, Indonesia, due to unspecified reasons. He will be represented by Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, who will join the meeting virtually. This decision comes as tensions between Russia and Indonesia have been rising, particularly over Ukraine. The G20 summit is set to take place next week, and the absence of Putin is likely to have significant implications for global economic discussions and diplomatic relations.

site_title: South Korea unveils 10t won in financing for property market
summary: South Korea unveiled 10 trillion won (S$10.2 billion) in financing to support its struggling property market, which has been experiencing its worst monthly decline since the 2008 global financial crisis. The measure aims to curb excessive contraction of housing projects and follows previous guarantees of 10 trillion won announced in October as part of a broader 50 trillion won aid package. The move is part of the government's efforts to stabilize the nation's housing market, which has been declining in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: The BOK has raised its benchmark rate by 50 basis points at two of its past three meetings.

site_title: Data, capabilities and pathways: MAS’ plan to support Singapore’s low-carbon transition
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has outlined a plan to support Singapore's low-carbon transition by setting up three broad enablers: a stronger data disclosure landscape, building capabilities in low-carbon technologies, and transition and sectoral pathways. MAS will commit S$129 million to low-carbon energy research and S$100 million to sustainable finance capability programs over the next five years. The central bank aims to shape the real economy towards decarbonization by focusing on transition plans and how financial institutions can support sustainable development, particularly in carbon-intensive sectors.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

Solar and wind energy took over a decade to transform the renewable energy landscape; hydrogen could reach maturity over a shorter period given ambitious climate goals amid the global race to hit net-zero
Decarbonising the power sector is key in the city state’s race to net zero by 2050 as the sector currently contributes about 40 per cent of Singapore’s total carbon emissions.
Sembcorp's cogeneration plant on Banyan, Jurong Island.

site_title: Brokers’ take: DBS expects DFI earnings to bounce back in FY2023; upgrades to ‘buy’
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded DFI Retail Group to an early, non-consensus "buy" rating, expecting associate performance to bounce back in FY2023. The research team believes the market is overly pessimistic on DFI's North Asia business and that current valuations are mispricing the group's strong earnings recovery. The target price was raised to US$3.07, representing a potential upside of 21.3% from the counter's last trading price.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Omicron threat draws mixed reactions from analysts covering Dairy Farm
Dairy Farm International has changed its name to DFI Retail Group Holdings, with effect from May 5.
CGS-CIMB also noted DFI Retail's intent to further invest in e-commerce and expects “elevated” expenses in the medium term.

site_title: Startup behind FastJobs raises S$10.5m in Series A funding
summary: FastCo, the startup behind job portals FastJobs and FastGig, has raised S$10.5 million in Series A funding led by OSK Ventures International and Kairous Capital. The company aims to breakeven within two years and has seen steady growth since its founder and management-led buyout in December last year. With over 4.4 million registered jobseekers, FastCo plans to deepen its regional presence and grow its sales and product development teams.

images.alt_text: Sharanya Pillai
L-R: Wavemaker Impact founding members Quentin Vaquette, Doug Parker, Marie Cheong, Paul Santos and Steve Melhuish.

site_title: Asia: Stocks down after US midterms turn global markets red
summary: Asian stocks declined on Thursday following US midterm election results and a turbulent cryptocurrency market, with markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Jakarta, and Taipei trading lower. The uncertainty about inflation and future interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve also contributed to the downturn. The US inflation data, due later Thursday, is expected to gauge the speed of future rate hikes, with economists predicting a rate hike to 5.0% or higher. The crypto market was also affected by a surprise decision from Binance to scrap a possible acquisition of FTX.com.

images.alt_text: Tokyo was down 0.2 per cent at the break, while Hong Kong lost 0.1 per cent in morning trade, with Shanghai up 0.3 per cent.

site_title: New Zealand central bank review says monetary tightening should have started earlier
summary: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's internal review of monetary policy decisions from 2017 to 2022 found that the easing in monetary policy during the Covid-19 pandemic was largely warranted. However, with hindsight, the review concluded that monetary policy should have been tightened earlier in 2021, potentially by lifting the cash rate or reducing asset purchases, to avoid future inflation risks. The review identified nine areas for improvement, including better insight into supply shocks on inflation.

site_title: UK hiring falls as political upheaval adds to employers’ worries
summary: UK hiring falls as political upheaval adds to employers' worries, with hiring of permanent staff via recruitment firms for the first time in nearly two years in October. Hiring of temporary workers stagnated, and wage growth for permanent new staff was Britain's weakest in a year and a half. The survey attributed the decline to economic and political uncertainty following former Prime Minister Liz Truss's government, with employers becoming more cautious in their hiring approach.

images.alt_text: British Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt exits a car outside Downing Street in London, Britain October 17, 2022. REUTERS/Henry Nicholls
The survey showed enquiries from new buyers fell for the sixth month running and buyer demand was negative across the country for the second month in a row.
The deal does not include staff and so there would be about 400 redundancies from the takeover of Made.com..

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 3.52 points or 0.24% to 1442.67 on Thursday, with 244 losers outweighing 82 gainers. Volume was 173.68 million lots worth RM56.21 million.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit by risk aversion, RBA talk on rates
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars declined 1.2% and 1.3% respectively on Thursday, amidst global risk aversion sparked by turmoil in cryptocurrency markets. The Aussie dollar steadied at US$0.6418, while the New Zealand dollar held at US$0.5875. Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) Deputy Governor Michele Bullock signaled that interest rates may rise further but also indicated they could "sit and wait" for a while, nudging bill futures higher.

site_title: Sequoia marks FTX investment down to zero
summary: Sequoia Capital marks its investment in FTX down to zero due to a liquidity crunch creating a solvency risk for the crypto exchange. The venture capital firm claims to have run "rigorous due diligence" on FTX at the time of its investment and its exposure is limited, accounting for less than 3% of committed capital. This move comes after FTX raised nearly $2 billion in funding and sparked further concerns for other investors, including Paradigm and Temasek.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
While crypto might seem like a niche corner of finance, the saga between two of its top players has upended the crypto ecosystem and is likely to have far-reaching repercussions.
Temasek is in talks with troubled crypto exchange FTX after it signed a non-binding letter of intent with rival Binance for a full acquistion.

site_title: Australia: Banks, miners drag shares down ahead of US inflation data
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.5% on Thursday, snapping a four-day winning streak, due to cautious investor sentiment ahead of US inflation data. Mining and financial stocks, including Woodside Energy and BHP Group, declined between 1.9% and 2.6%. Energy stocks lost nearly 2%, while financials dropped 0.6%. Despite this, shares of Origin Energy surged 40.3% after backing a buyout offer.

images.alt_text: Shares of Rio Tinto, BHP Group and Fortescue Metals advanced between 2.1 per cent and 3.1 per cent.

site_title: Credit Suisse forced to pay junk-level yields for cash infusion
summary: Credit Suisse is forced to pay high-yield interest rates of 9% to attract investors for a $2 billion bond sale in the US and a €3 billion bond sale in Europe. The move comes as the bank struggles with financial troubles and scandals, and is heavily oversubscribed, with $8 billion of orders for the US sale. The bank's long-term rating was downgraded to just one level above junk status, citing "material execution risks." The sales underscore the bank's declining creditworthiness and the surging cost of new funding in the market.

images.alt_text: The amount Credit Suisse will pay to buy back the euro notes ranges from 75.05 US cents for a 2028-dated issue to 97.75 US cents for a floating-rate note due next September.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open lower on Thursday
summary: Hong Kong stocks fell 1.35% to 16,138.22, following US and European markets' losses due to inconclusive election results and a turbulent cryptocurrency market. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.71% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.59%. The decline came amid concerns about global economic uncertainty and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Van Gogh landscape sells for US$117m at Paul Allen auction
summary: A Vincent van Gogh landscape painting, Verger avec Cyprès (1888), sold for a record-breaking US$117 million at Christie's auction, surpassing a 30-year-old global record for the artist. The sale, part of Paul Allen's estate, is expected to bring in over US$1 billion, with the buyer's premium pushing totals over US$700 million. The painting's sale price surpassed the artist's previous record-breaking Portrait du Dr Gachet sold for in 1990.

site_title: Prime residential property in Apac now a buyer’s market: Knight Frank
summary: Knight Frank Asia-Pacific reports that prime residential property in the Asia-Pacific region has become a buyer's market due to falling prices, with 11 out of 45 cities experiencing declines in Q3 2022. This marks a reversal from the previous year, when only four markets saw price drops. The region's cities, including Apac, are now seeing the fastest rate of growth since Q1 2015, with prices in prime central London experiencing its fastest rate of growth since 2015.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
A man walks past houses ‘For Sale’ in a residential street in London, Britain, September 27, 2022. REUTERS/Hannah McKay

site_title: Allen Auction tops US$1b, Freud sets own US$86m record
summary: A painting by Lucian Freud, "Large Interior W11", sold for $86.3 million at Christie's auction in New York, surpassing its $75 million presale estimate and setting a record for the artist. The work, part of a sale of art from Paul Allen's estate, has now made the entire sale the most valuable-ever single-owner sale, exceeding $1 billion. Other record-breaking sales included Seurat's "Dance at Le Moulin de la Galette" at $149 million and Gauguin's "The Vision After the Sermon" at $106 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at the open on Thursday, mirroring Wall Street declines amid concerns over a consumer price report and cryptocurrency market drops. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 3.67 points to 3,161.83, with losers outnumbering gainers 74 to 35. Top losers included Sembcorp Marine and OCBC, while Singtel rose 1.2% after releasing its half-year financial results. The decline in US stocks, including the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500, was attributed to anxiety ahead of the consumer price report and worries about margin calls.

images.alt_text: Singtel reports earnings of S$1.17 billion for the half-year ended Sep 30, up 23 per cent from H1 FY2022, after booking a net exceptional gain from its partial divestment of its stake in Airtel.

site_title: Tesla loses 2 years of gains amid Twitter saga, demand fears
summary: Tesla's stock price plummeted 7.2% to its lowest since November 2020, wiping out 2 years of gains, amid concerns over Elon Musk's sales of Tesla stocks. Musk's latest sale of $3.95 billion shares confirmed investors' suspicions, despite his denials. The sale brings his total proceeds over the past year to $36 billion, leaving him with about 14% ownership. The decline in stock price has raised fears about demand for Tesla's electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk unloaded 19.5 million shares, according to regulatory filings on Tuesday in New York, his first disposals since August.
The Elon Musk-led electric-vehicle maker’s shares closed with a market valuation of US$604 billion on Tuesday.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit’s Q3 distributable income slips 0.4% to 24.2m euros
summary: Cromwell E-Reit reported a 0.4% year-on-year decline in distributable income to €24.2 million in Q3, despite a 10.4% gain in gross revenue to €55.9 million and a 4.1% increase in net property income to €34.5 million. The decline was primarily driven by higher interest, trust, and tax expenses.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands
Cromwell E-Reit’s manager does not expect the transaction to have a material effect on the Reit’s net tangible assets.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower after Wall Street drops
summary: Tokyo's benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.02% to 27,432.71, following Wall Street's decline. Investors were discouraged by US election results and crypto upheaval, affecting global markets. The broader Topix index fell 0.84% to 1,933.21.

site_title: Gold traders in wait-and-watch mode ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices were steady on Thursday as investors waited for the US inflation report to gauge the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Spot gold remained flat at $1,705.77 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.3% to $1,709.20. Economists expect a deceleration in core inflation, and rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion. The report, due at 1:30 GMT, may provide cues on the Federal Reserve's rate hike plan.

images.alt_text: Although gold is seen as an inflation hedge, rising rates increase the opportunity cost of holding bullion.

site_title: Biden to discuss North Korea nuclear threat with Japan, South Korea leaders
summary: US President Joe Biden will meet Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol on November 13 in Cambodia to discuss ways to address North Korea's nuclear threat. The meeting aims to enhance trilateral cooperation in the Indo-Pacific region, particularly in countering North Korea's unlawful weapons of mass destruction and ballistic missile programmes. This comes after North Korea recently tested a ballistic missile that soared over Japan for the first time in five years, prompting a warning for residents to take cover.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on November 2, 2022, people watch a television screen showing a news broadcast with file footage of a North Korean missile test, at a railway station in Seoul. - North Korea fired four short-range ballistic missiles towards the sea, Seoul's military said on November 5, 2022, the latest in a blitz of missile launches this week by Pyongyang. (Photo by JUNG YEON-JE / AFP)

site_title: US, Taiwan wrap up ‘productive’ trade meeting: USTR
summary: The US and Taiwan concluded two productive trade talks in New York, focusing on 11 areas of trade, including trade facilitation, digital trade, and labor. The meetings were part of the US-Taiwan Initiative on 21st-Century Trade, which was launched after the Biden administration excluded Taiwan from its Asia-focused economic plan. China has opposed the talks, viewing self-governing Taiwan as its own territory. The two sides agreed to hold additional meetings in the near future, despite China's firm opposition.

images.alt_text: China and Hong Kong buy about 40% of Taiwan’s total exports, making those markets key trading partners.
MediaTek said the new Dimensity 9200 chip’s power efficiency helped achieve longer battery life and create a better gaming experience on the smartphone.

site_title: US midterms : Not red tsunami, more like a ripple
summary: US midterm elections did not yield a "red tsunami" for Republicans as expected, but instead resulted in a modest Republican gain in the House and a possible Republican takeover of the Senate. However, the gains were not as significant as anticipated, with many Republican candidates failing to win key races. Despite this, the elections were a bad night for Donald Trump, who had predicted a Republican landslide and had endorsed several losing Republican candidates. Trump's own re-election prospects in 2024 are now uncertain, with Florida Governor Ron DeSantis emerging as a potential challenger.

images.alt_text: House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy is poised to take over as Speaker of the House. Expect Congressional oversight hearings as soon as McCarthy assumes the role.
US Special Presidential Envoy for Climate John Kerry at an event on the sidelines of the COP27 conference at Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, on November 8, 2022.
Up for grabs are all 435 House seats, a third of the 100 Senate seats, and a slew of state-level posts.

site_title: Manulife takes hit from continued Covid restrictions in Asia
summary: Manulife's global wealth and asset-management business faced a decline due to falling equity markets, but largely withstood the industrywide drop. The company's Asia business, however, was hit by continued pandemic-related restrictions, with third-quarter core earnings falling 3.8% to C$513 million. Annualised premium equivalent sales in Asia fell 8.2% due to lower sales in Hong Kong, which recently lifted Covid-related restrictions. In contrast, core earnings in Canada rose 13% to C$350 million.

images.alt_text: Having access to STACS’ ESGpedia portfolio monitoring tool would allow the investment manager to see greater asset level details, such as the green certifications of the buildings financed by green bonds, thus supporting its due diligence and monitoring of investee companies, says Eric Nietsch, Manulife’s head of sustainable investing.

site_title: China property crisis threatens US$1.6t of local state debt
summary: China's deepening property crisis is putting pressure on a $1.6 trillion corner of the country's onshore bond market, with local government financing vehicles (LGFVs) stepping in to bail out troubled developers. LGFVs, which have replaced builders as the biggest buyers of land, are now purchasing half-finished projects of defaulters, including China Evergrande Group. Analysts warn that this could weigh on the credit profile of these state funding agencies, with potential default risks not elevated over the next six months.

images.alt_text: epa10268388 A handout photo made available by the Indonesian Ministry for Foreign Affair shows Cambodia’s Foreign Minister Prak Sokhonn (C) delivering his speech during the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) foreign ministers' special meeting at the Asean secretariat in Jakarta, Indonesia, 27 October 2022. The ASEAN secretariat host the Southeast Asian foreign ministers special meeting to discuss the ongoing crisis in Myanmar.  EPA-EFE/GALIH PRADIPTA / HANDOUT  HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES
The signs of funding stress underscore the pressure on the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) to keep liquidity ample when 1 trillion yuan of medium-term lending facility matures on Nov 15

site_title: AusGroup in advanced talks for sale of certain assets; suspends trading
summary: AusGroup, a MAINBOARD-LISTED integrated service solutions provider, is in advanced talks for the potential sale of certain assets and businesses. The company has suspended trading following a halt on Nov 7 and recommended shares be suspended due to discussions with its board and management over the company's financial position. There is no assurance that a sale will materialize, with indicative draft terms available. Managing director Shane Kimpton is stepping down but remains as chief executive to focus on operational matters.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
AusGroup secures contract for upcoming lithium refinery in Perth
Shane Kimpton, chief executive officer of AusGroup

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades ISDN to ‘hold’ on expected profit decline
summary: CGS-CIMB downgraded its call on ISDN to "hold" from "add" due to expected profit decline in the third quarter, citing foreign exchange losses and revenue decline. The research house lowered its target price to S$0.39, citing a lower five-year average price-to-equity multiple. Revenue and profit are forecast to decline 14.5% and 65.1% year-over-year, respectively, due to Covid-19 lockdowns in China and supply chain disruptions. ISDN's foreign exchange losses are also expected to rise due to a weakening yuan.

images.alt_text: ISDN sees demand from Asian businesses seeking industrial automation to relieve labour wage pressure, advance manufacturing capabilities and reduce business risk.

site_title: Business transformation in a volatile economy
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) face challenges in adopting digital transformation, with 65% agreeing on its importance but only 2 in 5 considering their transformation successful. Top challenges include high costs, upskilling employees, and a lack of digitally skilled workforce. SMEs need to shift their focus to holistic business transformation, investing in technology, re-engineering processes, and transforming people and processes to stay competitive.

images.alt_text: Singapore's research, innovation and enterprise ecosystem has many offerings to support small and medium-sized enteprises, from the Centres of Innovation in polyclinics to government funding.
Vincent Chuang, senior research engineer of ARTC (left) and Dr Xavier Lim, solutions director of Xnergy Autonomous Power Technologies with Xnergy’s universal wireless chargers.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, FLCT, Starhub, CLI, Sats, Cromwell E-Reit, Riverstone
summary: Key developments in Singapore's stock market include Singtel's 23% increase in earnings to S$1.17 billion for the half-year ended Sep 30, Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's lower DPU of 3.77 cents, and StarHub's decline in net profit to S$27.4 million for the third quarter. Other notable announcements include CapitaLand Investment's sale of a Penang mall for RM990.5 million, Sats' net loss of S$9.9 million for the second quarter, and Riverstone Holdings' 76.2% fall in earnings.

site_title: Amazon becomes world’s first public company to lose US$1t in market value
summary: Amazon, the world's largest online retailer, has become the first public company to lose a trillion dollars in market value. The e-commerce and cloud company's shares fell 4.3% on November 9, pushing its market value to around $879 billion. This decline is attributed to a sharp slowdown in e-commerce growth, rising inflation, and disappointing earnings updates. The company's market value has dropped nearly 50% this year due to slowing sales, soaring costs, and a jump in interest rates.

site_title: Crypto chaos stirs fresh Wall Street selling as inflation report looms
summary: Wall Street experienced its largest cross-asset selloff in a month on November 9, 2022, amid crypto chaos and an impending inflation report. The S&P 500 plummeted 2% for the second time in a week, with speculative tech firms and Bitcoin taking a hit. Investors are cautious ahead of the inflation report, which could influence the next round of monetary policy tightening. The selloff is part of a broader trend of risk-off sentiment, driven by concerns about economic data and Fed decisions, with the market vulnerable to an economic growth shock.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin, the largest token by market value, fell as much as 17 per cent on Tuesday to US$17,172, its lowest since November 2020.

site_title: FTX investors warned of likely bankruptcy without new funds
summary: FTX's Sam Bankman-Fried warned investors that the company would likely file for bankruptcy without a new cash injection, citing a potential shortfall of up to $8 billion. FTX is attempting to raise rescue financing, while Binance backed out of a takeover deal, citing issues beyond its control. The collapse of the deal has sparked concerns about contagion risk in the crypto industry, with Bitcoin prices plummeting to a two-year low. US regulators are also investigating FTX's handling of customer funds and its relationship with other crypto companies.

images.alt_text: Sam Bankman-Fried Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil drops as US inventories swell amid China’s Covid-19 challenges
summary: US oil prices dropped 3.5% to near $86 a barrel as US crude inventories rose 3.93 million barrels, the highest since July 2021. China's Covid-19 challenges, including rising cases in Beijing, are seen as a major driver of the decline. The International Energy Agency has raised concerns that OPEC's supply cuts may be damaging emerging economies, potentially leading to a rethink of its plans.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Capricorn Sun tanker is moored at Germany's port of Rostock, Germany, August 5, 2022. According to Refinitiv ship tracking data, the Capricorn Sun tanker loaded Mars Sour crude off the Louisiana coast in the United States and discharged at Rostock on August 3, 2022, as local refiners test alternatives to Russian oil.     REUTERS/Andreas Rinke/File Photo
Brent futures for January delivery fell US$2.56 to US$95.36 a barrel, a 2.6 per cent loss.

site_title: Is net zero by 2050 a pipe dream?
summary: A recent analysis by Accenture and the World Economic Forum suggests that digital technologies can accelerate decarbonization efforts and reduce emissions by up to 20% by 2050. The key sectors to focus on include energy, materials, and mobility. To achieve net-zero emissions, high-emitting industry sectors must adopt efficiency, circularity, and sustainability strategies. Singapore has committed to raising its 2030 climate target, but meeting the goal of net-zero emissions by 2050 will require substantial change and determination. Digital solutions hold significant potential to drive decarbonization efforts.

images.alt_text: Milk bottles in crates wait in chiller waits to be loaded up at a Fonterra Factory in Takanini South Auckland , North Island of New Zealand Tue 7th Oct  2009 ,Photographer Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg News      in Auckland, New Zealand, on Wednesday, Oct. 7, 2009. Fonterra Cooperative Group Ltd., the world's largest dairy exporter, said increased demand from Middle East, African and South-east Asian buyers helped push whole milk powder prices to a 13-month high this month. Photographer: Brendon O'Hagan/Bloomberg

site_title: UK house prices fall as rising mortgage rates temper property market
summary: UK house prices fell for the first time in 28 months in October, with the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) house price balance tumbling to -2 from +30 in September. Enquiries from new buyers fell for the sixth month running, and buyer demand was negative for the second month in a row. Rising mortgage costs, fueled by the "mini-budget" of former UK Prime Minister Liz Truss, are tempering the property market. Economists expect a recent financial market settling down to provide some relief, but lending rates are unlikely to fall soon.

images.alt_text: epa10279129 A general view along windows in a street in London, Britain, 01 November 2022.  House prices have fallen for the first time in nearly a year and a half, according to the Nationwide Building Society. Property experts are warning that the UK property market could drop by some twenty percent in 2023.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN

site_title: Europe: Stocks snap three-day gains on worries over US vote, inflation
summary: European stocks snapped a three-day gain, closing 0.3% lower, amid uncertainty over the US midterm elections and rising inflation concerns. The Stoxx 600 index, which had reached an eight-week closing high, was weighed down by economically sensitive stocks, including energy, travel & leisure, and miners. US crude stockpiles rose, and concerns over a potential rebound in Covid-19 cases in China also impacted fuel demand. The outcome of the US midterm elections remains unclear, with Republicans making modest gains, but control of Congress and President Biden's agenda still uncertain.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index fell 0.2 per cent to 7,291.90 points.

site_title: BT Future of Finance: Transaction banking and trade finance (Ep 1)
summary: HSBC's Chief Digital Officer, Shayan Hazir, discusses the evolution of transaction banking for trade finance clients. The key challenge to transformation is working capital, followed by internationalisation and mindset shifts. Resilience in volatile times is also crucial. Hazir emphasizes that every challenge is an opportunity, and HSBC believes that businesses can position themselves for the future by embracing change. The episode highlights the importance of blockchain technology in transforming banking and finance.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from top left: Dennis Tan, CEO, Prudential Singapore, Brendan Carney, CEO, Citibank Singapore, Shee Tse Koon, group executive and Singapore country head, DBS, Lim Khiang Tong, group chief operating officer, OCBC,  Shayan Hazir, chief digital officer for Asean, HSBC,  Michele Ferrario, co-founder and CEO, StashAway,  Kevin Lam, head of TMRW and group digital banking, UOB, Dwaipayan Sadhu, CEO, Trust Bank

Top executives at financial institutions expect the use of blockchain technology to be a game changer in improving processes and paving the way for more services and types of assets for end-customers.

site_title: Republican blowback at Trump after limited election gains
summary: US President Donald Trump's anticipated "red wave" in the midterm elections failed to materialize, with Republicans likely to gain control of at least one chamber of Congress but not the Senate. Trump's endorsement of underperforming candidates is blamed for the party's limited gains, with several of his hand-picked candidates losing seats. Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, a rising Republican star, resoundingly won reelection, positioning himself as a potential Trump opponent. Trump is expected to launch a presidential campaign, possibly as early as November 15, and analysts predict he will declare his candidacy for 2024 sooner than later.

images.alt_text: PALM BEACH, FLORIDA - NOVEMBER 08: Former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks during an Election Night event at Mar-a-Lago on November 08, 2022 in Palm Beach, Florida. Trump addressed his supporters as the nation awaits the results of the midterm elections.   Joe Raedle/Getty Images/AFP
Up for grabs are all 435 House seats, a third of the 100 Senate seats, and a slew of state-level posts.
Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer (pink) was re-elected in the “blue wall” state of Michigan.
US President Joe Biden on Wednesday said it was his “intention to run again” for a second term in office, but that he would decide for sure “early next year.”
Joe Biden’s Democrats are facing a struggle to hold on to control of Congress, after a race that he has cast as a defining moment for US democracy.

site_title: Schumacher Ferrari fetches record US$15m at auction
summary: Michael Schumacher's 2003 F1-winning Ferrari sold for 13 million Swiss francs (S$18.5 million) at auction in Geneva, breaking the previous record held by another Schumacher-driven Ferrari. The final price, after taxes and fees, stood at 14.6 million francs (S$20.9 million). The car, which powered Schumacher to his sixth F1 title and helped Ferrari win a 13th constructor's championship, is considered one of the most significant Formula One cars of all time.

images.alt_text: The company said its adjusted earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda) would grow this year to over 1.73 billion euros (S$2.4 billion).

site_title: Property players less optimistic in Q3, expect ‘muted outlook’ for suburban residential market
summary: Singapore property players have become less optimistic in Q3 2022, expecting a "muted outlook" for the suburban residential market due to rising inflation and interest rates. According to a survey by the National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies, the suburban residential sector recorded the lowest future net balance of -19%, while the hotel and serviced apartment sector remained positive at 68%. The overall sentiment is a decline from the current net balance of 35% in the suburban residential sector.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Generic pictures of properties landscape in Singapore
Singapore property executives see rising inflation and interest rates as top risk
New cooling measures overturn sanguine outlook for new private home market for 2022

site_title: Coinbase, Robinhood lead US$10b rout in crypto mayhem
summary: Coinbase and Robinhood shares plummeted 9.5% and 14% respectively, wiping out over $10 billion in value, amid the collapse of Binance's deal to buy FTX.com. The failed rescue of Sam Bankman-Fried's troubled crypto exchange has raised concerns over the crypto industry's longevity. Other cryptocurrency-linked stocks, including MicroStrategy and Riot Blockchain, also suffered significant losses, with Bitcoin falling 14% to a two-year low. The sell-off extends the week's losses, which now account for more than one-fifth of the market capitalizations of affected companies.

site_title: Japan’s credit ratings may hinge on BOJ policy changes, S&P says
summary: Japan's credit ratings may be influenced by the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) policy changes, according to S&P Global Ratings. Speculation suggests the BOJ may withdraw its decade-old monetary stimulus next year, which could impact inflation and the yen's value. The BOJ's actions could determine Japan's creditworthiness, with S&P noting the risks of policy changes or inaction are high. The central bank's yield-curve control policy has been tested this year, and Japan's public debt is the highest among advanced economies, at over 250% of annual economic output.

images.alt_text: The BOJ remains an outlier among a global wave of central banks tightening monetary policy to combat soaring inflation, as it focuses on supporting a fragile economy.

site_title: BMW’s Zipse: ‘We are not leaving lower segment for electric cars’
summary: BMW CEO Oliver Zipse stated that the company will not abandon its lower-priced segment in the transition to electrification, contradicting Mercedes-Benz's strategy of focusing on premium vehicles. Zipse emphasized the importance of the lower market segment to BMW's future business. Despite expected growth in electric vehicle sales, rising inflation and interest rates may impact orders, particularly in Europe.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: BMW logo is seen on a vehicle at the BMW manufacturing plant in Greer, South Carolina, U.S., October 19, 2022.   REUTERS/Bob Strong/File Photo

site_title: Binance backs out of FTX deal over issues beyond its control
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao announced that the company will not pursue a potential acquisition of FTX.com due to issues beyond its control, including a massive financial gap and US regulatory investigations. This decision leaves the fate of FTX and its clients uncertain. Zhao admitted there was no master plan to take over FTX, sparking concerns about contagion risks in the crypto industry. The move also prompted renewed selling in digital assets, with Bitcoin tumbling below $16,000.

images.alt_text: Temasek is in talks with troubled crypto exchange FTX after it signed a non-binding letter of intent with rival Binance for a full acquistion.
While crypto might seem like a niche corner of finance, the saga between two of its top players has upended the crypto ecosystem and is likely to have far-reaching repercussions.
Bitcoin, the largest token by market value, fell as much as 17 per cent on Tuesday to US$17,172, its lowest since November 2020.
The acquisition will reshape the more than US$1 trillion industry that is already dealing with a prolonged market downturn.

site_title: US wholesale inventories revised lower in September
summary: US wholesale inventories were revised lower in September, increasing 0.6% instead of the initially reported 0.8%. This decrease, combined with a 1.4% rise in August, suggests businesses are carefully managing their inventory amid slowing demand. Petroleum and computer equipment stocks decreased, contributing to the lower-than-expected increase.

images.alt_text: “Inflation, supply chain disruptions, and labour shortages continue to limit the ability of many small businesses to meet the demand for their products and services,” NFIB chief economist Bill Dunkelberg said in a statement.

site_title: GIFT City: Wooing foreign universities to India
summary: GIFT City, India's first greenfield smart city, is set to become a hub for foreign universities. New regulations allow certain foreign institutions to establish a branch in the city without certain domestic mandates, promoting research in banking, insurance, and fintech. This move aims to attract Western higher education to India, addressing the growing demand for international education. The regulations follow the global trend of shifting higher education aspirations to foreign universities due to the Covid pandemic and the war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong expresses hope that the agreement will open up the space for fintech companies from Singapore and India to experiment and pilot innovative products and services to serve both markets.

site_title: Biden will confirm ‘early next year’ if he seeks a second term
summary: US President Joe Biden confirmed his intention to run for a second term, stating it's his "intention to run again" but will decide for sure "early next year." This comes after the Democratic Party recorded a strong performance in midterm elections. Biden's decision follows a pattern of speculation about his re-election plans, with his wife Jill referencing their intention to run again.

site_title: Amid fears of a global recession, India is seen as oasis for investors
summary: India is gaining attention from investors amid global recession fears, with the country overtaking the UK to become the world's fifth-largest economy earlier this year. India's huge size, growing middle class, and robust digital infrastructure make it an attractive destination for businesses and investors. Apple's production of iPhone 14 models in India is a recent example of this trend, and India's stable foreign exchange reserves and rising exports further boost its appeal. As the "China+1" strategy gains traction, India is seen as a promising alternative for diversification.

images.alt_text: Paytm reiterated that it expects to reach operating profitability by the quarter ending September 2023 amid continued revenue growth.

“The goal of US$100 billion per year of climate finance by 2020 and every year thereafter through till 2025 is yet to be achieved,” the India government said in a statement ahead of the COP27 event in Egypt, which begins on Nov 6.
HDFC’s interest income rose 24 per cent to 131.43 billion rupees in the quarter.

site_title: Novogratz’s Galaxy Digital discloses FTX exposure
summary: Galaxy Digital, a crypto financial services firm founded by billionaire Michael Novogratz, disclosed an exposure of US$76.8 million to FTX, with US$47.5 million currently in the withdrawal process. Galaxy's net comprehensive loss was US$68.1 million, primarily due to unrealised losses on investments. The company maintained a liquidity position of US$1.5 billion as of September and plans to explore eliminating 20% of its workforce amid market downturns.

images.alt_text: Temasek is in talks with troubled crypto exchange FTX after it signed a non-binding letter of intent with rival Binance for a full acquistion.
While crypto might seem like a niche corner of finance, the saga between two of its top players has upended the crypto ecosystem and is likely to have far-reaching repercussions.

After dumping its holdings of FTX’s native coin and triggering an exodus of users from the rival bourse, Changpeng Zhao's Binance, the world’s biggest cryptocurrency exchange, is acquiring FTX in a rescue deal.
Bitcoin, the largest token by market value, fell as much as 17 per cent on Tuesday to US$17,172, its lowest since November 2020.
The acquisition will reshape the more than US$1 trillion industry that is already dealing with a prolonged market downturn.

site_title: Inflation brings end to beloved 114-year-old Japanese candy
summary: A 114-year-old Japanese candy, "Sakuma's Drops", is set to go out of business in January due to rising production costs, a labour shortage, and a drop in sales. The iconic candy, known for its hard, colourful fruit drops in a red steel can, has been a beloved treat for generations. The Tokyo-based Sakumaseika company cited the economic pressures as the reason for its demise. The discontinuation has sparked a sense of mourning in Japan, with the candy even appearing in a hit anime film.

site_title: ST Engineering’s US marine venture shows a rich order book is not always profitable
summary: ST Engineering plans to divest its US marine business to Bollinger Shipyards Lockport for $15 million, marking a full exit from the marine business in the US. The subsidiaries incurred a combined pre-tax net loss of $256 million over five years. Despite the loss, analysts view the deal favorably, citing the challenges faced by the US marine business and the potential for higher earnings in the future. The divestment is part of ST Engineering's portfolio review and rationalisation to focus on strategic ventures and higher-yielding businesses.

images.alt_text: Tay Peck Gek
Ai Weiwei, Frank Stella and Jannis Kounellis.

site_title: Financial planning more important than ever as recession risks rise
summary: High-net-worth individuals are advised to plan ahead due to rising recession risks and aggressive monetary tightening by central banks to curb inflation. The US Federal Reserve has raised interest rates, and companies like Alphabet and Intel have reported weaker earnings. Despite this, some investment opportunities exist, particularly in cyclical equities and technology sectors. Experts recommend a "barbell" approach to portfolios, combining passive and income-generating assets. Insurance products, such as endowments and whole-life plans, can also provide protection coverage and investment returns. Wealth advisers can help HNW individuals navigate these complex strategies and build trust in their long-term relationships.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Lack of legacy and succession planning can hurt businesses, family harmony

site_title: Innovation – A key link in Singapore-Switzerland collaboration
summary: Switzerland and Singapore, both small countries with innovative economies, are strengthening their collaboration on innovation. The two nations have a long history of cooperation, with Switzerland being the birthplace of the World Wide Web and Singapore ranking seventh in the Global Innovation Index 2022. Their collaboration is evident in the inaugural Point Zero Forum, a platform for global leaders to drive the exchange of ideas and knowledge in Web3 and sustainable finance. The forum aims to raise confidence in the adoption of digital assets and green finance, with a focus on developing enabling technologies for companies to track their ESG commitments and combat greenwashing.

images.alt_text: (FILES) In this file photo taken on February 06, 2020 Some of the 1232 dipole magnets that bend the path of accelerated protons are pictured in the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) in a tunnel of the European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN), during maintenance works in Echenevex, France, near Geneva. - Ten years after it discovered the Higgs boson, the Large Hadron collider will start smashing protons together at unprecedented energy levels in its quest to reveal more secrets about how our universe works, on July 5, 2022. The world's largest and most powerful particle collider started back up in April after a three-year break for upgrades to prepare it for its third run. From Tuesday it will run around the clock for nearly four years at a record energy of 13.6 trillion electronvolts, the European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN) announced at a press briefing last week. (Photo by VALENTIN FLAURAUD / AFP)

site_title: Tata Motors sees profit rebound on Jaguar Land Rover boost, lower costs
summary: Tata Motors, India's third-largest carmaker, expects profit and cash flow to rebound in the second half due to healthy demand for Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) cars and lower domestic steel costs. The company has doubled its market share in passenger vehicles to 14% over two years. JLR's order book remains strong, driven by new models such as the Range Rover and Range Rover Sport. Despite a 17.6% jump in wholesale volumes, the company faces chip shortages. Tata Motors reported a consolidated net loss of 9.45 billion Indian rupees in the second quarter.

site_title: IBM launches its most powerful quantum computer with 433 qubits
