summary: IBM has launched its most powerful quantum computer, Osprey, with 433 qubits, exceeding three times the qubits of its Eagle processor. This marks a significant step towards speeding up certain calculations millions of times faster than the fastest supercomputers. IBM's director of research, Dario Gil, announced plans to launch a computer with over 1000 qubits and is working on a modular system, Quantum System Two, which will enable further scaling and connection of multiple systems to build "quantum-centric supercomputing" by the end of next year.

images.alt_text: IBM expects full-year revenue growth will exceed the company’s previous mid-single digit guidance while free cash flow will hit the estimate of US$10 billion.

site_title: S$2,000 psf benchmark for suburban private homes to persist: poll
summary: A poll by the National University of Singapore Real Estate found that most real estate senior executives in Singapore expect the benchmark price of S$2,000 per square foot for private homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) to persist over the next 1-2 years. The median price of new launches in the OCR has surged beyond S$2,000 psf, with 84.3% of new non-landed homes sold above this price. Despite elevated prices, respondents expect demand to remain robust due to buyers' willingness to pay for good locational attributes and limited supply of new launches.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim

Rising inflation or interest rates was recorded as a top potential risk factor that might adversely impact future market sentiment, according to a survey by the National University of Singapore's Institute of Real Estate and Urban Studies.

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: New Politburo Standing Committee members Xi Jinping and Li Qiang arrive to meet the media following the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China October 23, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo/File Photo
The Lentor Modern condominium is one of many new launches this year that commanded psf prices of above S$2,100.

Despite the rising rental prices, volumes for both the HDB and condo markets remain strong as “it is still a landlord’s market now”, said Christine Sun, Orange Tee & Tie’s senior vice president of research and analytics.

Prices of non-landed homes saw an increase of 4.4 per cent in Q3 after notching a 3.6 per cent increase in the previous quarter. By region, prices of non-landed homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) saw the biggest jump at 7.5 per cent, thanks to major launches during the quarter, such as AMO Residence, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok.

site_title: GFanz dropping its Race to Zero requirement for members a ‘reality check’
summary: The Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero (Gfanz) has dropped its Race to Zero requirement for members as a "reality check" exercise amid concerns of antitrust issues. The decision was made due to banks' desire to determine their own future and criteria, highlighting vulnerabilities in governance between the net-zero alliances and the Race to Zero campaign. Gfanz director Yuki Yasui stated that the change reflects an evolution in its approach, allowing members to independently decide whether to adopt the Race to Zero criteria.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

Former US vice-president Al Gore (in a 2018 photo) said in an interview before Climate Week in New York last week that net-zero commitments by bankers and investors are welcome, "but obviously they have to be followed up".

site_title: Germany blocks Chinese stake in two chipmakers over security concerns
summary: Germany's government blocked Chinese investments in two domestic semiconductor producers, Elmos and ERS Electronic, citing national security concerns and the risk of sensitive technological know-how flowing to Beijing. The move comes amid heightened sensitivity in relations between Berlin and Beijing, and as Germany seeks to balance access to the Chinese market with security concerns. Economy Minister Robert Habeck stated that protecting Germany's technological and economic sovereignty is a priority, while China's foreign ministry expressed disappointment and called for a fair and open environment for Chinese investment.

site_title: China’s reopening will be a major wildcard for Asean and global economies in 2023
summary: China's potential reopening in 2023 is a major wildcard for Asean and global economies, with economists predicting a boost in consumption and exports. A relaxation of strict policies and border controls could fan reopening tailwinds for China tourists returning to Asean countries, particularly Thailand, Vietnam, and Malaysia. This could cushion the fall in Asean's exports and improve bilateral trade balances. However, a recovery in China's import demand may also worsen global inflation pressures and force central banks to tighten.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on tight race for control of Congress
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, November 9, 2022, due to the uncertainty surrounding the outcome of the mid-term elections, which could lead to a divided Congress and hinder the passage of drastic policy changes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 156.36 points, or 0.47%, to 33,004.47, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Investors await the results of the elections, which could impact market sentiment and policy decisions.

site_title: Thousands march as Greeks strike over ‘suffocating’ inflation
summary: Thousands of Greeks marched in Athens, protesting rising inflation and demanding higher wages as the country experiences a 12% inflation rate, the highest in the eurozone. The strike, called by unions, comes amid a growing cost of living crisis across Europe. The General Confederation of Greek Workers union is demanding a minimum wage increase and restoration of collective labour law, citing "jungle-like conditions" in the labour market. Brief clashes broke out between protesters and riot police, disrupting ferry services and public transport.

site_title: India will need coal until 2040 and beyond
summary: India's coal minister, Pralhad Joshi, stated that coal will remain an essential source of energy in India until at least 2040 and possibly beyond. This contradicts global calls to phase out coal by 2040 due to climate concerns. India's reliance on coal is high, with it accounting for 51% of the country's primary energy requirement and 73% of power generation. The country's power crisis in April led to increased coal mining, and the government is now under pressure to finance a transition to cleaner energy sources.

images.alt_text: “The goal of US$100 billion per year of climate finance by 2020 and every year thereafter through till 2025 is yet to be achieved,” the India government said in a statement ahead of the COP27 event in Egypt, which begins on Nov 6.

site_title: Apac Realty posts 8.5% fall in 9M earnings to S$23.9 million
summary: Apac Realty reported a 8.5% decline in 9-month earnings to S$23.9 million, down from S$26.1 million in the previous year. Total revenue fell 3% to S$527.5 million, with a 4.8% drop in resale and rental brokerage revenue. New home brokerage revenue decreased 0.6%. The company's ERA regional master franchise rights held 40.1% market share of all residential transactions. Shares closed flat at S$0.565.

site_title: Zuckerberg says ‘sorry’ as Meta cuts more than 11,000 jobs
summary: Meta Platforms CEO Mark Zuckerberg announced the company will cut over 11,000 jobs, about 13% of its workforce, in its first major round of layoffs. Zuckerberg expressed regret and apologized to those impacted, stating he wants to take accountability for the decisions. The company also extended its hiring freeze through the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms chief executive officer Mark Zuckerberg in September outlined plans to reorganise teams and reduce headcount for the first time, following a sharp slowdown in growth at the parent of Facebook and Instagram.

site_title: Malaysia’s budget should stand if government re-elected: caretaker finance minister
summary: Malaysia's caretaker Finance Minister Zafrul Aziz expects the country's national budget for 2023 to remain largely unchanged if the incumbent government wins the upcoming general election on Nov 19. The budget, which was tabled on Oct 7, involved a government spending plan of RM372.3 billion and included several "goodies." Zafrul believes the budget will be "roughly the same" as it was developed with input from the ground and represents the needs of various sectors. The government is focused on improving tax collection efficiency and has made conservative projections, with fiscal room to maneuver in case of external shocks.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Malaysian ringgit has hit another new low of close to RM4.70 against the greenback, and RM3.30 against Singdollar on Friday (Oct 14) morning.

A police stands guard between supporters of The National Front coalition, Barisan Nasional, and The Alliance Of Hope, Pakatan Harapan, outside a nomination centre on nomination day in Bera, Pahang, Malaysia.

site_title: US mortgage rates rise to 7.14%, near highest level since 2001
summary: US mortgage rates rose to 7.14% in the week ended Nov 4, near the highest level since 2001, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. This increase is attributed to the Federal Reserve's monetary policy tightening to reduce inflation. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate surge is expected to further weaken housing demand, leading more homebuyers to seek adjustable-rate loans. The overall measure of mortgage applications slipped to a 22-year low, with refinancing activity at a 22-year low, indicating a deteriorating housing market.

site_title: US dollar finds footing as investors await midterm results; cryptos jittery
summary: The US dollar found stability near its weakest point in two months against the euro as investors awaited US midterm election results and inflation data. Cryptocurrencies fell sharply for a second day after FTX's stability issues, with Bitcoin reaching a two-year low of $17,114. Investors are waiting to see if Thursday's CPI figures will influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions, potentially affecting the US dollar's value.

site_title: OKP wins S$100.3 million LTA contract for commuter infrastructure
summary: OKP Holdings, a Singapore-based infrastructure and civil engineering company, has won a S$100.3 million contract from the Land Transport Authority (LTA) to design, submit, supervise, and construct covered linkways and cycling paths at new MRT stations along the Thomson-East Coast Line, Circle Line 6 extension, North East Line extension, and Downtown Line.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
LTA on Friday said the opening of TEL will increase the resilience of Singapore’s MRT lines by lessening the load on the North-South Line, which has segments running parallel to the TEL.

site_title: China's Guangzhou city brings back mass testing to fight worst Covid outbreak
summary: China's Guangzhou city has reinstated mass testing for millions of residents to combat its worst Covid-19 outbreak, with 2,637 new locally transmitted cases reported on November 8. The city's population of almost 19 million is divided into five districts that will undergo testing, amid a rebound in infections in several economically vital cities, including Beijing. Authorities aim to control the outbreak without imposing mass lockdowns, in line with President Xi Jinping's zero-Covid policy.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices rises in China have been muted, in stark contrast to most other countries, with the weak price rises driven by subdued demand amid an economic slowdown.
Many analysts have said they do not expect significant easing to begin until after China’s annual parliamentary session in March.

site_title: CLI to divest Penang’s Queensbay Mall to CapitaLand Malaysia Trust for RM990.5 million
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) is selling its 91.8% stake in Penang's Queensbay Mall to CapitaLand Malaysia Trust (CLMT) for RM990.5 million, representing a 3.8% premium to CLI's 2021 valuation. The sale is expected to yield proceeds of about RM987 million and an estimated gain of RM59.3 million.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Investment highlighted that 17 of its properties within listed funds - including 1 Science Park Drive (above) - have undergone asset enhancement initiatives or redevelopment amounting to around S$1 billion since the start of 2022.

site_title: UK’s Hunt may make more Britons pay top income tax rate
summary: UK Chancellor Jeremy Hunt is considering lowering the £150,000 threshold for the 45% higher income tax rate, aiming to raise an additional £50 billion through tax rises and spending cuts. This move aims to stabilize the UK's public finances, but Hunt faces the challenge of balancing market confidence with the risk of aggravating a recession and upsetting voters, as the Conservative Party lags behind in the polls. Hunt's package is set to include measures such as an expanded windfall tax and increased capital gains tax.

site_title: Britain's Next buys failed furniture retailer Made.com, 400 jobs axed
summary: British fashion retailer Next acquired the failed online furniture retailer Made.com for £3.4 million after Made.com collapsed into administration, resulting in approximately 400 job losses. The deal does not include staff, and the redundancies are expected to occur. Made.com ran out of cash due to a weaker economy deterring Britons from buying new furniture. The acquisition includes Made.com's brand, website, and intellectual property.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Made.com web site is seen on a smartphone in this illustration taken June 16, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Firms behind Indonesia’s high-speed rail seek another 16.1 trillion rupiah loan from China
summary: Indonesia's high-speed rail project, funded by China, is facing a budget overrun due to increased costs. The consortium is seeking an additional 16.1 trillion rupiah (S$1.44 billion) loan from China Development Bank to cover the estimated US$1.45 billion increase in costs. China has agreed to fund 75% of this through a bank loan, while the remaining cost will be covered by an increase in stakeholder capital. The project, initially valued at US$6 billion, is expected to be completed in June 2023 and is the most high-profile Belt and Road Initiative in Southeast Asia.

site_title: Temasek is engaging with FTX after potential Binance bailout
summary: Temasek, a Singapore state investor, is in talks with FTX, the world's third-largest crypto exchange, after FTX signed a non-binding letter of intent with rival Binance for a full acquisition. FTX faces a liquidity crunch and has frozen user withdrawals. Temasek, which invested in FTX's Series B and C funding rounds, is engaging with FTX as a shareholder. The talks come after FTX's founder, Sam Bankman-Fried, was removed from a scheduled speaking engagement due to potential solvency issues.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

After dumping its holdings of FTX’s native coin and triggering an exodus of users from the rival bourse, Changpeng Zhao's Binance, the world’s biggest cryptocurrency exchange, is acquiring FTX in a rescue deal.
Zhao (right) and Bankman-Fried have been trading barbs on Twitter in the past few months, feuding over issues ranging from lobbying US politicians to allegations of frontrunning trades.
While crypto might seem like a niche corner of finance, the saga between two of its top players has upended the crypto ecosystem and is likely to have far-reaching repercussions.
Bitcoin, the largest token by market value, fell as much as 17 per cent on Tuesday to US$17,172, its lowest since November 2020.
The acquisition will reshape the more than US$1 trillion industry that is already dealing with a prolonged market downturn.

site_title: PropNex Q3 net profit rises 21.9% to S$17.6 million on higher revenue
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a 21.9% increase in net profit for the third quarter, rising to S$17.6 million from S$14.4 million in the same period last year, driven by higher revenue of 10.2%. The company attributed the growth to a resilient market, with both private residential and HDB resale segments experiencing price gains. PropNex expects transaction volumes for private residential resale to remain muted, but projects a 9-10% increase in HDB resale prices for the year.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
The HDB resale price index and transaction volume climbed in Q4 2022, growing 2.6 per cent and 10.7 per cent quarter on quarter, respectively.

Prices of non-landed homes saw an increase of 4.4 per cent in Q3 after notching a 3.6 per cent increase in the previous quarter. By region, prices of non-landed homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) saw the biggest jump at 7.5 per cent, thanks to major launches during the quarter, such as AMO Residence, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok.

site_title: Riverstone posts 76.2% drop in Q3 earnings to RM63.5m
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a cleanroom and healthcare glove manufacturer, reported a 76.2% drop in Q3 earnings to RM63.5 million, down from RM266.4 million in the same period last year. Revenue dropped 58.6% to RM270 million, and gross profit decreased 74.5% to RM91.2 million. Despite the decline, the company's clean room segment continues to hold steady. Riverstone's executive chairman and CEO, Wong Teek Son, attributed the challenges to macroeconomic headwinds, including price competition, US dollar fluctuations, and volatile raw material prices.

images.alt_text: Mr Wong Teek Son, founder and CEO Riverstone Resources.

site_title: Israel’s Netanyahu inches closer to power with victory confirmed
summary: Benjamin Netanyahu's Likud party has won the highest percentage of the vote in Israel's elections, securing 32 seats in the 120-member parliament. This victory puts Netanyahu on track to form a right-wing coalition government, potentially complicating foreign relations. Netanyahu, 73, is expected to partner with Religious Zionism and ultra-Orthodox parties to return to office after less than 18 months in opposition. The right-wing coalition raises concerns about Netanyahu's stance on minority rights, particularly Arab-Israeli and Palestinian rights.

images.alt_text: Foreign Minister Penny Wong said the city’s status should be decided by Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.
Although the coalition led by Netanyahu would provide a stable government, it would nevertheless unsettle Israel’s constitutional framework and social fabric.

site_title: TikTok slashes ad sales target by US$2b after tech downturn
summary: TikTok has reduced its 2022 ad revenue target by approximately $2 billion, from $12 billion to $10 billion, due to a global downturn that's affecting internet giants. This move reflects a pullback in marketing spending worldwide as companies and consumers prepare for a potential recession. The revised target doesn't include smaller business segments like e-commerce. The decision is part of a broader trend of reduced marketing spending and comes as ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, has postponed plans for an initial public offering amid investor concerns.

images.alt_text: Instagram, acquired in 2012, built an advertising business that is a major revenue driver for Meta.

“As part of the annual strategic assessment activity and as a response to enhanced focus on our core business services, we closed the Mi Financial Services in March 2022,” the Xiaomi spokesperson said.

site_title: UK renewables windfall tax risks ‘disaster’ for wind investment
summary: UK offshore wind farm investment may be at risk if a severe windfall tax on renewable producers is imposed, according to Orsted A/S CEO Mads Nipper. A windfall tax could slow investment, with a £60 per megawatt hour cap being particularly concerning. Nipper suggests long-term contracts to sell power at fixed prices would be a better approach. The UK's growth of offshore wind is crucial for reducing dependence on imported gas and cutting carbon emissions, with Orsted's Hornsea Three project capable of powering over 3 million homes.

images.alt_text: Wind turbines at the London Array project, the world's largest consented wind farm, a partnership between Dong Energy A/S, E.ON AG and Abu Dhabi-based Masdar are seen in the Thames Estuary, U.K., on Wednesday, March 13, 2013. "London Array will soon be the largest operational offshore wind farm in the world," said Benj Sykes, head of Dong Energy's U.K. wind business. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore wants open supply chains as US levels China chip curbs
summary: Singapore Minister of Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan urged for "open, inclusive" tech supply chains to counteract economic bifurcation amid US restrictions on China's access to semiconductors. Balakrishnan warned that a lack of strategic trust would lead to a "mutually escalatory vicious downward spiral." He emphasized the need for a multilateral network for science, technology, and supply chains to prevent inflation, supply chain disruptions, and slower technological progress. Singapore aims to counterbalance US influence in the region, while China accused the US of politicizing technology and economic issues.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Semiconductor chips are seen on a circuit board of a computer in this illustration picture taken February 25, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Singapore stocks extend gains, tracking Wall St strength; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to close at 3,165.50 on November 9, tracking Wall Street's gains. Amid a quiet economic calendar, optimism over a potential US mid-term election gridlock drove gains. Data from China showed a 1.3% year-on-year decline in producer prices, pushing the index into negative territory. Key Asian markets fell, except for South Korea's Kospi, which climbed 1.1%. Data centre-focused Keppel DC Reit was the top performer, while Hongkong Land fell 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Tokyo was down 0.2 per cent at the break, while Hong Kong lost 0.1 per cent in morning trade, with Shanghai up 0.3 per cent.

site_title: EC World Reit Q3 DPU down 17.9% to S$0.01364
summary: EC World Reit's third-quarter distribution per unit (DPU) fell 17.9% to S$0.01364, due to a 5.5% decline in gross revenue to S$29.8 million. This was attributed to the depreciation of the renminbi, higher property expenses, and the discontinuance of contribution from Fu Zhuo Industrial. Despite this, EC World Reit's manager noted that the results are consistent with the improving stability in China during the quarter.

images.alt_text: Stage 1 properties of Bei Gang Logistics. The Reit is proposing to divest its indirect interest in the asset, along with Chongxian Port Logistics, to pare down its loans while also making a special distribution to unitholders.

site_title: After neck-and-neck election race, divided US government will be tonic for stock market
summary: The US stock market is expected to benefit from a divided government, with Republicans taking control of the House of Representatives and Democrats maintaining control of the Senate. This gridlock is seen as a positive for the market, allowing corporations to continue their plans without new laws and requirements. Economists attribute the recent bout of inflation to the Russia-led war in Ukraine, rather than President Joe Biden's stimulus policies. A narrow Republican victory could lead to a bounce in the stock market, with some analysts expecting a 10% increase in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

images.alt_text: In the wider Singapore market, gainers outnumbered losers 323 to 213, with 1.6 billion shares worth S$1.1 billion traded.
Democratic Governor Gretchen Whitmer (pink) was re-elected in the “blue wall” state of Michigan.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open
summary: European stocks fell at the start of trading on November 9, 2022, due to weak Chinese data. London's FTSE 100 index dropped 0.2% to 7,291.90 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices lost 0.3% and 0.1% respectively.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man wearing a protective face mask walks past the London Stock Exchange Group building in the City of London financial district, whilst British stocks tumble as investors fear that the coronavirus outbreak could stall the global economy, in London, Britain, March 9, 2020. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: COE tracker
summary: Luxury brands and used cars saw a surge in sales, defying the poor car market, which is the worst in 8 years. Tesla marked its formal entry into India with a launch event in Mumbai, while also planning to expand its robotaxi service to California and Arizona. Meanwhile, FedEx partnered with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries in commercial areas. In other news, London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for a £10 billion upgrade, and Japan's carmakers have cut export prices to the US to offset the impact of tariffs.

site_title: StarHub Q3 net profit falls 32% to S$27.4 million despite stronger revenue
summary: StarHub reported a 32% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$27.4 million for the third quarter, despite a 14.2% increase in total revenue to S$590.8 million. The decline was attributed to higher staff costs, marketing expenses, and occupancy costs. Revenue growth was driven by service revenue, which rose 15.5% year-on-year. The company's net profit for the nine-month period ending September 30, 2022, was down 18.4% to S$88.3 million.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Raphael Lim
StarHub Shop at Plaza Singapura.

site_title: Race for US Congress is tight, no Republican ‘red wave’
summary: US midterm elections have resulted in a mixed outcome, with Democrats performing better than expected, despite President Joe Biden's low public approval ratings. Republicans made modest gains, but failed to achieve a "red wave" victory. The outcome is unclear, with several key races still being counted, including the Senate in Arizona, Georgia, and Nevada. Control of Congress will determine the future of Biden's agenda, and a divided government could slow policy changes and lead to investigations into his administration.

images.alt_text: Supporters cheer as Florida Republican Governor Ron DeSantis speaks during an election night party after winning his race for reelection in Tampa, Florida, Nov 8, 2022.

site_title: Chinese iPhone plant still under strict Covid curbs despite lift of lockdown
summary: Foxconn, a Taiwanese contract manufacturer, has confirmed its massive Zhengzhou plant in central China will maintain "closed-loop operations" despite the lifting of a seven-day lockdown in the industrial park. The plant, which produces iPhones, will continue to isolate staff and operations under a system where workers live and work on-site, isolated from the wider world. The duration of this system is unclear.

site_title: Explainer: How Binance and FTX sent shockwaves through the crypto world
summary: Binance, the world's largest crypto exchange, has agreed to acquire FTX.com, a rival exchange led by Sam Bankman-Fried, in a deal that has sent shockwaves through the crypto world. The acquisition is non-binding, leaving uncertainty about the future of FTX and its users. The move has plunged token values, with FTT falling 72% and Bitcoin reaching its lowest level since 2020. The deal has significant implications for regulators, with potential implications for market dominance and the need for stricter guardrails in the unregulated crypto space. The outcome is unclear, with Binance potentially taking over FTX or walking away entirely.

images.alt_text: After dumping its holdings of FTX’s native coin and triggering an exodus of users from the rival bourse, Changpeng Zhao's Binance, the world’s biggest cryptocurrency exchange, is acquiring FTX in a rescue deal.

site_title: Germany’s Bosch partners with IBM in quantum computing
summary: Bosch, a German multinational company, has partnered with IBM in quantum computing to simulate materials for carbon-neutral powertrains. Bosch is investing 10 billion euros in digitalization and connectivity by 2025, with a focus on sustainability and mobility. The partnership aims to leverage quantum computing to find surrogates for precious metals and rare Earths within the next decade. Bosch CEO Stefan Hartung stated that the partnership will gain deeper insights into the power and applicability of quantum computing.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.84 points to close at 1,446.19 on Wednesday, November 9. The market saw a higher close despite a relatively low volume of 3.070 billion lots worth RM1.722 billion. Gainers narrowly outnumbered losers 425 to 404, indicating a slightly positive trend in the market.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority granted in-principle approval to Atome for a major payment institution license. Golden Energy and Resources plans to exit its thermal coal business and delist from the Singapore Exchange, offering shareholders cash or shares. Residential property rents rose in October, while condo volumes decreased. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 0.6% to close at 3,165.50, tracking a US Wall Street rally.

site_title: WP leaders acted in good faith in waiving AHTC tender, but not when it came to payments: Court of Appeal
summary: The Court of Appeal ruled that Workers' Party (WP) leaders acted in good faith when waiving the tender for a managing agent at Aljunied-Hougang Town Council (AHTC) after the 2011 General Election. However, they failed to address potential conflicts of interest and grossly neglected the payments process, leading to over S$23 million in improper payments. The court found that WP leaders, including Low Thia Khiang and Sylvia Lim, breached their duties of care and may still be liable for damages. The judgment allows part of the appeals brought by the WP leaders, with potential damages to be assessed at a later date.

site_title: Democrats win governors' races in three crucial 'blue wall' states
summary: Democrats won gubernatorial elections in Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin, defending against Republican-dominated state legislatures on issues such as abortion rights and fair elections. Democratic governors Gretchen Whitmer, Tony Evers, and Josh Shapiro were re-elected, while Republicans won governorships in Florida, Georgia, and Texas. The victories marked a significant shift in the "blue wall" states, which were crucial to President Joe Biden's 2020 victory over Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Supporters cheer as Florida Republican Governor Ron DeSantis speaks during an election night party after winning his race for reelection in Tampa, Florida, Nov 8, 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks finish lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on November 9, 2022, as the Hang Seng Index fell 1.20% to 16,358.52, following weak Chinese economic data and the watchful eyes of traders on US midterm election results. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.53% to 3,048.17. The losses were attributed to the uncertainty surrounding the Chinese economy and the ongoing US-China trade tensions.

site_title: Honda posts 16% rise in Q2 operating profit, missing estimates
summary: Honda Motor posted a 16% rise in Q2 operating profit to 231.2 billion yen, missing analyst estimates of 243.3 billion yen. The company attributed the gain to higher pricing and a weak yen. Honda raised its full-year operating profit forecast to 870 billion yen from 830 billion yen. The semiconductor shortage disrupted vehicle production, but the weak yen helped offset the impact. The company's forecast surpasses the average analyst estimate of 922.05 billion yen.

site_title: Venture builder Wavemaker Impact’s debut fund reaches US$13m at first close
summary: Wavemaker Impact's debut fund has reached US$13 million at its first close, exceeding its minimum target size of US$25 million. The climate-focused venture builder, which launched in 2021, plans to fund 12 new companies in the next two years. Its limited partners include Temasek's Pavilion Capital, JG Digital Equity Ventures, and family offices in Asia and Europe. The fund will support sustainability-focused businesses in South-east Asia, addressing land use, agriculture, mobility, industry, buildings, and energy.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Microsoft’s cloud sparks complaint to EU by Amazon-linked group
summary: A European cloud-company policy group, CISPE, has filed an antitrust complaint to the European Union, alleging Microsoft uses unfair licensing practices to lure regional customers to its cloud infrastructure. CISPE claims the changes Microsoft made to its software licensing terms are a "smokescreen" that failed to address concerns. Microsoft has defended its changes, stating they provide customers and cloud providers with more options. This is the fourth complaint targeting Microsoft, which has a US$69 billion takeover bid for Activision Blizzard pending EU review.

site_title: Republican advances in US will not derail global climate agenda
summary: US Republicans may gain control of Congress and potentially the White House, but the landmark Paris climate agreement remains resilient due to its flexible and bottom-up approach. Despite a climate-sceptic Republican president, the agreement retains significant global support and can withstand US withdrawal. Cities, states, and regions will play a critical role in climate action, with initiatives like the Subnational Climate Action Leadership Exchange (SCALE) supporting US cities to cut emissions. The Paris agreement's decentralised approach and existing climate measures worldwide demonstrate that a flexible framework can still drive climate action forward.

images.alt_text: The city skyline of Cairo beyond horse riders on the Giza pyramid complex in Giza, Egypt. Leaders around the world will gather in Sharm el-Sheikh for the annual UN Climate Change conference, known this year as COP27.
Guterres asked countries to agree to phase out the use of coal, one of the most carbon-intense fuels, by 2040 globally,

site_title: China sees signs of liquidity stress as PBOC faces maturity test
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) faces pressure to maintain liquidity amid signs of funding stress, with two key indicators of interbank borrowing costs reaching a three-month high. One-year interest-rate swaps are now at 2.05%, and the cost of issuing negotiable certificates of deposits has jumped to 2.12%. The PBOC must decide how to manage 1 trillion yuan of medium-term lending facility maturing on November 15, either by extending loans or lowering reserve requirements to free up cash, amid waning demand in the world's No. 2 economy.

site_title: Adidas cuts profit forecast after ending Yeezy partnership
summary: Adidas has cut its profit forecast for the third time, citing the end of its Yeezy partnership and disappointing sales. The company now expects low-single-digit revenue growth and a 2.5% operating margin, down from previous targets. The decision to end the partnership, following Kanye West's anti-Semitic remarks, is expected to account for half of Adidas' total profits. The company is also seeking to revive its fortunes amid declining sales in China and Western markets, with the World Cup soccer tournament expected to provide some relief.

site_title: Aviva reiterates share buyback plans as 9-month premiums rise
summary: Aviva, under pressure from activist investor Cevian Capital, reaffirmed plans for a share buyback program alongside its 2022 results, which reported a 10% rise in general insurance premiums to £7.2 billion. The company's solvency ratio is well above its target range, and its dividend guidance remains unchanged. Aviva's CEO, Amanda Blanc, stated that the company is on track to deliver its financial targets and trading momentum is building, despite turmoil in the UK government bond market. The size of the share buyback will be decided by the board at year-end.

site_title: Potty over ceramics
summary: A surge of pottery exhibitions and shows is taking place in Singapore in November, with over 200 potters showcasing their wares. The success of last year's inaugural Singapore Clay Festival has led to an increase in potters participating, driven by the therapeutic and sensuous experience of pottery.

site_title: Investors, juggling greed and fear, creep back into ‘uninvestable’ China markets
summary: Investors are increasingly jumping back into China markets, despite economists' expectations of a reopening only after March next year, when the political reshuffle is completed. Valuations of Hong Kong and Chinese stocks have hit historic lows, sparking speculation about China's relaxation of its zero-Covid policy. Investors have poured trillions of dollars into sectors expected to benefit from China's reopening, including pharmaceuticals, hotels, and tech. Chinese stocks have seen their best week in over seven years, with Shanghai-listed shares recording their highest weekly gain since July 2020.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
China’s Covid policy pivot is unlikely to be straightforward, creating volatility as traders pore over covert signs and policy tweaks.
According to the report, 434 of China’s 598 stock ETFs, or more than 70 per cent, saw net inflows during the month.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks ended lower on Wednesday, trimming earlier gains as investors retreated from previous rallies following the US midterm elections. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.56% to 27,716.43, while the Topix index lost 0.41% to 1,949.49.

site_title: China’s Comac secures 330 aircraft orders, boosts demand outlook at air show
summary: China's Comac secured 330 aircraft orders for its C919 and ARJ21 jets, boosting demand outlook at the Airshow China. The orders were signed by 7 leasing companies, with 300 C919s and 30 ARJ21s ordered. This brings the total C919 orders to 815, with China Eastern Airlines being the only customer to announce a firm delivery schedule. Comac raised its 20-year aircraft demand forecast to 9,284 new planes, higher than Boeing's forecast of 8,485.

images.alt_text: Visitors walk past a display of Chinese passenger jet C919, at an exhibition titled "Forging Ahead in the New Era" during an organised media tour ahead of the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, in Beijing, China October 12, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: Black Panther sequel receives rave reviews despite some complaints
summary: Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, the sequel to Disney's Black Panther, has received a 94% positive rating on Rotten Tomatoes, with critics praising its purpose and authenticity despite some complaints about its length. Director Ryan Coogler scrapped his original script after Chadwick Boseman's passing, and the film follows Queen Ramonda and others as they mourn the loss of King T'Challa. While some critics, like Robbie Collin, found the film a struggle, many others, including Comicbook.com's Aaron Perine, praised its standout storytelling and emotional impact.

images.alt_text: The number of people subscribing to Disney+ reached 164.2 million people, more than the 161 million estimated by Factset, a data company.
Black Panther, in which the late Chadwick Boseman played the king of the fictional African land of Wakanda, became a global hit and was hailed as a milestone for racial diversity in Hollywood.

site_title: China’s security agency in Hong Kong buys HK$508m  luxury villa
summary: China's national security agency in Hong Kong spent HK$508 million (S$98 million) on a luxury villa in the Beacon Hill district, setting a record for the most expensive house sold in the Kowloon district. The 666-square-meter mansion features five bedrooms, a garden, and panoramic views. The purchase is a rare glimpse into the opaque organization, established in 2020 following the imposition of a sweeping security law in Hong Kong.

site_title: Australian climate protesters glue themselves to Warhol print
summary: Climate protesters from the group "Stop Fossil Fuel Subsidies, Australia" glued their hands to the transparent covers of Andy Warhol's famous Campbell's Soup screen prints at the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra, highlighting the "danger of capitalism" and government failure to end taxpayer subsidies for fossil fuel companies. The protest, part of a global civil resistance network, comes after similar incidents targeting artworks worldwide, with no damage to the prints.

images.alt_text: “The Sower”, an 1888 painting by the Dutch artist depicting a farmer sowing his land under a dominating sun, was exhibited behind glass and undamaged, according to news reports.
The two-day sale in New York comes as experts say the super wealthy are viewing art as a safe investment this year amid a tumultuous global economy and Russia’s war in Ukraine.

site_title: FTX’s sudden unravelling may allow DeFi to grow
summary: Cryptocurrency exchange Binance, led by Changpeng Zhao, has acquired FTX in a rescue deal, following FTX's sudden unraveling. This move may allow decentralized finance (DeFi) to grow, as DeFi protocols will now seek legitimacy under CZ's stewardship. The acquisition may also lead to fresh chaos in the blockchain world, revealing new fault lines in the Digital Commodities Consumer Protection Act. The move could ultimately benefit DeFi, which was threatened by the proposed law aimed at regulating centralized intermediaries.

images.alt_text: The acquisition will reshape the more than US$1 trillion industry that is already dealing with a prolonged market downturn.

site_title: UK broadcaster ITV forecasts slightly lower ad revenue in 2022
summary: UK broadcaster ITV forecasts slightly lower ad revenue for 2022, expected to be down 1-1.5% from 2021. Economic uncertainty and weaker summer advertising contributed to the slowdown. However, the World Cup in November and December is expected to boost ad revenue. ITV chief executive Carolyn McCall remains optimistic about the company's operational momentum, despite the uncertainty, and highlights the upcoming launch of its ad-funded streaming platform ITVX.

site_title: Asia: Markets turn tepid after China factory data
summary: Asian markets experienced a tepid start on Wednesday, following gains on Wall Street, after China's factory gate prices fell for the first time in nearly two years. Despite a positive open in Tokyo and Hong Kong, markets declined after official data showed China's economy languishing under strict zero-Covid policies. Other Asian markets were mostly higher, with Taipei up 1.4% and Seoul gaining 1.1%. The decline was attributed to speculation over China's lockdown policies and inflation data due on Thursday.

site_title: COE premiums hit new highs as old car extensions put brakes on new supply
summary: COE premiums in Singapore have hit new highs as the number of old cars being extended instead of scrapped has led to a crunch in the supply of new certificates of ownership (COEs). The premium for larger cars and electric vehicles increased by 4.9% to record highs, while motorcycle COE premiums rose 3.0% to S$13,189. The shortage of COEs is due to a decline in the number of 10-year-old cars being extended, which typically follow four scenarios: extending for low COE prices, not extending for moderate to high COE prices, scrapping and selling, or scrapping and deregistering. Experts predict that COE prices will remain high due to the current supply-demand imbalance, but may drop in the event of a recession.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Wednesday on US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, driven by gains on Wall Street following the US midterm elections. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index rose 0.15%, or 41.56 points, to 27,913.67, while the Topix index added 0.05%. The rally was seen as a positive sign for investors, despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Building the next data centre hub in Asean
summary: Asean is poised to become the world's largest data centre market by 2024, with a projected value of US$28 billion. The region's fast-growing tech-savvy population and 5G rollout are driving demand for high-quality data centres. However, operators must balance economic growth with sustainability and security concerns, including reducing energy consumption and implementing secure cooling systems. Policymakers are regulating energy consumption, while data protection policies are being strengthened to protect against cyber threats. Asean's data centre growth story requires a reliable, adaptable, and advanced network infrastructure to support sustainable and secure data centre operations.

images.alt_text: Sinarmas Land and K2 Data Centres' first development, K2 Data Centre Jakarta 1 Campus will see the first phase come online in early 2024.
Keppel Data Centres and Shell plan to leverage on each other’s expertise to explore the commercial and technical practicalities of establishing a low-carbon energy hub.

site_title: About 40,000 businesses face GST rate hike for first time; Iras reminds all firms to update systems
summary: About 40% of Singapore's 100,000 GST-registered businesses will face a rate change for the first time when the Goods and Services Tax (GST) rises to 8% on January 1. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has reminded firms to update their systems and contracts to ensure compliance. This is the first rate hike since 2007, and most businesses have started preparing for the change.

images.alt_text: From 2010 to 2019, an average of S$200 million, or about 2 per cent of total GST collections, was refunded to tourists each year, says Senior Minister of State for Finance Chee Hong Tat.
Rows of restaurants and bars are pictured along Boat Quay in Singapore on October 20, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
Singapore launched its inaugural pavilion at the United Nations COP27 climate conference on Nov 6, 2022.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the eligibility criteria for international carbon credits will “minimally reference” the Corsia standards for now, given that the carbon market is nascent and growing.

site_title: Airbus has to deliver 205 jets in two months to reach 2022 goal
summary: Airbus must deliver 205 jets in two months to meet its 2022 goal, exceeding the September figure by five. The company booked 177 sales in October, including 60 A320neo-series planes ordered by British Airways owner IAG. Airbus faces production challenges due to parts and labor shortages, but is receiving a steady supply of engines to ramp up A320 production. The company aims to deliver 75 A320 jets per month by 2025.

images.alt_text: Airbus delivered 60 jets in October, up from 55 the previous month.

site_title: Musk sells US$3.95b of Tesla stock after buying Twitter
summary: Elon Musk sold US$3.95 billion of Tesla shares, 19.5 million shares, just days after acquiring Twitter. This marks his first disposals since August, amid concerns about the platform's financial stability. Musk's drastic moves at Twitter, including layoffs and cost cuts, have sparked worry among shareholders that he's spreading himself too thin. The move comes as Musk has also sold around US$36 billion worth of Tesla shares in the past year, with the stock down 53% from its peak.

images.alt_text: The Elon Musk-led electric-vehicle maker’s shares closed with a market valuation of US$604 billion on Tuesday.
Twitter's increased debt load means it will have annual interest payments approaching US$1.2 billion, up from below US$100 million in the pre-Musk era.
Elon Musk fired Twitter’s previous chief Parag Agrawal and other top company officials last week.

site_title: Residential property rents climb in October; condo volumes down: SRX, 99.co
summary: Residential property rents in Singapore rose in October, with condo rentals increasing 2.7% and HDB rents up 1.8% from the previous month. Condo volumes fell 8.7% due to a lack of supply, while HDB volumes rose 10.3%. Overall, condo rental prices grew 32.7% and HDB rentals 26.6% year-on-year. Experts attribute the growth to cooling measures and increasing demand for space, with landlords passing on costs to tenants.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
HDB flats in the Queenstown area and Management Development Institute of Singapore (MDIS) as viewed from Block 90 Tanglin Halt on May 27, 2021.

site_title: Golden Energy proposes break-up and delisting in deal that values company at S$2.8b
summary: Golden Energy & Resources (Gear) proposes a break-up and delisting deal, valuing the company at up to S$2.8 billion. The deal involves exiting its thermal coal business and distributing its 62.5% stake in Indonesia-listed Golden Energy Mines (Gems) to shareholders. They can choose between receiving 13,936 Gems shares or cash equivalent to S$6,855.81. The company aims to reduce its exposure to energy coal and shift to its metallurgical coal business and other non-coal ventures.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Golden Energy and Resources falls 27.2 per cent, or S$0.25, to pause at S$0.66 as at the midday trading break, representing its lowest trading level since Aug 30.
While robust coal demand and high prices are helping to prop up companies’ earnings now, some coal producers are already taking steps to diversify their business and revenue streams.

site_title: Atome gets MAS’ in-principle nod for major payment institution licence
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has granted in-principle approval to Atome, a "buy now, pay later" platform, to operate as a major payment institution (MPI). With the MPI licence, Atome will be allowed to perform regulated payment services such as account issuance, domestic and cross-border money transfers, and merchant acquisition services. This milestone marks a critical step for Atome, according to CEO David Chen, and will enable the platform to expand its services.

site_title: One of world’s priciest cities turbocharges affordable housing
summary: Paris aims to increase affordable housing to 40% by 2035, with 30% for low-income tenants and 10% for middle-income tenants. The city plans to use defunct buildings, such as offices and hotels, to build new public housing units. To achieve this, the city will refuse permission for new office complexes that don't reserve space for homes, and new residential projects will be required to include affordable units. The city has allocated a budget of 500 million euros to support the initiative, which aims to address the city's affordability crisis and prevent it from becoming unaffordable for all but the very prosperous.

images.alt_text: Critics have argued the investment sum was too small and that the policy could drive up property prices, crowding out local ownership.

site_title: China developers soar as state help fuels bets on market bottom
summary: Chinese property developers surged on Wednesday, with Country Garden Holdings and Cifi Holdings Group rising at least 31%, as the government expanded a financing support program to help private companies, including cash-strapped builders, meet debt obligations. The move, part of a broader effort to stabilize the sector, comes as the sector faces a debt crisis and unprecedented offshore debt defaults. Analysts say the gains are cautious, with BofA Securities warning that policy disappointments and physical-market sales recovery remain key factors in the sector's recovery.

images.alt_text: China's producer price index fell by 1.3 per cent on-year in October, according to the National Bureau of Statistics (NBS), pushing it into negative territory for the first time since December 2020.
The Legislation Law was introduced in 2000 and amended in 2015.

site_title: Australia: Mining, gold stocks push shares to a near two-month high
summary: Australian shares rose near a two-month high on November 9, driven by gains in gold and mining stocks, with iron ore prices rising on hopes of China easing Covid-19 restrictions. The benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index gained 0.6% to 6,999.3. Shares of Rio Tinto, BHP Group, and Fortescue Metals advanced between 2.1% and 3.1%. Gold stocks also rose, with Newcrest Mining and Northern Star Resources climbing 6.8% and 7%.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.5 per cent to 6,996.4 by 2343 GMT on Wednesday.

site_title: Why transition financing of coal plants is important, and how to stop its abuse: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority Managing Director Ravi Menon emphasizes the importance of transition financing for coal plants, requiring accurate carbon data, abatement reporting, and clear exit plans to prevent abuse. This is crucial for early retirement of coal plants, a top decarbonization strategy in Asia, and to move heavy emitters beyond their business-as-usual. Menon calls for financial institutions to hold each other accountable for their transition plans, with clean energy financing needing to equal fossil fuels by the end of this decade.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Rows of restaurants and bars are pictured along Boat Quay in Singapore on October 20, 2022. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened higher on Wednesday, up 2.23 points or 0.15% to 1443.58. Volume reached 231.04 million lots worth RM62.59 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 169 to 115, with no specific reason given for the increase.

site_title: Republicans favoured to win US House in close-fought midterm elections
summary: US Republicans are favored to win the US House of Representatives in the close-fought midterm elections, with Edison Research projecting they have flipped five Democratic seats, enough to capture a majority. However, the outcome is uncertain with over 200 House races still unreported. A narrow Republican majority would block Biden's legislative agenda and launch investigations into his administration and family. The US Senate remains too close to call, with pivotal races in Pennsylvania, Nevada, Georgia, and Arizona. High inflation and abortion rights were top voter concerns, with Democrats fearing a wipeout election and Republicans echoing false claims of widespread fraud.

images.alt_text: Supporters cheer as Florida Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis speaks during an election night party after winning his race for reelection in Tampa, Fla., on Tuesday, Nov. 8, 2022. (Scott McIntyre/The New York Times)

site_title: Top JPMorgan Asean fund has Indonesia, banks as 2023 picks
summary: JPMorgan Chase's top-performing Asean fund has chosen Indonesian stocks and South-east Asian banks as its 2023 picks, citing high commodity prices, economic reopening, and tourism revival. The fund's co-manager, Stacey Neo, likes banks with low loan-to-deposit ratios, such as PT Bank Central Asia, and electric vehicle-related stocks in Indonesia. Most South-east Asia economies are forecast to grow over 4% in 2023, driven by inflation and pandemic rebound. The fund has a positive outlook for the region, with returns expected to outperform the global market.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan plans to hire “many, many dozens if not more people,” Max Neukirchen, the firm’s global head of payments & commerce solutions, said in an interview.

site_title: Inside the ‘living hell’ of Cambodia’s scam operations
summary: Cambodia is plagued by a thriving scam operation, with thousands of victims forced to work online scams to line their captors' pockets. Lu, a Chinese builder, was lured to a compound in Sihanoukville with promises of a construction job, only to find himself subjected to 12-16 hour shifts scamming victims out of huge sums. He and hundreds of others were trafficked, beaten, and locked up, with many suffering physical and emotional trauma. Authorities have shut down casinos and cracked down on the operations, but the issue remains a significant problem in the country.

images.alt_text: The metaverse became a tech buzzword in 2021, with companies and investors betting that virtual world environments will grow in popularity and mark a new stage in the internet’s development.

“For almost ten years, the whereabouts of this massive chunk of missing Bitcoin had ballooned into an over US$3.3 billion mystery,” Damian Williams, US attorney for the Southern District of New York, said in a statement.

site_title: Australia: Shares jump on mining boost; NAB falls on bleak outlook
summary: Australian shares rose 0.5% to 6,996.4 on Wednesday, driven by gains in mining stocks, particularly iron ore, which surged on hopes of China easing COVID-19 curbs. Heavyweight miners like Rio Tinto and BHP Group jumped 2.2% and 1.4%, respectively. National Australia Bank slumped 2.9% after warning of slowing lending volume due to higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ends 0.4 per cent higher at 6,958.9.

site_title: Simon Cowell sells bonds backed by ‘Got Talent’ franchise
summary: Simon Cowell's entertainment company, Syco, has sold $125 million in bonds backed by the "Got Talent" franchise, marking the first securitization of its kind. The transaction, facilitated by White Oak Merchant Partners and Guggenheim Securities, allows Syco to finance its assets without selling the rights to the franchise. This deal could serve as a blueprint for other media property owners looking to borrow without selling their rights, according to Freddy Boom, head of structured finance at White Oak Merchant Partners.

images.alt_text: Simon Cowell is partnering with TikTok to give users access to new unnamed songs by famous producers through the service StemDrop

site_title: Gold steadies near 1-month peak ahead of US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained steady near a one-month high on Wednesday, ahead of US inflation data due later this week. Spot gold was 0.1% down at $1,709.80 per ounce, while US gold futures fell 0.1% to $1,714.10. The focus is on the US consumer price index report, which may influence the Federal Reserve's rate hike stance. Rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding gold, despite its inflation-hedging properties.

images.alt_text: Gold is considered a hedge against inflation, but rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: SoftBank buyback spree sparks speculation that Son plans buyout
summary: SoftBank Group has accelerated its share buybacks, purchasing 197.6 billion yen (S$1.9 billion) in 10 days, exceeding its full-year plan. This aggressive pace has sparked speculation that founder Masayoshi Son is preparing to take the company private. SoftBank is using asset sales to fund buybacks, while reducing investments. Analysts, including SMBC Nikko's Satoru Kikuchi, believe changes in company structure, including a management buyout, could be imminent.

images.alt_text: SoftBank laid off employees within its Vision Fund unit last month.

site_title: Local brands make fashion and design sustainable
summary: Singapore Fashion Council's newly-rebranded retail and incubation space, Design Orchard, supports local eco-friendly brands. Two selected brands, MYE and Chokmah, showcase sustainable fashion and homeware products. MYE's activewear is made from recycled plastic bottles, while Chokmah's products are crafted from jesmonite, a non-toxic, eco-friendly material. Both brands aim to reduce waste and promote sustainable practices in the fashion industry, with MYE already selling 70-80% of its first collection and Chokmah expanding its business to the Philippines and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
Joyce Orallo, owner of Chokmah, a business selling handcrafted homeware made from a sustainable material called jesmonite
Mai Takemori, sustainable activewear brand whose garments are made from recycled water bottles
Joyce Orallo, owner of Chokmah, a business selling handcrafted homeware made from a sustainable material called jesmonite
Mai Takemori, sustainable activewear brand whose garments are made from recycled water bottles

site_title: China producer price index falls for first time in nearly two years
summary: China's producer price index fell by 1.3% in October, marking the first decline in nearly two years and pushing it into negative territory. This is attributed to strict Covid controls and travel restrictions that have impacted domestic demand. Consumer prices rose 2.1% in October, slightly moderating from the previous month. The country's economy is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping with members of the new Politburo Standing Committee. President Xi's consolidation of power has led to a more defensive stance on Chinese equities.
The Legislation Law was introduced in 2000 and amended in 2015.

site_title: Japan Foods turn profitable in H1 on new halal segment
summary: Japan Foods Holdings has reported a net profit of S$2.3 million for the first six months of FY2023, reversing a net loss of S$1.6 million from the same period last year. Revenue grew 79% year-over-year to S$38 million, driven by the new halal segment and relaxed Covid-19 dining measures. Gross profit grew 80.9% to S$32.2 million, with a 0.9 percentage point increase in the gross profit margin. An interim dividend of 1 Singapore cent was declared, and shares closed up 1.2% on the news.

images.alt_text: Takahashi Kenichi, executive chairman and CEO of Japan Foods. The group on Thursday reported net profit of S$1.4 million for the first quarter ended Jun 30.

Japan Foods broke into the halal market with its Tokyo Shokudo ramen brand, which opened in Tampines Mall in November 2020. “How to make a good taste, same as non-halal brands, is our most challenging point,” said chief executive and chairman Kenichi Takahashi.

site_title: Seoul: Shares on four-day rally as stronger won lifts blue chips
summary: South Korean stocks rose 1.06% on Wednesday, November 9, 2022, with the Kospi benchmark closing at 2,424.41. A firmer won and expectations of a Republican win in US midterm elections contributed to the gains. Technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rose 0.32% and 1.71%, respectively, while LG Energy Solution advanced 1.87%. This marked the fourth consecutive day of gains for the Kospi.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Currency dealers talk in front of an electronic board showing the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) at a dealing room of a bank in Seoul, South Korea, March 13, 2020.   REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Automakers, foreign governments seek changes to US EV tax rules
summary: Automakers and foreign governments are seeking changes to US electric vehicle (EV) tax rules, which make vehicles assembled outside North America ineligible for credits. Hyundai, South Korea, Japan, Brazil, and the European Union have criticized the overhaul, citing economic and global subsidy concerns. Automakers like VinFast, Toyota, and Tesla are requesting flexibility in the implementation of the new law to ensure they can continue investing in US production. The US Treasury is considering input from automakers and others as it implements the law, which includes rising sourcing requirements for battery minerals and bars content from "foreign entities of concern".

images.alt_text: Japan joins South Korea and European countries that have already expressed concerns about the legislation.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.6% to 16,650.92, driven by gains on Wall Street. Investors are speculating on the future of China's zero-Covid policy, which could impact trade volatility. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw slight gains, but the Shenzhen Composite Index remained flat. The gains come amid a rally on US stocks, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Asian Healthcare Specialists offer gets sufficient acceptances to turn unconditional
summary: Labrador Park's offer to take Asian Healthcare Specialists private has secured 90.15% shareholder acceptances, exceeding the minimum requirement. However, the offer remains conditional as the group has not secured requisite third-party consents. The closing date for the offer has been extended to 5:30 pm on Dec 15. Despite this, the group clarified that the offer has not become unconditional in all respects.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
There were 27 biotech venture investments worth US$530.1 million in South-east Asia this year, as at Aug 25, according to Preqin.
Asian Healthcare Specialists H2 profit up 56.4 per cent to S$2.45m

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at the opening on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,152.61 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 56 to 29 after 35 million securities worth S$30.4 million changed hands. Shares of The Place Holdings and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust were among the top gainers, while Golden Energy and Resources rose 19.4% after announcing plans to delist. The rally follows Wall Street gains ahead of key economic data, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 1% and the S&P 500 advancing 0.6%.

images.alt_text: United Hampshire US Reit posts an 8.1 per cent rise in distributable income of US$8.3 million for the quarter ended Sep 30, boosted by contributions from a Pennsylvania shopping centre it acquired in July (above).

site_title: National Australia Bank’s profit boosted by rising interest rates
summary: National Australia Bank's profit rose to A$7.10 billion, surpassing analyst estimates, due to higher interest rates boosting business lending. The bank's key business and private banking unit saw a 22% surge, while corporate and institutional banking grew 35%. Despite rising interest rates, bank CEO Ross McEwan warned that home owners could face more stress next year when fixed-rate mortgages mature. The bank maintained its focus on strong balance sheet settings and will pay a final dividend of 78 Australian cents.

images.alt_text: Australia’s biggest banks, including Westpac, are reaping the rewards of higher interest rates, part of a global trend of higher borrowing costs that’s bolstered lending profitability.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust’s YTD distributable income in line with forecasts
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust reported distributable income of S$29.8 million for the first nine months of 2022, meeting its forecast. Despite lower-than-expected net property income (NPI) of S$41.8 million due to foreign exchange volatility, the trust met its forecast distributable income. Gross revenue was 5.8% lower than forecast, but finance expenses decreased 18.6% due to lower interest rates and a weaker yen. The trust's overall portfolio occupancy rate remains at 98.6%, with all but one property fully occupied, and its weighted average lease expiry is 6.6 years.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
japan, flag, woods
A weaker yen against the Singapore dollar led net property income and gross revenue to fall short of the real estate investment trust’s pro-rated forecasts from the prospectus.
The Reit's financials for the quarter were in line with the pro-rated forecasts disclosed in its initial public offering prospectus, the manager said on Thursday.

site_title: UK to remain ‘bedrock’ of Nato: Sunak
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak reaffirmed the UK's commitment to NATO, stating the country will continue to play a vital role for generations ahead of a visit by Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg. The talks will focus on UK support for Ukraine following Russia's invasion and the alliance's future.

images.alt_text: Former Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak is widely seen by the Conservative party membership as being the right man for the times given the economic crisis facing the nation.

Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg  said he had spoken with Pentagon chief Lloyd Austin and Britain’s Defence Secretary Ben Wallace “about Russia’s false claim that Ukraine is preparing to use a dirty bomb on its own territory.”

Russian President Vladimir Putin speaking to China's President Xi Jinping during the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO) leaders' summit in Samarkand on September 16, 2022.. Both leaders are expected to attend the upcoming G20 summit in Bali.

site_title: FedEx parks planes as weak demand prompts cost-cutting steps
summary: FedEx has reduced flight frequencies and parked some planes to cut costs due to weak demand for package delivery. The company halted 23 domestic and 9 international flights, reduced sorting points, and consolidated loads. This move is in response to a shift in spending towards services, reversing a pandemic trend that hurt business in Asia. FedEx aims to reduce costs by up to $2.7 billion and will temporarily park aircraft, eliminate older planes, and maintain pricing power despite the cuts.

images.alt_text: Some analysts said FedEx had enough room to cut costs and pricing power was holding up, for now.

site_title: Twitter to introduce ‘Official’ label for some verified accounts
summary: Twitter will introduce an "Official" label for select verified accounts, including major media outlets and governments, when it launches its new premium subscription product. The label, which is not available for purchase, will differentiate these accounts from others that may have paid for blue check marks. However, the lack of ID verification raises concerns about impersonation. Twitter has pushed for the label after internal concerns about government officials unwilling to pay for verified check marks, and the move comes amid existing issues with fake accounts for government officials globally.

images.alt_text: “Twitter needs to become by far the most accurate source of information about the world. That is our mission,” Musk said on Sunday (Nov 6).
Tesla shares have been struggling for the most part this year, swept up in the broader risk-off market trend.
Twitter accounts with millions of followers have been suspended after their user name was changed to Elon Musk.
Twitter's increased debt load means it will have annual interest payments approaching US$1.2 billion, up from below US$100 million in the pre-Musk era.

site_title: Japan manufacturers’ mood down amid weak yen, global risks: Reuters Tankan
summary: Japan's manufacturing optimism plummeted to a 22-month low in November, with 247 firms responding to a Reuters poll citing concerns over the yen's weakness driving up import costs and prolonged chip shortages. The service sector, however, saw a three-year high in optimism. The mixed results pose a challenge for policymakers trying to sustain Japan's post-Covid recovery, which economists estimate slowed sharply in the third quarter due to the yen's fall and rising global risks.

images.alt_text: Some Bank of Japan policymakers are slowly becoming more open to the possibility of an eventual withdrawal of the radical monetary stimulus deployed by Governor Haruhiko Kuroda nearly a decade ago, a summary of opinions showed on Tuesday.

This photo taken on September 17, 2022 shows people shopping at a clothing store in the Motomachi shopping street in Yokohama, Kanagawa prefecture, south of Tokyo. - Inflation in Japan hit 2.8 percent in August, the highest level since 2014, government data showed on September 20, 2022 as soaring energy prices bite. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Tesla loses valuation race to Berkshire as growth stocks sputter
summary: Tesla's market valuation fell to $604 billion, surpassing Berkshire Hathaway's $645 billion, after a $360 billion decline in the electric-vehicle maker's shares. The shift is attributed to rising interest rates and the decline of growth stocks. Industrial companies, like Berkshire, are outperforming, with a 2% drop for Tesla compared to a 46% decline. The US stock market is witnessing the end of an era for richly priced tech companies, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average outperforming the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100.

images.alt_text: Tesla said it had identified 314 vehicle alerts for this condition among US vehicles that may be related to the recall but said it is unaware of any injuries or deaths related to this condition.

site_title: Salesforce cuts hundreds of sales workers on ‘accountability’
summary: Salesforce has cut hundreds of sales workers as it seeks to improve profitability and achieve a 25% profit margin target by 2026. The company has almost tripled its workforce in the past five years through acquisitions, but has pivoted to focus on profit margin growth. Salesforce cited "accountability" as the reason for the layoffs, with the company supporting departing employees through their transition. The move comes as the company faces slowing demand for its software products in a choppy economy.

images.alt_text: The Salesforce Tower in San Francisco.Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

site_title: Disney profit misses estimates as streaming costs rise, ad sales soften
summary: Walt Disney Co. reported sales and profit below Wall Street expectations, missing estimates by $1 billion and 21 cents per share. Despite beating expectations for streaming subscriber additions, with 12.1 million new customers for Disney+, overall subscribers rose to almost 236 million. Advertising revenue and streaming TV losses weighed on the company's performance.

images.alt_text: The number of people subscribing to Disney+ reached 164.2 million people, more than the 161 million estimated by Factset, a data company.

site_title: Europe: Stocks scale 8-week high with all eyes on US midterms
summary: European stocks reached an 8-week high, closing up 0.8% on Tuesday, driven by optimism over a market-friendly US midterm election outcome and strong quarterly sales from Pandora. Analysts expect a Republican victory, which would lead to a split government and potentially boost business-friendly policies. Investors also await US consumer prices data to gauge the Federal Reserve's inflation-fighting efforts.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index slid 0.5 per cent to 7,257.48 points, compared with the closing level on Monday.

site_title: Democrats shouldn’t be shocked by a miserable midterm
summary: Democrats are likely to lose the House, Senate, and competitive races in the midterm elections, a common outcome for a president's party. Despite passing large spending packages, including COVID relief and infrastructure bills, voters cited soaring prices as their top concern. Democrats failed to address crime and inflation effectively, and their messaging was criticized as out of touch. Republicans, meanwhile, focused on culture war issues, but now face a responsibility to advance an actual agenda. A pragmatic approach to bipartisan negotiations could lead to common ground on issues like crime, immigration, and energy independence.

images.alt_text: Up for grabs are all 435 House seats, a third of the 100 Senate seats, and a slew of state-level posts.

site_title: Fortune Pink diamond sells for more than US$28.5m
summary: The Fortune Pink diamond, a 18.18-carat pear-shaped "fancy vivid pink" diamond, sold for over US$28.5 million at Christie's auction house in Geneva. The diamond, mined in Brazil, is the largest of its kind ever sold under the hammer, surpassing previous records. The buyer, a private Asian customer, paid a hammer price of 24.5 million Swiss francs, with a total sale price of 28,436,500 Swiss francs, including buyer's premium.

images.alt_text: Mariah Carey has released “Happy Butterfly” collection with Chopard, which includes 12 pieces featuring a butterfly crafted in “ethical rose and white gold”.
Pink diamonds are the rarest of the precious gems and the most in-demand on the global market.
Cartier pearl and diamond lady’s wristwatch

site_title: CZ’s Binance to buy rival FTX after Sam Bankman-Fried faces liquidity crunch
summary: Binance's billionaire CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao has agreed to acquire FTX.com, a troubled crypto exchange led by Sam Bankman-Fried, after a liquidity crunch. The deal comes after a bitter feud between the two men, with Zhao undermining FTX's finances and sparking a user exodus. The acquisition is a significant move in the US$1 trillion crypto industry, which is already dealing with a prolonged market downturn. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, and the takeover is expected to reshape the industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies Bitcoin, Ethereum, DogeCoin, Ripple, Litecoin are placed on PC motherboard in this illustration taken, June 29, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Zhao (right) and Bankman-Fried have been trading barbs on Twitter in the past few months, feuding over issues ranging from lobbying US politicians to allegations of frontrunning trades.
Changpeng Zhao, CEO of Binance, says: "We want to be the bridge between crypto and the traditional, financial world."

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit Q3 distributable income up 8.1% to US$8.3m
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported an 8.1% increase in distributable income to US$8.3 million for the third quarter, driven by contributions from the newly-acquired Upland Square Shopping Center and rising self-storage rents. Gross revenue rose 24.7% and net property income increased 15.2% compared to the same period last year. The Reit's financial performance was partially offset by higher interest costs and the absence of top-ups.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Publix, a grocery-anchored tenant at UHREIT's Colonial Square property in Richmond, Virginia
Robert Schmitt, CEO of UHREIT's manager.
Robert Schmitt, Chief Executive Officer, United Hampshire US Real Estate Investment Trust.

site_title: Meta to begin widespread job cuts on Wednesday morning
summary: Meta Platforms, the parent company of Facebook, will begin widespread job cuts on Wednesday, November 9, as part of a plan to reduce costs following disappointing earnings and revenue decline. The cuts, announced by CEO Mark Zuckerberg in a call to executives, come after he acknowledged "missteps" by the company. Employees affected will be informed starting Wednesday morning, with a spokesperson for Meta declining to comment on the matter. The job cuts are part of Meta's efforts to slash expenses and restructure teams.

images.alt_text: Meta Platforms chief executive officer Mark Zuckerberg in September outlined plans to reorganise teams and reduce headcount for the first time, following a sharp slowdown in growth at the parent of Facebook and Instagram.
Earlier on Friday, Musk said Twitter had experienced “a massive drop in revenue”.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UHReit, Golden Energy, Daiwa House Logistics Trust, Prime US Reit, First Reit
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several companies reported financial updates, including United Hampshire US Reit, which saw an 8.1% rise in distributable income, while Daiwa House Logistics Trust and Prime US Reit reported in-line forecasts.
