First Reit's distributable income rose 23.7% year-over-year, and Japan Foods posted a net profit of S$2.3 million. In other news, Golden Energy and Resources will go private, and CSE Global is acquiring a radio-communications business for NZ$25 million. Shares of these companies and others fluctuated on Tuesday, with some closing flat or down.

images.alt_text: In the wider Singapore market, losers outnumbered gainers 288 to 220 with 1.65 billion shares worth S$1.11 billion changing hands.

site_title: Disney+ gains 12 million subscribers but losses accumulate
summary: Disney+ added 12 million subscribers in the July-September period, reaching 164.2 million users, exceeding analyst estimates. However, the company's streaming services, including Disney+, ESPN+, and Hulu, reported a year-to-year operating loss of $1.47 billion. Despite this, CEO Bob Chapek expects the streaming business to decline its peak operating losses and become profitable by 2024, with upcoming releases like "Black Panther: Wakanda Forever" and "Avatar: The Way of Water" expected to fuel subscription growth.

images.alt_text: Videos circulating on China’s Weibo platform on Monday (Oct 31) showed people rushing to the park’s gates, which were already locked.
The first game EA is making is based on Iron Man, a billionaire inventor and superhero who was the subject of one of the first hit Marvel movies, it announced last week.

site_title: China says committed to climate fight at UN summit
summary: China's top climate envoy, Xie Zhenhua, assured the UN COP27 summit that his country will continue to fight against global warming, despite a recent suspension of climate cooperation with the US. China has been actively responding to climate change, but urges developed countries to take the lead in scaling up emission reduction targets and achieving carbon neutrality ahead of schedule. Xie emphasized the need for multilateralism, solidarity, and cooperation to address climate change, and China's determination to participate in global climate governance remains unchanged.

images.alt_text: China's President Xi Jinping with members of the new Politburo Standing Committee. President Xi's consolidation of power has led to a more defensive stance on Chinese equities.

Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu said the eligibility criteria for international carbon credits will “minimally reference” the Corsia standards for now, given that the carbon market is nascent and growing.

FILE PHOTO: Smoke and steam billows from the coal-fired power plant owned by Indonesia Power, next to an area for Java 9 and 10 Coal-Fired Steam Power Plant Project in Suralaya, Banten province, Indonesia, July 11, 2020. Picture taken July 11, 2020. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: Cryptocurrencies plunge as doubts about FTX-Binance deal grow
summary: Cryptocurrencies plummeted on Tuesday, with Bitcoin falling 17% to its lowest since November 2020 at $17,172. The decline was linked to concerns over a potential takeover of FTX.com by Binance, with Binance CEO Changpeng "CZ" Zhao announcing a nonbinding letter of intent to acquire the rival exchange. Other digital coins, such as Ether, Polkadot, and Dogecoin, also dropped significantly, with some falling over 28%. The market downturn renewed trader concerns about trouble brewing in the industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Souvenir tokens representing cryptocurrency networks Bitcoin, Ethereum, Dogecoin and Ripple plunge into water in this illustration taken May 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Providing hospital-level care at home in a pandemic, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A new initiative aims to improve global maritime communication by establishing a standardized system of ship-to-ship communication. The project, developed by the International Maritime Organization (IMO), will create a single, universal language for ships to exchange critical information. The system will facilitate smoother navigation, reduce congestion, and enhance safety. The new protocol is expected to be implemented globally, benefiting over 90% of the world's shipping fleet. The initiative is seen as a major step forward in modernizing maritime communication, reducing the risk of misunderstandings and improving overall efficiency in the industry.

site_title: Shanghai bourse kicks off week-long conference to woo global investors
summary: The Shanghai Stock Exchange (SSE) launched a week-long global conference to promote China's capital markets, attracting Chinese regulators, global banks, and asset managers. The conference, which runs from November 9-16, focuses on capital market deregulation, economic outlook, and green finance. Senior executives from 100 Shanghai-listed companies will also participate in virtual face-to-face communications. The event aims to reassure global investors after China's policy direction raised concerns following the Communist Party Congress.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng surged 5.3 per cent and notched its biggest weekly gain in 11 years while the Shanghai Composite rose 2.4 per cent for a 5.3 per cent weekly gain, the largest in more than two years.

site_title: Citigroup, Barclays join rivals in cutting investment-banking jobs
summary: Major banks Citigroup and Barclays have started cutting investment-banking jobs, joining other banks in responding to a 64% decline in third-quarter fees at Citigroup and a 45% drop at Barclays. The job cuts, expected to total around 200 at Barclays, follow similar moves by Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs. The decline in investment banking revenue is attributed to the volatility in capital markets and asset management, with US banks particularly affected. This marks a reversal for Citigroup, which had been adding talent to boost its position in certain sectors.

images.alt_text: Citi added US$370 million to its loan-loss reserves in the latest quarter, compared with a reserve release of US$1.16 billion a year earlier.
C S Venkatakrishnan, CEO of Barclays, says: “We aim to hire more than 1,000 more people in coming weeks to improve that capacity.”

site_title: Singapore key to Shein’s South-east Asia ambition, says Shein’s Singapore head
summary: Shein, a Chinese fashion retailer, has established a significant presence in Singapore, with its office serving as the global headquarters and a base for tapping into South-east Asian markets. The company is hiring for key corporate functions and has tapped into social media influencers to reach its target market of young women. Shein's business model relies on technology and data analytics to optimize its supply chain management system, allowing for fast and efficient delivery of goods. Despite facing challenges such as worker exploitation in China and a declining valuation, Shein remains committed to fair labor practices and is focused on meeting customer demands in a challenging economic climate.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Leonard Lin, country general manager, Singapore, Shein

site_title: US: Stocks rise for third straight day
summary: US stocks rose for the third straight day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 1.0% to 33,160.83. The gains were driven by anticipation of gridlock in Washington, seen as reducing political uncertainty and potential tax hikes. The S&P 500 rose 0.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.5%. Individual companies saw mixed results, with Lyft falling 22.9% and DuPont jumping 7.3% after reporting better-than-expected results.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 107.56 points, or 0.33 per cent, at the open to 32,934.56.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher as voting in midterm election begins
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday as voting began in the midterm election, with investors hoping for a gridlock that could prevent radical policy changes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 107.56 points, or 0.33%, to 32,934.56. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also opened higher, with gains of 10.22 and 47.01 points, respectively. The midterms will determine control of Congress, with investors anticipating a more stable market environment.

site_title: What Malaysia’s young opposition leaders want: A government with integrity, courage
summary: Malaysia's young opposition leaders, including Syed Saddiq Syed Abdul Rahman and Anthony Loke, are campaigning for a government with integrity and courage in the upcoming 15th general election. The election, which began on November 5, features 945 candidates competing for 222 parliament seats. The opposition parties aim to move away from corruption and form a better government, which would lead to sustainable growth. Leaders like Nurul Izzah Anwar emphasize the need for a change, stating that Malaysia was "salvaged" from a kleptocratic scandal in 2018.

images.alt_text: A police stands guard between supporters of The National Front coalition, Barisan Nasional, and The Alliance Of Hope, Pakatan Harapan, outside a nomination centre on nomination day in Bera, Pahang, Malaysia.

site_title: Building the metaverse we want for SE Asia
summary: Southeast Asia is poised to shape the metaverse, but rapid growth must prioritize accessibility, inclusivity, and community. The region's potential for the metaverse is hindered by high barriers to entry, including expensive VR headsets and crypto wallets. To address this, developers should focus on low-cost VR hardware, mobile and low-bandwidth channels, and designing for those without credit cards. The metaverse must also prioritize societal benefits, such as education and economic opportunities, to entice participation from everyone. Governance and community standards are also crucial to prevent the metaverse's pitfalls, including exorbitant virtual land prices and non-participatory jobs.

images.alt_text: The metaverse became a tech buzzword in 2021, with companies and investors betting that virtual world environments will grow in popularity and mark a new stage in the internet’s development.
The performance of the metaverse funds shows the risk of piling in to an unproven industry regardless of the price you pay.

site_title: CSE Global to acquire radio-communications business for S$20.4m
summary: CSE Global to acquire radio-communications business Logic Wireless for S$20.4m. The acquisition, valued at NZ$25m, will expand CSE Global's radio-communication business and solutions to customers in NZ, Australia, and the UK. The company will fund the consideration using proceeds from a rights issue and banking facilities. Regulatory approvals are required for the transaction, which is expected to be completed subject to conditions.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Lim Boon Kheng, CSE Global’s managing director, said supply chain disruptions had affected the group’s operations in H1.

site_title: ‘Make my voice heard’: voters line up across United States
summary: Voters across the United States cast their ballots in the midterm elections, with millions expressing diverse concerns and exercising their right to democracy. Key issues included control of the US Congress, abortion rights, and the toxic political climate. Voters cited a sense of civic duty, anger over inflation and high crime, and a desire to send a message to Washington. The choices of voters will decide the control of various offices, with many believing that their voices will be heard and democracy will be strengthened.

images.alt_text: Former US President Barack Obama and US President Joe Biden participate in a rally in support of Democratic US Senate candidate John Fetterman in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, on Nov 5, 2022.

Republicans have made the economy their No 1 issue, and accuse President Biden and Democrats of fuelling inflation with major spending packages and then ignoring the economic plight of American families faced with soaring energy and food prices.

Congressman Lee Zeldin, Republican candidate for governor of New York (left) and New York Governor Kathy Hochul (right). Few expected New York to figure among the political battlegrounds ahead of Tuesday's crucial vote, but Democrats are scrambling as a Trump-backer gains substantial ground statewide and pivotal races narrow.
Up for grabs are all 435 House seats, a third of the 100 Senate seats, and a slew of state-level posts.
In poll after poll, voters cited soaring prices as their top concern.

site_title: Airbus speeds deliveries, books key Chinese jet order
summary: Airbus accelerated deliveries in October, reaching 497 airplanes for the year, exceeding the target of 495 after excluding two cancelled deliveries. The company delivered 60 jets, up from 55 in the previous month, and received 177 new orders, including an expanded order from British Airways owner IAG for 59 aircraft. Airbus aims to reach 700 deliveries in 2022, despite global supply chain issues.

images.alt_text: Shares tumbled 4 per cent after the results as cost overruns in Boeing’s defence, space and security segment have hobbled a recovery for the company attempting to come out of successive crises by cashing in on rising air travel demand.
Airbus' quarterly revenues rose 27 per cent to 13.31 billion euros.
Comac’s C919, the recently certified homegrown rival to the popular Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX narrowbody families, was in the show’s flying display for the first time on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore Airlines resumes codeshare flights with Virgin Australia, with plans to expand
summary: Singapore Airlines has resumed codeshare flights with Virgin Australia on 64 routes covering 31 destinations, following a pre-pandemic operations model. The partnership allows customers to book directly on virginaustalia.com for travel between Australia, Asia, Africa, Europe, and beyond. Virgin Australia will codeshare on 42 destinations covering 23 countries, with plans to expand to more destinations in the coming weeks, subject to regulatory approval. The partnership, formed in 2011, aims to increase connectivity and competitiveness in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
SIA on Friday swung to a second-quarter profit and declared its first dividend in three years as international borders reopened and travel demand rebounded.
Rising competition will pose a significant challenge to the airline, said CGS-CIMB analyst Raymond Yap.

site_title: To restore confidence in Sats, its board and management should buy the stock
summary: SATS' board and management should buy a significant amount of stock to restore confidence in the company, following a 30% decline in shares since the acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services. The proposed rights issue, which could fund the purchase, has raised concerns among investors. By personally investing, the board and management can demonstrate their belief in the company's value and potentially quell investor fears ahead of the Sias-SATS Hybrid Dialogue.

images.alt_text: Ben Paul
SATS logo on 15 December 2016.

site_title: Tackling Asean’s food crises
summary: Southeast Asian policymakers gather for the Asean summit amid growing concerns over soaring food prices and intense supply shortages. Russia's suspension of grain exports has led to cereal price surges, exacerbating an already dire situation in the region. Inflation rates are high, with Laos experiencing a 37% spike and the Philippines seeing a 9.4% increase in food prices. Food security is a key priority for Indonesia's Asean chairmanship, and policymakers must choose the right economic recipe to address the issue, which affects household spending and the health of the agri-food industry.

images.alt_text: South-east Asia's favourable climate and fertile soil make it a major crop grower. The region is home to key producers of  palm oil, rice and dried beans.
Indonesia will use around 500 electric cars as official vehicles during the G20 Summit in Bali on Nov 15-16, 2022.
Prices for meat, sugar, vegetable oils and dairy fell, and food inflation is slowing down in nations from Indonesia to Paraguay.

Moscow suspended its participation in the Black Sea deal on Saturday, effectively cutting shipments from Ukraine, one of the world’s top grain exporters, in response to what it called a major Ukrainian drone attack earlier in the day on its fleet near the port of Sevastopol in Russian-annexed Crimea.

site_title: Terra co-founder Do Kwon faces S$79.8m lawsuit in Singapore after crypto crash
summary: Terra co-founder Do Kwon faces a S$79.8 million lawsuit in Singapore over his alleged role in the collapse of the TerraUSD cryptocurrency, which crashed in May 2022, causing billions of dollars in losses. Julian Moreno Beltran and Douglas Gan, representing 359 plaintiffs, claim Kwon and three other defendants made false representations about the cryptocurrency's stability, leading to heavy losses. The lawsuit seeks damages and aggravated damages for fraudulent misrepresentation, with the next case conference set for November 16.

images.alt_text: Prosecutors last month said Kwon and five others face arrest warrants on charges including breaching the capital-markets law.
Kwon refrained from revealing his whereabouts in a podcast earlier this week, citing threats he’s received.

site_title: Singapore companies’ performance and optimism wane in Q3: BT-SUSS survey
summary: Singapore companies' performance and optimism waned in the third quarter of 2022, according to the latest BT-SUSS Business Climate Survey. The net balance for orders or new business fell to -1% from -4% in the previous quarter, while profits remained in decline at -7%. However, sales improved slightly to 11%. Firms remained optimistic about the next six months, with a positive business prospects net balance of 5%. Economists expect fourth-quarter GDP growth to be between 3.9% and 4.7%, exceeding the official forecast band.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
Manufacturing expectations still pessimistic, services sector less upbeat: surveys
Singapore firms are much less optimistic about business prospects than they were a quarter ago, according to the latest quarterly BT-SUSS Business Climate Survey.

site_title: Opec+ cuts that steadied market now bring risk of US$100 crude
summary: Oil prices have surged to a two-month high of $99.56 a barrel, threatening to reach $100 as the seasonal demand peak coincides with additional sanctions on Russian supplies. The Opec+ production cuts, which have steadied markets, now appear to be over-tightening, with experts warning of a potential surplus this quarter. The tension between weakening demand and tightening supply may dominate the next Opec+ meeting on December 4, with the International Energy Agency warning that restricting oil output could push fuel costs to levels that could trigger a global recession.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures dropped US$1.20, or 1.2 per cent, to US$97.37 a barrel by 0227 GMT on Monday, after hitting as low as US$96.50 earlier.
Saudi Arabia’s energy minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman said the Gulf countries were both increasing oil production capacity.

site_title: Oil prices slide US$2 on China demand worries, US midterm elections
summary: Oil prices fell US$2.56 to US$95.36 a barrel in choppy trading due to growing concerns over fuel demand in China, where Covid-19 outbreaks are worsening, and uncertainty surrounding the US midterm elections. Brent futures dropped 2.6% and US crude fell 3.14%. Despite concerns about potential lockdowns in China, the US is bracing for cold weather, limiting the downside for crude prices. Market participants also await US consumer price data on Thursday and watch for potential recession risks.

images.alt_text: An oil pumping unit, also known as a "nodding donkey" or pumping jack, operates at sunset at a drilling site operated by Tatneft OAO near Almetyevsk, Russia, on Friday, July 31, 2015. Eleven months of surviving with oil below $100 have left Russia hardened enough to endure a monthlong drop to $40 a barrel, a survey of economists showed. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

site_title: ECB supervisors show dark side of higher rates for banks
summary: The European Central Bank's interest rate hikes are expected to boost profits for most eurozone banks, with some potentially generating bigger profits if rates rise by 200 basis points. However, banks focused on consumers and the public sector may struggle, with some taking a hit of over 200 basis points to their capital ratios. Custodian banks, corporate lenders, and promotional banks are particularly sensitive to wider credit spreads. ECB supervisors warn that banks need to prepare for potential losses or provisions for expected losses.

images.alt_text: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), during a news conference in Amsterdam, Netherlands, on Thursday, June 9, 2022, 2022. The ECB brought down the curtain on years of ultra-loose policy, committing to a quarter-point increase in interest rates next month and opening the door to a bigger hike in the fall. Photographer: Peter Boer/Bloomberg

site_title: Italy unearths exceptional haul of ancient bronzes
summary: Italian archaeologists announced the discovery of over 20 bronze statues, nearly 2,000 years old, in the mud of hot springs in Tuscany. The statues depict deities venerated at a sanctuary established by the Etruscans and Romans. The find, which includes 5,000 gold, silver, and bronze coins, is considered one of the most significant in the Mediterranean. The hot spring water preserved the items, allowing inscriptions in Etruscan and Latin to remain visible. The statues will be the centerpiece of a new museum.

images.alt_text: The Palestinian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities said the flooring included several mosaic panels depicting animals and other features of social life during the Byzantine era.

site_title: Tesla recalls 40,000 US vehicles over potential loss of power steering assist
summary: Tesla is recalling 40,000 US vehicles from 2017-2021 Model S and Model X models due to a potential loss of power steering assist, which can increase crash risks. The recall affects vehicles that have been updated to better detect unexpected steering assist torque. As of November 1, over 97% of the recalled vehicles have received the update. Tesla has reported no injuries or deaths related to this condition, but the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration warns of increased crash risks.

images.alt_text: The insurance incentive is a cash rebate offered to buyers to buy insurance from Tesla’s partner insurers.
Tesla shares have been struggling for the most part this year, swept up in the broader risk-off market trend.

site_title: US dollar stems losses as investors eye mid-terms
summary: The US dollar steadied on Tuesday amid anticipation of US mid-term elections, which could lead to gridlock in Congress and potentially reduce fiscal stimulus, boosting bond markets. Despite rising US Treasury yields and pushing the dollar to multi-year highs, some analysts expect the trend to reverse as the dollar may be nearing exhaustion. The dollar index fell to 110.4, while the euro and sterling also declined, while the Japanese yen rose to a one-week high.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies, the safe-haven US dollar index fell 0.54 per cent to 110.49.

site_title: China, Russia to drive 10% default pain for ‘junk-rated’ EM firms: JPMorgan
summary: JPMorgan analysts predict a 10% "high-yield" corporate default rate for emerging markets (EM) in 2023, driven by China's 20% default rate due to its property crisis and Russia's 66% default rate due to Western sanctions. The overall EM corporate default rate is forecast to be 3.8%, with Latin America's default rate expected to jump to 5.7% due to Argentina's repeat defaulters and idiosyncratic stories. Distressed bonds totaling $178 billion make up 27.7% of EM corporate high-yield outstanding bonds, a ratio similar to 2008.

site_title: Diesel tankers are about to get the biggest demand surge since 1993
summary: Diesel tankers are expected to experience their largest demand surge since 1993 in 2023, driven by sanctions on Russian oil products and disruptions to global cargo flows. A 9.5% increase in ton miles, a measure of cargo volume multiplied by distance, is forecasted, with potential distances increasing five to six times, necessitating more ships. Combined with crude oil flows, ton miles are expected to rise 6.4% in 2023, the largest increase since 2014, according to Clarkson Research Service.

site_title: Work underway at COP27 to find more funding for ‘just transition’ in S-E Asia
summary: Germany, Indonesia, and Vietnam are discussing a Just Energy Transition Partnership to accelerate the phase-out of coal-fired power plants in the region. The partnership aims to provide funding for the transition to more sustainable fuels, with a focus on social and economic inclusivity. The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank has also announced a $1 billion initiative to finance green energy projects in the region. However, challenges persist, including limited financing options for companies in Southeast Asia and resistance from investors to investing in "dirty" assets. The partnership and initiatives highlight the growing importance of "just transition" financing at the international level.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim

(from left) Director of energy innovation at Bezos Earth Fund Nicole Iseppi; CEO of IKEA Foundation Per Heggenes; CEO of GEAPP Simon Harford; vice-president of policy and strategy at AIIB Danny Alexander; and president of AIIB Jin Liqun.
Britain, France, Germany, the United States and the European Union will provide funds in the form of grants and loans to help South Africa decarbonise its economy.

site_title: Japan's Cabinet approves extra budget spending, adding to debt
summary: Japan's Cabinet approved a 29.1 trillion yen ($278.9 billion) extra budget spending for an economic stimulus package this fiscal year, with most of it funded by additional new debt. The package aims to help households cope with surging costs of electricity, gas, and gasoline, and will also support regions to attract tourists. The move underscores Japan's struggle to achieve economic growth alongside fiscal reform, with the government warning of a severe fiscal situation and risk of national wealth outflow.

images.alt_text: The extra debt worth 22.9 trillion yen will bring the overall Japanese government bonds (JGBs) to 62.5 trillion yen (S$604.3 billion) for this fiscal year.

site_title: Uefa repeats opposition to Super League in meeting with ESL backer A22 Sports
summary: UEFA met with A22 Sports, backing the proposed European Super League, and reiterated its opposition to the breakaway league. The meeting, attended by UEFA President Aleksander Ceferin and representatives from top leagues, unanimously rejected the idea. UEFA stated that the status quo is satisfactory, and the European Court of Justice's review of UEFA's monopoly structure is expected to deliver conclusions in Spring 2023. A22 Sports CEO Bernd Reichart claimed that European clubs are "lagging behind" and that his company is in dialogue with clubs to discuss reforms, but UEFA provided assurances that it will refrain from activities that restrict such discussions.

site_title: US small business optimism drops for first time since June
summary: US small business optimism has dropped for the first time in four months, falling to 91.3 in October due to worsening sales outlook, inflation, and supply chain disruptions. The National Federation of Independent Business reported a decline in hiring plans and a mixed inflation metric, with some owners expecting higher prices and compensation. Labour shortages remain a significant issue, with owners continuing to struggle to attract qualified applicants. The survey's inflation metrics show a slight increase in price hikes and compensation plans.

site_title: Global headwinds: What lies ahead for Asia?
summary: The International Monetary Fund has downgraded Asia's economic growth prospects for the next two years, forecasting 4% growth in 2022 and 4.3% in 2023. This is due to headwinds including China's strict zero-Covid policy, a slow-motion real estate crisis, prolonged geopolitical tensions, and aggressive US Federal Reserve rate hikes. Asian currencies have tumbled against the US dollar, prompting large-scale foreign exchange interventions and reserve depletion, reminiscent of the Asian financial crisis 25 years ago.

images.alt_text: People walk along a pedestrian street surrounded by shops and shopping malls in Shanghai on October 24, 2022. (Photo by Hector RETAMAL / AFP)

site_title: Emerging markets see Oct portfolio inflows but investors rethink China: IIF
summary: Emerging markets received $9.2 billion in portfolio inflows in October, their second strongest month this year, despite China suffering $1.2 billion in fixed income outflows. Overall, China's flows are down $82.8 billion for the year, while emerging markets outside China attracted $18 billion. Investors are rethinking their exposure to China due to concerns over the country's zero-Covid policy and its impact on the economy, with some asset managers arguing that beaten-down Chinese assets are attractive.

site_title: EU extends Myanmar sanctions, targets minister and judge
summary: The European Union has extended sanctions on Myanmar's junta, targeting 19 individuals and entities, including a minister and a chief justice. The measures come amid "escalating violence and grave human rights violations" since the 2020 military coup. The sanctions include visa bans and asset freezes, affecting 84 individuals and 11 entities. The EU is also committed to bringing to justice those responsible for human rights abuses and war crimes. The move aims to pressure the junta to end the violence and transition to democracy.

images.alt_text: Asean, which Myanmar is a member of, has come under pressure to convince the junta to end violence and instability since coup leader Min Aung Hlaing seized control from the civilian government last year.

site_title: ‘Qatar is a mistake,’ says former Fifa president Sepp Blatter
summary: Former FIFA president Sepp Blatter stated that hosting the 2022 World Cup in Qatar was a "mistake" due to the country's small size and concerns over working conditions. Blatter, who led FIFA for 17 years, expressed his criticism despite acknowledging that FIFA had amended its selection criteria in 2012 to prioritize social considerations and human rights. The tournament is set to begin in less than two weeks, and Blatter will be watching from his home in Zurich.

site_title: TikTok urged by record labels to share more revenue, royalties
summary: Major record labels, including Universal Music Group, Sony Music Entertainment, and Warner Music Group, are urging TikTok to share more revenue and royalties for using their music. The companies, which have a deal with TikTok since its early days, are seeking a cut of advertising sales based on the number of plays their artists get. TikTok has earned $4 billion in revenue last year and is on track for $12 billion in 2022, prompting the labels to increase payouts. However, TikTok has positioned itself as a promotional tool that doesn't need to pay in the same way as Spotify or YouTube.

site_title: Singapore launches its inaugural pavilion at COP27
summary: Singapore launched its inaugural pavilion at the United Nations COP27 climate conference on Nov 6, 2022, to showcase its commitment to climate ambitions and innovations in renewable energy and green finance. The pavilion, "Building a Future of Green Possibilities," was a collaboration of over 100 partners and aims to catalyze sustainable solutions and strengthen global climate action. Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu welcomed the pavilion as a representation of Singapore's aspiration to advance global climate action.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies slide as concerns over FTX exchange rattle markets
summary: Cryptocurrencies, including Bitcoin, fell 6% to $19,351 on Tuesday, its lowest in two weeks, amid concerns over FTX exchange's financials. The FTX token dropped 15% and its in-house token fell 20% as investors reacted to pressure on the exchange. A leaked balance sheet from Alameda Research, a trading firm linked to FTX, raised questions about the exchange's solvency. A one-day net outflow of $630 million from FTX was reported, with analysts predicting a "messy week" for the market.

images.alt_text: Zhao (right) and Bankman-Fried have been trading barbs on Twitter in the past few months, feuding over issues ranging from lobbying US politicians to allegations of frontrunning trades.

site_title: UN warns of worsening food crisis in Sri Lanka
summary: The United Nations has warned of a worsening food crisis in Sri Lanka due to two consecutive seasons of poor harvests, foreign exchange shortages, and reduced household purchasing power. The number of people needing urgent humanitarian help has doubled to 3.4 million, up from 1.7 million in June. The UN has raised $79 million to feed those in need, but an additional $70 million is needed to address the crisis. Sri Lanka's economic crisis has led to high inflation, power blackouts, and fuel rationing, and the country is in talks with the International Monetary Fund for a $2.9 billion bailout.

site_title: Prime US Reit Q3 distributable income down 4% on lower NPI
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 4% decline in distributable income to US$19.2 million in Q3, driven by a 6.1% decrease in net property income. Occupancy remained steady at 89.6% despite year-on-year declines. Gross revenue rose 3.1% to US$40.6 million, with increased leasing activity and positive rental reversion. The Reit aims to enhance asset competitiveness and expand tenant engagement around ESG initiatives to support corporate goals, with a gearing ratio of 38.7% and interest coverage of 4.5 times.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong

RHB’s Vijay Natarajan says he will be looking at return-to-office trends and physical occupancy - such as at Manulife US Reit's Phipps Tower (pictured) - to assess potential leasing impact from the evolving hybrid working model.

site_title: Europe to fast-track permits for building renewable projects
summary: The European Union is proposing a fast-track regulation to speed up permit-granting procedures for renewable energy projects, particularly solar farms, to lower electricity prices and reduce gas use. The regulation will focus on clearing the way for technologies and projects that can be deployed quickly, with a maximum deadline of three months for permits. This move aims to accelerate the rollout of heat pumps and other renewables projects, which have been hindered by lengthy planning rules. The proposal builds on the EU's REPowerEU plan to reduce dependency on Russian fossil fuels and decarbonize energy.

images.alt_text: Britain, France, Germany, the United States and the European Union will provide funds in the form of grants and loans to help South Africa decarbonise its economy.
The UK government said on Thursday it would ban ships and services used to transport Russian crude oil above the price cap set by the G7 and Australia.

site_title: Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank in US$1b partnership to fund energy transition
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) has partnered with the Global Energy Alliance for People and Planet (GEAPP) to fund energy transition projects, worth up to $1 billion. The alliance aims to support grid-based renewables, distributed renewables, and fossil fuel transition in eligible countries. The capital will be directed to projects that align with the AIIB's strategies and GEAPP's charitable objectives, with a focus on countries eligible for AIIB financing.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Singapore launched its inaugural pavilion at the United Nations COP27 climate conference on Nov 6, 2022.

site_title: Grand Venture’s Q3 profit after tax down 33.4% amid semiconductor slowdown
summary: Grand Venture Technology reported a 33.4% decline in its Q3 net profit after tax to S$3.4 million, due to a semiconductor slowdown. Revenue rose 3.2% to S$32.9 million, driven by gains in the electronics, aerospace, medical, and others segment. Gross profit margin fell to 25.9% due to lower business activity in the back-end semiconductor segment. The company expects near-term demand in the segment to remain volatile and is expanding its value chain participation to offer higher-value front-end services.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Ricky Lee, executive chairman of Grand Venture Technology.

site_title: Playing the hand that markets deal
summary: US investors face an uncertain economic environment, with tight labor markets driving elevated wage growth and inflation persisting despite recent peak. The US economy is unlikely to return to a low-rate/low-inflation environment in the short term, and investors need to consider new tools for attractive risk-adjusted returns. The traditional 60/40 portfolio is under pressure due to stickier inflation, elevated wage growth, and higher interest rates, with alternative assets offering potential solutions. With a bear market in place, investors must adapt to changing market conditions and consider diversification strategies to maintain edge in pursuit of attractive returns.

images.alt_text: The onslaught of economic and geopolitical forces creating daily market turmoil may leave investors feeling like they're facing a mega storm of unknown proportions.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits slipped 1,000 to a seasonally adjusted 217,000 for the week ended Oct 29, the Labor Department said on Thursday (Nov 3).

site_title: Unique asset class to hedge inflation and diversify risk
summary: Fossil fuel prices are likely to remain elevated due to ongoing demand and limited supply, despite decarbonization targets. The commodity market is influenced by enduring trends, including the continued relevance of fossil fuels, the long-term transition to lower carbon intensity, and global fragmentation driving up price risks. These factors, coupled with chronic underinvestment in fossil fuel production and supply chain disruptions, will continue to impact commodity prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The sun is seen behind a crude oil pump jack in the Permian Basin in Loving County, Texas, U.S., November 22, 2019. REUTERS/Angus Mordant/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Evelyn de Rothschild, London head of banking dynasty, dies at 91
summary: Evelyn de Rothschild, the 91-year-old London head of the banking dynasty, has died peacefully at home. He served 27 years as chairman of N M Rothschild & Sons from 1976, uniting the British and French arms of the family's famous banking group. Rothschild was a key figure in bringing together the London business with its French counterpart, Rothschild mpagnie Banque, and was a long-planned goal to remain competitive with multinational banks. He was also a prominent figure in various roles, including chairman of The Economist magazine and a financial adviser to Queen Elizabeth II.

images.alt_text: Financier Evelyn de Rothschild, poses for a photograph during the 10TH Bloomberg BusinessWeek European Leadership Forum in London, U.K., on Tuesday, Nov. 23, 2010. ÒIreland will come through this and there are opportunities,Ó Rothschild said at a Bloomberg conference in London. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg *** Local Caption *** Evelyn de Rothschild

site_title: US votes with Biden agenda at stake and Trump in the wings
summary: US midterm elections are underway, with President Joe Biden's agenda hanging in the balance. The elections, which include all 435 House seats and a third of the 100 Senate seats, could determine whether Biden will be able to pass his legislative agenda. Republicans, led by former President Donald Trump, are campaigning on kitchen-table issues like inflation and crime, and polls show they are on track to win the House of Representatives. If the House and Senate flip, Biden would be left with little legislative power, raising concerns about his ability to address issues like climate change and Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Voters cast their ballots as a poll worker stands between them, in midterm elections in Miami, Florida, U.S., November 8, 2022. REUTERS/Joe Skipper

site_title: Blibli owner ends flat in Jakarta’s second-largest debut of 2022
summary: Blibli, Indonesia's e-commerce group, ended its first day of trading unchanged after raising US$510 million in the country's second-largest IPO of 2022. The company's shares finished at 450 rupiah (S$0.04) each, erasing gains of up to 4.9% shortly after the market opened. The IPO was supported by foreign investors, including sovereign wealth funds and retail investors, and the company plans to use the proceeds for debt repayment and working capital. Despite the mixed sentiment towards the tech sector, Blibli's existing shareholders, including Djarum Group, have committed to not exit the company after the IPO.

images.alt_text: Blibli CEO and co-founder Kusumo Martanto. The Indonesian e-commerce firm is aiming to raise 8.17 trillion rupiah at its upcoming IPO.

site_title: First Reit Q3 DPU rises slightly to S$0.0066
summary: First Reit reported a slightly higher distribution per unit (DPU) of S$0.0066 for the third quarter, unchanged from the previous year. Total DPU for the first 9 months of 2022 rose 1.5% to S$0.0198. Rental and other income increased 39.2% to S$80.9 million, and net property and other income rose 40.1% to S$79.1 million. The manager aims to increase its portfolio in developed markets to over half of its assets under management by 2027.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
First Reit's social loan was assessed to be able to secure houses for the elderly, and promote women’s active participation in society.
Siloam Hospitals Yogyakarta, one of First Reit's properties. The Reit is offering to buy back S$60 million of its perpetual securities at 70 per cent of the purchase price.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's net Goods and Services Tax (GST) revenue in 2018 and 2019 was mainly paid by tourists and foreigners residing in the country, accounting for around 50% of the revenue. Meanwhile, the top 20% of resident households accounted for approximately 20% of the revenue. Additionally, Malaysia's industrial production index rose 10.8% in September, while Singapore's stocks edged up 0.1% on Tuesday.

site_title: OKH Global to sell Tai Seng property to Chip Eng Seng unit for S$35m
summary: OKH Global will sell its Tai Seng property to Chip Eng Seng Corporation for S$35 million, below the book value of S$38 million. The disposal is expected to result in a loss of around S$3 million. Despite this, the company believes the sale will benefit its financial position and allow it to re-allocate resources for future growth and investments. The sale is considered an "interested person transaction" due to the ties between OKH's chairman and Chip Eng Seng's largest shareholder.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
OKH Global to divest holdings in two companies to repay loans
Celine Tang, who is also group managing director of property player SingHaiyi and non-executive chairman at OKH Global, became Chip Eng Seng’s chairman in 2018 after becoming its largest shareholder.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed lower on Tuesday, down 0.77 points to 1,441.35. The index saw a volume of 3.046 billion lots worth RM1.575 billion, with losers outnumbering gainers 470 to 361.

site_title: Foxconn electric vehicle alliance plans boxy three-seater
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, has announced plans for its first electric vehicle, Project X, a boxy three-seater designed for Asian markets. The vehicle, priced under $20,000, will be custom-built for the purchaser and features a modular design. Mass production is expected to start in 2024, with initial markets targeting Taiwan, India, Thailand, Indonesia, and Japan. Foxconn aims to replicate its success in assembling personal computers and cellphones in the EV industry, with the goal of disrupting the market and generating revenue through module sales.

site_title: Economists see recession coming, so maybe it’s not
summary: Economists have shifted their consensus view, predicting a US recession for the first time in records, with over 60% probability. Despite inflation at four-decade highs and central banks raising rates aggressively, economists' record accuracy at predicting downturns suggests their forecast may be unlikely. The "inevitable never happens" according to John Maynard Keynes, as unexpected events often occur.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - NOVEMBER 02: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on November 02, 2022 in New York City. Stocks opened low this morning as the Federal Reserve is expected to make a fourth straight interest hike of of three-quarters of a percentage point fueling recession fears as it continues to fight inflation.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: At Asean Summit, leaders must tread carefully to deal with worsening Myanmar situation
summary: Southeast Asian leaders are gathering for their annual summit in Phnom Penh, where the ongoing crisis in Myanmar is expected to dominate discussions. Despite a long-standing policy of non-interference, Asean leaders may need to reevaluate their approach to address the worsening humanitarian and human rights situation. Myanmar's military government has warned against pressure to implement a peace plan, while Cambodia's chairmanship has urged adherence to founding principles. Asean's leaders face a difficult decision on how to proceed, with some countries divided on handling the crisis and the junta showing no signs of genuine effort to build constructive dialogue.

images.alt_text: Asean, which Myanmar is a member of, has come under pressure to convince the junta to end violence and instability since coup leader Min Aung Hlaing seized control from the civilian government last year.

Foreign ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) are holding emergency talks on Thursday in Jakarta on Myanmar in advance of the Nov 10-13 Asean and East Asia summits in Cambodia.

In this file photo taken in August 2022, people in Yangon queue to receive subsidised cooking oil. The Financial Action Task Force is mulling placing Myanmar on its blacklist, a move that will make the country even less appealing to foreign investors.

site_title: North Korea's missile programme faces few hurdles, despite sanctions
summary: North Korea has fired over 80 missiles, including short-range ballistic missiles and intercontinental ballistic missiles, in a record-breaking year, despite international sanctions. Analysts say the country's willingness to launch expensive devices into the sea suggests its missile program faces few hurdles, citing the need for fuel, missiles, and complex machinery. Sanctions have failed to hinder the development, with North Korea relying on foreign assistance, including materials and technology from Russia, China, and other countries. The UN has imposed resolutions banning North Korea's ballistic missile program, but the country's ability to acquire components and materials from abroad remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Television screens show a news report about a North Korean missile launch at an electronics store in Seoul on Nov 3, 2022. North Korea fired an artillery barrage into a maritime “buffer zone” overnight, Seoul’s military said on Friday.
A Japanese emergency alert about North Korea's ballistic missile firing is pictured in Tokyo, Japan, Nov 3, 2022.

site_title: Twitter’s big debt bills add urgency to Musk’s turnaround plans
summary: Elon Musk's transformation of Twitter since buying the company for $44 billion has added urgency to his turnaround plans. Twitter's debt load has jumped to $13 billion, with annual interest payments approaching $1.2 billion, up from $100 million in the pre-Musk era. Musk has fired most of the senior executive team and is planning to cut costs, including slashing staff and closing offices, in an effort to reduce expenses and boost revenue. However, rapid cost-cutting may hinder Twitter's ability to develop better ways to earn money over time, and Musk's reliance on a monthly subscription service and revived Vine app may not be enough to offset declining advertising revenue.

images.alt_text: Twitter accounts with millions of followers have been suspended after their user name was changed to Elon Musk.
Tesla shares have been struggling for the most part this year, swept up in the broader risk-off market trend.

site_title: Pandora braces for recession despite resilient demand
summary: Pandora reported third-quarter sales above expectations, with total sales of 5.26 billion Danish krones, slightly above analyst estimates. Despite macroeconomic uncertainty, consumer shopping patterns have proven resilient, with store traffic and customer purchases remaining unchanged. The company expects full-year organic growth of 4-6% and operating profit margin of 25-25.5%. Pandora has taken precautionary measures, including cutting promotional activities and raising prices on a third of its products by 4%.

site_title: Cuscaden Peak Investments sells Yarwood Avenue GCB for S$29.7 million
summary: Cuscaden Peak Investments has sold a freehold bungalow in Yarwood Avenue in the Kilburn Estate GCB Area for S$29.7 million, or S$1,604 psf. The two-storey bungalow, with five bedrooms and a swimming pool, is currently leased and will be bought by a Singaporean businessman involved in various industries. The sale price is in line with fair-market value, according to veteran GCB agent KH Tan of Newsman Realty, who notes that uncertain economic conditions and rising interest rates are influencing buyer behavior.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
GCB deals volume set to ease, but prices expected to remain firm
Singapore luxury apartment sales double in 2021; GCB deal value soars to new high

site_title: Big C to weigh US$500m Thai IPO
summary: Big C Supercenter, a Bangkok-based retail company, is considering a US$500 million initial public offering (IPO) in Thailand. The company, owned by Berli Jucker, is sounding out investment banks for proposals on the share sale, which could happen as soon as next year. Big C operates 1,792 stores in Thailand, Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia, and previously raised US$112 million in a Thai IPO in 2012. The IPO plans are still in discussions and details are yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Nintendo cuts Switch sales forecast after chips shortage
summary: Nintendo has cut its fiscal-year forecast for Switch console sales by 10% to 19 million due to a prolonged chips shortage. Despite this, the company reported earnings in line with expectations and raised its net income forecast by 18% to 400 billion yen for the fiscal year. The company attributed the sales decline to the shortage, but expects to maximize deliveries in the holiday shopping season and maintain strong demand for its consoles. The latest Splatoon 3 game has also boosted sales, with 3.45 million units sold domestically in its first three days.

site_title: Dubai developer Nakheel secures 17 billion dirhams in financing
summary: Dubai state developer Nakheel secured 17 billion dirhams (S$6.5 billion) in financing from local banks, including Emirates NBD, MashreqBank, and Dubai Islamic Bank, to fund new projects such as Dubai Islands and waterfront developments. The financing includes 11 billion dirhams in refinancing and 6 billion dirhams through a syndicate.

images.alt_text: Emaar will buy Dubai Holding’s 50 per cent stake in the Dubai Creek Harbour project and finance the deal equally in cash and shares, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum’s holding firm says.

Capital spending jumped an annual 64 per cent in April to June, as Saudi Arabia embarks on a building spree including malls and parks as well as grandiose plans for a new city built from scratch and a luxury tourism development on the Red Sea.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dip at open
summary: Europe's stock markets dropped at the open on Tuesday, November 8, 2022, with London's FTSE 100 index sliding 0.5% to 7,257.48 points, and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices losing 0.1% and 0.5% respectively. The decline followed a mixed Asian showing and comes as investors await key midterm elections in the US.

site_title: Taiwan smartphone chipmaker MediaTek launches new chip
summary: Taiwanese smartphone chipmaker MediaTek has launched the Dimensity 9200 chip, aiming to expand into the premium market. The 5G chip's power efficiency enables longer battery life and a better gaming experience. According to analyst Phil Solis, the new chip is key to MediaTek's strategy to move upstream and gain market share in the US and Europe, where Qualcomm Inc dominates the premium market. MediaTek seeks to change consumer perception and close the revenue gap with Qualcomm.

site_title: British grocery inflation hit record 14.7% in October: Kantar
summary: British grocery inflation reached a record 14.7% in October, according to Kantar, with annual grocery bills expected to rise £682. Sales rose 5.2% on a value basis, but volumes dropped due to inflation. Discounters Aldi and Lidl saw sales jump 22.7% and 21.5% respectively, while Morrisons and Waitrose experienced sales falls of 4.6% and 1.9%. Many households are struggling financially, with 27% reporting difficulties and 9 in 10 citing higher food prices as a major concern.

site_title: Renault, Google expand pact to make cars ‘like mobile phones’
summary: Renault and Google are expanding their partnership to enable remote software updates for new car models, similar to mobile phone updates. Renault's CEO Luca de Meo aims to make cars "intelligent objects" that can learn and be upgraded over the air. The partnership will offer additional on-demand services, including car location features, and create new revenue streams for Renault. The move is part of Renault's "horizontal" strategy, collaborating with software developers rather than designing tech in-house. The partnership aims to bolster residual car value and retain customers.

images.alt_text: For Geely, the deal extends its pattern of building partnerships to expand beyond China.
Renault will brief investors about its revamp plans, which are still being finalised, during a capital markets day on Nov 8.

site_title: The sea is still a dangerous workplace
summary: A cargo ship, Tian Feng 369, sank off northern China's coast in bad weather, resulting in 11 deaths. Nearby ship Jian Qiao 502's chief officer, Xu Bo, jumped into icy waters to rescue two survivors, hauling them to safety despite exhaustion and cold. Xu received the 2022 IMO Award for Exceptional Bravery for his heroic actions. The incident highlights the dangers of the sea and the importance of knowing the cause of ship sinkings to improve maritime safety.

images.alt_text: An aerial view shows ships at the anchorage area of the Bosphorus southern entrance in Istanbul, on October 12, 2022. - The grain deal between Russia and Ukraine establishing safe corridors along which Ukrainian ships can come in and out of three designated Black Sea ports in and around Odessa creates a traffic jam in Istanbul. (Photo by Yasin AKGUL / AFP)

FILE PHOTO: View of a COP27 sign on the road leading to the conference area in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh town as the city prepares to host the COP27 summit next month, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sayed Sheasha/File Photo

site_title: A surprise midterm win by Democrats could roil markets
summary: US midterm elections could roil markets, with a surprise Democratic win potentially leading to concerns about tech-sector regulation and budget spending that could exacerbate inflation. Options positioning implies a 1.5% decline in the S&P 500 if Democrats win strongly. Analysts also expect a clean sweep by Republicans to boost Treasuries and support US stocks. Market participants are less focused on the election due to a calendar full of macroeconomic events, leaving traders vulnerable to surprises.

images.alt_text: Republicans have made the economy their No 1 issue, and accuse President Biden and Democrats of fuelling inflation with major spending packages and then ignoring the economic plight of American families faced with soaring energy and food prices.

site_title: Hot stock: Golden Energy falls 27.2% on heavy trading, prompting SGX query
summary: Golden Energy and Resources' shares plummeted 27.2% to S$0.66, their lowest level since August 30, amid heavy trading following news of the coal miner's potential restructuring or exit from its energy coal business. The Singapore Exchange issued a query at 11:37 am regarding the company's "unusual" share price movements.

images.alt_text: The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources

site_title: Primark owner plans £500m buyback amid falling profit
summary: Associated British Foods plans a £500m share buyback amid falling profit, citing "substantial and volatile" cost inflation. The company expects lower profit this year due to rising energy costs and a strengthening dollar. Despite this, it will not raise prices further than already done at Primark, which is struggling with cash-strapped consumers. The move aims to remove costs and help the business recover, with a 4% rise in Primark's stock in early trading.

images.alt_text: UK retail sales volumes dropped by 1.6 per cent in monthly terms in August, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said - the biggest fall since December 2021.

site_title: Singapore stocks shrug off weak China trade data to inch up on Tuesday; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) edged up 0.1% to 3,145.83 points on Tuesday, despite weak China trade data for October. The mixed Asian market trend was driven by Japan's 1.3% gain and South Korea's 1.2% increase. In the wider Singapore market, 288 losers outnumbered 220 gainers, with 1.65 billion shares worth S$1.11 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: Jude Chan
Recession woes as central banks tighten rates to cure inflation weighed heavily on markets

site_title: Carbon credits to offset Singapore emissions tax are subject to eligibility criteria
summary: Singapore has introduced a carbon tax regime with a 5% limit on using international carbon credits to offset up to 5% of taxable emissions from 2024. The eligibility criteria for international carbon credits will "minimally reference" the Corsia standards, and a whitelist of acceptable credits will be published. Companies in emissions-intensive trade-exposed sectors, such as chemical and semiconductor companies, will be granted transitory allowances to emit certain emissions without paying the carbon tax. The government aims to ensure high environmental integrity and compliance with the Paris Agreement.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting

GIC’s head of sustainability and total portfolio sustainable investing Rachel Teo and her associates laid out their method, the carbon earnings-at-risk scenario analysis, in a paper published on Tuesday (Oct 25).
Singapore reduced its emissions to 52.8 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent in 2020, equivalent to 32 per cent below business-as-usual levels, Wong said.

The paper’s authors, KPMG Singapore tax partner Mark Addy and principal consultant of indirect tax Gan Hwee Leng, said the lack of clarity around the GST treatment of the voluntary trade of carbon credits is hindering the young market’s uptake.
IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva says the pace of change in the real economy was still “way too slow”.
While robust coal demand and high prices are helping to prop up companies’ earnings now, some coal producers are already taking steps to diversify their business and revenue streams.

site_title: Veteran French designer Philippe Starck now looks to space
summary: Veteran French designer Philippe Starck, 73, is shifting his focus to space, despite his illustrious career in interior design and architecture. Starck, known for his work on the Elysee Palace apartments for President Francois Mitterrand, is increasingly drawn to space design. He was recently spotted at an exhibition featuring his early work, showing no signs of slowing down. Starck's foray into space design is a new chapter in his long and varied career.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed lower on Tuesday, Nov 8, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index falling 0.29% to 16,547.51, following a run of rallies fueled by hopes of China easing zero-Covid policies. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, losing 0.43% and 0.40%, respectively. The declines come after a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and amid US-EU trade talks, which investors are closely watching.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The name of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited is displayed at the entrance in Hong Kong, China January 24, 2018. REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo     GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: Weaker asset quality to weigh on Singapore banks’ profitability in 2023: Moody’s
summary: Singapore banks' profitability may be impacted in 2023 due to anticipated deteriorating asset quality, according to Moody's Investors Service. The credit rating agency expects loan defaults to increase as worsening economic conditions affect small and medium-sized enterprises, unsecured retail loans, and loans tied to Chinese property developers. Despite this, Moody's notes that the banks' capital ratios remain "good" and their funding and liquidity are expected to remain robust in 2023.

images.alt_text: Singapore banks posted robust earnings in the third quarter of 2022 with record figures, as the lenders continued to benefit from interest rate hikes.

site_title: Authorities turn seized home towers at Evergrande's resort island to rental, commercial use
summary: Chinese authorities have approved the conversion of 39 towers in the Ocean Flower Island development on Hainan island into rental housing, serviced apartments, and commercial spaces. The towers, which were initially part of a 65,000-home project, were seized by the local government due to environmental and construction violations. The conversion is part of the government's efforts to redevelop the 800-hectare project, which is valued at nearly $13 billion. The move is seen as a way to generate revenue and address the financial woes of China Evergrande Group, which is struggling with over $300 billion in debt.

images.alt_text: Saddled with more than US$300 billion in total liabilities, China Evergrande Group led by chairman Hui Ka Yan, has already seen many of its assets, both in mainland China and Hong Kong, seized by creditors..

site_title: China’s biggest air show opens under cloud of zero-Covid policy
summary: China's biggest air show, Airshow China, opened in Zhuhai with a scaled-down version due to the country's zero-Covid policy, which led to some delegates being blocked from attending. The show featured Comac's C919, a homegrown rival to Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 MAX, for the first time. Some Beijing-based delegates were allowed in at the last minute, while others returned home in frustration. The zero-Covid policy has disrupted the air show, with some attendees unable to attend due to travel restrictions.

site_title: UK housebuilder Persimmon flags slowing demand amid surge in mortgage rates
summary: UK housebuilder Persimmon reported a slowdown in sales due to surging inflation and high interest rates, with the company's sales rate slipping further in the last six weeks. Rising mortgage rates and economic uncertainty have impacted customer behavior, according to CEO Dean Finch. The UK housing market has been showing signs of a slowdown, with the government's mini budget in September contributing to the surge in mortgage rates. Persimmon's warning comes as the country faces a deepening cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: Terraced houses are seen in Primrose Hill, London, Britain September 24, 2017. REUTERS/Eddie Keogh/File Photo

site_title: OCBC enables authentication tech for foreign business owners to open new bank account
summary: OCBC Bank has introduced digital passport authentication to enable foreign business owners of Singapore-incorporated SMEs to open new business banking accounts without visiting a branch or mailing notarized documents. This service uses the electronic near-field communication (NFC) chip in digital passports to verify personal details. Starting from December, foreign business owners can scan their passport's NFC chip and biodata page using the OCBC Business mobile banking app, which will then compare the information with details provided during a virtual meeting and a facial scan.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
OCBC's SME Index report indicates positive readings in Q3 across all industries except for the Information, communications and technology (ICT) sector.

site_title: Australian insurer warns of ‘distressing’ data threat
summary: Medibank Private, a major Australian health insurer, warned customers to be "vigilant" after a hacker threatened to release data of 10 million people within 24 hours, following a data breach affecting 9.7 million former and existing clients. The breach, which initially targeted 3.9 million customers, revealed sensitive information including names, birth dates, addresses, phone numbers, and emails. The insurer's CEO, David Koczkar, ruled out paying a ransom demand, citing the limited chance of data recovery and potential for extortion.

images.alt_text: Medibank on Wednesday also confirmed it was not insured against cyber attacks, estimating the hack could cost the company as much as A$35 million (S$31.7 million).
Recent high-profile hacks at Australia’s second-largest telecoms company Optus and health insurer Medibank Private compromised some 14 million customer accounts combined.

site_title: New Swedish government cuts fuel taxes, boosts defence in first budget
summary: Sweden's new right-wing government has unveiled its first budget, which includes a 40.4 billion Swedish kronas (S$5.2 billion) spending boost in 2023. Key measures include cutting fuel taxes by 6.7 billion kronas, increasing local authority funding by 6 billion kronas, and boosting defense spending by 4.2 billion kronas. The budget aims to cushion the economy's downturn, but faces challenges, including a projected 0.4% economic contraction and inflation near 10%. The government's spending increase may risk pushing inflation even higher, adding to the long-term pain for households and businesses.

images.alt_text: The old town of Gamla Stan in Stockholm. House prices in the biggest Nordic country have been forecast to drop as much as 20 per cent, in a sign of what may be to come in other markets where home costs rose sharply during the pandemic.

site_title: Thailand scraps plan to allow foreigners to buy land
summary: Thailand has scrapped a plan to allow limited land ownership by wealthy foreigners, citing public backlash and concerns over property prices and local ownership. The policy, aimed at attracting foreign investment, would have required a minimum investment of 40 million baht (S$1.5 million) in securities or bonds for at least three years, limiting foreigners to 1 rai (0.16 hectares) of land. The government withdrew the proposal to listen to opinions from all parties and conduct further studies on the matter.

images.alt_text: The programme targets top professionals, high-net-worth individuals and retirees, who will be eligible to own housing sites – but only in Bangkok and Pattaya(top).

site_title: Seoul: Shares rise as firmer won lifts blue chips
summary: South Korean shares rose 1.15% on Tuesday, driven by gains in heavyweight blue chip stocks ahead of US midterm elections and inflation data. The Kospi benchmark rose 27.25 points to 2,399.04, with Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix leading gains. The won strengthened, lifting foreign investors' appetite for blue chips, and the benchmark bond yield fell.

images.alt_text: Among heavyweights, technology giant Samsung Electronics has risen 1.4 per cent and peer SK Hynix gains 2.4 per cent.

site_title: Boding ill for China: new economic regime, rising geopolitical tensions
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has consolidated power, extending his mandate for a third term and stacking the Politburo Standing Committee with his allies. This has led to a more defensive stance on Chinese equities, with the country's zero-Covid policy unlikely to ease in the short term. China's shift to a state-controlled economy, prioritizing state-owned enterprises, has resulted in a low-growth period, reduced profitability for private companies, and increased geopolitical tensions with the West. As a result, investors are advised to consider alternative markets, such as fixed income, US and Japanese equities, and commodity-linked equity strategies.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers are seen on a crane above containers at the Yangshan Deep Water Port in Shanghai, China January 13, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Speedoc raises US$28m in pre-Series B to scale up virtual hospital model
summary: Speedoc, a healthcare technology platform, has raised US$28 million in its pre-Series B round to scale up its virtual hospital model. The funding will be used to expand its H-Ward virtual hospital programme, offering integrated solutions like remote monitoring and patient dashboarding. The company aims to provide hospital-level care at home, reducing costs and improving patient outcomes. Founded in 2017, Speedoc has a presence in Singapore and Malaysia and is eyeing expansion across South-east Asia, with around 120,000 users and a team of 150 medical professionals.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Lavender Hill Capital is excited to partner Glints' co-founders (left to right) Seah Ying Cong, Wong Yong Jie, Steve Sutanto and Oswald Yeo
SolanaFM was founded in March 2021 by Nicholas Chen (centre), Fathurrahman (right) and Chen Bing Huang (left).

From left: A*STAR deputy chief executive (Research) Prof Andy Hor; Enterprise SG ACE Mr Soh Leng Wan; NTU Senior vice president (Research) Prof Lam Khin Yong;  NHG Deputy group ceo (Education and Research) Prof Benjamin Seet

site_title: Telco roaming revenues to recover, but stiff competition could still hurt earnings: analysts
summary: Telco companies' earnings are expected to show a positive bump in roaming revenues due to recovering revenues, but stiff competition remains a concern. Analysts, such as Fitch Ratings, note that 5G has not led to sustained significant average revenue per user uplift worldwide. Companies like Singtel and StarHub are set to report their financial results this week, with analysts relatively optimistic about their prospects. Despite this, competition from other telcos and potential operating losses may impact earnings.

images.alt_text: Yong Jun Yuan
Singtel's latest consortium project is to build a 6,000km undersea fibre optic cable system worth US$300 million connecting Singapore and Hong Kong to Brunei, the Philippines, and Hainan, China.
The combined entity will overtake Advanced Info Service (AIS), as market leader. True and DTAC have 34 per cent and 21 per cent of mobile subscribers, respectively.

site_title: Renault, Geely clinch deal for internal-combustion joint venture
summary: Renault and Geely have agreed to launch a new, equally held joint venture to supply petrol engines and hybrid technology to both brands and other automakers. The venture, based in London, will employ 19,000 people and produce 5 million engines and hybrid systems per year. The deal marks an important step for Renault to carve out its petrol car business as a separate company and is part of its efforts to expand beyond China, following Geely's pattern of building partnerships.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Geely logo is seen at a car dealership in Shanghai, China August 17, 2021. Picture taken August 17, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
Renault will brief investors about its revamp plans, which are still being finalised, during a capital markets day on Nov 8.

site_title: Xi Jinping needs to bring Jack Ma back into the fold
summary: China's President Xi Jinping needs to extend an olive branch to tech moguls, particularly Jack Ma, to boost the nation's entrepreneurial spirit, which has been sapped by two years of regulatory crackdowns and Covid-Zero lockdowns. Ma's disappearance from public view after criticizing China's state-dominated banking sector sparked severe fallout, including a record anti-trust fine and a struggling fintech giant. Xi's "common prosperity" drive, aimed at attracting scientists and engineers, has not convinced aspiring entrepreneurs, who see it as an excuse to take away their wealth. Xi's gesture to bring Ma back into the fold is crucial to show the world what common prosperity is not and to foster a more favorable business environment.

images.alt_text: Founders of major Chinese tech firms including Alibaba have exited their leadership roles.
Before the clampdown, China was emerging as the epicentre of the crypto world, spawning giant exchanges like Binance Holdings and the biggest Bitcoin mining firms.

site_title: China’s BYD to launch new premium electric car brand in 2023
summary: Chinese electric vehicle giant BYD plans to launch a new premium brand in the first quarter of 2023, with vehicles priced above 1 million yuan (approximately $193,662). The move follows BYD's successful electric vehicle sales in China, which more than tripled to 1.4 million in the first 10 months. BYD has capitalized on government incentives for electric cars, having ditched petrol vehicles from its product mix this year. The new premium brand is expected to further solidify BYD's position in the Chinese market.

site_title: Tesla changes insurance incentive scheme in China to urge purchases
summary: Tesla has adjusted its insurance incentive scheme in China to encourage early purchases. The company raised the incentive to 8,000 yuan for November orders and reduced it to 4,000 yuan for December orders. This move aims to boost sales, following a 14% decline in deliveries in October compared to the previous month. Tesla also recently slashed prices for Model 3 and Model Y cars in China and closed its flagship showroom in the country. The incentives are part of a broader effort to boost sales in the Chinese market.

site_title: Bank of Japan debated impact of future exit from easy policy amid rising prices
summary: The Bank of Japan debated the potential impact of exiting its ultra-easy monetary policy amid rising inflation, with some policymakers expressing openness to a future exit. The central bank's core consumer inflation rate reached an eight-year high of 3.0% in September, prompting concerns about the need for a policy adjustment. While Governor Haruhiko Kuroda ruled out policy tweaks, some board members emphasized the importance of examining the side-effects of prolonged easing and preparing for a potential exit strategy.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda's comment that interest rates would remain low for “two to three years” sent the yen sharply lower, later prompting the government to intervene in the currency market to prop up the yen.
The BOJ remains an outlier among a global wave of central banks tightening monetary policy to combat soaring inflation, as it focuses on supporting a fragile economy.
Fund managers were also bullish on the Japanese yen, as they believe the yen will find its bottom thanks to incipient inflation pressure and Ministry of Finance or Bank of Japan intervention.

site_title: Australia: Financials lift shares higher; James Hardie falls on outlook cut
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 6,945, driven by gains in financial stocks and optimism about the US Federal Reserve easing interest rates. Mining stocks also rose 0.7%, despite a decline in iron ore prices. However, James Hardie Industries fell 14.5% after cutting its earnings forecast for FY23. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand's governor was reappointed for another five-year term.

images.alt_text: Shares of Westpac Banking Corp has fallen 3.9 per cent after the country’s No 3 lender reported a drop in its annual earnings.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks ended higher on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 1.25% to 27,872.11. The rally follows Wall Street's gains, where the dollar retreated and markets looked beyond the US midterm elections. The broader Topix index also rose 1.21% to 1,957.56.

site_title: Malaysia’s industrial production beats expectations with 10.8% growth in September
summary: Malaysia's industrial production index (IPI) rose 10.8% year-on-year in September, exceeding economists' 10.3% average expectation. The growth was driven by robust mining, manufacturing, and electricity output. The increase was slower than August's 13.5% growth due to a base effect. Industrial production continued to rise sequentially, with electrical and electronics products being a key contributor. The result suggests the manufacturing sector remains resilient despite global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's industrial production index soared 13.6 per cent year-on-year in August this year, supported by robust mining production, manufacturing and electricity output.

site_title: Nvidia to sell new chip in China it says meets US export ban
summary: Nvidia has begun producing its A800 GPU, a graphics processing unit for China that meets US export ban rules. The A800 serves as an alternative to the A100 model and cannot be programmed to exceed the US government's speed cap, limiting its usefulness. The move follows the Biden administration's expansion of restrictions on China exports, which has affected Nvidia's revenue. The US is concerned that the processors might be used by the military, adding to existing tensions between the two countries.

site_title: Pelosi says attack on her husband will affect decision whether to retire
summary: US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the recent attack on her husband, Paul Pelosi, will factor into her decision about retiring from Congress, citing the same strain of misinformation that led to the January 6, 2021 Capitol storming. The attack, which left Paul Pelosi with skull fractures, was allegedly motivated by a desire to kidnap and interrogate the speaker. Pelosi, 82, expressed pain and vulnerability, saying she was the intended target and her husband is paying the price. Her decision on retirement may be influenced by the attack, which occurred just weeks before the midterm elections.

images.alt_text: The intruder shouts “Where is Nancy, where is Nancy?” before attacking her husband.

A courtroom sketch of David DePape, 42, who is charged with breaking into US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's San Francisco home and clubbing her husband in the head with a hammer, in court in San Francisco, California, Nov 1, 2022.

site_title: Australia: Shares clock third session of gains on renewed risk appetite
