summary: The S&P/ASX 200 index ended 0.4% higher at 6,958.9 on Tuesday, marking the third consecutive session of gains, driven by heightened risk-on sentiment amid hopes of easing Covid-19 curbs in China and a slowdown in US rate hikes. Financial stocks led the gains, with healthcare stocks also rising 1%. Meanwhile, Santos fell 5.3% due to a 10% expected decline in gas and oil output in 2023.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was up about 0.2 per cent at 6,945 by 2332 GMT on Tuesday.

site_title: Microsoft co-founder’s art collection may surpass US$1b at auction
summary: Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen's art collection, comprising 150 works, is set to surpass the $1 billion mark at an auction at Christie's Manhattan headquarters. The collection, which spans over 500 years of art history, includes masterpieces by artists such as Paul Cezanne, Georges Seurat, and Vincent Van Gogh. The sale is expected to break the current auction record of $922 million, set by the Harry and Linda Macklowe collection earlier this year. The proceeds from the auction will be donated to charity, with Allen's business partner Bill Gates also signing the "Giving Pledge" campaign.

images.alt_text: The two-day event included live performances and artworks by beneficiaries of SAMH and BT B

site_title: Kim Kardashian poised to beat investor suit over crypto hype
summary: Kim Kardashian and Floyd Mayweather Jr. have won a tentative court ruling dismissing a lawsuit accusing the celebrities of scamming investors in the cryptocurrency EthereumMax. The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) alleged that Kardashian and Mayweather broke US rules by touting the tokens without disclosing their payments. Kardashian agreed to pay $1.26 million to settle the allegations, and Mayweather also settled. The judge's ruling notes that the investors' lawyers attempted to mimic the SEC's approach but did not invoke a standard securities fraud claim. A final written order is pending.

images.alt_text: The Mandopop singer promised to “come back whenever he is free”, and it is something his fans will hold him to.

site_title: Foxconn ramps up EV push with stake in US truck maker Lordstown
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics maker, has taken a near-20% stake in Lordstown Motors, a US electric truck maker, for up to $170 million. This deal marks Foxconn's expansion into the electric vehicle (EV) industry, following investments in Fisker and Vedanta. The agreement also gives Foxconn an affiliate two board seats at Lordstown. This move is part of Foxconn's strategy to replicate its dominance in contract electronics manufacturing in the booming EV industry.

images.alt_text: The start of production with Lordstown comes 4 months after Foxconn completed its purchase of the plant.

site_title: Paytm loss widens after Indian fintech firm spends on expansion
summary: Paytm, India's leading digital payments brand, reported a wider second-quarter loss of 5.71 billion rupees, up from 4.73 billion rupees a year earlier, despite 76% revenue growth to 19.14 billion rupees. Total costs increased 60% to 25.61 billion rupees. The company expects to reach operating profitability by the quarter ending September 2023 amid continued revenue growth, despite concerns over mounting losses and competition from other fintech firms.

site_title: About 50% of net GST revenue in 2018 and 2019 paid by tourists, foreigners residing in Singapore
summary: About 50% of net Goods and Services Tax (GST) revenue in 2018 and 2019 came from tourists and foreigners residing in Singapore, with the top 20% of resident households accounting for nearly 20% of the revenue. An average of S$200 million was refunded to tourists each year from 2010 to 2019, with refunds in 2020 and 2021 being significantly lower due to travel restrictions. Despite this, the majority of the remaining 30% of GST revenue is spread across the rest of households and individuals, with support packages available to middle-income households.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan

The government will take "careful review" of whether to proceed with the second GST rate hike in 2024 should the economic situation deteriorate sharply, said Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in Parliament on Monday (Nov 7)

The paper’s authors, KPMG Singapore tax partner Mark Addy and principal consultant of indirect tax Gan Hwee Leng, said the lack of clarity around the GST treatment of the voluntary trade of carbon credits is hindering the young market’s uptake.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of US midterms
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai falling 0.6% amid speculation about China's potential relaxation of strict Covid-19 rules. In contrast, Tokyo stocks gained 1.3% and US stocks rose, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average finishing up 1.3% and the S&P 500 rising 1.0%. Investors await US inflation data on Thursday and look to the US midterm elections, which polls suggest could lead to a Republican takeover of Congress and potential policy uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong shares dipped slightly at the open but quickly recovered to add 1.4 per cent – adding to a jump of more than 5 per cent in the previous session.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Tuesday, down 1.41 points or 0.10% to 1440.71, with 203.95 million lots traded worth RM50.93 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 169 to 109.

site_title: China downgrades priority of economy for future legislation
summary: China is downgrading the priority of economic development for future legislation, sparking concerns that the government is prioritizing security and ideology over economic growth. A draft amendment to the Legislation Law, submitted to the National People's Congress, removes the emphasis on economic development and reform, instead focusing on the Communist Party's leadership and Marxist principles. This move amplifies concerns that the primacy of economic growth is being de-emphasized, contradicting President Xi Jinping's pledge that economic development remains the CCP's top priority.

site_title: Condo resale volumes slide 11.6% in October; price growth slows: SRX, 99.co
summary: Condo resale volumes decreased 11.6% in October, according to SRX and 99.co, with overall resale prices growing 0.3% for the month and 10.5% for the year. The Core Central Region (CCR) saw a 1.1% drop in resale prices, while the Rest of Central Region (RCR) and Outside Central Region (OCR) recorded 0.6% increases. Resale volumes were down 24.2% year-on-year but 0.7% higher than the five-year average for October.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Condominiums and HDB flats as viewed from CapitaSpring on Feb 9, 2022.

Prices of non-landed homes saw an increase of 4.4 per cent in Q3 after notching a 3.6 per cent increase in the previous quarter. By region, prices of non-landed homes in the Outside Central Region (OCR) saw the biggest jump at 7.5 per cent, thanks to major launches during the quarter, such as AMO Residence, Lentor Modern and Sky Eden@Bedok.
Generic properties in Singapore
URA does not prescribe sizes for different unit types within a development, provided they follow the broader set of measures that are already in place.
Homes in the Central Area will need to be at least 70 square metres for developments seeking approvals from 18 Jan 2023 onwards.

site_title: Analysts maintain ‘buy’ on SIA amid weakening cargo market concerns
summary: Analysts maintain a "buy" rating on Singapore Airlines due to growing passenger demand and a strong expected recovery in the airline's passenger business. OCBC raised its target to S$6.28, while CGS-CIMB lowered its target to S$5.97, citing concerns about a weakening cargo market and rising competition from South-east Asian carriers. The airline has redeemed its mandatory convertible bonds and is expected to redeploy more capacity in the coming months, with analysts noting that rising competition could pose a significant challenge.

images.alt_text: SIA on Friday swung to a second-quarter profit and declared its first dividend in three years as international borders reopened and travel demand rebounded.
SIA resumes dividend payments, with an interim dividend of S$0.10 to be pain in December.

site_title: Malaysia’s ruling coalition pledges basic household income as inflation bites
summary: Malaysia's ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition has pledged a "Basic Household Income" to households earning less than 2,208 ringgit (S$655) monthly, aiming to address rising inflation. The coalition also promises a 2% cut in income tax, free higher education, and measures to promote affordable eco-friendly vehicles. The pledge comes as the country faces rising inflation, a currency near a multi-decade low, and economic recovery concerns. BN is the last party to announce its election manifesto, ahead of polls in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Ahmad Zahid Hamidi Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand India Trust, NetLink NBN Trust, Metech
summary: CapitaLand India Trust has partnered with Indian property developer L&T Realty to develop nearly six million square feet of prime office space in India. NetLink NBN Trust is constructing a new central office at Sembawang Road at a total cost of around S$120 million over two years. These developments may impact trading of their securities.

site_title: Singtel co-led consortium to build US$300m undersea fibre optic cable system
summary: Singtel co-leads a US$300 million consortium to build a 6,000km undersea fibre optic cable system, known as the Asia Link Cable System (ALC), connecting Singapore, Hong Kong, Brunei, the Philippines, and Hainan, China. The system will enhance internet connectivity and satisfy rising demand for higher-bandwidth solutions in the region, reducing dependency on single network providers. Expected to be completed in the third quarter of 2025, the project leverages Singtel's technical expertise and is part of the company's efforts to drive economic growth in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: UOBKH forecasts a provision of around S$240 million for Singtel — including an anticipated regulatory fine of A$2.2 million (S$2 million) — in Q2 2023
Replying to a question about Singtel leadership’s takeaways from the digital life investments, group chief executive Yuen Kuan Moon pointed to “lessons learned in the past”.

site_title: Gold flat as investors seek direction from US inflation data
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $1,675.29 per ounce on Tuesday, as investors awaited US inflation data that may influence the Federal Reserve's rate-hike narrative. Rising interest rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, making gold less attractive. Despite a three-week peak in bullion prices the previous session, driven by a weaker US dollar, US gold futures fell 0.2% to $1,677.30. Investors are seeking direction from the inflation data, which is expected to shape the Fed's monetary policy.

images.alt_text: The hallmark details on a one kilogram gold bar are seen at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: China banks are now valued like US peers at depths of 2008 crash
summary: China's four biggest banks, including Industrial & Commercial Bank of China, are valued at near record low levels, averaging 0.4 of their book value, amid pessimism about the banking sector. This is comparable to the 2008 financial crisis, where US lenders traded at similar lows. The banks face growing concerns about bad debt due to the country's Covid Zero lockdowns and property crisis, which could impact loan losses and net margins. Analysts expect the banks' shares to remain volatile until the property market stabilizes, potentially presenting a long-term buying opportunity.

images.alt_text: Zhong Shanshan, whose listed companies are water bottler Nongfu Spring and vaccine developer Beijing Wantai Biological Pharmacy Enterprise, took first place on the Hurun Rich list with a fortune of US$65 billion.

site_title: IMDA, Huawei launch incubator focusing on Web3, fintech and more
summary: Huawei Cloud and the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) launched the Spark Incubator Programme, a Singapore-based incubator for early-stage startups in fintech, Web3, and other areas. The programme offers resources and funding, including up to $60,000 in Huawei Cloud credits, to support startups' growth to Series A and expansion in Singapore and Asean. The incubator aims to support up to 12 startups per cohort over five months, with the first cohort starting in November 2022 and subsequent cohorts launching in May 2023.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

Credit, rather than equity, is helping tech companies keep their operations going while avoiding a damaging “down round”, investors and tech startup heads said at the Web Summit conference in Lisbon this week.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened higher on Tuesday, Nov 8, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.27% to 16,640.60, extending recent gains despite China's continued zero-Covid policies. The Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.13% and the Shenzhen Composite Index dipped 0.20%. Traders remained optimistic, brushing off new US threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Take-Two tumbles after forecast for bookings misses estimates
summary: Take-Two Interactive Software reduced its annual forecast for net bookings to $5.5 billion, citing an industry-wide spending slowdown and strong dollar fluctuations. The company's shares plummeted 15% in extended trading. CEO Strauss Zelnick attributed the reduced forecast to production shifts, cautious macroeconomic views, and a decline in in-game purchases. Despite this, Take-Two remains optimistic about the growth potential of mobile games and expects sequential years of growth from its development pipeline.

images.alt_text: Take-Two Interactive Software gained in late trading after fourth-quarter earnings topped analysts' estimates, boosted by games such as NBA 2K22, though a forecast for the coming year suggests that an industrywide slump is poised to crimp sales.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index rising 0.71% or 194.51 points to 27,722.15. This follows Wall Street's gains, where the dollar retreated and markets looked past US midterm elections. The broader Topix index also rose 0.63% or 12.21 points to 1,946.30, extending a rally that has been ongoing.

site_title: Taiwan exports set to fall again on plummeting Chinese demand
summary: Taiwan's exports are expected to contract 6% in October, the worst fall since January 2020, due to plummeting Chinese demand and global economic slowdown. China, which buys 40% of Taiwan's exports, reported a 4.6% decline in purchases from Taiwan, marking the fifth consecutive month of declines. The contraction is expected to weaken Taiwan's export momentum in the fourth quarter, with economists predicting negative growth for the remainder of 2022. This worsens the outlook for Taiwan's economy, which is projected to grow about 3.2% this year.

images.alt_text: Photographer: Lam Yik Fei/Bloomberg

site_title: Lyft shares plunge after revenue forecast disappoints
summary: Lyft's shares plummeted 9% after the company forecast current-quarter revenue below Wall Street estimates, despite a surge in active riders and rising prices. The stock has lost nearly 70% of its value this year, underperforming Uber, which has declined 33%. Lyft's operating profit exceeded estimates, but its net loss widened to $422.2 million due to impairment charges related to its autonomous vehicle startup stake.

images.alt_text: The Lyft Driver Hub in Los Angeles, California. The increase in the service fee averages less than US50 cents per trip nationally, a Lyft spokesperson said.
Third-quarter sales jumped 72 per cent to US$8.34 billion, Uber said on Tuesday (Nov 1) in a statement.

site_title: Oil falls in choppy trade on mixed China Covid-19 signals
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with Brent crude futures dropping 65 cents to $97.92 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude falling 82 cents to $91.79 a barrel. The decline came despite mixed signals on China's Covid-19 restrictions, with some analysts expecting a potential reopening to tighten supply and drive up prices. However, Chinese officials reiterated their commitment to strict containment measures, weighing on the market.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures dropped US$1.20, or 1.2 per cent, to US$97.37 a barrel by 0227 GMT on Monday, after hitting as low as US$96.50 earlier.

site_title: South Korea urges more ESG focus on women to address fertility crisis
summary: South Korea's labour minister, Lee Jung-sik, urges companies to prioritize gender equality and ESG (Environmental, Social, and Governance) practices to address the country's low fertility rate, which reached 0.81 babies per woman last year, a world record low. He emphasizes that helping women balance work and family life is crucial to addressing the issue. The comments are seen as a significant step by a cabinet member of President Yoon Suk Yeol's administration to tackle the crisis.

images.alt_text: A wide-ranging probe is under way into the exact cause of the crush, and an investigative team on Wednesday (Nov 2) raided multiple police offices, including in the district where the disaster happened.

site_title: China’s super-rich see fortunes plunge as economy slows
summary: China's super-rich saw their fortunes plummet by 18% in 2022 due to the Russia-Ukraine war, zero-Covid measures, and falling stock markets. The Hurun Rich List reported 1,305 individuals with a minimum net worth of 5 billion yuan, down 11% from last year, with a total wealth of US$3.5 trillion. The number of dollar billionaires dropped by 239 to 946, and those with US$10 billion fell by 29 to 56. The list attributed the decline to the global economic outlook, exacerbated by China's economic slowdown and strict Covid policies.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product in that province shrank 0.5 per cent in the first nine months of the year, compared with growth of 1.6 per cent in the first half of the year.
Li Qiang, 63, was born in Wenzhou, a coastal city in Zhejiang province that emerged as a hotbed of China’s private-sector economy in the 1980s.
Chinese President Xi Jinping speaking during the opening ceremony of the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China at the Great Hall of People in Beijing, China, 16 October 2022.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at Tuesday's open, tracking Wall Street gains, as markets looked past the US midterm elections. The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 4.32 points to 3,145.63, with Sembcorp Marine and MarcoPolo Marine among the top gainers. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also rose, while CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust fell 0.5% due to operational growth in its third quarter.

images.alt_text: Capitaland India Trust has tied up with Indian property developer L&T Realty to develop nearly 6 million square feet of prime office space in India.

site_title: Rich nations greenlight South Africa’s coal transition plan
summary: Wealthy nations, including Britain, France, Germany, the US, and the EU, have agreed to provide $8.5 billion in grants and loans to help South Africa transition away from coal, with 80% of its electricity generation reliant on the fossil fuel. The funding will support decommissioning coal power plants and investing in renewable energy. The deal, part of the Just Energy Transition Partnership, aims to aid developing countries in decarbonizing their economies, following pressure from the UN's COP27 climate summit in Egypt.

images.alt_text: The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources
While robust coal demand and high prices are helping to prop up companies’ earnings now, some coal producers are already taking steps to diversify their business and revenue streams.
The Sharm el-Sheikh International Convention Centre, on the first day of the COP27 climate summit, in Egypt's Red Sea resort city, on November 6, 2022
Guterres asked countries to agree to phase out the use of coal, one of the most carbon-intense fuels, by 2040 globally,

site_title: Sembcorp should still account for emissions of India coal business even after disposal: Non-profit organisation
summary: A non-profit organization, the Anthropocene Fixed Income Institute, recommends that Sembcorp Industries continue to account for the emissions of its Indian coal power business after selling the asset, as it will provide financing for the buyer. Sembcorp has stated that there is no ambiguity in its emissions commitments, but the non-profit argues that Sembcorp would be shifting emissions from operational to financial exposure. The issue highlights the challenge of dealing with thermal coal-related assets, with investors and finance institutions increasingly excluding thermal coal.

images.alt_text: Kenneth Lim
Sembcorp Industries is staring at S$54 million in fines and civil claims for its water-treatment joint venture in China's illegal discharge of wastewater.

site_title: EU wants Airbnb, rivals to share bookings data with authorities
summary: The European Commission has proposed rules requiring short-term home rental companies like Airbnb to share data on the number of people using their platforms. The aim is to balance the interests of cities and rural areas, addressing concerns that popular tourist destinations are losing affordable housing due to Airbnb. The proposal also seeks to tackle the patchwork of national laws regulating the sector.

site_title: China deflation fears rise as demand weakens on Covid outbreaks
summary: China is facing increasing deflation pressure due to subdued demand amid an economic slowdown, driven by Covid outbreaks and controls. The producer price index likely fell into deflation in October, with consumer price growth moderating to 2.4% from 2.8% in September. The weak demand has damaged spending, export demand, and home construction, and has raised concerns about deflationary spiral and potential impact on corporate profits. Policymakers are under pressure to boost demand, which could also help curb global inflation pressures.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers are seen on a crane above containers at the Yangshan Deep Water Port in Shanghai, China January 13, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Australia business activity stays strong in October, mood darkens
summary: Australia's business activity remained strong in October, beating expectations with a business conditions index of +22, still above its long-run average. However, confidence in the economy decreased, with a measure of confidence easing 5 points to 0, below its long-run average. The Reserve Bank of Australia has lifted interest rates to a nine-year peak of 2.85% to combat inflation, despite this, businesses reported strong sales and profitability. Rising costs and a dip in forward orders took a toll on confidence, potentially signaling a slowdown ahead.

images.alt_text: Visitors at Pitt Street Mall in Sydney, Australia, on Wednesday, Dec. 15, 2021. Australian household sentiment declined this month as concerns mounted about the new omicron variant of coronavirus in the nation's recently re-opened eastern states of New South Wales and Victoria. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Oracle sells US$7b of debt to help fund Cerner purchase
summary: Oracle has sold $7 billion of debt to help fund its acquisition of medical-records systems provider Cerner. The software maker increased its previous $4.4 billion term loan by $1.3 billion, which will be used to pay down a bridge loan used to fund the acquisition. The bond sale, managed by Citigroup, Bank of America, and others, yields 2.55 percentage points above Treasuries. This move comes after Fitch Ratings downgraded Oracle to BBB from BBB+, citing concerns over the company's credit rating profile.

images.alt_text: Oracle completed its acquisition of Cerner in June.

site_title: Australia consumer sentiment drops to lowest since April 2020 on rates
summary: Australia's consumer sentiment has dropped to its lowest level in 2-1/2 years, with Westpac's index falling 6.9% to 78 in November, according to a statement on Tuesday. The decline is attributed to higher interest rates and surging inflation, with pessimists outnumbering optimists. The Reserve Bank's policy tightening cycle, initiated in May, has led to a 2.85% cash rate, causing concern about family finances. Consumer spending is expected to slow in the period ahead, with Christmas spending plans also being subdued.

site_title: BofA selling ESG bonds even as other big banks snub debt markets
summary: Bank of America (BofA) is selling US$11.9 billion worth of sustainability bonds, marking its first ESG debt offering this year, amid rising borrowing costs and reduced issuance by other major US banks. The six-year bonds may yield 2 percentage points above Treasuries, with the bank issuing bonds since 2013, making it the biggest issuer of ESG debt among US corporate and financial issuers. This move comes as the six biggest US banks have raised US$8.5 billion since their last earnings report, less than expected by Barclays.

images.alt_text: BofA’s report also found strong payroll spending per small-business client, the result of both higher wages and increased hiring.

site_title: China’s new No 2 faces challenge to make economy hum again
summary: China's new No 2, Li Qiang, faces a challenge to revive the country's economy, which has been hindered by demographic shifts, US technology sanctions, and anti-Covid measures. Li Qiang, who has been a pro-business advocate, is set to become premier in the coming months, overseeing key economic ministries. His tenure is expected to focus on encouraging high-tech investment and balancing economic growth with environmental protection and curbing real estate speculation. Li's promotion comes after a three-decade career in local and provincial politics, during which he worked under Xi Jinping and helped smooth Elon Musk's path to opening Tesla's overseas factory.

images.alt_text: Consumer prices rises in China have been muted, in stark contrast to most other countries, with the weak price rises driven by subdued demand amid an economic slowdown.

site_title: China’s trade unexpectedly shrinks as Covid curbs, global slowdown jolt demand
summary: China's trade unexpectedly contracted in October, with outbound shipments down 0.3% from a year earlier, as Covid curbs at home and global recession risks dented demand. This marks the first simultaneous slump since May 2020. The data highlights the challenge for policymakers in navigating a struggling economy, with analysts warning of further gloom for exporters and the country's manufacturing sector. The weak trade data also hurt the yuan currency, with a 0.4% decline against the dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Workers are seen on a crane above containers at the Yangshan Deep Water Port in Shanghai, China January 13, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Europe: Shares at seven-week peak as travel stocks shine
summary: Europe's benchmark Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% to a seven-week high, driven by gains in travel and technology stocks, including Flutter Entertainment and Ryanair. Luxury stocks, however, declined due to China's reopening uncertainty. The index closed up 1.6%, with Irish stocks jumping 1.9% after Ryanair's strong first-half profits. Investors await the US midterm elections, which may impact European stocks, with analysts predicting a split government.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 0.5 per cent to 7,300.54 points.

site_title: Democrats on defensive as Republicans encroach on ‘blue’ New York
summary: Democrats are scrambling as Republican candidate Lee Zeldin gains substantial ground in New York's gubernatorial and congressional races, with pivotal contests narrowing. A Trump-backer, Zeldin has brought the gubernatorial race within 10 points, sparking concern about a potential upset. President Biden and other Democrats have flown in to campaign, framing the race as a choice between fundamentally different visions of America. If turnout is low, Zeldin could win, with some predicting it as the most realistic chance for a Republican to win a statewide office in New York in decades.

images.alt_text: While many voters believe that democracy is under threat in America, they remain mostly apathetic about it and are more concerned about economic issues, including rising inflation.
Former US President Barack Obama and US President Joe Biden participate in a rally in support of Democratic US Senate candidate John Fetterman in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, on Nov 5, 2022.

Republicans have made the economy their No 1 issue, and accuse President Biden and Democrats of fuelling inflation with major spending packages and then ignoring the economic plight of American families faced with soaring energy and food prices.

site_title: Singapore ranks 5th in new index tracking sustainable global trade practices
summary: Singapore ranks 5th among 30 economies in the Sustainable Trade Index, which measures the readiness and capacity to participate in the global trading system in a manner that supports long-term economic growth, environmental protection, and societal development. The index, developed by the Institute for Management Development and the Hinrich Foundation, assesses 70 indicators across three pillars: economic, societal, and environmental. Singapore excels in environmental standards and participates in trade quality conventions, but has room for improvement in labor standards. The top five economies are New Zealand, the UK, Hong Kong, Japan, and Singapore, with the latter ranking 2nd in the economic pillar and 9th and 10th in the societal and environmental pillars, respectively.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

The consequences of the world’s failure to curb emissions are catastrophic, and not just for the Pacific islands. Climate-related disasters are proliferating; Florida in September suffered its deadliest hurricane since 1935.
Among names in the list of signatories are AIGCC members UOB Asset Management, Eastspring Investments Group and BNP Paribas Asset Management.
Today, the decreasing costs of renewable energy generation, coupled with better efficiency and storage solutions, is making clean energy more accessible than ever.

site_title: Tesla’s post-Twitter selloff pushes stock to a 17-month low
summary: Tesla shares have dropped to a 17-month low after CEO Elon Musk's purchase of Twitter. The stock closed down 5% to $197.08, following a 12% decline since Musk's Twitter acquisition. Investors worry Musk is spreading himself too thin, particularly with Tesla facing challenges such as slowing car demand, supply-chain issues, and high raw material costs. The decline is also linked to the broader risk-off market trend.

site_title: Coal market in danger of more company exits, stranded assets as challenges rise
summary: Coal companies face challenges as robust demand and high prices temporarily prop up earnings. However, some producers, like Golden Energy and Resources, are diversifying their business and revenue streams. The industry faces difficulties in securing funding, with banks halting coal project financing and a growing focus on environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors. This could lead to severe impacts, including stranded assets, as financing for coal expansion becomes increasingly difficult. The lack of available funds could hurt coal producers' growth plans.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources

Smoke rises from an illegally lit fire in an Amazon rainforest reserve, south of Novo Progresso in Para state, Brazil, in 2020. Among items on the agenda at Cop27 climate change summit, which convened on Sunday (Nov 6), is a push by delegates to speed action to protect forests between now and 2030.
A zero carbon economy could hardly be counted as a victory for the path towards net zero if it comes at the expense of the livelihoods of local communities.

site_title: Blue tick accounts suspended from Twitter after impersonating @elonmusk
summary: VERIFIED Twitter accounts with millions of followers, including comedian Kathy Griffin, have been suspended after changing their names to Elon Musk's, in a test of the platform's new owner's commitment to free speech. Musk, a self-described "free speech absolutist," tweeted that impersonation without clear labeling as parody would be permanently suspended. The suspensions have sparked a debate, with some users, including actor Mark Hamill, using the hashtag #FreeKathy to call for Griffin's reinstatement.

images.alt_text: Earlier on Friday, Musk said Twitter had experienced “a massive drop in revenue”.
Some of the Twitter staff who are being asked to return were laid off by mistake, according to two people familiar with the moves.
“Twitter needs to become by far the most accurate source of information about the world. That is our mission,” Musk said on Sunday (Nov 6).
Tesla shares have been struggling for the most part this year, swept up in the broader risk-off market trend.

site_title: Activision Blizzard beats estimates, boosted by mobile games
summary: Activision Blizzard reported a 2.6% decline in net bookings to $1.83 billion in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company's mobile gaming division grew 20% to $1 billion, driven by the popularity of games like Candy Crush and Diablo Immortal. Adjusted earnings per share were 68 cents, ahead of estimates. The strong performance was attributed to the success of Diablo Immortal's release in the first half of the year and its subsequent release in China.

images.alt_text: The US software company is betting on the acquisition to help it compete better with leaders Tencent and Sony, with the latter being a critic of the deal.
The launch of Overwatch 2 already had long queue times for players waiting to get a chance to play the new game.

site_title: China’s business elite sees the country that let them thrive slipping away
summary: China's business elite is facing uncertainty and anxiety as the country's leader, Xi Jinping, prioritizes security over the economy. Xi's near-absolute power and emphasis on security over markets has led to a "political depression" among businesspeople, with many considering withholding investment or leaving the country. The government's control over nearly every aspect of society has reduced agency for Chinese people, and tech entrepreneurs who previously operated with relative freedom are now seeing politics in command. Many are considering emigration to countries with more favorable business environments, fearing increased taxes and surveillance.

images.alt_text: China once rivalled the US for capital invested in startups, before president Xi Jinping’s administration embarked on sweeping efforts to reform the practices of giants like Alibaba Group and Tencent.

site_title: Bank of England wants more transparency for ‘non banks’ after gilts turmoil
summary: The Bank of England is pushing for greater transparency in the global non-bank sector, which includes pension funds, insurers, and investment funds, after the £1.6 trillion Liability Driven Investment (LDI) sector struggled to meet collateral calls in September. Executive director Sarah Breeden says transparency is a first step in addressing systemic risks posed by poorly-managed leverage and liquidity risks. Regulators will need to ensure leverage is well-managed, and consider broad market-wide measures to control excessive leverage, with the goal of reducing central bank intervention and improving stress-testing for risks.

images.alt_text: The Bank of England in the City of London. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: How inflation is changing the face of retirement
summary: Inflation is significantly impacting retirement planning in Singapore, with a sharp drop in confidence among individuals, particularly those in the mid-high income bracket. According to the Endowus Retirement Report, 42% of those in this bracket are now not confident about retirement adequacy, up from 24% last year. High inflation is reducing purchasing power, with a 1% annual rate reducing it by 26% over 30 years, and a 3% rate reducing it by almost 60%. Only 48% of Singaporeans are open to investing to tackle inflation, highlighting the need for a long-term approach to retirement planning and investing.

images.alt_text: US wheat prices, which spiked following Russia's first attacks on Ukraine, have fallen 31.8 per cent from their March highs.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher with focus on midterm elections
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, November 7, 2022, driven by investor focus on the upcoming midterm elections that will determine control of Congress. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 50.88 points, or 0.16%, to 32,454.10, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained ground. The rallies came after a volatile week, with markets seemingly brushing off concerns over US-China trade tensions and new Trump threats.

site_title: US$3b crypto seizure from Silk Road scammer
summary: US prosecutors have seized nearly $3.4 billion in Bitcoin from a property developer, James Zhong, who scammed the dark web marketplace Silk Road over a decade ago. Zhong, a 32-year-old computer science graduate, defrauded Silk Road of over 53,000 Bitcoin in 2012. The Bitcoin was found in an underground safe and a single-board computer in Zhong's home, and he has since surrendered over 1,000 more coins. Zhong pleaded guilty to wire fraud and will help prosecutors access the remaining coins.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s Chimera Capital launches US$2b private credit fund
summary: Abu Dhabi-based investment firm Chimera Capital has launched a US$2 billion private credit fund in partnership with US alternative asset manager Alpha Wave Global. The fund will provide senior secured, floating rate loans for companies globally, with a primary focus on the US, Canada, UK, EU, and Australia. This launch follows significant growth for Chimera and comes as part of Abu Dhabi's ambition to establish itself as a global hub for capital solutions.

site_title: US: Stocks rise ahead of midterm vote
summary: US stocks rose for a second consecutive session on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average gaining 1.3% to finish at 32,827.00. The dollar's retreat and reduced concerns over midterm elections contributed to the gains. Analysts welcomed the prospect of Washington gridlock, which reduces policy uncertainty and has historically led to higher stock market performance after midterm votes. Despite potential changes in government control, stocks are expected to continue rising, with the seasonally strong period of November through April potentially supporting equities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A Wall St. street sign is seen near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., September 17, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid//File Photo

site_title: Singapore in talks to establish green shipping corridor with key US ports
summary: Singapore is in talks with the Port of Los Angeles, the Port of Long Beach, and C40 Cities to establish a green shipping corridor focused on low- and zero-carbon fuels for bunkering and digital tools to support the deployment of ships on such fuel. The corridor aims to decarbonize the industry, catalyze investment in green infrastructure, and support the decarbonization aim of COP27. The partnership will work closely with stakeholders in the maritime and energy value chains to accelerate the deployment of low- and zero-carbon emission solutions.

images.alt_text: Decarbonising the power sector is key in the city state’s race to net zero by 2050 as the sector currently contributes about 40 per cent of Singapore’s total carbon emissions.

MOU signing ceremony between Keppel Infrastructure and Greenko. Standing: Keppel's chief executive officer Loh China Hua (first from left), Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong (second from right), High Commissioner of India to Singapore, Periasamy Kumaran, (third from left), Greenko's joint managing director and founder Mahesh Kolli (fourth from left). Seated: Keppel Infrastructure's CEO Cindy Lim (left) and Greenko's chief executive and founder Anil Kumar Chalamalasetty (right).

site_title: Why Asia’s push for a ‘rescue culture’ is a win for business
summary: Asia's push for a 'rescue culture' is gaining momentum, providing businesses in distress with more options for restructuring. Updates to the region's insolvency laws, such as Malaysia's new corporate rescue mechanisms, and judicial interpretations in China, prioritize loans provided by creditors during restructuring. This trend gives debtors more space to engineer a turnaround, potentially making complete liquidation less beneficial. The "rescue culture" offers a more favorable outcome for businesses, allowing them to continue trading while addressing financial issues.

images.alt_text: Singapore is looking to overhaul the judicial management regime to ensure that it is not used as a precursor to winding up.

site_title: Greener economies can reduce energy price ‘spikes’, says Lagarde
summary: European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde says transitioning to greener energy sources can reduce the risk of energy price spikes, which have contributed to a 10.7% rise in eurozone consumer prices. Lagarde argues that switching to renewable energy would lead to lower and more stable inflation rates, making economies work better. This comes as the eurozone faces a threatened "mild" recession due to the Ukraine war and energy price increases.

site_title: EU threatens US over electric car subsidies
summary: The European Union threatened to take retaliatory measures against the US for electric car subsidies that favor domestic manufacturers. The EU's Internal Market Commissioner, Thierry Breton, stated that the US tax breaks are "contrary to World Trade Organization rules" and could lead to a tariff war. France's Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire estimated $10 billion in investments at stake. The EU and US have set up a task force to resolve the issue, but Germany, a key car industry powerhouse, has warned that the US measures could trigger a tariff war.

images.alt_text: Fully electric vehicles (EVs), plug-in hybrids and hybrids made up less than 40 per cent of all sales in the same period last year, the European Automobile Manufacturers Association said.

site_title: Forecasting startup Stemly thrives in a time of supply chain woes, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary:
Shareholder capitalism is undergoing a significant shift due to the increasing availability and accessibility of data. This data-driven era is transforming the way companies operate, invest, and make decisions. Key findings include: 

- Companies are now prioritizing data-driven decision-making over traditional shareholder value maximization.
- Data analytics is becoming a key differentiator for companies, driving innovation and growth.
- The rise of data-driven capitalism is leading to a more nuanced understanding of value creation and wealth distribution.
- As data becomes increasingly important, the traditional shareholder-centric model is giving way to a more collaborative approach to capitalism.

site_title: Gates Foundation gives US$1.4b climate help to smallholder farmers
summary: The Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation has pledged $1.4 billion to help smallholder farmers in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia cope with climate change impacts. This funding will support climate smart agriculture projects, digital technologies, and innovations to improve food security and resilience. The foundation's co-chairs, Bill Gates and Melinda French Gates, emphasized the need for increased funding to address the climate crisis, which is causing harm to entire regions and economies. The funding is part of efforts to scale up adaptation finance and support vulnerable communities.

images.alt_text: Bill Gates is donating US$20 billion to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation this month as the philanthropic behemoth plans to speed up its pace of giving.

site_title: COP27: We’re on a highway to climate hell, UN boss says
summary: UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres warned countries at COP27 that they face a choice: work together to cut emissions or risk climate catastrophe. He urged countries to phase out the use of coal by 2040 globally, a move seen as a crucial step in mitigating climate change. The call to action came as governments gathered for two weeks of talks on how to avert the worst of climate change, amidst distractions from the war in Ukraine and energy shortages. Guterres' speech set an urgent tone, emphasizing the need for collective action to ensure a livable future.

images.alt_text: epa10258620 United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres visits the Temple of Literature in Hanoi, Vietnam 22 October 2022. Guterres is on an official visit to Vietnam from 21 to 22 October.  EPA-EFE/LUONG THAI LINH

site_title: Investment banking still has upside potential despite revenue slide: JPMorgan president Daniel Pinto
summary: JPMorgan Chase's President and COO Daniel Pinto believes investment banking still has upside potential despite a 43% revenue decline to $78 billion this year, compared to a record $132 billion in 2021. The decline is similar to levels seen in the 2010s, and Pinto notes that payments and retail functions have performed well. He attributes the slowdown to weak activity in equity and debt capital markets, as well as mergers and acquisitions. Pinto is cautiously optimistic about JPMorgan's future, citing the bank's diversified franchise and its ability to adapt to technological changes.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng
China stocks weakened further this week. Chinese president Xi Jinping's consolidation of power is seen as a major risk.
Economic conditions are going to “tighten meaningfully from here,” Goldman Sachs Group chief executive officer David Solomon said at Saudi Arabia’s Future Investment Initiative conference in Riyadh.

site_title: Two Metech substantial shareholders seek EGM to be appointed directors
summary: Two substantial Metech International shareholders, Ang Poh Guan and Ng Cheng Huat, have requested an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to consider and vote on removing CEO Samantha Hua Lei and appointing new directors. They hold a combined 15.07% stake in the company, citing "grave doubts" about Chay Yiowmin's ability to act as an independent director. The EGM would also consider appointing Ang as an executive director and Ng as a non-executive and non-independent director. The company has announced it will seek legal advice and provide further updates to shareholders.

images.alt_text: Besides the removal of the CEO, Ng in his requisition letter is also seeking a resolution that the appointment of any director to the company’s board from the date of the requisition to the date of the EGM be invalidated and such directors (if any) to be removed from office with effect from the date of the EGM.

site_title: Tensions between crypto’s two richest CEOs spill into markets
summary: Tensions between Binance CEO Zhao "CZ" Changpeng and FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried have spilled over into the crypto market, with Binance announcing plans to sell its $530 million holding of FTT, the native token of FTX. The move comes after "recent revelations" about Alameda Research's balance sheet, which CoinDesk reported is comprised largely of FTT. FTT's price fell, and traders rushed to withdraw funds from FTX, with prices of most cryptocurrencies declining on Monday.

site_title: UK faces £50b fiscal hole, government sources say
summary: UK Finance Minister Jeremy Hunt plans to fill a £50 billion fiscal hole with £30 billion of spending cuts and £20 billion in tax rises, aiming to restore financial market confidence. Early drafts included up to £35 billion of spending cuts and £25 billion of tax rises. Hunt's statement, due on Nov 17, follows his predecessor Kwasi Kwarteng's tax-cutting plan, which led to the resignation of Prime Minister Liz Truss.

images.alt_text: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, and Chancellor of the Exchequer Jeremy Hunt held a “sober” meeting on Thursday to run through their options.

site_title: China angered as UK trade minister visits Taiwan
summary: UK Trade Minister Greg Hands visited Taiwan for the first in-person talks since the pandemic, sparking China's rebuke. Hands described Taiwan as a "vital partner" for the UK in the Pacific, highlighting the island's global technology hubs. The visit aims to boost ties and secure Taiwanese supply chains, particularly in semiconductors and electronic components. China claims Taiwan as its territory and urged Britain to stop official exchanges with the island, while the UK denied any change towards diplomatic recognition of China.

images.alt_text: Total third-quarter exports rose only 3.38 per cent from a year earlier in US dollar terms, impacted by high global inflation, Covid-19 lockdowns in Taiwan’s largest export market China and generally weaker global demand.

site_title: Extra S$1.4b for GST Assurance Package; 2024 hike to be reviewed if economy ‘sharply deterioriates’: DPM Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced an additional S$1.4 billion for the Goods and Services Tax (GST) Assurance Package in Budget 2023, bringing the total to around S$8 billion. This move aims to help households cope with rising inflation. The government will review the second GST rate hike in 2024 if the economic situation deteriorates sharply, citing elevated inflation and expected rising household expenditure.

images.alt_text: Tessa Oh
