summary: In a recent episode of BT Money Hacks, co-founder of the Smart Investor, David Kuo, discussed how to outperform inflation. Kuo emphasizes that investors should focus on stock markets and companies that can increase prices, rather than traditional investments such as bonds. He also advises against changing investment strategies during periods of inflation and recession. Key takeaways include continuing to invest and diversifying one's portfolio to beat inflation. The conversation aims to provide listeners with useful financial tips to protect their portfolio returns in uncertain economic times.

images.alt_text: How affrodable is critical illness coverage? Correspondent Howie Lim finds out from Colin Chan from Great Eastern.
With low correlation to general market performance, is wine your best hedge against inflation?

site_title: Westpac profit meets estimates on rising rates, cost cutting
summary: Westpac's profit met analyst estimates, driven by rising interest rates and cost-cutting measures. The bank's cash earnings were A$5.28 billion in the year to Sept 30, meeting expectations. Despite a slowing economy and potential stress on households, Westpac CEO Peter King stated the bank is now "simpler and stronger." The bank plans to continue cost reductions and has completed the sale of nine businesses. A final dividend of 64 Australian cents per share will be paid.

images.alt_text: Signage at a Westpac Banking Corp. (Westpac) branch in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, Aug. 5, 2022. Australia’s central bank lifted its inflation and wage growth forecasts while predicting unemployment will remain under 4% through mid-2024, underscoring the need for even tighter monetary policy. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: The fall of big tech is boosting stock quants on Wall Street
summary: The recent tech stock crash has benefited factor investors, who focus on math-derived traits of equities. These funds are typically underweight on tech megacaps and diversify their exposures. The tech stock crash, with a US$568 billion loss in market value, has weakened the power of Big Tech companies, allowing broader indexes to gain ground. The S&P 500 has hit its lowest capitalisation-weighted value since 2019, reversing the dominance of tech stocks in the past.

images.alt_text: Sharmin Mossavar-Rahmani has remained relatively sanguine about the outlook for US equities.
American employers added 261,000 workers last month, far more than economists had forecast, though this eased from a revised 315,000 figure in September.

site_title: US dollar drops as non-farm payrolls show mixed results
summary: The US dollar dropped 1.1% against the yen and 1.9% against the dollar index after the October non-farm payrolls report showed a higher unemployment rate and lower wage inflation, contradicting expectations of a slowdown. The report also showed 261,000 new jobs added, beating forecasts of 200,000. Despite this, the Federal Reserve may slow the pace of future rate hikes, with Fed funds futures pricing in a 52.5% chance of a 75-basis-point interest rate hike next month.

images.alt_text: The pound initially slid by as much as 1.7 per cent against the US dollar after the BOE’s statement and dropped against the euro before recovering some ground.

site_title: Digital for Life movement in Singapore gets S$1m boost
summary: DBS Foundation has pledged S$1 million to support the Digital for Life (DFL) movement in Singapore, a nationwide initiative to drive digital literacy. The funding, matched by the government, will help around 100,000 Singaporeans, mainly senior citizens, youths, hawkers, and individuals with special needs, over the next two years. DBS will deploy 2,500 employees to run 800 workshops at branches, covering topics such as digital banking and scam prevention. The initiative aims to create a more digitally inclusive society.

images.alt_text: From left: Prof Leo Tan, chairman of Garden City Fund,  Kenneth Er, CEO of NParks, Helen Wong, group CEO of OCBC Bank and Desmond Lee, Minister for National Development & Minister-in-charge of Social Services Integration.
DBS’ volunteer programme – People of Purpose – encourages employees to give back and create positive impact in the community – each employee gets 2 days of paid volunteer leave each year.

site_title: With 5G towers, progress is quite tall
summary: New York City has agreed with CityBridge to install 2,000 5G towers over the next several years to eliminate "internet deserts" in underserved areas. The towers will provide free digital calling, high-speed Wi-Fi, and 5G service, replacing payphones in neighborhoods such as the Bronx, Brooklyn, and Queens. Residents have expressed concerns about the towers' size and proximity to homes and businesses, with some fearing health risks from non-ionising radiation. Experts, including a professor of electrical engineering, have reassured residents that 5G is safe and hyper-focused, emitting energy only to cellphones.

images.alt_text: India has said that launch of 5G will bring high-speed Internet to consumers, with simultaneous socio-economic benefits in sectors like agriculture and health.

site_title: Changi Airport Group awards eight new concessions in public areas
summary: Changi Airport Group (CAG) has awarded eight new concessions in public areas of the airport since September, including food and beverage outlets such as Sushi Deli, Superfood Kitchen, and Nam Nam, as well as Japanese restaurant Aji Ichi set to open in January. The new leases reflect the confidence of brands and retailers in the recovery of the Changi air hub, with sales rebounding strongly in line with passenger traffic recovery since the easing of Covid-19 measures in April.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala
Jetstar has agreed to move to T4 after initially refusing to budge until an impact study was conducted.

site_title: We want to set the government up for success, says outgoing Sports Hub chief ahead of project handover
summary: Outgoing Sports Hub CEO Lionel Yeo is preparing to hand over the facility to Sport Singapore on December 9, amid efforts to ensure a smooth transition. Yeo's team is working to novate or terminate over 100 existing contracts, including major ones related to sponsorship and facilities management. Nearly 90% of staff from the private sector consortium and over 95% of partners and vendors will transition to the new entity managing the Sports Hub. Yeo expressed confidence that Sport Singapore will succeed and be set up for success, while also citing the Sports Hub's track record and the benefits of the public-private partnership model.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
Quek who is currently the CEO of New Business in Surbana Jurong and will be the fifth person to helm the eight-year-old Sports Hub on a permanent basis.
In taking back the Singapore Sports Hub from the private sector, the government's main consideration was the desire for stronger community participation and activities.

site_title: Building the pipeline of global-ready Singaporean leaders
summary: Singapore aims to develop a pipeline of global-ready leaders as the country seeks to maintain its prominence as an international business hub. Despite recent efforts to attract top global talent, the country still faces challenges in developing local talent. A 2022 survey found that 60% of foreign companies in Singapore have Singaporeans as their senior-level workforce, but the number of Singaporeans in regional leadership roles remains stagnant. To overcome cultural and individual-level obstacles, Singapore needs to foster diverse talent, address biases, and provide opportunities for global exposure, including virtual pat opportunities and multi-axis global rotations.

images.alt_text: Office workers at a crossing in the Central Business District. High-calibre talent would have been able to enter Singapore under other passes, but the One Pass enables them to contribute as fully as possible.
Singapore needs to make these foreign talent moves now to strengthen its position as a global hub for talent, said Manpower Minister Tan See Leng.

The Overseas Networks and Expertise (One) Pass will be open to top talent across all sectors, and allows them to start, operate and work for multiple companies at any one time. Pass holders will also be able to sponsor their dependants, and have their spouses work in Singapore on a Letter of Consent.

The government is looking at building a more effective and comprehensive SkillsFuture system, given the need for a "fundamental upgrading" of Singapore's training ecosystem, says Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong.
Talent management concentrates on identifying and developing a small number of workers. Diversity management, on the other hand, promotes the inclusion of all.

site_title: China posts 6-month high Covid count as it sticks with strategy
summary: China reported a 6-month high of 4,420 new locally transmitted Covid-19 infections on November 6, disappointing hopes for an easing of strict coronavirus curbs. The country has stuck with its zero-Covid approach since nearly three years into the pandemic, involving lockdowns, quarantines, and frequent testing. Analysts expect significant easing to begin after China's annual parliamentary session in March, rather than sooner.

images.alt_text: China’s Covid policy pivot is unlikely to be straightforward, creating volatility as traders pore over covert signs and policy tweaks.

site_title: MS Holdings loses free float, privatisation offer closing date extended to Dec 2
summary: MS Holdings, a Singaporean company, has lost its free float and will be delisted after obtaining 92.37% valid acceptances for a privatization offer. The offer closing date has been extended to Dec 2, 2022. The company, which leases and trades cranes, is wholly owned by executive chairman Ng Chui Hwa. The delisting will occur when the offer closes, with MS Holdings set to proceed with compulsory acquisition.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: Nasdaq 100 expected to see near-term rebound
summary: The Nasdaq Composite Index, which slipped into a bear market for the second time this year, hit its lowest level since July. US stocks fell for the fourth consecutive session due to recent rate hikes and economic data hinting at a hawkish Federal Reserve. Despite this, some analysts see potential for a near-term rebound, particularly in the technology sector, which may be due for a bottom pick.

images.alt_text: American employers added 261,000 workers last month, far more than economists had forecast, though this eased from a revised 315,000 figure in September.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for November 4, 2022, shows a negative trend in the tanker and dry bulk market. The average Capesize time charter route closed at $11,139, a decline of $2,713 week on week. The market saw a decrease in demand, particularly in Asia, with lower rates recorded for Ultramax, Supramax, Handysize, and Clean vessels. VLCC rates rebounded, while Suezmax rates in the West remained stable. Aframax rates fell in the US-Caribbean region. The market is expected to be softer in the second half of the year.

site_title: Young UK homeowners seen in negative equity if property prices plunge
summary: A predicted 7.9% drop in UK house prices next year could leave nearly 16% of young homeowners (ages 16-34) in negative equity, where their home is worth less than their mortgage. This would impact nearly three-quarters of young non-home-owning families, making it difficult for them to purchase a house. UK rental values are also expected to rise 6.5% next year, further weakening the buying power of prospective homeowners.

images.alt_text: The average value of a home dropped 0.9 per cent in October, the most since the start of the pandemic, according to Nationwide Building Society.

site_title: Carbon markets, ‘just transitions’ key issues for Singapore, Asean at COP27
summary: Singapore and ASEAN countries will closely monitor COP27's discussions on carbon markets, 'just transitions', and loss and damage finance. The city-state has no domestic renewable energy supply, making it a likely buyer of carbon credits to meet its net-zero targets. ASEAN nations, heavily reliant on fossil fuels, will focus on achieving a 'just transition' to mitigate climate impacts. Negotiations on setting a new collective quantified goal for climate finance and establishing a loss and damage finance facility will also take place.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
Among names in the list of signatories are AIGCC members UOB Asset Management, Eastspring Investments Group and BNP Paribas Asset Management.
COP27 signage on the road leading to the conference venue in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

The city skyline of Cairo beyond horse riders on the Giza pyramid complex in Giza, Egypt. Leaders around the world will gather in Sharm el-Sheikh for the annual UN Climate Change conference, known this year as COP27.

site_title: A stock trader’s guide to China’s potential exit from zero-Covid policy
summary: China's potential exit from its zero-Covid policy is creating market volatility, with traders analyzing covert signs and policy tweaks. A recent surge in the Chinese market, fueled by unverified online posts about a potential reopening, has boosted key stock gauges and the yuan. Analysts expect a reopening to gather momentum, with one fund manager predicting the end goal is now in sight. The shift away from zero-Covid policy could have significant implications for the economy and global markets.

images.alt_text: A man looks at a board showing stock market movements at a securities company in Beijing on July 10, 2015. Chinese stocks surged for a second day on July 10 as a government rescue plan offered a respite from a month-long rout, but analysts warned of further uncertainty and volatility ahead. AFP PHOTO / GREG BAKER

site_title: COP27 summit opens as world races against climate clock
summary: The COP27 climate summit in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, has opened with a focus on addressing extreme weather disasters and slashing greenhouse emissions by 45% by 2030 to cap global warming at 1.5 degrees Celsius. The conference comes amid a year of extreme weather events, including massive floods, droughts, and heatwaves, and is marked by a lack of commitment from wealthy industrialized nations to compensate poorer countries. The summit will focus on creating a dedicated funding facility for "loss and damage" and will be attended by over 120 world leaders, including US President Joe Biden, who has expressed concerns about the outcome due to Republican hostility to international action on climate change.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: View of a COP27 sign on the road leading to the conference area in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh town as the city prepares to host the COP27 summit next month, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sayed Sheasha/File Photo

Smoke rises from an illegally lit fire in an Amazon rainforest reserve, south of Novo Progresso in Para state, Brazil, in 2020. Among items on the agenda at Cop27 climate change summit, which convened on Sunday (Nov 6), is a push by delegates to speed action to protect forests between now and 2030.

site_title: Seeking clarity in rules for retail ESG funds
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued guidelines for the labelling of retail ESG funds, exceeding EU rules by specifying an ESG investment threshold. This move aims to provide clarity on ESG investments amid growing demand. The guidelines, set to take effect in January 2023, will drive a shake-out among asset managers, potentially downgrading some funds. Japan has also tightened ESG disclosure requirements, with no new funds claiming the ESG label in the past five months. This move is part of a global trend to increase transparency and regulation around ESG investments.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua
Hands painting pollution blue and polluting chimneys green. Greenwashing malpractice concept.
Sustainable funds that avoided traditional oil and energy companies underperformed this year. Starving the sector of capital may be a disservice to the long-term energy transition.

site_title: Pound to lead UK market suffering as BOE flags long recession
summary: The British pound is heading for its worst year since 2008, with investors expecting little upside for sterling in coming months. The Bank of England's forecast of a long UK recession by mid-2024 has renewed bets on a slide in the pound, with some predicting a fall below US$1.10 by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Rishi Sunak sought to emphasise his credentials as a former chancellor of the exchequer.

site_title: Metech substantial shareholder seeks EGM to remove CEO
summary: Substantial shareholder Ng Eng Tiong has requested Metech International to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) to remove CEO Samantha Hua Lei. Ng, holding a 10.1920% stake, is also seeking to invalidate the appointment of any directors from Nov 4 to the EGM date and have them removed from office. The EGM is to be held by Nov 25, 2022, as per the Companies Act.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: PAP needs strong mandate to keep governing effectively, as seen in the pandemic: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) to maintain a strong mandate to effectively govern the country. The PAP's performance in delivering on policies during the COVID-19 pandemic was a key factor in its success. Lee stated that without a strong mandate, the PAP would struggle to make tough decisions and steer Singapore through turbulent periods. He also warned that the stakes are increasing with each successive election, and the PAP must work to convert its current approval into "strong votes" to win the political battle.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Singapore is "entering a more dangerous world" with tougher economic conditions and "a new cold war", Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says.
Omicron variant may force Singapore to roll back easing of Covid safety measures: PM Lee

site_title: Wilmar chairman increases stake at S$3.88 following Q3 update
summary: Wilmar International's chairman, Kuok Khoon Hong, increased his stake in the company after the Q3 update, with a total consideration of S$4,547,360. The acquisition brought his deemed interest in Wilmar International from 12.94% to 12.96%. The company reported its third consecutive record quarter result, with core net profit for the third quarter of 2022 surging 38% from Q3 2021.

images.alt_text: Trading sentiments remain cautious over fears that rising rates will hurt the global economy

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire loses money as stocks, Hurricane Ian offset rising demand
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway reported a $2.69 billion third-quarter loss, despite a 20% rise in operating profit. The loss was driven by a $2.7 billion after-tax loss from Hurricane Ian and rising costs from fuel and accidents at businesses like BNSF railroad and Geico auto insurer. Despite this, Berkshire generated more income from insurance investments and benefited from increased demand and prices for new home sales and energy. The company added $3.7 billion to its portfolio and repurchased $1.05 billion of its own stock.

images.alt_text: The share purchases significantly ramp up Abel’s stake in Berkshire.

site_title: Malaysia has room for tighter monetary policy: finance minister
summary: Malaysia's central bank has room to tighten monetary policy due to the country's strong economic growth, Finance Minister Zafrul Aziz said. The economy is expected to show stronger-than-expected growth in the third quarter, providing more room to increase interest rates. The current benchmark rate of 2.75% remains below the pre-Covid level of 3%. This comes as the Federal Reserve increases interest rates, putting pressure on Bank Negara Malaysia to balance inflation control with economic growth support.

images.alt_text: A police stands guard between supporters of The National Front coalition, Barisan Nasional, and The Alliance Of Hope, Pakatan Harapan, outside a nomination centre on nomination day in Bera, Pahang, Malaysia.

site_title: Asset managers hit by more bad news on top-ranked ESG funds
summary: Asset managers' top-ranked ESG funds may face a potential crisis as a study by Clarity AI found that nearly 20% of 750 Article 9 funds analyzed have more than 10% exposure to companies violating UN and OECD standards. The EU's ESG regulatory framework is under scrutiny, with some funds being stripped of their Article 9 designation, and investment clients retreating due to concerns over greenwashing and lack of coherence across the industry. The European Commission is yet to clarify key ESG concepts, and regulators are urging for more stringent standards to be established.

images.alt_text: Water-stressed region in the Middle East. Concern about climate change has raised demand for ESG/sustainable investments, but globally, rules around fund labelling remain fluid and in some calses, unclear.
The Delta Blue Carbon project in Pakistan is expected to produce 128 million carbon credits over its 60-year lifetime and sequester 142 million tonnes of carbon from the atmosphere.
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknote is seen in this picture illustration taken May 3, 2018. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Dell looks to corporate sales for revenue boost as consumer demand falters
summary: Dell Technologies reported a 9% revenue growth in Q2, driven by steady demand from commercial clients. The company's Client Solutions Group saw a 9% increase, while its Infrastructure Solutions Group reported a 12% rise in revenue. Dell's multi-cloud business is a key focus, with the company's annual recurring revenue from modern cloud computing services crossing $1 billion. Despite a 31.6% decline in shares over the last 12 months, co-COO Chuck Whitten believes the long-term dynamics around Dell's business remain good, driven by companies' need to upgrade their computing systems and invest in user experience.

images.alt_text: Venga (எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்)
Chuck Whitten, Co-Chief Operating Officer at Dell Technologies

site_title: US: Stocks end volatile day higher after solid jobs data
summary: US stocks ended a volatile day higher on Friday, closing up 1.3% after American employers added 261,000 workers in October, exceeding economists' forecasts. The jobs data eased from a revised 315,000 figure in September and eased pressure on the Federal Reserve to hike interest rates. Despite concerns about inflation, the solid hiring data could indicate a "soft landing scenario" and was boosted by rumors of China easing its zero-tolerance Covid-19 policy. Stocks rebounded after a four-day losing streak, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 advancing 1.3% and 1.4% respectively.

site_title: Malaysia begins 14-day election campaign, with 945 candidates getting the nod to contest
summary: Malaysia has begun its 14-day election campaign ahead of the November 19 general election. The Election Commission approved 945 nominations for 222 federal Parliament seats and 116 state seats. The ruling Barisan Nasional (BN) coalition, led by former Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob, nominated 295 candidates, while the opposition Pakatan Harapan (PH) coalition, led by former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, nominated 322 candidates. The Perikatan Nasional (PN) coalition, led by former Prime Minister Muhyiddin Yassin, also nominated 265 candidates. The campaign promises to feature intense battles and tough fights among prominent candidates, including many first-time contenders.

images.alt_text: Various names have popped up in social media as potential candidates for upcoming election, the full list will be unveiled during the nomination day on Nov 5.
UMNO president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi (left) left out eight ministers and deputy ministers from the candidate list of the Barisan Nasional coalition that the party leads.

site_title: Japan government sounds alarm over US EV tax credits
summary: Japan's government has expressed concerns over US electric vehicle tax credits under the Inflation Reduction Act, warning that the legislation could deter further Japanese investment and impact employment in the US. The tax credits, set to replace existing incentives, will have stricter requirements and may make current EVs ineligible for full credits. Japan joins South Korea and European countries in expressing concerns, with some US automakers also voicing apprehension about certain aspects of the law.

images.alt_text: Car giants such as Ford Motor and Toyota Motor say the government should loosen the terms of the US$430 billion Inflation Reduction Act to allow manufacturers to source EV components from more places.

site_title: Lighting up the future of road safety with smart helmets, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Japan's second-oldest museum, the Tokyo National Museum, is facing financial difficulties and has been forced to crowdfund to pay its bills. The museum, which was founded in 1872, relies heavily on donations and has seen a decline in visitor numbers due to the COVID-19 pandemic. To address the issue, the museum has launched a crowdfunding campaign to raise ¥1 billion (approximately $9 million USD) to cover its operating costs for the next two years. The campaign aims to ensure the museum's continued operation and preservation of its vast collection of Japanese art and artifacts.

site_title: Singapore is ‘entering a more dangerous world’ of economic threats, new Cold War: Lawrence Wong
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says Singapore is entering a more "dangerous world" with tougher economic conditions and a new Cold War between the US and China. The emerging Cold War will worsen climate change, and countries will scramble for resources. Wong notes that Singapore faces domestic challenges, including a maturing economy, aging population, and growing needs, which can lead to social cohesion issues. He emphasizes the importance of maintaining solidarity and trust, citing the country's "deepened reservoir of trust" in weathering the pandemic years. Wong also warns that the PAP must secure a clear mandate in the next general election, which could be before or in 2025, and notes that the party faces challenges in addressing the growing needs of its citizens.

images.alt_text: Janice Heng
Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong

site_title: CapitaLand Reits see operational growth in Q3
summary: CapitaLand Reits, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust (Reit) manager, reported operational growth in Q3 2022. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit, Ascott Residence Trust, and CapitaLand India Trust achieved steady portfolio occupancy and positive rental reversion. CapitaLand Ascendas Reit also made two acquisitions in Singapore, totaling S$296.7 million. Meanwhile, CapitaLand China Trust and CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust reported year-on-year growth in net property income, driven by strong demand for retail and office spaces.

images.alt_text: Manulife US Reit reported 85.7 per cent of debt pegged to fixed rates as at end June 2022.

site_title: Renault to target US$10b valuation for its electric-vehicle business
summary: Renault aims to value its electric-vehicle business, Ampere, at around $14 billion for a potential initial public offering (IPO) on the Euronext Paris exchange next year. The carveout is part of a broader overhaul by CEO Luca de Meo to navigate the transition to electric vehicles amidst a possible European recession. Renault's current valuation is 9 billion euros, making it challenging to obtain a higher valuation for Ampere. The IPO is contingent on market conditions, with recent share price turbulence affecting new offerings.

images.alt_text: Revenue advanced 22 per cent to €9 billion (S$12.5 billion), falling short of the €9.6 billion projected by analysts

site_title: Xi vows to expand quality imports, build strong domestic market
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping announced plans to expand high-quality imports and build a powerful domestic market. He emphasized the need for the global economy's recovery momentum to accelerate and vowed to join international agreements such as the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership and Digital Economy Partnership Agreement. China aims to optimize and upgrade its goods trade, while actively practicing multilateralism.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors stand in front of an image of Chinese President Xi Jinping, at an exhibition titled "Forging Ahead in the New Era" during an organised media tour ahead of the 20th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, in Beijing, China October 12, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo

site_title: Ford, Toyota are at odds with their suppliers over EV tax credit
summary: Ford and Toyota are at odds with their suppliers over tax credits for electric vehicles under the US$430 billion Inflation Reduction Act. Automakers want to loosen restrictions on sourcing EV components from non-domestic suppliers, while US mining companies argue that domestic production is crucial for the country's supply chain. Ford and the Alliance for Automotive Innovation have urged the IRS to allow suppliers from countries with less than 50% foreign ownership to receive tax credits, while Toyota has called for explicit inclusion of Japan as a source eligible for tax credits.

images.alt_text: Toyoda talked about tax concession in a meeting with prime minister Fumio Kishida, who was willing to discuss the issue.

site_title: Malaysia’s nearly century-old Mahathir seeks re-election
summary: Malaysia's 97-year-old former Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has filed his candidacy for the upcoming general elections, despite suggestions he should retire. Mahathir, who ruled the country from 1981 to 2003, is expected to win his parliamentary seat in Langkawi, but a third term as Prime Minister is uncertain. Corruption will be a key issue in the election, with Mahathir warning that a jailed ex-leader's allies may be freed if they win. The election is seen as a tight contest, with at least four blocs vying for a majority in the 222-seat lower house of Parliament.

images.alt_text: UMNO president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi (left) left out eight ministers and deputy ministers from the candidate list of the Barisan Nasional coalition that the party leads.
The long-time opposition leader is the second politician to offer himself as premier in the national vote that will be held on Nov 19.
Former Malaysian premier Mahathir Mohamad is contemplating returning as PM for the third time.

site_title: MooVita wants to drive the future of mobility, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Singapore-based Yinson and SMRT Ventures have co-invested in MooVita, a technology startup focused on autonomous vehicle solutions. The investment aims to enhance MooVita's capabilities in developing autonomous shipping systems. This collaboration will enable MooVita to improve its technology, expand its customer base, and accelerate its commercialization. With this investment, MooVita will be able to leverage Yinson's expertise in the maritime industry and SMRT's experience in autonomous transportation. The partnership is expected to drive innovation and growth in the autonomous shipping sector. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: Crypto trading firm Amber seeks US$100m in fresh funding at ‘flat’ valuation
summary: Amber Group, a digital asset trading platform, is raising US$100 million in fresh funding at a US$3 billion valuation, following a major crypto market downturn. The Singapore-based startup had previously aimed to raise at a US$10 billion valuation but opted for a "flat round" due to investor caution. Amber Group has conducted major layoffs, cutting 10% of its staff, and plans to complete the remaining closings by the end of this year or early 2023. The company is structured to raise funds in multiple parts to accommodate cautious investors.

site_title: World’s top female golfer Thitikul set to grace Singapore Women’s Open in Dec
summary: Thailand's Atthaya Thitikul, 19, is set to compete in the inaugural Singapore Women's Open from Dec 9-11 at the Tanah Merah Country Club. As the world's top female golfer, she is the second youngest female golfer in history to reach the top of the rankings, following Lydia Ko's 17-year-old achievement in 2015. Thitikul will participate in the US$1.1 million event, which she is affiliated with through title sponsor Hana Financial Group.

images.alt_text: SOMIS, CALIFORNIA - OCTOBER 09: Atthaya Thitikul of Thailand plays her shot on the fifth tee during the final round of the LPGA MEDIHEAL Championship at The Saticoy Club on October 09, 2022 in Somis, California.   Meg Oliphant/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Twitter says 50% of staff laid off, moves to reassure on content moderation
summary: Twitter has laid off 50% of its employees, affecting 15% of the trust and safety team, as part of a restructuring effort following the company's takeover by Elon Musk. Despite this, content moderation capabilities remain unchanged, according to Twitter's head of safety and integrity, Yoel Roth. The layoffs come as the US midterm election approaches and amid concerns from civil rights groups about the impact on moderation. Major advertisers, including General Mills and General Motors, have stopped advertising on Twitter.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Twitter logo and stock graph are seen through a magnifier displayed in this illustration taken September 4, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Elon Musk fired Twitter’s previous chief Parag Agrawal and other top company officials last week.

site_title: Sunak plans to rebuild trust lost during Truss’s tenure: report
summary: Rishi Sunak plans to rebuild trust lost during Liz Truss's tenure as UK Prime Minister by presenting a "fair and compassionate" budget on November 17. He denied raising income tax or other payments, pledged to control inflation, and defended his Home Secretary's comments on migrant numbers. Sunak also stated that many UK challenges are global, citing the impact of Covid and Russia's invasion of Ukraine. His comments aimed to reassure the public and the Conservative Party, which has faced criticism for its handling of the economy.

site_title: Blockchain game studio cuts 10% of staff amid downturn
summary: Blockchain game studio Mythical Games laid off 10% of its staff amid the economic downturn, following a significant decline in interest for pay-to-earn video games. The company, valued at $1.25 billion, had raised over $270 million in venture capital but saw its flagship game Blankos Block Party receive a tepid reception. The layoffs come as investors have poured billions into blockchain gaming without finding much success, with several games experiencing hack incidents or low player counts. The company's departures of top executives further indicate the challenges faced by the industry.

images.alt_text: Attendees play the Battlefield: V video game during an Electronic Arts Inc. (EA) event ahead of the E3 Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles, California, U.S., on Saturday, June 8, 2019. Photographer: Patrick T. Fallon/Bloomberg

site_title: C919 narrowbody jet to make its first public appearance at China air show
summary: The C919, China's narrowbody jet, will make its first public appearance at the China Air Show in Zhuhai on November 8. The aircraft, designed to rival Airbus and Boeing single-aisle jets, has never been displayed or publicly flown. The C919 will join the opening flight display alongside China's AG600 amphibious aircraft and Y20 military transport aircraft, showcasing the country's home-grown aviation technology. The air show will feature 740 businesses, including 740 businesses.

site_title: Rolex raises prices in Europe for second time this year
summary: Rolex has raised retail prices in Europe for the second time this year due to currency fluctuations, particularly the strong US dollar. The price increase is about 5% across its models, with some in-demand steel sports models becoming 10% more expensive. The move follows a similar increase in the UK in September and is attributed to the eurozone's alignment of prices due to currency fluctuations. This is the second price hike for Rolex this year, with prices previously increased by an average of 3.5% in January.

site_title: Fed says financial system holding up through turbulent year
summary: The Federal Reserve released a semiannual report on financial stability, stating that US households, banks, and businesses have adapted to global central banks' rapid tightening of financial conditions. Despite rising interest rates, household and business indebtedness remains stable, and they have maintained the ability to cover debt servicing. However, the Fed expresses concerns about the amplification of vulnerabilities due to strained liquidity and hidden leverage, amid global risks such as inflation and the ongoing war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The Fed’s aggressive streak of rate increases this year has heaped about US$25.6 billion in additional interest onto Americans’ yearly credit card bills.

site_title: HKMA buys HK$3.054b from market as currency weakens, aggregate balance below HK$100b mark
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) purchased HK$3.054 billion from the market to prevent the Hong Kong dollar from weakening below its peg to the US dollar. This action will decrease the aggregate balance to HK$96.977 billion, bringing it below the HK$100 billion mark. The HKMA's intervention aims to maintain the stability of the local currency and its tight band of 7.75 to 7.85 against the US dollar.

site_title: Biden says Musk bought platform that ‘spews lies’ around world
summary: President Joe Biden criticized Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter, calling it a platform that "spews lies" globally. Musk acquired Twitter for $44 billion, removing top executives and embarking on a plan to lay off half of the company's 7,500 employees. Advertisers, including Pfizer and General Mills, have paused ad spending on the platform due to concerns over content moderation. Civil rights groups are also pressuring Musk to take steps to reduce hate speech and disinformation on the platform.

images.alt_text: Earlier on Friday, Musk said Twitter had experienced “a massive drop in revenue”.

site_title: Boeing’s US$14b Indonesia jet deal stalls over financing
summary: Boeing's proposed $14 billion sale of 36 F-15 fighter jets to Indonesia has stalled due to financing concerns. Executives from Boeing met with Indonesian officials in Jakarta, but no conclusive outcome was reached, likely delaying plans to sign the deal before the end of the year. Indonesia has insisted on paying in installments, while Boeing is concerned about the country's ability to finance the jets. The deal is vital to US national interests and would reinforce a key partner in the region, with the State Department previously approving the potential sale in February.

images.alt_text: Both Airbus and Boeing have already announced a flurry of significant deals this year which may limit how many blockbuster sales there are left to do in Farnborough.

site_title: Fed sees risk of big declines in still-lofty US house prices
summary: The US Federal Reserve warned that lofty US house prices could experience steep declines due to valuations being at high levels, making them susceptible to shocks. Despite recent slowing housing price increases, valuations remain stretched compared to other metrics. The report also highlighted strained liquidity conditions in financial markets and elevated leverage at hedge funds, which could put pressure on household balance sheets in the event of an economic downturn or correction in real estate prices.

images.alt_text: The Fed nodded to the recent market upheaval in the United Kingdom, where in September a sharp rise in government yields forced pension funds that had taken on leveraged interest-rate positions to liquidate assets to meet margin calls, pushing yields up further.

site_title: Vietnam to continue facing difficulties securing fuel supplies: minister
summary: Vietnam's Industry and Trade Minister, Nguyen Hong Dien, stated that the country will continue to face difficulties securing refined petroleum products due to global supply constraints and the rising dollar, making fuel imports more expensive. Hundreds of petrol stations have shut or limited sales, and some importers are struggling to access bank loans. The situation is expected to persist until November 11, when the finance ministry adjusts the costs for fuel importers. Vietnam's two refineries, which supply 70-80% of the country's fuel needs, also rely on imported crude oil.

images.alt_text: State Bank of Vietnam (SBV) has held three meetings with more than a dozen banks this week, to address “difficulties” for some lenders to access sufficient liquidity and about deposits in the system, one of sources said.

site_title: Fed’s latest rate hike costs credit card holders US$5.1b
summary: The US Federal Reserve's latest 75 basis point rate hike will cost Americans with outstanding credit card debt over $5 billion in additional interest over the next 12 months. The rate increases have heaped $25.6 billion in extra interest onto yearly credit card bills, with 58% of cardholder accounts carrying balances. This has put American consumers in a "financial Catch-22," forcing them to swipe plastic to keep up with soaring prices while facing higher borrowing costs.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell holds a news conference following the Federal Open Market Committee meeting in Washington on Nov 2, 2022. The Fed raised its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a point for a fourth straight time.

site_title: Saudi LIV boss accused by PGA of stonewalling in lawsuit
summary: Saudi-backed LIV Golf founder Yasir Al-Rumayyan is refusing to testify or provide documents in a lawsuit filed by the PGA Tour, citing lack of US jurisdiction. The PGA is seeking his testimony and documents from a Saudi investment fund, but Al-Rumayyan and the fund have objected, saying they are immune to discovery requests. This move comes as the PGA counters LIV's lawsuit, accusing the Saudi-backed tour of being an "entrenched monopolist" that illegally strangles competitors.

images.alt_text: Thai teenager Atthaya last week became the second-youngest world No 1 in women’s golf history after a stunning debut year on the elite tour.

site_title: G7 to be ready with details of Russian crude price cap by Dec 5: official
summary: The G7 countries aim to finalize the operational details of a price cap on Russian seaborne crude oil by December 5, when the measure is set to kick in. The price cap is intended to limit Moscow's revenues from oil sales and reduce its ability to finance its invasion of Ukraine. The cap is expected to be set just above Russian production costs, and technical talks are ongoing to discuss pricing and governance.

images.alt_text: Though fears of global recession capped gains, Brent crude futures settled up US$3.99 to US$98.57 per barrel, a weekly gain of 2.9 per cent.

site_title: Credit Suisse buyback sees investors hold on to half of debt
summary: Credit Suisse Group has seen investors hold on to half of its debt after a US$3 billion buyback offer, with about US$1.2 billion of dollar notes accepted. The bank repurchased debt at discounted prices, with some bonds trading below 80 US cents. This move is part of a 3 billion Swiss franc operation to scoop up debt at attractive prices and signal confidence in its liquidity. Despite the buyback, the bank remains vulnerable to takeover bids and concerns about its stability, with S&P Global Ratings cutting its score to BBB-.

images.alt_text: The Swiss bank’s long-term rating was cut to BBB- from BBB, with a stable outlook. The rating is just one notch above the BB “speculative grade”.

site_title: Apple’s next step in ads will be built around new soccer deal
summary: Apple is building an advertising network for live television as part of its deal to stream Major League Soccer (MLS) games in 2023. The company aims to increase its ad revenue, currently around $4 billion annually, to double-digit billions. Apple will hold discussions with advertising partners and MLS sponsors to air ads during soccer games and related shows, marking a more aggressive push into advertising.

images.alt_text: Apple joins other tech giants in tapping the brakes on hiring, a response to sluggish consumer spending and higher interest rates.

site_title: Oil settles up 5% as further interest rate hikes loom
summary: Oil prices rose 5% on Friday, with Brent crude futures up $3.99 to $98.57 per barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures up $2.96 to $92.61 per barrel. The gains were driven by uncertainty around future interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve, a looming EU ban on Russian oil, and rumors of China easing Covid restrictions. However, fears of a global recession capped gains, and the US Labor Department's non-farm payrolls report showed a rise in the unemployment rate, which could give the Fed cover to shift towards smaller rate increases.

images.alt_text: Brent futures were down US$1.49, or 1.5 per cent, to settle at US$94.67 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell US$1.83, or 2.0 per cent, to settle at US$88.17.

site_title: Japan’s Honda launches new EV model in China
summary: Honda unveiled its second electric vehicle (EV) model in China, part of its e:N Series lineup targeting the fast-growing battery-driven car segment in the world's largest auto market. The Japanese automaker aims to roll out 30 EV models globally and produce 2 million EVs annually by 2030. The e:N Series is a China-only brand, with partners GAC and Dongfeng Motor. Honda CEO Toshihiro Mibe stated the company is transforming into an electric brand in China with unique and diverse electric mobility products.

images.alt_text: Atsushi Ogata, CEO of Honda Motorcycle and Scooter India, says: “Our internal target is minimum, one model, the first model of flexi-fuel motorcycle to be launched by end-2024.”

site_title: Jetstar agrees to move to T4 at Changi Airport
summary: Jetstar has agreed to relocate from Terminal 1 to Terminal 4 (T4) at Changi Airport after a joint impact study was completed. The airline initially refused to move until the study was done, but has now reached an agreement with Changi Airport Group. The move is expected to optimize gate usage and create space for Jetstar and other airlines to grow, reducing the need for buses to remote stands. The relocation will also enable Changi Airport to meet increasing travel demand, particularly during the early morning peak period.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher

site_title: Puma CEO Gulden set to become new Adidas CEO:  source
summary: Puma CEO Bjorn Gulden is set to become the new CEO of Adidas, replacing Kasper Rorsted, according to an industry source. Gulden's departure from Puma is expected at the end of the year. Adidas shares rose nearly 20% after the report, with analysts praising Gulden's reputation for leading Puma's turnaround and strengthening its brand. Gulden's appointment could help strengthen the momentum of the Adidas brand, according to Stifel analyst Cedric Lecasble.

site_title: Will you BTO with me?
summary: Singaporean couples face a unique challenge in their romantic journey: waiting for at least four years before moving into their built-to-order (BTO) flat. The most romantic gesture for a man, according to an article, is to ask his partner "will you BTO with me," symbolizing the long-term commitment and waiting period involved in purchasing a home together. This unusual approach highlights the significance of patience and planning in Singapore's housing market.

images.alt_text: Vivien Ang

site_title: Lagarde says ECB may need restrictive rates to fight inflation
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned that interest rates may need to be lifted to restrictive levels to combat inflation, which is expected to remain above-target for an extended period. The ECB may need to take rates to a point where they act as a brake on the economy to bring inflation back to the 2% target. Lagarde stated that a "mild recession" would not be sufficient to tame price growth, and the risk of a wage-price spiral increases.

images.alt_text: The ECB says banks have to pay going rates on their TLTRO credit, rather than the average rate over the whole duration of the loans.

site_title: Eurozone downturn deepens, points to winter recession
summary: The Eurozone's economic downturn deepened in October, with business activity contracting at its fastest pace since 2020. The S&P Global PMI fell to 47.3, a 23-month low, and industrial orders in Germany slumped more than expected. High inflation, driven by energy costs, pushed services companies to raise charges sharply. The European Central Bank is likely to raise interest rates further, adding to the burden of indebted consumers. A Reuters poll found nearly 65% of respondents believed the cost of living in the eurozone would worsen.

images.alt_text: All of the currency bloc’s biggest economies except Ireland saw the downturn deepen in October, according to surveys of purchasing managers by S&P Global.
The ECB last week doubled its deposit rate to 1.5 per cent and indicated it would lift borrowing costs again.

site_title: Prosecutors seek 40-year jail sentence for penny stock crash mastermind, 19½ years for ex-girlfriend
summary: Prosecutors in Singapore are seeking a 40-year jail sentence for John Soh Chee Wen, the mastermind behind the country's largest stock market manipulation case, which wiped out nearly S$8 billion in market capitalization in 2013. His ex-girlfriend, Quah Su-Ling, is seeking a 19½-year jail sentence. Both were convicted of all 10 market manipulation charges brought against them under the Securities and Futures Act. The court will decide on the sentences on a later date.

images.alt_text: Malaysian dealmaker John Soh Chee Wen arrives at the Supreme Court on 27 January 2016. His request to return to Malaysia was turned down by the courts, after the prosecution said that charges may be brought against him soon.The Malaysian businessman, who has not been charged to date, has been helping the CAD with its sweeping probe launched in April 2014 into October 2013 penny stock crash that wiped out $8 billion in market value.##########PENNY1##########WONG KWAI CHOW
$8b penny stock crash trial. Quah Su-Ling (picture), along with John Soh Chee Wen, are accused of masterminding Singapore’s most serious case of stock market manipulation.

site_title: US: Wall St up after Oct jobs report
summary: The US stock market rose after the October jobs report showed job growth exceeding expectations, but an uptick in unemployment rate sparked hopes for smaller Federal Reserve rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 263.76 points, or 0.82%, to 32,265.01, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also rose. The jobs report's mixed signals suggest the market is cautiously optimistic about future rate hikes.

site_title: Vietnam central bank held emergency meetings with banks over liquidity: sources
summary: Vietnam's central bank held emergency meetings with over a dozen commercial banks this week to address liquidity issues and deposits in the system. The meetings aimed to help lenders access sufficient liquidity amid tightening credit conditions and higher interest rates. The State Bank of Vietnam did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the meetings.

site_title: SIA Q2 operating profit soars to record, resumes dividend payout
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) reported record operating profits for its second quarter and first half of 2023, with a Q2 operating profit of S$678 million, a 21.9% increase from the previous quarter. Revenue rose 14.3% to S$4.5 billion, driven by high demand for air travel. SIA resumed dividend payments with an interim dividend of S$0.10 per share, set to be paid in December. Passenger flown revenue jumped 22% while cargo flown revenue fell 8.5% due to softening air freight demand. The airline expects strong demand for travel heading into the peak year-end season.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Singapore Airlines is calling its 2020 MCBs and the airline group is the sponsor of Formula One Singapore Grand Prix.
Singapore Airlines (SIA) aeroplane / aircraft at Changi Airport, 20 June 2022.
SIA continues to ride on the travel recovery as it reports improved performance for the month of September

site_title: 2022 BMW X7 gets X-treme makeover
summary: BMW has unveiled a revamped version of its X7 SUV, which boasts a new engine, transmission, dashboard, and face. The X7 now features a 3.0-litre turbocharged six-cylinder engine producing 380 horsepower, a 48-volt mild hybrid system, and an eight-speed gearbox. The car can accelerate to 100 km/h in 5.8 seconds and features a five-zone climate system, allowing rear passengers to adjust their temperature and fan speed. The X7's new design aims to give it a more premium feel, with a slim row of LEDs and a panoramic glass roof, and is priced at S$569,888.

images.alt_text: Resilient demand and low inventories have allowed BMW and other carmakers to raise prices.

site_title: AEM reports higher revenue, net profit for Q3 2022
summary: AEM Holdings reported a 41% jump in Q3 2022 revenue to S$206 million, with a 38.3% increase in net profit to S$32.2 million. The company attributes growth to new and existing customers, as well as contributions from its acquired subsidiary CEI. Despite near-term recessionary concerns, AEM CEO Chandran Nair believes the mid- to long-term outlook remains strong, driven by customers' confidence in its solutions for next-generation product launches.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Chipmakers around the world have already begun to trade at significantly lower valuations, and that negative sentiment is spreading to Singapore’s shores.
The revenue guidance revision comes after the company's shares saw huge selloffs on Thursday (O

AEM, which derives over 60 per cent of its group revenue from Intel, could ultimately be affected by any further weakness or drop in capital expenditures from the US-based chipmaker, DBS said in a report on Thursday.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally on hopes of smaller Fed hikes, China reopening
summary: European stocks rallied 1.8% on Friday, Nov 4, after US jobs data suggested smaller Federal Reserve rate hikes, easing anxiety among investors. The Stoxx 600 index marked its fourth straight weekly gain, driven by hopes of easing Covid-19 curbs in China and better-than-expected earnings season. Mining and luxury stocks led the rally, with basic resources, personal & household goods, and automakers also rising.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index won 0.7 per cent to 7,237.13 points.

site_title: Bivalent Covid-19 vaccine to be offered to those aged 18 to 49; each household to get 12 ART kits
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health invites people aged 18 to 49 to receive their bivalent Covid-19 vaccine booster shot starting November 7. Those in their 40s will be invited to register first through an SMS with a personalized booking link. The move aims to shore up defenses against the ongoing Covid-19 infection surge driven by the Omicron XBB variant. Each household will also receive 12 antigen rapid test kits starting November 21 to encourage self-testing.

site_title: Twitter’s Singapore office hit by  layoffs amid wider job cuts
summary: Twitter's Singapore office has been hit by layoffs as part of the company's efforts to cut costs under new owner Elon Musk. Job cuts span across various teams, including engineering, sales, and marketing. Employees received notifications via email, with those who kept their jobs receiving a notification and those being let go receiving a private email with next steps. The layoffs are part of Musk's plan to eliminate around 3,700 jobs, or half of Twitter's global workforce, in a bid to focus on the core product.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk's photo is seen through a Twitter logo in this illustration taken October 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: UK airport workers to strike in run-up to World Cup
summary: UK airport workers, represented by Unite, will strike for three days starting from Nov 18 at London's Heathrow airport, affecting 700 workers. The strike is over demands for better pay ahead of the football World Cup in Qatar.

site_title: Climate activists hurl pea soup at Van Gogh in Rome
summary: Climate activists from Last Generation threw pea soup at Vincent Van Gogh's "The Sower" painting in Rome, Italy, as a protest against climate change. The attack, carried out by four individuals, was deemed non-violent and scientifically grounded. The group claims the action will continue until governments address demands to stop gas and coal and invest in renewables. The painting, exhibited behind glass, was undamaged, and the incident is the latest in a series of protests targeting major artworks by artists such as Van Gogh, Leonardo da Vinci, and Claude Monet.

images.alt_text: epa10285959 Climate activists stick their hands to the wall beneath Vincent Van Gogh's 'The Sower' in Palazzo Bonaparte, Rome, Italy, 04 November 2022. Climate activists protested by throwing a vegetable soup on the work 'The Sower' by Van Gogh's. According to organizers of exhibition, the painting was not damaged as it was protected by a glass.  EPA-EFE/ANSA BEST QUALITY AVAILABLE

site_title: Intesa sees 2022 profit at high end of range after strong Q3
summary: Intesa Sanpaolo, Italy's largest bank, reported a net income of 930 million euros in the third quarter, exceeding analyst forecasts. The bank's full-year profit is expected to be at the upper end of its range, driven by higher interest rates and reduced loan loss provisions. Intesa cut its exposure to Russia by 2.3 billion euros, or 65%, in the quarter, after reporting stronger-than-expected earnings. This move aims to mitigate potential losses on Russian and Ukrainian assets. The bank's 2022 net profit is now expected to be above 4 billion euros.

site_title: Former CEO of Sentosa Development Corporation to lead Sports Hub from Dec 10
summary: Former Sentosa Development Corporation CEO Quek Swee Kuan will lead the Singapore Sports Hub from Dec 10 as the fifth permanent CEO. Quek brings 26 years of public service experience, including at the Economic Development Board and the Singapore Tourism Board. He will oversee the 35-hectare facility, which includes the National Stadium and Kallang Wave Mall, with a focus on community activities and entertainment. Sport Singapore appointed Keith Magnus as chairman, effective Dec 1, following the termination of the Sports Hub public-private partnership in June.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
The S$1.3 billion facility was completed in 2014.

site_title: BT journalist Claudia Chong wins award for work on Singapore’s startup community
summary: BT journalist Claudia Chong has won an award from the Action Community for Entrepreneurship Youth Sub-Committee for her reporting on Singapore's startup community. She was recognized for her "crucial role in amplifying the success of the local startup ecosystem and spotlighting the stories of local entrepreneurs." This award is part of a group of 10 recipients, including venture capitalists and startups, who were honored at the event.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 17.9 points to 1,438.28. 2.386 billion lots worth RM1.719 billion changed hands, with gainers outnumbering losers 588 to 269.

site_title: Row over beer sparks political debate in Thailand
summary: A row in Thailand pits the government against small businesses over liberalizing the production and sale of liquor and beer, which is tightly regulated. An opposition-led proposal aims to reduce barriers to entry for local producers, who argue they've been dominated by large companies. The government has relaxed some entry barriers, but activists say the changes are insufficient. A minimum capital requirement and production capacity will be removed for fermented beverages.

images.alt_text: Cans of Thai Beverage Pcl's Chang Beer, above, are pictured on a supermarket shelf in Singapore on Sunday, May 7, 2006.  Thai Beverage Pcl, Thailand's largest brewer, is planning to sell as much as $1.1 billion of shares in an initial offering in Singapore, the biggest stock sale in the city-state in more than a decade.  Bottles of Boon Rawd Brewery Co.'s Singha Beer, one of Chang's competitors, are seen below.  Photographer: Munshi Ahmed/Bloomberg News.

site_title: Global food prices at nine-month low, easing strain on households
summary: Global food prices have reached a nine-month low, easing strain on households. Prices for meat, sugar, vegetable oils, and dairy fell, and food inflation is slowing down in countries such as Indonesia and Paraguay. This decline is attributed to supply disruptions caused by the war in Ukraine being offset by slowing demand for staples. The UN food-cost index is down 0.1% from October, its lowest level since January, offering some relief to households grappling with a cost-of-living crunch.

images.alt_text: Consumers care about whether food producers and stores are sustainable in the way they produce, package and sell products.

site_title: China lockdowns overshadow palm oil outlook despite output slowdown
summary: Palm oil prices have dropped amid concerns of a global economic slowdown and strict Covid-19 policies in China, the world's largest palm oil importer. Despite Indonesia's export restrictions and a slowdown in production, prices are expected to ease to $920 per tonne, down from $940. Analysts predict Malaysian benchmark prices to range from $3,500 to $4,500 per tonne until March next year, and global production is expected to rise by 2.9 million tonnes in the 2022/2023 season.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Indonesian migrant worker pushes a cart as he collects bunches of palm oil fruit during the harvest at a plantation in Banting, Selangor, Malaysia, June 10, 2022. Picture taken June 10, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: At the World Cup, every underdog has its day
summary: The FIFA World Cup is just 15 days away, with host nation Qatar set to face Ecuador in the opening match. Four dark horses are expected to cause upsets: Denmark, who have a history of defying odds and reached the semi-finals of Euro 2020; Senegal, led by 30-year-old Sadio Mane, who are in good form after qualifying with ease; Iran, Asia's top-ranked team, seeking their first knockout stage appearance; and Uruguay, with a mix of veteran and young players, including Darwin Nunez and Federico Valverde.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
