site_title: China stocks notch trillion-dollar gain on hopes of reopening, better US ties
summary: Chinese stocks surged, with the Hang Seng and Shanghai Composite reaching their largest weekly gains in over two years, as hopes for US-China tensions easing and potential relaxation of China's strict COVID rules fueled optimism. The Hang Seng surged 5.3% and the Shanghai Composite rose 2.4%, with shares in Alibaba, JD.com, and property manager Country Garden Services leading the way. The yuan also rose, adding approximately $1 trillion to the value of Chinese stocks in a week, despite China's COVID policies remaining unchanged.

images.alt_text: The screenshot claimed that on Sunday, China’s No 4 official Wang Huning – one of seven men on the powerful Politburo Standing Committee – held a meeting of Covid-19 experts at the request of President Xi Jinping.

site_title: EU approves preventative treatment for common infant virus
summary: The European Union has approved a preventative treatment for respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), a common virus that causes bronchiolitis in infants. The treatment, nirsevimab (Beyfortus), developed by AstraZeneca and Sanofi, will provide protection against RSV with a single injection. The approval comes as several countries face surging cases of bronchiolitis, putting pressure on hospitals. The drug will be available for the 2023 season, and several RSV vaccines are in development, with Pfizer's vaccine showing nearly 82% effectiveness in preventing serious illness.

site_title: Tech startups are turning to venture debt to survive bear market
summary: Tech startups are turning to venture debt to survive the bear market, avoiding "down rounds" where companies raise equity funding at reduced valuations. Credit, rather than equity, is helping companies keep operations going. The trend is fueled by high-profile revaluations of Swedish fintech Klarna Bank AB and payments giant Stripe. This shift allows companies to maintain operations while avoiding a damaging down round, which can lead to a loss of investor confidence and reduced valuations.

images.alt_text: Servers and hard drives stand inside pod one of International Business Machines Corp.'s (IBM) Softlayer data center in Dallas. Photographer: Ben Torres/Bloomberg

site_title: Germany’s Scholz secures deal for expats in China to use BioNTech vaccine
summary: Germany's Chancellor Olaf Scholz has secured a deal with China allowing expatriates in the country to use the BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine. This marks the first non-Chinese coronavirus vaccine to be administered in China, as Beijing has previously insisted on domestically produced vaccines. The agreement comes amid rumors that China will soon lift its stringent Covid-19 lockdown policies, but no official announcement has been made. Scholz hopes to expand the vaccine's availability to Chinese citizens in the future.

site_title: German factory orders decline as recession looms
summary: German factory orders declined by 4% in September, worse than expected, driven by a 7% drop in foreign orders. The decline adds to concerns of a recession in Europe's largest economy, with surging energy costs and record inflation affecting demand. Domestic orders grew slightly, while consumer goods orders rose 7.2%, but capital goods orders declined 6%. The German economy ministry warns of a weak fourth quarter, following a positive third quarter.

images.alt_text: All of the currency bloc’s biggest economies except Ireland saw the downturn deepen in October, according to surveys of purchasing managers by S&P Global.

With the notable exception of Sweden’s Northvolt, some European startups hoping to build so-called gigafactories to compete with the Asian behemoths are going for smaller plants, with the aim of attracting more investment further down the line.

site_title: Venture posts 25% rise in 9M net profit to S$271 million
summary: Venture Corporation reported a 24.9% increase in its 9-month net profit to S$271.1 million, driven by broad-based and diversified growth across its technology domains. Revenue rose 28% to S$2.82 billion, while earnings per share increased 25.1%. The company maintained a net cash position of S$700.7 million. In its outlook, Venture Corporation noted that the science and technology market segments may face volatility beyond 2022 due to geopolitical tensions and other headwinds.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
In its outlook, Venture Corporation said that its Malaysian entities delivered the most impressive contributions to its overall performance.

site_title: No fresh elections in Northern Ireland this year: Britain
summary: The UK government will not call fresh elections in Northern Ireland before the year's end, despite a 12-week deadline to form a power-sharing government. The decision comes after the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) boycotted the regional assembly in protest of post-Brexit trading arrangements. Minister Chris Heaton-Harris said he will make a statement next week outlining his next steps, following concerns from the region about the impact of an election. The deadlock has persisted since February, with the DUP demanding checks on goods moving to Northern Ireland from Britain be scrapped.

images.alt_text: Britain's King Charles III greets newly appointed Conservative Party leader and incoming prime minister Rishi Sunak during an audience at Buckingham Palace in London on Oct 25, 2022.
With Prime Minister Liz Truss in so much difficulty, the UK is in the mood for a reset.

site_title: Twitter sued for mass layoffs by Musk without enough notice
summary: Twitter is being sued by a class-action lawsuit over mass layoffs of approximately 3,700 employees without sufficient notice, allegedly violating federal and California law. The lawsuit, filed in San Francisco federal court, seeks to require Twitter to follow the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act and restrict the company from soliciting employees to sign documents giving up their right to participate in litigation. The lawsuit follows a similar claim filed against Tesla, which Musk previously described as "trivial."

images.alt_text: Musk is under pressure to find ways to slash costs of a business for which he says he overpaid.

site_title: All the ways Britain’s housing market is starting to go wrong
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing disruptions due to ultra-low interest rates coming to an end. The average home value dropped 0.9% in October, the largest decline since the pandemic began. The Bank of England raised its benchmark lending rate to 3%, the largest single increase since 1989, and fixed-term mortgage rates are expected to rise to 4-5% in the coming years. This increase will weigh on prices, contributing to a significant fall in 2023. The housing market faces severe disruption as it adapts to the new interest rate environment.

site_title: One in two food delivery riders want CPF contributions; some fear it may backfire
summary: A Singaporean study by the Institute of Policy Studies found that about half of food delivery riders want Central Provident Fund (CPF) contributions, contradicting a previous survey by the platforms. Concerns over riders' vulnerability to accidents and take-home earnings are also highlighted. The research suggests that riders value social protection, but prioritize income over protection, with 62.9% opting for higher income over CPF contributions.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
Platforms like Grab and foodpanda have rolled out welfare initiatives, but these cannot match national job protections.
The TWG includes members from ComfortDelGro, Grab, Lalamove and foodpanda.
Singapore is deliberating how to ensure basic job protections for platform workers

site_title: India says Xiaomi misled Deutsche Bank on ‘illegal’ royalty payments
summary: India's Enforcement Directorate has accused Xiaomi's Indian unit of misleading Deutsche Bank about "illegal" royalty payments to US chip firm Qualcomm. Xiaomi claims the payments were legitimate, but documents show the company did not have an agreement with Qualcomm and instead remitted royalties based on Chinese executives' directions. The agency alleges Xiaomi provided false information to the bank, with the intention of remitting money outside India. The case is ongoing, with a court hearing scheduled for November 7.

site_title: US job growth beats expectations in October; unemployment rate rises to 3.7%
summary: US employers added 261,000 jobs in October, beating expectations of 200,000, as domestic demand softened due to higher borrowing costs. The unemployment rate rose to 3.7%, suggesting some loosening in labor market conditions. This may allow the Federal Reserve to shift toward smaller interest rate increases starting in December. The Labor Department revised September's jobs data to 315,000, higher than the initial 263,000.

images.alt_text: The ISM survey’s measure of services industry supplier deliveries increased to 56.2 last month from 53.9 in September.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits slipped 1,000 to a seasonally adjusted 217,000 for the week ended Oct 29, the Labor Department said on Thursday (Nov 3).

site_title: Indonesia targets sugar self-sufficiency in 5 years, eyes ethanol production
summary: Indonesia aims to become self-sufficient in sugar production within the next five years by expanding its sugarcane plantations to 700,000 hectares. President Joko Widodo plans to utilize excess sugar to produce ethanol, starting with a 5% blend, with the possibility of increasing the blend to 10% or 20% in the future. This initiative is part of Indonesia's effort to diversify its energy sources and reduce its reliance on imported raw sugar.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on September 19, 2022 shows a worker processing sugarcane to produce brown sugar at a home industry in Ketol, central of Aceh province. (Photo by CHAIDEER MAHYUDDIN / AFP)
The country depends on imported wheat — mainly from Australia, Ukraine, Canada, Argentina and the US — to produce things like instant noodles, which make up a major part of the Indonesian diet.

site_title: Toshiba’s preferred bidder expected to miss financing deadline
summary: A consortium led by Japan Industrial Partners (JIP) is poised to miss a Nov 7 deadline to secure financing for a potential takeover of Toshiba, valued at about 2.4 trillion yen. Four banks, including Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, have decided not to issue commitment letters before the deadline due to unresolved details on equity partners and loan amounts. JIP's group continues to work on the takeover proposal, while a rival group led by Japan Investment has received approval to increase its fund size to 900 billion yen. Deliberations are ongoing, and lenders could still decide to issue the letters before the deadline.

site_title: Dubai homes reasonably priced despite record surge, Emaar says
summary: Dubai's nimble handling of the pandemic helped end a years-long property slump, pushing prices higher across most localities. Despite a 70% surge in prime real-estate prices, Emaar Properties' founder Mohamed Alabbar says Dubai's prices remain reasonable compared to global hubs. This outperforms cities like London, Paris, and New York, which experienced lower price increases due to economic slowdowns.

site_title: Japan to issue extra new bonds for stimulus, straining debt
summary: Japan plans to issue $154.8 billion in new bonds to fund its economic stimulus package, adding to its already heavy debt burden of 62.5 trillion yen ($604.3 billion). The stimulus package, worth 39 trillion yen, aims to boost Japan's GDP by 4.6% and is seen as a delicate balance between short-term economic revival and long-term fiscal sustainability. Critics argue the package is too large and lacks a clear exit strategy, sparking concerns about the government's ability to manage its debt.

site_title: COP27 is an opportunity to boost renewable energy sources
summary: The UN's COP27 climate summit in Egypt will focus on boosting renewable energy sources to meet the goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. Rising energy prices are expected to lead to an expansion of fossil fuel capacity, exacerbating the climate crisis. To counter this, COP27 must set higher targets for all forms of renewable energy and incentivize their expansion. The International Energy Agency recommends a massive boost in renewable plant capacity and energy generated by renewables, including cross-border trading. Governments must also take decisive steps to address fossil fuel interest groups and subsidies, and mobilize resources for the energy transition.

images.alt_text: COP27 signage on the road leading to the conference venue in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb as traders plough in after Fed hike decision; STI up 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.9% on Friday, driven by bargain-hunting after the previous day's sell-off, as traders looked ahead to key US jobs data. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 27.60 points to 3,130.11, with gains held up by banking stocks DBS, UOB, and OCBC. Regional peers also posted gains, but Japan closed sharply lower. Uncertainty over the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike pace and recession fears persisted, but analysts expect a slower pace of hikes to bring relief.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Singapore's STI gained 2.3 per cent over the week, having spent four days in positive territory

site_title: Australia weighs energy price caps as policy battle heats up
summary: Australia's government is weighing options to cap energy prices amid a surge in gas and power costs, with the goal of preventing 20-30% price hikes over two years. Treasurer Jim Chalmers has stated that regulatory action, taxes, or subsidies are being considered, but analysts warn that price controls could worsen the gas crunch and deter producers from investing in new supply. Manufacturers are pushing for a price cap of A$10 per gigajoule, but experts consider it unrealistic given global prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Supply vessels for the offshore gas rigs sit at Darwin port in northern Australia, April 21, 2017.  Picture taken April 21, 2017.   REUTERS/Tom Westbrook/File Photo

site_title: Emerging market equities – why now?
summary: Emerging market equities are considered a compelling investment opportunity due to their resilience and attractive valuations. Unlike developed economies, emerging markets have effective monetary policies and low debt, positioning them to weather current challenges. They offer opportunities in high-quality and high-growth companies, with many emerging market companies being global leaders in electric vehicles and renewable energy. Emerging market equity valuations are trading at near historic discounts versus the developed world, making it an attractive time to consider the asset class.

images.alt_text: Andrew Ness
Rally in support of Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, who is a candidate in the current elections. Brazil's presidential election is seen as a key test of Brazilian institutional strength.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower with eyes on US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Friday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 1.68% to 27,199.74, amid concerns over US jobs data and interest rate hikes. Investors are disheartened by Wall Street's decline and expect the US Federal Reserve to continue rate hikes. The dollar strengthened against the yen, while individual shares such as Mitsubishi Motors rose, while KDDI and Nippon Yusen fell. Markets are now watching US jobs data, particularly average hourly earnings, to gauge labor market tightness.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Nikkei 225 index was down 1.34 per cent, or 371.41 points, at 27,291.98 in early trade on Friday.

site_title: German mortgage rates hit highest level in decade on ECB hikes
summary: German mortgage rates reached a decade-high of 3.03% in September, according to ECB data, driven by several interest rate hikes to combat inflation. This is a significant increase from the previous year, when Germany was one of the cheapest places to get a mortgage. The European Central Bank has signaled plans to continue tightening monetary policy, with the cost of borrowing to buy real estate expected to remain high. The rate hike has made Germany one of the most expensive places to buy a home in the euro area.

images.alt_text: Sunlight falls onto the balconies on a block of residential housing located in the Wedding suburb of Berlin, Germany, on Monday, April 29, 2013. Rents and home prices in GermanyÕs largest cities are rising at the fastest rate in twenty years, according to data compiled by Bulwien Gesa AG. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: Philippine central bank ready to take further action as inflation nears 14-year high
summary: The Philippine central bank is prepared to take further monetary policy actions to combat a 7.7% inflation rate in October, the fastest pace in nearly 14 years. The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) stated that inflation risks are tilted to the upside for 2022 and 2023, but are balanced for 2024. The central bank aims to bring inflation back within its target range, which has not been breached in over a decade.

images.alt_text: A security guard stands beside a logo of the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (Central Bank of the Philippines) posted at the main gate in Manila, Philippines April 28, 2016.    REUTERS/Romeo Ranoco/File Photo

site_title: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments to acquire MoneySmart at raised price tag of S$221.5m
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments (APS) has proposed to acquire Catapult Ventures, the owner of personal financial marketplace MoneySmart, for S$221.5 million, a 75% premium over MoneySmart's estimated value after its last funding round in 2019. The acquisition will result in a reverse takeover (RTO) of APS, allowing Catapult Ventures to become listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The deal aims to provide significant growth capital for MoneySmart to accelerate its growth ambitions and expand its insurance business, as well as enhance APS' financial performance through entry into the financial services industry in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments eyes RTO with US$161.7m acquisition of MoneySmart

site_title: Europe: Stocks jump at open, before US jobs data
summary: European stocks surged at the open on Friday, driven by strong Asian gains and anticipation of key US jobs data. The FTSE 100 index in London rose 0.7% to 7,237.13 points, while the DAX in Frankfurt and CAC 40 in Paris gained 0.6% and 1.0% respectively. The rally was attributed to mining and healthcare stocks, and traders are focusing on US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks surge on China zero-Covid hopes
summary: Hong Kong stocks surged 5.36% on Friday, Nov 4, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 16,161.14, a gain of nearly nine percent over the week. Speculation of China winding back zero-Covid policies and positive reports on US auditing of Chinese firms fueled the rally. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also rose, with Alibaba up 20% at one point, as traders cheered potential relief from delisting fears. A shift away from zero-Covid could boost the economy, which has been impacted by lockdowns in major cities.

site_title: Google Cloud launches climate finance accelerator with MAS, KPMG
summary: Google Cloud has launched a climate finance accelerator in collaboration with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and KPMG. The six-week program, now open to climate fintech firms and startups, will shortlist up to 15 finalists by January 2023. The accelerator aims to channel capital to companies with market-ready climate fintech solutions, facilitating financial institutions' adoptions and growth. Eligible applicants will receive cloud computing credits of up to US$100,000 each year for two years under the Google for Startups Cloud Program.

images.alt_text: With the global investment community rallying around ESG mandates, Asean’s tech companies must establish tangible baselines for impact reporting.
Singapore has made impressive strides in the climate fintech space, and our hope is that other Asian markets will be able to follow in its footsteps., says Jonas Thuerig, head of F10 Singapore.
MAS managing director Ravi Menon says many of the ESG data problems that we have today can be addressed by the use of technology.
Greenwashing could lead to erosion of confidence in environmental, social and corporate governance (ESG) products, said Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Retail sales in Singapore excluding motor vehicles expanded by 16.8% from a year ago and 4.2% from the previous month, according to seasonally adjusted data. This growth reverses the previous month's decline, with September retail sales up 11.2% from August. The latest figures from the Department of Statistics (Singstat) indicate a continued increase in retail sales, marking growth in September.

site_title: Seoul: Shares mark third weekly gain on strong foreign inflows
summary: South Korea's benchmark KOSPI index closed up 19.26 points, or 0.83%, at 2,348.43, marking its third weekly gain, driven by strong foreign inflows and a rebound in Chinese tech shares. The Korean won strengthened, while the benchmark bond yield fell. Foreigners were net buyers of shares worth 42.2 billion won, and the won was quoted at 1,419.2 per US dollar, 0.32% higher than its previous close.

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB upgrades SingPost to ‘hold’, says worst could be over
summary: CGS-CIMB has upgraded its rating on SingPost to "hold" from "reduce", maintaining a target price of S$0.55. The analyst believes SingPost's recovery is likely to be bumpy, with potential headwinds from lower ocean freight rates and domestic volume weakness. Despite a net loss of S$9.9 million in the half-year ended Sep 30, SingPost's Q2 operating profit of S$30.7 million signals a strong rebound, driven by e-commerce growth and reversed losses in its post and parcel segment.

images.alt_text: The board has declared an interim dividend of S$0.0018 per share for the half-year, which will be paid to shareholders on Nov 30.

site_title: Japan's GPIF posts US$12b Q2 investment loss on market downturn
summary: Japan's Government Pension Investment Fund (GPIF) reported a Q2 investment loss of $16.4 billion, marking its third consecutive quarter of negative returns. The loss was attributed to market downturns in the US and Europe, as well as recession fears. The fund's assets decreased by 0.88% for the quarter, with losses in its foreign stock and bond portfolios. Despite this, the GPIF remains a closely watched global financial market indicator due to its massive size.

images.alt_text: The latest intervention helped to trigger an immediate drop in the dollar of more than 7 yen, but the Japanese currency has since come under renewed pressure.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts split on NetLink NBN Trust despite ‘healthy’ yields
summary: Analysts Maybank and DBS Research have differing views on NetLink NBN Trust, with Maybank upgrading its call to "buy" and a slightly higher target price of S$1.02, while DBS downgrades to "hold" with a lower target price of S$0.90. Maybank attributes the upgrade to NetLink's higher-than-expected earnings and a 6% sustainable dividend yield, while DBS sees limited upside and a higher risk-free rate.

images.alt_text: The 36.1 per cent jump in net profit came despite a 6.2 per cent rise in revenue to S$199.6 million in H1, compared to the year ago period, NetLink’s interim financial statements showed.
NetLink’s Q1 FY2023 net profit of S$27.6 million, up 11.3 per cent, was in line with CGS-CIMB’s expectations.
Maybank deems DIF a “stable yield play” for its long-term lease agreements with True Corp which are due to expire in 2043 for fibre and September 2033 for towers

site_title: Shareholder Ping An asks HSBC for 'aggressive' cost cuts amid breakup push
summary: Ping An, a China-based shareholder, is urging HSBC to be "much more aggressive" in reducing costs, citing the bank's high expenses compared to rivals. The shareholder, Michael Huang, also criticized the bank's board for lacking experience in Asia and called for further cost-cutting measures, including job cuts. This comes after Ping An started a campaign earlier this year to pressure HSBC to explore options, including listing its Asia business.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on commodity boost; financials fall on RBA view
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.5% to close at 6,892.5 points, driven by a rebound in commodity stocks, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia downgrading its economic growth outlook and warning of more interest rate hikes to combat inflation. Energy stocks led gains, while financials fell 0.2% on the RBA's rate hike. The S&P/ASX 200 index posted its second straight weekly gain, rising 1.6%.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index was down 0.3 per cent at 6386.00 points, as of 2358 GMT, but was set for a weekly climb of 1 per cent, if gains hold.

site_title: The world is missing its lofty climate targets. Time for some realism
summary: The world's failure to curb emissions has led to catastrophic climate-related disasters, with global warming exceeding 1.2 degrees C above pre-industrial times. The Paris agreement's 1.5 degree C target is unachievable, and global emissions continue to grow. Climate-related disasters are proliferating, including the deadliest hurricane in Florida since 1935 and extreme heatwaves in Europe, causing significant economic damage. The consequences of inaction are dire, with small, low-lying countries facing the most severe impacts.

images.alt_text: Rich nations are increasingly looking to the private sector for money.
COP27 signage on the road leading to the conference venue in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

site_title: Xi tells Scholz China and Germany should work together during ‘times of turmoil’
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz held a meeting in Beijing, emphasizing the need for cooperation between the two nations during "times of change and turmoil." The talks focused on issues like Russia's war on Ukraine, climate change, and developing economic ties. Scholz's visit marks the first by a G7 leader to China in three years, testing relations between Beijing and the West. The two leaders discussed topics including Europe-China relations, global hunger, and Covid-19 measures, with Scholz administered Covid-19 tests upon arrival in Beijing.

images.alt_text: Supporters of the deal say it will allow Hamburg, where Scholz was mayor for seven years, to keep pace with rival ports that are also vying for Chinese trade and some of which are partly owned by Cosco.
The planned phase-out will take place despite Germany’s July decision to reactivate coal-fired power plants and to extend the lifespans of those already operating.

Germany, led by Chancellor Olaf Scholz, is working to hone a new national strategy on China that aims to weaken reliance, diversify supply chains and enhance security, while reinforcing business ties.

site_title: Trump considering launching fresh White House bid after midterm elections: advisers
summary: Former US President Donald Trump is considering a third bid for the White House, with advisers saying he may announce a fresh campaign as early as this month. Trump hinted at a comeback during a rally in Iowa, stating he "will very, very, very probably do it again." An announcement could box out potential rivals and give Trump an advantage over his opponents, with a possible announcement after the midterm elections on November 8.

images.alt_text: Joe Biden’s warning about right-wing threats to democracy comes six days ahead of Tuesday’s vote, in which Republicans are favoured to capture the House of Representatives and possibly the Senate.
In a complaint Trump says was filed on Wednesday in state court in Palm Beach County, Trump accused New York Attorney-General Letitia James of a “war of intimidation and harassment.”

site_title: Former Pakistani PM Imran Khan's party to hold protests after 'assassination attempt'
summary: Former Pakistani Prime Minister Imran Khan's party plans nationwide protests after an apparent assassination attempt on Khan in Wazirabad on Thursday. Khan was shot in the leg while leading a protest march to pressure the government for snap polls. His party demands the resignation of Prime Minister Shehbaz Sharif and a transparent inquiry into the shooting. Khan's supporters are calling for the march to continue despite the attack, which has left tensions high in the South Asian nation.

images.alt_text: “It was a clear assassination attempt. Khan was hit but he’s stable. There was a lot of bleeding,” said Fawad Chaudhry, a spokesperson for Khan’s Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf (PTI) party.

site_title: Private credit : An investment opportunity but also a path to regional growth
summary: Singapore is increasing its investment in private credit, a path to regional growth and a chance to build its financial system's international competitiveness. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has allocated an additional US$1 billion to private credit, taking its private markets programme to US$6 billion. This move aims to enhance Singapore's status as a leading financial centre for the region, providing opportunities for investors and driving growth. Private credit also complements private equity, supporting the development of a local talent pool for complex financial advisory services and positioning Singapore as a financial hub for all seasons.

images.alt_text: Anderson Bridge, Central Business District and Marina Bay Financial Centre as viewed from Esplanade Park on Apr 23, 2020.

site_title: BT Market Focus: Hopes for dovish Fed dashed (Ep 19)
summary: Hopes for a dovish Federal Reserve (Fed) have been dashed due to recent interest rate hikes. The Fed's actions have negatively impacted market sentiment, with investors becoming more cautious. The podcast episode discusses the market drivers and movements in Singapore, the region, and globally. Central banks' interest rate hikes are seen as key drivers, and investors are advised to consider these factors when making decisions. The episode provides insights into the current market situation and offers analysis from SGX and The Business Times' newsdesk.

images.alt_text: How did markets do this week and what drove them?
Have rising interest rates fears dampened markets? Claressa Monteiro finds out.
Markets have had a bearish week and is there end in sight? Claressa Monteiro finds out.

site_title: Scholz lands in Beijing for talks with Xi amid Europe tensions
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz arrived in Beijing for talks with President Xi Jinping, amid rising tensions between Europe and China. The visit aims to strengthen business ties while diversifying supply chains and enhancing security. Scholz's trip comes after Xi secured a third term in office and China rebounded from a record market rout. The one-day visit is seen as a significant move by China to re-engage with Europe.

images.alt_text: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz will use the talks in Beijing to also seek clarification on China’s ambivalent role in the conflict over Russia’s military invasion in Ukraine.

Supporters of the deal say it will allow Hamburg, where Scholz was mayor for seven years, to keep pace with rival ports that are also vying for Chinese trade and some of which are partly owned by Cosco.

site_title: Societe Generale beats estimates as traders post bumper quarter
summary: Societe Generale reported a 50% increase in net income for the third quarter, beating analyst estimates, driven by a 34% surge in fixed-income and currencies trading revenue and an unexpected 1% increase in equities trading. The bank's debt trading and lending revenue helped offset declines in trading stocks and dealmaking, aided by sharp interest-rate increases by central banks. The bank's cost of risk and provisioning policy remained prudent, with a contained cost of risk and lower provisioning than analyst estimates.

images.alt_text: Lear Is Dead.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust posts 15.9% rise in H2 DPS on industry recovery
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust (FHT) reported a 15.9% rise in half-year distribution per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.009316, driven by better gross revenue and net property income amid the hospitality industry's gradual recovery. The stapled group's gross revenue for H2 FY2022 rose 13.5% to S$51.8 million. This improvement is attributed to improved performance across all regions, contributing to the increase in DPS.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu
FHT dropped to a low of S$0.535 right when the market opened on Tuesday, down 24.1 per cent or S$0.17. The last time the counter closed near this level was Apr 1, 2022.

Intercontinental Hotel Singapore, a portfolio property within FHT

site_title: The evolution of America’s China strategy
summary: The US-China strategy has evolved over two decades, with the Biden administration recognizing Russia and China as distinct challenges. The US initially sought to create an environment where China's rising power would reshape its behavior, rather than forcing fundamental changes. Critics argue that engagement was naive, but a more realistic goal is to achieve a steady state of clear-eyed coexistence. China's President Xi Jinping has consolidated power and promoted his ideological and nationalist objectives, dashing earlier expectations of rapid economic growth leading to liberalization. The US should focus on seeking favorable terms for US interests and values, rather than trying to force fundamental changes in China.

images.alt_text: Joseph S Nye
On Oct 7, the US Department of Commerce's Bureau of Industry and Security announced major controls on exports to China of advanced semiconductors, chip-making equipment and supercomputer components.
House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy is poised to take over as Speaker of the House. Expect Congressional oversight hearings as soon as McCarthy assumes the role.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 11.2% in September, extending August’s growth
summary: Singapore's retail sales increased 11.2% in September, extending the 13.3% rise in August. Excluding motor vehicles, retail sales expanded 16.8% year-over-year and 4.2% from the previous month on a seasonally adjusted basis. This marks the sixth straight month of double-digit growth. The performance was considered "better than expected" by analysts, reversing a 1.2% decline in August.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
Almost all retail sales categories saw growth in August, with the exception of supermarkets and hypermarkets; motor vehicles; and mini-marts and convenience stores.
Digital payment options level the playing field for consumers who may struggle to access traditional financial institutions.

site_title: North Korea fired artillery barrage overnight, Seoul says
summary: North Korea fired an artillery barrage into a maritime "buffer zone" overnight, according to Seoul's military. This comes after a record-breaking series of launches, including a failed intercontinental ballistic missile test. The move prompted South Korea and the US to extend their largest-ever joint air drills through Saturday, amid warnings of a potential nuclear test. Pyongyang responded by firing three short-range ballistic missiles, labeling the move as "very dangerous and wrong." The incident raises tensions in the region.

images.alt_text: Tensions on the peninsula are at their highest point in years, with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un last month declaring his country an “irreversible” nuclear power, effectively ending negotiations over his banned weapons programmes.
A Japanese emergency alert about North Korea's ballistic missile firing is pictured in Tokyo, Japan, Nov 3, 2022.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise, dollar holds gains ahead of US jobs data
summary: Most Asian markets rose on Friday, despite Tokyo's decline, as investors awaited US jobs data. The dollar maintained gains amid concerns of a global recession. The Federal Reserve's expected monetary tightening increase sent shivers through markets, with Fed boss Jerome Powell pushing back against expectations of a softer approach. The dollar held gains ahead of US jobs data, with investors focusing on the potential impact on interest rates and the economy.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell had said “there is still ground to cover” in terms of future rate hikes, adding that the ultimate level of interest rates in this cycle would be higher than previously expected.

site_title: An Olympic marathon runner’s tip for staying hydrated? Not water
summary: Olympic marathon runner Abdi Abdirahman shares his pre-race rituals and mental toughness tips ahead of his final NYC marathon. He emphasizes the importance of hydration, carb loading, and recovery. Abdirahman suggests drinking Pedialyte instead of water to stay hydrated and advises runners to focus on their own comfort zone, rather than trying to keep up with others. He also recommends exploring new trails and finding personal rituals, such as shaving his head, to help manage nerves. Abdirahman, who is on a quest to run all six major marathons, believes that mental toughness comes from within and that runners should prioritize self-care and recovery.

images.alt_text: The marathon route unveiled on Wednesday (Oct 5) was modelled on the path of the October 1789 Women’s March on Versailles

site_title: Brokers’ take: CGS-CIMB downgrades Nanofilm Tech, lowers estimates amid slowing outlook
summary: CGS-CIMB analysts downgraded Nanofilm Technologies' call from "add" to "hold" due to slowing economic outlook and supply chain disruptions in China. The analysts lowered the target price to S$1.78 from S$3.05 previously. The downgrade comes after Nanofilm reported a 10% year-on-year increase in revenue for the nine months ended Sep 30.

site_title: Gold heads for weekly loss on hawkish Federal Reserve stance
summary: US gold futures rose 0.2% to $1,633.70 on Friday, but gold prices are headed for a second straight weekly drop due to a stronger dollar and the Federal Reserve's hawkish policy stance. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,631.33 per ounce, down 0.6% for the week so far. The Fed's stance has clouded the outlook for non-yielding bullion, with a stronger dollar also contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: One kilo gold bars are pictured at the plant of gold and silver refiner and bar manufacturer Argor-Heraeus in Mendrisio, Switzerland, July 13, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse

site_title: Unfamiliar economic and political forces buffeting investors
summary: Investors are navigating market volatility due to rising economic and geopolitical forces, including inflation and geopolitical tensions. Trade patterns are shifting, with companies seeking alternative suppliers and maintaining backup inventories. Central bankers are tightening policies to combat inflation, leading to changes in global financial flows and stress on balance sheets. Emerging markets, particularly those in the G20, are showing resilience, while developed economies are experiencing sluggish growth. The world's richest economies have shown cohesion, but rising tensions with emerging countries pose risks, and the outcome is uncertain.

images.alt_text: Morgan Stanley CEO James Gorman said his gut feeling was that central banks would manage to curb price rises but investors would need to get used to higher inflation – of around 4 per cent versus 1-2 per cent before “this crisis”.

site_title: UK bans transporting Russian oil above price cap
summary: The UK government announced a ban on ships and services transporting Russian crude oil above the price cap set by the G7 and Australia, following EU and Australian support for the measure. The goal is to reduce the Kremlin's revenues and curb soaring energy prices. The ban comes as the G7 ministers agreed on the price cap, which aims to limit Russia's oil exports and mitigate the impact of the ongoing conflict.

images.alt_text: The loss was a result of a wrong bet on the difference between benchmark Asian and European gas prices over the summer months.
Brent futures were down US$1.49, or 1.5 per cent, to settle at US$94.67 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell US$1.83, or 2.0 per cent, to settle at US$88.17.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open slightly higher on Friday
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 0.67% on Friday, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 15,442.76. The move came after a volatile week for investors, who are awaiting US jobs data later in the day. Meanwhile, Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes were barely moved, with Shanghai edging down 0.81 points and Shenzhen flat. The gains came as investors focused on the day's economic data.

site_title: Australia: Shares extend losses as Federal Reserve stance spooks investors
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.3% on Friday, led by financials, amid a hawkish US Federal Reserve stance. The S&P/ASX 200 index was set to rise 1% for the week, despite a downgrade by the Reserve Bank of Australia warning of more rate hikes to combat inflation. Miners rose 0.5% on iron ore price gains, while energy stocks climbed 1.1%. The RBA also downgraded its economic growth outlook, citing the need for further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index falls 1.84 per cent to end at 6,857.9.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 2.29 points or 0.16% to 1422.67 on Friday, with 157 gainers outnumbering 114 losers. The country's stock market opened higher, driven by gains in various sectors, despite global market uncertainty.

site_title: Qantas’ CEO succession planning in good shape: chairman
summary: Qantas' CEO Alan Joyce is expected to stay until at least the end of 2023, but the airline's succession planning is in good shape, according to Chairman Richard Goyder. The board regularly assesses succession and has identified strong internal candidates, including CFO Vanessa Hudson and loyalty division head Olivia Wirth. Joyce will meet with Goyder next year to discuss his planned departure, which could potentially be earlier. Despite Joyce's long tenure, Qantas has never had a female CEO.

images.alt_text: The surge in travel demand immediately after Covid restrictions eased this year caught Qantas on the hop.
Airlines are running out of time to scale up production of SAF, aviation’s best shot at reaching net-zero carbon emissions by 2050.

site_title: Tee International’s CFO Chua Siong Kiat resigns
summary: Tee International announced that its CFO Chua Siong Kiat is resigning to pursue other career opportunities. Chua, 51, had been with the company since October 2021, overseeing financial reporting, accounting, and corporate finance. With most debt restructuring work complete, Chua cited it was time to move on. His role will be taken over by the group's chief financial controller and corporate finance senior manager.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்

TEE International’s earlier plans to raise up to S$14 million through new share subscription and issue has fallen through after its 2 investors decided not to proceed with the proposed investor transaction, it said in an announcement on SGX on Tuesday (Aug 2).
Tee International has entered into a conditional subscription agreement with Meta5 to issue new shares in the company for S$7.5 million each.

site_title: US offers bounty for Singaporean over North Korea oil shipments
summary: The US Department of State has issued a $5 million bounty for information on Singaporean businessman Kwek Kee Seng, who allegedly flouted international sanctions by transporting fuel to North Korea. Seng, director of Swanseas Port Services, is accused of directing the delivery of petroleum products to North Korea and using one of his own oil tankers for illicit ship-to-ship transfers. The US is ratcheting up pressure on anyone supporting North Korea's weapons programs, with the bounty aimed at disrupting these activities.

images.alt_text: A Japanese emergency alert about North Korea's ballistic missile firing is pictured in Tokyo, Japan, Nov 3, 2022.

Television screens show a news report about a North Korean missile launch at an electronics store in Seoul on Nov 3, 2022. North Korea fired an artillery barrage into a maritime “buffer zone” overnight, Seoul’s military said on Friday.

site_title: Elite Commercial Reit posts 7.8% lower DPU despite higher revenue
summary: Elite Commercial Reit reported a 7.8% decrease in its nine-month distribution per unit (DPU) to 3.79 pence, despite a 10.3% increase in revenue to £27.9 million. The decline in DPU was attributed to a 0.3% decrease in income generated for distribution to unitholders. The Reit's revenue growth was driven by its higher revenue, but the decrease in distribution was a result of various factors, including a lower interim distribution of 2.56 pence per unit.

images.alt_text: Distributable income rose 9.7 per cent to £12.2 million, driven mainly by the full half-year rental contribution from the Reit’s maiden acquisition and tax savings.
Value could be emerging for S-Reits such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), which hit a 52-week low on Oct 21.
Cromwell European Reit has signalled its pivot to light industrial and logistics, with its acquisition of assets woth 57.8 million euro in the UK and the Netherlands

site_title: Landmark carbon credit auction by Singapore-based Climate Impact X oversubscribed, credit priced at US$27.80
summary: Singapore-based Climate Impact X (CIX) successfully held its first major carbon credit auction, selling 250,000 credits tied to the Delta Blue Carbon project in Pakistan for US$27.80 per credit, a 40% premium above current spot prices. The project aims to produce 128 million carbon credits and sequester 142 million tonnes of carbon over its 60-year lifetime, making it the world's largest mangrove restoration project. The oversubscribed auction demonstrates growing demand for carbon credits and underscores the increasing importance of carbon pricing in the global market.

Mikkel Larsen, chief executive officer of Climate Impact X.
The London Stock Exchange on Monday (Oct 10) published the final admission and disclosure standards for its voluntary carbon market designation.
Controversies to do with unclear rules in the carbon market still occasionally make headlines.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment fund management earnings up 6.3% in Q3
summary: CapitaLand Investment's fund management fee-related earnings grew 6.3% in Q3 to S$101 million, driven by private funds, which increased 44% to S$118 million. The company's lodging management business saw a 43% increase in revenue per available unit to S$110. Fund management earnings rose 16% to S$339 million year-to-date, while revenue from its real estate investment business increased 48% to S$1.6 billion. Despite a tough operational environment, analysts see positive momentum in CapitaLand's private funds business, with current valuations offering a good entry point.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
The two private funds will add over 8.2 billion yuan (S$1.6 billion) to CapitaLand Investment's funds under management when fully deployed, it said.

120 Spencer Street, a 22-storey freehold office tower in Melbourne’s Central Business District, is CLI’s fifth investment in Australia within 6 months.
CLI reported that it achieved green building certifications for 48 per cent of its global portfolio by sqm

CAPITALAND Investment (CLI) posted a 16 per cent growth on year in revenue to S$598 million for its first quarter ended Mar 31, 2022, amid a healthy growth in fee-related earnings (FRE) from its fund and lodging management businesses.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb at Friday’s open, bucking global trend; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% at the open on Friday, bucking the global trend, as the Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,108.21. Losers outnumbered gainers 57 to 49, with Sembcorp Marine trading flat and Keppel Reit seeing brisk trading. Local banks OCBC rose 0.9% on a 31% profit increase, while DBS and UOB declined. The global market retreat, with the US Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite falling due to interest rate hike expectations and key US jobs data.

images.alt_text: OCBC posts a 31 per cent net profit increase to S$1.6 billion, and its quarterly net interest income gain crosses the S$2 billion mark for the first time.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars regain their footing after Fed setback
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars regained some ground after a setback due to market expectations of higher US interest rates. The Australian dollar rose 0.5% to US$0.6320, while the New Zealand dollar eased 0.4% to US$0.5795. The Reserve Bank of Australia maintained its dovish stance, sticking to a 25-basis-point rate hike, and the Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to hike rates by 75 basis points later this month. Markets expect the Federal Reserve to step down to a 50-basis-point hike in December, which could allow the Aussie to edge up to US$0.6500.

images.alt_text: The Aussie was hovering around US$0.6414, unwinding sharp gains from a few sessions ago, which saw the Antipodean hit the highest level in three weeks on hopes of a pivot in the global tightening cycle.
Inflation is now expected to peak around 8 per cent later this year, up from a previous forecast of 7.75 per cent, according to the RBA.

site_title: Fintech funding holds strong in 2022, but signs of headwinds ahead
summary: Fintech funding remains strong in 2022, with $4 billion invested in the first half of the year, despite a funding winter. Singapore and Indonesia led the way, with $1.9 billion and $1.5 billion, respectively. However, some experts, like Ron Savino, expect a slowdown due to valuation corrections and a decrease in investor interest. Others, like Herston Powers, forecast a super cycle of fintech market expansion and funding. Fintech startups that make it through the current market conditions will be well-positioned to capitalize on the large unbanked population in emerging markets.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Potential candidates look to join fintechs for opportunities to develop their careers, yet they leave for the same reasons, the report said.

The real value in the crypto industry comes not from speculating in cryptocurrencies, but from tokenising assets for use cases that increase economic efficiency or enhance social inclusion, said Ravi Menon.
MAS will be consulting on ending corporate cheques by 2025, DPM Wong said in a speech on Wednesday (Nov 2)

site_title: Russia turns to Japan for used car imports as domestic production slumps
summary: Russia is turning to Japan for used car imports as its domestic car industry struggles due to Western sanctions. Japan accounts for over 76% of used car imports, with Belarus second at 5.3%. The country's car market has slumped since Russia invaded Ukraine, with new car sales down 60% in January-September. The sanctions have limited access to parts, and logistical challenges have driven up prices. Meanwhile, individuals are increasingly buying used cars, with a 50% increase in imports via Vladivostok port.

site_title: Branson says his luxury travel empire will thrive during slump
summary: British billionaire Richard Branson says his luxury travel empire, Virgin Group, will thrive during an inflation-fuelled cost-of-living crisis due to pent-up demand from those who can afford to travel. Despite the challenges posed by the pandemic, Branson's focus on luxury travel has proven resilient, with strong bookings for flights between the US and Europe and a strong rebound in Virgin Cruises and hotels. Branson also expressed concerns over the UK's economic and political instability, calling for stability to support business growth.

images.alt_text: The company had previously disappointed investors by pushing back the launch, once planned for the third, then fourth quarter of 2022.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower with eyes on US jobs data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, with the benchmark Nikkei 225 index down 1.34% due to falls on Wall Street and focus on key US jobs data later in the day. The Nikkei 225 index fell to 27,291.98, while the Topix index slipped 0.86%. Investors are awaiting US jobs data, which could impact global markets.

site_title: Japan, China eyeing Kishida-Xi meet in mid-November: Sankei
summary: Japan and China are planning a meeting between Prime Minister Fumio Kishida and President Xi Jinping for mid-November, according to the Sankei newspaper. The meeting is expected to take place alongside an international conference in South-east Asia. The summit aims to address the long-standing dispute over the uninhabited East China Sea islets, a legacy of Japan's World War Two aggression. The meeting is seen as a significant step towards improving Sino-Japanese ties.

site_title: US is not in recession, White House not preparing for one
summary: The US economy is not in a recession, according to White House Chief of Staff Ron Klain, despite concerns from some economists and CEOs. Unemployment claims remain at a historical low, and the economy is growing, creating jobs. Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre also stated there are no preparations for a recession, citing a strong labor market. This contradicts a Reuters poll showing the global economy is approaching a recession and some US CEOs' concerns about the US economy potentially tipping into recession next year.

site_title: UK researchers cure man who had Covid-19 for 411 days
summary: UK researchers have cured a 59-year-old man of Covid-19 after 411 days by analyzing the genetic code of his virus to find a suitable treatment. The man, with a weakened immune system due to a kidney transplant, was infected in December 2020 and continued to test positive until January this year. The researchers used a combination of monoclonal antibodies from Regeneron, which was effective against an early B.1 variant, and successfully cured the man. This breakthrough offers new hope for patients with persistent Covid infections, which can pose a serious threat due to associated symptoms like lung inflammation.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product in that province shrank 0.5 per cent in the first nine months of the year, compared with growth of 1.6 per cent in the first half of the year.
China should unwaveringly stick to its dynamic zero-Covid policy, the National Health Commission said.

site_title: Musk orders Twitter to cut infrastructure costs by US$1b: sources
summary: Elon Musk has instructed Twitter to cut over $1 billion in annual infrastructure costs by reducing cloud services and server space. The goal is to find up to $3 million in daily savings. Such drastic cuts may jeopardize the Twitter website and app during high-traffic moments, such as the US midterm election.

site_title: US: Stocks decline as markets await jobs data
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday as markets awaited key jobs data, following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and hawkish comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5% to 32,001.25, while the S&P 500 dropped 1.1% to 3,719.89. Tech stocks also plummeted, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 1.7% to 10,342.94. Investors await the US employment report and inflation figures due out this week for signs of cooling in the economy.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - OCTOBER 07: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on October 07, 2022 in New York City. Stocks fell in early trading on Friday as new employment numbers show steady hiring which investors fear will lead to increased interest rate hikes.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: Europe: Shares hit one-week low as Federal Reserve signals further tightening
summary: European shares plummeted 0.9% on Thursday, logging their worst single-day performance in four weeks, as the Federal Reserve hinted at continued interest rate hikes to combat inflation. The pan-European Stoxx 600 fell, with rate-sensitive stocks shedding 2.3-2.9%. The Fed Chair, Jerome Powell, signaled that future hikes may slow but will remain hawkish, dampening hopes for a downshift in the aggressive fight against inflation.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index dropped 0.9 per cent to 7,080.17 points, with the Bank of England (BOE) expected later Thursday to lift its key rate by the biggest amount since 1989 to combat red-hot inflation.

site_title: Oil slips 2% on China demand worries, US rate hikes
summary: Oil prices slid 2% on Thursday due to concerns over China's zero-Covid policy and US interest rate hikes, which raised fears of a global recession. The US dollar strengthened, reducing demand for oil, while a tightening market provided limited support. The European Union's embargo on Russian oil and Opec's output cut also contributed to the decline. Despite these factors, expectations of a tightening market in the coming months limited losses.

images.alt_text: Brent crude settled up US$1.51, or 1.6 per cent, to US$96.16 while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude settled up US$1.63, or 1.8 per cent, to US$90.
The loss was a result of a wrong bet on the difference between benchmark Asian and European gas prices over the summer months.

summary: OCBC Bank reported a 31% increase in Q3 net profit to S$1.6 billion, crossing the S$2 billion net interest income mark for the first time. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Investment (CLI) saw a 43% increase in revenue per available unit and a 16% growth in fund management fee-related earnings.

site_title: Australia sees spike in cyber attacks from criminals and states
summary: Australia experienced a significant spike in cyber attacks, with 76,000 reports received by the Australian Cyber Security Centre (ACSC) last financial year, a 13% increase from the previous period. State-sponsored groups, including China's Ministry of State Security and Russian state-linked groups, were among the attackers. The attacks resulted in multiple incidents against critical infrastructure and essential services being thwarted, with business losses attributable to cyber crime rising 14% over the period. The government has warned that companies must step up their cybersecurity measures to protect customers and prevent further attacks.

site_title: Saudi crown prince launches Ceer, first Saudi electric vehicle brand
summary: Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has launched Ceer, the country's first electric vehicle brand. Ceer is a joint venture between the Saudi Public Investment Fund and Hon Hai Precision Industry (Foxconn), expected to attract $150 million in foreign investment and contribute $8 billion to the kingdom's GDP by 2034. The brand is set to launch in 2025, marking a significant step in Saudi Arabia's push towards sustainable transportation.

site_title: Apple pauses hiring for roles outside of R&D in escalation of cost cuts
summary: Apple has paused hiring for most roles outside of research and development as part of its efforts to reduce budgets and cut costs amid a sluggish consumer spending environment and higher interest rates. The company continues to hire for future devices and long-term initiatives, but has halted hiring for some corporate functions and standard engineering roles. This move is part of a broader industry trend, with other tech giants such as Amazon and Twitter also cutting hiring. Apple's shares fell 1% after the news, despite the company's confidence in its future.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk has told Twitter Inc’s teams to find over US$1 billion in annual infrastructure cost savings by cutting cloud services and extra server space.

site_title: Sembmarine bags exclusive wind farm maintenance contract
summary: Sembcorp Marine has secured an exclusive planned preventative maintenance contract from Orsted for the Hornsea 2 Offshore Wind Farm in the UK. Under the contract, Sembmarine SLP will maintain and service low voltage and ancillary systems on the offshore substation and reactive compensation station. This marks Sembmarine SLP's first sole supplier maintenance award, highlighting the company's capabilities in the renewable energy sector. The contract was awarded for systems installed by Sembmarine Offshore Platforms in Singapore.

site_title: Coinbase CFO sees risk of ‘sustained’ revenue hit in crypto rout
summary: Coinbase's CFO, Alesia Haas, warns of a "sustained" revenue hit in the crypto industry due to a trading slump. Revenue for the third quarter fell to $590.3 million, less than half of the $1.2 billion from the same period last year. Haas attributes the decline to investors' decreased interest in speculating in tokens, partly due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. Coinbase is preparing for a more conservative 2023 with plans to slash costs and develop strategies to address the headwinds, making sustained low revenue a probable scenario.

site_title: Starbucks reports record sales but lower profits on weak China
summary: Starbucks reported record quarterly revenues of $8.4 billion, driven by a 3.3% increase, but profits plummeted 50% to $878.3 million due to weak China sales and increased expenses. Strong US sales, with a 10% rise in average ticket size, contributed to the revenue growth. This illustrates robust consumer demand in the US despite inflation, with comparable sales surging at North American shops.

images.alt_text: Starbucks expects to return US$20 billion to investors via share buybacks and dividends from fiscal 2023 to 2025.

Starbucks Singapore said the coffee chain was made aware of the data breach only on Sept 13, adding that the customers affected were those who had accounts and had previously made a transaction via itsapp or online store.

site_title: Layoffs hit Silicon Valley as Amazon freezes hiring
summary: Amazon, a tech giant, has frozen new corporate hires amid a highly uncertain economic environment. Payments firm Stripe and ride-hailing company Lyft have also announced major layoffs, citing economic uncertainty. Stripe will cut 14% of its staff, while Lyft will let go 13% of non-driver employees. The tech industry is bracing for potential layoffs at Twitter, which was acquired by Elon Musk for $44 billion, with reports suggesting thousands of jobs may be eliminated. The moves come after a downbeat earnings season for tech giants, including Facebook-owner Meta, which saw its share price plummet by 73% this year.

site_title: OCBC Q3 profit rises 31% to S$1.6b; net interest margin sees stronger expansion than peers
summary: OCBC Bank reported a 31% increase in net profit to S$1.6 billion in Q3, beating consensus forecasts. The bank's net interest income surpassed S$2 billion for the first time, rising 44% to S$2.1 billion. OCBC's net interest margin (NIM) expanded 35 basis points, the strongest among peers for two quarters, and 54 basis points on a year-on-year basis. This marks a significant rise in earnings, with EPS increasing to S$1.40 from last year's S$1.07.

Yong Hui Ting

Many analysts have maintained their “buy” calls on the three Singapore banks, on higher absolute dividends for FY2022.

site_title: Canada sees lower deficit in updated fiscal plan, possible 2023 recession
summary: Canada's government has announced an updated fiscal plan, slashing its budget deficit ahead of a possible economic downturn. The plan includes new spending measures, such as eliminating interest on student loans and lowering credit card transaction fees, totaling about C$30 billion over six years. Investment tax credits for clean energy projects and taxes on corporate share buy-backs were also introduced. The measures aim to balance the budget without fueling inflation, as the country faces a possible recession.

images.alt_text: The Canadian government ordered the divestiture after “rigorous scrutiny” of foreign firms by Canada’s National Security and Intelligence Community, Industry Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said in a statement.

site_title: Netanyahu set to seal victory, returning him to power within weeks
summary: Israel's opposition leader Benjamin Netanyahu is set to seal victory in the country's general election, returning him to power as prime minister. His right-wing bloc is expected to score a clear victory, driven by concerns among right-wing Jews about perceived threats to Israel's Jewish identity. Netanyahu's return will test Israel's diplomatic relations, particularly with the US and Persian Gulf states, and may lead to tensions with the Palestinians. His coalition partners are likely to push to legalise corruption charges against him, and his return may empower extremist figures in his coalition, sparking fears of a shift towards fascism.

images.alt_text: A camper wagon with electoral banner depicting Benjamin Netanyahu, who has focused his message on high living costs – a top concern for voters – and dismissing his trial as “rigged” and “a joke”.

site_title: SIIC Environment to acquire Yun Shui Technology for S$57.4m
summary: SIIC Environment will acquire Yun Shui Technology, an investment holding company in China, for S$57.4 million. The acquisition, funded by internal resources, will expand the company's wastewater treatment capacity in the Yangtze Delta region. Assuming the acquisition occurred in 2021, it would have increased pro forma net profit by 1.4% and slightly decreased earnings per share. The deal is expected to generate returns for the group and enable expansion in the region.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
SIIC Environment said that the divestment would recover shareholder investment and generate profits for the group.

site_title: The regulator US financial markets need
summary: Gary Gensler, the chair of the US Securities and Exchange Commission, has been credited with strengthening the regulator's credibility. In contrast to his predecessors, Gensler has proposed more rules in his first 18 months, aiming to address weaknesses in US financial markets exposed by the 2008 global financial crisis. Critics, including industry representatives, argue that the rules are too restrictive, but Gensler's track record at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission suggests he will win most lawsuits challenging SEC rules, leading to fairer markets.

images.alt_text: Gensler said the 2024 timeline could also be accelerated to 2023 if US lawmakers pass legislation now under consideration.

site_title: More advertising woes for Musk’s Twitter as brands hit pause
summary: Companies such as General Mills and Volkswagen have suspended their advertising on Twitter amid pressure on Elon Musk to turn the platform into a successful business. The move comes as the platform faces ongoing advertising woes. Musk has been working to revamp Twitter, but the efforts have been met with skepticism. The suspension of advertising is a significant blow to Twitter's revenue, further highlighting the challenges Musk faces in transforming the platform.

site_title: Sri Lanka holds debt restructuring talks with bilateral creditors
summary: Sri Lanka held productive talks with its bilateral creditors, including India and China, to restructure its debt amid a deep financial crisis. The talks, led by Sri Lanka's Treasury Secretary and Central Bank governor, aim to carve a path out of the country's worst financial crisis in decades. The country defaulted on its foreign debt in May, and the meeting is expected to discuss reforms and a possible haircut on debt. Chinese officials indicated a willingness to be more flexible on maturity extensions, but remain unwilling to accept haircuts.

site_title: Meta’s India head Ajit Mohan quits to join Snap
summary: Meta Platforms announced the departure of Ajit Mohan, its India head, who has joined Snap as president, Asia-Pacific. Mohan left after four years in the role, amid regulatory challenges in India where Meta faces criticism for spreading fake news and hate speech. Manish Chopra will take over as interim head of Meta India. The move comes as Meta remains "deeply committed to India," according to Nicola Mendelsohn, vice-president of the global business group.

site_title: OUE C-Reit posts 4.4% rise in net property income in Q3
summary: OUE C-Reit reported a 4.4% year-on-year rise in net property income in Q3, reaching S$48.3 million, driven by lower property expenses. Revenue increased 1.7% to S$59.5 million. The Reit's manager attributed the growth to cost-cutting measures.

site_title: UOI 9M 2022 net profit falls 38.7%
summary: UOI, the general insurance arm of UOB, reported a 38.7% fall in net profit to S$10.5 million for the first nine months of 2022, due to higher claims and lower management expenses. However, net underwriting profit increased by 1.6% to S$12.4 million. The decline in net asset value per share to S$6.72 was attributed to the loss.

site_title: US service sector slows in October; price pressures build up: ISM survey
summary: The US services industry experienced its slowest growth in nearly 2-1/2 years in October, with the ISM survey's non-manufacturing PMI falling to 54.4 from 56.7 in September. Despite this, businesses continued to face higher prices for inputs, indicating inflation is shifting from goods to services. Economists had forecast a reading of 55.5, and a reading above 50 indicates expansion. The services sector accounts for over two-thirds of the US economy.

images.alt_text: The Commerce Department said on Thursday (Nov 3) that the trade deficit increased 11.6 per cent to US$73.3 billion. Exports of goods and services fell 1.1 per cent, while imports increased 1.5 per cent.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits slipped 1,000 to a seasonally adjusted 217,000 for the week ended Oct 29, the Labor Department said on Thursday (Nov 3).

site_title: NYSE parent ICE beats profit estimates, takes US$1.1b writedown
summary: ICE, the parent company of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE), reported a loss of 34 cents per share in the third quarter due to a US$1.1 billion impairment charge related to its investment in Bakkt Holding. Despite this, the company beat profit estimates and saw robust trading volumes, with adjusted quarterly profit coming in at US$1.31 per share. Revenue from its biggest exchanges segment rose nearly 10% to US$1.6 billion, and total revenue exceeded analysts' estimates. The company attributes its strong growth to market volatility and investors shifting out of higher-fee risk assets.

site_title: Microsoft extends free tech support for Ukraine through 2023
summary: Microsoft is extending free tech support for Ukraine through 2023, providing an additional $100 million in technology aid, bringing the total support to over $400 million since the crisis began in February. This support will help government agencies, critical infrastructure, and other sectors in Ukraine continue to run their digital infrastructure and serve citizens through the Microsoft Cloud.

images.alt_text: MICROSOFT is substantially reducing its business in Russia, joining the list of prominent technology firms cutting back or exiting the country altogether after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
A handful of hacker groups aligned with the Russian government have carried out hundreds of cyberattacks against Ukraine since Moscow invaded, Microsoft said in a report on Wednesday.

site_title: US mortgage rates pull back after three straight weeks of gains
summary: US mortgage rates fell to 6.95% after three weeks of gains, marking a decline from a two-decade high. Despite the drop, rates have more than doubled this year, pushing out would-be buyers and fuelling a drop in home prices. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike has contributed to the decline, with the average monthly payment on a $300,000 mortgage increasing by $685 since January. Real estate companies are feeling the impact, with Opendoor Technologies laying off 550 employees due to the challenging market.

images.alt_text: The ISM survey’s measure of services industry supplier deliveries increased to 56.2 last month from 53.9 in September.

The Commerce Department said on Thursday (Nov 3) that the trade deficit increased 11.6 per cent to US$73.3 billion. Exports of goods and services fell 1.1 per cent, while imports increased 1.5 per cent.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits slipped 1,000 to a seasonally adjusted 217,000 for the week ended Oct 29, the Labor Department said on Thursday (Nov 3).

site_title: Fidelity opens wait list for retail crypto trading with zero fee
summary: Fidelity Investments has launched a wait list for its retail crypto trading platform, Fidelity Crypto, offering zero-commission trading for Bitcoin and Ethereum. The platform will provide custody and trading of the two tokens, with an integrated view of both crypto and traditional investments. A spread of no more than 1% will be collected, and additional cryptocurrencies are being evaluated. Fidelity aims to reach younger clients, following the recent launch of a new mobile app and investment account for teenagers. The platform's launch is part of Fidelity's expansion into digital assets, which is expected to bring in 500 employees by the end of 2024.

site_title: US factory orders rise moderately in September
summary: US factory orders rose 0.3% in September, matching economists' expectations, after a 0.2% gain in August. The increase was driven by a 2.2% advance in transportation equipment bookings, including a 21.9% rebound in civilian aircraft. However, orders for computers, electronic products, electrical equipment, and machinery declined. The Federal Reserve raised its policy rate by 0.75% to 3.75-4.00% to combat inflation, signaling future rate hikes in smaller steps. Manufacturing accounts for 11.3% of the US economy, with a survey showing its manufacturing PMI fell to its lowest level in nearly 2.5 years.

images.alt_text: The ISM survey’s measure of services industry supplier deliveries increased to 56.2 last month from 53.9 in September.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits slipped 1,000 to a seasonally adjusted 217,000 for the week ended Oct 29, the Labor Department said on Thursday (Nov 3).

The Commerce Department said on Thursday (Nov 3) that the trade deficit increased 11.6 per cent to US$73.3 billion. Exports of goods and services fell 1.1 per cent, while imports increased 1.5 per cent.

site_title: US trade deficit widens in September
summary: The US trade deficit widened 11.6% to $73.3 billion in September, driven by a strong US dollar and softening global demand. Exports of goods and services fell 1.1%, while imports increased 1.5%. This increase in the trade deficit was a contributing factor to the US economy's 2.6% annualized growth rate in the third quarter, following a 0.6% contraction in the second quarter.

site_title: Shell's flagship LNG trading made nearly US$1b loss in Q3
summary: Shell's LNG trading division reported a nearly US$1 billion loss in Q3 due to a wrong bet on the difference between Asian and European gas prices. The loss was caused by a sharp rally in European gas prices after Russia halted supplies. This was despite Shell's second-largest quarterly profit of US$9.45 billion reported earlier in the week. The company does not disclose trading results, but the loss highlights the volatility of the gas market.

images.alt_text: Shell is one of Australia’s biggest liquefied natural gas exporters.

site_title: US dollar rallies after hawkish Fed; pound slides as BOE warns of ‘very challenging’ outlook
summary: The US dollar strengthened after the Federal Reserve signaled higher interest rates, while the pound slid after the Bank of England raised rates but warned of a "very challenging" outlook. The BOE lifted UK interest rates to 3% and forecast inflation to hit a 40-year high of around 11%, but pushed back against expectations for further steep rate hikes. The pound initially fell by 1.7% against the US dollar before recovering some ground.

site_title: Canada orders three Chinese firms to exit lithium mining
summary: Canada ordered three Chinese firms, Ganfeng Lithium, China Lithium Corporation, and Ganfeng Group, to divest their investments in Canadian critical minerals due to national security concerns. The decision was made after "rigorous scrutiny" by Canada's National Security and Intelligence Community. China responded, accusing Ottawa of using national security as a pretext and violating international commerce rules. The order is seen as part of Canada's efforts to secure critical minerals needed for a cleaner economy.

site_title: Streaming tech firm Roku dives as tough ad market hits performance
summary: Roku's market capitalization dropped nearly 20% on Nov 3 after the company issued downbeat forecasts for fourth-quarter revenue, which was substantially below market estimates. The adjusted operating loss outlook was also wider than Wall Street expectations. Analysts attribute the decline to a tough ad market, citing similar warnings from Snap, Meta, and Alphabet. Roku's stock has lost over three-quarters of its value this year, with some analysts predicting it may be "dead money" for the next two quarters but expecting a rebound within the next year.

site_title: Digital payments firm Stripe to lay off 14% of workforce
summary: Digital payments firm Stripe is laying off 14% of its workforce, reducing its employee count to approximately 7,000, following a 28% cut in its internal valuation. The layoffs come amid a tough investment market, with startups struggling to justify high valuations due to tightening monetary policy and recession concerns. Stripe's founders cited overhiring and growing operating costs too quickly as reasons for the cuts, stating they were overly optimistic about the Internet economy's near-term growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Small toy figures are seen in front of Stripe logo in this illustration picture taken March 15, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Chef Joe Leong balances croissants and mod-Asian cooking at Sonder
summary: Sonder, a Singaporean eatery, excels in its bread offerings but stumbles in hot cooking. Chef Joe Leong's pastry background is evident in his croissants, which are light and flaky. However, his attempts at savory dishes are uncertain, with some promising ideas falling short in execution. Tasting menus start at $88, and while the bread is a highlight, the restaurant's overall performance is a mixed bag. Despite this, Leong shows determination and a strong foundation in his baking skills, suggesting potential for growth and improvement.

images.alt_text: Summer Hill's mural tries to brighten up a dull walkway in Claymore Connect.

site_title: Aztech Global net profit grows 34.2% for 9M 2022, declares interim dividend of S$0.03 per share
summary: Aztech Global's nine-month net profit rose 34.2% to S$63.7 million, driven by strong revenue from IoT devices and data communication products. Revenue grew 55.4% to S$607 million, and the company declared an interim dividend of S$0.03 per share, totaling S$23.2 million. Despite a 0.61% decline in shares, the group's order book remains healthy at S$783.3 million.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
