Chipmakers around the world have already begun to trade at significantly lower valuations, and that negative sentiment is spreading to Singapore’s shores.
Maybank Securities noted in its Wednesday market report that the strong earnings posted by semiconductor-related stocks in Q3 might not hold in the longer term.
Michael Mun, executive chairman (right) and CEO, as well as Jeremy Mun, executive director and COO for Aztech Global. CGS-CIMB has reduced its price target on the stock to S$0.96 form S$1.22.

site_title: Lawyers, general counsel and boards – the next level of partnership
summary: General counsel (GCs) are evolving from gatekeepers to influencers and trusted advisors to boards and top management. To succeed, GCs must step out of their legal box and provide solutions to issues, rather than just offering opinions on compliance. They must balance company performance and corporate integrity, building trust with the board and senior management. GCs should be proactive in counselling the board on how legal and regulatory environments can be used to a company's strategic advantage, and are increasingly expected to attend board and senior management discussions.

images.alt_text: Businesses need to be responsive to their stakeholders in the ESG space to remain relevant, competitive and sustainable.

site_title: US labour market resilience persists; productivity remains weak
summary: US labor market remains resilient despite slowing domestic demand and interest rate hikes. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell to 217,000 for the week ended October 29, down 1,000 from the previous week. The labor market's strength gives the Federal Reserve cover to continue tightening monetary policy. Productivity, however, remains weak, with hourly output per worker increasing only 0.3% annually, and unit labor costs rising 3.5% due to wage pressures.

images.alt_text: A resilient job market has fuelled fast wage growth, contributing to rapid inflation and putting pressure on the Fed to aggressively tighten monetary policy.

site_title: Marriott joins Hilton in lifting profit forecast on unabated travel demand
summary: Marriott International raised its annual profit forecast, joining Hilton in doing so, due to strong travel demand despite recession risks. The company expects adjusted profit per share of $6.51 to $6.58, up from its previous forecast of $6.33 to $6.59. Marriott CEO Anthony Capuano anticipates continued demand growth and a 2-4% increase in global RevPAR compared to 2019.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage for the New York Marriott Marquis is seen in Manhattan, New York, November 16, 2015. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
Hilton, which own several brands including the Waldorf Astoria Hotels & Resorts, said it now expects net income between US$1.22 billion and US$1.24 billion this year

site_title: Thai monetary policy will consider economic outlook, inflation: central bank
summary: Thailand's central bank said its monetary policy will consider the country's economic outlook, inflation rate, and financial stability. Despite a weakening baht currency, capital flows remain normal, according to Bank of Thailand's assistant governor Chayawadee Chai-Anant. The bank's comments come after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates, prompting short-term volatility in Thai capital markets. The Bank of Thailand will accommodate economic recovery and manage the impact of the Fed rate hikes, with Finance Minister Arkhom Termpittayapaisith stating that the central bank will take a flexible approach to monetary policy.

site_title: Under Armour cuts annual forecasts as sportswear demand slumps
summary: Under Armour cut its annual revenue and profit forecasts, citing weakening demand from consumers due to inflation and a stronger US dollar. The company, which has been increasing discounts and promotions, boosted its net revenue by 2% in the latest quarter. Under Armour now forecasts low single-digit percentage growth in net sales for fiscal 2023, down from an earlier outlook of 5-7%. The company's shares rose 2% in premarket trading, despite a 2/3 decline in value this year.

site_title: Yusnor Ef named Lifetime Achiever at 24th Berita Harian Achiever of the Year awards
summary: Malay music veteran Yusnor Ef, known as the "grandfather of Malay songs," was named Lifetime Achiever at the 24th Berita Harian Achiever of the Year awards. The 85-year-old has penned hundreds of Malay songs and held various professional roles, including educator, comedian, and film expert. He received the award for his lifetime accomplishments, with Ef expressing gratitude and hope to inspire younger generations. The awards also recognized Associate Professor Hadijah Rahmat and Lee Syafiq Muhd Ridzuan Lee as Achiever of the Year and Young Achiever of the Year, respectively.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
Incoming IMF CIO and late batik artist named Berita Harian Achiever of the Year 2021

site_title: Bank of England hikes rate by biggest amount in 33 years
summary: The Bank of England raised interest rates to 3% on November 3, its largest hike in 33 years, to combat a predicted 40-year high inflation rate of around 11% during the current quarter. The central bank forecasts a recession that could last two years, with unemployment rising to 6.4% by late 2025. The decision was in line with economists' expectations but not unanimous, with two policymakers voting for smaller increases. The BOE warned that further rate rises may be needed for a sustainable return to inflation target.

images.alt_text: While the BOE is expected to deliver a 75 basis-points hike on Thursday, its biggest since 1989, the risk is that the move doesn’t filter fully through to the market.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on rate hike worries
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, November 3, 2022, due to concerns over the US Federal Reserve's rate-hike cycle. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 162.71 points, or 0.51%, to 31,985.05. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped, with the S&P 500 falling 26.44 points, or 0.70%, and the Nasdaq Composite falling 125.35 points, or 1.19%. The rate hike worries outweighed hints of smaller rate increases in the future.

site_title: Former Pakistan PM Imran Khan shot and wounded in ‘clear assassination’ attempt
summary: Former Pakistan Prime Minister Imran Khan was shot in the shin during a protest convoy attack in Wazirabad, nearly 200 km from Islamabad, in what his aides described as a clear assassination attempt. Khan was taken to hospital and is stable, while several others in the convoy were wounded. A suspect has been arrested, and reports indicate one person may have been killed. The attack comes amid ongoing protests by Khan's party, the Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, demanding snap elections.

site_title: Cheniere Energy revenue more than doubles on soaring LNG demand
summary: Cheniere Energy's revenue more than doubled to US$8.85 billion in the third quarter, driven by soaring liquefied natural gas (LNG) demand following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The company's LNG revenue increased significantly, and it also posted a year-over-year increase in revenue. Cheniere is expanding its LNG capacity, with Stage III expected to enter service in 2025 and additional liquefaction trains under development. The company has a US$5.5 billion contract to build the Stage III trains and holds significant land positions for further capacity expansion.

site_title: A mission to turn customers into brand advocates, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Alibaba Group has expanded its AI cloud services to Malaysia and the Philippines, aiming to boost its presence in Southeast Asia. The move is part of Alibaba's efforts to strengthen its cloud computing business globally. The AI cloud services will enable businesses in the region to leverage cutting-edge AI technologies, such as natural language processing and computer vision. This expansion is expected to drive economic growth and create new opportunities for Malaysian and Filipino businesses. Alibaba's cloud services will be available to businesses in both countries through its cloud platform, Alibaba Cloud.

site_title: After latest rate hike, Federal Reserve looks set to drive US economy into recession
summary: The US Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 75 basis points, bringing the benchmark overnight rate to 3.75-4%, for the sixth rate increase of 2022. Fed Chairman Jerome Powell signaled that the central bank will continue to raise rates to combat inflation, contradicting market expectations of a pivot. This move is expected to push mortgage rates beyond their current 20-year high and potentially drive the US economy into recession. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell by over 400 points, and Powell warned that stopping rate hikes too soon could be more detrimental than going too far.

images.alt_text: US wheat prices, which spiked following Russia's first attacks on Ukraine, have fallen 31.8 per cent from their March highs.
Price pressure may rise further as the Malaysian government plans to reduce subsidies next year.
Higher borrowing costs add to headwinds facing Hong Kong’s economy.

site_title: Tesla’s China deliveries fall in October from a record high
summary: Tesla's China deliveries fell 14% in October to 71,704 cars, after reaching a record high of 83,135 in September. The automaker cut prices across its lineup to boost sales amid competitive and economic pressures. Total new energy vehicle sales in China rose 87% to 680,000 units, with BYD remaining the top seller with 217,518 deliveries. The price cuts aim to increase sales and counter the challenges posed by economic conditions in the Chinese market.

site_title: UK services slump at fastest pace since early 2021
summary: The UK services sector experienced its fastest decline since January 2021, with the S&P Global UK Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) falling to 48.8 in October, below the 50.0 threshold for growth. This marked the biggest contraction in business activity since the start of 2021. Rising energy costs, increased borrowing costs, and volatile financial markets are contributing to the slowdown, with household spending and business investment decreasing. The Bank of England is expected to raise interest rates sharply, and the economic indicators point to a worsening slowdown, raising concerns about a potential recession.

images.alt_text: The BOE is coordinating with the government on which bonds to sell and when. A gilt maturing in 2029 is excluded from Tuesday’s sale because it was recently auctioned by the DMO.

site_title: Goldman-backed project44 valued at US$2.7b in latest funding round
summary: US-based supply chain management technology company project44 has secured a $80 million funding round, valuing it at $2.7 billion. The funding, led by Generation Investment Management and AP Moller Holding, will be used to measure and reduce emissions across its global supply chain. Founded in 2014, project44 provides technology to shippers, carriers, and logistics professionals, including customers like Coty, Baker Hughes, and Nordstrom. The company aims to address supply chain bottlenecks, which have worsened inflation and pressure on central banks to control price hikes.

site_title: Britain’s Rolls-Royce sticks to guidance despite inflation headwinds
summary: Rolls-Royce maintained its 2022 forecasts despite rising energy and raw material costs, as well as supply chain challenges. CEO Warren East stated that the company's pandemic-induced cuts positioned it well for the uncertain economic environment. The company aims for low-to-mid-single digit underlying revenue growth, a profit margin similar to last year, and modestly positive cash flow. Despite a 5% drop in shares, Rolls-Royce remains optimistic about its recovery from the pandemic. New CEO Tufan Erginbilgic will face challenges including £4 billion in Covid-19 debts and travel restrictions in China.

site_title: Switzerland, Singapore, Denmark rank top three on global talent competitiveness index: Insead
summary: Switzerland, Singapore, and Denmark top the global talent competitiveness index, according to a report by Insead. The US ranks fourth, while China moves up to 36th place, marking a new record. The report highlights rising international tensions, inflation, and financial shocks as significant impacts on labor markets, particularly in poorer economies. Experts call for employers to adapt to new work trends and governments to address talent inequalities, especially in achieving sustainable development goals.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

The Fullerton Hotel, center left, and commercial buildings in the central business district are illuminated at night in Singapore, on Wednesday, June 13, 2018. Tourism as well as the consumer sector will likely see a lift thanks to the influx of international media at the recent DPRK-USA Summit, according to RHB Research Institute Singapore Pte. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

site_title: China’s venture funding tumbles after crackdown
summary: China's venture funding has plummeted 44% to $62.1 billion through October, making it one of the worst-performing countries globally, after the Communist Party's crackdown on tech giants and declining tech valuations. Venture firms have pulled back globally, with China's decline worse than the global drop and US pullback. The semiconductor sector remains a bright spot, with $7.9 billion in deals so far in 2022. The US-China tensions have driven investors to regional clusters, and investors are assessing which technologies may be affected by the two nations' considerations.

images.alt_text: A robotic dog at the Digital Media Experience Space following a press conference at the Hotel Nikko New Century in Beijing on Monday (Oct 17). Reporters were briefed on how the Communist Party of China (CPC) will continue to exercise its strict self-governance over the party.
Preqin forecasts that Asia-Pacific VC funds will post annualised returns of 16 per cent from 2021 to 2027, lower than the returns from 2018 to 2021.

site_title: Caution reigns at state land tenders, despite developers’ low unsold private housing inventory
summary: State land tenders for private housing and EC plots drew fewer-than-expected bids, with caution prevailing among developers due to rising interest rates, cooling measures, and macroeconomic uncertainties. The Hillview Rise site, near Beauty World station, received four bids, with Far East Organization and Sekisui House's top bid of S$320.78 million (S$1,024 psf ppr). The Bukit Timah Link site, near Hillview MRT station, fetched five bids, with Bukit Sembawang Estates' top bid of S$200 million (S$1,343.13 psf ppr). Developers expect launch prices to range from S$1,800 to S$2,300 psf for new projects on these sites.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

CMG20220831-HoPY01/韩宝镇/何炳耀/URA launches tender for two residential sites at Bukit Timah Link and Hillview Rise[Bukit Timah Link & Hillview Rise]

Location:Hillview Rise Site
Photo by Yen Meng Jiin. Generic pictures of properties in Singapore
krtender2 - Aerial view of Dunman Road site
The Hillview Rise site spans an area of 10,395.2 sq m and has a maximum GFA of 29,107 sq m.

krtender13 - Land parcel along Lentor Central. URA tender for this site closes on September 13, 2022.



Source: URA

site_title: Cracks in Vietnam the latest alarm from frontier markets
summary: Vietnam's financial markets are experiencing a downturn, with the benchmark stock index and currency heading for their worst annual performance since the 2008 financial crisis. A crackdown on property lending, a falling currency, and rising interest rates are major contributors to the decline. The property sector, which accounts for a significant chunk of the US$24 billion corporate bond market, is particularly affected. Foreign fund managers who had invested in Vietnam as a promising destination for manufacturing investment from companies like Apple and Samsung are now facing losses.

images.alt_text: Investors have poured money into investment apps targeting millennials.

site_title: Morgan Stanley to start lay-offs in coming weeks as dealmaking slows: sources
summary: Morgan Stanley is set to start layoffs globally in the coming weeks, with the majority of cuts expected to come from teams focusing on China-related business in the Asia-Pacific region. The bank's headcount reduction plans come as dealmaking slows due to rising inflation and an economic downturn. The cuts, which will be greater than the bank's annual staff losses from natural attrition in the region, are expected to affect teams in Hong Kong and mainland China, as well as its technology investment banking team in the Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The corporate logo of financial firm Morgan Stanley is pictured on the company's world headquarters in the Manhattan borough of New York City, January 20, 2015.   REUTERS/Mike Segar (UNITED STATES - Tags: BUSINESS LOGO)/File Photo

site_title: STI sheds 1.2% on Thursday as US Fed hike spooks markets
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.2% to close at 3,102.51 points on Thursday, following overnight losses on Wall Street amid the US Federal Reserve's 75-basis-point rate hike. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.6%, the S&P 500 shed 2.5%, and the Nasdaq Composite tumbled 3.4%. Local lenders DBS, UOB, and OCBC led the losses, with investors awaiting the US Consumer Price Index (CPI) print for a potential market rebound.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Wall Street's overnight losses following US Fed's remark that inflation was still high and more rate hikes are afoot dented sentiments in the Singapore bourse

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore aims to establish itself as a crypto assets hub, but it will focus on tokenising assets for use cases that increase economic efficiency or social inclusion, rather than trading and speculating in cryptocurrencies. This approach is emphasized by Ravi Menon, managing director of the Monetary Authority of Singapore.

site_title: Driving South-east Asia’s great green transition
summary: Singapore is poised to lead Southeast Asia's transition to a net-zero economy, driven by the growth of its green financial ecosystem. The city-state is home to the Asia-Pacific arm of the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero, which aims to support investors' concerns about net-zero by 2050. To achieve this, a just transition must prioritize energy security, economic, and social equity, and require collective efforts from governments, regulators, consumers, investors, financial institutions, and the real economy. The region faces a 35% risk of losing GDP by 2050 due to climate change, making a successful transition crucial.

images.alt_text: As the focus of stakeholders shifts more towards climate-related issues, auditing practices have to change in order for financial statements to remain “useful and relevant”, said KPMG Singapore partner Reinhard Klemmer.

site_title: India's Adani Wilmar profit plunges on cost rise, soft rural demand
summary: India's Adani Wilmar reported a 73% slump in second-quarter profit to 487.6 million rupees due to dull rural demand and industry-wide input cost inflation. The company's total expenses rose 6% to 141.5 billion rupees, while revenue from operations increased by 4% to 141.5 billion rupees. Adani Wilmar attributes the decline to challenges in edible oil demand and macro headwinds such as high inflation and delayed monsoon. The company expects a recovery in consumer demand in the second half of the fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Adani Wilmar, the kitchen essentials firm owned by Gautam Adani, has earmarked 5 billion rupees (S$88.4 million) from its initial public offering for purchases.
Wilmar International’s headquarters at Biopolis Road, Singapore. In spite of a strong Q3 FY2022 performance, brokerages hold mixed views on the agribusiness giant's earnings prospects going forward.

site_title: On the path to net zero, architects race to design greener
summary: Architects in Singapore are designing greener buildings to meet the country's goal of net-zero emissions by 2050. The 63-storey tower at 8 Shenton Way, designed by Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, aims for a 55% energy reduction compared to the benchmark and is expected to obtain the Building Construction Authority's Green Mark Platinum certification. The building features an expansive landscaped lobby and terrace, providing an indoor-outdoor gathering space for occupants. This design aims to reduce carbon footprint and promote sustainability in the built environment.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang
Sustainability is key at Potato Head in Bali.

site_title: WhatsApp launches Communities group organiser feature
summary: WhatsApp is rolling out a "Communities" feature, allowing administrators to organize multiple chat groups under a single umbrella and send alerts to thousands of users. The feature also includes larger group video calls and in-chat polls. Chat groups can now have up to 1,024 users, a significant increase from the previous 256 participants. This move aims to make the feature more suitable for workplaces and schools, competing with rival messaging apps like Telegram and Discord.

site_title: Companies filing corporate taxes from software get automatic 15-day extension: Iras
summary: The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore (Iras) has announced that companies and tax agents filing corporate income tax returns from software will receive an automatic 15-day extension of their filing due date for the 2023-2025 years of assessment. This extension is in support of companies and tax agents transitioning to using software for Form C-S filings. Additionally, penalties for errors due to unfamiliarity with software use will be waived.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay

site_title: SGX RegCo proposes amendments to CDP margining and clearing fund rules
summary: SGX RegCo proposes amendments to the Central Depository's (CDP) margining and clearing fund rules to reduce the likelihood of using the clearing fund in the event of a default. Proposed changes include differentiated margin rates for groups of securities with different risk profiles, margin offsets for Group One securities, and enhanced anti-procyclicality measures. Additionally, four other changes are proposed to the clearing fund, including refining the approach for determining the size of the clearing fund, apportioning contributions among clearing members, de-prioritizing contingent contributions, and introducing a cap on contributions used for each default. The public consultation will close on Dec 5.

images.alt_text: SGX RegCo upcoming consultation on pay disclosure comes amid poor compliance from SGX-listed companies when it comes to remuneration disclosures, which currently apply on a “comply or explain” basis.

site_title: Europe leans on Asia for 'homegrown' EV batteries
summary: European startups building electric vehicle (EV) gigafactories face funding challenges as investors shy away from backing them against Asian competitors. Despite some exceptions, such as Sweden's Northvolt, most startups aim for smaller plants to attract further investment. Britishvolt, a UK-based startup, is struggling to secure £3.8 billion to build a gigafactory in northern England, putting its plans in jeopardy. The EU's drive to create a homegrown EV battery industry is being hindered by investor skepticism, highlighting the need for more investment and support to challenge Asian dominance in the market.

images.alt_text: Demand for lithium, a material that’s key to the renewable-energy transition, is forecast to almost triple by mid-decade from last year’s level.
While the semiconductor crunch was easing, other supply chain issues were looming on Stellantis’ operations, especially around logistics in Europe.

site_title: Rare vintage Cartier on show in Singapore
summary: A rare vintage Cartier collection is on display at Dover Street Market Singapore, featuring exquisite pieces crafted decades ago. The exhibition showcases items such as a 1928 pearl-and-diamond wristwatch, a Turbogas choker from the 1970s, and a Lovebirds brooch from 1950. The collection includes jewellery, watches, clocks, and objets d'art, highlighting Cartier's timeless designs and creative excellence. The exhibition runs from November 4-17 at DSMS, with private appointments available from November 4-7.

images.alt_text: Volutes Mystérieuses transformable necklace and earrings with detachable pendants in white and rose gold with diamonds and rubies

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close down more than 3%
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed down 3.08% on Nov 3, following a plunge on Wall Street, as US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell indicated interest rates would rise to fight inflation. The losses reversed two days of gains, which were driven by speculation of China's potential policy rollbacks. The Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined, with the Hang Seng Index falling to 15,339.49.

site_title: Indonesia sees higher crude oil price boosting bio-content in fuel
summary: Indonesia is considering raising its mandatory 30% mix of palm oil in biodiesel to 40%, or B40, due to the higher price of crude oil. The country is conducting a road test for B40, with trial results expected to be completed in the next two weeks. The move aims to reduce production costs and increase the use of palm oil-based fuel, which could boost consumption to 15 million kiloliters a year. The government has not yet decided on the implementation timeline for the B40 mandate.

images.alt_text: Indonesian authorities are attempting to pump out the oil from a supertanker that ran aground in Indonesian waters just off Singapore.

site_title: A history of economic Whac-a-Mole
summary: US monetary and fiscal policymaking since the 1960s has been likened to a never-ending game of Whac-A-Mole, with no linear development or progress in managing modern economies for macroeconomic stability. According to a new book by Princeton University economist Alan S. Blinder, historical contingency drives economic problems, and policymakers often respond to new issues without fully addressing previous ones. The book highlights the limitations of current theoretical frameworks, including monetarism and New Keynesian DSGE models, and emphasizes the need for policymakers to consider the complexities of fiscal policy in managing demand and supporting growth.

images.alt_text: After two hikes in July and September, it appears that the US Federal Reserve may have given up on trying to find a safe path between secular stagnation and stagflation, and started to hew toward the former.
Finding a vision for our time

site_title: India’s top mortgage lender HDFC reports 18% rise in Q2 profit
summary: HDFC, India's largest mortgage lender, reported a 17.8% rise in Q2 profit to 44.54 billion Indian rupees, driven by strong demand for home loans despite interest rate hikes. Interest income rose 24% to 131.43 billion rupees. Analysts had expected a profit of 41.55 billion rupees. The lender's net interest margin fell to 3.4% in the first six months due to increased funding costs. HDFC is set to merge with HDFC Bank to create a lending behemoth with a combined balance sheet of US$237 billion.

site_title: T:>Works dives headlong into NFT world
summary: Singapore's performing arts company T:>Works is launching its first NFT series, featuring 30 single-edition digital artworks by artist Brian Gothong Tan. The collection, titled "Metazomia," is a visual representation of Tan's concept of a new world order. The NFTs will be minted on the Polygon blockchain, which has pledged to be climate-positive, and will be sold in a silent auction from Nov 8-18, 2022. The company aims to engage with the digital arts landscape and promote sustainability in the creative industry.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

Creative entrepreneur Jaye Foo (centre) launches the Bored And Boozy beer (left) featuring Bored Apes avatars, as well as a virtual band called Manifest featuring CryptoPunk avatars (right). He and fellow NFT enthusiasts often meet at The Parlour (centre), an "NFT bar and lounge" which Foo owns to discuss how to monetise their NFTs. 

Credit : JAYE FOO
Conditions for usage: Free use with credit
put into BT EL

hynft2 - Shavonne Wong and Lenne Chai's series of 60 NFTs follows a digitally-sculpted girl on the cusp of adolescence. The successful series sold out in less than an hour in April, before the collapse of terraUSD in May. This work is inspired by Hitchcock's The Birds.

Credit : SHAVONNE WONG/LENNE CHAI
Conditions for usage: Free with credit
Janesh is seeking to repossess BAYC No. 2162 from an online persona named “chefpierre”, whose identity is stated as unknown in court documents. His lawsuit, commenced in Singapore, is still ongoing.

site_title: Turbulent times weigh on UOB Painting winners
summary: This year's UOB Painting of the Year winners in Singapore focus on turbulent social, political, and economic changes, depicting human struggles in the face of 2022's challenges. Winners, such as Thai artist Chomrawi Suksom, use elaborate visual metaphors to convey the difficulties of war, inflation, and restarting lives. In contrast to previous years, melancholic pandemic-themed paintings have largely disappeared, instead, artists opt for more complex and nuanced representations of the world's troubles.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

hyuob3 - (PHOTO CANNOT BE CROPPED) A Painting about Nothing and Everything by Lester Lee won the UOB Painting of the Year (Singapore).



Credit : UOB

site_title: Volume of ESG bond issuances declines 13% to US$215b in Q3 2022: Moody’s report
summary: Moody's report reveals a 13% decline in global ESG bond issuances to $215 billion in Q3 2022, down from $248 billion in the same period last year. The decline is attributed to a challenging macroeconomic and geopolitical environment. Over the first nine months of 2022, $679 billion of ESG bonds were issued, a 17% decrease from the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Janice Lim
At least 35% of bonds in Asia ex-Japan will be ESG-labelled in 2023: JPMorgan
Relatively newer sustainable bond markets around the globe are increasingly complementing sustained growth in more seasoned markets such as China, according to Moody's ESG Solutions.

site_title: Stellantis Q3 sales up 29% as better chip supplies lift shipments
summary: Stellantis reported a 29% increase in Q3 sales, driven by better semiconductor supplies and higher volumes. Net revenues reached 42.1 billion euros, exceeding analyst expectations. Consolidated shipments rose 13% to 1.281 million units, with global BEV sales increasing 42% to 68,000 units. Logistics issues in Europe led to an increase in vehicle inventory stock, while dealer sales to final customers were down 4%. Despite supply chain concerns, the company remains confident in its ability to manage production without significant interruptions.

site_title: Nissan stops taking orders of Sakura EV, X-Trail in Japan
summary: Nissan has temporarily stopped taking new orders for its Sakura EV and X-Trail crossover in Japan due to prolonged delivery periods of a year or more. The company had initially attracted 23,000 orders for the Sakura and had also stopped taking new orders for the Leaf EV. The suspension is for the domestic market, and Nissan's spokesperson cited the global semiconductor chip shortage as a major factor. The move aims to draw more Japanese drivers to battery-powered cars, but it remains unclear when the company will resume taking orders.

images.alt_text: Nissan in a statement said it had decided to exit the Russian market and expected to incur an extraordinary loss of approximately 100 billion yen from the asset transfer.

site_title: Europe: Stocks sink after Fed news, before BOE decision
summary: European stocks plummeted 0.9-1.1% on Thursday, November 3, amid a global selloff following the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and hints of further increases. The Bank of England is expected to raise borrowing costs by 0.75 percentage points, its largest hike since 1989, to combat inflation. Analysts predict the move will be insufficient to curb inflation, leading to a potential full percentage point hike in the future. The decision is set to be made later Thursday, with markets watching closely for its impact on the economy.

site_title: India banks’ reliance on bulk deposits rises amid strong credit growth, tight liquidity
summary: Indian banks are relying more on certificates of deposits (CDs) due to strong credit growth and tight liquidity in the banking system. Credit demand remains high, while retail deposit inflows lag, leading to a liquidity deficit. Major state-run and private banks are raising funds through CDs, with credit growth jumping 17.95% in the fortnight ended October 7. Despite a recent surplus, liquidity is expected to remain tight in the rest of the year due to normalization of monetary policy, currency leakage, and potential RBI intervention in the foreign exchange market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A customer hands Indian currency notes to an attendant at a fuel station in Mumbai, India, August 13, 2018. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo

site_title: Ant digital bank expands in Singapore with small business loans
summary: Ant Group's Singapore digital wholesale bank, Anext Bank, will offer loans to small and medium-sized businesses, ranging from S$5,000 to S$100,000. This move aims to diversify Ant's business and generate growth in the city-state, where regulatory headwinds at home are expected to impact its operations. Anext Bank can be applied for through IN Financial Technologies and Bizmann System, expanding Ant's fintech reach in South-east Asia, similar to its successful strategies in China.

images.alt_text: Angel Zhao, president of Ant’s international business group, says e-wallets are a “valuable and effective” channel for digital marketing.

site_title: Seoul: Shares fall after Fed rate hike; battery makers jump
summary: South Korean shares fell 0.33% to close at 2,329.17 due to the US Federal Reserve's hawkish comments and fourth consecutive 75-basis-point rate hike. However, battery manufacturers saw gains on solid earnings, limiting losses. The South Korean won weakened, and the benchmark bond yield rose.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong led the losses as traders gave back a chunk of the previous two days’ gains that came on the back of speculation China was planning to roll back some of its painful zero-Covid policies.

site_title: iPhone factory lockdown shows risks of China dependence, analysts say
summary: Foxconn, Apple's principal subcontractor, has locked down its Zhengzhou factory in China due to a surge in Covid-19 cases, highlighting the risks of relying on China's manufacturing sector. The lockdown, which affects the world's largest iPhone producer, has resulted in a 10-30% loss of production, according to analyst estimates. Apple's heavy dependence on China poses potential risks, especially given the ongoing US-China trade war. The company has begun outsourcing production to India and is considering Vietnam as a way to diversify its manufacturing.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This file photo taken on May 27, 2010 shows Chinese workers in the Foxconn factory in Shenzhen, in southern China's Guangdong province. - Chinese authorities locked down the area surrounding the world's largest iPhone factory on November 2, 2022, after workers fled to avoid a coronavirus outbreak and the resulting restrictions. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: Ajoomma: Life as it tumbles along
summary: The Singapore film "Ajoomma" has garnered international recognition, earning four Golden Horse Awards nominations and an official selection into the 2023 Oscars race. Directed by He Shuming, the film tells the story of a middle-aged woman, Lim Bee Hwa, who embarks on a late-life cross-cultural adventure after her son cancels their trip to South Korea. The film, which explores themes of loss, self-discovery, and the beauty of everyday life, has been praised for its relatable characters and unexpected moments. With its modest budget, "Ajoomma" has proven to be a charming and captivating film that has resonated with audiences worldwide.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof
Kinuyo Tanaka (right) directing top actor Shuji Sano in The Moon Has Risen (1955).

In today's age of AI, the eerie central conceit of Pinocchio – the talking, walking puppet, lively yet not wholly alive, and the attendant issue of what makes a “real boy” – has never been more pressing or more provocative.

site_title: BMW expects sales dent as inflation hits consumer buying power
summary: BMW reported a better-than-expected quarterly net profit of 4.1 billion euros, driven by high car prices despite lower sales volumes due to supply chain issues. The company warned that rising inflation and interest rates will hit consumer purchasing power, leading to a potential dent in sales. BMW expects its "positive momentum" to continue in 2023, with sales slightly lower than in 2021 and sales of fully electric vehicles expected to double. The company's full-year operating margin forecast remains within a 7-9% range.

site_title: Maybank appoints Michael Oh-Lau as CEO of investment banking arm
summary: Maybank appoints Michael Oh-Lau as CEO of its investment banking arm, effective December 1, succeeding Ami Moris. Oh-Lau, with 27 years of tenure, was instrumental in cementing Maybank's position as a leading regional sukuk arranger. He will oversee investment banking services across ASEAN. The appointment is seen as a testament to the bank's strong internal succession pipeline, according to group president Khairussaleh Ramli.

site_title: EVs and hybrids account for 43% of third-quarter EU new car sales
summary: Electric and hybrid vehicles accounted for 43% of new car sales in the European Union in the third quarter, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers Association. This represents a significant increase from the same period last year, when such vehicles made up less than 40% of sales. Fully electric vehicles, in particular, saw a 22% rise in sales, with 11.9% of cars sold being zero-emission models. The growth in EV sales highlights a shift towards more environmentally friendly transportation options in the EU.

images.alt_text: While the semiconductor crunch was easing, other supply chain issues were looming on Stellantis’ operations, especially around logistics in Europe.
Resilient demand and low inventories have allowed BMW and other carmakers to raise prices.

site_title: Shell seeks acquisitions to bolster Australia power presence
summary: Shell is targeting acquisitions in Australia to bolster its presence in the country's energy market. The company aims to become an integrated energy provider, generating electricity and selling power, with a focus on building significant battery positions. Shell, one of Australia's largest liquefied natural gas exporters, has already made several acquisitions in the country, including ERM Power, Powershop, and WestWind Energy Development. The move is part of Shell's strategy to diversify away from fossil fuels and become the world's largest power company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen at a Shell petrol station in London, Britain, May 5, 2022. REUTERS/Toby Melville/File Photo

site_title: Manulife pilots ESGpedia for better ESG data visibility on sustainable bonds
summary: Manulife Investment Management has partnered with fintech company Stacs to pilot ESGpedia, a central ESG registry for specific financial datasets. This will provide better visibility of ESG data at the asset and portfolio levels, addressing industry challenges around ESG data fragmentation and lack of standardization. Manulife's head of sustainable investing, Eric Nietsch, stated that access to ESGpedia will enable the investment manager to see greater asset level details, supporting due diligence and monitoring of investee companies. A pilot phase of the arrangement is currently underway.

site_title: Asia: Stocks join Wall Street plunge as Powell wrecks Fed pivot hopes
summary: Asian stocks plummeted on Thursday after Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell hinted that interest rates will surpass 5% and remain high, shattering hopes for a dovish pivot. Hong Kong led the losses, with traders reversing previous gains fueled by speculation about China's zero-Covid policy rollbacks. The Fed's rate hikes and Powell's comments sent Wall Street's indexes tumbling and pushed the dollar higher, while investors expect borrowing costs to top out above 5%.

images.alt_text: The refurbished Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Hong Kong, China, on Friday, June 24, 2022. Hong Kong dusted off the gong for the city's first in-person listing ceremony in two years. Photographer: Bertha Wang/Bloomberg
Last month, the MSCI’s broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares fell 1.97 per cent, compared with the MSCI World’s 6 per cent gain.

site_title: Malaysia raises key policy rate to 2.75% in fourth hike this year
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara, raised its overnight policy rate (OPR) by 25 basis points to 2.75% in its fourth hike this year to manage excessive demand and price pressures. The move is expected to continue into next year, with two rounds of 25 basis point hikes each, to balance inflation and growth. The decision comes amid a backdrop of strong economic growth and simmering inflation, with household spending and tourist arrivals expected to remain strong despite moderating external demand. The central bank also plans to reduce subsidies next year, which may delay the peaking of inflation.

images.alt_text: Price pressure may rise further as the Malaysian government plans to reduce subsidies next year.

site_title: Kitchen Culture’s requisitioning shareholders announce Nov 25 EGM to remove directors
summary: Kitchen Culture's largest shareholder, Ooway Group, along with seven individuals, has requisitioned an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) on November 25 to remove five of the company's six directors. The directors in question are executive director Lim Wee Li and four independent directors, with the shareholders seeking to replace them. The shareholders, who collectively own 21.7% of the company, claim the board's composition is not in the best interest of the company. If successful, the resolutions would see new directors elected to the board.

images.alt_text: Michelle Zhu

Poggenpohl showroom by Kitchen Culture.  The group is urging its shareholders not to attend a Nov 1 extraordinary general meeting (EGM) proposed by requisitioners, as it deems notices for the EGM defective and invalid.
Kitchen Culture shareholders fail to confirm whether EGM notices have been sent out
Kitchen Culture is in the midst of taking legal advice on the validity of the EGM Notice by a group of shareholders.
Kitchen Culture was listed on SGX Catalist as a provider of solutions and products for kitchens and wardrobes.
A group of Kitchen Culture shareholders intend to convene an extraordinary general meeting remove these 5 individuals from their directorships as well as appoint 5 new directors.

site_title: China’s Lenovo posts first revenue drop in 10 quarters as Covid lockdowns weigh
summary: Lenovo Group reported its first revenue decline in 10 quarters, with total revenue in the July-September quarter falling 4% to $17.09 billion, due to the end of pandemic-fueled sales boom in China. The company's struggles reflect a weakening global PC market, with global shipments declining 15% year-over-year. Despite a 2% decline in its fiscal first half, Lenovo's net income rose 6% to $541 million. The company is shifting focus to non-PC businesses, which now account for over a third of its sales.

images.alt_text: Revenue growth in the second quarter was the slowest in more than one and a half years.
Lenovo Group's profit beat market estimates after the world's biggest personal computer maker widened its lead over longtime rival HP.

site_title: China’s services activity skids in October on Covid restrictions: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector contracted in October, with the Caixin PMI falling to 48.4, the lowest since May, due to Covid-19 containment measures and disruptions to consumer confidence. The sector, which relies on face-to-face interactions, also contracted in an official survey. Despite this, employment in the service sector rose, and firms maintained a positive outlook for business activity over the next 12 months. The contraction is a setback for China's economy, which is struggling amid persistent anti-virus measures, a protracted property sector crisis, and mounting global recession risks.

images.alt_text: A China official said the country’s foreign investment has increased steadily so far this year and that it will encourage more foreign investment in the manufacturing industry.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Thursday
summary: Japan's financial markets are closed on Thursday for a public holiday, with trading resuming on Friday. In contrast, Singapore's stock market reached a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Meanwhile, Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation to over US$1 billion. US stocks, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, edged towards fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts lower Manulife US Reit target price amid higher financing costs
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB and RHB have lowered their target prices for Manulife US Reit to US$0.69 and US$0.64, respectively, citing higher financing costs and lower occupancy. The Reit's portfolio occupancy dropped to 88.1% in Q3, with a major tenant, TCW Group, set to vacate its space in 2023. Despite this, analysts maintain a "buy" call, citing a "distressed valuation" and projected forward yield of 15%.

images.alt_text: The lobby of a 35-storey class A office building in the South Park district of downtown Los Angeles, U.S.

site_title: Meta adds new tools to help content creators make money on Instagram
summary: Meta is introducing new features on Instagram to help content creators monetize their presence on the platform. Users can soon buy non-fungible tokens (NFTs) directly within Instagram, and creators can earn money through subscriptions, gifts, and digital collectibles. The company is also expanding access to subscriptions to all eligible creators in the US and launching a professional mode for Facebook profiles. These features are part of Meta's efforts to compete with TikTok and other platforms, and will be tested with a small group of creators before expanding to more countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Instagram app is seen on a smartphone in this illustration taken, July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: North Korea fires multiple ballistic missiles, residents in Japan told to shelter
summary: North Korea fired multiple ballistic missiles on Thursday, triggering an alert in parts of Japan, where residents were warned to seek shelter. The launches follow a record year of missile testing by the nuclear-armed North, with at least 23 missiles fired on Wednesday. A missile landed off South Korea's coast for the first time, prompting a warning from South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol. The launches come amid a dispute over large-scale military exercises by the US and South Korea, with North Korea demanding an end to what it sees as "territorial encroachment".

images.alt_text: Tensions on the peninsula are at their highest point in years, with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un last month declaring his country an “irreversible” nuclear power, effectively ending negotiations over his banned weapons programmes.
People watch a television screen showing a news broadcast with file footage of a North Korean missile test, at a railway station in Seoul on Nov 2, 2022.

site_title: BlackRock expands corporate voting choice to more clients
summary: BlackRock, the world's largest asset manager, is expanding its corporate voting choice program to more clients, allowing those with around $1.8 trillion in equity index assets to choose how to vote at company annual meetings. This move aims to increase shareholder involvement and diminish criticism from politicians. The program, launched last year, has already seen 452 billion dollars in client assets participate. CEO Larry Fink hopes to make voting choice available to all individual investors in the future, believing it can enhance corporate governance.

images.alt_text: BlackRock is among the world’s largest investors in the energy industry, with stakes in publicly traded companies like Exxon Mobil and ConocoPhillips.

site_title: HDB resale volume down 24.1% in October as median price hits high of S$545,000: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB resale volumes decreased 24.1% in October to an estimated 1,965 transactions, the lowest since 2017. The median price of an HDB resale flat reached a record high of S$545,000. This marks the 28th consecutive month of price increases. Year-over-year, resale volumes declined 21.6% and declined by 22.8% for almost all room types.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Resale HDB flats

site_title: Australia: Banks, miners drag shares lower as Fed sticks to hawkish tone
summary: Australian shares fell 1.84% to 6,857.9 on Thursday, November 3, after the US Federal Reserve's hawkish tone and rate hike sparked market anxiety. Heavyweight miners and financials led losses, with BHP Group, Rio Tinto, and Fortescue Metals Group down 2.9-3.7% and all "Big Four" banks losing 1.2-1.8%. Perpetual rose 7.1% after rejecting a $1.07 billion buyout offer, while Woolworths Group fell 3.5% due to declining supermarket sales.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index fell about 2.2 per cent to 6,836.7, as of 0030 GMT on Thursday.

site_title: Blackstone’s US$70b real estate fund for retail investors is losing steam
summary: Blackstone's US$70 billion real estate fund for retail investors, known as Blackstone Real Estate Income Trust (Breit), is facing a significant test as rising interest rates threaten to drag down property values and make cheap debt harder to come by. Despite outperforming stocks with a 9.3% net return in the past nine months, inflows are slowing and redemptions are rising, with some wealth advisers advising clients to review their exposure to the fund. Breit has thresholds on withdrawals, which could limit investors' ability to cash out if too many people redeem their shares. The fund's size and importance as a bellwether for financial markets make it a key concern, with some experts warning that some retail investors may be caught off guard if they assumed they could get their money when they wanted.

images.alt_text: Blackstone says it will receive an upfront payment of about US$9.5 billion, which it will use to scoop up more companies, especially in the automation segment.
Blackstone has had a majority stake in the Burlington, Massachusetts-based company since 2020.
Blackstone invests in everything from apartments to offices to warehouses to biotech businesses to power transmission projects.

site_title: Singapore’s crypto hub ambitions do not involve trading, speculating in cryptos: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore aims to be a crypto assets hub focused on tokenising assets for use cases that increase economic efficiency or enhance social inclusion, not trading and speculating in cryptocurrencies. Managing Director Ravi Menon of the Monetary Authority of Singapore emphasized the importance of atomic settlement, instant remittance, programmable money, and trusted sustainability data. The authority is launching initiatives such as Ubin+, a global project studying cross-border exchange and settlement of foreign currency transactions using wholesale central bank digital currencies, and a digital marketplace for access to environmental, social, and governance data.

images.alt_text: Kelly Ng

Top executives at financial institutions expect the use of blockchain technology to be a game changer in improving processes and paving the way for more services and types of assets for end-customers.
MAS managing director Ravi Menon said central banks must continue to stay resolute in tackling high inflation and restoring price stability.
MAS intends to first issue a set of guidelines for crypto service providers after this consultation, and later legislate them.

site_title: EBay’s focus on luxury to refurbished goods drives results beat
summary: eBay's holiday-quarter revenue forecast came in slightly below analysts' expectations of US$2.49 billion, with the company beating targets due to increased demand for refurbished luxury goods. The platform expanded its offerings to include pre-owned sneakers and jewelry, attracting enthusiasts of high-value items. Despite forecasted revenue being slightly below estimates, eBay's stock rose nearly 8% in extended trading. Executives warned of uncertainties, including a strong US dollar and Europe's energy crisis, but noted a steady demand for home energy products in Germany.

images.alt_text: For the current quarter, eBay forecasts revenue between US$2.29 billion and US$2.37 billion.

site_title: Philippines announces 75-basis-point rate hike weeks ahead
summary: The Philippines' central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, has announced a 75-basis-point interest rate hike, its most aggressive tightening in two decades, to combat accelerating inflation and a record-low peso. The move, set to take effect on November 17, aims to match the Federal Reserve's recent hike and maintain price stability. The rate increase will bring the benchmark interest rate to 5%, the highest level since 2009, in an effort to temper inflation expectations and stabilize the currency.

images.alt_text: Philippines trade department is looking for investors in solar and wind energy, Trade Secretary Alfredo Pascual said.
Governor Felipe Medalla said the BSP could afford to be more aggressive in its policy tightening to support the peso, and added the economy is strong enough to absorb the impact of higher rates.

site_title: China property bonds are ‘no longer analysable’ as crisis grows
summary: China's offshore property dollar bonds have plummeted to record lows due to a deepening crisis, with defaults reaching unprecedented levels. Analysts say meaningful analysis is no longer possible, as the market has become a "black box" influenced by policy risk and investor confidence. The market value of investment-grade bonds has dropped 23% in the past month, while junk-rated firms have seen prices fall to a record low of 50.2 US cents. The crisis is rooted in a crackdown on excessive leverage and speculation in 2020, exacerbated by Covid restrictions.

images.alt_text: Gross domestic product in that province shrank 0.5 per cent in the first nine months of the year, compared with growth of 1.6 per cent in the first half of the year.

site_title: Asian markets tumble again after Fed hikes interest rates to highest since 2008
summary: Asian markets plummeted after the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates to a 14-year high of 3.75-4% in its fourth 0.75-point hike of the year, with the Straits Times Index falling 1.2% and the Hang Seng Index dropping 3.1%. The Fed chair, Jerome Powell, stated that there is "still ground to cover" in terms of future rate hikes, suggesting rates will peak higher than previously expected. This move has sparked concerns about a financial crisis and greater volatility for equity markets, with analysts predicting interest rates will peak at around 5%.

images.alt_text: Uma Devi
Hong Kong led the losses as traders gave back a chunk of the previous two days’ gains that came on the back of speculation China was planning to roll back some of its painful zero-Covid policies.
The Hang Seng Index sank 2.21 per cent, or 349.43 points, to 15,477.74.
The Straits Times Index declines 0.7 per cent or 22.68 points to 3,118.45 as at 9.01 am.
The S&P/ASX 200 index fell about 2.2 per cent to 6,836.7, as of 0030 GMT on Thursday.
The Federal Reserve, chaired by Jerome Powell, raised its benchmark interest rate by three-quarters of a point for a fourth straight time.

site_title: Credit trend for Apac corporates stable but risks remain
summary: The credit trend for non-financial companies in the Asia-Pacific region is expected to remain stable for the rest of the year, with 82% of Moody's Apac corporate portfolio having a stable ratings outlook. However, risks are rising, particularly for Chinese property developers, due to a tight funding environment, concerns about slowing economic growth, and the risk of project incompletion. Despite government efforts to stabilize the property market, these factors weigh on property sales.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan
China’s offshore property notes have plummeted to record lows that reflect deep distress, as defaults mount to unprecedented levels.
Iron ore’s advance also came after data showed iron ore exports by Brazil fell 13 per cent in October from a year earlier.

site_title: Australian: Shares dive on hawkish Federal Reserve; Perpetual soars on rejecting buyout bid
summary: Australian shares fell 2.2% to 6,836.7, tracking US Federal Reserve's hawkish messaging and a 75-basis-point rate hike. Heavyweight miners and financials also declined, while asset manager Perpetual rose 10% after rejecting a buyout bid. New Zealand's benchmark index fell 0.5%, with dairy firm a2 Milk and Synlait Milk gaining 7.7% and 3.9%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index ends 0.14 per cent higher at 6,986.7.

site_title: New Zealand central bank can get inflation under control: RBNZ governor
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank Governor Adrian Orr expressed confidence in controlling inflation, citing the central bank's focus on the interest-rate environment. The country's inflation rate is currently 7.2%, exceeding the bank's target of 1-3%. The RBNZ has increased interest rates since 2021 and is expected to hike again, with a 70% chance of a 75 basis point increase at the November meeting. A tight labour market, driven by global shortages, is also a major constraint on businesses in New Zealand.

images.alt_text: The New Zealand dollar rose slightly after the data showed inflation was hotter than expected.
Economists polled by Reuters had forecast an unemployment rate of 3.2 per cent and employment growth of 0.5 per cent for New Zealand.
The RBNZ expects a decline in new residential construction once existing development projects are completed.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.41 points, or 0.37%, to 1446.20 on Thursday, with 222 losers outweighing 95 gainers. The market saw a lower opening, with 198.69 million lots traded worth RM60.96 million.

site_title: Yellowstone, Kilimanjaro glaciers among those set to vanish by 2050: Unesco
summary: A study of 18,600 glaciers at 50 World Heritage sites found that a third of the sites' glaciers are "condemned to disappear" by 2050, including those at Yellowstone and Kilimanjaro National Park. The glaciers have been retreating at an accelerated rate since 2000 due to CO2 emissions and warming temperatures. Unesco is urging leaders to act fast to save the remaining glaciers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: View of a COP27 sign on the road leading to the conference area in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh town as the city prepares to host the COP27 summit next month, in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt October 20, 2022. REUTERS/Sayed Sheasha/File Photo
Carbon prices in China are but a fraction of what they are in developed countries, making it hard for them to have much of an impact now, say panellists. (PHOTO: AFP)
COP27 signage on the road leading to the conference venue in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh.

site_title: Uber whistleblower says current business model ‘absolutely’ unsustainable
summary: Uber whistleblower Mark MacGann stated that the company's business model is "absolutely" unsustainable, despite recent efforts to improve its work culture. MacGann, who led Uber's lobbying efforts, claims the company knowingly flouted laws and misled drivers about its gig-economy model. Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi acknowledged the need for change, but MacGann believes the company has much work to do to address its unsustainable model.

images.alt_text: Third-quarter sales jumped 72 per cent to US$8.34 billion, Uber said on Tuesday (Nov 1) in a statement.

The settlement is the latest ripple effect from a major March 2021 ruling by Britain’s Supreme Court classifying Uber drivers as employees, rejecting the company’s contention that the drivers should be categorised as self-employed.

site_title: Hong Kong follows Fed with rate hike, adding to economy’s woes
summary: Hong Kong's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate for a sixth time, following the US Federal Reserve's move, to 4.25% to combat severe inflation. The move adds to the city's economic woes, including weak global demand, slow reopening, and talent exodus. Economists downgraded full-year growth forecasts, citing a sharp contraction in investment and curbing demand in the property market. Hong Kong banks are expected to raise their prime rates, potentially further curtailing consumer borrowing.

images.alt_text: Hong kong city Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: Musk plans to eliminate half of Twitter jobs to cut costs
summary: Elon Musk plans to eliminate about 3,700 jobs, or half of Twitter's workforce, as part of a cost-cutting effort following his US$44 billion acquisition. The job cuts are part of a broader plan to reverse the company's work-from-anywhere policy and focus on core product development. Affected employees will be informed on November 4, with some possible exceptions made. The move aims to drive down costs, which Musk says he overpaid for.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk said on Tuesday the site will charge US$8 per month to verify users’ accounts.
Elon Musk fired Twitter’s previous chief Parag Agrawal and other top company officials last week.

site_title: SingPost sinks into the red with S$9.9m loss in H1 on exceptional charge
summary: SingPost reported a net loss of S$9.9 million in its first half of 2023, driven by a fair value charge of S$21 million from the acquisition of an Australian logistics unit. Despite this, the company's revenue reached S$958.9 million, with its logistics business contributing 79.4% of the total. The company remains optimistic about its future outlook, citing growth in its international logistics business and a "healthy interest and demand" in its property business.

images.alt_text: The property player announced on Thursday that it has established two onshore renminbi funds totalling around 4 billion yuan (S$796 million) to invest in business park opportunities in China.
In his new role, Li Yu will be responsible for establishing long and short-term business strategies for SingPost's international businesses.

site_title: GIC, ESR establish US$600m joint venture to invest in India’s logistics assets
summary: GIC and ESR Group have established a US$600 million joint venture to invest in India's logistics assets. The partnership, with GIC holding 80% and ESR holding 20%, will focus on stabilised operational assets in Tier 1 and Tier 2 cities. The joint venture aims to capitalize on the growth of organised retail and e-commerce in India's industrial and logistics sector, which GIC expects to outperform other asset classes in the medium term. This is ESR's third core-plus logistics partnership with GIC in India, following previous ventures in 2020 and 2022.

images.alt_text: ESR Australia Logistics Partnership III is the third iteration of ESR's core-plus logistics strategy with Singapore state investor GIC.

Wholly-owned subsidiaries of ESR and GIC entered into an investment agreement on Sunday, agreeing to respectively contribute 10 per cent and 90 per cent to the capital of the new China income venture.
GIC in joint venture to buy Australian office building for A$335m

site_title: Google wants AI in 1,000 languages
summary: Google aims to develop artificial intelligence using the world's 1,000 most spoken languages to tap into global data and create more accessible products. The company's goal is to make AI more widely available to users, particularly in Africa and other regions where English is not the primary language. This move is part of the tech giant's efforts to dominate the internet's next battleground and improve AI's performance. Google plans to leverage data from 1,000 languages to enhance AI capabilities and make products more user-friendly.

images.alt_text: Google is concerned that the Competition Commission of India’s (CCI) Android ruling could increase regulatory pressures in other jurisdictions.
The plan also includes a target to increase the total value of the industry to more than 350 billion yuan, which the ministries say includes hardware and software sales.
The tools will be available through Google’s AI Test Kitchen app.

site_title: Gold ticks higher on dollar pullback; hawkish Powell caps upside
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,638.32 per ounce, driven by a slight dip in the dollar. US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's hawkish remarks limited further gains. Analysts downgraded forecasts for platinum and palladium prices for 2023 due to a global economic slowdown, reducing demand.

images.alt_text: Gold is highly sensitive to rising US interest rates, as that increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding metal and boosts the dollar.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 2.21% at the open on November 3, 2022, following a heavy sell-off on Wall Street due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike and warning of future increases. The Hang Seng Index dropped 349.43 points to 15,477.74. The Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indexes also declined, with the Shanghai Composite Index losing 0.74% and the Shenzhen Composite Index losing 0.90%. The decline was attributed to global market volatility and investor concerns over interest rate hikes.

site_title: Europe: Shares lose steam on caution ahead of Fed move
summary: European shares slipped 0.3% to snap a three-day winning streak, as investors exercised caution ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike decision. The Fed is expected to hike its benchmark lending rates by 75 basis points, with some pricing in a smaller 50 bps rate hike in December. The healthcare sector bucked the trend, with Novo Nordisk jumping 7.4% after raising its full-year earnings outlook. The Stoxx 600 index remains near seven-week highs, but personal and household goods, miners, and technology sectors were hit hard.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index rose 0.2 per cent to 7,197.89 points, also on the eve of another widely-forecast large rate increase from the Bank of England.

site_title: Trump sues New York Attorney-General in Florida to keep control of company
summary: Former US President Donald Trump sued New York Attorney-General Letitia James in Florida, seeking to stop her from obtaining information about his finances and preventing his companies from doing business in New York. James had previously sued Trump and his children, claiming they inflated the value of his real estate company's assets, and is seeking $250 million in disgorgement. Trump accused James of a "war of intimidation and harassment" in the complaint, filed in Palm Beach County state court.

site_title: Singapore shares extend Wall Street losses at Thursday’s open; STI down 0.7%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.7% at the open, following Wall Street losses as the Federal Reserve delivered another round of interest rate hikes to tame inflation. The Straits Times Index fell 22.68 points to 3,118.45, with losers outnumbering gainers 112 to 33. Key stocks fell, including Singtel, DBS, and OCBC, while Golden Agri-Resources gained 3.4% after announcing plans to restructure or exit its energy coal business.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Oil prices gain by tight supply; other risk assets swoon on Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: Oil prices rose by 1.6% to $96.16 for Brent crude and 1.8% to $90 for US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) after US oil inventories declined and refineries picked up activity ahead of the winter heating season. The Federal Reserve's fourth interest rate hike of the year, which boosted the dollar, led to a decline in other risk assets, including stocks and the Treasury market. The EU's embargo on Russian oil, set to start on December 5, is expected to limit supply and tighten the market, further supporting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude for January delivery rose US$1.84, or 2 per cent, to settle at US$94.65 a barrel.

site_title: BOE set to deliver biggest rate rise in 33 years
summary: The Bank of England is set to deliver its largest interest-rate increase in 33 years, with a 75-basis-point hike expected to bring the base rate to 3% and the highest since 2008. The decision comes amid a prolonged economic slowdown, with most economists predicting a 7-2 split in favor of the rate hike. The BOE's outlook for inflation is also expected to be revised downward, with inflation forecast to peak around 12% in April. The move aims to combat double-digit inflation, which has been fueled by the UK's cost-of-living crisis.

images.alt_text: While the BOE is expected to deliver a 75 basis-points hike on Thursday, its biggest since 1989, the risk is that the move doesn’t filter fully through to the market.
The BOE is coordinating with the government on which bonds to sell and when. A gilt maturing in 2029 is excluded from Tuesday’s sale because it was recently auctioned by the DMO.

site_title: MGM resorts slumps after surprise loss on Macau business expense
summary: MGM Resorts International reported a surprise loss of $1.39 per share due to a $1.2 billion expense in Macau, where China's pandemic restrictions limit travel. Revenue rose to $3.41 billion, exceeding estimates. The company's shares fell 15% in after-hours trading before recovering, down 22% this year. MGM expects a decision on its Macau concession by the end of the year, with potential investment in New York if granted new licenses.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, CLI, SingPost, NetLink, The Hour Glass, Nanofilm Tech, SMG
summary: DBS reported a 32% year-on-year rise in net profit for the third quarter, with a dividend of S$0.36 per share. CapitaLand Investment established two onshore renminbi funds to invest in China, adding S$1.6 billion to its funds under management. Singapore Post reported a loss of S$9.9 million despite a "record half-year revenue" of S$958.9 million. NetLink NBN Trust posted a 36.1% jump in net profit to S$54.6 million. The Hour Glass reported a 35% jump in net profit to S$84.6 million, and Nanofilm Technologies' revenue grew 10% year on year. SMG raised its offer price to take the company private.

images.alt_text: The rally in the Singapore bourse ran out of steam on Wednesday ahead of the US Fed rate decision

site_title: US says its worries are growing over Russian nuclear talk
summary: The US has expressed growing concern over Russia's talk of using nuclear weapons in Ukraine, following a report that top Russian military officials discussed the use of tactical nuclear weapons on the battlefield. White House national security spokesman John Kirby stated that the comments are "deeply concerning" and the US takes them seriously, despite no indication that Russia is making preparations to use nuclear weapons. The US has warned Moscow for weeks over public comments from top Russian officials, and the EU's Josep Borrell has warned that Russian forces would be "annihilated" if Putin uses nuclear weapons against Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Nato Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg  said he had spoken with Pentagon chief Lloyd Austin and Britain’s Defence Secretary Ben Wallace “about Russia’s false claim that Ukraine is preparing to use a dirty bomb on its own territory.”

site_title: Blockchain technology a key enabler to transform banking, investments and insurance
summary: Top executives at financial institutions expect blockchain technology to revolutionize banking, investments, and insurance by increasing efficiency, reducing risk, and making more products accessible to end-customers. Executives from DBS, HSBC, and OCBC cited blockchain's ability to remove friction, build trust, and enable faster payments as key benefits. The technology also has potential applications in insurance, such as simplifying claims processes and enabling more frictionless payment processes. Industry leaders believe that blockchain will continue to shape the financial sector, enabling breakthrough solutions and reshaping financial markets.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
Digitalisation has been the crucial step which has enabled most businesses to continue operating through lockdowns and closed borders

site_title: Binance, with over US$1b to spend, weighs buying a bank
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao is considering acquiring or investing in a bank as part of its efforts to bridge the gap between the crypto and traditional finance worlds. With over $1 billion to spend, Binance is looking at banks with local licenses, payment-service providers, and even full acquisition. Zhao believes that partnering with banks can drive up their valuation and create opportunities for Binance to capture equity upside. This move comes as traditional financial institutions, such as Goldman Sachs and BlackRock, are increasingly pushing into the crypto market.

site_title: DBS Q3 profit rises 32% to record S$2.24b; declares S$0.36 per share dividend
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, reported a 32% year-on-year rise in net profit for the third quarter, reaching a record S$2.24 billion, driven by higher net interest margins, healthy loan momentum, and stable fee income. CEO Piyush Gupta expects the bank to remain resilient in 2023, with loan growth reaching mid-single-digit figures, and double-digit fee income growth. However, he warned of potential challenges from high interest rates and inflation, particularly in Asia. The bank declared a dividend of S$0.36 per share and expects its cost-to-income ratio to be below 40% in 2023.

images.alt_text: Tan Nai Lun
Vivienne Tay
DBS raised the maximum interest rate on the Multiplier account to 4.1 per cent a year, up from 3.5 per cent previously.
DBS chief Piyush Gupta believes DBS’ use of AI is scoring at just two or three on a scale of 10, reflecting the untapped potential for the bank.
Many analysts have maintained their “buy” calls on the three Singapore banks, on higher absolute dividends for FY2022.

site_title: US: Stocks end sharply lower as Fed hikes rates again
summary: US stocks plummeted sharply on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1.6% to 32,147.76, and the S&P 500 dropping 2.5% to 3,759.69. The Federal Reserve raised interest rates by 0.75 percentage point, but a more hawkish tone from Fed Chair Jerome Powell during a press conference led to a sharp sell-off. Investors had initially cheered the rate hike, but the Fed's language suggested more increases ahead, leading to a broader market decline.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 76.92 points, or 0.24 per cent, at the open to 32,576.28.

site_title: The four trends driving change in wealth management
summary:
The wealth management ecosystem in South-east Asia (SEA) is expected to undergo significant changes in the next decade, driven by four key trends: 

1. Increasing number of investors, with 40% of households in SEA holding uninvested cash, compared to 14% in the US and 23% in Australia. 

2. Declining cost of investing, thanks to the growth of exchange-traded funds (ETFs), which are becoming more cost-effective than unit trusts. 

3. Wealth advisers shifting to digital platforms, as investors prefer self-service solutions and unbiased advice. 

4. Financial services firms evolving to attract and retain tech-savvy talent, with a shift towards digitalization and a smaller number of investment advisers.

images.alt_text: Many use their smart devices for most of their transactions, including banking.

site_title: Google plans slow rollout of AI app creating art from text
summary: Google plans a slow rollout of an AI app that allows users to create images from text descriptions, with initial features including "City Dreamer" for building construction and "Wobble" for interacting with a cartoon monster. The app is part of Google's AI Test Kitchen and aims to mitigate concerns about generative AI's risks, such as spreading misinformation and enforcing biases. Google also announced improvements to AI tools for coding, audio generation, and translation services, with a goal of supporting 1,000 languages. The company's slow rollout reflects its caution about the emerging technology.

site_title: Booking Holdings results top estimates after summer travel boom
summary: Booking Holdings reported a stronger-than-expected third quarter with gross bookings increasing 36% to $32.12 billion and revenue rising 29% to $6.1 billion, a quarterly record. The surge in travel bookings follows two years of pent-up demand, but rising inflation and a strong dollar may impact the outlook for the rest of the year.

site_title: Top execs of Singapore Medical Group bump up offer price to S$0.40 to take company private
summary: Top executives of Singapore Medical Group (SMG) have increased their offer price to S$0.40 per share to take the company private. The revised offer, an 8.1% increase from the initial S$0.37 per share, aims to address prevailing market conditions and business environment. The new offer also represents a premium of 25.4-28.6% over the past 12 months' volume-weighted average price and 16.8% over the net asset value. The offeror, TLW Success, reserves the right to revise the offer in a competitive situation.

images.alt_text: எஸ். வெங்கடேஷ்வரன்
SMG CEO Beng Teck Liang believes that privatisation will provide greater flexibility to execute long-term investments.

site_title: Amazon sees record interest from retail investors after earnings
summary: Amazon saw a record surge in retail investor interest after its earnings, with $292 million in purchases last Friday. Despite a broadly negative set of results, retail flows into Amazon remained above its historical average this week. The tech giant's market valuation dropped under $1 trillion for the first time since 2020. Other affected stocks, such as Meta, Apple, and Alphabet, also saw significant retail buying, with Amazon leading the way, followed by Meta, Apple, Tesla, and Alphabet. Retail investors viewed the decline as a "buy-the-dip" opportunity.

site_title: After lengthy slump, Boeing outlines path to comeback
summary: Boeing has outlined a path to comeback, expecting to return to operational health and robust financial performance by mid-decade. The aerospace giant guided investors to 2025-26 as the timeframe for a strong financial performance, following years of losses and stumbles. Boeing's CEO, Dave Calhoun, stated the company is on the right path to regain its financial strength.
