images.alt_text: “It means a lot for my team, my family, my supporters and myself. It is such an honour to have my name at the top amongst the biggest names of the game,” said Atthaya Thitikul.
(Right to left) The winners of this year's BMW Golf Cup National Final are Jeffrey Goh, Aloysa Atienza and Allen Gong.

site_title: Circle Internet Financial gets in-principle approval to offer digital payment token products
summary: Circle Internet Financial, a global digital financial technology firm, received in-principle approval from the Monetary Authority of Singapore to offer digital payment token products, including cross-border and domestic transfer services. This approval enables the company to work with stakeholders and demonstrate the potential of digital currencies to drive economic growth in Singapore. Circle, which issues stablecoins like USD Coin, plans to continue hiring in Singapore as its principal hub in Asia and expand its regional business.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting

site_title: Big brands set to miss plastic sustainability targets
summary: Major consumer goods companies, including PepsiCo, Mars, and Nestle, are likely to miss a 2025 target to make plastic packaging more sustainable, according to a report by the Ellen MacArthur Foundation and the UN Environment Programme. Despite pledging to reduce virgin plastic use, some companies, including Coca-Cola and Pepsi, are using more virgin plastic. The report comes ahead of UN negotiations on a global plastics treaty, which aims to curb waste pollution and promote recycled content in packaging. Greenpeace calls for a legally binding treaty to enforce reductions in single-use plastic packaging.

images.alt_text: Young people engrossed playing a game on their mobile phones in suburban Manila. Eventually, when they are discarded for newer models or stashed away, the valuable gold, copper and other metals they contain will be hoarded, dumped or incinerated, causing health and environmental harm.
Consumers care about whether food producers and stores are sustainable in the way they produce, package and sell products.

site_title: China regulator says it’s concerned about property sector
summary: China's Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission expressed concern over the country's property sector, citing risks despite manageable exposure to real estate. Vice-chairman Xiao Yuanqi stated that the sector is "stable" with a 26% loan-to-value ratio and a mortgage default ratio of 0.1%. China's prolonged property crisis has sparked economic turmoil, with at least $292 billion in borrowings due by 2023. The central bank aims for a "soft landing" and has implemented measures to stabilize the market, but analysts say these efforts have been ineffective.

images.alt_text: Prices in 100 cities dropped for a fourth month in October, falling 0.01 per cent month-on-month after a decline of 0.02 per cent in September.

site_title: Sweden’s home prices fall by most since at least 2013 in latest data
summary: Sweden's housing market experienced its fastest decline since 2013, with home prices falling 4% in October and 2.3% seasonally adjusted. This represents a 19% drop from the peak and a 13% decrease in apartment prices. The decline is attributed to record-high inflation and increasing borrowing costs, with detached houses in Gothenburg experiencing the largest drop. Forecasts predict a 20% drop in residential property prices, surpassing previous estimates.

site_title: China’s Covid curbs, droughts hit tourism, and factory hubs
summary: China's economic data for the first three quarters of 2022 shows slower growth or contraction in at least eight provincial-level jurisdictions due to Covid disruptions and a historic drought. The economy's fragility is highlighted, with popular tourist spots and factory hubs affected. Thirty of the country's 31 provinces have published their data, while Shaanxi remains unpublished. The economic slowdown raises pressure on policymakers, who are concerned about the impact on the country's GDP growth.

images.alt_text: Prices in 100 cities dropped for a fourth month in October, falling 0.01 per cent month-on-month after a decline of 0.02 per cent in September.

site_title: Robinhood, Coinbase find sanctuary in interest income amid market rout
summary: US online trading companies Robinhood Markets and Coinbase Global are expected to benefit from interest income amid a market rout. The US Federal Reserve's rate hikes are expected to drive up interest income for these companies, with Robinhood's net interest revenue projected to surge 65% and Coinbase's subscription and services revenue estimated to grow 28%. Despite a decline in overall revenue, the interest income is seen as a key factor in the companies' financial performance.

images.alt_text: Coinbase has around 100 employees in Singapore.
USDC, which is principally issued by Circle, is the second largest stablecoin with over US$50 billion in circulation today.

site_title: North Korean missile lands close to South Korean waters for ‘first time’: Seoul military
summary: North Korea launched at least 10 missiles on November 2, 2022, including one that landed close to South Korea's territorial waters, prompting a warning for residents on the island of Ulleungdo to shelter in bunkers. This was the first time a North Korean missile crossed the Northern Limit Line, the demarcation between the two countries since the peninsula's division. The Joint Chiefs of Staff described the launch as "unacceptable."

images.alt_text: Tensions on the peninsula are at their highest point in years, with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un last month declaring his country an “irreversible” nuclear power, effectively ending negotiations over his banned weapons programmes.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.52 points or 0.24% to 1449.44 at 9:09 am on Wednesday, with 131 gainers outnumbering 86 losers. Volume reached 87.18 million lots worth RM40.64 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Wednesday
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Wednesday, following a decline on Wall Street due to mixed US economic data and anticipation of a major Federal Reserve decision. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.36% to 27,580.26, while the Topix index dropped 0.06%. The decline extends the global market's nervousness ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open down on Wednesday
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened down on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index slipping 0.43% to 15,389.55, following a surge the previous day. The decline was attributed to an unverified statement suggesting China was forming a committee to discuss rolling back zero-Covid measures. Shanghai and Shenzhen indices also edged down, with the Shanghai Composite Index down 0.29%. The decline was a reversal of the previous day's gains.

site_title: New Zealand to impose regulation on buy now, pay later providers
summary: New Zealand plans to require buy-now, pay-later providers to conduct affordability checks on customers before agreeing to loans above NZ$600. The checks will provide protections similar to those for credit cards and personal loans. The government aims to prevent vulnerable people from getting into debt. BNPL products typically allow consumers to pay in four instalments with little to no fees, but late fees are charged if payments are missed. The amount spent on BNPL in New Zealand grew to NZ$1.7 billion in 2021, prompting the government to develop regulations to ensure accountability.

images.alt_text: Each BNPL provider will permit customers to accumulate no more than S$2,000 in outstanding payments at any given time.
Increased rainfall in some parts of New Zealand has seen devastating flooding this year while rising sea levels are starting to threaten coastal properties.
Economists polled by Reuters had forecast an unemployment rate of 3.2 per cent and employment growth of 0.5 per cent for New Zealand.

site_title: Malaysia ruling party drops PM’s allies from elections
summary: Malaysia's ruling party, Barisan Nasional, has dropped eight ministers and deputy ministers from its election candidate list, led by UMNO president Ahmad Zahid Hamidi, amid a power struggle with Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob ahead of the November 19 elections. The move signals a strained relationship between the two leaders, with Zahid pushing for snap polls and Ismail wanting to hold a national vote after the economy is on sounder footing. The removal of Ismail's allies may weaken his position as PM-designate, potentially paving the way for Zahid to consolidate power in UMNO.

images.alt_text: The long-time opposition leader is the second politician to offer himself as premier in the national vote that will be held on Nov 19.

site_title: MAS to commit S$150m for FSTI scheme over next 3 years; consults on ending corporate cheques by 2025
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has committed S$150 million for the Financial Sector Technology and Innovation (FSTI) scheme over the next three years, aiming to enhance and empower the financial sector through technology. The scheme will focus on areas such as artificial intelligence, analytics, and cybersecurity. Additionally, MAS will consult on ending the use of corporate cheques by 2025, with the goal of eliminating cheques and terminating central cheque clearing over the medium term. The government also plans to extend the Singapore Financial Data Exchange (SGFinDex) to include insurance policies, providing a single view of an individual's finances.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim

Pixgeneric / Generic picture taken on 19 July 2022 of MAS . The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS). The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) recorded a loss of S$7.4 billion in the last financial year, with lower investment gains on the country’s foreign reserves and as the Singapore dollar appreciated.
OLYMPUS DIGITAL CAMERA

site_title: Uber reaches £615m tax settlement with Britain
summary: Uber has agreed to pay £615m in taxes to settle a dispute with British authorities after a 2021 ruling classified its drivers as employees, not self-employed individuals. This follows a Supreme Court decision in March 2021 that rejected Uber's contention. The company began paying VAT taxes in March 2022 and has now agreed to the settlement, with the payment to be made in the fourth quarter.

site_title: South Korean inflation picks up, boosting case for more tightening
summary: South Korea's inflation rose 5.7% in October, exceeding economists' estimates, and core inflation accelerated to 4.8%. The Bank of Korea is expected to raise interest rates again, with a possible 50 basis-point hike, to combat inflation and maintain economic growth. Despite falling exports and a deteriorating consumer outlook, the central bank is tightening monetary policy to narrow the rate gap with the Federal Reserve and stem the won's depreciation.

images.alt_text: South Korea also marked its first annual decline in exports since October 2020.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as US data tempers Fed hopes
summary: Asian markets experienced mixed trading on Wednesday, following losses on Wall Street due to forecast-beating US data that tempered hopes for the Federal Reserve to slow its interest rate hikes. Despite initial optimism, the news took the wind out of risk assets' rally, with Hong Kong stocks edging down after a 5% gain on Tuesday. The mixed trading comes as investors await GDP data and consider the implications of the US data on the global economy.

images.alt_text: Shanghai climbed more than one per cent, along with Singapore and Seoul, while Tokyo, Sydney, Taipei and Bangkok. However, Jakarta and Wellington edged lower.

site_title: This 7.7m yen Japanese turntable is what your vinyl has been waiting for
summary: Esoteric Company has released its first analogue turntable, the Grandioso T1, priced at 7.7 million yen. The turntable features a contoured brushed aluminium chassis, mirroring the company's other components. This release comes as vinyl record sales reached a record $1 billion in 2022, surpassing the 1986 figure. The T1 is a high-end product catering to vinyl enthusiasts, with its premium price tag reflecting its advanced design and quality.

images.alt_text: Esoteric's analog turntable Grandioso T1 with its power supply unit, left.Source: Source: Esoteric Company

site_title: Australia: Shares gain on mining, energy boost
summary: Australia's shares rose 0.4% to 7,002.4 on Wednesday, driven by gains in the mining and energy sectors. Iron ore prices rebounded, lifting miners like BHP Group and Rio Tinto 2.1% and 1.5% respectively. Energy stocks also rose 1.4% as oil prices increased on hopes of China's reopening. The Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate hike was met with a modest response, with financial stocks rising 0.4%.

images.alt_text: The S&P/ASX 200 index rises 1.7 per cent to 6,976.9.

site_title: Great Eastern Q3 net profit up 30%
summary: Great Eastern, the insurance arm of OCBC, posted a 30% increase in net profit to S$278 million in Q3, driven by higher profit from its insurance business. Non-operating profit rose 25% to S$311.2 million, while operating profit declined 38% to S$208.1 million. The insurer expects a challenging business climate in the near to medium term due to geopolitical uncertainty and inflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: Ry-Anne Lim
Lower-risk options are now more attractive due to higher interest rates, but inflation remains a risk.
Gleneagles Hospital operating theatre. Private hospital healthcare inflation is much higher than overall healthcare inflation.
Khor Hock Seng, Group CEO, Great Eastern
The pandemic acted as a “wake-up call” for many in Asia to take a first look at insurance.
Singapore's life insurance industry saw a dip in weighted new business premiums to S$1.21 bilion, down 2 percent year-on-year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Manulife US Reit, Great Eastern, SIA Engineering, Golden Energy
summary: Key stocks to watch include Great Eastern's 30% rise in Q3 net profit to S$278 million, SIA Engineering's 87.6% increase in group net profit to S$19.7 million, and Golden Energy's plan to restructure or exit its energy coal business.

site_title: RBNZ says economy will slow as rising rates curb consumption
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the RBNZ, expects a decline in economic growth due to rising debt servicing costs and falling house prices. Household spending is expected to be limited by rising mortgage rates, negative equity, and mortgage servicing arrears. The RBNZ forecasts a decline in new residential construction, which will contribute to slower economic activity and employment. Rising interest rates and unemployment are also seen as risks to financial stability, with the risk of higher unemployment leading to further stresses among households.

images.alt_text: Increased rainfall in some parts of New Zealand has seen devastating flooding this year while rising sea levels are starting to threaten coastal properties.

site_title: Weak yen prodded Bank of Japan to debate inflation pressure: minutes
summary: Bank of Japan policymakers discussed the need for an exit strategy from ultra-loose monetary policy amid growing inflationary pressure, with one member calling for communication of a potential exit from low-interest rates. Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's statement that interest rates would remain low for "two to three years" led to a sharp decline in the yen, prompting government intervention. The BOJ maintains ultra-loose policy to ensure wages rise and achieve 2% inflation, but some members expressed concerns over potential distortions in the yield curve.

images.alt_text: In fresh quarterly projections, the BOJ will slightly revise up its price forecasts but still project inflation to slide back below its 2 per cent target next fiscal year as commodity and fuel price rises peak, sources told Reuters.
The decrease in carmakers’ output dragged on overall figures by 1.85 percentage points, accounting for most of the fall.
Output and overall new orders both contracted for the fourth straight month.
The latest intervention helped to trigger an immediate drop in the dollar of more than 7 yen, but the Japanese currency has since come under renewed pressure.

site_title: Singapore stocks dip at Wednesday’s open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks opened weaker on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 0.3% to 3,122.64. Sembcorp Marine was the top-traded counter, dropping 0.8% to S$0.13. The US stock market declined for a second consecutive day, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.2%. European shares rose, driven by hopes of slower US interest rate hikes. Asian markets, including Tokyo, also fell, extending losses on Wall Street.

images.alt_text: Great Eastern posts a net profit of S$278 million for Q3 FY2022, up 30 per cent from S$213.3 million a year ago.

site_title: Gold edges higher ahead of key Fed rate verdict
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,650.13 per ounce ahead of the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, as investors focused on the potential for a 75 basis point rate hike. A weaker dollar also supported gold, making it less expensive for holders of other currencies. The dollar index fell 0.1%, while US job openings unexpectedly rose in September, indicating strong labor demand and potentially slowing the impact of interest rate hikes on the real economy.

images.alt_text: Gold is typically seen as a safe asset for times of uncertainty or turmoil.

site_title: Stan Lee's former business manager cleared of theft charges
summary: A Los Angeles judge cleared former business manager Keya Morgan of grand theft charges related to the sale of Stan Lee memorabilia in 2018. Prosecutors alleged Morgan stole $222,480 in cash, but a jury voted 11-1 in favor of acquittal. The judge dismissed the charges "in the interests of justice" after the acquittal. Morgan was accused of stealing the funds in the months before Lee's death at 95 in 2018.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO - Comic book creator and executive producer Stan Lee poses at the world premiere of the film "Marvel's The Avengers" in Hollywood, California, April 11, 2012. REUTERS/Danny Moloshok/File Photo

site_title: Hong Kong fights to prove it’s still a dominant financial hub
summary: Hong Kong is facing challenges in maintaining its status as a dominant financial hub, with its share of regional initial public offerings near the lowest in over two decades. Despite efforts by the new leader, John Lee, to attract top bosses from global banks, the city has lost ground to Singapore, which ranked as Asia's top financial center. Hong Kong's asset and wealth management industry has seen a slowdown, with assets managed in the city rising just 2% in 2021. The city's labor force is also shrinking, with nearly 70% of fund-management companies reporting difficulty in hiring and retaining expatriates.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong Chief Executive John Lee speaks to the media before an Executive Council meeting in Hong Kong on September 6, 2022.
Hong Kong retail sales rose to HK$28.1 billion. That compared with a revised 0.2 per cent slide in August.

site_title: Baht set for relief as Thai current-account turns surplus
summary: Thailand's central bank has hinted at a measured approach to policy normalization to shield its fragile economic recovery. The country's current account turned into a surplus in September, driven by a rebound in foreign tourist arrivals, lower oil prices, and sliding shipping costs. Economists expect the current-account surplus to reach up to $3 billion during the October-December period, potentially offering relief for the nation's currency, which has been near a 16-year low.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: New baht banknotes featuring Thailand's King Maha Vajiralongkorn are unveiled during a news conference at Bank of Thailand headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, July 3, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: New money inflows to Singapore jump 15.8% to a record S$448b in 2021
summary: Singapore has seen a record $448 billion in new money inflows in 2021, a 15.8% jump from the previous year, making it the Asian financial hub. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) chief, Ravi Menon, believes the city can absorb these inflows without concerns of a real estate bubble, citing measures to prevent overheating in the property market. The influx of wealth is largely from growing Asia, with North Asia's affluent contributing significantly, and is expected to boost the financial hub's efforts to add 20,000 finance jobs over five years.

images.alt_text: Chinese Vice-Premier Han Zheng (left) and Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat meet at the Four Seasons Hotel on Tuesday.
While MAS deems the case for a retail CBDC in Singapore as “not compelling for now”, the authority said it continues to actively explore good use cases for digital currencies.

site_title: AMD beats earnings estimates, but gives lukewarm forecast
summary: AMD beat earnings estimates in the third quarter with profit of 67 US cents per share, exceeding analyst expectations. Revenue was in line with projections. The company forecasts fourth-quarter sales of $5.5 billion, slightly below average estimates. Gains in servers and robust demand for custom chips are expected to bolster AMD's performance, contrasting with peers suffering contractions.

images.alt_text: AMD blamed the PC market for hurting sales, citing weaker demand and a build-up of inventory in the supply chain.
Meta’s new open-source AI platform is based on an open-source machine learning framework called PyTorch.

site_title: Suspect pleads not guilty in attack aimed at Nancy Pelosi
summary: A 42-year-old man, David DePape, pleaded not guilty to attempted murder and other charges in connection with the attack on US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's husband, Paul Pelosi. DePape broke into the couple's San Francisco home, intending to tie up Pelosi and break his kneecaps, and instead attacked Paul Pelosi with a hammer. The suspect faces 13 years to life in prison if convicted on state charges and federal authorities have also charged him with attempting to kidnap a US official and assaulting her family member.

images.alt_text: Members of the House Select Committee investigating the Jan 6 attack on the US Capitol hold their 9th public hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington on Oct 13, 2022.
The intruder shouts “Where is Nancy, where is Nancy?” before attacking her husband.

site_title: Singapore must stay open, invest in its people to seize Asia’s growth opportunities: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore must refresh its economic strategies, stay open, and invest in its people to seize opportunities presented by Asia's growing middle class, shift to renewable energy, and digitalization, according to Manpower Minister Tan See Leng. The region is expected to be among the world's fastest-growing economies, and Singapore must partner with other countries to seize opportunities, while also addressing challenges like climate change through international cooperation and investing in clean energy.

images.alt_text:
Generic photo of the office crowd, some were masked and others without masks after office hours at Raffles Place on September 7, 2022.

site_title: Biden in Florida for a final push before the midterms
summary: US President Joe Biden visited Florida to make a final push before the midterm elections, focusing on social spending issues and courting the blue-collar vote. Despite signs of a potential "red wave" that could give Republicans control of the House and Senate, Biden made no significant concessions on social spending. The visit came as Biden seeks to rally Democratic support ahead of the elections.

images.alt_text: In Sept 2022, US consumer prices were 15 per cent higher than they were just pre-pandemic. Average wages were up by 14 per cent over the period, almost matching inflation.
Joe Biden criticised major oil companies that are bringing in big profits while Americans, weary of inflation, pay a tidy sum to fill up their cars.

site_title: Oil up nearly 2% as weaker dollar offsets China concerns
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Tuesday, recouping losses from the previous session, due to optimism that China, the world's second-largest oil consumer, may reopen from strict Covid-19 curbs. Brent crude for January delivery rose to $94.65 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose to $88.37 a barrel. The stronger US dollar initially offset concerns, but the recovery in oil prices suggests a shift in market sentiment.

images.alt_text: Oil output in the United States climbed to nearly 12 million barrels per day in August, the highest since the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Sri Lanka’s financial crisis has been stretching on for months, impeding its ability to pay for food and fuel.

site_title: Walmart, Walgreens agree to pay US$13.8b to settle US opioid claims: sources
summary: CVS Health, Walgreens Boots Alliance, and Walmart have agreed to pay approximately $13.8 billion to settle thousands of state and local government lawsuits alleging the chains mishandled opioid painkillers. The proposed settlement includes CVS paying $5 billion over 10 years, Walgreens paying $5.7 billion over 15 years, and Walmart paying $3.1 billion mostly upfront. The deal, the first nationwide settlement with retail pharmacy companies, follows $33 billion settlements with drugmakers and distributors. The funds will be used to combat the opioid crisis, which has caused nearly 650,000 overdose deaths since 1999.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk by a CVS pharmacy store in Manhattan, New York City, New York, U.S., November 17, 2021. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: New Zealand’s jobless rate holds at 3.3%, employment jumps
summary: New Zealand's jobless rate remains steady at 3.3% in the third quarter, contrary to economists' forecasts of 3.2% and 0.5% employment growth. Employment surged 1.3% as more people sought work. Meanwhile, private sector wages rose 3.8% year-over-year, up 1.1% from the prior quarter.

images.alt_text: Increased rainfall in some parts of New Zealand has seen devastating flooding this year while rising sea levels are starting to threaten coastal properties.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as market anxiously awaits Federal Reserve decision
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as investors anxiously await the Federal Reserve's decision, despite mixed economic data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.2% to 32,653.20, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes declined 0.4% and 0.9%, respectively. A survey of manufacturers showed prices dropping for the first time in two years, but Labor Department data showed a surge in open positions. Investors are awaiting the Fed's decision, which could impact the jobs market and inflation.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - OCTOBER 07: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on October 07, 2022 in New York City. Stocks fell in early trading on Friday as new employment numbers show steady hiring which investors fear will lead to increased interest rate hikes.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP

site_title: New Zealand house prices suffer first annual decline in 11 years
summary: New Zealand house prices suffered their first annual decline in over 11 years, falling 0.6% from a year earlier in October, according to CoreLogic New Zealand. The decline is attributed to surging home-loan interest rates, with the Reserve Bank increasing the Official Cash Rate to 3.5% and trading banks lifting home-loan interest rates to match. Economists forecast a 13% decline in house prices this year and a peak-to-trough slump of 18-20%.

images.alt_text: Increased rainfall in some parts of New Zealand has seen devastating flooding this year while rising sea levels are starting to threaten coastal properties.

site_title: Apple’s online store and information systems chiefs are leaving
summary: Apple's top executives in charge of its online retail store and information systems divisions are leaving. Anna Matthiasson, vice president of online retail, and Chief Information Officer Mary Demby are departing, marking the latest changes to the tech giant's operations. The departures follow those of Vice President Evans Hankey and Chief Privacy Officer Jane Horvath, who have also left the company in recent weeks. The moves are part of a larger shake-up within Apple's executive team, with at least three vice presidents leaving in recent weeks.

images.alt_text: iPhones on display at the new Apple Inc. store, due to open to the public on Thursday, in the Knightsbridge district of London, UK, on Tuesday, July 26, 2022. Apple is set to report earnings this week against the backdrop of an economic downturn and a plan to slow hiring. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg
To keep plants running at fill speed, Foxconn is raising hourly pay by as much as 36 per cent to roughly 38 yuan an hour for key positions.

site_title: HK’s ambitious plans to attract global talent miss the wood for the trees
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive John Lee unveiled ambitious plans to attract global talent, aiming to stem the brain drain and revitalize the city's economy. However, critics say the government's schemes are insufficient without addressing wider concerns, particularly Covid-19 travel restrictions. Until restrictions are eased, the plans are seen as aspirational at best. The government's initiatives include a new talent scheme, increased public housing supply, and a partial refund of stamp duty for foreigners. Despite these measures, investors remain skeptical, and observers await the government's execution of its promises to deliver long-term growth.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng Index surged 5.23 per cent, or 768.25 points, to 15,455.27, having risen more than six per cent at one point before falling back slightly.
The city on Monday recorded a 4.5 per cent plunge in GDP for the July-to-September period from a year earlier, far below the median estimate of a 0.8 per cent slump.

site_title: Clorox sales beat expectations even as cleaning demand wanes
summary: Clorox reported a 23% decline in earnings per share, but beat expectations with $1.74 billion in sales, ahead of estimates. The company cut 100 jobs, or 2% of non-manufacturing workforce, as part of a restructuring effort. CEO Linda Rendle predicted economic conditions will worsen, with consumers under increased pressure, and expects additional job cuts. The company maintains its full-year net sales guidance, with a contraction of up to 4% or growth of up to 2%.

images.alt_text: Benzene can cause certain blood cancers, such as leukemia.

site_title: Manulife US Reit mulls recycling of assets, diversification as US office headwinds persist
summary: Manulife US Real Estate Investment Trust (Manulife US Reit) is exploring asset recycling and diversification amid US office sector headwinds. The Reit's occupancy fell 1.9 percentage points to 88.1% due to Quinn Emanuel's downsizing at its Figueroa property. A strategic working group is assessing opportunities, including diversifying into other asset classes and geographical markets. Manulife US Reit's weighted average interest rate rose to 3.34%, impacting its distribution per unit. The Reit manager aims to strengthen its balance sheet and manage gearing, considering acquisitions in alternative asset classes like industrial and multi-family properties.

images.alt_text: The lobby of a 35-storey class A office building in the South Park district of downtown Los Angeles, U.S.

site_title: Millennials send Vietnam’s investing scene into overdrive
summary: Millennials in Vietnam have driven a surge in investments, with many turning to apps targeting their generation. In 2019, Huynh Anh Tri, a 22-year-old, quit his sales and teaching jobs to invest in foreign exchange and commodities, citing the opportunity to start early during the Covid-19 pandemic. The trend has continued, with foreign investors returning to Vietnam's stock market due to sweetened US trade terms. Analysts predict a rebound in GoTo shares and a growth in Vietnamese stocks, as millennials seek to diversify their portfolios and capitalize on the favorable market conditions.

images.alt_text: Claudia Chong
IT job openings in Vietnam have grown more than 5 times since 2017, an analysis by recruitment platform TopDev finds.
Investors are getting increasingly optimistic about Vietnam, partly due to rising consumption driven by a middle class population expected to expand by as many as 36 million people by 2030.

site_title: South-east Asia grapples with challenge of ‘just transition’
summary: South-east Asia is grappling with the challenge of achieving a "just transition" to a more sustainable future, balancing decarbonization efforts with energy security, economic, and social equity concerns. The region relies heavily on fossil fuels, with coal-fired generation accounting for over 40% of total power generation in 2020. Investments in renewable energy are needed, but capital costs remain high due to uncertainties over remuneration mechanisms and tariff levels. To achieve a just transition, the region requires significant investments, including in sectors such as renewable energy, transportation, and the built environment.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank announcing their decarbonisation targets on Monday (Oct 31). From left: Frederick Chin, UOB’s head of group wholesale and global markets, Wee Ee Cheong, UOB's chief executive officer, Eric Lim, UOB's chief sustainability officer, and Chan Kok Seong, UOB's chief risk officer.
Sembcorp Energy India's two thermal power plants in Nellore District, Andhra Pradesh, have four 660-megawatt supercritical coal-fired units and a total installed capacity of 2.64 gigawatts.

site_title: KKR earnings slump 11% in third quarter as dealmaking slows
summary: KKR's earnings declined 11% in the third quarter, beating analyst estimates of 87 cents per share. The alternative-asset manager cited volatile markets and a slowdown in dealmaking due to recession concerns. KKR's distributable earnings fell to $823.7 million from $925.1 million a year earlier. Co-CEOs Joe Bae and Scott Nuttall expressed confidence in the firm's $113 billion in dry powder, stating that market dislocations create investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trading information for KKR & Co is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., Aug. 23, 2018. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Musk announces US$8 monthly charge for verified Twitter accounts
summary: Elon Musk announced that Twitter will charge $8 per month to verify users' accounts, aiming to create a new revenue stream and end the platform's "lords & peasants system". This move comes days after Musk took sole control of the social media giant in a $44 billion deal. Musk's plan is to introduce a blue checkmark for verified accounts, with the hashtag #BlueFor8. The announcement has sparked mixed reactions from users, with some expressing support and others opposing the new fee.

images.alt_text: Musk’s US$44 billion takeover of Twitter is an individual buying something for himself that 240 million people around the world use regularly. He will have absolute control over the fate of the social media platform.
According to media reports on Saturday, Elon Musk (centre) fired top executives in an effort to avoid hefty severance payouts, while lining up other layoffs as soon as Saturday.
Twitter had over 7,000 employees at the end of 2021, according to a regulatory filing and a quarter of the headcount amounts to nearly 2,000 employees.
Elon Musk fired Twitter’s previous chief Parag Agrawal and other top company officials last week.

site_title: ECB still has a long way to go on rates, two policymakers say
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) policymakers, Bundesbank president Joachim Nagel and Spain's central bank governor Pablo Hernandez de Cos, agree that the ECB still needs to raise borrowing costs to combat record inflation. The ECB has doubled its deposit rate to 1.5% and plans to lift borrowing costs again. Consumer prices in the eurozone hit a record 10.7% in October, and the policymakers believe monetary policy must be "even tougher" to bring inflation back to the ECB's 2% target. The ECB will discuss reducing its balance sheet at its December meeting.

images.alt_text: The ECB says banks have to pay going rates on their TLTRO credit, rather than the average rate over the whole duration of the loans.

site_title: Asean-India partnership a model of cooperation and a work in progress
summary: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and India have celebrated 30 years of their dialogue partnership, marked by a mutually beneficial cooperation. The partnership, rooted in shared history and cultural ties, has achieved significant progress but still faces challenges. A new book, 'ASEAN and India: The Way Forward,' highlights the need for continued cooperation to address regional issues such as the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) and China's growing influence. India has gained from its partnership with ASEAN, including bolstered ties with Japan, South Korea, and China, and the book suggests that the 21st century cannot be the Asian century without a successful India.

images.alt_text: DPM Lawrence Wong met India's Power and New and Renewable Energy Minister R K Singh (above) on Tuesday, as well as Health Minister Mansukh Mandaviya.

site_title: Tough road ahead as Indonesian e-commerce firm Blibli gears up for mega IPO
summary: Indonesian e-commerce firm Blibli is set to raise 8.17 trillion rupiah (S$737.5 million) through its upcoming initial public offering (IPO), making it the third-largest IPO on the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX). Despite concerns from analysts, CEO Kusumo Martanto believes Blibli's strong ecosystem and direct partnerships with brand principals and distributors will give it an edge over competitors. The company aims to generate "strong, high-quality and sustainable growth" and is backed by the Djarum Group, one of Indonesia's largest conglomerates.

images.alt_text: Even if priced at the bottom of the marketed range, it is set to be the largest IPO in the South-east Asian country after tech company PT GoTo Gojek Tokopedia raised US$959 million in an April listing.
A slowdown in funding for Indonesian startups is giving founders a taste of a downturn, and potentially giving rise to companies that will make an impact
Indonesia's largest IPO turns into a flop as Bukalapak falls

site_title: Europe: Shares kick off November on bright note
summary: European shares rose 0.6% on November 1, hitting a near seven-week closing high, driven by gains in miners and retailers amid hopes of a slower US interest rate hike. The Stoxx 600 index reached a high, with luxury stocks like LVMH and Kering advancing 1.9-3.0%. Investors await the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates, expecting a possible 50-bp increase in December. A better-than-expected earnings season has also supported the market.

images.alt_text: London’s benchmark FTSE 100 index rallied 1.3 per cent to 7,186.55 points, compared with the close on Monday.

site_title: Qatar World Cup may allow rainbow flags, political protests
summary: Qatar's FIFA World Cup guidelines may allow peaceful protests, promote LGBTQ rights, and permit public displays of affection, including kissing. The guidelines instruct security officials to exercise "less intervention, more mediation" and prioritize behaviors that don't threaten physical integrity or property. The policy shift marks a change from Qatar's conservative laws, which have faced criticism from activists and foreign officials. The guidelines are still subject to change before the tournament begins on November 20, and the Qatar government has declined to comment.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 Preview - Doha, Qatar - October 22, 2022
Country flags are seen along a street in Lusail

site_title: US job openings unexpectedly increase in September
summary: US job openings unexpectedly rose to 10.7 million in September, exceeding economists' forecasts of 10.0 million. This increase suggests strong labour demand despite the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes. The Labor Department's JOLTS report was published as Fed officials gathered for a policy meeting, where a potential rate hike of three-quarters of a percentage point is expected to combat inflation. The data may indicate the Fed's efforts to cool the economy are having limited impact on labour demand.

site_title: US manufacturing nears stagnation, price gauge at two-year low
summary: US manufacturing contracted in October for the fourth time in five months, with the Institute for Supply Management's gauge of factory activity falling to 50.2, the lowest since May 2020. The median projection had called for a drop to 50, which separates expansion and contraction. Prices paid for raw materials also fell to a two-year low, while new bookings shrank and export orders contracted. Ten industries reported contraction, while eight expanded, with manufacturers preparing for potential lower demand amid global recession concerns and central banks raising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Job openings, a measure of labour demand, increased 437,000 to 10.7 million on the last day of September, the Labor Department said.

site_title: Companies’ nonchalance toward SGX queries on pay shows why mandatory disclosure may be necessary
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is proposing a rule change to make mandatory disclosure of how much listed companies pay their chief executives and directors. A review by KPMG found that only 35% of companies disclosed directors' remuneration on a named basis, and 18% disclosed CEOs' remuneration. Companies like Sakae Holdings cited competitive reasons for not disclosing remuneration details, but experts argue that transparency is necessary for investors to assess alignment of interest. The proposal aims to bring Singapore's disclosure requirements in line with global standards, and experts believe that mandatory requirements would promote corporate governance and move the market forward.

images.alt_text: Raphael Lim
SGX RegCo will review market feedback before making a decision, including whether the hard tenure limit will be set at 9 years or some other number.
More can be done to elicit detailed director remuneration disclosures

site_title: Many dry shampoos contain cancer-causing agent, study shows
summary: A new study by Valisure found that 70% of 148 batches of dry shampoos from 34 brands contained benzene, a known cancer-causing chemical. Not Your Mother's and Batiste dry shampoos were found to have high levels of benzene, with some products containing up to 158 ppm. The US FDA has confirmed that propellants can be a source of benzene contamination and has asked companies to test for the toxin. Valisure is seeking to have the products with high benzene levels recalled and has asked the FDA to clarify its guidelines for benzene testing in cosmetics.

images.alt_text: Healthcare giant Johnson & Johnson to split into two companies
In its home and beauty care businesses, Unilever has also been trying to reduce its products’ reliance on petrochemicals and make them more sustainable.

site_title: Tokenised wine portfolio now on ADDX, managed by Intraco subsidiary
summary: ADDX, a digital securities exchange, has listed a tokenized wine portfolio on its platform, managed by Provenance Treasures, a subsidiary of SGX-listed Intraco. The portfolio features curated French wines from Burgundy, with half of the bottles carrying the "Grand Cru" appellation. The tokens were fully subscribed by investors, including wine connoisseurs, with an initial subscription price of S$0.83 per token. The wine portfolio has outperformed equities and bonds this year, with returns of 14.1% and 8.1% respectively, according to Liv-Ex indices.

images.alt_text: Genevieve Cua

Charlie Holland, head winemaker and chief executive at Gusbourne Estate, says: “In England, now we can make an exceptional sparkling wine, we have a perfect climate, we have a very long growing season.”
Resorts World Sentosa's Wine Pinnacle Awards takes place from Oct 28 to Nov 1.

site_title: Sri Lanka can’t afford enough fuel imports, says Energy Minister
summary: Sri Lanka is struggling to afford international fuel prices due to its financial crisis, according to Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera. The country is seeking financial assistance from oil-producing nations, but has yet to secure any aid apart from an existing deal with India. Sri Lanka expects a diesel cargo from China to arrive by the end of November, which will help meet its needs for several months. The country is also considering imports of Russian oil and fuel, as long as they are affordable.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka’s monthly fuel bill doubled to US$600 million this year, partly because of the hike in global prices due to the war in Ukraine, but the country can only afford to spend about US$350 million, Power and Energy Minister Kanchana Wijesekera told Parliament.

site_title: South Korea launches government-backed battery alliance to source key metals
summary: South Korea has launched a government-backed battery alliance to bolster supply chain stability and secure key metals, aiming to become a major player in the battery industry. The move comes as the US Inflation Reduction Act requires at least 40% of battery critical minerals to be sourced from the US or an American partner for tax credits. South Korea's three major battery makers, LG Energy Solution, Samsung SDI, and SK Innovation's SK On, already have production sites in the US and are expected to benefit from the new rules, with analysts predicting they can consolidate their presence in the US EV market.

images.alt_text: The strong quarter came despite challenges that LG Energy has faced since its initial public offering in January, with the whole industry battling supply chain disruptions and rising raw material prices.

The R&D centre of Contemporary Amperex Technology Ltd (CATL) in China's Fujian province. CATL has made spending commitments of US$20 billion to build new, bigger factories at home and abroad including in Hungary with Mercedes-Benz, and also plans to tap resource-rich Indonesia for expansion.

site_title: Brazil’s Bolsonaro to accept election loss in speech to nation: minister
summary: Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro will address the nation after accepting his election loss, potentially defusing protests by his supporters who have blocked highways in various states. The protests, which have disrupted the country's economy, have been led by truckers who benefited from Bolsonaro's policies. Despite initial reluctance, Bolsonaro's allies have begun contacting the winning candidate, Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, to discuss a transition. The Supreme Court has ordered police to remove blockades, and some truckers have called for a military coup to stop Lula from taking office.

images.alt_text: Luis Inacio Lula da Silva defeated President Jair Bolsonaro in an election runoff that marked a stunning comeback for Lula.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher on hopes of slowing rate hikes
summary: US stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones rising 129.84 points, or 0.40%, to 32,862.79, and the Nasdaq gaining 166.59 points, or 1.52%, to 11,154.74. Investors are hopeful that the US Federal Reserve may slow its interest rate hikes, leading to a positive market sentiment.

site_title: Taylor Swift announces return to touring with ‘Eras’
summary: Taylor Swift announced her return to touring with the "Eras" tour, her first since 2018's "Reputation" tour. The tour will be a journey through her musical eras, featuring acts like Paramore, Phoebe Bridgers, and HAIM. The tour kicks off on March 18, 2023, in Glendale, Arizona, with stops in Houston, Atlanta, Chicago, and two final domestic shows in Los Angeles in early August. International shows will be announced later. This announcement comes two weeks after the release of her 10th album, "Midnights," which debuted to chart history.

site_title: US dollar drops as optimism spreads before Fed and BOE decisions
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.57% to 110.9 on Tuesday as optimism grew ahead of Federal Reserve and Bank of England interest rate decisions. The Fed is expected to hike rates by 75 basis points, while the BOE is expected to follow with a 75-point hike. However, traders speculate that the BOE may slow down in December, leading to a potential decrease in the dollar's value. The euro and sterling rose, while the yen fell, as investors await the central banks' decisions.

site_title: Almost-full oil supertanker runs aground near Singapore gas pipeline
summary: A crude oil supertanker, the Young Yong, grounded off Takong Kecil in Indonesia's Riau Islands, near a key pipeline supplying natural gas to Singapore, on October 26. There were no reports of injuries or oil spills. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) was informed of the incident, but no further details were provided.

images.alt_text: Oil tankers at a terminal of Sinopec Yaogang oil depot in China's Jiangsu province. Such tankers have earned more than US$40,000 a day for the last 14 weeks, a feat not recorded since the start of the collection of data in early 1997.

site_title: Apac suppliers feeling the heat from ‘buyer-led’ ESG regulations from EU players
summary: Asia-Pacific suppliers are facing increased pressure from EU-led environmental, social, and governance (ESG) regulations. Companies such as HSBC are scoring suppliers in Greater China for their ESG performance, including human rights and policy data. This trend is expected to heavily impact the region's supply chain, particularly with the upcoming EU supply chain directive. Suppliers are being required to provide detailed information on their ESG practices, making it a significant challenge for those to meet the new standards.

images.alt_text: Wong Pei Ting
Preliminary data reported by EU member states showed that greenhouse gas emissions rose by 5 per cent in 2021 from 2020, mainly due to the post-Covid economic recovery, a new EEA report showed.
Mall in Beijing. Inflation in China is more muted than in the US or UK but the zero-Covid policy is a challenge
SMEs account for most of the businesses in South-east Asia, and helping them to decarbonise can have major impact on the total ecosystem.
Carbon prices in China are but a fraction of what they are in developed countries, making it hard for them to have much of an impact now, say panellists. (PHOTO: AFP)

site_title: China Evergrande unit gets notice for 32.595 billion yuan loan from Shengjing Bank
summary: China Evergrande Group's unit received a notice of enforcement for 32.595 billion yuan (S$6.3 billion) in unrecoverable funds from Shengjing Bank. The funds were provided from 2020 to 2021, and the bank failed to recover them. The notice also enforced the 30.99% stake in Xinjiang Guanghui Industry Investment Group, which was pledged to the bank. This move comes after state-owned companies bought Evergrande's shareholding in Shengjing Bank in an auction for 7.3 billion yuan in early September. Evergrande has about US$300 billion in debt.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The China Evergrande Centre building sign is seen in Hong Kong, China December 7, 2021. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: US memory chipmaker Micron ships latest DRAM chip to smartphone partners
summary: US-based memory chipmaker Micron Technology has started shipping samples of its latest DRAM chip, made using its 1-beta manufacturing technology, to smartphone partners. The new chip boasts 15% better power efficiency and a 35% improvement in storage capacity compared to its predecessor. The LPDDR5X DRAM chip is designed to meet the growing demands of smartphone manufacturers, and Micron plans to use this technology to further enhance its volume shipments.

site_title: French auction of US$3m relic delayed after Vietnam request
summary: A French auction of a 19th-century Vietnamese imperial golden seal has been postponed until November 10 due to a request from the Vietnamese government to negotiate the possible return of the artifact. The seal, valued at up to $4.2 million, was owned by Bao Dai, the final emperor of the Nguyen dynasty, and is part of 330 pieces of Vietnamese artwork being auctioned. Vietnam's Ministry of Culture claims the seal has significant historical value and seeks to return it to its home country amid a global backlash against the sale of historical artifacts.

site_title: Boston-based quantum computer QuEra joins Amazon’s cloud for public access
summary: Boston-based quantum computer startup QuEra has joined Amazon's cloud for public access, making its 256-qubit computer, Aquila, available to the public. This is the first neutral atom quantum computer to join Amazon's Braket quantum computer service, which offers five other quantum computers. According to QuEra's CEO Alexander Keesling, Aquila's unique feature is its programmable qubit layout, allowing for more efficient computation. This partnership expands access to quantum computing for researchers and developers.

site_title: Singapore and China reach 19 deals, boosting ties in green financing, digitalisation
summary: Singapore and China reached 19 agreements, the most in recent years, at their annual top-level meeting, deepening cooperation in green financing, digitalisation, and innovation. The agreements were announced after an in-person meeting between Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat and Chinese Vice-Premier Han Zheng, marking a significant boost to bilateral ties. The agreements cover various themes, including green, digital, and connectivity, reflecting the growing depth and breadth of cooperation between the two nations.

site_title: UAE and US to spur US$100b in clean energy projects: WAM
summary: The UAE and US have signed a partnership to invest $100 billion in clean energy projects globally by 2035, aiming to add 100 gigawatts of clean energy. The initiative will assemble private and public sector funding for clean energy innovation, carbon management, and industrial decarbonization. The UAE and US will provide technical and funding assistance for sustainable energy projects in emerging economies, focusing on responsible supply chains and green mining. The partnership aims to deliver climate progress with energy security and inclusive economic growth.

site_title: Pfizer raises sales estimates for Covid vaccine by US$2 billion
summary: Pfizer has raised its full-year sales estimates for its Covid-19 vaccine by US$2 billion to US$34 billion, driven by demand for its Omicron-focused booster shots. The company maintained its forecast for Covid-19 pill Paxlovid at US$22 billion. Despite falling demand for original vaccines, Pfizer's Covid-19 franchises are expected to remain multi-billion-dollar revenue generators. The company also reported third-quarter sales of US$22.60 billion, beating analysts' estimates, and earned US$1.78 per share.

site_title: Breaking China’s grip on rare-earths markets a ‘pipe dream’, Australia says
summary: Australia's resources minister Madeleine King says breaking China's grip on rare-earth markets is a "pipe dream" due to China's existing control over global markets. Despite this, Australia and the US are working together to boost investment in critical minerals, aiming to provide an alternative source of supplies. Australia has significant reserves and production capacity for lithium and rare earths, and the country plans to invest in domestic processing to secure supply chains. The US and Australia share a strategic interest in securing critical mineral supply chains, and the US is investing billions of dollars in boosting supply chains under the Inflation Reduction Act.

images.alt_text: Even after a meeting last week where Chinese authorities pleaded with major producers to stabilise prices, lithium carbonate surged to a fresh record, rising to 500,500 yuan (S$100,291) a ton.
The S&P/ASX 200 index held its ground at 6743.4 points, as of 0040 GMT on Monday.

site_title: China property slump persists in October with falling prices, sales as Covid bites
summary: China's property market continued its slump in October, with home prices and sales falling 0.01% and 20% year-on-year, respectively. The sector's recovery depends on Covid containment measures and policy strength. Despite 230 stimulus policies, the property slump has widened to major cities, with new home prices in Shanghai and Shenzhen falling. Cash-strapped developers suspended debt repayments, adding to the woes. The property sector's performance is expected to be delayed by strict Covid restrictions, which are expected to remain in place for some time.

images.alt_text: China is particularly important because it had the second-highest number of ultra high net worth individuals with wealth of at least US$50 million in 2021, behind only the US.

site_title: SIA Engineering Q2 net profit up 87.6% to S$19.7m from stepped-up flight activities
summary: SIA Engineering Company posted a 87.6% increase in Q2 net profit to S$19.7 million, driven by higher flight activities and revenue growth. Revenue rose 38% to S$190.7 million, while expenditure increased 39.1% to S$197.5 million. The company will not declare an interim dividend due to operating losses and macroeconomic uncertainties. Despite this, the group's first-half net profit reached S$32.5 million, a 30% increase from the previous year.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim
A Singapore Airlines (SIA) Boeing 777-300 is seen parked in the SIA Engineering Company hangar at Changi on 25 September 2013.

site_title: DBS raises interest rates on its Multiplier account, after similar move by OCBC
summary: DBS Bank raised the maximum interest rate on its Multiplier account to 4.1% per year, matching a similar move by OCBC Bank earlier in the day. The interest rate applies to the first $100,000 in eligible transactions and offers tiered interest rates based on spending categories. DBS also simplified its balance cap structure and raised the bonus interest on the POSB Save As You Earn account to 3.5%. The move aims to attract more customer deposits in a rising interest rate environment.

site_title: China aims to ship 25 million virtual reality devices by 2026
summary: China has released an action plan to boost its virtual reality industry, aiming to ship 25 million devices and increase the industry's total value to over $68 billion by 2026. The plan, led by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, categorizes virtual reality as a key industry for the digital economy under the country's 14th five-year plan. The plan also includes augmented and mixed reality, and is expected to drive growth in the industry.

images.alt_text: The "extended reality" (XR) unit is tasked with building up the extended reality business for Tencent including both software and hardware, the sources said,

site_title: Uber beats sales estimates on strong ridership, driver supply
summary: Uber reported a 72% increase in third-quarter sales to $8.34 billion, beating analyst estimates. The company's ride-hailing driver base is now "on par with September 2019 levels," indicating a recovery from a protracted shortage. Gross bookings rose 26% to $29.1 billion, and adjusted earnings reached $516 million. Despite a decline in food-delivery arm Uber Eats' gross bookings, the company remains optimistic, citing its "global scale and unique platform advantages" as drivers of profitable growth.

site_title: Hong Kong Airport opens ‘skybridge’ in preparation for revival
summary: Hong Kong International Airport has opened a "skybridge" connecting a terminal and satellite concourse as part of a $9 billion upgrade. The move aims to prepare for a full recovery in air travel, which remains far off due to ongoing restrictions. The airport is currently handling around 20,000 passengers daily, with Cathay Pacific carrying nearly 266,000 passengers in September, a 89% drop from 2019. A larger $144 billion upgrade, including a third runway, is also underway.

images.alt_text: Cathay Pacific has held a recruitment drive in Hong Kong on Friday (Oct 7); the airline is also adding passenger aircraft and freighters.

site_title: Golden Energy and Resources seeks to ‘restructure or exit’ energy coal business, offers notes exchange
summary: Golden Energy and Resources is seeking to restructure or exit its energy coal business, citing a need to "loosen certain covenants" in its debt covenant. The company has offered notes exchange for its US$285 million senior secured notes due 2026, with the new notes set to be listed in November. This move aims to allow the company to restructure or exit its energy coal business, which has seen significant revenue growth in the past six months. The exchange offer expires on November 21, and the company has mandated Mandiri Securities as dealer manager.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
The shift away from energy coal - the world's largest single source of energy-related greenhouse gas emissions - could seem somewhat less opportune for Golden Energy and Resources

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange cuts trading fees to boost market
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange, HKEX, has cut trading fees for its cash market to boost market efficiency and activity. The new fee structure lowers the effective rate on cash market trades to 0.565 basis points from 0.576 basis points and removes a fixed trading tariff of US$0.50 per transaction. The move aims to simplify the complicated fee structure and lower costs, with the goal of attracting more algorithmic trading to catch up with other markets.

site_title: Supply shock-induced slowdown in China could shave Asia’s growth by 1.3%: IMF
summary: A supply shock-induced slowdown in China could shave Asia's growth by 1.3% in the medium term, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). China's growth is projected to moderate to 3.2% in 2022 and remain below 5% for the next five years, generating regional spillovers. The impact depends on the type of shock, with a trade-related slowdown affecting countries with stronger trade links, particularly advanced economies in Asia. Emerging markets could see an additional drag of 0.41-0.46 percentage point on their GDP.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
China's President Xi Jinping arrives for the opening session of the 20th Chinese Communist Party's Congress at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing on October 16, 2022. (Photo by Noel CELIS / AFP)

This photo taken on October 19, 2022 shows a resident taking photos of an installation welcoming China's 20th Communist Party Congress in Hangzhou in China's eastern Zhejiang province. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: How seriously at risk is China’s property market?
summary: China's property market is experiencing a structural downtrend due to population aging and decreased housing space, exacerbated by Beijing's efforts to reduce debt. The market's contraction since 2021 has been swift, with real estate investment accounting for 25% of China's total fixed-asset investment. The government's "three red lines" policy, implemented in 2020, is seen as a catalyst for the downturn, leading to a liquidity squeeze and increased developer defaults. While systemic risk is unlikely, the short-term impact may be significant, with potential job losses and a drag on GDP growth, but the long-term effect may be positive if the sector's liabilities are redeployed to emerging sectors.

images.alt_text: Greenland is also seeking to extend the maturity of the June 2023 note by one year and other bonds by two years.

site_title: Keppel DC Reit’s manager appoints Yeo Siew Eng as independent director
summary: Keppel DC Reit's manager has appointed Yeo Siew Eng as an independent director, bringing over 30 years of experience in finance and professional practice to the role. Yeo is a director in Transit Link and a fellow of the Institute of Singapore Chartered Accountants. Her appointment follows a bourse filing on November 1, 2022.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: Africa must use gas reserves to drive economy, industry officials say
summary: African countries must utilize their gas reserves to drive economic growth and industry development, despite global efforts to cut emissions. Africa holds 13% of the world's natural gas and 7% of its oil, but has the lowest per capita energy use globally. Industry officials suggest that fossil fuels are needed for baseload power generation for industry, while renewables will play a significant role in Africa's energy supply in the future.

images.alt_text: A coal-fired power plant in Huntingtown, Utah, on Feb 7, 2019. Sixty-nine of the 86 governments analysed were found to be subsidising fossil fuel production and consumption, for a net total of US$400 billion in 2019.
Brent crude futures settled up 63 cents, or 0.7 per cent on Thursday, at US$90.46 after rising by more than US$2 earlier in the session.

site_title: Tesla to start mass-producing Cybertruck at end-2023: sources
summary: Tesla plans to start mass-producing its Cybertruck at the end of 2023, two years after its initial target, according to two people with knowledge of the plans. The production ramp-up in H2 2023 would mean the company won't record revenue from the new model until early 2024, with the vehicle seen as key to its growth. Tesla has not announced final pricing or specified how it will manage the battery supply for the new model.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Tesla is seen in Taipei, Taiwan August 11, 2017. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Federal Reserve likely to persist with another big rate hike this week before slowing down
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to announce a 75-basis-point rate hike at its meeting on Wednesday, with Chairman Jerome Powell potentially signaling a "pivot" in the size of rate hikes. This could lead to a 10% overnight gain in the S&P 500 if the Fed downsizes to 50 basis points, but strategists warn that the Fed may deny the bulls' hopes and instead over-tighten. The Fed has consistently refused to give the market a pause, and Powell has cast himself as the "crusader" against inflation. The rate hike is expected to further weigh on equities, with the average 30-year mortgage rate now above 7%.

images.alt_text: Investors remain deeply divided over what the Fed will do in December, with futures traders still pricing in the chance of another 0.75 percentage point rate increase.

site_title: Sony hikes FY profit forecast by 4.5% on foreign exchange boost
summary: Sony hikes its full-year operating profit forecast by 4.5% to 1.16 trillion yen, driven by a foreign exchange boost from the music business, offsetting weakness in the gaming sector. The company trimmed its full-year profit forecast for the games business by 12% to 225 billion yen due to lower software sales and dollar-denominated costs. Despite a 49% fall in second-quarter gaming profit, Sony plans to ramp up PS5 production and expand its games portfolio.

images.alt_text: Microsoft says the Competition and Markets Authority adopted the complaints of market leader Sony without the “appropriate level of critical review.”

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) offers an all-time high first-year and 10-year average interest rates of 3.26% and 3.47% respectively for the December tranche, amidst a rising-interest-rate backdrop. Nexia TS rebranded as CLA Global TS, and previews for the Hill House condominium project will start on November 5 with prices starting at S$1.3 million. Best World International plans to resume trading on November 14 following the release of its financial results.

site_title: Nearly one-fifth of German industrial firms scaling back due to energy crisis
summary: Nearly one-fifth of German industrial firms are scaling back production due to the energy crisis, with 14% of firms and 17% of industry-sector firms planning to reduce production or offerings. Energy-intensive manufacturers, such as those in the chemical and glass industries, are particularly affected. Companies are also looking to pass on increased energy costs to customers, with 60% of companies overall and 70% of industrial and construction firms planning to do so. The German government is exploring measures to mitigate the effects of rising energy costs.

images.alt_text: Energy prices continue to drive inflation, but food and imported industrial goods all pushed prices sharply higher.

site_title: Tokyo recognises same-sex relationships
summary: Tokyo has begun issuing partnership certificates to same-sex couples, allowing them to be treated as married couples for public services such as housing, medicine, and welfare. The move, which started on November 1, is a significant step towards recognizing same-sex relationships in Japan, where marriage equality is not currently recognized. Over 200 local authorities have already implemented similar systems, and campaigners hope the certificates will help fight anti-LGBTQ discrimination. While the certificates do not grant the same legal rights as marriage, they represent a welcome change for couples like Miki and Katie, who have long had no official proof of their relationship.

images.alt_text: Malaysia has a dual-track legal system, with Islamic criminal and family laws applicable to Muslims running alongside civil laws.

site_title: Darco appoints Zhang Zhenpeng as new CEO and executive director
summary: DARCO Water Technologies has appointed Dr. Zhang Zhenpeng as its new CEO and executive director, effective Nov 2. Zhang replaces Kong Chee Keong, who held the positions from Sep 1 last year. Zhang previously served as CEO of Tianjin Ruiyuan Business Management Partnership Enterprise in China. He holds a PhD from Nanyang Technological University and brings experience from Beijing Enterprises Clean Energy Group and Singapore's Beijing Enterprises Water Group.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: British furniture retailer Made.com fails as consumer squeeze bites
summary: British online furniture retailer Made.com has failed after running out of cash, becoming one of the first retailers to collapse due to the economic squeeze on household budgets. The company, which floated with a value of £775 million just 18 months ago, will appoint administrators after talks to find a buyer failed. This is a warning for retailers across Britain, with consumers cutting back on discretionary spend due to rising energy bills, mortgage rates, and food prices. The company had previously suspended customer orders and warned of supply chain snags and higher costs.

images.alt_text: About half of small and medium-sized businesses said the pricing and availability of loans was “poor” in the three months through September.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 14.46 points to 1,445.92. The market saw 2.978 billion lots worth RM1.564 billion change hands, with losers outnumbering gainers 479 to 381.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Kuala Lumpur city skyline.

site_title: Hong Kong summit surrounded by drama before it even begins
summary: A summit for global bankers in Hong Kong is marred by drama, with at least four top executives pulling out due to COVID-19, including Blackstone's Jonathan Gray and Citigroup's Jane Fraser. The event comes as tensions between the US and China escalate, with Beijing's aggressive moves against Taiwan and a crackdown on private enterprise and the property market. Despite the approach of a severe tropical storm, the summit is expected to proceed, with top policymakers, including People's Bank of China governor Yi Gang, set to address the gathering.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is anxious to maintain its standing as a global finance hub.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Bitcoin wants to break its bond with stocks
summary: Bitcoin has made its strongest effort yet to break away from stock markets, with its 30-day correlation with the Nasdaq dropping to 0.26, its lowest since early January. This move is seen as a sign of strength by some crypto backers, who believe investors are looking for the next growth industry, such as Bitcoin and crypto. Despite a cold crypto winter, long-term holders, or "HODLers," have accumulated more bitcoin, and a record 55,000 were withdrawn from Binance, signaling coins are moving to wallets for longer-term storage.

images.alt_text: Ang Chin Tah was appointed Crypto.com's first general manager in August this year, after spending 16 years in the public service.

site_title: UK's National Grid launches £50m energy support fund
summary: The UK's National Grid has launched a £50 million fund to provide financial relief for consumers struggling with rising energy costs over the next two winters. The fund will target charities offering emergency support, energy efficiency measures, and advisory services for households in need. The move aims to help households affected by the cost-of-living crisis, with rising energy bills, food prices, and inflation. Charities such as the Fuel Bank Foundation and Citizens Advice will receive £10 million each, with the aim of easing the financial burden on households this winter.

images.alt_text: Electricity pylons hold power cables leading away from the SSE (Scottish and Southern Energy) gas-fired Keadby Power Station near Scunthorpe in northern England September 6, 2022. - New UK Prime Minister Liz Truss inherits an economy set to enter recession before the end of the year, with double-digit inflation forecast to soar further. site_title: US publishing mega-merger blocked by federal judge
summary: A US federal judge blocked Penguin Random House's $2.2 billion acquisition of Simon & Schuster, siding with the Justice Department's argument that the mega-merger would substantially lessen competition in the US publishing market. The deal, announced in 2020, would have combined two of the largest American publishers. Penguin Random House announced it will request an expedited appeal, strongly disagreeing with the judge's ruling.

images.alt_text: The first game EA is making is based on Iron Man, a billionaire inventor and superhero who was the subject of one of the first hit Marvel movies, it announced last week.

Annie Ernaux, winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature, calls herself a "class defector" for leaving behind the humble neighbourhood of her childhood. But in her writing and her politics, she has never turned her back on her working class roots.

site_title: UK house prices fall after 'mini-budget' turmoil
summary: UK house prices fell 0.9% in October, the first monthly decline since July 2021, after Prime Minister Liz Truss's mini-budget turmoil led to soaring borrowing costs and a fire sale of assets. Nationwide Building Society reported house prices were 7.2% higher than a year earlier, down from a 9.5% annual increase in September. Economists expected an 8.3% annual increase. The market is expected to slow, with inflation and rising interest rates squeezing disposable income.

images.alt_text: London properties would face the biggest loss of value with 13 months of capital gains wiped out in this scenario.
Almost one in four people with a mortgage is already finding it difficult to afford the repayments, according to one survey, as daily living costs rise at the fastest pace in four decades.

site_title: Hong Kong September retail sales edge up as travel rules ease
summary: Hong Kong's retail sales rose 0.2% in September to HK$28.1 billion, driven by improved tourism from eased pandemic restrictions. The city scrapped hotel quarantine requirements for all visitors in September, leading to a surge in tourist arrivals, which increased by 568.5% to 66,037 in September. However, tightened financial conditions and rising interest rates pose a challenge for the outlook, with private home prices and trade performance remaining weak.

site_title: A backlash against the Fed?
summary: The US Federal Reserve, under Chairman Jerome Powell, is facing a backlash over its aggressive interest rate hikes to combat inflation, which has reached a 40-year high of over 8%. Critics argue the Fed is overreacting and may be causing an economic contraction that could lead to recession and job losses. Economists blame the Fed for not responding immediately to inflation fears, while others point to President Biden's fiscal policies as a contributing factor. The Fed's actions may pose new challenges for the Biden administration ahead of the midterm elections, where inflation remains a top concern for voters.

images.alt_text: U.S. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell delivers opening remarks to the "Fed Listens: Transitioning to the Post-pandemic Economy" listening session in  Washington, U.S., September 23, 2022. REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque

site_title: The truth about America’s economic recovery
summary: The US economy is experiencing a favorable recovery, contrary to public perceptions. As of February 2020, before the pandemic, the economy had made a near-complete recovery in jobs and production, with unemployment and employment rates returning to pre-pandemic levels. Average wages were up 14% and wages of nonsupervisory workers up 16%, matching inflation in some cases. While inflation is high, the impact on living standards is relatively small, and some economists argue that disinflation will be easier this time than in the 1970s. The public's negative economic perceptions may be driven by divergent views of personal and national economic conditions.

images.alt_text: Try to make a reservation in a restaurant, book a flight or get a room in a hotel, and you would have to conclude that the American economy is booming – a sentiment that runs contrary to the Fed’s mission of getting consumers to stop spending so much, in its fight against inflation.

Gross domestic product (GDP) rose at a 2.6 per cent annualised rate in the July to September period after falling for the first two quarters, US Commerce Department’s preliminary estimate showed on Thursday (Oct 27).

site_title: Lack of relevant research splits South-east Asia’s net zero path forward
summary: A lack of region-relevant research hinders decarbonization efforts in South-east Asia, according to recent decisions by major banks. United Overseas Bank (UOB) excluded large parts of the oil and gas sector from its net zero emissions commitments due to uncertainty over a "just transition" for developing nations. Better data and research are needed to support economic development and livelihoods in the region, highlighting the need for region-relevant research to drive action on decarbonization.

images.alt_text: United Overseas Bank announcing their decarbonisation targets on Monday (Oct 31). From left: Frederick Chin, UOB’s head of group wholesale and global markets, Wee Ee Cheong, UOB's chief executive officer, Eric Lim, UOB's chief sustainability officer, and Chan Kok Seong, UOB's chief risk officer.
