This trend highlights the need for CEOs to rally together and use their collective resources to serve the greater good.

images.alt_text: Towards sustainable giving : Instead of only writing that big cheque in a very profitable year, Corporate Singapore can lead by allowing customers to “round up” credit card or utility bill payments for charity.
Wee Ee cheong, UOB's chief executive.

In the last couple years, we’ve seen an increase in “virtual pat” opportunities, where Asian leaders can take on regional and global roles from their home base. While these opportunities are proving to be an excellent stepping stone to boost global leadership capability, they can not fully replace overseas experience.

site_title: Uefa welcomes Fifa pledge to tackle Qatar labour issues
summary: European football associations welcome FIFA's pledge to support migrant labourers in Qatar and create a legacy fund from 2022 World Cup proceeds. FIFA has confirmed support for a permanent ILO office in Doha to advise migrant workers and established a "labour excellence hub" to protect workers globally. The Uefa Working Group on Human and Labour Rights also welcomes financial compensation for workers and plans to return to Qatar next year to monitor these initiatives.

images.alt_text:
Soccer Football - FIFA World Cup Qatar 2022 - Migrant workers watch Qatar v Ecuador - Doha, Qatar - November 20, 2022
Migrant workers watch the match REUTERS/Marko Djurica

site_title: European gas prices drop as weather is predicted to warm up
summary: European gas prices dropped 10.2% on Thursday as warmer temperatures forecasted for Scandinavia and south-west Europe pushed back the start of the heating season. Benchmark futures declined, following a 8.2% slump on Wednesday, amid strong LNG flows and near-full gas storage. Experts warn that if a sudden cold snap boosts demand, stocks could quickly deplete, but analysts predict Europe can get through its first winter with curbed Russian supplies if the weather remains mild.

images.alt_text: Efforts to save energy, coupled with weak Chinese liquefied natural gas (LNG) imports, means that Europe’s gas inventories will be near 30 per cent full at the end of March, compared to a previous outlook of 21 per cent to 23 per cent, Goldman Sachs analysts said.
Russia’s Gazprom has made a last-minute decision not to turn the crucial Nord Stream pipeline back on after maintenance.
High imports of liquefied natural gas means even more fuel is being injected into brimming storage sites.
The Eiffel Tower is currently illuminated until 1.00 am by a lighting system that lends it a golden glow.

site_title: F1 launches all-women racing series
summary: Formula One has launched an all-women racing series, F1 Academy, set to debut next year. The series will feature 15 drivers, divided into five teams, competing in seven events with three races each. Drivers will be required to bring €150,000 in funding, with F1 matching the amount. The series aims to create greater diversity and provide a route for young female drivers to progress to higher levels of competition, including the W Series.

images.alt_text: F1 World Champion Michael Schumacher's 2003 F1-winning Ferrari fetched 13 million Swiss francs (S$18.5 million) at auction on Nov 9, 2022.
Overall, hotel room revenues surge to S$390.8 million for the month, surpassing August 2019’s S$383.4 million to mark a new high.
Workers sweep excess rainwater off the Formula 1 track to ensure safe race conditions. Similar efforts are needed to ensure mental health at the workplace.

Winner Red Bull Racing's Mexican driver Sergio Perez celebrates after the Formula One Singapore Grand Prix night race at the Marina Bay Street Circuit in Singapore on October 2, 2022. (Photo by MOHD RASFAN / AFP)

site_title: Yeap Medical Supplies aims for growth beyond the pandemic, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: UG Healthcare, a glove manufacturer, will transition into operating active retirement homes. The company, which previously focused on producing gloves for the healthcare industry, aims to capitalize on the growing demand for elderly care services. UG Healthcare's decision to diversify into retirement homes is seen as a strategic move to tap into a lucrative market. The company plans to convert its existing facilities into active retirement homes, providing residents with a range of services and amenities. This shift is expected to enhance the company's revenue streams and contribute to its long-term growth prospects.

site_title: North Korea missile launch did not pose threat to US homeland: White House
summary: The White House stated that a recent North Korea missile launch did not pose a threat to the US homeland. However, the US expresses strong concern over North Korea's surge in test launches of short and long-range missiles with nuclear capabilities. The US has offered talks with North Korea for denuclearization without preconditions, while also working to enhance defensive capabilities with South Korea and Japan.

images.alt_text: People watch a television screen showing a news broadcast about a North Korean missile test in Seoul, Nov 2, 2022. In October, North Korea test-fired a ballistic missile farther than ever before, sending it soaring over Japan for the first time in five years.
The United States is concerned that North Korea plans to resume nuclear bomb testing for the first time since 2017 and believes China and Russia have the leverage to persuade it not to do so.

Japan says the missile, which is capable of flying as far as 15,000 km, flew to an altitude of about 6,000 km with a range of 1,000 km, before landing in the sea roughly 200 km west of Oshima-Oshima Island in Hokkaido.

site_title: Nimbleness and backups power Superworld’s growth, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Yeap Medical Supplies, a Malaysian healthcare company, aims to expand its business beyond the COVID-19 pandemic era. The company reported a 10.5% increase in revenue in 2022, driven by the pandemic. Yeap Medical Supplies plans to diversify its product portfolio, focusing on non-pandemic related medical supplies. The company also plans to expand its international presence, targeting key markets in Asia and the Middle East. With a strong foundation during the pandemic, Yeap Medical Supplies is poised to achieve sustainable growth in the future. The company's expansion plans are expected to drive its long-term success.

site_title: US dollar gains with bond yields up, Fed in focus
summary: The US dollar gained against the euro and yen, while down against sterling, as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's interest rate hiking path. Rising bond yields and hawkish Fed comments from President James Bullard fueled the dollar's gains. The dollar index rose 0.19% and Treasury yields increased for a second day, with the 10-year yield at 3.825%. Investors also positioned for year-end, with some speculating that the dollar's strong run could continue.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6 per cent to close at 33,745.69, while the broad-based S&P 500 edged up 0.5 per cent to 3,965.34 on Friday.

site_title: TS Group eyes business opportunities in supporting ‘underserved communities’ , Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A national wellness drive in Malaysia, "Malaysia Wellness 2030", aims to promote healthy living and reduce the country's obesity rate. The initiative, launched by the government, includes various programs and services such as health screenings, fitness classes, and nutrition workshops. Minmed Group, a healthcare company, is set to benefit from the drive, with plans to expand its wellness services and increase its market share. The initiative is expected to boost Minmed's revenue and improve its financial performance, positioning the company for growth and success in the wellness industry. The drive is expected to start soon.

site_title: Sri Lanka exploring debt relief through nature conservation
summary: Sri Lanka is exploring a debt-for-nature swap programme with the United Nations Development Programme, aiming to restore degraded ecosystems in exchange for cancelling debt. The country faces its worst economic crisis in decades due to a lack of foreign currency, leading to inflation, debt default, and shortages of essentials like food and medicine. A deal is in the preliminary stages, with a US$1 billion figure being considered, and the nation's creditors must be consulted once a value for the ecosystem is decided.

images.alt_text: P Nandalal Weerasinghe, governor of Sri Lanka central bank, says: “Budget has to look at what reforms are needed to ensure Sri Lanka remains stable and does not return to crisis.”

site_title: Tough times can still be opportune times for transformation, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A company's business transformation is crucial in a volatile economy, where adaptability is key to survival. Amidst economic uncertainty, companies are shifting their focus to digital transformation, diversification, and innovation to stay competitive. This involves investing in emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and blockchain, to enhance operational efficiency and customer engagement. Successful transformations enable companies to respond quickly to changing market conditions, capitalize on new opportunities, and mitigate risks. As the economy continues to evolve, businesses that adapt and transform will be better positioned for long-term success and growth.

site_title: Qatar primed for the Beautiful Game
summary: The 2022 FIFA World Cup, hosted by Qatar, is set to begin on November 20, 2022, with 32 teams competing in 64 matches over 29 days. The tournament has been marred by controversy, including allegations of corruption, human rights abuses, and criticism from former FIFA president Sepp Blatter, who called Qatar a "mistake" for hosting the event. Despite these concerns, Qatar has invested an estimated $220 billion in hosting the World Cup, with an estimated revenue of $17 billion. The tournament will feature top teams, including defending champions France, and is expected to have a significant impact on advertisement spending, despite clashing with major shopping events.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
A billboard featuring France's striker Kylian Mbappe (L) and Argentine's captain Lionel Messi in Doha on Nov 8, 2022, ahead of the Qatar 2022 FIFA World Cup football tournament.
Football’s most prestigious tournament, which will be hosted in Qatar in 2022, will kick off on Nov 20, with the hosts meeting Ecuador.
Qatar wants to use the World Cup to showcase its rapid expansion from a small pearl-diving enclave to Gulf metropolis and expects it to add as much as US$17 billion to its economy.

FILE PHOTO: Soccer Football - World Cup - Asian Qualifiers - Group A - United Arab Emirates v South Korea - Al-Maktoum Stadium, Dubai, United Arab Emirates - March 29, 2022
 South Korea's Min-Jae Kim in action with United Arab Emirates' Harib Abdalla Suhail
 REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo

site_title: Q3 demand for resale private homes slips as prices continue to rise: Savills
summary: Singapore's resale private home market saw a 10.5% decline in Q3, with 3,961 units transacted, mainly due to economic uncertainties and cooling measures. The largest decline was in the Rest of Central Region, with transaction volumes falling 14.3% quarter-on-quarter. Prices, however, continued to rise, with a 3.8% increase in the private property index, driven by a 7.5% growth in non-landed OCR home prices. Savills revised its price forecasts upwards, estimating a 10% gain in private property prices this year.

images.alt_text: Yong Hui Ting
Leonard Tay, head of research at Knight Frank, points to the popularity of Copen Grand as evidence that “homebuyers are hungry for new products”.

site_title: National wellness drive could put Minmed Group in the pink, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: As the year 2023 comes to a close, a surge in COVID-19 vaccination and testing has led to a significant increase in demand for medical services. This trend is expected to continue into the new year, with many healthcare providers reporting a rise in appointments and consultations. The boost in demand is largely attributed to the ongoing presence of the Omicron variant and the introduction of new COVID-19 treatments. Healthcare professionals are preparing for a busy period ahead, with many urging patients to stay vigilant and follow public health guidelines to manage the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Former Hyflux CEO, CFO, independent directors charged
summary: Former Hyflux CEO Olivia Lum and CFO Cho Wee Peng, along with four independent directors, have been charged with disclosure-related offenses under the Securities and Futures Act in Singapore. Lum faces up to 7 years imprisonment and a fine of up to S$250,000, while Cho and the independent directors could face imprisonment and fines of up to S$250,000 each. The charges relate to Hyflux's failure to disclose information about the Tuaspring Integrated Water and Power Project.

images.alt_text: Olivia Lum Ooi Lin
Olivia Lum founded Hyflux.
KPMG faces litigation by embattled Hyflux, which is under liquidation.
Hyflux's unsecured creditors likely to receive 'small dividend', liquidators say
In compulsory liquidation, Hyflux has filed pre-emptive lawsuits against former auditor KPMG and founder Olivia Lum.
Hyflux winding-up hearing adjourned after intervention by Utico
The demise of Hyflux - issues to be addressed

site_title: Directors’ independence, interest alignment remain concerns for listed trusts: governance index
summary: Singapore-listed trusts have shown improvements in corporate governance practices, with the average score for all ranked trusts increasing to 66.0 in the Governance Index For Trusts (Gift) 2022. However, concerns persist regarding directors' independence, interest alignment, and board renewal, with many trusts merely "ticking boxes" on independence and failing to diversify their boards. The index's authors plan to raise the bar by reducing points for disclosure-type items and warn that business risks may deteriorate, particularly if trusts venture overseas without adequate management or board experience.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah
Investors in Singapore are becoming more active at listed companies’ annual general meetings and making their voice heard through their votes, said corporate governance experts.

While institutional shareholders with large stakes, and major shareholders in management or board roles can make their case, minority investors rely on independent directors to champion their interests.

Incorporating ESG metrics into executive remuneration is not a simple matter of merely selecting some measures and linking them to executive remuneration; ESG must be integrated into strategies, policies and practices of a company, says Prof Mak Yuen Teen

site_title: Asia: Markets sink as rate hike woes return to the fore
summary: Asia markets sank on Thursday as rate hike woes returned, with Hong Kong losing over 2% and Shanghai experiencing losses. The decline came after a 14% surge between Friday and Tuesday, amid data showing US consumers' resilience to interest rate hikes. The Federal Reserve's ability to continue hiking interest rates remains intact, despite recent inflation easing reports.

images.alt_text: “Foreign investors, who are reluctant to invest directly in Myanmar, Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam, can invest in those equities through ETFs and DRs on Thai stock exchange,” said Pakorn Peetathawatchai, the exchange’s president.
An index of Asian currencies versus the dollar has jumped over 3 per cent so far in November, poised for its steepest monthly advance since 2008.

site_title: Lessons learnt from the pandemic stand companies in good stead, Events & Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Yeap Medical Supplies, a Singapore-based medical equipment manufacturer, is shifting its focus from pandemic-era growth to long-term expansion. The company has seen significant demand for its products during the COVID-19 pandemic but now aims to diversify its customer base and product offerings. Yeap Medical Supplies plans to increase its global presence through strategic partnerships and investments in research and development. With a strong foundation built during the pandemic, the company is poised for sustainable growth in the medical industry, driven by its commitment to innovation and customer needs. Expansion plans are expected to begin in 2024.

site_title: China's BYD scraps IPO plan for semiconductor unit
summary: Chinese automaker BYD scrapped plans to list its semiconductor unit in China due to a need for large-scale investments in wafer production capacity to meet growing demand in electric vehicle manufacturing. The company cited current wafer supplies as insufficient and plans to restart the listing process once expansion is completed. BYD stated the move would not have a material adverse impact on its existing operations or future development strategies.

site_title: Eat your way through Okinawa with chef Tetsuya Wakuda
summary: Celebrated chef Tetsuya Wakuda is exploring the culinary potential of Okinawa, a Japanese prefecture renowned for its unique diet and health benefits. Wakuda, owner of restaurants Waku Ghin and Wakuda, has been incorporating Okinawan ingredients into his menu since April. He recently visited the prefecture, learning about its diverse produce, including acerola cherries, big-eye tuna, mozuuku seaweed, and shikuwasa limes. Wakuda was impressed by the quality and variety of Okinawan ingredients, citing the prefecture's tropical climate, mineral-rich soil, and warmer waters as contributing factors. He aims to share Okinawa's bounty with the world, highlighting the importance of the local diet and its potential benefits for physical well-being.

images.alt_text: Cherry blossoms in Chidorigafuchi park

site_title: Bumitama Agri’s 9M net profit surges to 2.8t rupiah on higher palm oil prices
summary: Bumitama Agri, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a 48% surge in revenue to 12.6 trillion rupiah for the first nine months of 2022, driven by higher crude palm oil prices. The company's net profit rose to 2.8 trillion rupiah, more than double the previous year. Average selling price climbed 47% to 12,889 rupiah per kg, marking the third consecutive year of growth. The company's Ebitda and net margins reached decade highs, despite rising cost pressures.

images.alt_text: Paige Lim

site_title: ‘I got this wrong’ wasn’t the apology we needed from Big Tech
summary: Tech giants Facebook, Twitter, and others are cutting thousands of jobs for the first time, marking a significant shift in the industry's reputation. Founders, including Mark Zuckerberg, Jack Dorsey, and Elon Musk, have apologized for growing too quickly, but critics argue that the real issue lies with their control structures, such as the dual-class system that makes them untouchable. The layoffs come as the tech industry faces its worst moment since the dot-com bust, and investors are reevaluating the wisdom of such structures.

images.alt_text: Hung Truong, who remembers feeling relieved after sharing online about his layoff from Lyft at the start of the pandemic, at his home in Seattle on Nov 8, 2022. As Twitter, Meta and other companies that helped create a culture of more workplace transparency slash their work forces, some laid off employees are very publicly using those social media platforms to critique their former employers.
The Facebook parent says it is slashing 13 per cent of its workforce, the first mass layoffs in the company’s 18-year history.
GoTo is gauging the interest of early backers including Alibaba and SoftBank for a managed sale of some of their shares to new investors.

Meta Platforms Inc. signage during the virtual Meta Connect event in New York, US, on Tuesday, Oct. 11, 2022. Mark Zuckerberg unveiled his company's newest virtual-reality headset, the Meta Quest Pro, the latest foray into the world of high-end VR devices that Meta Platforms hopes will entice creators and working professionals to adopt its vision for a virtual future. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: China ramps up property support with US$56b in new funding
summary: China's financial policymakers have announced a new funding package of $56 billion to support the country's struggling property sector, adding to a previous $85 billion in financing. The move aims to revive growth in the sector, which has been weighed down by a slump and a crackdown on the real estate industry. The funding will be provided by the country's six largest lenders, including joint stock lenders like China Merchants Bank. The move comes as home prices have sunk for a 13th month, and developers face looming debt maturities.

images.alt_text: The PBOC injected funds in the policy banks through a programme called Pledged Supplemental Lending for a second month in October.

site_title: Metro H1 profit down 7.9% to S$16.9m, dragged by lower share of profit from joint ventures
summary: Metro Holdings' net profit for the half year ended Sep 30 dropped 7.9% to S$16.9 million, despite a 32.1% jump in revenue to S$53.9 million. The decline was mainly due to a 37.7% drop in profit from joint ventures, which fell to S$14.9 million.

images.alt_text: Sharon See
Metro holdings reported a 68.4 per cent fall in net profit in H2.
Yip Hoong Mun, group CEO of Metro Holdings, said the completion of the acquisition of the four UK student accommodation properties "is testament to the capability of the joint venture partners".

site_title: Hong Kong’s economy shrinks for third straight quarter, outlook dims
summary: Hong Kong's economy contracted 4.5% in the third quarter from a year earlier, marking the third consecutive quarter of year-on-year contraction and the worst since the second quarter of 2020. The decline was driven by rising global interest rates and a slump in trade, with the government revising down its full-year growth forecast to minus 3.2%. Geopolitical tensions, uncertainties over Covid-19, and a largely closed border with mainland China are expected to pose pressure on exports.

site_title: AMD launches data centre CPU ‘Genoa’, taps Google, Microsoft as customers
summary: AMD has launched its fourth-generation EPYC processor, code-named "Genoa", targeting data centre markets. The chip offers significant performance and energy efficiency improvements over its predecessor. Key customers include Microsoft's Azure, Alphabet-owned Google Cloud, and Oracle, despite rival Intel's Sapphire Rapids chip experiencing delays. CEO Lisa Su stated that Genoa's benefits translate to lower costs for enterprises and cloud data centres, offering improved performance, energy efficiency, and total cost of ownership.

images.alt_text: Gains in servers and robust demand for custom chips will help bolster AMD’s performance.

site_title: Japan avoids rebuke from US, keeping intervention door open
summary: Japan avoided criticism from the US over its intervention in currency markets, with the US Treasury's latest report showing no significant change in its assessment of Japan's currency policy. The report reiterated Japan's transparency in foreign exchange operations and noted that the country's intervention to support the yen is reserved for exceptional circumstances. Japan's currency has regained ground against the US dollar, and officials see the unchanged assessment as evidence that the US does not view Japan's currency policy as problematic.

images.alt_text: The dollar fell sharply as US consumer prices rose less than expected in October. The Japanese yen at one point climbed by its biggest single-day rise since 2008, hitting 140.9350 to the dollar.

site_title: UK economic contraction heralds start of protracted recession
summary: The UK economy contracted by 0.2% in the third quarter, marking the start of a protracted recession. This is the first time a Group of Seven economy has yet to fully recover from the pandemic. Consumer spending and business investment fell, and the Bank of England expects the slump to last until mid-2024, potentially making it the longest recession in records. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is set to announce tax rises and spending cuts to plug a hole in the public finances.

site_title: China’s Covid cases rise, Guangzhou on edge
summary: China's Covid-19 cases surged to 8,824 on Wednesday, with Guangzhou experiencing over 2,000 new cases for a third consecutive day. Authorities have launched mass testing, but have resisted a city-wide lockdown, instead urging residents to work from home. The country's zero-Covid approach continues to fuel public frustration and economic disruption, with the auto show in Beijing postponed due to high infection numbers. Experts predict a prolonged economic slowdown, with some companies, like Foxconn, adjusting production to mitigate the impact of curbs.

images.alt_text: The latest round of mass testing in Guangzhou comes as China battles a rebound in infections in several economically vital cities, including its capital Beijing. This has dampened hopes that the world’s second-largest economy would ease curbs and restrictions soon.

site_title: Vickers Venture’s SPAC closes business combination with Scilex; starts trading on Nov 11
summary: Vickers Venture's SPAC has closed its business combination with Scilex Holding Company, a pharmaceutical company specializing in non-opioid pain management products. The deal was approved by 80% of shareholders and marks the start of Scilex's transition to a public company, with shares and warrants trading on Nasdaq under SCLX and SXLXW respectively, effective November 11. Scilex will own 88% of the combined entity, while Sorrento Therapeutics retains 96% ownership prior to the combination.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Cher
Vickers Venture SPAC to merge with subsidiary of Sorrento Therapeutics

site_title: TLDR: Tackling climate change can be hardest on those who aren’t even responsible for it
summary: A "just transition" is crucial to tackle climate change, considering its impact on developing countries that contribute least to emissions but would be heavily affected by environmental regulations. A just transition involves investing in greener technologies, industries, and better housing conditions for marginalized communities, while incentivizing investors to pull out of environment-damaging sectors. This approach requires special consideration of the real-life implications of sweeping climate actions, ensuring a fairer and more inclusive transition to a greener economy.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan

site_title: US midterms saw ‘widespread disinformation’ affecting voters: monitors
summary: US midterm elections saw widespread disinformation affecting voters, according to international observers from the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe. Campaigns were highly polarized, involving harsh rhetoric and baseless claims of election fraud, including former President Donald Trump's assertion that the 2020 election was stolen from him. The OSCE noted that these claims had a "harmful effect" on public discourse, lowering confidence in the electoral system, and that intimidation of election workers was concerning.

images.alt_text: In a critical win, Democratic candidate John Fetterman flipped a Republican-held US Senate seat in Pennsylvania, bolstering his party’s chances of holding the chamber.
Election workers provide voters with their ballots on Election Day at a polling location in Wisconsin.
US President Joe Biden on Wednesday said it was his “intention to run again” for a second term in office, but that he would decide for sure “early next year.”

site_title: Markets cheer Singtel’s special dividend; company posts 23% higher H1 profit
summary: Singtel has reported a 23% increase in its first-half profit to S$1.17 billion, driven by a S$1 billion net exceptional gain from the sale of its stake in Airtel. The telecommunications giant declared an interim dividend of S$0.046 and a special dividend of S$0.05 for FY2023, with shares rising 3.9% following the announcement. Group operating revenue fell 5% year-on-year, but regional associates' pre-tax profit contributions rose 15% to S$1.16 billion, driven by Airtel's strong performance in India.

site_title: Nissan to trim production at US plant over chip shortage
summary: Nissan plans to cut some production days in November at its Canton, Mississippi, assembly plant due to supply chain issues related to ongoing semiconductor chip shortages. Production will be trimmed for the Titan and Frontier pickup trucks, as well as the Altima sedan, with estimated losses of around 9,000 units. Despite the cuts, Nissan forecasts total shipments to retailers to be up quarter-over-quarter and anticipates the start of sales for its next-generation EVs before the end of the year, aiming for 40% EV sales by 2030.

images.alt_text: The Japanese automaker unveiled the Sakura in May and said in July it had attracted orders of 23,000 units.
Nissan in a statement said it had decided to exit the Russian market and expected to incur an extraordinary loss of approximately 100 billion yen from the asset transfer.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble amid crypto market upheaval
summary: US stocks tumbled on Wednesday after the US midterm elections, with the Dow losing nearly 650 points. Analysts say divided control of Washington, despite smaller Republican gains, is still likely to be favorable to stocks. The declines came amid anxiety over the upcoming consumer price report and a drop in bitcoin and other digital currencies, which raised worries about margin calls. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.0%, the S&P 500 fell 2.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index slid 2.5%. Individual stocks, including Disney, Paramount, and Fox, also plummeted.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 156.36 points, or 0.47 per cent, at the open to 33,004.47.

site_title: Homebuilder DR Horton results miss estimates as demand shrinks
summary: US homebuilder DR Horton reported Q4 earnings that missed estimates, with revenue at $9.64 billion and net income per share at $4.67, down from analyst expectations. Demand for houses has moderated due to significant increases in mortgage interest rates and economic uncertainty. The company's chairman attributed the decline to these factors, but noted that the supply of affordable homes remains limited. Economists predict a significant slowdown in housing growth by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increased to 7.14 per cent in the week ended Nov 4, near the highest since 2001.

site_title: Between coal and a hard place: Golden Energy’s intended exit from the dirtiest fossil fuel
summary: Golden Energy and Resources (Gear), a Singapore-listed energy firm, is considering an exit from its energy coal business, a move aimed at reducing its exposure to the dirtiest fossil fuel. The company has already taken steps to distance itself from coal, including divesting a stake in its Indonesian coal miner and not exercising its right to acquire more shares. Gear's decision to restructure or exit its energy coal business comes as investors and banks shun energy coal due to climate concerns, and the company faces challenges in a rising interest rate environment.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Higher average selling price of energy and metallurgical coal have sweetened Golden Energy and Resources' (GEAR) earnings

site_title: China preparing a plan to lift Covid-19 flight suspensions: report
summary: China is working on a plan to lift flight suspensions for passengers infected with Covid-19, following a recent directive from the State Council to end the circuit-breaker mechanism. The move comes as policymakers prioritize growth and reforms, as stated earlier this week. However, Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Zhao Lijian denied knowledge of the report, citing consistent and clear Covid-19 policies. The plan's implementation is yet to be confirmed.

site_title: Egypt’s COP27 climate summit comes at a ‘watershed moment’
summary: The COP27 climate summit in Egypt is a critical moment for global warming efforts, with leaders from around the world gathering to address the devastating impacts of climate change. The UN chief, Antonio Guterres, calls for a "historic pact" between developed and emerging countries to provide financial and technical assistance to poorer nations. The summit will focus on three key priorities: emissions, accountability, and money, including the creation of a separate pool of capital for "loss and damage" and a timetable for delivering $100 billion per year to help developing countries green their economies. The success of COP27 will depend on whether leaders can agree on these critical issues.

images.alt_text: The Delta Blue Carbon project in Pakistan is expected to produce 128 million carbon credits over its 60-year lifetime and sequester 142 million tonnes of carbon from the atmosphere.

The consequences of the world’s failure to curb emissions are catastrophic, and not just for the Pacific islands. Climate-related disasters are proliferating; Florida in September suffered its deadliest hurricane since 1935.
COP27 must set higher targets for all forms of renewable energy.

site_title: Sats posts S$9.9 million loss in Q2; says rights issue will not exceed S$800 million
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based inflight caterer and ground handler, reported a net loss of S$9.9 million for its second quarter, reversing a year-ago profit of S$6.8 million. Excluding reliefs, the net loss would have been S$19.7 million, an improvement from the S$30.1 million net loss in the previous year. Revenue rose 46% to S$429 million, driven by aviation recovery and consolidation of revenue from Asia Airfreight Terminal. The company plans to raise up to S$800 million through a rights issue to address its financial challenges.

site_title: Citigroup to buy Deutsche Bank’s licence in Mexico
summary: Citigroup has agreed to buy Deutsche Bank's Mexican bank licence, allowing it to continue offering institutional services after exiting consumer, small-business, and middle-market banking in the country. The deal does not include Deutsche Bank's broker-dealer or assets/employees in Mexico. Citigroup plans to set up a local unit to serve large corporations and wealthy clients. The acquisition, subject to regulatory approvals, facilitates Citigroup's consumer exit and allows it to maintain its institutional operations in Mexico.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk beneath a Citibank branch logo in the financial district of San Francisco, California July 17, 2009. REUTERS/Robert Galbraith/File Photo

site_title: Buyer beware: Avoiding pitfalls when buying fine art
summary: The art world is returning to Singapore after a three-year hiatus due to the coronavirus pandemic. The Affordable Art Fair is set to return in November, followed by the debut of Art SG, the largest art fair in South-east Asia, in January. Buying art comes with risks, and first-time buyers or seasoned collectors should exercise vigilance when purchasing an expensive art piece. Conducting due diligence, including verifying information about the art and seller, is crucial to protecting oneself from pitfalls. Careful consideration and common sense are essential in navigating the art market.

images.alt_text: Works by Swiss artist Alberto Giacometti, including "Buste de Diego" (1961, above) , are among those on display at gallery owner Kamel Mennour’s stand in Paris.

The two-day sale in New York comes as experts say the super wealthy are viewing art as a safe investment this year amid a tumultuous global economy and Russia’s war in Ukraine.

site_title: TLDR: How bad is it for companies to neglect workplace safety? Let us count the ways.
summary: In Singapore, a disturbing trend of workplace accidents has led to a rise in fatalities over the past three years. Neglecting safety practices can result in severe consequences, including a decline in the company's rating with the Building and Construction Authority, potential disqualification from government projects, higher insurance premiums, and damage to reputation and staff morale. However, there are programs available for employers to educate workers on safety and for companies to follow the Ministry of Manpower's code of practice to create a safe working environment, ultimately preventing accidents and protecting human welfare.

images.alt_text: Jeanette Tan
With about two months left in the year, the 40 workplace deaths so far already surpass the full-year counts of 37 in 2021 and 39 in 2019.
Workers at a construction site with worksite safety banners at Short Street on Sep 15, 2022.

site_title: ARA H-Trust records net property income of US$11.9m for Q3
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust reported a net property income of US$11.9 million for its third quarter, a 30% increase from the previous year, driven by "strong recovery momentum" in its second and third quarters. Gross revenue rose to US$48.7 million, with a 16% increase in occupancy and a 13% rise in revenue per available room. The trust's year-to-date net property income was US$33 million, up 80% from the previous year, and gross revenue was up 38%.

images.alt_text: Vivienne Tay
Hyatt Place Pittsburgh Cranberry in Pennsylvania is among the 4 properties to be divested by ARA US Hospitality Trust.
ARA H-Trust to sell Chicago hotel asset for US$7.75m
Net property income jumped 131.2 per cent to US$21.1 million, from US$9.1 million in the corresponding period a year ago.

site_title: China’s exports to Russia grow faster despite softening demand elsewhere
summary: China's exports to Russia rose 34.6% in October, the fourth consecutive monthly double-digit growth, despite weakening demand in other major economies and global recession risks. This contrasts with falling demand in Europe and the US, where surging inflation and interest rates have reduced trade. China-Russia bilateral trade surged to $153.94 billion in the first 10 months of the year, with imports from Russia growing 36% in October. China's willingness to deepen its relationship with Russia, as stated by senior diplomat Wang Yi, suggests a growing economic partnership between the two nations.

site_title: Gold retreats from three-week high as US dollar stabilises
summary: Gold prices retreated 0.5% to US$1,672.30 per ounce, following a three-week high, as the US dollar stabilized and interest rates remained a concern. The dollar index edged up 0.1% after US job growth data raised hopes for a less aggressive interest rate hike. Physical gold demand in India eased due to higher prices. Silver, platinum, and palladium also declined.

site_title: India calls for enhanced climate ambition beyond US$100b per year pledge
summary: India is urging rich countries to meet their US$100 billion annual climate finance pledge, which has yet to be achieved. The goal, set in 2009, requires developed countries to provide this amount by 2020 and every year thereafter. India, the world's third-largest greenhouse gas emitter, has ramped up its renewable energy share but still relies heavily on coal for power generation. Developed countries need to increase the pledge as costs have risen, according to Indian government sources. The issue will be discussed at the upcoming COP27 event in Egypt.

site_title: Rewarding travellers when they claim tax refunds, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A company launched a mission to turn customers into brand advocates, aiming to create a loyal community of supporters. The initiative involves offering incentives, such as exclusive discounts and rewards, to customers who share their positive experiences with friends and family. The goal is to encourage word-of-mouth marketing and build brand loyalty. By doing so, the company expects to increase customer retention, drive sales, and ultimately, become a household name. This customer-centric approach is seen as a key strategy for long-term success in a competitive market.

site_title: Ang Mo Kio Sers residents to get compensation from HDB that is about 7.5% higher than estimates
summary: Residents of 606 Ang Mo Kio households who had their flats picked for the Selective En bloc Redevelopment Scheme (Sers) will receive compensation that is about 7.5% higher than previous estimates. The actual compensation amounts range from S$290,000 to S$450,000, with 99% of affected owners able to buy a new replacement flat of a similar size with no cash top-up. Residents can opt for new replacement flats in Ang Mo Kio Drive with estimated selling prices ranging from S$438,000 to S$563,000, and registration will start in the first quarter of 2023.

site_title: Twitter to start layoffs on Friday: internal email
summary: Twitter will inform employees by email on Friday about whether they have been laid off, following a week of uncertainty under new owner Elon Musk. The company will temporarily close its offices and suspend badge access to ensure employee safety and data security. This move caps off a week of purges by Musk, including the firing of top executives and cost cuts. Hundreds of employees have already said goodbye to the company on Slack channels, and Musk has directed teams to find up to $1 billion in annual infrastructure cost savings.

images.alt_text: Amazon announced that it would freeze new corporate hires amid a highly uncertain economic environment.
Elon Musk has told Twitter Inc’s teams to find over US$1 billion in annual infrastructure cost savings by cutting cloud services and extra server space.
Companies such as General Mills and Volkswagen have suspended their advertising on Twitter on Thursday.

site_title: New Zealand to probe country’s resilience to supply chain disruptions
summary: New Zealand's government has asked the Productivity Commission to investigate the country's resilience to supply chain disruptions, citing ongoing challenges with international freight and key goods imports. Despite the country's ability to import and export goods during the Covid-19 pandemic, inflation remains high at 7.2%. The inquiry aims to identify ways to enhance the economy's resilience and recommend policy responses to anticipate and respond to future disruptions.

images.alt_text: Shoppers queue outside a supermarket in the suburb of Devonport in Auckland on August 12, 2020. - New Zealand's dream run of 102 days without locally transmitted coronavirus ended on August 11, prompting a stay-at-home lockdown order for the country's largest city. (Photo by DAVID ROWLAND / AFP)

site_title: Evergrande chairman’s Hong Kong mansion seized by bank: media report
summary: China Evergrande Group chairman Hui Ka Yan's Hong Kong mansion has been seized by lender China Construction Bank (Asia), according to a local news report. The 465 sqm mansion, valued at HK$700 million, was taken over after being pledged to raise about HK$300 million to repay an overdue Evergrande bond. This is the first known case of Hui's personal assets in Hong Kong being seized, following the company's significant asset seizures by creditors.

images.alt_text: Children play basketball in front of a housing complex by Chinese property developer Evergrande in Beijing. The bonds of several Chinese property companies are trading at deeply discounted levels, and market watchers expect to see more players come under pressure.
Evergrande is aiming to shift the group’s primary business from real estate to the automobile venture over the next decade, with plans to make 1 million vehicles by 2025.
The Evergrande unit’s 30.99 per cent stake in Xinjiang Guanghui Industry Investment Group, which it had pledged to the Shengjing Bank has now been enforced, the notice said.

site_title: Goldman wealth strategist sees buying opportunity in stock slump
summary: Goldman wealth strategist Sharmin Mossavar-Rahmani believes the stock slump has discounted the risk of a recession, making it a buying opportunity. Despite a 50-50 chance of a recession, Mossavar-Rahmani expects the equity market to rally before the trough in earnings. She advises investors to buy steadily after a major decline, accumulating stocks at low prices. This view contrasts with other market experts, who caution that the bottom of the market is hard to call and investors should be cautious.

images.alt_text: The Hang Seng surged 5.3 per cent and notched its biggest weekly gain in 11 years while the Shanghai Composite rose 2.4 per cent for a 5.3 per cent weekly gain, the largest in more than two years.

site_title: Demographics, post-Covid rebound to keep Asean region stable in uncertain times: panellists
summary: South-east Asia is expected to remain stable despite global economic concerns, thanks to its large population and favourable demographics. The region is poised for growth driven by digitalisation, sustainability, and domestic demand. Key areas of opportunity include domestic demand, tech and digital economy, and energy transition. Countries like Vietnam and Malaysia are stepping up, while Indonesia is trying to get plugged into global supply chains. The agri-food sector is also seeing opportunities, with a focus on diversification and innovation. The region is also a hotbed for tech SMEs and startups, with Singapore playing a key role in supporting innovation and entrepreneurship.

As governments begin to focus more on solar panel supply chain diversification, South-east Asia could emerge as an important player in sustainable energy production.

Growth of the Islamic financing industry in South-east Asia is mainly led by Malaysia and Indonesia, amid supportive regulatory environment and strong government support.

site_title: 5 Questions with Kelvin Teo, fintech man on a mission
summary: Kelvin Teo, co-founder of fintech company Funding Societies, has navigated several crises since starting the company in 2015. He shares his experiences, including a near-death experience in 2016 when investors pulled out due to regulatory changes, and how he rallied his team to stay afloat. Teo credits Jack Ma's advice on perseverance and resilience in the face of adversity, and believes his company will be driven by profitability through its focus on empowering SMEs in Southeast Asia. Funding Societies aims to continue regional expansion and deepen its product scope to achieve fair profitability.

site_title: Binance CEO says support for free speech is reason he invested in Twitter
summary: Binance CEO Changpeng Zhao stated that his company's $500 million investment in Elon Musk's Twitter buyout is due to support for free speech, a key reason for his investment. Zhao, an active Twitter user with over 7 million followers, emphasized the importance of the platform for expressing opinions. Following Musk's takeover, it is unclear how Binance's minority stake will influence Twitter's future, with Musk controlling the board and decision-making. Binance plans to work with Twitter on integrating blockchain and crypto.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk said on Tuesday the site will charge US$8 per month to verify users’ accounts.
Elon Musk fired Twitter’s previous chief Parag Agrawal and other top company officials last week.

site_title: Wine Pinnacle Awards 2022 ends on a high note
summary: The Wine Pinnacle Awards 2022 concluded with 18 winners being recognized at a gala dinner and ceremony at Resorts World Sentosa. New categories were introduced to address the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on wine consumption, including Comfort Wine and Pandemic Hero. The awards honored wines, winemakers, and personalities for their quality, diversity, and contributions to the industry. Winners included Domaine Zind-Humbrecht for Best Friend of the Earth, 2019 Joh. Jos. Prum for Comfort White, and Barbara Banke for Pandemic Hero. The event featured exclusive wine dinners and industry masterclasses, with 500 leading figures in the wine world in attendance.

images.alt_text: Resorts World Sentosa's Wine Pinnacle Awards takes place from Oct 28 to Nov 1.

site_title: UK fresh food prices rise 13.3% in year to October: BRC
summary: The cost of fresh food in the UK rose 13.3% in October compared to the same period last year, according to the British Retail Consortium. This is the largest annual increase since 2005. The rise in food prices, combined with soaring energy bills, has led to a 40-year high in consumer price inflation at 10.1% and is expected to peak at nearly 11% this month. Retailers are under pressure due to rising energy and commodity costs, and some are urging the government to freeze planned business property tax rises.

images.alt_text: The number of employers expecting to increase staffing levels rose for the first time in five months.

Made.com’s rapid decline is a warning for retailers across Britain, as consumers cut back on discretionary spend in the face of rising energy bills, mortgage rates and food prices.

site_title: Bank Negara Malaysia set to hike for fourth time in a row on Nov 3: poll
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia is set to hike its policy rate by a quarter point for the fourth time in a row on November 3, amid persisting upside risks to inflation and to support the weakening Malaysian ringgit. The rate hike is expected to tighten monetary policy, with nearly 90% of economists forecasting a rate increase in Q1 2023. The move aims to keep inflation in check, despite a weakening global outlook and the risk of further rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: Securities Commission Malaysiachairman Awang Adek Hussin unveils a series of digital-centric initiatives with measures that will further harness the potential of the capital market in accelerating the recovery and continued growth of the country's economy.

site_title: Oxley Garden’s second attempt at S$200 million en bloc closes with no bids
summary: Oxley Garden's second attempt at a S$200 million en bloc sale closed without a bid, leaving the prime District 9 site back on the market. The site, which can be rebuilt into a five-storey condominium, was previously put up for sale in April but also failed to attract a buyer. The owners of an adjacent property, 5 Oxley Rise, had expressed interest in buying both sites together for a comprehensive redevelopment. The site's owners will now reassess the market and potentially put it up for sale again.

site_title: Eezee makes B2B procurement easy, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Amazon sellers are significantly reducing Prime Day discounts due to increasing tariffs on imported goods. The tariffs, imposed by the US government, have led to higher costs for sellers, who are passing on the expenses to customers. As a result, discounts on popular products have decreased, and some sellers are choosing not to participate in the promotional event. This shift is expected to impact sales and revenue for Amazon sellers, who rely heavily on Prime Day as a major revenue generator. The tariffs have disrupted the traditional Prime Day discount model.

site_title: Digitalising the agricultural supply chain, from farm to fork, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: China is promoting rural revitalisation through a unique initiative: "new farmers" who have turned to livestreaming to boost local economies. These rural entrepreneurs use social media platforms to showcase local products, share recipes, and offer services, attracting tourists and generating income. The program aims to revitalize rural areas by leveraging technology and online presence. Since its launch, some rural livestreamers have gained significant followings and revenue, with some earning up to $10,000 per month. The initiative has shown promise in revitalizing rural communities and promoting sustainable development in China's countryside.

site_title: AP Technologies wants to lead the world in medical tubing, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: Advances in medical technology have significantly improved healthcare outcomes. Quick scan capabilities and more accurate diagnoses are now possible due to innovations such as AI-powered imaging and machine learning algorithms. These advancements enable healthcare professionals to quickly identify potential issues, reducing the need for lengthy and invasive procedures. As a result, patients are experiencing faster recovery times and improved treatment outcomes. Furthermore, these technologies have also reduced healthcare costs by minimizing the need for repeat tests and procedures. Overall, cutting-edge medical tech is revolutionizing the healthcare industry with more precise and efficient care.

site_title: How technology can support pensions for the underserved
summary: Singapore experts discussed how technology, including central bank digital currencies, can support micro pensions for the underserved. Panelists emphasized the need for embedding financial services in existing ecosystems, such as ride-sharing apps, and for understanding customer needs. They also highlighted the importance of programmable money, digital tokens, and transparent data ownership. Key challenges include trust, cost, and complexity in delivering micro pensions. Experts recommended simple design, user-intuitive apps, and better training to increase digital inclusivity and prevent online scams.

images.alt_text: 'There is an opportunity to restructure the transfer of direct benefits, to allocate a portion of that money to long-term wealth protection. This is a use case for central bank digital currencies,' says Sopnendu Mohanty, Chief FinTech Officer, Monetary Authority of Singapore

site_title: Summoning data from sensors anywhere, Emerging Enterprise - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: The Emerging Enterprise Awards 2025 applications are now open, with submissions accepted until June 30. The awards recognize and celebrate innovative and growing businesses across various industries. The awards aim to provide a platform for emerging enterprises to showcase their achievements and gain recognition. The selection process will evaluate applications based on factors such as business strategy, innovation, and impact. The winners will be announced in the second half of 2025, with the exact date to be confirmed. More information about the awards and application process can be found on the official website.

site_title: The high costs of neglecting workplace safety
summary: Singapore has seen 40 workplace deaths this year, surpassing the full-year counts of 37 in 2021 and 39 in 2019. Industry players argue that implementing workplace safety measures can save costs, as the costs of accidents are far greater than prevention. Despite a decline in general fatality counts over the years, accidents have risen since 2020. Companies are urged to prioritize workplace safety to avoid such tragedies.

site_title: ChildAid 2022 returns as a big bash
summary: ChildAid 2022, a charity concert for underprivileged kids, returns with a show of thrills and top-flight performances on December 13. The 90-minute concert, themed "All Together Now," will feature a diverse range of musical acts, including K-pop and classical music, and has been organized by The Business Times and The Straits Times. The event promises to be a spectacle similar to the 2019 pre-pandemic edition, after two years of pandemic restrictions.

site_title: EU Commission proposes longer, negotiated debt reduction paths for EU countries
summary: The European Commission proposed changes to the EU's fiscal rules to give countries more flexibility in reducing debt. The new system would allow countries to negotiate debt reduction paths of varying lengths linked to reforms and investments, but with stronger enforcement. This change aims to make countries "own" their debt plans and address the unrealistic ambition of existing debt reduction requirements. The Commission also proposes a focus on net primary spending, which is directly observable and under government control, and would ease the burden on countries with high debt levels, such as Italy and Greece.

site_title: Foreigners offload Chinese bonds for 9th straight month in Oct
summary: Foreigners sold 34 billion yuan worth of Chinese interbank yuan bonds in October, marking the ninth consecutive month of outflows. Foreign holdings of yuan-denominated bonds fell to 3.38 trillion yuan, down from 3.40 trillion yuan in September. The pace of outflow has slowed, with a 80 billion yuan decrease in September. The yield gap between China's and US bonds remains a driving factor, with interest rate differentials favoring the US. Experts predict that a less hawkish US stance on rate hikes could reduce capital outflows.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of a giant display of stock indexes, following the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) outbreak, in Shanghai, China October 24, 2022. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts cut targets for StarHub on rising expenditure
summary: Analysts from CGS-CIMB, DBS, and RHB have cut their target prices for StarHub, citing higher expenditure due to the telco's transformation plan, Dare+. The group posted a 32% year-on-year decline in net profit for its third quarter. Despite this, Maybank Securities raised its target slightly to S$1.33, while maintaining its "buy" call. Analysts expect increased costs for the English Premier League broadcast rights and Dare+ to pressure earnings in the coming year.

images.alt_text: StarHub Shop at Plaza Singapura.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up further as China moves provide support
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, with Hong Kong and Shanghai advancing more than 2% as investors focused on signs of slowing inflation and China's efforts to shore up its economy. Despite US Federal Reserve officials warning of more interest rate hikes, Asian traders were buoyed by China's easing of COVID-19 restrictions and support for its property sector. Tokyo, Singapore, and other markets also rose, while Sydney and Seoul dipped. Investors remain hopeful for a market recovery, but caution remains about the potential for recession.

images.alt_text: The flag of Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEx), top center, the Chinese national flag, bottom center, and the Hong Kong SAR flag, bottom right, fly in the Central district of Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, March 2, 2016. HKEx, owner of the London Metal Exchange, posted a 68 percent increase in profit from commodities last year as expanding fees from trading countered the first decline in metals volume since 2009. Photographer: Justin Chin/Bloomberg

site_title: Keppel O&M bags S$155m worth of rig charter contracts
summary: Keppel O&M has secured S$155m worth of rig charter contracts with ADES Saudi Limited Company for two jackup rigs to be deployed in Saudi Arabia, starting in H1 2023. This brings the total number of rigs on charter with ADES to four. The charters, for a period of five years, demonstrate continued demand for Keppel's KFELS B Class rigs, marking the fifth and sixth bareboat charters secured by the company this year.

Keppel O&M’s state-of-the-art KFELS B Class rig (pictured)

site_title: Introducing a new chapter of luxury in Singapore with the BMW 7 Series and BMW Excellence Club
summary: BMW has unveiled a new lineup of luxury vehicles in Singapore, including the BMW 7 Series, BMW 8 Series, and BMW X7. The models showcased include the BMW 735i, BMW i7 xDrive60, BMW 840i Gran Coupé, and BMW X7 xDrive40i. Attendees at the event in Capella Singapore were able to experience the new features of these vehicles. This marks a new chapter in luxury for BMW in Singapore, offering fans a range of high-end options.
